Disappointing yet somewhat interesting. This is a collection of old teak homes gathered by Thompson after WW11. It is interesting only in that aspect. There is a silk museum on site and people demonstrating silk thread spinning the day I went. Had a very nice lunch in site.

It is a temple of Thai silk history.... At Jim Thompson House I found the true and beautiful pieces of silk. Many sites offer Thai silk but with questionable quality.Visit the Thai architecture and silk history , buy a nice silk parts , beautiful design and quality, and enjoy a good Thai food at the local restaurant.

Interesting stop for artisans. Didn't know what to expect, other than silk. Jim Thompson was obviously in love with the place and preserved some interesting cultural relics/antiques, which are still there. Arty types will particularly like this.
Wonderful and Serene Visit. The admission comes with a guide, who gives great insight into how this complex borrows influences from both Thai and Western building practices.

Well managed . This is a place you really should visit. Nice interesting well-managed museum with a good shop and restaurant. So pleasant to be shown around by a well trained guide and to be let into Jim Thompson's old but interestingly modified Thai house(s). An extra tip; try the local public transport ferries on the khlong next to his house when going back.

Ditch a Buddha and head to Thompson's place.... Well, not really. All the huge, gold, emerald, standing, seated and reclining Buddhas are well worth a visit, of course, but the contrast with such a marvelous, eclectic, and prescient "designer" home is a breath of fresh - and stylish - air. Thompson single-handedly resurrected the nearly defunct Thai silk industry back in the late 1950's - 1960's following an unusual trajectory from America to the army in Asia and finally to Bangkok, where he settled at a time when it wasn't so easy tho access. The extraordinary house he created is a love-letter to Thai culture, cobbled from an assortment of old, traditional wood homes and filled with an exceptional collection of Asian and European antiques, many of which are museum-quality. For anyone even vaguely interested in design or architecture this is a must-see, a truly unique home now emulated all over the world - Thompson was way, way ahead of his time. This is an "insider" stop, with noticeably sophisticated tourists making pilgrimages to a famous temple of style not on the typical Bangkok itinerary - another reason it's so special. Many just stop by to visit the beautiful store on the premises, though the big 4-story emporium elsewhere in the city is the place to immerse yourself in truly fabulous items - easily accessed from the Sky Train. Tickets are required but can be bought on the spot, and there are guided tours only, starting every 20 minutes or so to control the numbers. Don't miss it. You'll hate yourself later.

Beautiful architecture. I recommend joining a guided tour (English, French, Japanese, Chinese), where the staff explain the history of the place and about Jim Thompson. It was a relaxing break from a long day of travelling and a good place to sit down and rest. The garden was beautiful and you might even see someone weaving silk outside the gift shop!

Interesting story and beautiful Thai houses. I recommended foreign friends to visit. And it was not disappointing at all. They enjoyed. Got off at National Stadium and waited for a free pick up by Jim Thompson House. Entrance fee is around 100-150 THB (I couldn't remember the exact amount - sorry but this includes guide fee already) At the lobby they got an outlet for silk products which are a bit dear but very nice design and quality. On the right hand side they got a Thai restaurant as well. This property used to belong to Mr. Jim Thompson who disappeared somewhere in Malaysia. Local guides by languages are well trained and give good information to us. The tour took around 45 minutes approximately. After the tour we had lunch options at 6th floor food court of MBK. Our friends are happy on this tour

Good insight into silk trade and Thai art. Variety of things to see. A good opportunity to see Thai architecture. Nice cafe. Great opportunity for good quality souvenirs/gifts. Nice garden and Thai dance demonstration.
Don't miss this place. Beautiful gardens, unique home and piece of history. Convenient two locks from the Sky Train. Very nice bar/ restaurant.

silk and more. this a great place to know a little more from bangkok and thailand history. and it´s not just about silk... cool place to take the kids to see how from the bug to silk the cloths are created
As great as everyone says it is. Great way to spend an hour or so at this lovely, historic house museum. Very easy access from the subway.
A nice piece of history in the bussy city. Beautiful gardens, allot of explanation about the history of the house and its previous owner. A fun way to relax away from the intense city.

Silk Business made popular by a foreigner. I did not realize that the Silk business in Thailand was made popular by a foreigner from England(I think). Of course the Thailand folks have been doing this for a long time, but its expansion to a business form was done by Jim Thompson. That's why his house is a museum and tourist attraction now. Good place to visit. I saw silk worms for the very first time at Thai spot. They had a demo of how the thread was harvested. I found this most interesting. Rest of it , was like walking into another museum. Must visit once at least
Interesting place about Silk. Been here with my Australian friend and took a house tour. Very interesting story and got a super friendly and nice guide.

Architectural Brilliance, very quite and serene place. If you are in Bangkok do visit this place. The place is very near to Sky Train. Do come here by public transportation otherwise traffic will be very annoying. This place will relax you and will help you get your inner peace. Entry fee is 150 Bhat per person. After entering you will be accompanied by guide, this would last for 40 minutes. You can replenish yourself with drinks (non alcoholic strictly) and food at a restuarant situated in the premises. There is also a shop where you can do shopping. After guided tour you can sit there and relax.

A Silk House of Jim Thompson. If you seek pure silk, Jim Thompson is the right place. You can also buy the ticket to entry the museum. Walking distance round 5 minutes from the main road, and you can find a lovely house. Seek the silk you want to buy, and there's a golf car as a shuttle that can take you back to the main road for free.
Wonderful. Very interesting visit in a wonderful place. Despite the number of visitors, this house and its gardens retain a peaceful atmosphere in the midst of busy Bangkok.

For those who like different things. Did you know about Jim Thompson story and its silk scarfs?Do you know what happen to him? Why is he famous? Recommend it, for those who like to know small different things such as how did a northern american end-up living in Thailand, building up a million dollar silk company and disappear without leaving trace more than 30 years ago in Malaysia...

On rainy day. I usually buy polos from their shop at airport or the mall..Same collection for the last couple of years maybe be time to innovate Made in Italy bit confused ??They could make the visit of the museum free..Otherwise nice visit on a rainy day
Hidden gem. Great discovery between Bangkok's concrete jungle. Well worth a visit to this beautiful Thai house and garden. Guided tours only but they leave you time to walk back and take pictures.

Best appreciated when wandering freely by oneself. I had been to the house a long time ago, so wanted to visit it again in Feb 2016 when I found myself in Bangkok again.Although I hesitated, my party and I opted for a guided tour which lasted 30 minutes. The beauty of the architecture and layout, the thought and planning behind them, the siting by the canal, the landscaping and the garden itself, none of that was given the highlighting which they deserved. As for he collection of antiques on display, we were told of the age of some objects, as if that was sufficient to give value to them, while nothing was said about the artistic traditions or the appearance of the works. A pity indeed.

Good for Tourists. The house is interesting, but if you go at a busy time you may wait an hour for a tour (language dependent). The restaurant has pleasant fare that's not too expensive, and the showroom is filled with beautiful silk items that are priced like Hermes or Turnbull & Asser. If you just want the silk, you can visit the outlet in the Bangna district.
Nice history . They have all kind of tour staff that speak different languages! It was nice to see the house and learn about Jim Thompson house. And the silk.
Good time and great visit. Very good visit with a french speaking guide who was very nice. The house is a nice place, quiet although in the city, must see.

Too much talk about it !. True, it is a nice touristic visit. The house of a typical Thailand lover open to the public make you feel the life he had just a few decades ago. But it is so crowded !! And the stop at the shop is really not necessary !

informative tour. Worth a trip out for a different kind of sight in Bangkok. Very organised, we bought tickets and were allocated a tour twenty minutes later so had a nice coffee looking out over the koi carp pools. You take your shoes of to go in the house and leave bags in lockers.I wouldn't say it!'s a must do but the tour was interesting and Jim Thompson's house is a lovely oasis in the city. Gets busy. There is also a shop selling silkware.

An oasis of peace in a busy city. I found Jim Thompson house impressive not because of what it is (a memorial house and museum in the same time), but because it is a calm and green place in an otherwise busy and noisy city. The visit is always guided and informative with many insights in the Thailand customs (eg: what is a spirit house? why it's built? why Thailand doors have tall limits?)

History with art!!. The house is beautiful, built according to the traditional Thai architecture. Gardens look good too.You have to buy tickets outside after which you are assigned a group and a guide in your selected language.There is a restaurant in the premises as well.
Exceeded expectations. Not sure what I expected but this is a lovely place. Fascinating old buildings - a slice of a lifestyle that has disappeared. Well worth the visit.

jim Thompson get away . it's a great place, it's easy to get using the bts skytrain, make sure to take the opposite exit from d mbk center, or can just ask d security t safe u time, and it's a 3 minuts walk through a straight road, well organized, french and english guide, nice restaurant, 150 for adults over 22 and 100 for under 22 but get show them d passport, must see place. after that u can also enjoy d bangkok museum of art and culture and there was a tokyo food festival down at mbk center d food was good not sure how often they've it.

Oasis. We enjoyed visiting the Jim Thompson house. You feel like you are not in a big city!! We had lunch in the restaurant which was delicious. There was also a dance performance by the girls showing how to make silk.

A must . Went as seen the recommendations on Fb. So glad we did. We did walk from our hotel but realised you can get a canal bus if you have one near you which stops right outside the house. Only $3 to get in which includes a tour. Fascinating story to be told and beautiful house to look round. It's also nice to be away from the noise of the city so quickly. A must do.

A little piece of how the other half lived. I was intrigued about this man and the company and lifestyle that he created in Thailand years ago. Visiting his house only added to the mystique. It's both traditional and somewhat modern. The dark moody wood interior and furniture accented by the silks and native art pieces made the rooms stunning and somewhat cold. It's felt like a stage set at times. What warmed it up for me was the landscaping around the home...nothing like nature as the great equalizer. What I loved about this place was how it's hidden amidst the urbanity of the city. Malls, busy roads, people and then you turn the corner and a piece of nirvana...stop by for a breather from the chaos.

Mandatory tour... but that's ok. I missed seeing this house the last time so I took the Skytrain to National Stadium, then it was a short walk to the house. I hate taking tours and this one is mandatory which I now understand why. You also have to put your stuff in a locker which some German tourists rebelled against but a precious statue getting knocked over by an errant backpack would not be nice. The house is so lovely and full of rare art... and in some small spaces. If you appreciate architecture and style, you should go. I find the style of Jim's gift shop items a bit frumpy and expensive, but it was fun to look. They need to update their swag though... it's grandma city. (And I'm no spring chicken)

An American in Bangkok. Though the Wats of Bangkok are stunning, the Jim Thompson House is truly what made me love visiting the city. A short walk from the skytrain ushered me into this exquisitely unostentatious and intimately lovely refuge. Jim Thompson must have been quite an extraordinary man to have assembled the houses and art collections into what it is. Though we weren't allowed to take photographs inside the main house, the tour was informative. I wish it were possible to go on a solo tour, the better to appreciate the elegance of the house. Visitors to Bangkok who have had a surfeit of temples, take note of this place!

Very interesting and intriguing visit. This attraction showcases Jim Thompson's home in Bangkok. The home itself is beautiful and showcases a lot of art and antique Buddhas throughout. The tour itself is only about 30 minutes. Jim Thompson was an American who started export of Thai silk and he mysteriously disappeared when he was 61 while he was out for a walk. Definitely a place to see!

Can't miss this lovely House. Loved this House so much. The tour is only 35 minutes but is so informative and interesting. A real haven of peace and tranquility in a crazy city. If you get a chance visit the Jim Thompson Outlet - amazing silks and much cheaper!

Beautiful building. Such a beautiful building with a lovely garden, it was a nice experience going around the house and being given a bit of the history of Jim Thompson and what he did when he came to Thailand. Part of the deal when going there is that you are given a guided tour of the house, in either English or French, with a group of people. Our tour guide was a really nice and pleasant lady.

A must. This place is fantastic. You will enjoy aFresh break while visiting the crowded Bangkok.A very romantic house telling you everything you need to know about Jim Thompson.I will go again and again.

Amazing garden. We took a taxi boat to visit this place. The garden and house are really nice and calm. We did not try the food in the restaurant. But there are wonderful silk products in the shop - unfortunately very expensive.

An oasis of history. This house provides a fascinating insight into the life and obsessions of an American silk trader. His collections of local art and artefacts housed in traditional Thai buildings convey his love of the country and its traditions. An early morning visit provided us with the tranquility we didn't experience at Wat Pho or at the Royal Palace. Highly recommended.

My "favorite" in Bangkok. This is a must see for art lovers and interior designers. An amazing complex of traditional Thai wooden houses cobbled together by an American expatriate decades ago. Fascinating story of a man who fell in love with the Thai culture. His story and vision lives on in this house.
Way over rated. Nice enough house and friendly staff, but compared to some of the temples and palaces this is pretty tame. English tours last around 45 minutes, but there isn't a huge amount to see.

A wonderful gem in the centre of busy Siam. If there is any place in Bangkok that take you from the hustle and bustle of busy Bangkok then Jim Thompson's House is one such place. The staff here are extremely helpful, knowledgeable and best of all greet you with a smile that last throughout the tour and nothing seems to be any trouble for them.A tour of the house cost 150 baht, well worth the cost, as the house is full of history and artefacts, with the guides giving a full appreciation of the house, it's owner and the contents.Then garden that surrounds the house is also well worth the time to explore.One of the things that impresses is how quiet it his here, considering it is in the centre of the busy Siam area with all it's shopping centres and traffic. All you can hear is the frogs, birds, insects and the occasional passing boat on the canal, very relaxing.
Interesting and quiet. We spenf a nice half day. Our girls (age 8 and 11) enjoyed it. Not action packed but peacefull and nice. Not a "must see" but a fine attraction.

Educating . This place was a great insight into Thai life and architecture also about the work Jim done to preserve the traditional silk making. And by bring it to the western world he brought a lot of business to Thailand and money. A great couple of hours learning the history and with an english speaking guide made the whole visit a lot more appealing.

Great History and Gardens. The house is very unique, as is the story of Jim Thompson and how he helped to market Thai Silk on the world market.....great gift shop,and tour.....we took the Skytrain and walked from there ....easy walk......

Great hideaway in the centre of BKK. Jim Thompson House is one of those travelling-delights that you stumble upon from time to time.Having visited BKK numerous times I had never been here. What a great surprise and what a great great man. He is to Bangkok what Robert Louis Stevenson is to Samoa.An amazing house that when you step into from the manic Bangkok craziness you are instantly transported to another time and place. Go discover for yourself!! It's an highlight.

This house tells many stories. The compound of six well-preserved traditional Thai houses provides a pensive transport to an elegant historical past. The guided tour introduces visitors to salient aspects of Thai architecture; however, I read about it and watched tourists' videos prior to travel so I took away much from the visit unlike fellow tour mates who were wondering about many details. The collection of Southeast Asian art is not museum-grade; instead, it is an unpretentious reflection of what a genuine lover of Asian culture surrounded himself with. Tip: Some items are cheaper at the DFS Jim Thompson store at the Suvarnabhumi airport.

Interresting. I had a great Tour , love the style. Well set up .I never had heart from Jim thompson , but Intrestiing to know more .Easy to find .not far from mkb shopping mall so shop and combine culture ....

Beautiful. We loved this calm oasis in the midst of the busy city. The history is very interesting, the silks are magnificent and the gardens tranquil. All in all an excellent way for us to spend the morning.

Fine but not essential. We visited with our two kids at the end of a day that also included the Grand Palace and other major sites. The house was nice and pretty but kind of a letdown after the amazing sites of Bangkok. Still worth a visit as long as you adjust your expectations.

Sight Seeing Staple. Our daughter in law, a Thai native, took us here as part of our sight seeing tour of Bangkok. Apparently it is a popular spot. The place is the residence of a US ex pat that moved to Thailand in the 1950's (?). He loved the culture and built the home as a traditional Thai home. It was filled with antiques and artwork. The gardens were very nice. The residence is connected to a silk store, which was the business the Mr. Thompson was in. The intriguing part of the story was that Mr. Thompson disappeared in the jungle and was never found. The tour guide spoke excellent English and was very informative. Nice little tourist spot.
Overrated!. An expensive experience for shoppers thats for sure! While an important guy for silk trading the hype does not match the reality. Dont bother in my opinion!
Lovel place with nice restaraunt. Beautiful tranquil location. My boyfriend and I aren't that interested in history etc but still enjoyed a lovely few hours here checking out the gorgeous garden.

Absurd.. Long review: CIA operative in Southeast Asia uses black money to leverage a silk plantation to exploit workers and amass treasures from neighbouring poor states. Said CIA operative 'disappears without a trace' and a 'private organization' leverages the property into a swanky museum where rich people can swank at each other with tight security. Short review: 150 Baht for not much. Go there for a full day, to get your full money's worth, and to make the security team here twitchy.

Well worth a visit. Intriguing home of an expat American architect. Tour is obligatory and takes about 30 mins. Would have arrived by boat if I had realised this was an option. Air cond shop. Didn't try the restaurant but it looks good. They have a shuttle tuk tuk which worked well for us

good variety of gift items. had been last week to big Jim Thompson House in main Sukhumvit road somewhere near Soi 91 or so ,huge building with 4 floors of textiles , curtain fabrics , silk shirts , silk scarfs , ties etc.
Old in New. Jim Thomson has done a remarkable job in creating this collection of old houses in the center of Bangkok. The museums and gift shop are worh a visit

Wonderful Simple Neat Place. I dropped a visit to Thompson house and it was really exciting to see this nice house with good engineering and living the life of this elegant manI advise anyone going to Bangkok shall not miss this experience at all

Good tour, peaceful setting. I've now been here three times, and it's a nice change from the crowds around the Grand Palace, even if it is a private collection. The tours are informative and there's demonstrations of Thai silk and dancing. There is a free art gallery located above the silk shop.

Quick tour of Jim Thompson residence. Beautiful home and grounds of Jim Thompson, American lover of Thai culture. Won't take more than 60-90 minutes of your time. Well worth it especially to see the home environment of a Thai home.

One of the best experiences I've had in bankok. This place is amazing, if your keen on a little bit of history I would highly recommend. They do a great tour for only 100 to 150 baht very cheap! Also there is an amazing restaurant with delicious food and cocktails, also they have a great store.
Nice Stroy About An American. Home is small & cannot take pictures inside. The history of Jim Thompson was very interesting and worth the 1 hour visit.

Showcase into the life of one of Thai important person. Jim Thompson house is very interesting. Get to see how Thai silk is produce. Furthermore it look into the house of a traditional Thai house and how it is build. The man have save the Thai silk industry which plays a major role in Thailand until now.

A very interesting place and informative tour. Very well organised tour, which depart to tour the house and grounds regularly with a variety of guides who speak many different languages. The House itself is beautiful, and very interesting. The story of Jim Thompson is indeed also interesting, and i would certainly return in the future. Security here is tight but not "In your face", but it is good to see that the place is well protected. Very enjoyable.
Cool house!. Surprising visit! It's a beautiful house, pretty gardens, and they have guided visits in English and other languages! Very interesting to learn more about this man.

very interesting site. I had read that if you had time to only see one site in Bangkok, this should be the one. I agree. You get a wonderful view of the culture of the city at that time. Only complaint is that since everyone else seems to think this is the place to go, it is naturally very crowded. Tip: they offer a free shuttle up and down their street to the main road.

A legend and a riddle. Jim Thompson's former residence is a must. Widely known for his beautiful silk products and is mysterious disapperance in the jungle, there are even more interesting riddles to the LIFE of this man. A former OSS secret service operative during WWII, he settled down in Thailand as a businessmen, soon to antagonize his former masters in US Intelligence and the Thai conservative establishment. Even though it is strictly forbidden, I could not help doing a sneak shot of his living room. This place was frequently the stage for his (in)famous 'lecturing' of visiting the US jornalists on the folly hos countrys foreign policy in South East Asia.

Interesting place to visit. Interesting and informative. Small hidden gem and not someone I had ever heard of. You must go with a guide as the information shared makes it more interesting. Lots of different things to see, but the house is the best part.

Interesting collection of artifacts. This was an interesting collection of buildings and artifacts, essentially culture rescued by a Western outsider, so his take on it added to the interest factor, for example, the two Mahjong tables used as a dinning table. We spent about 2 hours here.

Silky smooth. To be honest, I'd never heard of Jim Thompson before arrival in Bangkok and even then I only noticed it en passant in the 'places to visit' list and hadn't really expected to visit. Anyhow, my sense of direction failed several times around Siam to the point that we were about to jump back on good old Skytrain and give the day up to prepare for the evening's entertainment but I had one last look at the map and lo and behold, I noticed JT's house was only a relatively short distance away. Even so, we elected to take a taxi (an experience in itself involving driving the wrong way down the main road....) and arrived in 'fight or flight' mode, well pumped! But at least a bit less footsore....As soon as we alighted we were hit by an overwhelming sense of peace and greenery - a tranquil oasis if you will - with Thai dancing, silk cocoon spinning, birds and canals! Tickets were very reasonably priced and included mandatory accompanied tours in many languages (one language per tour obviously) and if I had to make any criticism it would be that the tours are rather quick and it's difficult to hear and take in all the info. After the tour you're free to wander around the site and study in a bit more depth, have a snack in the cafe and admire the clothes / bags etc on sale. Didn't buy anything as a bit expensive for me but you have to say the items are spot-on!

Don't believe the hype. Really couldn't see what the fuss was all about with this house ? Nothing really exciting to see and the guided tour had too many people on and didn't grab my attention. Wasn't worth the trip to fond

Well maintain & homely . The house is well maintained original structure and full of history. It's like a museum with the artefact preserved in excellent condition. There a few structures in a very large compound with a history of silk work & the Muslim community of Bangkok.

Timeless fascination. The mystique surrounding Jim Thompson's disappearance adds a layer of interest that lingers once one has left his beautiful collection of traditional Thai houses. A guided tour is the only option and it's quite expensive to get in but worth every penny. The architects eye that Thompson brought to his collecting passion adds a finesse and perfection to this compound.A nice restaurant is a welcome addition and the food is good.

Beautiful place. Beautiful house, great restaurant, very nice shop.House/museum - guided tour included in the entrance fee. Beautiful house with great collection of ceramics, statues, wooden arts, and paintings. Beautiful garden, interesting architecture.Restaurant - The food is very yummy, and not that expensive. I would recommend the coconut ice cream and pomelo salad.Shop - I want to buy everything in the shop!

Fascinating. Well worth a visit but gets very busy with the inevitable Chinese Tourists. Go early if you can to avoid the crowds, the gift shop has some nice things but there are larger Jim Thompson shops around town with more choice.

Always pleases. What a little oasis in busy Bangkok.We always return each time we visit the city and now they even have a shuttle to run you from the corner to the house.The gardens are so well kept and picturesque and the restaurant and shop very tempting and a way to help you enjoy your shopping and eating experiences in Bangkok

I would stay there too!. The houses are beautifully arranged. It worths the effort to get there. Our tuk-tuk driver didn't know the address althuogh we showed him the map too. You can visit the house by arranged guided tours. The visit takes 30 minutes. After the tour we sat in the coffe bar, the mango smoothy is delicious! (Bit expensive)

Good place to look back at history. If you have a good guide, story telling should be good. Nice to know and learn. The cafe serves resonably priced choices in the menu. Very clean.Just have a look at the shop but probably more towards the higher end. Walkable frm National Stadium MRT.
So worth a visit. I was so pleasantly surprised by this house. Besides being beautiful architecture it has a massive collection of Thai antiques.

Once is enough . While I enjoyed the tour and seeing the house and learning the history, it was a little drawn out and would have preferred to see on my own. The shop here is nice, but if looking for more variety, go to their other location - much larger and more options. This shop was great for any last minute must haves.

Jim Thompson House. This wooden built well preserved building houses a mass of relics from earlier in the 20th century, based on a collection initiated by Jim Thompson in his heyday. It is beautifully presented and preserved and is well worth a visit.

interesting, if you like a bit of history. This is very popular with tourists consequently always busy. The tour is guided only, about 10 in our group and you usually have to wait a while before your tour begins. The guide was informative and spoke good english. This is all about Jim Thompson, so apart from a sole person spinning silk no info was offered on silk production. Well stocked on-site shop but expensive. Worth a visit though.

The tour of the Jim Thompson house was very interesting and informative.. I learned a lot about the Thai history and people from the tour guide at the Jim Thompson house. I highly recommend this tour. The tour as about 35 minutes long and full of interesting items and stories/facts about Thailand and Thai people.

Must see - easy to get to and nice tour. Take the BTS to National Stadium. Very easy and avoid the traffic. It is clearly sign posted. The tour is compulsory and was very entertaining, so don't be put off by it. Done in a variety of languages and lasts about 30 minutes. Finish off with a drink and snack in the restaurant.

Very Interesting Tour. We were in Bangkok with friends one of whom is a long time Jim Thompson fan so we thought she love really enjoy this and in fact we all had a great time. Its really easy to get here yourself on the train and just a short walk, its about 3 pound each so good value too. Once you have paid you go to a counter in the grounds, they will give you the letter of your tour and approximately how long you will be waiting. Would highly recommend it

A by Gone Era. The story surrounding Jim Thompson is mysterious. This is a tour of his private home whilst he lived. Our tour guide was so funny with her little antidotes she had us in stitches throughout the tour. A beautiful tour. The little shop downstairs sells products made of Thai Silk and Thai fabrics. A little pricey but exceptional quality. In the courtyard we were fortunate to see silk worms and the silk being harvested. We were also entertained with Thai dancing. The restaurant within the complex was very welcome on a hot day. I loved the whole experience.

Amazing place. It's an amazing place, full of beauty. Incredible architecture, wonderful furnitures, marvelous garden. You breath the art and you feel the unconditional love for the beauty. Great service, well organized.
Very interesting. I had no idea about Jim Thompson until I was told to go see this house. It was a great experience to learn about him and see his place. Very interesting.
Interesting. Interesting place and interesting story, it is nice to go to have a look around and learn something new about Thailand.

A beautiful house in the heart of Bangkok. A very peaceful museum and you don't feel like you are in the middle of the city. We ate at the restaurant while we where there and the food was good although a bit pricey. They have dance performances about every hour.

Very interesting. A lovely and well preserved bit of history in the heart of the city. We had an excellent tour through the house and our guide explained all about the art and architecture of the house. A very intriguing story behind this interesting man.....and the mystery surrounding his end

fantastic. very interesting piece of history, well kept and organized. Guided tour took around 35 mins, could have been more exhaustive but still very interesting to hear. Very well organized too. Do not miss the gallery space on the second floor, in front of the ticket office.

Silk lovers must visit!. It's like a museum now .Lot of art and antique collection keeps the vistors busy.its a good building and has a very good back yard. Lot of flowers and palm trees. This gives a unique appeal!

Interesting piece of Bankok history. A little piece of history in the centre of Bangkok. We enjoyed the tour through the house with our guide who was very informative and had a good sense of humor. The Thai architecture and furnishings are interesting as is the story of Jim Thompson. A very well organised centre and we also enjoyed watching the thai girls dance after the tour.

soothing house in a crowded city. Take a black2 "tuk-tuk" with Jim Thompson's logo for a free ride from in front of the escalator of BTS national stadium to the House (vv).Nice treat from the entrance with a traditional silk fabrication display, traditional dance & humble greetings. But, it's quite hard to understand the tour guide who explain in Eng. I've asked one of tour members from Canada, and she's felt the same thing.
Catch the Art Gallery. What a peaceful space . . . very good food in the restaurant . . . a stunning installation in the art gallery was a delightful surprise.

Whatever happened to Jim Thompson?. Well worth a visit to the father of the Thai silk industry's interesting home. Lots of beautiful art pieces in a lovely garden setting. Plus there is the mystery of what became of Jim!

A lot of hype. Felt I had to go have a look but not really that great from my point of view. If you like the thai history then ok but think over sold. Amazingly some of the clothes etc on sale are made in Italy !!!

Simply beautiful. Even though I have visited Jim Thompson's house a number of times, it is still my favourite place to come when I am in Bangkok. The houses and garden are beautifully maintained and there is such tranquility there. Rare examples of traditional Thai housing, furnished with Thompson's collection of Thai and SE Asian art and furniture - as well as some of his own designs give insight into the man's lifestyle, values and influence. Arrive early though as the queue for the compulsory tours can be very long. We arrived at midday, and with the line reaching to the street, decided to stay just for lunch. And the lunch was really delicious. Next morning we returned at opening time when there was hardly anyone there. The tour was really worthwhile, with our guide providing interesting information, anecdotes and clear explanations. A lovely day out.

Hard to believe where this is located...central Bangkok!. Always reassuring to visit this iconic location to remind oneself what Thailand used too be like once upon a time, and not so long ago. Not to be missed.

A little oasis in the heart of Bangkok. This house and the surrounding gardens are so peaceful that it's hard to believe you're just a few blocks from the bustling commercial center of the city. Jim Thompson certainly was a man of vision (excellent taste, too) and it's well worth the time and money to hear his legend and see what he created. One tip -- remember the house is on Soi Kasem 2, which is away from the shopping area as you get off the train at National Stadium. Soi Kasem 1 does not connect, so if you make a wrong turn, you'll be doing a lot of walking.

Short but Sweet. I like to seek a little bit of history and culture when I travel, so I thought that the Jim Thompson House would fit well with me. And it did - it was short and sweet. The tours are short and last less than an hour, but they are very well organized by the staff there. I had my tour in English, and I thought my tour guide's English was well trained. I liked being able to see the artifacts and remnants of a past Thai cultural enthusiast. The tour guide also explained some of the artifacts' purposes and design meanings. I would recommend going early so that you can catch the first tour in your appropriate language and then go on about your day (this is what I did.) I feel like if you go in the middle of the day, you might end up waiting a while for the next tour in the language you want and then you may feel restless about the time you're spending there. So to avoid this, I would arrive early! I also purchased a zodiac guide in their small bookstore adjacent to their reception desk. It made a great souvenir gift. I wouldn't say the experience was exceptional and spectacular, but it was interesting and worthwhile. If you have some time in Thailand, I would recommend. If you only have a few days, maybe not so much.
A nice surprise and worth the trip!. You dont need much time for this but I would put it in your schedule. It is worth it. The house is beautiful and the history behind it is exciting.

Historic place. Friendly staff.. Great place to visit for history and architecture lovers. This is a nice old bungalow built almost entirely out of teak. Well preserved. Really friendly staff and guides.
A wonderfull shop for silk!. You can buy almost all silk fabrics, meaning ties, scarfs and other items and a very good price. These items would probably be a lot more expensive in your countries.
Pretty House and Gardens. Interesting story of how the home was constructed from separate houses that were moved to the location..... nice history lesson and artifacts.

Worth a visit . This was easily accessible by Sky train during our stay in Bangkok. It's an interesting house and an interesting contrast to the ornate temples and palace. Interesting history. Worth a visit if you're in the area. We spent a pleasant couple of hours there

Jim Thompson's house. Excellent and relaxing place with the most tranquil cafe with a beautiful pond full of colourful carps! The house is a perfect example of Thay arctecture and it has very nice gift shop! You also get a tok tok train like transport back ant to the main road if you feel to hot to walk down the lane (Soi).

Well maintained cultural place in BKK. Jim Thompson House is just near the city and very accessible. Just take the BTS Skytrain Silom Line and go down at National Stadium. From there it's just a 5-10 minute walk. From the main road, they offer free tuktuk ride (and going back as well).He was an American Architect expat who became interested in the Thai Culture. He combined 6 different Thai houses and made it into one (which is now the Jim Thompson House).The house is very well maintained and offers tour every approx 30 minutes (150THB). For history, art & architectural lovers, I think the price of the tour is worth it.

Excellent!!. If you love a little bit of history, this place is a must while visiting Bangkok.
The house is very well preserved, there are tour guides that take you back in time (they speak very good english/french and german). The tour is one hour long.
After the tour you can enjoy a drink and some local cuisine at the restaurant.

Spectacular, but know what you are viewing. This is a gem of a piece of Thai history. Thompson assembled several teak houses here in BKK and filled them with antiquities. A quick read on his background will aid to your enjoyment of this marvelous Thai home. Tours in several languges.
Lovely place. So glad I went there. Beautiful house, relaxed. But no much to see there, just the house and garden. They have little restaurant and a shop.

Fascinating, very well run place. Jim Thompson House is a well oiled tourist attraction. It's fairly small and there isn't all that much to see, but it's well worth a visit nonetheless as it presents a fascinating window into a Thai culture and history through the lens of a foreigner who made the country his home.There are regular tours in several languages carried out by well trained guides. Lockers are available for your possessions, as are foot lockers for shoes (taken off during the indoor segments of the tour). The tour is carried out in a very professional and informative manner, highlighting the idiosyncrasies of the buildings and key differences from traditional Thai homes. Surprisingly, there isn't too much to see that relates to the silk industry that Thompson kick started.The grounds are beautiful and very well maintained, and it's worth wandering around before or after the tour at your own speed, most of the grounds are accessible. It's definitely worth committing a couple of hours for this if you are visiting the MBK mall, which is within walking distance (be aware that the house is some way down the soi it's on, though they do provide free tuk tuk shuttles to get back to the main road).

A bit of a tourist trap.. The house and the artifacts are lovely and the commentary is good but just be aware that the guided tours (about 30-40 minutes) are compulsory. Entrance is 150 baht. Go to the garden area to register FIRST because usually you have to wait around half an hour for your turn. Go there if you want to buy Thai silk. Otherwise, there are so many great little art galleries and things like that that are more off the beaten track, completely free and in my opinion, more interesting.

A good, worthy visit. Jim Thompson has different sessions in different languages, every 20 minsutes or so. They take you around the museum and the house and explain the relevance of the artefacts. it would be helpful had they explained the link between Thai silk and Jim Thompson, the origin of Thai silk etc. There is an entry fee of 250 Bhat per person. The restaurant and the shop are a must go.The restaurant was top notch and served amazing food. The silk shop had a variety of scarves, pillow covers, table mats, neck tie etc. Although I would recommend not to buy Pashmina shawls from there as they are extremely over priced. You can buy them from India, with better quality and much cheaper prices.

An oasis. Arriving early on a Sunday morning, we were greeted by a traditional Thai dancer performing in the shady garden. Joining the guided tour, we enjoyed walking round this impressive house, admiring the history and listening to the stories of when Mr Thompson lived there. We had lunch in the restaurant, which was very reasonably priced. My only comment would be the air con was a little cold!

Interesting piece of Thai modern history. The house is as is the day Jim Thompson disappeared in the jungles of the Malaysian highlands. Beautiful old Thai house, antiques, silk and a nice restaurant.Very nicely located by the klong (canal), a sort of getaway in the center of town.

Interesting place. Beautiful grounds and worth a visit on a slow day. Nothing out of this world, but it is very interesting.Can be difficult to find, 2 taxi drivers didn't know what I was talking about.

Beautiful teak home of an expat. The tour is mandatory. It lasts about 45min. After free to browse the garden and boutiques. They offer free tuktuk from the main road but if on a taxi they will drop you off at the house

Fantastic place. A beautiful house museum, well worth taking the time to visit here. They allocate you to a 30 minute tour (available in five languages) for inside the house, so that you can get the most from the visit. You are then free to wander the gardens. The lady I had was brilliant - lots of information about Jim Thompson's life and how the house came to be built. The house is stunning and each room is exquisite. When I visited there was also an exhibition, which is included in the entry fee. You will not be disappointed.

Fantastic place steeped in mystery and history.. We were told by a friend to visit Jim Thompson house, this was a good bit of advice, what a fabulous place to visit. Tranquil, Mystery surrounds the disappearance of Jim Thompson but the architecture is fabulous You must not miss this.

Very pretty grounds, a great activity for a slower day. The Jim Thompson house is a very beautiful home with many lovely items in it. There's a guided tour that's worth it as they take guests around to show them some of the lovely items. It's a perfect activity if you're in search of something calmer or low key in Bangkok

A stunning place . Worth the visit.. The Jim Thompson House was the highlight of my Bangkok leg of my Thailand Backpacking tour. You can get a brilliant paid tour around the house which is completely worth it because you get a sense of how he lived there. No photography is allowed in the house( a good thing) . The house is very charming with some fabulous and strange architecture(all the entrances to the rooms have a wooden block to walk over which wards of spirits and avoid baby's getting into the next room....)Jim Thompson had a significant impact of the silk industry of Thailand and his story gets a little mysterious with his disappearance. A lovely store at the entrance sells shawls and other stuff made out of silk.
Great history tour. Our tour guide was very knowledgable and her English was very good. Enjoyed learning about this part of their history

Wonderful tour!. We visited the Jim Thompson House in the late afternoon after a hectic day of visiting temples and the Grand Palace. It was an excellent way to end the day. The grounds were very beautiful and peaceful. The tour lasted about 40 minutes and it offered some incredible insight into the Thai Silk industry. I didn't buy anything at the gift shop but it was not for lack of wanting! I highly recommend this attraction for your time in Bangkok - it is a must see! It's also located quite conveniently to the BTS sky train!

Wonderful house and history. Excellent tour of the house and history of an extremely interesting man, well worth spending a couple of hours, with a 45 minute guided tour.We walked a lot in Bangkok, and only mistake we made, was to take a tuk tuk nearby the house, driver quoted 20 Baht (Euro 0.5), but then took us first to a jewellery house, where of course he gets commission, he was not happy we did not buy anything, but gave him 40 Baht - beware!

A great introduction to traditional Thai homes. The house and the gardens around it are fascinating and we learned a lot during the tour about why traditional Thai homes are built and laid out the way the are.

Interesting house if you have spare time. Not the no. 1 attraction but interesting tour around the old teak home, fascinating to see how the guides manage the groups cross crossing each other. You will have a wait to start but pleasant garden to wander round and good cafe, shop,etc to make this a few hours trip.

A must visit.... Amazing house with beautiful landscaping and architectural detailing. You can explore a water taxi at the end of the road if you find yourself adventurous. On our visit we jumped on water taxi and took it to the end of a canal then hopped off to walk aimlessly exploring the city.

Better than I expected. . We had never been to Jim Thompson house on our previous visits but really glad we did.
Amazing serene gardens surrounded by original teak houses brought to site from around Thailand.
Interesting collection of furniture and art amassed by Thompson over the years also.
Worth a visit

Tourist visiting Bangkok. A must visit stop to see how the American Royalty of the day lived. This house is exquisite and must be seen. Plus to learn the history of Jim Thompson, who lives on with the legacy of his silk business.

Definitely worth the vidit. Was a little dubious to start...
Tour guide was fantastic and made it for us. Really interesting and relatively cheap to get into 150 baht pp
Watch out for expensive tuk tuk drivers outside when you leave

Excellent if you're interested in history and culture. I've been here twice and the second time was even better. It's in central Bangkok near Siam Square and very well organised. You can only get into the house if you pay for a tour. The tours only take around 45 minutes and you can take one in Thai, English or French. The guides are excellent and the story is really interesting (although somewhat safe compared to the unofficial story) but it's true he did a lot for the country in getting the silk trade up and going after the war. There's also a store with Jim Thompson books etc as well as the larger retail store with silk products (scarves, pillows, clothes, handbags etc) and it's not cheap by local Thai standards. There's a chain of JT stores, incl the international airport so you won't miss out if you don't get anything on the day. There's also a restaurant on site which is fine but again at tourist prices and the menu hadn't changed in the 7 months since my last visit. This is definitely worth a visit to give really good historical context to Thai history through the centuries.

Interesting guided visit and great for lunch. The Jim Thompson house is a collection of old Thai buildings put together to create this house. The guided tour is brief and interesting. The shop has some beautiful and expensive items for sale. The restaurant makes a great lunch time stop.
Enjoyable Afternoon. Enjoyable afternoon spent touring the museum. Beautifully restored and kept up. Excellent tour staff and plenty of time provided to enjoy.

Fascinating insight into the man who revived the Thai silk industry. I've visited the Jim Thompson house several times over the years, often taking visitors there. The tour of the house is quite fascinating, and it prompted me to read a book on the life of the man himself.The restaurant is lovely and serves good quality Thai food,a s well as some western favourites. It's a welcome respite from the heat of Bangkok, and right next door to the house. There is also a shop front selling a range of silk products.It's easy to get to from the National Stadium BTS station, and thoroughly recommended.

Fun and Manageable. This museum was interesting and fun. We enjoyed the history and the house tour. The gardens were nice. They also had a great gift shop with nice but affordable things to buy. It was small enough to see it thoroughly in a short time.

History, Art & Museum Lovers Will Enjoy This. We took a tour in English, and our guide was quite knowledgeable and spoke English well enough that we understood most of what she said. The house is so interesting, and the art collections and decor reflect an owner who had eclectic tastes, so there really is something for everybody in this tour. Just enough earthy trivia to keep people who are not "intellectual" happy as well. While you wait for your tour to start there are some silk weavers to watch, or they might do a traditional dance to keep you entertained, or you can step into the air conditioned gift store and buy some expensive silk items... The waiting areas are pleasant with shady arbors and fans also. BE AWARE! You will have to walk barefoot through the house (though not the garden portion of the tour) and putting your purse or bags in a locker. Also no photos can be taken inside the house.
A charming restaurant. Very good food in a very interesting place. A charming restaurant. Price is fair enough. Excellent experience.
An interesting escape from the shopping.. Informative great gardens the restaurant is good. Architecture is outstanding as is the collection. Outstanding Contemporary Art exhibitions also.

Good attraction with silky smooth organisation. A VISIT to Jim Thompson’s House is a must to appreciate his importance to Thailand for revitalising Thai silk and showcasing it to the world.Thompson’s mysterious disappearance while on a visit to Malaysia in 1967 has never been explained and his body has never been found, but visitors can tour his home in Bangkok and gain some insight into the man, his business and how it developed.The house itself is actually a combination of six traditional Thai homes that Thompson had brought in and skilfully combined.Entry costs 150 baht or about £3 and your whole visit is well organised through a guide system, visitors being asked to wait in a central area until their number and letter are called and they can step forward to begin a tour of the house with their selected guide.My tour began in dramatic fashion with a huge cloudburst which forced our guide to issue umbrellas so we could get across a little courtyard to the start of the house tour. The rain was so heavy it was actually bouncing off the ground!Shoes are taken off and backpacks left behind in lockers before you get taken up this staircase, down that corridor and into a variety of rooms to see everything from porcelain – Thompson was a great collector of antiques – to beds, statues, furniture and paintings.Some of the exhibits are priceless and the house is set in a lovely garden near a klong or canalway which, at one point during my visit, had a large boat cruise through setting up an aftermath of huge waves.It was a very enjoyable and informative hour while the site includes a tourist point which is very helpful, toilets which are clean and well kept and there are even koi carp cruising a pond to enjoy. Excellent value for the entry fee.The quality of the gifts available, as you might expect, is very high. The main shop is air conditioned which was very welcome while a subsidiary shop offered a highly unusual chance to walk away with a sheet of heavy duty paper with your horoscope on it, definitely an unusual memento and it only cost 100 baht or £2.An interesting and absorbing attraction where a couple of hours flew by before you realised it. Well worth a visit.

Interesting .... I have interest in Architecture so I enjoy my visiting.it's very calm and relaxing, the visitors will be split in groups and provided with a guide who will make a tour and explain everything about Jim and his house. they provided guides speaking different languages (english, french, chinese .... ).a lots of items to be seen in the house, it's very interesting and the story of Jim and his disappearance gives a mystery feeling about the house. they have a good restaurant and Bar there offers a good Thai food, and good cocktails.it's a little pricey comparing with other restaurants but the food is good and the sitting is great.

Beautiful house and interesting tour. This is a nice spot to tour after you have seen enough temples. The house is very pretty with a nice 30 minute tour. Easy location to get to - near the Siam Paragon.

Very pleasant refugee . This place was a very pleasant refugee in the middle of chaos! The house is amazing, showing many values of Thai culture and and many art objects such as paintings and sculptures. They have a very pleasant bar and restaurant. Their mojito is so refreshing! He best I have ever had!And they have a Jim Thompson store, where you can buy clothes, purses and silk scarves (wonderful!). Visits are guided, in english and French. Definitely recommend!
I am so glad we made the effort to see this. What a beautiful place in the middle of crazy Bangkok. This had very interesting history about Jim Thompson.

A great place experience Thai Architecture.. We went as a family. The place is well organized. Tour groups are provided using different languages. The novelties shop is amazing. The cafe is nicely design but the food is only average. A great place to chill and have a drink though.
Great place to visit. Loved visiting this site, peaceful, good guides, very interesting architecture , interesting story about Jim Thompson .
Nice ambience with Thai dance performance. Good thai food served inside or outside. Staff is young and may improve. A store nearby sells beautyful silk fabrics!

Good as a house-museum, but not unmissable. Story about him and the house is interesting. He was an architect who constructed the house with wood and parts of others buidings from de old capital, Ayudhya. It´s a house-museum and as this is nice, beautiful. But if you are not for a long time in Bangkok you can skip this atraction.

The Silk has long gone. Don't go here to buy silk. The part of the Jim Thompson story has long gone. It's now just a brand happy to sell in its shop expensive polo shirts from Italy under the brand and probably few items using indigenous silk or labour.The house museum however is well worth a visit and does give some real insight into the Bangkok of the past.
It's alright. It's alright, you have to take a guided tour and it was pretty cheap. But you can't take pictures inside and my guide sorta just rushed things through.
Worth the visit. Amazing place and garden with so beautiful luxury shop! Must be visited. Guided tours inside only. You will find sopmething to buy for sure.

Nice example of old city architecture. Didn't take the tour. Just met a friend for lunch in the restaurant/bar. It was fine. Quiet and idyllic location but nothing out of the ordinary. Easy walk from the BTS.

Great, Informative Tour. I've lived in Thailand for 2 years, in a small community in Isaan, and yet this tour still managed to teach me new things about Buddhism and Thai culture. For only 150 baht you get to explore the gardens (which are breathtaking) and the unique house that Jim Thompson put together. As a fan of architecture, it was really interesting to see how he respected Thai architecture and culture while blending it with the elements of a western home, and the tour guide is great and points all these things out to you. The gift shops offer some really great souvenirs and some beautiful silks. I highly recommend spending a couple hours here.

Very interesting architecture and collections . I would highly recommend this oasis in Bangkok. It has very beautiful gardens, interesting statues, beautiful porcelain, and an interesting story of silk and spies. While I was glad that we did the tour as only then can you walk into the house and explore / the grounds are very lovely as well.

A Must For Tourists, But Not 'Touristy'. A very interesting display in a beautifully conserved Thai house. One can really imagine living here.Well worth a visit, even for people who try to avoid the tourist trail.

Very interesting tourist site. This was a really interesting place to visit. American Jim Thompson, renowned for growing Thailand's silk industry, built this house in the 1950s in a very traditional Thai style, using dismantled buildings from other places and bringing them together. It's very beautiful, surrounded by lovely gardens, and the rooms are filled with Thai art and antiques. It's 150B to have a tour (which is the only way to visit) and the tour only lasts 40 monies unfortunately, but you can wander round the gardens as much as you like. They offer tours in Thai, Chinese, Japanese, English and French. There's also a restaurant and a shop selling predominantly silk products.
Nice. I love the way you can see everything it is a nice hideaway from the city center and very informative to know something about the history

Old Thai house of a colonial expat in Bangkok. Jim Thompsons house & garden is a haven of peace in a hectic Bangkok. His wooden Thai house is beautiful and has some wonderful artefacts that he collected during his years as an expat Thai silk manufacturing entrepreneur. A 5 mins walk from MBK shopping mall its well worth an hour or so to visit and see how the rich expats used to live not so long ago.

A glimpse into old Bangkok. Great tour of an authentic Thai home. Was actually reconstructed from a few homes that Jim Thompson bought and brought to this location. The furnishings are as interesting as the house.

Iconic tourist spot is not friendly. The house does regular tours. We bought our tickets and waited in the shop. Outrageously high pricing: trading on name not quality.
Time for the tour: handbags not allowed. Lockers are provided but we weren't prepared to leave all our money and passports etc out of site. No flexibility - though they did give a refund. Unnecessary security.

A beautiful place to spend an hour. The amazing museum contains beautiful artifacts housed in a house that the wealthy Jim Thompson built for himself. The structure is a good vehicle for displaying the interesting art
very nice visit. The house is very interesting to visit, in the heart of modern Bangkok it is a haven of peace, surrounded buy well kept gardens, there is also a shop selling silk items.
Very nice.. The 150 baht per person is expensive. Mr. Jim Thompson had put in great effort to build the house. Shopping was very nice.

Nice furniture and houses, informed guide. Captivating info on silkworms. Well-managed tourist flow. The life of Jim Thompson is intriguing in itself, from the beginning on the OSS to the final, mysterious disappearance...but the museum does much more, than documenting his life: our guide clearly explained the background of the house (houses) architecture, from both the historical and the religious perspective; the house furniture has some nice pieces; in the courtyard, some panels (suitable for children and adults as well) well explain the silkworm's life cycle; a guy demonstrated the extraction of the silk thread from a bunch of cocoons...  There were a lot of tourists, but they were divided in reasonably-sized groups and well managed in terms of time available in each room etc. Last but not least, a couple of pretty dancers performed in front of us with the usual Thai grace

Very enjoyable outing, interesting tour. Didn't realise before entering that the tour is compulsory but it was well worth it. The story of Jim Thompson and his possessions / home is an interesting one. I would have liked the opportunity to ask more questions. It's an easy half day activity and lunch in the restaurant was delicious. Also very easy to get to from Skytrain. The shop was pricey but I guess that's to be expected!
Typical thai house. The gardens were beautiful and a great place to start the day, however didn't find it particularly interesting.

Jim Thompson's House_Silk fabric museum with mysterious story. Jim Thompson's house exceed my expectation. I truly enjoy the English tour and it is the best way to get to know the history of Thai silk fabric and the story of Jim Thompson. I love the architecture and Jim Thompson is quite the art collector, so being inside his house and his study, even his dinning room was so interesting. The lovely garden and the cute house, we spent a great sunny morning there. It's also got a very nice gift shop and art gallery close to the entrance, highly recommended.

Mystery House. This was a nice trip and interesting. Jim Thompson was a good business man and I can understand why he settled in Thailand. He re-energised the silk trade in Thailand so we now may all experience this wonderful material. The shop on site was very expensive - with some exquisite items, but high prices for a holiday souvenir.
Wonderful museum !!!. Well worth the 150 bt for the guided tour around the fab gardens and house(s) ... There is a great quality gift shop of high quality silk wear etc Plus restaurant and bar

Interesting but very commercialized.. The Jim Thompson house is an interesting historical place to visit, in relation to one foreigner's footprint on Bangkok and its commercial impact on its tourist business over time. The architecture of the house itself is functional but not spectacular. The furnitures and fixtures are not museum grade, but they are very nicely selected and presented. So at the end of the guided house tour, one does get some sense of how life was decades ago when Jim Thompson lived there. Our tour guide was proficient but looked like she was just going through the motions. After all, it seems that the house is there mostly to promote the vast silk business in the name of Jim Thompson.
Beautiful house. It is a beautiful house where you get a good impression how life was in these days. Very organised, they make many little groups per language.
Never tire of. I live in Bangkok, and always take visiting friends, and some locals! Great value, a great part of not only Thai but American history.

Nice traditional Thai houses infused with western elements.. If you are tired of shopping, Jim Thompson House is a good visit. Located near to National Stadium BTS, the place manage to still hold an old-world charm. One could visit the exterior of the house on our own, but need to wait for a guide for the interior one. The guide is very polite and knowledgeable about things related to Jim Thompson. All in all, a nice break from shopping and good taste of the Thai culture.
Enjoyable morning. Interesting visit. Small Tranquil garden. Nice cafe. Convenient location to skytrain and some hotels. Tired of temples and shops then this is the place to head for.

Calm in the chaos!. Beautifully preserved teak house, full of fantastic art, with charming guides. The shop sells the famous silk, which is expensive but beautiful. The restaurant is very reasonably priced, and the smoothies are delicious. Its a lovely, calm space, worth a visit.
Surprisingly interesting. Nearly didn't bother but in fact really enjoyed it. Lovely restaurant for peaceful stop and gorgeous shop. Loved the Thai dancers.
Lovely peaceful place within walking distance of MBK. We went here via the canal boat which was great fun.Enjoyed the tour but didn't use the restaurant as we went MBK food hall after

Jim Thompson House is beautiful and peaceful. Be sure and read a little about Jim Thompson before you go through the house with the docent. A truly complex and fascinating man who brought Thai Silk to the world. His story and sad and mysterious demise make the house a moving home to see.Don't miss the gift shop but bring your credit card!

Lovely and fascinating!. The Jim Thompson House is a lovely sanctuary with in crowded and crazy Bangkok. Jim Thompson's story as the creator of the Thai silk trade, spy for the U.S. and a disappeared, make his home and gardens all the more intriguing.This was one of the best places we visited while in Bangkok and everyone should see it. Thompson moved 5 teak houses to the location and combined them to make an elegant home and gardens. His collection of Asian art and antiques is spectacular. The entire location can be visited and enjoyed in 1.5 hours. The BTS has a stop about a block away from the location and a free shuttle is provided by the venue. Though it is only a 5 minute walk down a lovely lane.Don't miss this gem!

An interesting house built by an intriguing man. Jim Thompson built a house sensitive to Thai traditions but also to Western sensibilities, and filled it with wonderful objects that he collected over the years he lived in Bangkok. Well worth a visit

A must visit when in Bangkok. Jim Thompson House and Museum is conveniently located in the heart of Bangkok right across to the National Stadium. If you want to experience transportation in Bangkok, the place is easily access Sky Train, buses, and boats other than taxi. The museum is at the end of a small road 5 minutes walk from the Sky Train station (just follow the sign). The museum (main house) was once a place to get silk and silk product by the canal and how is used to display Jim Thompson's collection of arts and artifacts. With a small entrance fee, visitors will be guided through the museum by well trained guides. Once the tour ends, visitors can roam around the ground and take photos (photos are not allowed inside the house (museum). It is worth visit to learn about Mr. Thompson's life and the history of "Silk in Thailand". A restaurant and Jim Thompson's product are at the two main building before entering the museum. I visited this place many times, especially the restaurant and the gift shop.

Overrated, but peaceful.... Although I enjoyed my tour of the Jim Thompson house, it wasn't really anything standout on my trip to Thailand. It's well preserved however, and the tour guides are well informed, which makes it worth a stop. However, I'm not sure why it was so hyped in the guidebooks...
I visit almost every year. Fun place to go and spend a few hours. Lots of history about Jim Thompson and the silk trade. Also has a wonderful if not inexpensive gift shop and a fantastic Resturant.

Overrated. Personally we were a bit disappointment. Not by the house or the cáfe, but by the really lousy and very short tour through the house. There are different tour guides. Our guide was a lazy lady not really speaking English, merely repeating a scripted text with the worst tone and intonations, not allowing questions and skipping stations. The other tour guides sit around and block the seats in the shade for the guests that are waiting for the start of the tour.The best part of the attraction are the general atmosphere and the history and mystery around Jim Thompson and his activity. The Cafe is also nice and calm.
Great tour. It was a well arrange tour. Interesting info in many different languages. Lovely lunch at the attached restaurant.

So historic and lovely. This was quite a cultural experience. So glad these beautiful old houses were preserved in one place. Our tour guide was excellent. Everything is beautifully preserved. It was fascinating to see them spinning the silk into thread and the gift shop was lovely. Wonder what happened to Jim Thompson ???

Jim Thompson House. We took the BTS to this charming house and compound. The Thai tour guide there spoke English clearly and informed us on every aspect of the house, it's furnishings and Jim Thompson himself..The cafe on the premises was convenient with good and reasonable food. Of course we had to purchase some item in the gift store which had many attractive, colorful items to take home.It was one of our favorites in Bangkok.

Well organised tour of the house. Easy to find from the SkyTrain station, take the tour of the house guides are well informed and it's a peaceful haven in the middle of the city, beautiful shaded garden and cafe witn terrace....

Local History. After a lon flight we wanted to do something close to our hotel. The concierge recommended this which was in easy walking distance. very interesting visit finished with a cold beer in the gardens.
Peaceful area. Close to the national stadium station. Is an itinerary item. However nithing much can be done except photography and relaxing ambience.

A beautiful house with great collections. Not to be missed. The visit makes you dream of a South East Asia that does not exist any longer.
Five or six wood buildings filled with beautiful pieces of furniture and objects of art, clearly chosen with love by Jim Thompson.
And the garden on the river is also beautiful.

An OK trip. I thought it was probably a bit over-rated. A quite impressive house but I'm sure there are others like it if not better. We combined it with a trip on the Sky train as we had a bit of spare time. It wouldn't be a must do for me next time.

unexpected highlight. Ticket includes a guided tour in English, French, Chinese or Japanese. Tour guide was very informative, and happy to explain various scenes from Buddhism depicted in Thompsons art colllections. The house and gardens are beautiful.Theres a free to enter gallery above the shop. We had a great and reasonably priced lunch in the beautiful restaurant in the garden afterwards. Very short signposted walk from National Stadium BTS.
Nothing much.. Just a house with good architecture. That all I can say about this. We didn't like it so much. ......

Highlight of Bangkok. I didn't know much about Jim Thompson before I visited and I was completely captivated. A great story, beautiful grounds, nice shop and Cafe, and wonderful tour guide. A very unique spot. Also, it isn't far from the BTS and there are free shuttles from the house to the train.

Lovely home. The house is undeniably beautiful and the story accompanying it is no doubt fascinating. But I came away confused and without learning anything about Jim Thompson aside from a few sparse facts. This is because there were no signs around the place, just a tour guide who kept things brief. I was expecting more.

Silk man of thailand. Jim Thompson was an American businessman who helped revitalise the Thai silk industry in the 1950s and 1960s. At the time of his disappearance he was one of the most famous Americans living in Asia. His house is well preserved and worth a visit to get an insight into the traditional thai houses and the way silk was made in the old times.

A nice old house and grounds. It's an interesting place to see if you are into Thai silk and products. I was more interested in a history behind the Jim Thompson silk and somewhat disapointed with their current products line. I think that the old products line when I first visited 20 years ago was much better.

OK attraction. Really just a look around his house. You don't actually find much out about the silk or the trade. Great traditional thai house to see. The guides explain all the nooks and crannies in great detail.
very interesting. found the place after a little searching - the tour is certainly interesting. not a long tour stop - but ideal for morning or filling in an afternoon that you have free.

A fascinating Thai-style home. We loved this museum. It is fascinating to see the house pretty much as Jim Thompson left it and to learn his history in Bangkok. On the grounds are silk-making demos and Thai dancers, as well as a restaurant. The gift shop has very nice Thai silks, although they are very pricey.

Not fussed really. This is a new stop in Bangkok which is not a temple... It is very highly rated but I don't see what the fuss is all about. A bit of nice history to it and a beautiful Thai style house but nothing life changing.

I want it all. Wonderful house, full of wonderful things! The grounds are also wonderful! The silk spinning was awesome. A look into Bangkoks past. At the store I wanted one of everything, so beautiful.

Beautiful grounds. Went with my 3 and 5 yo boys. The oldest was intrigued with the tour, but the youngest one was bored which is understandable. We walked through the rooms quickly enough before they started getting antsy. We were able to listen to everything the tour guide said about the house. Do bring bug spray. We all got bit as we were looking around the grounds while we waited for the tour to start. Tour runs 150 baht/person. Our boys were free. Also, there is a free tuk tuk that takes you from the house to the Main Street. Knocks out a good 5 min of walking.
Worth finding. Not easy to locate, but a fascinating insight into how one man rekindled interest in Thai silk.A lasting tribute to a true advocate for Thailand, it's people, culture and history.
Nice Visit. If you are interested in Arts & History, Jim Thompson house is a nice place to visit. Guided tour with good english speaking guide.

Well worth the effort to get there. I fully agree with Greg N's review one or two reviews prior to mine. If you use the sky train (National Stadium Station) as your transportation, look for the courtesy vehicles that will give you a free lift to the compound and return you to the sky train after your visit. If you don't see them, the walk up the alley isn't too far, but Bangkok is hot. Jim Thompson had amassed a large collection of asian art and the Thai government has done a great job of operating this museum.
Peaceful house. beautiful architecture, interesting part of history, warm welcome, quiet moment. the only thing is that it is difficult to walk around without a guide

Highlights why people fall in love with Bangkok. The tour around the house was very entertaining. The tour guide was friendly and very witty and informative at the same time. Seeing Jim Thompson's stuff and how life used to be like in Bangkok was a great experience and gave us a peak on Thailand's rich colorful culture. Jim Thompson's knack for collecting broken Buddha statues was also an interesting feature of this house.
beautiful but overrated. Yes, it is a beautiful place and as such worth a visit but IMHO there isn't more to it. The tour you have to take is ok but doesn't give you many insights.

An interesting mystery.. We love the mystery of Jim Thompson but didn;t really engage with the house. We understand the house is lots of old buildings put together to form the house as it is now and the place has a truly tranquil feeling. We cooled off in the restaurant with a singha beer and very slow service.

Best staff in Thailand, my favorite outing so far.. I thought it sounded kinda lame at first and not that interesting. I was wrong. This is a cool place with a cool story. My favorite attraction in Bangkok and totally unique. Not air conditioned, except for the restaurant, but you stay cool because of all the trees etc and the fans inside. Reachable by sky train and a short walk, or of course taxi. Your cheap admission includes a tour in your choice of 7 languages. The 6 parts of the house are old structures moved here by canal! I would say a "must-see", and if short of time feel free to skip a wat here or a palace there....

Busy but well organised. We were impressed at how well Jim Thompson House is run, we had no sooner paid the 300 baht for the entrance tickets when we were escorted to the desk to be given the time for our guided tour. The tour takes 35 minutes and does help with understanding the layout of the house. We enjoyed the visit, that makes 3 visits to JT's various enterprises. The outlet store, the flagship store near Lumpini Park and now the house.

Nice place, tranquil. The house was lovely and the grounds were beautiful. A calm oasis in the middle of bustling Bangkok. Learned a bit about Thai culture, but overall it was a bit mechanical. The insight restaurant was lovely and the food was good!Tours offered in English and French. Price was 150 for adult entrance.

Fascinating experience. We loved the well organised tour through the historic collection of buildings that make up what was Jim Thompson's house. A fascinating insight into a remarkable man and the industry he helped revive.

Overrated. Personaly I think the place is overrated, there are lots of houses in bangkok with outstanding architecture that people don't know (as the Vinmanmek) . Apart from that I can say that the guide was good, I really learned some interested facts about Thai Silk and Thai Culture.

Very Interesting, Beautiful architecture . Very detailed tour of a beautifully designed house. Tour guide was very insightful and very smiley.
