There is a restaurant and full size gift shop on premise. They have everything silk at this gift shop! For the home, for him/her/children accessories, etc. (I spent so much money!) The tours of the house are given every 30mins. While you wait, they have dancing ladies who entertain you or you can shop or eat on premise. there is also a flagship Jim Thompson store in Bangkok that is expansive and 3floors. Lots more merchandise ...went there as well and spent more money! Put this on your list when visiting Bangkok
Nice place to visit in the city.... Classic tourist place to visit, old-style, private house turned to museum, located between modern skyscrapers

Pleasant afternoon. We were there today .nice houses ,nice gardens and very well organised .The young guide gave us a 40 minute tour .very interesting .Not for young children we saw young children bored

Very nice guide visit. We spent half day there including lunch. There is a store of course but the main point is the visit of the teck house where lived Jim Thompson. As the visit are given in various language, you can easily find a place on the tour, even if you have not booked in advance.Food wise, very good but the day we went, service was very slow.We enjoy this visit overall.

The garden alone makes this worthwhile!. In a crowded, noisy, smelly city this is a jewel. We were so very glad we visited. The home of an architect turned silk merchant, the complex is walking distance from the National Stadium skytrain stop. The enclosure creates a world apart: tropical paradise with traditional Thai wood structures, pools, and lush and gorgeous plantings. The house tour is interesting - the design involved assembling several traditional houses in a non-traditional manner. The rooms are lovely, the art inside is worth seeing, and always, the views to the garden are framed beautifully.

My favorite spot in Bangkok. I travel to Bangkok at least twice a year and Jim Thompson House is my favorite spot to dine at. Their sticky rice pudding is to die for. Naturally I encourage my friends to visit the house and gardens and to learn about Jim Thompson's fate but I go there to dine. Nowadays I particularly appreciate the free modernized shuttle tuktuk.

an excellent attraction in Bangkok. Jim Thompson House attracts many more visitors than it did even a few years ago but it just seems to keep getting better and better. If I had only a short time to spend in Bangkok, this would be one of the top places to visit on my list.We had an absolutely excellent guide to take us round the house then leave us to look round the grounds. The admission fee has gone up to 150 Baht and there is a short wait to get on a tour. Once you have bought your ticket, go directly to where you're directed to book a time slot. Most tours are in English though, if you're prepared to wait a while, other languages are available. We noticed another guide who spoke French very well.As well as the house, the other facilities are of a high standard. We were delighted to see a display of traditional Thai dancing by a couple of very skilled and elegant young women. The shop is nice too but, with the sky-high prices, we noticed many people looking and very few buying!Don't bother with a taxi to Jim Thompson house if you have easy access to the BTS Skytrain system. It's only a short walk up the soi which is right beside the exit from National Stadium station.

Quiet place to visit. A nice spot to spend some time in. Tranquil and calm in comparison to the rest of the city. The shop is very expensive, but nice to browse around. The restaurant is also on the expensive side, and the food has been adapted for western tastes, but a nice place to sample some Thai food if you are nervous about spice!
Lost paradise. Ancient Bangkok wooden house with tropical garden. Jim thompson was an architect who wanted to preserve this typical style house. Must see

Beautiful Traditional Thai House with Fascinating Story!. The Jim Thompson House is incredibly fascinating, and equally beautiful! I read a book about Jim Thompson "The Ideal Man" before visiting the house which made it that much more interesting. A top attraction in BKK.

Beautiful house with very informative free tour!. I was a little apprehensive about this place as it didn't sound super interesting to me, but we had time and it was near a BTS station, so we decided to try it out. We were so glad we did! The house and grounds are gorgeous, very well kept, and a lot of fun to explore, but the highlight for me was what we learned on the tour! They offer tours in several different languages, which I thought was very convenient, and our tour guide was extremely well spoken and informative. We learned a lot about Thai architecture, including tidbits I had wondered about while visiting other Thai buildings. It's definitely a great place to take some great photos as well.

Restaurant is the best thing here, the house not so much. I guess the history of the now-missing Jim Thompson is what this is all about. But NO PICTURES allowed inside !! Really? Honestly, found this a very boring attraction. And there are a lot of stairs to deal with if you have climbing issues. The more interesting stuff for us was the making of Silk outside by the women. This particularly was kind of a waste of $ for us. The restaurant was great though, and reasonably priced.

Good to see and hear about this as there are Jim Thompson stores at all the high end malls. . Nice to hear about the background And home They should have better designs if they want to attract younger,ie under 50 yrs olds. Also I don't understand them selling cotton shirts from material shipped in from Italy. They could do a lot more with the Thai silk. They should also highlight the canal behind the house. Was it used?

Lovely House. Great to visit a little oasis in the middle of a busy busy city.Not expensive to get into and the onsite restaurant is great for a meal and cooling drink.Beautiful traditional house set in lovely gardens, there are also displays of silk weaving and also traditional thai dancers.Really enjoyed this little trip

Very Different Look at Thailand. The man that worked with the OSS in WWII, then moved to Thailand to revitalize the silk industry, then disappeared mysteriously in the Cameron Highlands of Malaysia left behind a beautiful property that is very interesting to visit.Upon entering the compound there is a silk shop, silk demonstrations, a cafe, and traditional Thai dancers. The grounds are kept immaculately, as is the house.The guides, in several different languages, have a vast knowledge of Jim Thompson and tell the story of his history, the history of the items in the house, Thai history, and how all these things join together to create a fascinating and beautiful place in Bangkok. Even our children were captivated during the tour (which was conducted while we were barefoot).

Nice peaceful place. This is a nice peaceful place in the middle of a busy city. The house is cool. Lots of interesting antiques and architecture. I learned a few interesting facts on the tour. It was worth the hour or so to visit. They had Thai dancers and someone making silk by hand which was interesting. There is a nice little foot massage spot right down the street.

Interesting history. We enjoyed our visit to this unique attraction. It's a lovely traditional Thai home made up of a number of Teak pavilions. Price for adults 150 baht (about $6; 100 baht for Students <22), and includes a guided tour in a major language of your choice. We had a good look around the gift shop and art gallery upstairs while waiting for our English tour time. Our guide was interesting and enthusiastic. Jim Thompson was a famed American Thai silk entrepreneur who vanished quite mysteriously in 1967.

great change of pace from the temples!. They run this place so smoothly, what a delight. A short 30 minute tour to give you a bit of history and perspective and then you are free to roam. On site restaurant is tranquil with good food and views. Shop has the best, high quality items made from Jim Thompson textiles. What an interesting guy and his home is gorgeous!

Beautiful peaceful location. This is a tranquil Thai home/cafe/art museum in a beautiful garden setting. It's an easy walk from the National Stadium BTS Skytrain stop down a side road called Kasem San 2 Alley. But if you have walking issues there is a free little shuttle that will run you up & down the road.You have to take a tour to see the house. They offer tours in many languages- just buy your ticket at the booth and walk to the courtyard. The tour takes about 45 minutes. They make you leave all your belongings (including shoes & cameras) in a locker at the base of the house. You can take photos of the grounds but not the inside of the house. It's an interesting tour with time in each room to look around a bit.Make sure you visit the art museum/display above the gift shop it's really quite interesting. There is a full restaurant on the property that has Thai dancing through the evening.
Interesting place for a 1 time visit.. Interesting to see, and hear about Jim Thompson. A little bit of a tourist trap, but worth the visit 1 time.
Cozy house in town !. We have lovely lunch and small tour in Jim Thompson house. Impressed with survice and thier local guide. Well done !

Green & cool. Very interesting location - breezy and cool so do this in the heat of the day. There is an exhibition upstairs at the moment - gold tear drops! You must see it! It's not well sign posted but we got some fabulous photos!

A tranquil oasis - for the inquiring mind. Ex-CIA operative, businessman, man of mystery: truth is stranger than fiction. When Jim Thompson went missing in the Cameron Highlands of Malaysia, the mystique was assured. The tour itself is a well choreographed homage to the man who reputedly "single-handedly revitalized the Thai silk industry." The house itself is a collage of six traditional Thai houses with some interesting architectural modifications. What is most interesting to me, however, is the authorized version of the history of Jim Thompson - and the almost complete lack of personality the man left behind in the house. Someone has done an excellent job of creating the legend behind the brand. There is a very nice cafe attached to the house, which serves up refreshing drinks and good food. Although the tour guide was at pains to tell us that the Jim Thompson House is a museum foundation separate from the silk shop, there is a store outlet on the premises - all very beautiful and accordingly priced articles. For me the best part of the visit is that you are in central Bangkok, yet a five minute walk up a soi gets you away from the bustle of the city. A golf cart will take you up the soi if you are mobility reduced; simply wait at the end of the soi and a cart will come along shortly. Access from National Stadium BTS station.

Good to visit . Very well organised commercial venture now compared to when I first visited many years ago. As others have said you can only tour the house with a guide, so have a good look as you won't be able to go back and wander by yourself. Our guide had good English, but spoke very fast which I found hard to follow at times. ( I am English speaking!!). The gardens are lovely with many water features which can be photographed - no photos inside the house. There are demonstrations of silk harvesting from the silkworm cocoons and of silk weaving.The retail outlet was beautiful but expensive. The restaurant served lovely refreshments. There is a courtesy tuk tuk to take you back to the main road. I'd recommend a visit while you're in Bangkok as this could be the only place you will see a 'gracious' Thai stye house.

King of Thai silk. Nice place to see and feel the old rural Thai residential architecture and culture. Highly recommend anyone who are interested in Thai interior design, hand made silk, and collectibles.

Beautiful. Jim Thompson was an American citizen that established a very successful silk business in Thailand, contributing to rebuilding the industry in the country and creating international demand for it. Today's museum is hosted in what was his private house, a cluster of traditional teak and theng buildings that he got relocated from Ayutthaya. The house in itself, the pond and the garden are worth a visit; inside it is a showcase of his art pieces and silk garments. Spend some time to have a look at the store: blankets, scarves, ties and pillows are really good value for money. And the restaurant is very good as well.
interesting. if you are interested in textiles especially in silk then you definitely should visit this place for sure!

Good afternoon out. Seems ac little out of the way but plenty of good eating roundabout. Who knew that Jim Thompson was such an influential carachter? I do now since the innfo here is so well presented and accesible. Lots to take i but presented very well without any pressure.Certainly recommending this place come rain or shine.

Exquisite - Definitely worth a trip. I absolutely love the tour of Jim Thompson House. Aside from the stunning interiors and design work, the building itself is absolutely incredible. It was an amazing visit and well worth doing.

A pleasant hour . My wife and I got there hopping to hear more about the Thai silk traditions. The 150 per person buys you a tour guide (offered in many languages and very frequent). The tours are too heavy on who was mr Thompson and not enough on the art or silk work. Defiantly worth seeing but not a must see

Insight into the Figure who Made Thai Silk Populat the World Over. The Jim Thompson House is a must visit location for those interested in the person behind the popularity of Thai silk. A good place to see traditional Thai fabric. The attraction is actually a complex of Thai traditional houses. So, those into architecture will find the houses interesting.

Surprisingly interesting. I was with my wife and my little son and had a great hour and half. The building is really interesting like the gardens. You get a half an hour guided tour you can choose in english, french or chinese. The staff is superfriendly and kind. Recommended to do and learn something different in the busy Bangkok.

Dull with some interesting elements . We visited in November and while it was a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city we found the whole thing rather boring. Our tour guide did her best to relay the information in English but there were still chunks of narrative the group didn't understand. It was a good way to kill some time but I wouldn't go out of my way to go again

Really cool. Great souvenirs. Nice restaurant.. Jim Thompson was an American who stayed in Bangkok after World War II and revived the Thai hand made silk industry. He moved this traditional Thai house from the country side piece by piece to Bangkok. The house is incredible and his collection of antiques is museum quality. The house is as he left it when he disappeared in 1967. They don't let you take pictures inside the house, which is my only complaint. The 30 min tour is excellent though. Great hand made silk products in gift shop are a perfect gift or souvenir and take time to eat at the restaurant, it's very good. Next to a BTS station too.
Interesting. Did this as a gap filler and was pleasantly surprised, only planned a quick visit but spent over a hour and half here, got here by boat, give it a go

Worth a look. Worth a look to see the old Thai building that an American designed and lived in until he dissapeared in the Malaysian jungle! Nothing too special but go if you have some spare time in Bangkok!

Gather like locals, under a Thai House. Instead of meeting in a shopping mall, my local friends picked the cafe here. It's a nice Thai House setting surrounded by greens and water feature. We sat at the back area, this we could see some boats passing along the river besides the cafe. Food was not fully authentic as it tweaked to international palette. But dessert was pretty good. My friends brought some kids, and they took the kids into the gallery when they became restless. It's a pretty good space to meet friends.

A Must See. Beautiful collection of traditional Thai homes and gardens. The home is full of antiques from all over SE Asia. A great experience for antique lovers. The restaurant was also great. Wonderful Thai food and service.

Don't miss it. We needed more than an hour to travel from Pin Kao to the Jim Thompson house but it was worth it. It is a small peacefull place to spend some time. The tour was very interesting! Afther the tour was over we could wonder around in the gardeb. We had a lovely dinner after it. If you visit Bangkok it should be on your to do list :)

Exquisite!. This place is truly a masterpiece! Jim Thompson had such a interest and respect for the cultures he learnt about and you can see that in the items displayed throughout the home. The house itself is a piece of art.

Lifestyle . First of all I knew that Jim Thompson is clothes brand. Well here you will know about their history and lifestyle. There have multi spoke language guide Thai, English, French, Russian, Korean, Japanese etc.

A wonderful oasis in the city.. If you are looking for a quiet and relaxing diversion in downtown Bangkok, this is a great place to go. Jim Thompson House is actually a small compound of several buildings in a tropical setting on a khlong. Jim Thompson made his fortune by taking Thai batik to the world. He built this compound as his home and personal retreat from the heat and noise of the city. Thompson bought several traditional wooden Thai homes and arranged them in a garden with breezeways connecting them. The interiors are decorated with historic pieces representing Thai culture and values. There is a nice restaurant for lunch as well as an outlet that sells Thompson batik. Be sure to take the guided tour of the compound.

Interesting and a nice cafe.. We visited on a really hot day and it was nice waiting for our tour to start while sitting by the pond under a fan! You are allowed to take photographs outside the house but not inside and shoes and bags are checked into lockers, as is common with many attractions in Bangkok. Our english speaking tour guide (included in the price) was lovely and very informative. The rooms were interesting and she explained Jim Thompson's involvement with the silk industry as well as telling us about the antiques he collected and kept in his house. I wish there had been more information on silk textiles, or perhaps an exhibition involving the craftspeople who sat outside the house spinning silk. The cafe was nice and cool and the food was reasonably priced and very good. There is a free shuttle tuk-tuk back to the main road which we enjoyed, then it was just a short step to the BTS Skytrain.

House of full of collection. We visited JT House as part of our Bangkok Trip. Well maintained small oasis in the middle of Urban Bangkok. There are guided tours for different languages (english, chinese etc.,) as part of the entry Fee. Staffs are helpful, welcoming and very kind as during the tour, my 2 years old son was crying for water and the tour guide girl managed to find cold water for him. There are lots of Jim Thompson 's personal collections from different countries. Recommended for people who love to experience the unique collections and life of Jim Thompson who is the pioneer of revolution the thai silk industry. There are shop and restaurant in the same compound.It would be extra nice that if they can arrange air condition in every room as it can be very hot in some rooms without aircon.

Garden in the middle of the city. Living in Bangkok I was surprised that there was a place like Jim Thompson house. The place is very nice, for very little money, there is a guided tour in many languages about the history of Jim Thompson and his venture into Thailand. If you are not interested in the history I would highly recommend you can just relax and read a book at the shop with a refreshing drink that they serve
Cross it off your bucket list.. Excellent tour. Take the time to learn about Jim Thompson, the architecture and the history. Fun way to arrive by way of the water taxi.
Good. . A weird kind of vibe but good way to see the what Bangkok was like not so long ago. Shop is quite good as well. I wonder what really happened.

interesting but highly commercialised. very intersing how he put the houses all together and what he did for the thai silk trade and the mystery of his disappearance but the whole thing is a tourist attraction The shop actual sells Jim Thompson tea bags!..

don't miss it. For a nominal cost you get a guided tour of a house that was assembled by a man who gave Thai silk a place in the world of fashion. The house, the history and the oasis from the bedlam of Bangkok is so worth the effort and He price of admission (150 baht).

Simply wonderful! . What can be said that hasn't been said already? We didn't get to this until our last day in Bangkok and despite having been to numerous temples and museums already this was still a remarkable place to visit.

Interesting Museum . A traditional thai house where in you can see Jim Thompson lifetime collections of asian artifacts and antiques..
Interesting house and life story..
Entrance fee for 100baht..

Perfect cocktails and dining experience. Starting with welcome drinks on the grounds, being photographed with beautiful, costumed Thai ladies - makes one expect a good dinner appointment. We were then ushered into the main dining hall and served a parade of exquisite Thai cuisine. Then came performances of Thai cultural dancers, followed by stunts performed by pseudo Thai kick boxers. It was quite a treat and a nice glimpse into Thai culture.

I would pass it. I heard highly about this place, but I found it very disapointing. The story about Jim Thompson is very nice, his house is nice and the service this place offers is very organized and clean, but the visit is kind of expensive and you don`t learn to much about Thailand or even see something extraordinary. I would pass...

What a wonderful wooden house full of history. The Jim Thompson House is the former home of a mysterious American silk merchant. Upon arrived we received a tour of the traditional teak house, whose pieces were moved to Bangkok from various parts of the country. Jim Thompson was credited with revitalizing Thailand's silk industry and expanding its international markets. During the tour you will see many artifacts and artwork. I enjoyed my visit here.

Exquisitely Beautiful. Elegant, full of beautiful art, the stunning quality of the teak, the gardens, the melancholy and mystery that surrounds the Thompson story all make this a must see. Excellent restaurant too. The place is well worth hanging out in even without the paid house tour. For the full flavor arrive here by the 8baht canal boat from the pier by the Golden Mount.

A Must-Visit for History Buffs. Jim Thompson apparently lived a very exciting life and was responsible for introducing Thai silk to the world. His house is a nice thing for anyone with an interest in history. The tour guides have a good command of whatever language they are guiding in. The house is nice, nothing special, but the artwork and artifacts are beautiful. The Thais love Jim Thompson and it is a nice gesture for a foreigner to pay respects as well.

Worth a Look. Came here because of Tripadvisor. But the entrance fee did include an English speaking tour guide, who did well guiding us around the house. Tour was 30 mins. Left after that. Not my cup of tea

A nice piece of history. If you are interesting in seeing a western touch to traditional Thai style and homestead, then this is the place. Guided tours are offered or you can walk around at your leisure. Its easiest accessed by travelling along the klong and getting off at the Saphan Hua Chamg Pier in the Phanfa Bridge - Water Gate stretch of the klon, and walk about 50m along the klong until you reach the house Otherwise get off at National Stadium BTS and walk +-200m down Kasem San 2 Alley

Very interesting visit. A great place to appreciate traditional Thai architecture, and art, as well as learning a little about the silk industry. A beautifully presented historical house. I enjoyed our tour with the English speaking guide and the traditional Thai dancers.

Lovely little tour . Great to see, not as in depth as I was expecting. No real history about the man, the house or the history of silk. The tour mainly consisted of showing us various rooms of the house and lacked detail regarding the history behind items or artefacts in the rooms.

Jim Thompson House & Restaurant. This is a must see..not spectacular like the Temples and Palaces but quite a bit of Thai History. They have a gift shop with their brand silk products, there is a very nice restaurant on the site..with good service and nicely air conditioned also clean restrooms. It is a bit of a pickle to get to but most Taxi drivers know the way. It is quite a little walk from the BTS however if you are young and healthy it is OK to take the BTS and walk HOWEVER they have a free shuttle that goes back and forth from the main street to the Jim Thompson House..watch for it..looks like a large 6 seater golf vehicle..a taxi of course will take you right to the property. Google the Jim Thompson House for exact BTS stop...half a day at the most for entire experience including dining at their restaurant.

Interesting and worth visiting if you have the time. . We enjoyed our tour of this very interesting house and found the guides helpful and well informed. Its well worth a visit if you can avoid the crowds. Our only gripe was that we arrived early to miss the crowds but for some reason had to wait around for nearly half an hour for our assigned tour to begin. By the time it did several coach tours had arrived that went straight in so instead of the relatively quiet tour we'd hoped for and could have received when we arrived it was crowded and noisy. Other than that we had a nice visit. If you want to miss the crowds though you'll need to start your tour before 10.00. After 10.15 it becomes a bit of a zoo because it's too small for the numbers of visitors and coach tours.

A must see. This is what Bangkok must have looked like and it's one of the few places were you can get a flavour it. A sea of serenity amid the noise and traffic fumes of modern Bangkok with a great restaurant and shop as well.

tranqulity. this house and the history its amazing, beautiful antiques, the restaurant food I highly recomended , very nice decor, the garden are ery impresive and you feel the tranquility everywhere. The boutique is very selected all silk and fancy.Love it.

A must see in Bangkok!. The Jim Thompson house an amazing oasis in Bangkok. The traditional red painted wooden houses with carefully curated furniture, art and accessories is stunning. What an amazing place to have lived! The legend and tragic sudden disappearance of Jim Thompson is still unresolved. His beautiful rich colorful silk fabrics are still revered by designers worldwide. I wanted to move into this sanctuary of old Thai houses and lush gardens. Take time to enjoy a bite or beverage after the tour at the cafe next to the koi pond and visit the retail store and gallery above. A golf cart will take you to the BTS National Stadium, but is is an easy walk with good signage to find. No need to use the pushy tuk-tuk drivers.
Old Thai houses. It is worth to go to this place if You want to experience the inside of some sort of old style Thai houses. It is a kind of oasis in Bangkok.

I'm Thai, and I love it.. My experience with Thai style building wasn't that good. But this place changed my mind. It's very well tended and originally traditional Thai. The guide was very informative and helpful. Nice atmosphere. Love it.

Nice but not as great as the reviews suggest. Not sure what I expected. House was interesting. Guide was great but I couldn't get excited by some statues and paintings. Grounds were chilled and the bar by the pond was lovely. So it was nice but not a high point of the trip.Perhaps I'm not cultured enough.

A touch of class!. Mr Thomson, an American architect born in 1906 and disappeared in 1967, set up this complex of traditional Thai houses, where he lived himself in full comfort and full glory. The guided tour is well done. Recommended!

Tranquility in noisy Bangkok. This is an old teak house where Jim Thompson lived. There are demonstrations of how silk is made and a shop selling beautiful gifts. The restaurant is good too. They do not have vegetarian meals on the menu but were happy to make a nice veggie meal for us.
Jim Thompson House. This is a quiet and secluded spot away from the general pace of Bangkok, and takes one back to a bygone era! Lovely collection and well worth visiting!

traditional thai house by the river. The Thai house of Jim Thompson's is situated in a lush compound by the river. Here visitors can go back in time and see the house's history and functionality. Available also are drinks and snacks in the garden, silk and gift shops as well as traditional dance and music shows. My favorite part of the visit however, is simply walking around the compound and learning snippets of Thai history and imagining what it would have been like to be a guest at one of Jim Thompson's renowned parties.

A must on any visit to Bangkok. Jim Thompson is credited for reviving the Thai silk industry. An American who settled in Bangkok, he built his own house out of six traditional buildings brought in from the country side - the oddest being two hundred years old. Crammed with antiques, the home is a model of style and elegance and you can imagine him entertaining the likes of Robert Kennedy and Somerset Maughan. The small garden is an oasis in bustling BK. It costs 150 baht (£3) to enter and you are taken n a tour (English and French spoken) which lasts for 40 minutes. You can then explore the out buildings and gallery at leisure. There is a Jim Thompson shop at western prices - over 30 for a printed silk tie. But the quality is outstanding. A free shuttle takes visitors to and from National Stadium skytrain station. Try a boat on a klong to go on (Pratunam 14 baht). It runs from the bottom of the garden.

Great attraction in spite of the over-exploitation. I first went to this charming house on the klong 23 years ago when it was dead simple, a bit run down and much more true to form. The restaurant, conference room, shop and general touristy over-exploitation have a purpose, to pay for the upkeep and make the foundation viable, but they all detract from the original charm and purpose of this amazing house. You get a sense that Thompson just stepped out for a bowl of noodles, when standing in his austere bedroom or at his simple writing desk. The salon is still glorious and the dining table, made of two mahjong table antiques, is set with great style. Pity about the commercialism, the crowds on any given day and the annoying tourist touts in the lane. Bangkok is sullied by this kind of parasitic preying on hapless tourists. The no-photography ban is risible, but it is easy to pinch shots without the useless guards noticing.

Our favorite place while living in Bangkok; an enchanting, easily accessible oasis!. Enchanting, easily accessible oasis in downtown Bangkok. Jim Thompson is an intriguing, complex character. It frequently seems to be the case that it takes a foreigner to understand the uniqueness of a country's art, culture, and history. The restaurant is top-notch Thai food-while adjusted to the non-Thai's taste (i.e. not tons of fish sauce). It was one of my favorite places to enjoy a meal by the peaceful koi ponds. The staff were always attentive and crazy about our young kids!! We felt like celebrities whenever we visited--which was six times in 1 1/2 years!! Each visit I learned something new. One of the experiences I miss most about Bangkok : )

Lovely house and a informative tour. Tours take you through the garden and house while explaining the cultural context of the different features of the house. Architectural features have an underlying reason that is often either historical or religious in nature. Also includes some history on Jim Thompson himself.Tour took about 45 minutes and we had a wonderful time. Note that you do have to take your shoes off before going into the house so plan to wear a pair of shoes that are easily taken off.
Really nice.. Great architecture. Very well maintained. Really relaxing to view. Immaculately built. Extremely charming.

Hidden Gem. My partner and I were very impressed with the tour and garden of this hidden gem. If you go by public transportation, there is a little shuttle that will pick you up at the station and take you directly there (otherwise a 5 minute walk).

A wonderful Tour. Our tour guide was excellent. This is a great way to learn a little about Thai culture, architecture, and history. The tour was only 150 thai baht, but it is cheaper for students under 21. This attraction is very accessible from the Skytrain.

Very nice museum. The house is very well maintained. The reception is very professional and the guide is very friendly. It has a collection of beautiful antiques. Make sure to visit the restaurant and the shop.

Beautiful oasis in downtown. Have visited the house several times. It is such a peaceful beautiful oasis in the downtown jungle of Bangkok. Washrooms are impeccably clean. Tours are available in most languages. The gardens provide enough shade to make the tour passably cool. Interesting tour with some unique objects- the mouse maze, the chamber pots for boys and for girls. The shop contains beautiful things but they are very expensive. We went to the Jim Thompson outlet instead where prices were much more reasonable.
Honeymoon . Way to expensive- beautiful to see but totally out of our price range (South Africans)R1000 for a t-shirt ... Is a little over the Top!

Amazing. We loved our visit to this museum. The guides were knowledgeable, the house was beautiful and so were the grounds. We were the youngest people there by far but we all loved it. The gift shops are beautiful as well - we both bought books and wanted to buy some lovely silks as well, but slightly too expensive for our student budgets. I would definitely recommend this museum if you're interested in silk or Thai architecture and artefacts.
Worth a visit. Finally we got to visit Jim Thompson's House. It was well worth the visit, but the guide we had rushed us through the house.

One of my favorite attractions in Bangkok. Jim Thompson was an enigmatic character, and he built an amazingly beautiful house in the classic Thai style, using vintage Thai homes as his building material. In addition be re-booted Thailand's silk industry, and the shop on-site has some very nice products to buy from his factories. I highly recommend that everyone visit this attraction. It's a short walk from the National Stadium BTS station.

Stunning example of the old Thai architecture. In a way romantic, beautiful house, rebuild by JT from 5 different ancient Thai houses. Excellent garden, calm, relaxing, with nice pond (+ turtle), fishes and exhibition of silk products. Interesting art collection. You can just sit in the garden in a hot day in a shade an enjoy the perfect ambiance.
so boring. the house itself is great in design but spending the time there is boring and there are many other places in Thailand to spend better time in before coming here

A great place to visit. Really Enjoyed the tour, the house is smaller than I expected it to be (it is six houses combined) but i was great to see Thai antiques and architecture, The gardens were lovely but again smaller than I expected. The tour guide was fabulous - she had a great sense of humour and took the mickey out of the people on the tour!

An amazing combination of architecture and amazing design. This is a special place of amazing design and composure. a brilliant respite from hectic Bangkok. Enjoy the beautiful designs and structure of old Thai houses re purposed by Thompson with amazing effect.
nice tourist attraction. its good for tourists only, can do some sight-seeing and some shopping, the restaurant is nice too!!

Surprisingly Nice. I think the fact that this is located away from most other tourist sites helps to limit the crowds here. There are free tours which are pretty nice. Only downside is that you have to lock up ALL bags for the tour in a semi-unsupervised area.Gift shop is expensive, but they have items that I didn't find elsewhere. If you can't make the trip, there are Jim Thompson House gift shops at some airports in Thailand.

An Insight Into the Silk Trade in Thailand. A fascinating house unspoilt by the high rise architecture surrounding it. Very much an experience of going back into what a home would look like in the 50s. It also went into the history of how the American, Jim Thompson, succeeded in the silk trade.
A Good Time Filler. This is basically a private residence that was turned into a historical land mark/ souvenier shop. A bit overrated in my opinion

Mixture of western and Thai culture . It's a museum expanding about Jim Thompson's life and to exhibit his antique collection. The design of the building is a mixture of thai and American culture. He was the person that introduce Thai silk to the worldWhat to see- the architecture of the buildings, antiques mainly Buddha carvings, landscaping of the garden, process of making Thai silk (real one and they are really extracting the silk in front of you), dance. With tour guides available (40mins tour) that can speak English, mandarin, Japanese and some unknown languages to me. Walking around the main house requires tourist to remove their shoes. No camera/bags allowed in the main building but lockers available. There is a cafe available. Never forget the souvenir shop Thai offer Thai silk product like clothes scarf neck tie etc.Also there is a show area for the process of making teardrop decoration. Toilet is clean. Entrance fee is 150baht

A part of the silk trade history, but there are many other places to visit in Bangkok first.. The home of the American silk industry pioneer, Jim Thompson has been turned into a museum. Other than walking around the beautifully maintained home and gardens, there is only a brief amount of information provided into the history of his life and the silk industry.If you are on a budget or haven't seen all the great temples and attractions of Bangkok, don't bother. If you have been to most of the other sites and want to spend some money on learning a little bit about this man, than visit. It's just outside the BTS station at the National Stadium so very easy to get to.The products sold and restaurant on the grounds are expensive. I didn't buy anything or eat in the restaurant.
Great Tour. The tour is very interesting and worth taking. The location is beautiful, with plenty of greenery and unique artistry. Would definitely visit again.

Better than expected. I was interested in this attraction but it was better than I expected. The house is beautiful inside and out. It's a little haven amongst the hustle and bustle of modern Bangkok.The English speaking guide (included in the ticket price) was very informative about the house, Jim Thompson, Thai history and culture.Well worth a visit.

Must visit!. Very educational and fun experience, different to usual museum. The gardens and house itself were beautiful and we enjoyed learning the history behind a lot of things such as the silk industry and Thai homes.

Informative and professional. We visited the Jim Thompson House in December 2015 (150 baht per adult) and really enjoyed our experience. We took the small ferry down the canal and got off at Sapan Hua Chang stop. That was a fun experience in itself! If you don't want to catch the ferry, you can catch the BTS to National Stadium station. It is compulsory to go around the house on a tour. The tours start every 20mins or so and are offered in English, French, Chinese, Japanese and Thai. While you wait you are allowed to walk around the grounds and visit the shop. They had a man demonstrating the way the silk threads are pulled from the cocoon as well as a woman doing traditional Thai dancing so we had plenty to do while we waited. The tour itself took about 35mins and was very informative. We learnt about the life of Jim Thompson, his business, the house and a bit of Thai culture as well. We really enjoyed the experience and if you are in the fashion or decorating industries you will find it especially interesting and relevant.
Well worth a detour. The tour around the house is well worth doing - there are frequent tours in different languages. Didn't think much to the art installation, but the silk spinning was interesting.

An oasis in the city. The Jim Thompson House is set in a beautiful garden within walking distance of the Sky Train station. A guided tour of the house is provided in several languages and then you can wander the grounds and take photographs. An interesting morning's visit.
Interesting . The house offered so many stories to tell and every part of it was interesting. You get a free tour guide while you're there who would explain everything for you.
Beautiful house. Some 45 mins rather relaxed tour of an absolutely beautiful house. The furnishings and interiors are exquisite.

Yes, worth going to.. After awhile shopping and eating and temples gets old. So wny not take a break, yet you can still shop and eat here and see something very nice from just the last century. Jim Thompson was born in Delaware in 1906. An architect and art lover by trade. He ended up in Thailand as WW2 ended. He fell in love with Thailand and collected ancient art. He created this teak house on a canal in central Bangkok in the 1950s out of old houses he bought and parts of homes, windows and doors to make a beautiful house, authentic Thai in most ways, but with a few western features, most important was the indoor toilet. The house was completed in 1959, and he disappeared in Malaysia when he went for a walk in 1967 and was never found. Entry is 150 Bhat for adults. You must check your bags in a locker. This includes purses. You can take pictures in the gardens and from the outside but NOT inside the house. Group tours leave about every 5 minutes if it is busy and last 35 min. They put about 14 max in a group. Once you get your ticket walk back and they will assign you a time by the garden. If not that busy you should get a tour right away. If busy it might be a short wait but the gardens are nice to pass your time and there is a book shop and a silk shop. They also had silk weaving demonstrations and some Thai dance to watch while you wait or after your tour.  There is a restaurant too that looked good. Take the BTS to National Stadium exit and turn left and just a block you will see a sign for a right turn to Jim Thompson house. Its probably a 3 minute walk from the station, very easy! The house went to Jims Nephew in the USA, but it was then transferred to a trust who does an excellent job of managing the property. They make money in the shops and even a Jim Thompson line of bags and clothing now!

a restful, interesting haven. we went on Sunday and there was Thai dancing, silk weaving, delightful. Sweet guide,Siriluck, spoke excellent English. Beautiful house, green garden, turtles, fish, and then the restaurant/cafe of my dreams. Felt so luxurious, as one doesn't always in Bangkok There's a shuttle bus [free] from the mainroad which is useful. And then there's the shop!
Nice story. You need to wait for the next tour in your language, no free visit.The story told by the house is interesting but not 100% relevant to Thailand
Wonderful visit. Our tour guide was great- she gave an interesting tour, blending humor and history. Afterwards, we had a drink at the bar and relaxed. It is quite the oasis in busy Bangkok!

Very serene... You get off a busy street and walk down and alley to get to JT House. You feel like your in another area all together. It's very serene/peaceful just walking around looking at the Kois and lots of plant life. A nice way to slow down in the busy, hectic world of Bangkok.

A pleasant little side excursion. Easily accessible via the train; a small oasis in the concrete jungle. Reasonably priced and a good way to spend three hours. The guides were informative and the tour duration is just the right amount of time (40 minutes). Skip the restaurant.

Historical interest. What happened to Jim Thompson? Visit the home he left behind when he disappeared into the jungle. See period Thai furnishings and gain appreciation of the beauty of Thai silk in decorating.

resting point. Great place to visit if you want to leave the big city
also historical very interesting. Good guids who know alot and many beautiful ats and furniture.
nice place but very expensive products. nice place but very expensive products. I went there twice and I think the products there are too expensive.
good enough for a down afternoon. We were in Bangkok between stops and decided to do the tour. I hoped it would be a little more informative than it was. The collection is gorgeous!
Really Interesting Visit. A great trip and the tour was very interesting. Definitely worth a visit. Even the gift shop was lovely and great quality.

Worth to visit. It is undeniable that Jim Thompson House is not a such great place if you don't know about Jim Thompson. It's a big Thailand Traditional house with a small garden. But, there is a very awesome service at the Jim Thompson House. It's TOURS with variety of languages. A number of staffs who can speak many languages very fluently will explain the details about the house, history of Jim Thompson, tradition and culture of Thailand. Each and every piece of the house has interesting history and tradition. You should see it!And there is also a book store beside the reception and you can observe the mystery of Jim Thompson, interesting Thailand Horoscope and many souvenirs.Moreover, opposite to the ticket office, there is a building. In the upper floor, there is an exhibition of GOLDEN TEAR (DROP) PROJECT. It's just a place of showing the photos and videos. May be it has some history and I don't know yet. In the ground floor, there is a store where Jim Thompson brand are sole. VERY EXPENSIVE!!!There is also a restaurant in there. Foods are pricey and taste is good. If you want to use the public transportation, I'd like to recommend to use BTS sky train and ride to the National Stadium (the last terminal of Silom Line). There is also a shuttle service from the National Stadium to Jim Thompson house and vice versa. Of course, it is FREE!.Last but not least, if you arrive Jim Thompson House, before you go with their TOUR, when you look around the house, DON't put your hands in the lake and pots. There are fishes and they BITE.

Ok, but My Least Favorite Place in Bangkok. I was under impressed after reading some of the reviews. The best part was the grounds before you went into the house museum. The guide was hard to hear with the boats passing along the waterways.

Interesting. Learning about Jim Thompson's history as the Father of Thai Silk was interesting. The guided tour of his home is lovely! The tour also can be experienced in different languages, making this attraction open to all! There were women who demonstrated how the silk is spun and they also performed a cultural dance. There is a shop for your convenience with beautiful pieces for yourself or as a gift to another.

It just ok. Seems a very rushed tour. It's also quiet expensive, given the fact your rushed though. Double the price for food and drink, given the prices of other places to visit and even a little stuffed toy is 900 bhat from the gift shop. I would recommend it.

Beautiful and secluded. You wouldn't believe you were in the centre of Bangkok. The place is so tranquil and beautiful. Plus it's got pristine artefacts and a regal atmosphere. The high volume of tourists is well managed into groups of language-specifc tours. Plus there is a fab restaurant on site - the mango smoothie I had was to die for!

Fantastic visit . Finally got a chance to get here on our second trip to Bangkok - can't believe we missed it the first time!We're not normally the type to do tours, but you don't have a choice when visiting the Jim Thompson House. We were pleasantly surprised by the woman who lead the tour (ours was in English but a variety of other languages are offered). Feels like an urban oasis, and is a way to spend part of an afternoon in Bangkok.

A really intriguing story from the CIA to the revival of Thai silk culture. I think the home of this peculiar man is really a must see: he started off as a CIA officer and a hedonist men, became collector and admirer of Thai and other Asian cultiral items (even parts of the houses were taken there as authentic building blocks!)Nice garden, a lot of explanation - you can really imagine what it must have been like!You can also ride there on the river boat - I suggest you do: another authentic experience! :)

Fascinating . I have been to bangkok many times but always failed to make it here, Mistake! With the concrete jungle surrounding you this is a fascinating place in which to gain just a small snap shot of old Thailand. It's very easy to get to and only 400 meters from the stadium MRT station. It's well priced but you do have to go on a guided tour which probably makes sense, about forty minutes but it's so fascinating. It's all original and beautifully maintained with many treasures inside so a real experience to see how these houses were constructed, decorated and lived in. There is also a very good restaurant and shop selling expensive silk products for which he is famous, perhaps a little over the top on price? However I'm glad we finally made it here and thoroughly recommend it.
Interesting. A good visit but you are forced to do a tour. I would rather explore on my own. It is interesting to visit and see what his contribution to Thailand was
A must do in Bangkok. A real Thai style house with great artworks and style. Jim Thompsons story is intriguing too. A nice place to relax late afternoon.

A paradise hidden in Bangkok. The story, the house and the guided visit are all very interesting. The cafe has amazing western cakes, in case you are craving for one. The shop offers the best quality gifts from Bangkok that we came across during our 4 days stay in this amazing city.

Interesting place to visit. This one is not huge place, but speaks lot of history. Ticket is around 150 bahts for an adult. It includes 45 mins guided tour where guide will explain everything about the house and jim thompson. Each guided tour will have group of people with a time slot. Both English and French guides are available.

A tranquil oasis . We didn't know much about Jim Thompson before our visit to the museum. We were exploring the area and it was a tranquil way to spend an hour or so. The house was beautiful and the tour was very informative. There was a restaurant and gift shop onsite. Toilet facilities were spotless.If you are in the area I would highly recommend a visit.

House Tour. I love house tours. I enjoyed seeing the interior of this home, learning about the life of Jim Thompson, and looking at the art and furnishings. And what happened to Jim Thompson? We’ll never know!Shoes and handbags are not allowed inside the house. You will be asked to remove your shoes before entering the house. Lockers are available to store bags and personal items.Photography is not permitted inside the house. However, it is possible to photograph a few rooms while outside, looking into the house. There are many photo opportunities in the lush garden.

Worth the visit . It is a very interesting place to visit especially if you are in the Siam area and want to have a break from the shopping malls! It is also very well organised with guided tours in several languages which give you some insight on silk and more in general on Thai traditions and habits.
It is worth to pay a visit. If you appreciate fine silk and like to learn a bit history of Thai silk, then you won't be disappointed. The house was beautiful, you won't see it anywhere else.

Interesting Thai traditional house. Well worth a visit. Gardens to wander in and ( with a helpful guide) a fascinating house with many stories behind it. There is also a restaurant with delicious Thai food. Allow 1 1/2 hours for the visit plus the restaurant time. The alley it is in has a free tuk tuk which will transport you to/from the main road.

A gem...beautiful and interesting!. A friend turned me on to this and I was happy he did. A great informative tour, very well organized. I learned more than I thought I would...and the gift shop is just amazing. I bought all my friends souvenirs off the street, but got myself some truly special items here. Very friendly staff.

It's good to see. Well this is good to see but i won't say it is amazing .
But yes when we really look at history , it does makes some significance

Good way to spend some time. The tour was ok way to spend a hour. It was guided and took about 40minutes. It was fun way to spend a little time but probably would not go another time. It would have been nice to spend a little bit more time to explore the building and the art inside. We had to wait about 25 minutes for the tour to begin. Tours were available in thai, english, french, japanese and maybe also in chinese (not sure for this one).

Interesting and good value for money. A friend and I were recommended this place by a local travel agent. Wasn't really expecting much but we were pleasantly surprised! It was very well organised with full guided tours offered in multiple languages. This was included in the entry price which is very reasonable, especially if you are under 22. Learnt a lot about Thai silk and Jim Thompson and brought a few small items from their store.I would definitely recommend a visit. I probably wouldn't travel all the way across Bangkok to see it but if you are in the area or staying close by then check it out for sure.

U can enjoy the guided short tour . This was the first time I visisted there, on a weekend day, with my friend. As for the access to reach there, someone might find difficult since a path from a mainroad is small one. I found a shuttle service after I reach there, so it would be easier for visiters to take it. Joining the guided tour (300tbt per person), you will see the great rooms, collected arts and firnitute by Jim Thompson. Off course you can buy the lot of silk items in the shop there. I think it is worth to visit if you have interest in silk, traditional but western concept mixed style of house and arts.
Silk house. History, beauty, gardens and silk! All wrapped up in a lovely package! The guides are very good.. Really know their history! The porcelain collection is stunning ..
Silk trip. Watch how silk was and is made, very interesting tour of his house he had some very unusual items in his home. His story is amazing.

Nice tour. I enjoyed the tour, it had a lot of interesting information on it and the building was really nice to explore on the tour.
They give you a time and appear to offer lots of tours in a variety of languages. We didn't have to wait long though for the tour at all.
A great experience. A great experience and the food at the eatery was very nice too. The merchandise is a bit pricey, but first rate.

a real mystery. Jim Thomson who worked for the OSS built this house and established the Thai silk industry went missing never to be found. The House and grounds are stunning and the tours are limited to small groups with a very good English speaking guide in our case.

Worth the trip. This is a beautiful house in a little jungle of trees and flowers right in town. The house is beautiful and filled with antiques and other treasures. There are 2 shops on the property as well as a restaurant. One shop sells Jim Thompson merchandice made from the most beautiful fabric--such colors!

Lovely and so Peaceful. Now that is a place that tourists and non tourists should visit.It is easily accessible by public transport. Take the BTS to National Stadium and you are almost on Jim Thompson's door step. It is clearly indicated from the exit of the BTS.Visit the house, see how people lived in Bangkok before the High rises came. Enjoy a nice Thai lunch in the garden restaurant and have a look inside the souvenir shop for quality silks. All at your own pace.
Interesting and lovely silk. Jim Thompson was an American who settled in Thailand after WWII. His life is an interesting story, up until he disappeared on a holiday... the silk there is fabulous.

Wonderful. It is a quick tour where you can visit a wonderful place in bangkok. It is really quiet and doesn't take a long time to make a tour. We were not supposed to visit this place but we were next to it so we gave it a try. We were really surprised and I would recommand.

Interesting tour and story of Jim Thompson.. We enjoyed this....the tour guides at the house speak very good English and are animated in telling his story and the history of the house(s). The interiors and the furniture are beautiful. Their gift shop is top notch.

Fascinating, calm & peaceful. This is an interesting place to visit. Beautiful gardens & a house stuffed full of artefacts & art.Well worth a visit & our guide was interesting & knowledgeable.Recommend the restaurant as well

Really good change of pace. This is a complete change from the bustle of Bangkok, it's a beautiful quiet complex of buildings set in a lovely garden. The price was 150bhat a person, for that you get a great guided tour round the place. I didn't think I'd find it that interesting but the guided tour made all the difference and brought it to life. The guides are friendly and really know their stuff. It takes about 45 mins for the tour though you may have to wait for a few minutes so it takes about an hour in total. The restaurant looks and smells really good, but there are street food vendors on the road outside where you can get excellent food for a fraction of the cost.

A fascinating glimpse into East-West exchange. This house is a fascinating place to visit and learn about how Thai silk was popularised in the British world. Mr Thompson himself was an interesting character with a mysterious end. Well worth a visit.

Lovely. Charming, lovely.
Mu husband grew up in BKK. When I suggested we visit Jim Thompson, he balked. But he loved it. The colonial decor inspired him to decorate our home the same way.
We had a lovely lunch there. It was peaceful, serene, lovely.
Worth it. I was sceptic about it visting this place at first,than I changed my mind.If you are interested in thai design and culture you should give it a try.

Lovely cool green oasis. The Jim Thompson House was a great way to spend an hour or so in the afternoon. I can just imagine drinking gin and tonic with Somerset Maugham and Jim Thompson in that lovely colonial style lounge room. Some exquisite tapestries.

Cheap tour on the basics of Thai architecure and lifestyle. Not far from the last stop of the BTS (skytrain) line and the popular MBK mall.
Affordable entry fee with guided tour provides the basics of Thai architecture, culture and the silk industry.

Preserve well!. It might take a while to walk from the main road to this place cuz it's in a deep Soi. They offer a shuttle to BTS as well but you might have to wait for them.Inside Jim Thompson is very nice. Covered with trees and decorated with modern looking but still preserve the Thainess. There are Thai and English guides, dont remember of they have other languages. The guide will talk us around and tell the story of Jim Thompson. It is very interesting and worth a visit cuz they really maintain Thai culture atmosphere in this place. As I am Thai, I joined the English version tour. The guide has got good English, so no worries!! It's an open air Thai house, so it would be very hot if you go in April. Well, Thailand is very all the time anyway, :(I would recommend Thais and foreigners to visit Jim Thompson. It is really cool for Thais to check this place out as well!!!

Really good. Me and my wife were staying near by and had lots of time to kill before our flight. We came to Jim Morrisons house because I have an interest in eastern architecture. Beautiful gardens with amazing fish and tortoises in the ponds. They take you on a tour of Jim Thomas's house and explain the balance between the traditional thai houses and Jim being a westerner, having fitted the normal western mod cons. I'm still not really sure who Jim Davidson is and I'm not really interested but the house and grounds are beautiful and well worth a look.

A peaceful gem. If you're done with temples and tuk tuks offering a lift somewhere then head to JTs house. A window into one man's personal residence buried in a busy, hectic, 21st century city.150 bahts gets you through the front door and a 30-40 minute guided tour. No shoes or bags allowed and definitely no selfish sticks (free lockers are provided), also no photos inside house so be warned. You are issued a time slot for tour and have time to visit shop and gardens there is also a restaurant/bar on site so you will not feel rushed and you will also not hear the traffic, horns or calls from the rest of Bangkok. I guess that's why they call it the Tranquil Garden....

Haven of peace. Beautiful teak palace - an unbelievable haven amongst the unbelievably busy streets of Bangkok. Visited at Songkran and got absolutely soaked walking past - loads of young people in pick-up trucks with huge grins on their faces!

Beautiful house but beware no A/C so it is very very hot during the 40 minute tour. Jim Thompson's house is visually beautiful and contains gorgeous artifacts and decor. This is undisputable.As others have noted, the entrance fee is B150 and a guided tour is mandatory. It is also essential to note that it is hotter in the house than outside (hard to believe but true), and there is no A/C except in one tiny room. The tour lasts for 40 minutes so be prepared. You have to check all bags so you cannot have any bottled water with you.It is an easy 10 minute walk to JT's house from the National Stadium SkyTrain station.

A little oasis in busy Bangkok. Easily reached and is surprisingly located in a very serene street in the middle of this fast-paced city. I've been to Bangkok countless of times over the past 10 years but this was the first time I actually got to visit the Jim Thompson House.Entrance fee of THB 150 per person was worth it as there is a lot to see in this place--plus we weren't expecting that the fee included an English-speaking tour guide. The estate itself is quaint yet sturdily made. A lot of love seemed to have gone into the details of creating this house and its surrounding gardens; it would definitely be a very comfortable and beautiful place to live in.The grounds also include a museum on the upper floor (which my boyfriend and I very much enjoyed; it was free to go in) as well as a gift shop and a dining place. Things looked pricey though so we didn't bother buying anything.Bangkok's grand temples define the proud history and culture of this city, yet the Jim Thompson House is well worth a glimpse into the past. I do recommend seeing it.
Review. OK to fill a day's activities. Nice gift shop, tour so-so. Can get there by public transportation, recommend sky train.

Lovely compound and beautiful gardens!. Made the trip here with low expectations, and found we stayed much longer, really enjoyed the little tour and the story behind the late owner. One can get carried away in the gift store as they have some lovely items that are very well made and reasonably priced, given the quality. The cafe is a great place for a coffee or snack. At noon, during our visit, some of the staff dressed in traditional clothes, did a little Thai dancing in the central receiving area. Free shuttle back to the BTS is also a very nice touch!

Beautiful scenery!. Tired of the hustle and bustle of MBK? Just a short walk, taxi or tuck tuck drive away there is a beautiful hidden sanctuary.. The Jim Thompson house is a great refuge from the city and the artifacts and history is really interesting. The tour takes about 30 minutes but are are welcomed to walk around and take pictures on your own. Also, the cafe is a great place to take a break over looking the pond.

Love visiting this little bit of culture . I think JTH is a must for a visit to Bangkok it is a little piece of history and quiet in the city and a wonderful place to cool off in the hot sun. 150Baht entrance fee with a guided tour is certainly a fair price. The guided tour is great and the beautiful Thai ladies that do the tours are so knowledgeable about the house and man himself. Would throughly recommend it, this was my third visit in ten years and will certainly go again.

A nice place to visit, if you are not constrained by time.. In between the packed city, Jim thompsons house is a small enjoyable place with a lot of history. The ticket includes a mandatory guide and look around the place. Good place to visit if you have some time and you are around the siam area. If you are on a packed schedule no harm in dropping this.The tours are in a group of 7-10 people, so depending on the crowd and the language you might have to wait for you time. So plan the trip accordingly.

Very interesting and beautiful. . Lovely tour that did not take very long. Beautiful shop with articles made of silk. The houses were interesting and the history very captivating. Well worth a visit and you learn all about how silk is made.

Tranquil oasis of calm, beautiful old house. The house was very tranquil and the garden beautiful, a far cry from the hustle and bustle of hectic Bangkok sightseeing. There is a lush green garden and some beautiful old teak houses to look at, full of artefacts collected by the owner. The entrance fee is B150, and you have to take a guided tour, but that is included in the price. Our guide's English was quite heavily accented and she was a bit hard to understand at times. We had lunch in the restaurant on site. Whilst fairly expensive compared with some places in Bangkok, the food was of a good quality and the staff were friendly. My watermelon shake was fantastic.The toilets are very clean and up to Western standards.

Nice visit when in Bangkok. Enjoyed free tour and history. They also showed silk worm and how they pulled thread over hot stones. Even had a couple of Dancers. Loved the architecture and stories of Jim Thompson and his disappearance.

Interesting place to fill in a hour or two. This place was enjoyable and interesting with an English speaking guide - the guide is compulsory. It is a bit of an oasis in the middle of Bangkok and is worth having a quick look.

Very interesting. This is peaceful oasis right in the middle of downtown Bangkok. It is a beautiful home and a very interesting tour. If you are interested in architecture, this is a must see. It is also very interesting to learn about Jim Thompson's impact on the Thai silk trade.

Beautiful home turned into museum. The home of Jim Thompson contains numerous antiques and interesting pieces. I noticed that multi-lingual guides led tour groups. The store had a lot of items but were too pricey.

Paradise in the city. A small patch of paradise in the heart of Bangkok City, enjoy an informative tour around the beautiful teak house, then enjoy a cold drink or maybe purchase some beautiful Thai silk products from the gift shop. Well worth a look.

Nice but overrated. I have mixed feelings about this place. Good if you have an hour or so to spend but it's not fair to list this place in "top 10 to see" list. I appreciate that Thais preserve the place so well and take very good care of it. Also, it's interesting to see how rich used to live around mid 1900's in Thailand. Mr Thompson's personal collection of antiques was beautiful.However, I'd appreciate more info about Mr Thompson himself, processing silk etc. The tour was too short for my liking.Gift shop had some nice items but the material used in majority of the objects was not even silk and the prices were ridiculously high. I had lemongrass drink in their cafe which was basically nothing but water with lots of ice and slight lemongrass aroma.

A Must for Art and Design Lovers. Wonderful succinct tour of the house and gardens of Jim Thompson. Gorgeous architecture customized to suit his tastes and lifestyle. Filled with beautiful objects, some precious and some humble, but all absolutely perfect in this space. The shops are in various locations and there is one here too, also a restaurant overlooking the picturesque koi pond.

An OK venue but not among my top Bangkok favourites. First time I have felt that I have been ripped off as a tourist in Bangkok. It all seemed to be about money here, from the cattle herding of guests and allocating them rigid times for tours thru to mentioning the gift shop during said tour then charging crazy prices just for a water at the end. It was a pleasant house but not worth the effort of travelling there from Rambutri
Do not miss this!. A guided tour is compulsory, but worth it as it is very informaive and allows one to see the place without interferring crowds. Stroll through the gardens after the 30 min tour.

Great for tour and family. I like taking friends and tours to this place. There are guides in languages. It is relaxing house amd good to stop by for Lunch. My favourite part is having a great lunch after touring around the house. (always beautiful taste)

Elegance and Mystery in the middle of Bangkok.. Jim Thompson house was elegant and historical located in the middle of busy, bustling Bangkok. This home and it's grounds can only be imagined back in the day when it wasn't surrounded by skyscrapers and the unending of variety of apartments, businesses, homes and the tangled wired that links them all together. The home is made of teak and holds many beautiful ancient artifacts from many places in the orient. The architecture is elegant and purposeful, from the entrance to the commode to the crystal chandeliers hanging above. A must see in Bangkok!

Beautiful. Great place to go for lunch. Slightly more pricey than the usual thai establishments but it is still very reasonable and the beautiful ambience makes it worth while. I make sure I go for lunch at least once every time I visit bangkok

Interesting place. Quite an interesting house. Our guide was a real character and had lots of great stories to tell as she led us through, as well as a wicked evil eye for those not paying attention during her talk! Gift shop/store has absolutely stunning silks and very high prices. The cafe there has lovely tasty things. Don't miss the sticky rice and mango. Mmmm

Good guided tour but loved the gift shop!. The roughly 40 minute guided tour was well done- hard at times to understand the guide. The highlight for us (went to the shop twice) was the gift shop. Yes, it was very expensive but I thought they had high quality goods. Bought Holiday presents there.

lovely historical house. Great historical wooden house. The guide we had did her job but that was it. The house itself is wonderful and for a moment I forgot I was in the urban area of Bangkok.Tip:Visit the canal at the rear of the house.There is a street vendor cooking food on the canal and you can eat affordable Thai food thereTip 2:Arrive to the museum via canal boat.For those that would like more information there is a book in English about the curious disappearance of Jim Thompson at Asia Books
Very beautiful restaurant. Food is fair but decoration and goods from Jim Thompson made the visit unforgettable. Highly recommended.

nice historical sight but really jsut a shop. tucked away in the centre of bangkok, visiting this old house is like a trip through time. It is interesting and worth a visit if you have seen everything else in Bangkok but other than an interesting old house it really is just an elaborate shop.

Worth the visit. This is a wonderful place to visit. It is a typical Thai house. It belonged to Jim Thompson and has now been donated to Thailand. They have guides to take you around the house which is very useful. The restaurant is also very nice. We ate there in November and enjoyed the Thai cuisine. At different time throughout the day they have dancers, demonstrations of silk weaving.

Very interesting!. Very interesting museum in the heart of Bangkok. Learn a whole part of Bangkok/Thailand's silk market raise. Mix of culture, love, techniques and arts.Also good as you can combine your visit with the use of a boat on the klongs to get to your next destination.

You wont be disappointed. If you have a couple of hours it's worth the visit. A beautiful traditional Thai home and gardens with knowledgeable guides show show you around. I was very impressed with Jim Thompson's life story and home. Definitely glad we wentThere is a restaurant and shop on site and a complimentary shuttle serve to the main road.

Good tour and definitely worth a look. Interesting tour in an excellent hidden home near siam central. Easy to get too and has some unique and wonderful architecture. Very knowledgable staff on the tour and will also learn a lot about the thai way of living

Well worth a visit. really worth taking an hour or two to visit here. Beautiful thai buildings and the guides are knowledgeable with very good english. Take time to stop and have a look around, a great break fromthe hustle and bustle of BKKAdmission includes a 40 minute guided tour.
History of the countryside in town. Interesting view of the living in a original Thai house, beautifully decorated with a splendid garden. Extensive guided tour

Very interesting museum. Lovely place, feeling cool in hot And humid Bangkok. Very interesting museum with beautiful furniture And decorative items. We had a lovely guide with a wonderful sense of humour. Is very much worth a visit. Good clean toilets And a Nice restaurant.

Easy to get to and worth the visit. We decided to go here with friends and asked for directions at our hotel. We took the Sky Train which was a reasonable price and then walked a short distance following the signs. We found the house to be very interesting and I guide gave a very good tour in English. Even injecting a bit of humor while giving a great look into Thailand during Jim Thompson's era. Also you can't help speculating on the mystery of his disappearance.
Interesting. A beautiful place and has interesting stories. But not quite sure what the draw is. Proceeds from ticket sales goes to local charities, that's the plus.

Good, but not great. . I had a quiet and enjoyable visit here, but frankly I think some people may find it simply boring.It is a reconditioned set of 6 teak houses which Jim Thompson ( an American who reinvigorated the Thai silk industry in the 1960's) lived in. It houses his extensive personal antique collection from Thailand and Myanmar. It is a large personal collection but in terms of a museum, very small.There are compulsory 40 minutes guided tours in a variety of language am. Our guide spoke excellent English and I only had to wait 10 mins for my tour from when I arrived. No photos inside but you can take at leisure in the surrounding gardens. Cost was 150 Baht which is on the upper end for a tour like this. Gift shop in site as well as a restaurant. There were demonstration of silk spinning and weaving when I visited.

Great Tour!. Sometimes attractions like this can be more hype than substance. For a little house down a little ally, this place has a ton of culture, a great historic feel, and a supporting cast who work hard to make the experience worthwhile. The restaurant on-site and the gift shop are not bad either.

Nice and interesting. We enjoyed our visit there, it's really nice and peaceful. You need to do it with a guide (price included in the ticket), they have it both in french and english. We also had lunch here, who was not cheap but good.
Proud History. The time spent at Jim Thompson house is great and gives you a view into the wonderful silk story of Thailand. In addition, the classic Thai buildings on the site are interesting.

An amazing art gallery and a snap-shot of 1950s Thailand. The Jim Thompson house is an oasis in Bangkok. Beautiful art, wonderful gardens and the quirky aesthetic of a US ex-soldier turned silk baron, it features some of the most impressive Thai art in town. Highly recommended.

A lovely piece of history. I loved my visit to the Jim Thompson house. The lush green gardens and the house are truly beautiful in their simplicity. The house boasts some exquisite artworks and tapestries collected from within Thailand and South East Asia. The story of Jim Thompson is fascinating. The shop has a collection of gorgeous silk and fabric.

Informative. I was amused that one can learn a lot in the Jim Thompson house not only about him, but his contribution to Thailand. One can learn about different thai structures and thai silk. You will also enjoy the area. It has a display center and museum and a shop for authentic thai silk. :)

Educational indeed. This house is set at the end of a quiet alley near the National Stadium Metrp stop. Well worth the visit. My guide had excellent English and answered all the questions very well. With the few pennies it cost to visit.

Worth Visiting If you are into arts and history. I enjoyed visiting museum and historical place, and so visiting this place is a must for me. You will learn a lot of things, and will understand more the culture and tradition of a certain country by visiting place like this. The entrance fee is 150 baht with guided tour. Its an old house with antics and other art works from old centuries. You will be amazed by Jim Thompson collections, his passion for silk industry and his love for Thai people. Just wondering what really happened to him in that wilderness desert in Malaysia.

A Bangkok experience not to be missed.. Easy to reach from the Sky Train. This is a well kept example of traditional Thai houses adapted to provide the comforts enjoyed by expats in the early to mid 1900s; well worth a visit. The on site restaurant is excellent too.

Really interesting!. My friends and I found this totally by accident while traveling through Bangkok. We went to visit on very little information, and it turned out to be one of the most interesting places in Bangkok. The story of Jim Thompson is very cool and mysterious. His house his beautiful -- I'd definitely but a bid in should it ever go up for sale! We really enjoyed the tour that was given, and the guides know the history of Jim and the house inside and out. Would highly recommend if you have a bit of time to kill!

Interesting Complex. It will take between 90 minutes and 2 hours to see this entire complex, including the guided tour which is about 40 minutes. There's a gift shop (which is rather pricey) and a restaurant on site. If you have a few hours, it's worth visiting. The grounds are beautiful, the story interesting and buildings and contents historically significant.
Lovely way to spend an afternoon in Bangkok. Lovely way to spend an afternoon in Bangkok, The house is beautiful and there is some lovely art works etc in the house.
Enormously expensive. Although this attraction partly presents as an historical interest, the prices are extraordinarily high.
