Beautiful and interesting. Beautiful and interesting place. I learned a lot about Bangkok's history and the influence of silk trade. The house is beautiful and if you appreciate art, it's a must visit. The souvenirs at the gift shop were pricey under BKK's standards, but definitely tasteful.

Not all that. I was expecting much more from this. It was just a short tour through an old house, and saw part of the man's collection. I expected a lot more history and more written explanation of things. As something to kill an hour and a half its not bad, for 150thb (if you're over a certain height), i probably wouldn't recommend bringing children there unless they have previous enthusiasm to specifically go there. For the entry price you get a guided tour (i know they do english tours, however not sure for other languages), who explains various things within the house and rooms.

Good if you have 90 min to kill.... A nice house, beautiful if simple garden.There was a restaurant which appeared to serve quality dishes, though we did not partake (having gorged ourselves on street eats).The tour guides are well versed and able to answer many questions.All in all, place is just smaller than I'd like and the content (architectural, historical, and that pertaining to Thai silk - history, distribution, garment production) was lacking.That said, there were some lovely Thai dancers as well as silk spinning exhibitions in the main courtyard.
Great oasis, interesting story. Lovely place and a good, fairly short (35 minutes) tour of the place with an interesting back story about Jim Thompson

Interesting Site. A visit to Jim Thompson House, is intetesting...informative, and well organized...learn about the man that created the silk market in Bangkok...and mysteriously disappeared, on a trip to Malaysia...recommend...

Stunning beautiful Place to visit!. The house is tastefully done and the garden is beautiful. One of the best garden I ever seen in Bangkok. The area around the house itself has been improved a lot and now have large parking space. The retail shop also great. Only the restaurant that I think it could be better.
Anot really impressive. Maybe it was my tour guide but I'm really not sure why anyone goes to this attraction. I found it to be boring and not the price of admission.
Impressive. We have lieve our sgvist to the house. The Guinee Tour was worth the money. The restaurant is a Nice placenta have a lunch while the store Hans annexerend selectief of Jim Tompsonroducts.
Interesting and worth the time. Fascinating story and architecture -stopped in the cafe as well and relaxed in the tranquil setting. (not many in Bangkok).

Beautiful House, Great Tour. We toured the Jim Thompson House because it was literally next to our hotel (Siam@Siam--which was awesome, by the way). We were not sure what it was but thought it looked nice. The tours were in English or French, and they seemed to have multiple groups timed throughout the property. Well-rehearsed information, lovely house. If you enjoy antiques, architecture or Thai culture, you will enjoy this tour. The gift shop was a bit pricey, so we bought some nice postcards to frame. If you have 40 minutes to spare, it's worth the 150 Baht to check it out.

Beautiful house, don't miss it. The house is very well preserved, beautiful and interesting how was the living at the time. Take the guided tour and don't forget to walk in the the beautiful garden.They don't allow you to take pictures inside the house, we bought the book instead.

Nice oasis in the middle of busy Bangkok. This was a nice, calm oasis where visitors get to not only learn about silk and it's creation, but you get to see live demonstrations. There tour and information about Jim Thompson and his impact on the Thai silk trade was very interesting. I have visiting the House during both my trips to Bangkok and will probably visit again - I enjoyed the restaurant and gift shop during repeat visits.
nice place, over priced clothing. beautiful home just in the city center. beautiful rooms and good guidance. clothes are beautiful but too too expensive. this is a minus

Interesting facet of history. Jim Thompson's House is Thailand's ode to its Silk revivalist! The house was built by Jim Thompson who unfortunately disappeared in the late '70s and has since been preserved and converted into a heritage tour of sorts by Thailand tourism. Full credits to them for maintaining the house as is, preserving the artefacts (which are a lot) and glorifying each aspect of Mr. Thompson's existence in their culture and history. The house in itself is very vast, very Thai in architecture and open to tourists 6 days a week. There's a guided tour every 10 minutes with an English or French speaking guide, who will take you to the important parts of the house and explain in detail its importance. Every nook of the house has a part of Thai culture embedded in it. It's fascinating because Mr. Thompson himself was not Thai but adopted the land as his when he visited. There's a Thompson boutique that sells amazing silk bags and clothes for a slightly steep price and a Thompson restaurant on the premises that serves good food and alcohol at decent rates! Visit it if you're interested in seeing preserved history in its untouched form. Worth your while and a touristy checklist when in Bangkok.

Commercial tourist trap-ish sight. This is a commercial tourist gift shop type stop. Worth a look and to check in on some modern history I suppose. Go by Klong Boat to make it a cheap and very interesting outing.khlongsaensaep dot com

Beautiful house, good museum. The house is very well preserved, beautiful and interesting how was the living at the time. The guidance was below average, pleasant but speeding the tour without time to appreciate the details, as was the annoyingly bumping with the next two groups. The prohibition of taking pictures inside the house is really so 20th century, too anachronistic.
Take the guided tour. Worth it to take the guided tour, you'll understand a lot about Bangkok culture and the story of the house.

History and Beautiful Products at a Lovely location. The historic Jim Thomson House is both a sales outlet for the famous silk product range as well as being a wonderful "museum" providing a glimpse of the lifestyle in Bangkok in the early 20th century. Wandering around the gardens is also very pleasant (although it can be very warm to hot depending on time of year). I first saw this property only a few years ago even though I have lived in Bangkok for over 20 years. I had heard of it before, but had not visited, so I was very pleasantly surprised when I got there. It is certainly worth a visit, and perhaps pick up a nice silk product while you are there. I bought a silk scarf for my mother, and a few other things for family members overseas - not expensive either.

enjoyed the story, and the house tour. For 150 BHT you can tour Jim Thompson's house. House is a great example of a Thai style teak house, built in a grand manor. The mystery of Jim Thompson, the artwork and history of the house make this a well spent 150 BHT.

Mixed views. I liked it, but my girlfriend was a bit bored. She thought it was a bit insignificant compared to all the temples. I liked seeing some period architecture, and the tour was insightful. Shop is ludicrously over priced, but of course you don't have to buy!

Very well presented attraction with amazing historical facts.. The House is a great attraction and of significant historical relevance. Jim Thomson, American, was originally stationed in Asia with the infamous OSS (CIA) for World War II missions and fell in love with Thailand so stayed and established a traditional Thai silk industry. He built his house on the river in the Muslim Quarter to grow silkworms and produce world class silk. The house and interior are fabulous with highly knowledgeable guides who explain the stories of him and the history. Best accessed by BTS from Siam to National Stadium and 5 mins walk.

Visit if you have lot of time. Visit this place if you lot of time to spend in Bangkok. However, it gives a sneak peek to thai culture and architecture. We went with our kid who wasnt to interested in exploring the house. Tour takes about an hour. Expensive in comparison to other spots in Bangkok.
Amazing. A must visit when in the area. You must also visit their store which is a very short stroll from the subway.

Really interesting tour, good food. We came here on the last day of our time in Bangkok, this is a really interesting tour, all about the house and the silk industry, particularly good if you have an interest in architecture or decor. The food in the restaurant was really good and tasty, and the atmosphere lovely, though it is very busy and hard to get a seat. The only one problem we had was getting there, we ended up in the Jim Thompson museum first which was also interesting with some beautiful products for sale, only very pricey!

Jim Thompson house Museum and Restraunt. Great place to visit, won't take all day to visit the Museum as its a guided tour, no photos as I think they make money on postcards and guides. The restraunt is fantastic but not buy always seems to be quiet when ever I have visited and some nights they have Thai dancers which make the experience special. Nice place for a intimate dinner very good food probably designed for a western taste.

Quick tour of expat culture. Joining the tour is the only option, which his a pity as the artwork is interesting, but you don't really have time to look at it properly and you can't take photos inside. The gardens are really amazing. The shop seemed a little cheaper than the airport, but I guess that is to be expected. It's a short visit, but well worth it if you like this sort of thing.

Unique Attraction in the Middle of Bangkok. More than anything the story about Jim and how he came to love Thailand was the most interesting part of the visit. The buildings were unique compared to much of what we had seen, and the grounds were well maintained also. We ate at the restaurant, and the food was actually very good (and coming from someone who doesn't generally like food at tourist spots). I recommend this to people visiting Bangkok for something different, but probably not a place to bring kids. The location is somewhat hidden, but there were a couple of signs hanging on nearby street poles to help guide you there. And, there is a shuttle from the main road, that takes you the two blocks to the property. You can probably also catch the public transport as it is right along the main road where the cab dropped us off, if you don't mind walking a third of a mile roughly.

A beautiful place to visit and eat at too!. The history of Jim Thompson is really quite interesting...his home here is lovely and the gardens are a delight to visit. There is a shop here to buy silk products and wonderful food to eat at the restaurant.

Beautiful Silks. Jim Thompson resurrected the silk industry in Thailand- he was an American.The house is beautiful, heavy woods, many antiques and shows his appreciation for the art and craft of his time.This is a great place to buy his silk goods- many tshirts,scarves, fine silk clothing, etc. lots of Jim Thompson stores around town as well although this has a great selection.
Interesting. Well worth a visit. Lovely relaxed atmosphere in the site. Beautiful woodwork. Friendly guides. Nice restaurant. Silk material seemed a bit pricey.

Stunning House.. This is a must see in Bangkok. I would love to live in this house. It is beautifully furnished and offers a range of buildings and styles. It is discreetly tucked away down a side road, but must taxi and tuk tuk drivers know of it. The staff are very helpful and knowledgeable, and the shop is a challenge to your credit card!

Step back in time. Had a few hours to kill, went on a drizzly afternoon. So glad we did. Easy to get to. Reasonabley priced 45 minute tour available in several languages giving overview on Jim Thompson, architecture and gardens. Pretty outdoor space with minor events taking place - 3 young costumed thai dancers, gentleman spoiling/spinning silk. Lovely shop with silk scarves, dresses, shirts, etc. not inexpensive but nice quality. All in all , a break from hustle and bustle, temples, etc. Allow 2 hours, plenty of time unless you want to eat at restaurant.

no interest whatsoever. boring. Nothing to visit really. You will visit a house of Jim Thomson who is not even a famous figure and there is nothing to see nor anything interesting in that visit. Save yourself a day and do something else more interesting than this boring visit.
Beautiful traditional wooden house. A nice wooden house in typical Thai style that used to belong to Jim Thompson, the King of Thai silk who has dissapeared on a trip to Malaysia...

Beautiful and interesting place. The 150 baht entrance fee is reasonable as it includes a guided tour. The grounds are beautiful and the house itself is crammed with artefacts. The tour is interesting and gives a good introduction into Thai culture as the guide will inform you what is in keeping with Thai tradition and what is a peculiarity due to the fact it is a Thai house built by an American. The restaurant is pretty pricy but if you're not on a budget then it's worth a visit as the food is delicious.

Excellent selection, excellent assistance. We hit the airport outlet at Suvarnabhumi where we thrived and shopped for friends and family in Europe. Most noticeable was the staff and their true smiling commitment. Having traveled Asia extensively this little shopping experience was fun and unique. Thank you!
Good moment in nice place.... We went many time in this place ( the first time was 35 years ago...) each time it ´s réal pleasure....Good team...good work .thank´s Mister Jim!!!!Paulo.

Very pretty gardens and unique Thai architecture. Price of admission includes guided tour through the house. Gardens are very nice to walk through and inside the house is also very neat. Large and very interesting collection of old Buddha statues. Total time needed for visit is about 2 hours.

Beautiful Place. Actually 150 Baht for visiting the House with Guide. The Guide explains a lot and is very kind. It is its price worth! Takes about one hour. There is a good Restaurant, too. But it is quite expencive.

Must see architectural Masterpiece. Located in nice quiet alley within walking distance from BTS station National Stadium.Fee is 150THB and your go on guided tour of the house. It is nice house done very well with all Asian accents, a lot of paintings and old collector items. On the grounds there is souvenir shop and bar with restaurant.

Worth the visit. An interesting venue from recent history. We enjoyed the short tour of the joined traditional homes, the Thai traditional dances, and the ongoing demonstration of silkworm harvesting and spinning.

Beautiful quite place for in busy Bangkok. We really like the visit. A beautiful house with garden and fascinating story of the owner. Walking around you forget you are in the middle if a busy and big city. The kids liked it so much, they now want to live in a house like this.

Excellent museum . Really well run and obviously well-managed. Good tour, nice restaurant and museum shop. The house is beautiful and so nice to visit. 150 baht for a tour. Nice products in the shop, at a price, but quality costs.

A delightful glimpse into this time capsual from the King of Thai Silk Jim Thompson. A breath of fresh air in the heart of Bangkok, loved seeing this delightful glimpse into the life and times of the King of Thai Silk Jim Thompson, the famous expat American business man who revived the dying art of silk weaving right at the golden age of glamour of the 50s and 60s. There some amazing art pieces that rightly now belong to the people of Thailand. The immaculately keep old house and gardens are now a treasure for open for all international travellers and Thai locals. Loved seeing all the Indochina treasures so beautifully displayed in the well preserved long houses that Jim Thompson brought from the region to create a wonderful chic Indochina inspired apartment house artfully merging east and west!

I JUST LOVE IT!!!. First time I been there and just fell in love with it! Definitely worth a while and probably will go again. Oh and the tour guides are so friendly and always wearing a smile on their faces.
It's worth seeing.. Jim Thompson's story is fascinating. The architecture is very interesting, but the biggest thing is his art collection is staggering and well worth checking out.
Beautiful. So happy I went here, love the architecture and all the different details of the house.Definitely worth going to see!!!

Interesting Place to Visit. Jim Thompson's House and Museum is a must visit for those who appreciate silks and weaves. In this place you can visit / tour Jim Thomson's house, a souvenir shop and get a brief glimpse of how silk is woven. There is a small café that provide short eats & drinks.Timing: 9 am to 6 pm all days of the week.The tickets cost for Adults is 150 Baht & 100 baht for students.The ticket cost is for entry and a guided tour of the house and museum. The place is very beautiful and well laid out. The house or the museum per se was nothing spectacular. This is definitely not a "must-see" if have limited time, according to me.It is a homage Mr Jim Thomson for putting Thai Silk industry on the world map and from that perspective, it is an interesting place to visit.
Home of the mysterious Jim Thompson. Very entertain as I love any Thai artefact's, especially art and architecture----very interesting and fun on a rain gloomy day.

A Taste of Thailand. Bangkok is a fantastic place to shop but this is one of those rare places where you can experience the true Thai culture. The tour around the house is available in different languages and definitely worth it. Apparently you can also reach it by water taxi.

Real Cocoon. Remarkable place. One could see that good old Jim was man of essence, indeed. You will be pleasantly surprise by this jewel project in this sometimes chaotic city. Definitely a must for all those looking for serendipity and escape to something different on the hot BKK afternoon. And yes add to that Tom Kha Gai (chicken coconut soup) from nearby restaurant. Nice...

Nice oasis hidden in bustling Bangkok. The house is a nice oasis hidden in bustling Bangkok, but I thought the paid tour was just okay. I don’t think I left there fully understanding Jim Thompson’s significance/importance. If you are on a tight budget, I might consider skipping the tour and just walking around the garden yourself.
Guided visit very good. Travelled here by water taxi . Guided tour well worth the money and the food in the restaurant is very good

A glimpse of times gone by. The story of Jim Thompson is well known and documented. Advertisements and brochures can be found displayed in most Bangkok hotels which cater for tourists.Like many others, I was attracted by them and visited. The house and compound are located down a small road and is easy to reach by taxi.Built mainly of teak, the buildings are indeed good to admire, the construction methods of a bygone age.As one would expect there are many photographs and artefacts which belonged to the man himself and the era in general. Those persons interested in those historic visuals will certainly appreciate them.Others, more attracted to the silk products on display and being offered for sale will not be disappointed although the priced marked are on the high side of normal retail.Overall, it is worth a visit .

Interesting story & architecture in the middle of Bangkok. After our tour of the house you become more curious as to what happened to Jim Thompson! Lovely setting for a quick afternoon tour. The gift shop with all of the silk is great...largest and best variety here, but no cheaper than buying it elsewhere.

Go for the restaurant and the house. The restaurant is tops and increased my regard for Thai food. The house is so beautiful. The gorgeous artifacts on display are museum-worthy, but alas, aren't labeled or dated. The tour was rushed with no time for questions and no explanation of the art. The gift shop offerings are mostly cotton, very little silk. You'll do better finding silk in the street markets. I gave this a 3 rating because there is no explanation of artifacts or the silk making process.

very interesting tour and must see bit of Thailand silk history. very interesting tour and must see bit of Thailand silk history. its in nice cool garden area and is well priced for the budget minded . Restaurant is a bit more expensive but food was great and i would eat there again

Beautiful residence with guided tour. Lovely old house with wonderful collection of antiques. Tour guides walk you through the house sharing interesting tidbits of information. Unfortunately most are repetitions of what's said in guidebooks and on websites. I'd never heard of Jim Thompson before, but after reading and hearing his story four+ times, I think I could be guide Just kidding. The ladies do a nice job, and there's the added bonus of getting tours in English, French, Mandarin. I even heard a guide in Italian.The tour itself takes about 30 minutes after which you can walk around, visit the gift shop and eat at the cafe. It's an easy way to pass a couple hours.Note: No photos allowed in the house.

Small and strict. This place costs quite a bit to tour, I think it was 500 Bhatt each. Also, you can not explore it on your own, you are required to sign up for a tour, at a particular time. The tour however, was good and they have many different language options. The whole tour took about 30 minutes and we only waited about 20 minutes before it started. It is an interesting history of Thai silk but I think I could have passed it up, for something else. Also, this place is a bit tucked into the middle of an ally/street that is next to the shopping center MBK.

An American working in Bangkok with a mysterious ending.. A look at the way an American business man and CIA agent lived . Elegant and casual setting... with a fabulous shop with high-end silk and clothing items to buy.

One of a must see in Bangkok,Thailand. There are three parts of building,museum,gallery and restuarent.The museum is great to see how Jim Thomson's living and history of thai silk in his hand.Tour guide is fantastic! Gallery and showroom are in well presented and also the restuarent where you should not miss.

Must see!. It's a must see in Bangkok. Their items in the boutique are really expensive but definitely of good quality. Touring the house was like a breath of fresh air, well in a way it's a haven in the middle of a bustling metro.

Beautiful Thai wooden house. The house was so beautiful and interesting. Before you get into the ticket checking point, they show you how to make silk. The story of Mr. Jim who spent live in Thailand and has gone missing was so interesting. Silk products were very high end.

Not a must see. . My family was visiting me in Bangkok and of course they wanted to do some touristy things while in the city. A tour of Jim Thompson's house was on that list of things to do. The information given on the tour wasn't intersting and the house itself isn't anything out of the ordinary. A definite skip if you are short on time while traveling. If you are interested in purchasing Jim Thompson quality silk gifts, there is an outlet shop that you can find directions to online located near one of the BTS Sky train stations, which will save you a lot of money and has a wider selection of goods.
Take a trip to the early 1900's. This is a wonderful example of old Thai traditional architecture. It is a sad story of a wonderful man that has remained alive through his home and textile business.
must see. The history of Jim Thompson is amazing and ultimately tragic. The house gives on the flavor of his story and his industry in a foreign land. The setting is charming
Nice typical thai housing visit. Visit of the house is nice, the rooms are furnished as they were by Jim Thomson's time and guided tour is available in English and French.

Great historical value, excellent guides and experience . The Jim Thompson house is located near the National Stadium BTS, just a 5 to 10 minute walk away. The museum runs on guided tours only, which is perhaps the better way to take in the different sights and heritage of the various pieces. The guides are friendly and knowledgeable, ensuring that you will leave the house with a better understanding of Thailand and the silk industry. Definitely recommended to stop by if you have time to spare in busy Bangkok.

Typical Asian fare. Before I didn't know who Jim Thompson was. Now I still don't know, but I've seen his house, which is filled with a bunch Asian art. As someone who has traveled extensively throughout Asia, this didn't really impress me.
Nice. This is first time we go there after many friend is recommend.It very nice place and the fabric sale high quality.
Fun for Jim Thompson Fans. It's interesting if you like Jim Thompson products. There's a tour you can take for a minimal fee. Also a store there if you want to pick up some items.
What a sight. Must attraction for the family with children or couples without. I have been in Thailand for 5 years and saw this a while ago but I cannot say enough.

Iconic historical house with great restaurant and gift shop. This was my second trip to the house to show a friend. The restaurant is great if you go and the shop actually is not as good as their store in the Siam Shopping Center. The first time i bought a Jim Thompson silk shirt I shocked at the sticker price and bought one. Later I noticed the amazing craftsmanship plus it is a comfortable and lightweight shirt for hot and humid climates. My next trip back I bought five more. I think I own about 12 shirts now counting the two I bought this last trip. I am really sold on their clothes. The house tour is great. You can sometimes see Thai dancers there in costume. The history and mystery of Jim Thompson is captivating.

Surprising little gem.. Fascinating. I had no idea who Jim Thompson was - and now like everyone else I am intrigued about how he simply disappeared without trace in 1967.Guided tour was in English (you have to do a tour, it's included in the entry price).They provide a free tuktuk shuttle service between the museum and the local Sky Train station (National Stadium station).The Cafe adjacent is good for a cup of tea before you leave.
Tourist trap . Not really my thing so may be doing an injustice but thought it just a tourist trap with not much to see and high priced goods aimed at the tourist

Beautiful!. Great place to visit to learn about Jim Thompson's role in reviving the Thai silk industry. Unfortunately, there are no pictures allowed inside of the home. High-end gift shop is very nice. Free shuttle to the main road.

Special. Have been to Bangkok a few times and this has been on the bucket list. Cost 150bht per person. Be prepared to wait for your tour guide. Ours took 25 mins but it is worth it. Loved the history art and amazing story. If you love the culture of this country this is worth every moment.

good idea. I read about this place in Internet and when i arrived to bangkok i was so excited to visit this place.it is now a museum in Bangkok.It is a complex of various old Thai structures that the American businessman Jim Thompson collected from all parts of Thailand in the 1950s and 1960s. It is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Thailand.I had not a clue about who Jim Thompson was or why he was important to Thailandbut it worth visit if you need now about Thai handcraft.

A calming experience in the middle of the city. The Jim Thompson House is a complex of Thai structures full of Asian art. The guided tour is excellent and the tour guide knew her subject which is for a small fee. The grounds are beautifully kept with many photo opportunities but you are unable to take photos inside the house. There is a shop selling silk items and a museum. There is a restaurant on site with very good prices. Walking up to the museum a free shuttle stopped and asked if we were visiting the museum. When we confirmed this he asked us to climb aboard which in my opinion is service above the norm.

Historcial/Antique Interests.. A friend gave me the book on Jim Thompsom before I visited so I knew a bit about him. The tour does not take long and is not expensive. The garden and the antique houses and contents provide photo opportunities. There is a shop selling various silks and other souvenirs, most of which I think is overpriced. You are not going to get good silk cheap at any time but I think other items are overpriced because of the association with Jim Thompson. They used to have an outlet selling 'end of line' items over on Sathorn Street, I think, but not sure if it is still there. The house Museum is a short walk from National Stadium BTS station or from the MBK shopping centre.

Mystery to the disappearance of Jim Thomson. Guided Tour is advised. The tour guides are well-versed in english, chinese & thai. The tour is about an hour. There also free tuk tuk shuttle service to get you to the nearest BTS. For the souvenirs shop, Suvarnabhumi airport sell cheaper but only on certain products. Though i bought a lovely coin pouch from the original shop. Not sure whether the airport carry it.

Short visit at Jim Thompson House. In the middle of Bangkok one can visit the Jim Thompson house. We took the small tour which was perfectly well organised and gives good insights into how this house was built, what behind Jim Thompson is and how the Thai Silk industry profited from him.
Nice but nothing spectacular. This house is a portion of history of the thai. Better go here if you have spare time because Its out of the way to most of the attraction.

Great insight to anyone wanting to learn about the Thai silk industry. . Really nice day out. My guide was lovely and spoke very good English. She was very informative and answered all our questions about the place.

Lush setting for a fantastic story. I love the story about Jim Thompson, including did also seek to find his place in the Cameron Highlands... if you are in Bangkok, take the time to visit, its easy accessible and has some history about an american in Thailand... and what he meant to the silk business. Its a beautiful Lanna Architecture antique house collection in the hear of busy Bangkok. You can walk through it within an hour and end for lunch of drink at the restaurant. This sunday I only went there for food after a stroll at the Bangkok Arts and Cultural Centre. Its that nice, just to enjoy! Touristy, but yet fresh. Next to the Klong if you fancy a boat ride on the canal...

I had no idea.... I had not a clue about who Jim Thompson was or why he was important to Thailand, but my husband read the reviews and it seemed like something we needed to see. I'm so glad we visited the Jim Thompson House! They have a tour of the house, which is beautiful, it was very interesting to learn about Mr. Jim Thompson, his impact on the silk market in Thailand, and his mysterious disappearance...... Go check out the house if you have time. It was worth it!

Very interesting and informative. I like who this place and mini tour caught me by surprised when the tour guide(fluent in english) and the information she gave me really kept my interest in place. I just wanted to listen all the time and feast my eyes on all the possession of Jim Thompson. They way I toured this house brought me to a whole new level of trance and imagination of how the past of bangkok looked like.

Interesting . Pretty interesting place to see if you are fed up of seeing statues....Story behind the scene are surprising. This guy had a serious taste of design and fashion. Decoration is wonderful.

Charming place. This is a great place to experience the life of Jim Thompson and the charming Thai-themed house he created. There were many priceless antiques collected by Jim Thompson over the years and were there to be seen. Please visit when in Bangkok.

History of western influence and the silk industry. And a pretty Zen place. The only thing is that you have to sign up for a tour to enter the house. There should also be more sitting places around the garden, as it is a very nice area indeed. Since it´s very central there is no real reason why not to go.

Interesting. We did this as part of the city in motion tour. For me it was interesting but not really a highlight. I read as much in the guide book as the in house guide told us. The construction of the house is interesting but wasn't that impressed with seeing his possessions and no photos can be taken inside the house. Many more great things to do/see in Bangkok.

A good first attraction. Bangkok can be hot, sticky and a bit hectic. This attraction is handy for the sky train, is relaxed and peaceful and hence a good way to help get acclimatised. The history of the house is interesting, the conducted tours informative and the little restaurant a good place to chill before moving on.

A step back into traditional Thai history. The Jim Thompson House is an absolute Gem ! A must see for any visitor who is interested in the arts and culture of South East Asia and Thailand in particular.With his Architectual background, Jim Thompson put an amazing selection of traditional Thai teak houses together and filled it with traditional art and antiques of the region.His mysterious disappearance in the early 70s adds even more interest to this legacy.Today it's an oasis of calm with beautifully kept gardens and charming staff to make sure your visit is most memorable. No double pricing for foreigners either. 150 baht admission; a bargain !! Photography inside the house is not permitted.Also try the small restaurant by the pond next to the house ........ Enjoy !!An easy way to get to the Jim Thompson house is to take the BTS Sky Train to "National Stadium", from there walk, about 350 mtrs. A courtesy vehicle from the JT house also operates from under the BTS station. The house is virtually in the Soi next to the station on the north side, direction of the canal (San Seap)As a side note, don't let taxi and tuk- tuk touts distract you when you walk up to the end of the small Soi to get to the house. "Oh.. were you go ? Jim Thompson closed today". Don't believe them !! They want to take you shopping in High pressured sales shops, from which they get commission for bringing you there.... The Jim Thompson house is always open 365 days a year apart from perhaps Songkraan festival....

One of the last jewels of tranquility left in downtown Bangkok. Over the years I have visited several times Jim Thompson House. With downtown Bangkok slowly looking like every other Asian metropole this is one of the last original jewels left.

Interesting history, home, and we loved the shop!. We really enjoyed this home- it is a traditional Thai home, and has many rare artifacts. There are examples of silk spinning to view and a fabulous gift shop. One of the highlight of our trip!
A must see in BKK. I really liked this place. The house is very beautiful, well decorated and the gardens are amazing. The restaurant is fantastic too.

A slice of history in the heart of BKK.. Slip away from the bustle for a moment and imagine ye olde KrungThep within the secluded walls of Jim's house. If you get a chance do the tour, very interesting with excellent guides and when you get hungry the restaurant serves all manner of goodness!
Charming. This museum was very interesting, as you can see the processes by which silk is made and the house itself has very interesting architecture. The food at the restaurant was also very nice.

Must see!. Every time I'm back in Bangkok I always spend a couple of hours visiting Jim Thompson's house. Not only for the place itself that's anyway a visit worth, the atmosphere here is something magic and you can't avoid falling in love with it.At the end of the visit take time to relax in the garden and don't miss to take a cake at the restaurant! Best place in Bangkok for me.

Fantastic place to visit.. This house is beautiful and so much bigger than I expected. at 150 baht I thought it was a bargain. We were asked to put our bags in lockers before we went on the tour and you get to take the key with you so perfectly safe. I enjoyed the break from carrying my heavy handbag around with me!!Our tour was very informative and interesting. After the tour you're allowed to walk around the gardens at your leisure and take photos.I would definitely recommend visiting.

Lovely Thai style house with equally lovely surroundings. This traditional Thai style house is in a small, quiet, tropical garden setting. The story of the American, Jim Thompson, who basically started the Thai silk industry is quite interesting. The tour, which is compulsory and one has to pay for it in order to see the house, it not as informative as it could be, but one is free to ask questions. The inside of the house is nice with some beautiful pieces of Thai art and Buddhas and we found it interesting and enjoyable to see. On entering the grounds there are people pulling the silk from the cocoons and how they process the silk from the cocoons before weaving it. I have never seen this before and found it also quiet interesting. There were also some women in traditional Thai dress doing some traditional Thai dancing. We enjoyed this quiet, aesthetic attraction although it might not be everyone's cup of tea. There is a gift shop there with some nice silk clothes, and scarves etc that could probably be bought elsewhere for less money. There is also a nice restaurant and bar with good, but a bit pricey food overlooking the house and grounds and a pool with large gold fish in it. We enjoyed having a smoothie and a snack there. The larger meals looked quite good. A quiet peaceful artistic attraction.
TYPICAL THAI HOUSE. Actually a collection of 7 traditional wooden houses linked together. A good collection of Thai and regional furniture and antiques. Worth the visit.

Enchanting story of a unique entrepreneur. Peaceful, beautiful complex and enchanting story - we were motivated to buy the book to read once home. High quality goods in the gift shop, most above our budget, but we did buy a t-shirt each which is quite different to anything you would buy at home. Don't leave Bangkok until you go there.

A lovely house, an expensive uniformative tour.. We took the canal to get here from the Phan Fi Lilat stop it was three stops and 8 Baht each. A delightfully smelly introduction to the waterways of Bangkok. From the ferry stop its a short couple of hundred meter walk back along the canal to the entrance (and it's well signposted).At 150 Baht its not a cheap entrance fee, but does include a guided tour (the only way to visit). Our English language group (tours are also available in Thai, French, Japanese and Chinese) numbered 15, which was too big for the spaces visited (12 would be better). The guided tour told me nothing that I hadn't already read on Wikitravel or in the Insights/Lonely Planet Guide Book, but the English was good.The tour would last, 45 minutes (it actually lasted 33 minutes) and we were tripping over the group in front of us and half listening to the group behind as groups came very close together.The house itself is lovely and the antiques are stunning. After the tour (during the "inside the house" part you must lock your bags in a locker and remove your shoes) you're free to walk around the garden and into some smaller buildings, where further - unlabelled - antiques are displayed. You can take photos of these and photos in the garden, but not in the house.There were also displays of silk spinning and weaving.

Chilled Out Oasis In Bangkok. If we are honest we visited the Jim Thompson house purely because it was located near to our hotel (Pathumwan Princess). We were pleasantly surprised with what we found. There's a really nice old style house to look round with a guided tour. It was also good to learn about Jim Thompson himself and his life in Thailand. You hardly notice you are in Bangkok whilst in the house or its garden area.It was raining whilst we were there so we took shelter in the cafe / restaurant while it passed. The food in there was also good.It's an ideal place to visit in Bangkok if you're looking for something different from visiting the temples. There is a Skytrain stop close by, and also a khlong canal boat stop near by.

Interesting, informative with a lot to see and do. Jim Thompson arrived in Thailand during the war and stayed on. He developed the Thai silk industry and clearly made some money as well as building up the work for many people. As an architect he then designed his own house incorporating many fascinating aspects and artifacts of Thai housing. The entrance fee is affordable and you then get a guided tour around the house and gardens. It is well done and offers a glimpse of life for the well-healed foreigner in Thailand in the 50s and 60s.There is also an art gallery with interesting videos, an up-market shop selling rather nice but expensive silk and wool products and a cafe/restaurant which is well worth visiting.Wheelchair access to the house would be impossible but more or less OK for shop, restaurant and gardens.The site is easy to get to from the canal ferries but don't fall in en route! Scary but cheap and very fast!
Well worth a visit. An interesting insight into an interesting man who was largely responsible for re-establishing the Thai silk trade. Take the tour and learn more - its worth it.
Amazing Thai house in Bangkok. Not only story of Jim but you also can see the traditional Thai house in the middle of Bangkok. I'll be back again

Lovely Place. Wasn't sure what to expect as we didn't know much about this place before visiting. It is beautiful, a nice calm oasis in the centre of the city. Lovely antiques and beautiful gardens. The restaurant here was also very good. The art installation part of it was pretty bizarre!
Excellent attraction. This was a really pleasant surprise. This is a great attraction. Really well set up and good quality. Great insight into Jim Thompsons life and work. I'd really recommend this.

Beautiful!. Jim Thompson House was just around the corner from our hotel so decided to wonder down and have a look. Glad we did. You see the house on a guided tour which was very good, informative and just the right length of time. After the tour you can walk back through the gardens. We went for an iced coffee at the restaurant which was lovely overlooking the house and a lily pond. At the end of our trip we were back in Bangkok before flying home and decided to have lunch at the restaurant. The food was excellent and it was peaceful and restful before braving the trip to the airport.
a pearl! . in the heart of Bangkok there is beautiful garden serounding the Jim Thompson museum. the museum can be seen only by a guided tour. was great! better than expected!!

Thompson House a Thai classic. Fascinating home of Thompson who revitalized the silk industry in the 1950s. His home is designed in classic Thai style with some compromises to Western comfort. It contains priceless tapestries and ancient artifacts collected when things were very cheap. Silk store nearby has lovely products at lovely prices.

A calm place in a loud city. Jim Thompson house was my favourite thing to see when visiting Bangkok.The tour is guided, the guide was very nice and told us a lot of interesting things. House is truly amazing and the garden around is so calm you don't have a feeling you are in the middle of a city. We ate cake and drank ice tea at a restaurant inside and it was great.

Much better than anticipated. I have been to Bangkok several times and was never interested in seeing this, but went this time and glad I did. Jim Thompson's house was beautiful, and the collection of art even better. The tour guide did a great job relating significant facts about JT's life and construction techniques on this most interesting house. There were also some interesting shows going on right before you get to the start of the tour. Beware people standing outside JT's house telling you that the house is closed and offering to give you a bargain tour somewhere else and that tour would not be a bargain.

Most Enjoyable. I really enjoyed my visit to Jim Thompson s house. The six Thai houses put together to make his house are beautiful, his story is very interesting. Strange that an American started off the Thai silk industry!Location is handy, right in the centre of Bangkok. Well worth a visit .

Interesting!. Beautiful complex with exhibitions telling the story of how Jim Thompson revived Thai's silk industry. You must take the guided tour through the buildings, which are given in plenty of foreign languages. Get there early to beat the heat!

An amazing piece of Thai history.. Jim Thompson was a unique individual and amassed an impressive collection of Thai and Buddhist art. The Foundation is a bit commercialized, but if this will help preserve the Thompson legacy then I'm all for it. A quiet haven in a bustling city. Great for lunch or tea even if you're not touring the house.

A history and a mystery in a beautiful thai garden setting. Jim Thompson's house is a good visit to recall old Bangkok, the tasteful mix of traditional and comfortable house compound, and the beautiful silk weaving he started. The restaurant is a good relaxing place by the coy pond. The tour will relate the mystery.

Interesting place, lots of visitors. At 150 baht it was an OK diversion. Interesting architecture and a house loaded with art and craft. The guide had an excellent grasp of English, and in spite of doing the tour for many times managed to be informative and occasionally entertaining!Plus for house being naturally air conditioned which was needed and lent the other claims about its construction veracity.Being allowed to visit the outlying houses on our own was great.Minuses - the house was packed with tours (Sunday so maybe try weekday) and after about half the tour there was either a call to meditation/prayer, an impromptu Thai jojk or a lamentation going on for 5 minutes. Made it hard to hear the guide.Do visit - it is very near National Stadium BTS and there are tuktuk shuttles (it is far down the soi).
Lovely place, amazing story.. Discover the incredible story and history of one of Thailand's most colourful and mysterious figures. And grab some great silk while you're at it!

Visit Jim Thomson's house - gateaway from BKK hustle and bustle. Visiting Jim Thomson's old house is a very good idea when in Bangkok. There is a very beautiful garden and the guided tour is included in the ticket (in French, English, mandarin, etc.) The collection of artwork from the region (Thailand, Myanmar, China, etc.) is rich and it is very nice to be in this traditional Thai house. The museum shop sells very beautiful article of silk and there are traditional thai dance performed at the entrance, which is enjoyable.

Tranquil escape from the bustle of the city. Excellent guided tour, outlining the life of Jim Thompson, and the history of the silk trade, Explanations of his collections and furnishing. A truly tranquil place,beautiful gardens, hard to believe you are still in the centre of Bangkok! Recommended !

Relaxing tour in central Bangkok. Access to the house itself is wonderful, and the guided tour provided a good background of the house, Jim Thompson and a bit of Thai history. The guides are happy to answer questions, and after the tour you are free to wander around the grounds and side buildings on your own.The House is easily found via BTS in central Bangkok, and a free tuk-tuk shuttle is provided from Sukhumvit to the House.There is a regularly scheduled Thai dance show near the obligatory gift shop.This is a good touring alternative to temples, and tours are provided in multiple languages. In the house you must take off your shoes and store you camera in a locker provided.

A brilliant and unique old style Thai mansion built by the late Jim Thompson.... This stunning house and its history worth experiencing with wonderful guides. Beware of narrow lane/street at front where there have been recent motorbike accidents, in other words have eyes in the back of your head! Shop is great but expensive.
Best Venue To See i. Bangkok . Nice, cozy and very nice staff! Must See in Bangkok included free shuttle to Main street. Very interesting guided tour in Bangkok

Jim Thompson house. This is really a wonderful place to visit. I have been a few times. Jim Thompson revived the silk producing industry in Thailand. He put together his house from some old wooden houses around Thailand and is really an elegant trip back into the past.

An oasis of calm in busy Bangkok. In the 1940s and 50s, US citizen Jim Thompson was instrumental in creating an international demand for Thai silk, and his preserved house in Bangkok is a fascinating place to visit, even if you have no interest in the textile trade.Located down a quiet backstreet, the Jim Thompson House is peaceful, beautifully maintained, and packed with interesting objects its globetrotting owner collected during his lifetime. Tours of the house are conducted by local guides who speak impeccable English, know the history of the building inside out, and are more than happy to answer questions. I felt like I learned a lot while exploring the House, and the guides helped me to make sense of objects and statues I'd spotted in other tourist sites around Bangkok.After the tour guests are free to wander around the outdoor areas of the house, and admire a collection of monster koi carp. There's also a large souvenir shop where you can buy silk – but as I have no interest in textiles, I didn't even browse the items on offer.In a city as busy and exhilarating as Bangkok, the Jim Thompson House offers a brief respite from the relentless traffic and noise. And while backpackers hungry for the heady delights of Khao San Road may find it boring, it's an interesting stop for more sedate travellers, and you'll leave the House feeling educated and enriched.

Beautiful.. There is only one word to describe an hour or two at Jim Thompson's House. Beautiful.Set back from the hullabaloo of a main road, it is fitting that the house stands so close to a klong (canal). You could envision Thompson riding one of the long tail boats up the klong.The houses themselves are stunning representations of rural Thailand. Teak and endowed with Thompson's perchant for fine art and quality. He has done Thailand proud in leaving behind, a legacy which has obviously outlived him but stands as a beacon to some of the true beauty of this country. Attached are a couple ooutlets where Thai silk is available for sale as well as curios, souvenires if you will, of your visit. There is also a cafe on site.

A Must See in Bangkok for History Lovers. Jim Thompson House is a beautiful home located on a canal in the center of Bankok. It is an example of several old style Thai homes and is full of very rare and beautiful Thai antiques and art. Thompson was an American who retired from the CIA and disappeared in Asia, never to be seen again .

Traditional Thai Buildings. A large complex of houses all built or imported by the Thai Silk magnate. Worth doing the guided tour to fully appreciate the size of the place. The Koi in the ponds are huge! Worth visiting.

Beautiful Thai Culture display. Lovely staff , well done tours . Accommodates many different languages . The fish ponds alone are worth the admission price . The history of Jim Thompson is also fascinating . The restaurant is excellent . Not to be missed

History and Horticulture in this Pocket Paradise. This place is beautiful. The house itself is an architectural wonder and to think this was built so many years ago. Beautiful decor and timeless pieces make the place even more exquisite. The tour was a feast for the eyes but it was also very enriching with tidbits on history and textile production.

Must see in Bangkok. A unique place that will make Americans proud of Jim Thompson. Curiously, I went to FinsterFest in Georgia this past June(2015) and met several people from The Jim Thompson house visiting American Folk Art locations. Learned about the difference about silkworms from China and Thailand. I loved it!

Wonderful Thai house - a little oasis in the city. A must see in Bangkok. Open daily you have a guide - in your own language - to take you around the gardens and the house. Our guide was very informative. You cannot take photo's inside the house (but one of our party kept on doing this). The guide was very polite telling him not to but he continued. The guide kept her smile and composure - not sure I would have done. There is a small restaurant which is nice and a shop selling lots of Thai silk items and souvenirs. The facility is well worth the trip and easily accessible by the Skytrain.

A step back in time. Jim Rhompson was one of the earliest examples of the meeting Western and Thai influences. His house reflects this interface - plus you can buy products that have resulted from this confluence!

intersting historical attraction. Jim Thompson was a famous man who promoted the Thai silk and made Thai silk world famous. Although the Thomson house is worth visiting. The Thomson silk is is totally overrated as all True Thai silk is the same as the Thomson labeled silk. Only difference is that you will pay through the nose just for the label.

Very interesting. We toured the Jim Thompson House during our visit to Bangkok. . The house and grounds are kind of like an oasis in the middle of a very large city. I'm sure when the house was built the area was not as hectic as it is today. I thought the silk was a bit pricey but I kind of expected it. You can read more about him on line. It is worth the trip to see his art collection and the way the houses were built at that time.

Very informative tour. I personally enjoyed this visit. The guides have solid knowledge of the history of the person and of the place. Excellent place to relax and calm the mind. Just take the BTS skytrain and alight at National Stadium station. From there, it's a 5-minute distance by foot.

Beautiful Thia-style house and garden. We took the guided tour through the beautiful house which contains an amazing collection of art. The gardens are full of stunning orchids. The property has a coffee shop, clean toilets and an outlet for all the silk products on sale. Well worth doing. Close to Sky Train Station so really easy to get to too.

Interesting, not Amazing. I enjoyed our visit and tour to the Jim Thompson house, but was not blown away. Perhaps my expectations were too high after I had heard so many good things. The home itself is gorgeous, and is definitely worth the visit, but it's not incredible or a true highlight. I am glad we went, but I have no need to go back. We were also underwhelmed by the selection of silk goods in the shop. Again, this may be a product of so much hype. It's a good experience, but not amazing.

... a pretty special tale. There is so much history - not just the designs but the whole Jim Thompson story. For that legacy to continue - and as a tourist - my mother passed her "gifts created by" Jim Thompson people - my generation followed and now my own children recognise the significance ... Teak that can be treasured, we have stunning silks worthy of framing - and each one reminds of good times in a great place - a pretty special tale about a very special country.
Thai silk. wonderful thai silk produkts but prices are rather high for Thailand. Learn something about Jim Thompson and the history - its very interesting

Commerce, conspiracy, craftsmanship...one stop. Jim Thompson re-estabished the high quality Thai silk market, at the same time he is credited with conspiracies, disappearing into the arms of the CIA or some other shadowy group. Whatever, the reality, his home which is convenient to the National Stadium stop on the skytrain. The home is exquisite with excellent examples of Thai furniture and treasures. This is a shop and an excellent restaurant.

Unique views of a successful ex-pat's digs. Our small group toured JTH soon after arrival in Bangkok. We especially enjoyed the beauty of the gardens and plantings, and the food and ambiance in the restaurant/bar. Also enjoyed seeing the high-quality locally produced merchandise as an introduction to Thailand.

cannot do it in half an hour. fantastic collection of traditional houses put together by Jim Thompson to form a great estate in the middle of busy Bangkok. Ther eis even a guided tour in French but it does NOT take you around in half an hour ! as promised by the guide. We were only two and it took us about 45 minutes and we had not seen all of it. No time to look at the beautifull artifacts and to ask questions. Consider at least an hour and ask questions , it's just a wonderfull collection but the guide is a bit sparse with her comments. Spend more time in the garden , the shop and the coffeeshop (menu looked good. Final great point : use the shuttle to the main street,

A very enlighting visit. The guided tour takes 40 minutes and it was an opportunity to learn about Thai culture and habbits.It also helped me to understand a bit more about what I saw in the shrines in Bangkok.The pieces in the house are realy a piece of art.

I Want to Live Here. Fantastic glimpse into the life of a real life mystery and enigma. The House is located in the heart of the city, near MBK Mall, but you feel transported to a different world and time. A peaceful few hours, and don't forget a cool drink in the cafe by the koi pond!
interesting visit. a very interesting visit which has many historic pieces to see. A guided tour is a must to ensure you dont miss all the details .

Interesting. This is a great house to visit - it also has a restaurant and a shop (selling Jim Thompson stuff). Its a short walk from the sky train and there's also a shuttle (to the skytrain if you don't want to walk). Once you get there, entry is on a tour - it takes about 40 minutes and its reasonably interesting. The star is the house itself - great design and full of interesting pieces of Asian art and local furniture.

Great afternoon out. Lovely house, great value visit with tour included in entry fee. They seem to do tours in several different languages too (at least Thai, English, French, mandarin Chinese). Very interesting insight into life of Jim Thompson, the Thai silk trade and also there is a pretty tropical garden around the house.

A bit disappointing from other descriptions I read.. After reading about what a must to see this attractions is, I was a bit disappointed. I expected a home with traditional Thai furnishings but there is not much to this place. It's a nice house built by a rich silk merchant but it's small and not much inside to see. There is a tour with a guide which takes about 30-40 mins. Definitely not a must in Bangkok.
Amazing. We went there for lunch . Very clean and nice ambiance delicious food and friendly waiters u can find there american food or thai food . And the dessert was delicious .

Interesting visit and beautiful house. This is lovely house and museam tucked away down a quiet Soi off the busy road but it is signposted well from National Stadium. It is not the sort of place you can just wander around, you are given a small group to go on a guided tour with and then visit the main house with your guide. I found it very interesting and probably learnt more that way than doing it by yourself. The tour is not too long, around 45 mins so not too onerous!!! You cannot take any photos inside the house but are allowed outside and in the gardens. A definite house worth a visit
Worth the visit, a view into the history of Thailand. Really worth the visit. An interesting history and a real gem in the center of Bangkok. I can also recommend the restaurant.
Beautiful piece of Thai heritage . The house is absolutely gorgeous, well decorated and the gardens are lush and beautiful as well. This is a must do for anyone visiting Bangkok the first time.

Great activity takes about 1.5 hours. Great activity to learn more about the Thai silk industry and legendary Jim Thompson. His home is beautiful and I learned a lot of about Thai and Buddhist architecture. The art and personal artifacts in the home are very interesting.

American enthusiasm in a Thai setting!. Visited here and was monumentally enthused by everything about it, from the colours to the plants to the woodwork to the history to the person behind it all. Really excellent version of tourism that I am keen to remember as I move on.

Number two after baan botanica. Good language option tour guideWell ive been here last time as a tourist. Its a good way to introduce thai architecture the way thai live. Good restaurant good interior, fabrics collection by talented jim thompson. And the chinese philosophy that explain why he missing in action. Nice place but very busy with so many guest. I hope someday i can get vip access to be there early morning or even stay.Just like baanbotanica.

Interesting historical house museum and boutique in the heart of Bangkok.. It is a very interesting house museum where one can see how wealthy and cultured Jim Thompson, who revered Thai culture, lived in Bangkok in the 50s and 60s. Jim Thompson encouraged and promoted the revival of Thai silk production and promotion.

Nicely maintained . This museum is a nice place to visit especially in hot weather. The garden surrounding the house/museum is nicely manicured and lush. The house is maintained very well by the management. Tour guide was very informative. Yes, it feels scripted but if you ask for more clarification, the guide will be able to answer satisfactorily. I wished we were allowed to re-explore the inside of the house after the tour was completed, as I feel the time given to explore by the guide was too short (only a few minutes was allocated for each part of the house).

Great Visit. Had a very enjoyable few hours here. Staff professional and spoke great English. Tour very informative and all included for the admission price of 150baht - great value for money! Didn't go to the cafe attached due to time constraints but looked very nice and clean and reasonably priced. They have a shuttle that will drop u back to the main road every 15mins. We didn't use it but great service for people that need it especially in the heat! Can take your camera just can't use it inside his actual house but they tell u when that is and provide lockers with a key that you keep yourself so safe. Highly recommended.

Wonderful experience. This is a must see place in Bangkok. It is really worth the time you spend. Take the boat to get there, it makes it even nicer. The girls dancing at the entrance are super sweet and kind
Pretty. An interesting museum/shop to visit with pretty gardens as well. Possibly a hidden gem of Bangkok...

interesting- worth a trip. A very nice way to spend a few hours in Bangkok. The guides are helpful, courteous and speak excellent English. The architecture and history of the house is incredibly interesting and offers a bit of space to relax away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Interesting. An interesting way to spend a couple of hours. The house shows some great little antiques and a westerners interpretation of Thai culture. We found the place enjoyable and the 35 minute English tour which is included in the price is enjoyable. I'd come back with friends if ever visiting again!!

Please do not miss it !!!. This place is like a heart of Bangkok and telling the some part of history of adventures.
Still remaining building without owner tells the mystery of the past and showing the JT's products those proudly producing by themselves. Trade mark JT became one of the signature of Thailand and been trusted by customers all over the world.

Oasis of Calm in Hectic Bangkok. If you are overwhelmed by noisy Bangkok, I highly recommend a visit to the peaceful Jim Thompson House, home of an adventurous American who helped revive the Thai silk industry. Take a fascinating tour of the complex consisting of six traditional Thai-style houses; the guides are Thai students who are charming and dedicated to the mission of preserving this unique cultural site. In addition, the gift shop has wonderful souvenirs, and the café overlooking an idyllic gold fish pond is superb. Easy to get to by taking the Skytrain to National Stadium station.

Worth a visit. Beautiful old Thai house...nicely combined from different thai houses in a Western way.love the veranda and open spaces,beautiful,lush garden and many orchids.silk is exquisite.very affordable and varied

Interesting place, good resaurant. I really liked this place. The tour is interesting and the house and architecture are traditional. It's also a good escape from the heat. There's a very good restaurant for visitors.

I would visit over and over again. A little oasis in the midst of bustling Bangkok. The guides are excellent - courteous with good English skills. When you have wandered to your heart's content, visit the restaurant - extensive menu and good value for money. Oh, and don't forget the complementary tuktuk ride back to the BTS.

It is like a small museum about Jim Thompson. I guess Jim Thompson is one of the well known names in Bangkok, you won't miss it because there are Jim Thompson shops in 5 star hotels, high end shopping malls and at the airport. I visited the Jim Thompson House, obviously it has a more personal touch about Jim Thompson, there is, of course, a shop selling its signature goods: thai silk scarfs, handbags, clothes.

a perfect idea of the classic thay. If you want an idea about the classic thay style, go there, you discovers what you can do if you have the culture and the feeling it is a very nice to see, go there and understand the silk master where it had stay

A lovely little oasis in the hustle and bustle. Directions info: BTS National Stadium, follow the signs to Exit 1. At the bottom of the stairs turn left. After the second road you will find a complimentary tuk tuk to the house. The house is lovely. A reasonable price to visit. You get a guide in your language included in the price. The restaurant is fantastic too, especially the mango and sticky rice.
Nothing interesting . It was in top ten places to see in Bangkok But I don't feel it's in top 10Nothing interesting Only important thing is owner was from u.s

Best place in Bangkok. Jim Thompson's house is an oasis amid Bangkok's busy streets. Here about this fascinating glimpse on Bangkok at the turn of its commercialisation. Jim Thompson was a major force in reviving the silk industry here. Restful gardens, fabulous house, it's small but beautiful. The shop on site is hard to resist, as is the casual glamour of the cafe/ restaurant.

Worth a visit. They work hard to promote this place. Man of mystery. The spy who disappeared. The Western who brought the Thai silk industry to the attention of the world. Traditional style house in the heart of Bangkok. Etc., etc., etc.The truth is it is an old wooden house with some nice Oriental antiques. We never saw any other houses like this, so I guess it is "Thai style as imagined by a foreigner." We did enjoy the beautiful setting, the natural surroundings, the view onto the khlong, the harmonious use of natural materials.The house is used nowadays as a draw to get people interested in Thai silk, specifically Jim Thompdon brand Thai silk. This is gorgeous, sumptuous, beautiful. There's a dmonstration of how it was made, in case you don't have time to go up country to see for yourself. The inevitable shop is wonderfully air-conditioned. What a life to step in there on the hot afternoon we visited. Goods are beautiful. Prices are high. We found other outlets for the same brand in other parts of the city as well as in the airport.

Nice historical tour. A great historic tour that gives you lots of interesting factual information on the short tour. In house shop has quality Jim Thompson products that are pricey but good for a splurge and a great gift.

Good guide. Beautiful house, nice art and sculptures. We had to wait about 15 min. before the english guide through the house started. One can not fo into the house without a guide. The guide was smiling a lot and explain well. She was very nice. The house and story is not much. Nice to been there, but I do not think one misses out one much not going here eighter.

Definitely worth a visit. I loved visiting the Jim Thompson house, the tour is very interesting and the house is beautiful. The location feels very serene compared to the bustling area just outside. Definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful house and informative guide. Given the house is relatively small you may need to wait a short while before getting into a guided group. You can explore the gardens independently but you need a guide inside the house.The house itself is an interesting amalgamation of Thai and Western architecture with plenty of pretty details.

Good Place to Unwind for a Short Time. If you have ample time in Bangkok, you may drop at Jim Thompson House, it's an old teak wood house. Its nearby National Stadium, there's a free shuttle service, it looks like a Tuktuk ride. I personally want a house like it.

Story of JimThompson. The story of how he died is mysterious they don't know if a tiger ate him or if he was abducted his wife back in Connecticut also mysteriously died about the same time he revived Thai silk industry and the house is worth visiting you can also take the SkyTrain to the Jim Thompson outlet where I bought some pareos inhis signature fabric

Very good. Very cheap tour with a good english speaker guide walking you through the house (included on the base price). After the tour we could still stay around and explore more of we wanted to. Definitely worth visiting.

West meets East. A place where you actually see silk created by skilled artisans from the worm to the finished materials. There is also he merging of two cultures in both the physical buildings created by Jim Thompson and the many local historical artifacts.

Ok for an hour or so. I'd recommend not planning your whole day around this as there is a small tour of the house and your own time to go around the gardens. It wasn't the cheapest place of interest and the interest in going would have to be up to the individual's taste. Service was excellent and the tour guides had a lot of information to give with a number of different languages provided.

A tour around his house with a little bit if history. I was disappointed that more wasn't made of this house. There was very little reference to silk apart from two spinning at the entrance,although their costumes were beautiful! The tour was regimented and there were too many people in the house.

Excellent blend of local culture and food. The Jim Thompson restaurant is an unforgettable experience. Very authentic flavours.Not many restaurants in the world are furnished with fine SILK cushions that you can cuddle during a meal. They provided free TUK TUK shuttle service from the main road outside, which is at the bottom of a BTS station. Otherwise, you can walk in within 10 minutes.
Very nice. We had lunch there. It was nice and quiet and we had a good meal. We arrived along the canal that made for interesting transportation. We liked it.

Excellent place to be in to relax...good food n wine. Good place to relax.. excellent guided tour...do not miss the guided english speaking tour... After which you should try out their food n wine in the restaurant inside the complex...

Very Interesting. Taking the tour around Jim Thompson house provied a fascinating insight into his life, the silk trade and life for a foreigner in Thailand at that time. Well worth a visit. Some beautiful silk things available for purchace too.
Good place to visit. We went there 2 nights when only the restaurant was open.Food was good value and authentic. Service was also top notch.

Need something to buy....go there once....but...... The restaurant is not good enough. If you are going to die for a hunger , order some. But except that, DO STAND till finish shopping. ( sorry to restaurant's owner) Food's prices is not reasonable to taste n quality. But for a goods shopping, visit once. It's cheaper than the department store but i'm not sure a quality. So visit once then make your mind this shop is your style or not.I usually buy cushion covers, hankys n scarfs. ( It's good for a home interior or a gift )

Beautifully kept and well thought out regarding the history of how life was some years ago.. This was a great place to get a glimpse of life gone by for the Thai folk. The place although set in a busy town is somewhat quiet and beautiful, worth a visit.

Nice traditional Thai house. The house is a traditional Thai construction. You have a guided tour around it, explaining different parts of the house and items within. The staff were nice, and the grounds were beautiful. The restaurant on site was pretty good too.
Fine. This was definitely a great place to visit if you have extra time. If your visit is short, don't bother.

Lovely, calm and serene place!. Visiting this place is a lesson in history. Do take the guided tour that is available for this place as that is the only way one can understand and appreciate all that this place has to offer.This place offers one of its kind chance to see and touch relics and antiques at close quarters. The canal next to the house and speed boats running in the canal came as a bit of surprise to me as I was not aware that such a thing existed in Bangkok

Experiencing how the traditional Thais live in the past & good for souvenir shopping. Experience the Thai traditional way of living. Well-preserved houses and decoration from the old time. Nice food and good for souvenir shopping
Amazing Home and Silk. One of the most beautiful houses and gardens on the planet for a man that transformed the Thai Silk business.

Wonderful place, you'll remember it forever. Way exceeded expectations, from the entrance display, garden, fish and of course stunning house and interiors. Highly recommended, would do it again in fact. Bring plenty of money to take back cushions, shawls, etc from the pricey but lovely shop.
Leafy place. Nice place to visit. Gives You an idea of life in the traditional thai houses. Furthermore it is a nice escape from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok

One of my favourite places in BKK. I visit the Jim Thompson House at least once a year. There is something I find very peaceful about it, even though the tours are in groups. I always learn something new, and it is a very unique aspect in history!

A must-see attraction in Bangkok!. This "museum" of sorts takes you back into another age, decades befor the large skyscrapers dominated the city of Bangkok. You will find this house in a Central location- a wonderful place to spend a couple of hours and see first-hand some beautiful home craftsmanship and beautiful silk fabrics. It's definitely on my "must-see" list when you come to Bangkok.

Interesting afternoon trip!. An interesting trip into the home of a remarkable man. The guided tour is both affordable and informative. It is very hot in the house though, so be prepared with plenty of liquid.
Good old style of Thai house. I would recommend anyone who wants to see the old style of Thai houses in the old days. The tour around the house was good also.
Great tour. Really lovely tour. We had a guide with great language skills. Must see! I am still wondering what happened with Jim!

A must see. For a very small fee an interesting tour of the house. Tours are well planned and on time. Seeing the house was quite a moving experience - it is haunting in it's own way! A visit to the shop for a silk souvenir is a must.

If you have nothing to do, going to Jim Thompson is a good choice.. Jim Thompson location is very convenient to visit, just walking distance from sky train or MBK. Fee is 150 bahts. It is nice to have tour guide to explain things and get some knowledge. I think it is a perfect place if you have foreigner friend and you are tired to do things or take them around. This is a place. While I was there, I heard tour guide in Thai, Japanese, English and French. I am pretty sure that there are more languages than these 4.

Some interesting pieces, overall just ok.. I'd never heard of Jim Thompson before visiting this house, but apparently he was a silk/clothing magnate in Thailand before mysteriously vanishing in a Southeast Asian jungle in his 60s. The house itself was full of interesting tapestries and artifacts and is supposedly unique in its structural design elements. Admission gives you a guided tour through the gardens and the house which last about a half an hour. Overall, it was an interesting tour, got to learn a little about Jim Thompson, his life, and his fascination with the art of the region. The grounds themselves though were fairly small and though the tidbits we did learn were fascinating i think the allure of the place would have been magnified had i known of Jim Thompson's legacy before hand. As a museum, it's just ok, you're basically looking at the stuff a clothing magnate owned during the mid 20th century. Would have appreciated more history behind his empire and his rise to fame incorporated into the tour.
busy but cute. Although not hugely impressive, it's a really nice compound to look at, very well organized tours and interesting facts about Bangkok's history.

A World Away from Bangkok. In a desperate bid to rid ourselves of the noisy river, roads and shops, we sought sanctuary at the House. It was delightful, if a tad too brief.Again, as I have mentioned in numerous reviews on Bangkok lately, the signposting is terrible. But when you eventually find it, it's worth it. Welcomed warmly by the sort of staff I expected at other attractions around the city (and didn't find), we were asked to wait for the next tour group departing in a few minutes. This is the first gripe I have - there should, by now, be capacity for individuals to tour the House on their own.When we eventually set off, we were asked to remove our shoes. So you may want to wear slip-on footwear. The tour was 40 minutes and very scripted. The guide was lovely, but almost gave the impression she had learned the script parrot fashion. I'd have liked to have learned more about Jim, more about silk weaving and his impact on it, and more about the history of individual pieces of art in the house.The restaurant was also a more-than-acceptable food stop. In fact, one of the better dining experiences I've had on this first visit to Bangkok. Quiet, tranquil, with a good menu and amiable staff. Rare, in these parts.

A must see in Bangkok!!!. Next to the Grand Palace, this is probably the other sight that you absolutely should see when you come to Bangkok. It is beautiful and truly gives you a taste of what Bangkok was like centuries ago. I highly recommended ended your visit at the restaurant - the food is very good and the ambiance lovely.
nice-but overrated. The place is nice but as I said overrated. In my opinion it is really not a must-see. The instructor of the tour was fine

If you like history, culture and a bit of mystery!. This was something I've been wanting to do for a while now, but never had the chance. I'm glad I finally got down to it.
