Guided tours are a must - available in English, French and a selection of other languages - but you get to wander around after. Each tour lasts approximately 30-35 minutes. Our guide Anna was so gracious, and clearly passionate about what she does. Tours are organised in groups, so if you arrive early and have to wait for your assigned group tour to start, you can choose to have a look around the gift shop, the gallery upstairs, or hang out at the roadside stall just 50m or so outside, which serves a pretty decent bowl of kuey tiaw for 40 baht. No regrets about visiting here - 150 baht was a very decent price for a delve into the history of the place, the Thai silk industry, and the mysterious circumstances surrounding Mr Thompson's disappearance. Easily accessible on foot from the National Stadium BTS station.
Silk at its best. Knowing what Jim Thompson didfor theThai people and how he built the house is truly amazing.Everyone who goes to Bangkok should go there

bit of history tucked away in bangkok. the house where jim Thompson lived is open for view. he was responsible for thailands successful silk and textile international trade. definitely worth a visit to this beautiful and serene place. very friendly staff too. not far from the river too so you can catch a cheap boat into the city when you're finished. a trip in itself. make sure the water doesn't splash on your mouth though - its where the city's sewage runs into. all of it! visit 2001

A bit of a snore. I went here on a longer tour of Bangkok sites, and I definitely would have skipped it. It was a little interesting learning about some random American who kicked off the silk industry, yada yada. But overall, it just wasn't that great. I'd skip it.
To discover!. In the midst of the chaos of the city there is this beautiful house with a thousand secrets and a thousand virtues, decorated with a beautiful garden, charming!
Nice place. Nice place to buy silk scarf, i visited here with my friend and it's quiet difficult to park a car, we stay for an hour.

Nice break from the city. This was a very well run establishment. It felt relaxing and you got to learn some neat history. I recommend for anyone looking for a different tour than the typical museum or temple.

Gorgeous little house and nice gardens.. A very interesting and knowledgeable guide showed us around the house. Very friendly and explained Thai tradition and customs and how that led to the design of the house. Also gave some history about Jim Thomson himself. A must see if time allows.
Must see. must see sight in Bangkok! Exciting story of Jim Thompson , great garden and the house are worth the trip

Wow! Amazing lush house in the middle of Bangkok!. Was absolutely amazed by this house/grounds. Felt like a little paradise hideaway away from the chaos of Bangkok. Really really relaxing tour and great food from the restaurant! This place is a must!

The charm of colonialism. Wonderful teak house in private gardens - actually a compote of five houses rebuilt to a beautiful living design. Includes some history of the revival of the silk industry, and some beautiful furniture, ceramics and art. Built on the disparity between the haves and have nots.

Leave an past moment.. It is a real important step fro any first visit in Bangkok. The charming house reveal the traditional antique house with so much romanticism on each room.Each step on the marvelous wood floor of this house will give you a flower of this period when Jim Thompson design the place. It is really an authentic place in the middle of the chaotic City.
Relaxed place, short visit. Interesting place that shows the house were Thompson used to live. Explanation about Thai life style too. Also a terrace there. Relaxed place just near Siam.
Worth visiting. It's interesting to go there, it's really nice house with nice design, but the english tour guide speaking with such strong Thai Accent which made difficult to understand.

Ultimate Urban Oasis in Bangkok!. We found this gem fascinating! The gardens are beautiful and were created to resemble a jungle. Took advantage of the English speaking tour (given hourly) and learned so much about Jim Thompson and his contribution to Thai silk in the country. Did not know he created the silk for the "King and I" costumes which put him on the map. His home is a work of art along with his collections of art and antiques. Interesting life he led, tinged with a mysterious disappearance. Could not leave there without purchasing a silk piece which will always remind me of this experience. Also had a nice lunch there as well.

Uneven tour quality but still worth the visit. We love seeing this house, but this time, the English tour was a bit difficult to understand. I wish that you could just visit without taking the tour, but that's not going to happen any time soon, I imagine. They have increased the admission price, too. It is still a must visit when in Bangkok, even with these quibbles.
My favorite place in Bangkok. The best attraction in town. If you like architecture of course. Friendly staf. Lots of languages spoken by the guides.
Thai house and antiques. This house was belong to Mr. Jim thompson, who introduced thai silk to the world. In this house, There are many asian antiques. Take about 1 hour to see around.

A good plavce to see worth the visit. Easy to get to by sky train and a short walk its not hard to find if unsure just ask someone The house is amazing you need at least two hours to go through the house and garden it is worth the visit

the blending life between Thai and western. I had few days short staying in Thailand. My Thai friend took me to here for a little sightseeing.. I enjoyed the atmosphere here.. it blended the feeling of Thai and western. Let me image how if I stay here.. Besides, I like brand of Jim Thompson. it raised up the quaitly of Thai good.. I, even, bought a purse from Jim Thompsan in Bangkok airport..

Brilliant Bangkok experience. My family and I must have been to JT House at lease ten times with various visitors to Bangkok. It is a little island of serenity that makes it feel like you have traveled back in time to the way Bangkok used to be. The house itself is a masterpiece of restoration and the lush garden setting is fantastic. Viewing is only by tours which are inexpensive. And, while you are waiting - or afterwards, there is a great restaurant! Having said all of this, one of the best things about the House is the courteous and friendly staff. Children, in particular, are made very welcome - there are turtles and fish to look at etc - although taking them on a tour of the actual house might not be the best of ideas if they have difficulty resisting touching things. One of us generally stays with the child in the restaurant / grounds, while the other goes with guests on the tour.
Better than expected. This is really worthwhile visiting. Beautiful wooden thai style house, nicely decorated by a inspiring man. Excellent restaurant and nice shop.

A little bit of Thai history. A little bit of jungle in Bangkok. An interesting tour in English telling the story of Jim Thompson, the Thai silk industry, and how his house came to be. There are lots of objects of cultural importance to see in the collections. A nice way to spend an hour.
A memorable place. Very good experience. Lovely and interesting building. Loved the shop as well but a bit expensive, but then you are getting genuine silk.

Urban Legend of Jim Thompson. The house of Jim Thompson is a very interesting place to visit, and you can go on your own because the entrance fee includes a tour guide around the house. You see what the American legend collected, how he built the house, how he entertained, and managed his Thai silk business before he mysteriously disappeared. Many attractions around the site for pictures, with a boutique shop for souvenirs, and a very nice restaurant with good food. The staff is very organized, and tour is timed efficiently. Worth visiting.

Close to MBK. Just around the corner from MBK you will find Jim Thompson House. We did this on the last day and was a great way to end our trip. The house has been well looked after and if you are after some quality silk products this the place to get it. Interesting art displays around the place. There is a Thai massage place in the little lane leading up Jim Thompson House that I highly recommend 250 baht for 1 hour massage!

just looking to take a little share. When you read about the history of Jim and what it has brought to the country/region you'd expect more of it. Far too touristic and guides don't really share the story. Restaurant looks nice but is expensive without great dishes or anything really related.

House of Thai silk. Jim Thompson was an entrepreneur who designed and produced Thai silk of excellent quality famous around the World. He disappeared during the late sixties in the highlands of Malaysia, but his company and legacy goes on. The house is beautiful and made of teak, has a very good Thai restaurant and a shop which sells Thai silk of excellent quality

good for museum types. I've been thinking of visiting here since 1988, finally got around to it. It's beautiful but I'm not really the museum type. Really enjoyed taking the river boat from the stop on Soi 3 just walking down the road from the Nana Hotel in Soi 4 (you need a sense of adventure for this boat)

Hidden places. This is a hidden corner in Thailand....made of teak in classic Thai architecture. It was collectedfrom all parts of Thailand in the 50s and 60s... Mr Thompson was instrumental in saving the Thai silk industry. His disappearance is still one of the greatest mysteries.

Nice place to chill out. Nice place to chill out. Amazing to see a traditional house. Also, very interesting to learn that Jim relaunched the silk industry in Thailand. Shop is expensive but items are good quality.

A nice surprise. This is a bit of a hidden gem. We had some spare time in Bangkok and were around the area so we thought we'd visit. It's pretty cheap to get in and they run a free shuttle service to the nearby station.Inside the house you get a guided tour which was very interesting, they went over the history of the house the contents inside it. After than you're free to explore the ground level and there's some exhibitions and artwork to view. It's well worth seeing if you're in Bangkok, we didn't see anything else like it there!

A must for all. This museum of an American that truly made a difference in Thailand and didn't take from South East Asia is a must visit. And to see how they my silk from silk worms is probably the most interesting I have seen in a long time///

History in Teak. The Jim Thompson House near the BTS Station National Stadium is a Thaihouse build with Teak and without nails. You can walk from the station the small street or take the free shuttle provided by the attraction which will leave every 15 minutes. The house ist opened every day. To take a tour through the house and walk into the garden you have to buy a ticket. The tour and the garden are worth it. Beside these there is a very good Thai restaurant with the classic Thai dishes like Pad Thai noodle, minced pork with Thai basilicum etc. The portions are small, well cooked and not too expensive.On the ground floor of the house is a shop which sells the products of Jim Thompsom mostly made of silk. These are expensive but the quality is high. The designs are also interesting. If you don't buy just look at the items you will enjoy it.In case you take your time for tour, garden, restaurant and shop you can spend there a whole morning or afternoon.

Beautiful experience. The house, the atmosphere, the antiques, the silk, the architecture and the decor makes it unique. A place where the culture of the east meets the convenience of the west. The guided tour is very informative and the restaurant serves fabulous food as well. A place not to be missed in Bangkok.

Still great 15 years later!. I was here 15 years ago, and the home tour is still great! Just wished we knew what happened to Jim. Would recommend taking BTS or taxi to outlet store, prices are more reasonable. Both of our teen boys enjoyed the tour also.

a good cultural trip amongst all the shopping centres of bangkok. I had 1 afternoon spare in Bangkok between work meetings and I walked over to this museum from the Arnoma Grand hotel. It was a pleasant couple of hours spent learning about JT, his life and his legacy, and was easier to get to and quieter than some of the bigger more famous temples and the like.

Peaceful gem in the heart of BKK. Great place to go to if you're done with hectic Bangkok. It's a beautiful well maintained traditional Thai house which gives you a good idea how Thailand was before cars and skyscrapers became the main thing in BKK. Good tour guide that you can use, but you can also just walk around yourself if you like. Love the coffee shop in the middle. Definitely a must if you visit Bangkok and looking for a peaceful / cultural experience in the middle of Bangkok.

It's a house, where man called Jim once lived. Somewhere between creating the muppets and writing the classic 'fear and loathing', Jim H. W. Thompson, architect and silk baron too, took a trip to Thailand and liked it so much he decided to buy six houses and stick them all together. The visit featured a 45 minute tour round the house, teaching us a little about Jim and his silk business, and teaching us about some of the artifacts he'd filled his house with- mostly artwork from southeast Asia and China with a strong Buddhist theme. It was nice enough, though at the start we were given a piece of paper detailing his life story and were then retold pretty much everything on the flyer in the tour, which was somewhat pointless.
Brilliant . Highly recommended. A great tour and fantastic buildings with some nice history. Definitely a must for any trip to Thailand.

nice to see, but not a highlight. Jim Thompson house is a beautifull place to walk around and the guides sure tell some interesting facts about the man's life. But then again for me it was not something i will Always remember. If you have seen most other things in Bangkok, then go see this place.

Definitely not the best place to visit at bangkok.. Well,I read alot about this place reviews but I don't get what I read here there.The place is not that good,not that interesting,it's just a wooden house.And the prices are too expensive for me. Unless, you're a person who wear a 57 usd boxer at home or wear a 135 dollars pajama.I would rather buy silk clothes somewhere else,the price is too much.

Take the tour!. I was very impressed by the knowledge and English of our tour guide. It was quick, but thorough tour. The house is interesting, but you need to really be there to appreciate this place.

Calm and tranquil haven in the middle of the bustling city.. A tranquil space in a bustling city. I have waited 4 visits to BKK to visit this haven. You are provided a tour time on entry with knowledgeable staff, we were lucky to have a guide who had a wicked sense of humour and made our visit special. The restaurant has some lovely food and beverages. The shop has some grand bargains. Finding the house is so easy, right off the BTS and there is a free tuk tuk bus from the main road but it is walkable.
Small but memorable tour. Had a really well spoken guide to show group around. Even though it is only a house, the history about it and some of the treasures inside is fascinating.

Worth a visit.. We went here during a tour and we didnt actually know wht this was. Tbh we would not go again. Not because it wasn't interesting but you only need to go once. The tour was very good and we really enjoyed how friendly the tour guide was,
must visit when in Bangkok. Must visit when in Bangkok, very relaxing and interesting experience. the tour guide was very informative and friendly.

Enjoyable. This location is well worth the visit if you wish to experience the old time Thai house which forms this complex and gardens and see some of the antiques collected over the years. You can dine here (although I didn't use) and there is a shop to allow you to make purchases of genuine JT merchandise
Something other than a Temple.. An amazing place. Well worth a visit to see some beautiful Thai architecture and garden, learn some history and enjoy a meal.

A wonderful place to visit. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Jim Thompson House. The house and garden were lovely and it was interesting to hear the tale of how Jim Thompson set up the silk industry as a commercial enterprise in Bangkok and then disappeared on a trip and was never heard of again. The shop has some lovely items although they are quite expensive, but just as you would expect for fine quality silk. The restaurant is a great place for a reasonably priced lunch whilst watching the big fish in the pond.
Architects & Engineers. Construction Engineers/Architects/Designers and builders in general will be enthralled by it. My trade is in construction H&S and I loved it.

Well worth a couple of hours.... Best time early morning.. Apparently this is a must stop to see. The archecture itself is worth the time. The history of Mr. Thompson's involvement in the silk industry is quite interesting as his demise. Our guide's english was very difficult to follow.
Fun place . It's just simply beautiful, very good tour within the house, great value of money for the entrance fee 150B, there's a cafe in side of the place, didn't get to go but looks very nice!

Well worth visiting. This was high on my list of places to visit in Bangkok. It did not disappoint. The tour guides do a very good job of bringing Mr Thompson's character to life. It is a lovely experience with the garden and house kept beautifully intact.

Enchanting!. This beautiful house immersed in an enchanting garden really expresses the fascination of Jim Thompson for Thai culture: his collection of antiques from all around South East Asia is impressive and very well displayed
A must in Bangkok. Have visited a few times, bringing friends from different countries. Great friendly staff who can guide in multiple languages.

Interesting . Interesting and an amazing house but a but overpriced (in Thailands terms) for what it is. Me and my group agreed it wasn't our cup of tea but not to say it isn't anyone else's. Tour guide was helpful and interesting.

Surprisingly Good. I really didn't think this would be up to much but was really surprised how interesting it all was. Has a nice restaurant beside the complex which is a great place for lunch or just a drink.

Worth seeing. The gardens are Incredible. The house of Jim Thompson is a great visit. The gardens are incredible! Pity that they don't allow you to take photos inside :-(A little paradise in the middle of the city.Also a pity that they don't explain anything about his silk business.

So UCU to learn. I had read about JimmThomoson, but what an extremely interesting person he was, he brought so much to the world of fabric and exposed us to his view on quality fabric, worthy of dropping by and learning.

Smething Special. We’ve visited here before, so this time we just went to the art exhibition, the shop and the restuarant. Spents a very pleasant afternoon browsing the first two, and had an enjoyable snack in the third.Pleased to see they now have a golf-cart to take people to the nearby Skytrain, so that one does not have to run the gauntlet of the taxi etc touts in the soi leading to the House! Although they’re sometimes quite amusing!

Well Developed Tourist Attraction. I first visited Jim Thompson about 20 years ago. At that time, it was a nice quiet traditional Thai house on a rather dirty khlong. It has since been developed into a real tourist attraction, with museum quality displays, tours, restaurant, shop, first class loos, free shuttle from and to National Stadium BTS station, etc. All of this development has been done very effectively. Highly recommended for a visit.

Still a top attraction. We were first here almost 20 yrs ago and it is now a much bigger operation. There was a small shop previously, but no restaurant or art gallery. I don't remember having to join a structured tour - I think we just walked through the house (but...perhaps my memory isn't what it used to be). It still retains the feeling of what it must have been like in the mid 20th century, the added administration and tourist facilities are far enough away from the house and garden and are quite tastefully done. We enjoyed a Thai meal in the restaurant - Tom Yum Goon and Tom Ka gai soups - both were delicious.

Well worth a visit. Easy to find with a buggy service from the main road. Very efficient timed tours. Reasonable security and shoes and bags are left in lockers. Fascinating story well told. Good restaurant with well priced Thai food.

Nice change of pace. Nice change of pace from other attractions. Very tranquil and peaceful. The tour, which is required and provided with the $5.00 admission, is very interesting. We had a very delicious and reasonably priced lunch in the restaurant. And I bought a silk scarf from the gift shop for about $50, which I thought extremely reasonable. A very rewarding experience.

Mildly interesting!. A guided visit and a free stroll in the garden.There is souvenir shop( expensive) and a cafe/food. The centre provided free tuk tuk rides back to the Skytrain station but you also walk back as there aren't enough tuk tuk for everyone.The houses in itself are nice and all. But you skip it if you're on a short visit.

Great visit !. This is a great attraction. The place is beautiful , lovely houses along a river, a place with a lot of history. It may be a less touristic place than many others in bangkok but really worth visiting. Great café and great shop to finish your visit.Highly recommended visit !

Amazing . We were staying quite close to this restaurant, I had noticed the sign post when out exploring, I checked the reviews and decided to give it a try, what a shame it was our last night, what a lovely restaurant. The food was delicious, the staff attentive possibly the best food we had eaten whilst in Bangkok. The only negative is the walk down the dark alley, a little nerve racking when you are not sure where you are heading. But the complimentary ride back to our hotel was greatly appreciated.
Extremely interesting. Easy place to get to even tho off the beaten track. The guided tour with their guides is informative.

Beautiful house, fantastic restaurant.. My family and I loved the Jim Thompson House, and especially the shop. Spent a fortune on presents for friends, family and ourselves. Such beautiful items, amazing quality and really unique. Even the children enjoyed the tour of the house, the Thai dancing and learning how silk is made. Fascinating... The shop and restaurant are a must!

Recommendable visist. This was a very nice and quit place in the crowded city of Bangkok. The tour was good, with good englisch speaking tour guides. The house is reachable with the BTS and the city transport longboats (which is the more adventurous option!)

Well worth the trip. A real cool experience and just the whole story behind Jim Thompson is very interesting. Seeing demonstrations of silk making, the Thai dancers, the shop....would definitely visit again.

Best quality silk selection in Bangkok. Great place for shopping any kind of silk items, whether it is a gift (small bag, necktie, foulard etc.) or for own use. Probably the most famous silk brand in Asia.

House with History. Jim Thompson House were very exquisite. Real architectural piece with modern and native combined. Tour guides were very good and know lots of different languages. We enjoyed the visit. You should also buy gifts and crafts next to the house since they have lesser prices than the city gift shops.

Nice garden and refined interiors but too commercial. We visited the Jim Thompson House as part of the tour booked with Viator. The house / museum is nice with in-house guided tour with explanations included (we had to wait for the group to form...). The formal living units are made of teak and the fine interiors are pretty much kept that show the rich taste of glorious times. The museum has a lush garden with a little pond that is also pleasant but for me overall the spot was a bit too touristic and commercial-oriented with too much focus on displaying the silk products. Not bad but maybe there are more interesting places to visit if in Bangkok - e.g. Wat Arun instead.

Hard to find!. We loved this house, so tranquil compared to the hussle and bussle of Siam. Make sure to take down the directions well or to book a tuktuk as we have a few locals trying to tell us it was not open.Please note this is open every day until 5.30 pm (I think) and they do student discount.Lovely restaurant and cocktails.
JIM THOMPSON HOUSE. You cannot visit Bangkok without including a trip to the Jim Thompson House which is stunning and has so much history. No far from MBK Shopping Centre and worth the visit

Close to BTS station. It is very close to BTS national stadium station. Take just 5 mins by foot.The tour guide is quite nice, hilarous, can speak fluent English with thai accent.All inside is quite interesting, ticket is only 150 Baht.Restaurant is quite expensive.It is close to Bangkok art and culture centre, and you can go there after you visit Jim Thrompson House.

calm in amongst central bangkok. interesting litttle place 5 mins walk from MBK.The shop is expensive but interesting to look aroundthe tour is worth it so wait your turn,if you are lucky you will also see some thai dancing in the gardens.
Interesting. Very Interesting. Guide are good in explaining the hostory of Jim Thompson. Easy to reach. Provide Tuk-Tuk to go drop you off at the main road. Good food at the restaurant.

Beautiful traditional houses. Jim Thompson legend is an intriguing one, a rich trademan who disappeared without a trace during an afternoon walk leaving behind his silk company and a house that was put together out of several traditional thai houses and has been maintained in the middle of beautiful gardens. The gift shop is delightful (albeit pricey), and the restaurant is very good as well.

Different perspective of Bangkok. We visited this very interesting house recently and had a good tour with a helpful and knowledgeable guide. There are well preserved rooms to visit and it is in a good location for other attractions It also has a good shop with some nice artwork at reasonable prices. Thailand needs our visits lets keep coming

great place. It is a complex of various old Thai structures that the American businessman Jim Thompson collected from all parts of Thailand in the 1950s and 1960s. It is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Thailand

Never tire of this place! . I've been a couple of times to the house & I have to go when I visit to Bangkok! It's such a lovely place....very calming & full of history. The guides are top notch! They are so knowledgeable about the house & can explain the importance of things in the Thai culture. We had lunch there for the first time & the western food was just as good as the Thai menu - a rare occurrence from what we've found in Bangkok. Your not allowed to take pictures in the house which is a shame, but understandable. Definitely going back again.

Great restaurant! . That's what we mostly remember and highly recommend. Service in the restaurant was not great but the food was excellent The house itself is worth visiting and different from the temples and shopping of previous days!

Several traditional teak houses painstaking assembled into a very nice rustic home. A charming oasis of rustic traditional Thai architecture of a bygone era right in the heart of bustling Bangkok. Just up the road from MBK shopping mall. This is actually not a single Thai house but several Thai teak houses painstaking assembled into a very nice rustic home,with lots of furniture, antiques, etc all laid out as it was in the past.
Definitely worth a visit. An interesting attraction that offers a slightly different look at aspects of Thai history. Easy to access and very educational.
Really interesting. Shuttle bus from National Stadium station (or a few mins walk). Free guided tour, informative. Can wander around on your own afterwards. Pond with turtles!

A Don't Miss Experience. This is a fascinating destination, easily reached on foot from the National Stadium BTS Station. Guides are well informed and the visitor groups are well managed. Great architecture and artifacts.

Favourite place in Bangkok. The Jim Thompson house is absolutely worth a visit. It is the most tranquil and relaxing oasis in such a busy city. In order to see the house you must go on a guided tour but it is only 150 baht ($6 Aus) and is very interesting. It is hard to find a taxi driver who knows where it is and they will often try to take you to a JT silk shop. It is very close to MBK, make sure you take a map there is one on the JT website. This is my favourite place in Bangkok, the collection of antiques is as good as any museum and in a beautiful setting. I make sure to visit every time I am in Bangkok.

An oasis in downtown Bangkok - a great break from Wats!. Jim Thompson house and gardens are a great break from visiting temples, especially on hot afternoons. The place is close to National Stadium BTS, has a great indoor/outdoor café where you can enjoy coffee, desserts and lunch. The admission price (150 bht for adults, 100 bht for youth below 22 years old) includes a free guided tour (about 30 min long) in the language of your choice. The four of us toured with a french-speaking guide and 10 other French people. Note that before visiting the house, You have to put your belongings in a locker, take your shoes off and are not allowed to take pictures inside of the main house. The house is beautiful with many chinese ceramics and various paintings and sculptures. It's is like a small museum.After the tour, you are free to wander around the gardens and secondary houses and take pictures. There are also "mini shows" with traditionally dressed dancers, "artisans" working with silk and a great (but expensive) shop with beautiful silk and textiles wares (clothes, accessories, scarves, table wares, ties...). If your budget is limited you can still buy there some great souvenirs like high quality linen tea towels or coasters. They're more expensive than at the Chakutchak market but also more classy as a gift. My husband bought some nice silk ties for 1600 bht each with whimsical elephant prints. For any total purchase above 2000 bht, they give you papers to claim VAT reimbursement at the airport.

Quiet fascinating visit for Art and Architecture lovers. This museum house offers very interesting information about Thai traditions and Asian art. When purchasing the ticket (150 B adult) you are offered a guided tour (English or French) which provides further information and allows you to get into the six houses. Beautiful gardens, peaceful atmosphere and very clean and well mantained place.Their expensive souvenir shop is absolutely sublime with amazing pieces of clothing and accesorizes.

Wonderful. Calm, interesting specially after we learned more about it and about jim thompson the american architect from thhe guide who told us many details, the restaurant was very good, the food was just tasty and amazing

Nice sight for Bangkok. It gathers cultural features that are not so easily seen anymore in Bangkok. The houses show the deep Thai tradition as it was a long time ago. It's a nice "escape" from the concrete jungle, being still in the city. Worth it.

A great place...must for all. Wow how did Jim Thompson revive the silk industry? What a house! Beautiful campus. Most important of course, is his dedication which revived the Thai silk. A must-see place for all tourists.

quite interesting place. Entrance fee 150 per person. It is an interesting place to know more about the foreigner lived in Thailand at the history. A place easy to find. Luckily when we arrive the street to the house(at least 5-8 min walk). A free shuttle tuk tuk call us so we can enjoy a nice ride to the front door. And when we leave, we get in the car again. So good for tourist.After the visit, you will want to know more about Mr Jim Thompson - a mystery man~

Nice buildings, but big crowds.. The buildings are some of the last old wooden structures right in the of gleaming skyscrapers in Bangkok. Browsing through the interiors shows you how a rich man's expat life in SEA in the 1950s must habe looked like. For my taste however, the people who run this Museum today seem to greatly overemphasize the significance of the whole place and the opaque life of its former owner.The biggest downer however were the crowds. Even though they only allow guided tours (their way of crowd management), the place was so thickly full with visitors that it was really hard to enjoy the serenity of these buildings.

A very nice place. A very nice place. the architect at that time of 1930 has build 5 houses independently from wood and joined them together to make a single house with such a beautiful garden around . also build on top of river. A must visit place in bangkok

Only if you do not want to stay in your hotel room and watch BBC. Wanted to try something different to celebrate my sis birthday at BKK and she suggested we visit the Jim Thompson House. Firstly, we have our late lunch at the cafe there. The restaurant's decor is the usual Siam oriental chic design, food was nothing to shout about, though the price was reasonable.After lunch, we visited the Jim Thompson shop. I was expecting exquisite merchandise that are only available at the Jim Thompson House shop but was disappointed that the gifts and merchandise are the same that one can find in the usual Jim Thompson shop situated at any BKK major shopping malls. later booked a English-speaking guided tour of Jim Thompson House for $150 Baht per person.A word of caution, before you started on the tour, you have to deposited all your personal belongings, including all shopping bags, into a locker which is of unlimited size!All bulky bags that cannot fit into the locker must be placed on top of the shelve At Your Own Risk! The less-than -30 minutes tour was ok, but the tour guide could have shown more enthusiasm in explaining all the details of the house. I realized that she must have conducted this tour a zillion times but she sound like she is reading from a script and can't wait for to read off the last sentence! Overall, a visit only if you have tried all the other touristy spots in BKK and still got one day before you departed for home.
Jim Thompson House Visit. I highly recommend you visit and tour of his house. Very interesting life he led. It is conveniently located near near the lower Sukhumvit Rd and a taxi ride from the BTS.

Interesting experience. This is a worthwhile activity. Just a short stroll from the National Stadium rail station is this old historic house surrounded by high rise buildings. After you pay your fee, you get allocated to a tour group ( in your preferred language)- it is very easy and well organised. You learn about Jim Thompson and his effect on the Thai silk industry.

Interesting diversion...worth a trip. Great story, wonderful tour guides, very well organized. I will go back. The tour of the house and the information about the like of Thompson was unknown before going.

Impressing collection. The museum, run by a foundation, shows an impressing collection of Thai antiques. Guided tours are available in several languages. The only back drop is the huge amount of tourists flooding the place. Premises also have a Jim Thompson brand silk shop.
Interesting spot. A great spot to visit and learn about Jim Thompson. You get a guided tour of the house and grounds and the guides are very good. A must if you're a tourist in Bangkok

Informative and inexpensive tour of historic Bangkok house. Inexpensive tour of house in various languages gives a good insight into life 50+ years ago. Lovely shop with excellent silk and non-silk items.

Insight in Thai silk making. JT house gives you a good insight in the live of this silk entrepreneur and in the way silk is made. Sometimes you have to wait a while for the compulsory tour but there is a very nice (but expensive) shop on the premises. JT house is good accessible by khlong boat and makes a good combination with the big shopping malls like MBK or Siam Paragorn.

Thai silk and culture. Great view into Thai culture, architecture and history of Thai silk and an interesting look into the life of Jim Thompson. For 100 Baht in admission that comes a good 40min guided tour or is totally worth it.

Nice break. Great place for fabric, if you like this kind of shopping. They also have other cloth related items in the store. You probably won't find a better selection of fine fabric in one location in Thailand.

A lot about Asian culture. We expected to hear about silk, but the tour is more about Jim Thompson's house, Asian culture, antiquities ... Definitely worth a visit! A nice getaway from the noise and traffic.

Lovely place. Jim Thompson's house is a must. This typical Thai house is a gem and the works of art in it are enchanting. It also has a nice restaurant to relax after your visit overlooking a lovely pond and the food is good. The guide we had was excellent! Her English was so good... Her explanations of the premises and history in general were clear and interesting. Highly recommended!! Ah... The couple of shops nearby are cheap and sell good souvenirs.

Traditional Thai house. It is built based on old Thai architecture and filled with old art and artefacts. You can take the tour in English, as well as other languages like Chinese and Thai. Place is very close to national stadium BTS station. Worth a visit if you have time on your hand.No photos are allowed inside the house.

Shady low key stop - nice break. Lovely house and interesting story, great small thing to do, plus I loved, loved the scarves and fabrics. They run a little shuttle to the BTS, very easy transportation.

Nice silk souvenirs. There is a scheduled hourly tour, be sure not to miss it. The english speaking tour guide can converse in english well. The antiques inside the house are well preserved. Taking pictures are not allowed inside and bags are not allowed to. So just bring your basic stuffs when going here. Also, using shoes that can easily be taken off is also good for when inside the house, all must be barefoot. The souvenir inside the compound has a wide array of colorful silks. A little expensive compared to those sold in chatuchak, but the quality is superb.

Very interesting!. All the Tourist Guides say that this is the first destination in Bangkok. I don't agree. I think that it is worth to visit and it is the house that you imagine as the typical Thai house. Take advantage of the Foot Massage shop at the beginning of the street, it was great and very cheap

Thai Silk a terrific gift. Jim Thompson's House is quite pretty, and the silk of course is beautiful. You will pay full price of course, as this is a major tourist attraction. But the history of Mr. Thompson is as interesting as the silk. Take a taxi.

Interesting. A great place to go for 2 or 3 hours and learn the history surrounding Jim Thompson's life and disappearance and also to spend some extra dollars on fine Thai Silks. Definitely worth going if you stay 3 days or more.

Worth a visit. The Jim Thompson house is a tribute to traditional Thai house building. Many years ago Jim fell in love with Thailand and decided to buy a block of land. Instead of building a single house, he bought five and combined them. The tour guides here speak great English. They also do tours in Japanese and French. Only takes about an hour to complete, and is a great little side visit.

Do not miss this attraction when in Bangkok!. Absolutely stunning example of Thai lanna architecture, and an interesting insight into how Westerners came to Thailand- it's a hidden gem, but close to the Siam BTS or you can take a khlong (canal) boat! Outstanding restaurant!

History. This is history in the middle of crowded and noisy Bangkok. A must see! The story of Jim Thompson is really interesting and the place is a ''Hâvre de Paix'" You just disconnect in one of the best place in Bangkok to visit. Take your time while there and enjoy the quiet...

Great Breakaway in a crazy City!!. I wanted to see a few things in Bangkok that did not involve huge crowds of people. This turned out to be one of my favorite things. I loved all the artifacts that were throughout the property. The tour guide was extremely detailed, and spoke perfect English. I highly suggest this little stop in paradise.

Excellent Restaurant and a bit of History!. The restaurant was excellent as was the Koi Pond next to it. The Tour was nice and very informative. The layout and architecture was impressive. The Silk Store was very expensive and the Design Staff needs to get more creative, I love elephants...but please!
Good tour. Well worth a visit! Lots of entertaining stories as you tour the house. This is a must see if you have two or three days in Bkk.

Beautiful traditional Thai house . A nice visit if you want to kill time. Very beautiful and peaceful. Also great for just to have lunch and coffee. Beware of the scammed in front of the street they will say that it close today so they can sell you rides to other attractions

Worth a visit. This place is definitely worth a visit if you're in the area. We had read about it previously but weren't all that fussed about going but we happened to just walk past it so decided to venture in.The grounds are beautiful and the history you learn is interesting. The tour was very detailed and the guides were knowledgable should any further questions be asked.
Must see for history buffs. Our favourite place to send people! If you like history, Jim Thompson's house and story are really interesting, easy to get to by sky train, and cheap!
Jim thompson. A great house showing an insight into Jim Thompson's life whilst living in Bangkok. House is full of antiques and artefacts. Well maintained.

worth to visit. i love this museum, all the staff is very friendly, beutifull house and scenery, peace and calm. the entrance fee is 150thb for adult and 100thb for child under 22years old. the ticket price include free tour, you can choose the language in english, japanesse, chienese or thai languange. i recommend this place when you're in bangkok

Lovely house, beautiful garden. Jim Thompson House is a must for those visiting Bangkok. Amongst the high rise buildings it's great to visit a traditional Thai house with the original furniture. The garden is pretty with tropical plants. We enjoyed a meal in the restaurant which was one of the best meals ever.
fun, but not a must-see. Worth a visit. Not the most exciting activity Bangkok has to offer, but they do a solid tour, and the grounds are beautiful. I enjoyed it.

A tranquil oasis. A stunning example of traditional Thai teak architecture. I am not so much a fan of Jim Thompson's silk however the sum of it's parts makes this a truly tranquil location in what is a very busy part of town
special house. there have chinese, english, japanese, french and other tour guide to explain the history and concept of the house. free performance
Unique house near canal. . Tour is 150 baht. House is amazing both inside and out. Something different outside of all those temples. You go Jim Thompson!

Interesting Little Museum Hampered by Poor Explanations. Pros: interesting exhibition of curios and furniture, intimate atmosphere, convenient location in the city centre
Cons: supremely overcrowded, poor explanations by the museum guide (could have be alleviated by display labels)

Must visit Jim Thompson House. Love Jim Thompson's house. Aside from viewing the house, they show how silk is made. Eat lunch there and get a table by the pond. You/ll forget you're in a city for a while... If you come by the Skytrain, there is lady selling Kanon Krok (8pcs, 35baht). Buy! It was so yummy!

Paradise and art in the heart of city chaos. I debated what to do with my last full day in Bangkok, and decided to visit the Jim Thompson House. What a fantastic decision. I think I ended up spending over 3 hours here, between looking around on my own, visiting the art museum, taking the tour, and having lunch.To get here, from my hotel in the Sukhumvit area, I took the BTS Skytrain from Asoke station to National Stadium station, changing at Siam. From the National Stadium station, look for the exit map that shows the Jim Thompson House (I think it was Exit 1, if memory serves). The street is a few steps from the BTS exit, and you follow it all the way to the end (by American standards, it feels more like an alley than a street) where you turn into a property that feels like you've been transported out of city chaos and straight into paradise. The buildings and grounds are gorgeous, and if you are into art, this collection is fantastic. The tour, offered in English, French, or Thai, cost about B 150 and lasts roughly 40 minutes. You get to go through the entire house, and the guides do a great job of telling the story of Jim Thompson, his role in the Thai silk trade, and the history of key art pieces. Be prepared to remove your shoes and place your personal belongings, including any purses or other bags, in a locker. You lock it up and take the key with you, and all my belongings were intact at the conclusion of the tour (I'm not one to part company with my purse, so I was apprehensive at first, but it was fine). The architecture and furnishings are amazing, and I love the story behind the spirit house and why those are important in the Thai culture (I'm not telling, you have to go hear the story for yourself!) The garden is spectacular - it really does feel like a small, private jungle. I saw plants and flowers I'd never seen before, and I loved the surprise of finding fish swimming in several of the urns. I had lunch at the restaurant on site, and it was delicious. They had lemongrass juice, which is now one of my favorite things in the world, and I sat at a table near a small pool filled with enormous koi. I confess I had a very American club sandwich for lunch (after a week of delicious Thai food, I was ready for a sandwich!), but I had a traditional Thai dessert that was delicious. There were a couple of Thai people demonstrating silk spinning and silk weaving, and there is an outlet of the Jim Thompson store, where you can purchase a scarf or another memento. Items in this store are a higher price point and appear to be of good quality. My final stop was in the art museum, where they currently have a rotating exhibit featuring various Southeast Asian artists. When I visited, the exhibit featured art in the form of a few short films.I strongly recommend the Jim Thompson House as a required stop in a visit to Bangkok.

Beautiful garden and home. This was a definite bonus in our trip to Bangkok. The history of the house and the person make this a must see if you enjoy historical sites. Very well done tour in muliple languages so we were in a English group but there tours also in German, French and I believe Chinese. The tour is about 40 minutes and the guide we had spoke English better than most. They have a area where we were able to watch a tradesman pull the silk and gather it and also exhibits that explain the silk worms and care. All in all a very nice exhibit and tour.

Good lunch place. Visited the restaurant at the Jim Thompsons for lunch. The restaurant is well designed with an outdoor and indoor seating area. The ambience of the restaurant was great with greenery around - very serene and calm.Cocktails were good. They had very few vegetarian options on the menu and the hot sauce they used had shrimp in it limiting our food options considerably. Despite that enjoyed our lunch.They provide a shuttle service in a tuk tuk to the main road which saves the 5 minute walk and is convenient.
Lovely house, nice collection. We really enjoyed visiting Thompson's traditional Thai-style house and gardens.The art collection is a nice sampling of Asian art. Our tour guide was excellent!

Enjoyable museum. One of the few museums and by far one of my favorites in Thailand.It combines the interesting mixture the East with the West, plus, the mystery behind the disappearance of Jim Thompson.His legacy can be seen is the whole house, where every corner has a meaning, every piece of art in his antiques collection has an historical value and the artistic work with high quality silk of his brand makes this, relatively small museum an invaluable piece of art.The guides are friendly and always happy to answer your question.No pictures are allowed inside the house, wish can be dissapointing, but, can be compensate with the beautiful gardens and exteriors where pictures are allowed.There is a cafeteria and a silk shop for Jose wh want to have a refresh enemy or buy some souvenir.The silk shop offers a very beautiful and high quality tailor work in different sizes and prices.Take the shuttle tuk tuk from the National Stadium to the museum, it's free and convenient, however, you can walk from the station as well.

Well worth a visit. We had a day to ourselves and this place was recommended by our hotel concerge. On a map it looked easy enough to find so took the Skytrain and hoped for the best.Negotiated our change quite easily from the line we were on changing at Siam Station to the line whioch would take us to The National Stadium, a bit lost but a young girl approached and asked if she could help (if that was London would still be looking!) and we eventually ended up at the Stadium. Again we looked a little lost and a guy pointed us in the right direction, as we halted to check the map a local just sitting at the side of the road asked 'Jim Thompson House?' and pointed down a narrow side street. The house was a little way down the side street but found it without problem. The guided tour was both informative and entertaining. His life was described along with the love of Thailand, down to his eventual disappearance. Being ex intelligence for the USA there are many conspiracy theories as to what happened. His house has been preserved with lots of artifacts on show. Be prepared to walk bare footed around the house as per tradition and no bag of any sort allowed. One lady refused to leave her handbag and was told she could not tour so to leave only to appear a few minutes later and just pop her handbag into lockers provided which you get to keep the key of until you retrieve your bag.

Lovely city oasis. This is a serene spot in the middle of Bangkok, up a side street and not very well marked from the cross street but well worth seeing. Your entry fee buys you a tour and you can't see inside the house unless you go on the tour. It's shoes off inside as well and no photos. It's really a museum and really very beautiful. The gardens are lovely and there's a restaurant/cafe and shop. The shop has high quality silk scarves, cushions, clothes etc. and the prices aren't too bad for what you get. I bought a couple of things there but if you decide not to, there are a couple of Jim Thompson shops at Bangkok's airport duty free as well (although not as big a range).

interesting and worth a visit. well organised. guides take you round in small groups giving you a talk on the history and Thai culture. There is also demonstrations of Thai dancing and spinning silk, before a wander round the cafe and shop.
A must see. A must see tour stop when in BKK. It's a short walk from Siam Square. Nice restaurant for a break after the tour.

Worth a visit. Love the interior and the ground, the garden, the live shows at this museum. As animal lovers I'm very happy to see koi fish, big river fish and huge turtles in the ponds. The café is also really nice.

An oasis in the amidst of chaos. Having Visited Bangkok some years ago, at the time never even thought about visiting the Jim Thompson house, I’m glad I did this time around. Away from the hustle and bustle of Siam Square lies Jim Thompson’s tropical oasis. Packed full of tropical trees, ponds, fish and flowers it was welcome break from the chaos down the road. We booked ourselves onto the tour once we arrived and whilst we waited for our tour group to be called we had a look around the plot. Very pretty surroundings and really interesting pieces of art of look at. The tour itself was also very good, the house was beautiful and has obviously been very well looked after and loved over the years. Our guide was great and even tried to crack a few jokes. Sadly we did not visit the restaurant which was a shame as we’d just had an enormous lunch and we had heard great things about it. If you miss your opportunity to buy your silk etc from here, there is a Jim Thomson shop in Siam Paragon. All in all this was a welcome break from Bangkok chaos, although still very humid there. I’d say the whole visit only took two hours max including our own walk around prior to the tour, but it is extremely close to the sky train and so easy to get to. If you are wanting something easily accessible.

Fabulous place to visit. A definite must see! These original Thai houses are tucked away in a quiet street in the heart of Bangkok. It is very easy to get to. You can take the BTS and then it is a short walk. Be prepared for the tuk tuk drivers as you leave. They will escort you to a nearby jewelry store. They will take you back to the station though! The guides were very good! They offer several different language guides. Very interesting! The cafe offered a fabulous selection of Thai food. What I had was delicious! I would love to try The Thompson Restaurant.
Don't skip it. The story is so cool - former CIA agent becoming silk tycoon - I wish I had a house and art like his - Tasteful - Plan on buying shirts, ties and handbags.

Fascinating insight into Thai architecture. The buildings and the collections on display give you an insight into some of the history of Thai culture and are beautiful to explore. We were surprised at how busy the house was though. Prepare for queues and lots of people!
Traditional combined by a foreigner. The late Jim Thompson brought houses from Ayuthaya many decades ago and combined the houses with beautiful decorations. Must come!
Tranquil and serene afternoons walk. Not as busy as some other places but just as interesting. The smaller crowds make it the more enjoyable place to have a look at.

Architecture and Garden are superb. Although there are not many or clear signage to point to this house once you left the skytrain station, the locals in the area all know where it is. Once on the property you pay at the ticket office after which you are allocated to a tour guide who informs you on the hitorical facts surrounding Jim and the property - very interesting. Apart from the historical facts, the current garden is magnificent and well maintained.The house itself is an architectural masterpiece and well worth the visit even though you may not take any photos of the inside of it.After the guided tour, you can spend money in the shop on the premises ($$$$$) Do not miss a visit to this house. It reflects so much about the true Thai architecture. The brief introduction to the silk industry was also very interesting.
Place from dreams. Everyone dream of living in Bangkok - You can see a dream come true in long past :) Our tour guide was nice. A place worth visit.

Very relaxing and interesting place. An amazing find in the middle if BK, very tranquil and peaceful place to loose yourself for a couple of hours.150baht per person for a 40min guide( not optional, the only way to go around the house initially).She explains who Jim Thompson was and what he was trying to achieve before his death, how he built the house and the purposes for it.Very interesting, a gorgeous house and gardens - a hidden jem.Visited the cafe and the shop, and yes , of course I bought !Well worth a visit.

Great history lesson. Jim Thomson's house gives visitors a history lesson on how silk was brought from Thailand to the world. The furnishings and exhibits as well as the tours are well thought out. A nice change of pace from temples in Bangkok.

Beautiful art collection. This is the house where Jim Thompson lived, by a canal. Jim Thompson is the American who developped the silk industry in Thailand during the first part of the 20th century. This house is amazing. The antiques and art collection is truly very beautiful. They exhibit a "walking buddha" statue that is so modern and beautiful. It is also very nice to see the bathroom, and the office of Jim Thompson. Everything looks like the house were still occupied by an art connaisseur.
Peaceful hideaway. Very nice house with a beautiful garden. Tour with a lot of information and guide was able to answer all our questions. If you're tired of temples this is a nice alternative.

Peaceful & well exhibited. Jim Thompson is the individual credited with introducing Thai silk to the world. The house was well shaded and cooler than many of the other popular attractions I visited. We really learned a lot not only about Jim Thompson and Thai silk but also about Thai culture in general. If you have the time, definitely go see this!

Very educational and well managed.. This would be the cleanest and best managed experience we had in Bangkok. they limit they number and timing of tours (groups of 10 every 15 minutes it seems) so you do get to hear the guide, see things without being crowded and learn a lot about Jim Thompson and the history of that place.

Fascinating. Went with my wife and 15 year old son and we all enjoyed and even felt a little inspired. Interesting man and interesting house in a quiet, attractive part of the city. It's also easy to get to as only 100 metres from the sky train terminus at the National stadium

a quiet escape for us from chaotic Bangkok. The beautiful, Thai architecture of the buildings + the zen gardens created a quiet escape for us from chaotic Bangkok. The 150 B entrance fee gets you into the grounds + a 40 minute guided tour in a small group. They have a restaurant (didn’t eat there) and a free shuttle the MBK (large shopping mall) nearby.If you want to learn about an interesting story of a man who was fascinated with Thai culture and captured the essence of that culture and you need a reprieve from everything else that Bangkok offers, definitely visit.

A small but fantastic place in the middle of Bangkok. This small attraction is well worth a visit. The small exotic garden is beautiful and the traditional wooden houses are picturesque. Great photo opportunities. The place is calm and quiet despite being located right in the middle of the city.The buildings contains Jim's art collection.The friendly guides are good at English and French (and maybe other languages too, I don't know).The shop features some high quality clothing at a moderate to high price.The cafe is good. I haven't tried to restaurant.A perfect place to visit in the morning before heading to the classy shopping malls.
Enjoyable and well organized. I enjoyed this visit. It was easy to get to by train and I found the guide affable who took us on the tour. There were a lot of tours happening though! Worth a visit!

Admonishing decoration and engaging behind story. Acceptable fare, 150 baht per adult. The tour guide is well trained. Can answer any questions. Astonishing Buddha images of 1000years history. Entertaining dance performance.Free shuttle is ridiculous , 15 mins per session with four seats only. Souvenir store is disappointing.

A lovely and educational retreat. Close to the major shopping centers, nestled in a side street the JT House is a lovely retreat into calmer times and a wonderful introduction into JT's contribution to today's Thai silk weaving industry. Nice shop and restaurant - surely worth a visit

Interesting Visit - Glad I took the time. Worth a BTS ride! Lived in BKK for several years, but never made it here so had to go on my first BKK return visit. About a 10 minute walk down a small Soi from a BTS station. We took the Jim Thompson House courtesy electric shuttle to save walking!Tours are conducted in many languages (must purchase tickets, but were inexpensive). Tour groups are small. The "House" is really a compound of several buildings. To appreciate the compound one should remember that when Jim Thompson built/assembled his "house" the location was in the suburbs of BKK, i.e. no large/high buildings around.House is adjacent to a Klong which stinks like a sewer plant intake structure overtime a water taxi goes by. Oh well, that's BKK for you (GRIN).Tour is worthwhile. Takes about 35 minutes. The house/buildings, except for one room isn't air conditioned. Dress in cool clothes and bring a hand fan if you have one.After the tour we ate lunch in the cafe on the grounds. Good food, cold beer, and the AC in the cafe worked well.

Visiting Bangkok? Do visit Jim Thompson House. An experience in learning about traditional Thai culture with a CIA twist. We did an English tour with a very competent and knowledgeable guide. The historical wooden house and gardens are beautiful. An exquisite peaceful experience away from the Bangkok hustle and bustle.Definitely worth a visit when visiting Bangkok.
beautiful house!. It's small and the tour is short, but the house is beautiful and unique and we're very glad we went.

An interesting piece of Bangkok history. This was an interesting tour of Jim's house, and what an amazing house! The tour went for about 40 minutes through the beautiful house and gardens. The architecture and decor is really beautiful, Jim Thompson's story quite intriguing and the young Thai women who conduct the tours are gorgeous.

Classic Thai Architecture. The American who revived the Thai silk industry drew on his training as an architect to combine two classic residences in building his home. A former OSS agent, he later mysteriously disappeared in Malaysia.

It's ok. It is not as crowded as other turist places in Bangkok. Pretty interesting to see Jim's house, but the whole museum is pretty small. Take the tour to go inside the house, otherwise you can walk around the gardens for free.

Tasteful collection of art. A beautiful house on the banks of the canal with a tasteful collection of art and antiques. The grounds are pleasant to wander around and there is a restaurant here which serves reasonable good food. The guided tours are efficiently run and lasts about half an hour. Worth a visit if you are in the area.

Worth a visit. Didn't know much about this place, but was told to go and was glad we did! A beautiful home - wish we could have been a house guest of Mr. Thompson's back in the day. We actually ate at the resturant and while it is defintely not "Street food" prices, the good was great and was worth the price - and it was nice to sit down in the AC and enjoy our meal. I would defintely recommend a visit to the JT House.

Good tour, interesting story and beautiful art in the house. We had a great time learning a little bit about Thai silk trade development, and seeing the beautiful art in the house. Tours are available every 10 minutes or so, and are avaliable in multiple languages (including English and French). We had a twenty minute wait or so, during we explored the grounds and gift shops. The tour itself was very efficient and quick, but allowed for a good walkthrough and interesting historic anecdotes. There is a free shuttle back to the main road/beginning of the Sky Train - there is also a restaurant onsite and a second story above the gift shop with small contemporary art installations.

A peaceful oasis in the middle of BKK hustle. I really enjoyed the visit to JT House: in the very centre of BKK, this is an oasis of peace where you can learn a lot: on traditional Thai dwelling culture and how a foreigner successfully appropriated it for living a comfort life. It offers a good tour of the compound; you can also see parts of the silk production; and of course enjoy a meal at the restaurant or buy a silky item in the shop. Do not miss an exhibit of modern art in an exhibition area; I really enjoyed the one on the show now. However, I must say that the lunch I had at the JT restaurant, although it tasted well (pad thai), probably caused my tummy problems. Unfortunately so, because I chose this place as a "safe" place to have a meal.
Very Good. Great place to visit when visiting Bangkok and it has a very nice shop and good tours round the house.

Informative tour. Do not make the mistake of missing the Jim Thompson house on your trip to Bangkok. It is not only a beautiful house, but complete peace and serenity in the chaos of the city! You purchase your tickets when you arrive and then are booked on a tour with a guide. We had to wait only 20 minutes for our tour to start. Our tour guide spoke excellent English, although, the tour did feel slightly rushed. It would be nice if the groups were a little bit more spread apart. There is some interesting history regarding the house and Jim Thompson, and his art collection is pretty neat. Would highly recommend to anyone visiting Bangkok.

Tranquility.... The silence and tranwuility that the place brought in me is still there to cherish.. i could live thtough the life of Jim...and i loved the house for all that it symbolises.. creativity, tradition and respect for culture...
One of the nicest things in Bannock. Lovely house and gardens , very calm and not too busy, tour is very efficient and nice guide,well worth the visit

Worth a visit. Beautiful example of a traditional, albeit bourgeois Thai home.Interesting tour available in several languages.Would have liked more facts about the history of the house and how Jim Thompson helped resume the Thai silk trade.
Nice, tasteful house. Well organized and efficient, 30 min guided tour of the "houses" very tasteful and the art objects used in the decoration are superb. Worth the visit

Nice but maybe a little over-hyped.. Although easy to get to from the BTS, I didn't understand all of the hype about this place. The buildings are neat to see, but it's a little underwhelming. We had lunch there which was quite good, and the shop is nice, but if you are short on time this is definitely something you could skip.

Jim Thompson. The history of this man is amazing. We had heard about him from a daughter who had been to see his Museum and work. We had a really nice visit there, and had dinner in the restaurant. great

Very interesting tour. Free guided tour, very informative. Take some time to just walk around on your own to really appreciate the house. Not too expensive compared to Grand Palace. "Kids" under 22 get cheaper prices, so feel free to bring your teenage children for a tour. If you don't mind walking, I would recommend starting the day with Jim Thompson, then walk down to Siam Square & Siam Paragon, followed by Central World and Platinum Mall if you're into shopping. No wifi though, would have expected that at least.

Unexpected retreat in Bangkok. Such incredible architecture and you can just breathe fresh air and a gorgeous garden in the middle of the hustle and bustle. The shop on site is gorgeous if expensive but high quality silks.

My favourite place in Bangkok. This is the second time I've visited the Jim Thompson house and it is still my favourite place in Bangkok. The house and gardens are a small paradise and haven in Bangkok.There's a guided tour which takes you though the house and tells of Jim Thompson's love of art and collecting and how he adapted some of the traditional Thai houses to make this home so truly beautiful. A fascinating tale of he and his life, an inspiring man. The restaurant serves good tasty food at reasonable prices - loved the mango smoothie. Spend time in the shop too.

Must-see tourist destination, full of history. This is well worth the visit. The architecture and artifacts collected by Jim Thompson are quite fabulous, and if you know little about Thai architecture or history, you will learn a lot on this tour. No photographs are allowed inside, so just relax, listen and learn as you observe these beautiful treasures. Really enjoyed learning about this fascinating man and his place in Thai culture.

Interesting, but not outstanding.. Good setting, but the museum story is just so-so. The shop goods are nice, but pricey. It's a bit off the beaten path and in the chaos around the shopping area that was nice.

Beautiful history. This was not high on our Bangkok visiting list but we were so pleased we went. It is a lush property once belonging to Jim Thompson, a man who had a passion for Thai art and culture. Here you can stroll through the lovely gardens and beautifully reconstructed old Thai wooden homes that house a stunning collection of Asian antiques. It also has a shop of georgeous silk items based on JT designs and they are irresistible. A pretty cafe next to a pond of waterlillys and fish is a great place cool off and escape the crowds.

a good place to spend half a day. this establishment is well located and has transport provided to take you right to the front door for free, if you prefer the walk it is a 10 minute walk from the main road. Once there there is a multitude of things to do and visit ranging from manufacturing sites to sales centres. The visit can be concluded with a meal and cool drinks.

Traditional Thai Style House in the Middle of Bangkok. This was our first taste of Thailand when we first arrived and was a nice short introduction after having just been on a plane and not slept for 18 hours! The tour is about half an hour and is very informative but you are also given the opportunity to walk round parts of it at your leisure after the tour. The house is really beautiful and gives you a good taste of Thai architecture and design (even though Jim Thompson was an American!)
Very interesting. Great artifacts from Asia. His collection is amazing and you kinda see why he went missing because his knowledge of antiques and Asian history must have been imposing at the time.

One hour away.... It's a nice place to visit and forget about Bangkok hectic life. Jim Thompson integrated into Thai culture and practices their traditional way of living, as well as makes dinning room more suitable for his western guests. Beautiful house and garden.

A must see. This place will take you back in time when the city didn't tower over you and the lush tropical feeling consumed you. See a magnificent home of legendary Jim Thompson and see how this man lived in local style.

Beautiful spot in the middle of Bangkok. Easily accessible by the BTS sky train, short walk from the station. The estate is beautifully preserved and tended. Not as much insight as I had wished on Jim Thompson's personal life but one certainly can sense the grandeur that once was in the good old days when he threw dinner parties. Good to soak in the atmosphere and wander around the gardens.

Take time out from Bangkok. We've been to Bangkok many times & have never gotten around to visiting.It's very easy to get to, a few minutes walk from National Staduim.It's amazing on a few fronts- the location, nestled amongst modern condos &minutes from one of the busiest streets in Bangkok The garden- what an oasis on a hot day, again hidden away in that location.Lastly, that the whole place has been so well looked after. The house doesn't seem so unusually set out to us, but it would have been quite different for the Thai people who helped construct it. The house is full of antiques & Jim has recycled interesting pieces, such as chandeliers from palaces. It is a great/ lucky thing that the house has been maintained as he left it. It has lots of important art pieces & history that could easily have been lost with the modern world creeping up on it from all sides.The tour goes for 35 minutes & are held continuously, so you don't need to book ahead. You can take external photos, but none inside the house.It does not go into detail about his disappearance & it's not the time or place to pick him apart with tour guide, as one of the visitors tried on our tour.It's a place to take a break from the heat, noise & pace of Bangkok. Enjoy.

A nice way to spend and hour or two. We read a lot about this place and thought we would check it out. Even the kids enjoyed the tour and seeing how he lived. It is a beautiful place and worth a visit.
Interesting. this tourist attraction was recommended by our son. We found it very interesting and learnt a lot about the silk industry.

History and tranquility. I love traditional Thai teak houses, and you wont find much better than this. Preserved as a historical museum, i highly suggest a visit here one day. Tucked down a little soi near MBK..Good food too.
Great excursion with a tour and history. Did this one morning as was impressed with the English tour and history provided. Easy to get to via train. Would definately recommend

works of art in a beautiful place. One of my favorite places in the world. This house is beautiful and the garden is lovely.
The works of art are exquisite and the atmosphere is very peaceful - incredible for a top tourist destination.

High quality silk and stuff. Love the place. If you are wonder around Bangkok and looking for something as a gift for the person back home, here is the place to visit.
Fair price and unique.

Wonderful tree covered home with a story!. This lovely home, owned by the late Jim Thompson, houses lots of artifacts, art, statues and love. The wood is unbelievable. Our tour guide was fantastic! This is a great 1hr tour that should be on everyone's list of things to see in Bangkok.

Some interesting history. The owner of the hotel in which we stayed recommended we take this tour. Jim Thompson is the individual credited with introducing Thai silk to the world. You can take a tour of his house which was built from teak and designed in the local Thai style. It's about a 40 minute tour and a bit of a history lesson.

Beautiful architechture!. Really really amazing peaceful tranquil house. Great place to buy some silks and things for the kids too. Take care when walking around the house as you need to climb a little bit as you move from room to room.

A Breath of Fresh Air. A small, peaceful museum of Thompson's house. It was well shaded and cooler than many of the other popular attractions I visited. There is also a nice cafe and restaurant on the property. I had a relaxing time here.

For me, it was a waste of time. In hindsight, somewhat a waste of time, unless you basically live in Bangkok and have infinite time to explore. The house is "nice" and there are some interesting (albeit a limited collection) Thai art objects, gathered by Jim Thompson. But nothing more than that.The guided tour was, unfortunately, very poor. The guide was a young Thai lady, whose English was incomprehensible and who seemed not to know basic facts about the house beyond the manual she must have memorized. For example: what is the area of the house? It took my group some longer time and a joint effort of both the native and non-native English speakers to make her understand this and other questions. Still, she was not able to answer any of them.

Great tours!. This was one of my favorite things I did in Bangkok. It is a beautiful house that has been preserved and changed into a museum. The tours are small (8-10 people) and the tour guides were so knowledgeable and friendly. From what I can remember, the tours ran pretty regularly (every 20-30 minutes). We really learned a lot not only about Jim Thompson and Thai silk but also about Thai culture in general. If you have the time, definitely go see this!
Silk history. Easy to get to by skytrain then walk a few blocks. Guides were great and had lots of interesting history to tell.

Guide will introduce JimThamson's collection ahd his life in Thailand. How to combine 6 building in one, is not mention. 中文導覽在捷運有免費接駁車。原以為會介紹，如何將6棟泰式建築結合成一棟，導覽多著重在JimThamson 個人收藏及生活方式，讓人有點失望。Guide will introduce JimThamson's collection ahd his life in Thailand. How to combine 6 building in one, is not mention a lot.

Interesting. i am not really much into yankee showmanship but this has a bit of intrigue about it.
The house,or houses are old traditional Thai style houses modernised by the ingenuity of Thompson,s architecture skills.
There is a good collection of musuem pieces.
The guide gave a good explanation of the houses and the antiquities.

Lovely buildings, lack of silk. Jim Thompson's house is a beautiful example of architecture but I was expecting a lot more information and examples of silk to be included. Unfortunately our tour guide was a trainee who was quite difficult to understand and was lacking a little in information. I'm glad I went but would struggle to recommend it.

Must see hidden gem in Bangkok. This is my favourite place in Bangkok, it's like a tiny retreat in the middle of the city. Tours are in different languages, it's worth seeing at least once. The story behind the place is quite interesting, the restaurant on site serves great stuff.

Lovely lush garden and teak house. Good 30 min tour, some beautiful antiques and seriously old Buddhas on view. Respite from busy BKK in lush garden and charming house next to a canal. Restaurant good for a rest and Thai snacks. Shop has beautiful Jim Thomson silk, wool and cotton clothing, scarfs and bags. They can fill out a VAT claim form for you if needed.

Bangkok's hidden secrets. This museum has collection of beautifully restored wooden traditional Thai houses, which are well preserved; set in a lovely garden and all the information you need to know about silk, silk making and the King of silk. Our guide was very knowledgeable and it took about 45 minutes to give us a tour on the property, which also houses many precious antiques. Will definitely return….

Too crowded.. Was nice to see such an untouched area left in the middle of Bangkok. This was however too crowded for us and really offputting. We paid for the tour however seeing the amount of people and given the extreme heat on the day, had some food at the restaurant and gave up.

Wonderful place in Bangkok. Jim Thompson House was not in our plans for our short weekend visit to Bangkok but we ended up spending lesa time in the Chatchuk Market than planned so decided to go. Great and wonderful surprise! The place is beautiful, pleasant and the tour of 40 minutes to the house is very nice. The shop has very nice silk products at reasonable prices and the restaurante is very good (it was lunch time so we took a chance and did not regret it. A must go in Bangkok!
It is just the business. The house and the stoy is nothing special. I never write any comment on trip advisor but just as no way it deserves such a high rate.

lovely insite into the Bangkok of a previous era!. We loved our visit here!The price is low and includes a guided tour - with a wonderful guide who was friendly, great english skills and mad eeverything fun!Made the trip much more interesting having a guide who coul tell us about everything! The gardens are beautiful and an oasis in Bangkok! A lovely way to spend a few hours and wonder about the mystery of Jim Tom!
