An oasis in busy Bkk. Like an oasis in the heart of Bkk, this house is a very charming and green. Love the way Jim Thompson had created new living space from old Thai structutres. The tour is arranged well but it is a little bit rush. Do not miss the gallery space on the second floor of main house.
lovely cool gardens. Something a bit different to the many temple tours .the tour guide spoke good english and afterwards you can sit in the cafe and have a nice wine.Right opposite the sky train

A Must. In Bangkok, even if you only have a little bit of time, go to the Jim Thompson house. The atmosphere in the old teak house is amazing, and Thompson's life and mysterious disappearance
are fascinating stories to hear.
A haven in the big city. Very popular but a very quiet tranquil environment. Very interesting tour. The items for purchase are beautiful but pricey.

Interesting morning spent at the Jim Thompson House - but don't take pictures in the shop!. Decided to visit during our holiday in Bangkok. It was easily accessible, being only a five minute walk from the BTS (Skytrain). There is a free shuttle (Golf buggy which takes you from the end of the street to the main road, but we never used it). Visitors are given a tour time, dependent on their language. Shoes are not allowed to be worn in the house and they have to be put into free, onsite storage lockers. The tour itself was fine and reasonably interesting, although a bit superficial. That said, it was pretty cheap for a 40 minute tour. There are other buildings in the small complex including a shop where silk items are sold. **Warning** - no photography is allowed in the shop, as I found out to my cost by a rather aggressive female staff member woman who approached me when she saw me taking a picture of my wife in the shop. A bit over the top, in my view.Other than that, visit was as expected and a reasonably pleasant experience. Other than the shop, there is also an exhibition on the first floor which has various videos of the silk trade.

details of visiting. This place is good tourist attraction in the heart of Bangkok, not too far from Siam district. Thai and some other old sculptures and arts are kept there, like a museum, and exploring Thai-traditional house is interesting.

good surprise. as it was very hot in Bangkok, we were looking for a visit which did not expose us too much to the heatwhen you come out of the skytrain, ask a local for the small lane leading you to the Jim Thompson house: really a good surprise : very well renovated traditional house , interesting guided tour and a nice walk to the klong nearby where you can take a boat back to the river! and not too hot!

Great house at the heart of Bangkok. We went there during the last day in our stay in Thailand because it is conveniently located few steps away from our hotel (Muangphol Mansion). Definitely, Jim Thompson house experience is worth it! When you get there you have to queue for about 15 to 30 mins to wait for the tour guide to the house. Entrance fee is 150 baht about $5. We got there at 9:20AM and waited for 20 mins for our tour's turn. I think the more late you go, the longer you have to wait. My family was combined with 6 other tourist for our group tour to the house. Everything inside and outside the house was amazing! You will appreciate antiques and architecture of the house built by Jim Thompson. Everything there is thoroughly and artistically planned to every bit of its detail. The tour guide can speak clear English. There is also a relaxing cafe beside a huge koi pond if you want to lounge after the tour. Overall, its really a different experience going there. You might consider going to this place to maximize your Bangkok experience!
to spend some spare time. We went there at the end of our visit in BKK. OK, yes, there he lived J.T , and it was good to see how a wooden thai house was made of , but that's it....

Historic Wooden Houses for tour and silk shop. Make sure to visit this museum of a collection of Thailand wooden houses, collected by an American silk merchant in the late 40s; these houses are well preserved and good tours are offered. Also able to visit a silk workshop via provided transportation.
Thai silk. Over priced! This is the place if you want authentic Jim's Thai silk. Otherwise, you can get similar items for less else where.

Beautiful house with interesting story. Definitely worth a visit to this beautiful hidden house with its amazing cool garden. Get to know something about Jim Thompson, his spectacular collections and his life in Thailand. Our English guide provided us with all the information we needed and you can feel free to peacefully walk around and enjoy beauty of architecture. Oh and don't miss on delicious cocktails at Jim Thompson Restaurant. Very well spent day I must say.

Worthy. To feel really the blood of an authentic thai house.Such in a good taste of choice of fabrics, carpenters and paint colors!The gardens around are lovely and peaceful along the little river.Shop and quality restaurant in the same area

The asking of Thai silk. There are several traditional Thai houses connecting to each other. Here you can see how life once was. Jim Thompson's antic collection is here to be seen. It is located in the middle of Bangkok and next to the river.

A taste of days gone by. As bkk becomes more western and like many other big cities of the world, so good to have a hidden gem of how life used to be. You feel you are stepping back in time as you are led through the residence of the very interesting Jim Thompson, who had the most amazing sense of style and taste. Also see a very successful business in action (if you do buy gifts for friends and family tell them the background and the wonderful quality of the goods. People may not appreciate how wonderful their gift is. If you have time visit their factory shop Soi 93 or 95 Sukhumvit (ask for closest bts Stop) a must if you love fabric 3/4 floors of amazing silks and cottons and lots of little and light gifts at reasonable prices. E..g purses, scarfs Lovely mature garden and the cafe is very well run and food is of a good standard. Nice break from hustle and bustle.
Good to see. Very nice staff. A nice visit of a 'traditional' Thai wooden house, and very good food at the restaurant next to it.

Set expectations low to be surprised. This place was not originally on my "must-do" list for a short Bangkok stay, but I met up with a jet-lagged friend and decided that we could handle something easily accessible from our hotel. With low expectations, we went on the obligatory tour -- and LOVED it! The simple architecture, the lush gardens and the historical importance of a fellow American made me feel a deep connection to a piece of the past. It's a small place, with live exhibits showing silk worms and old-fashioned spinning wheels. A very nice shop sells silks of excellent quality. The highlight of the place, however, is the excellent, air-conditioned restaurant. It takes a while to get used to the heat of Bangkok, and the restaurant knew just what we needed -- icy fruit drinks and delicious appetizers to share! A bonus was the free "luxury" tuk-tuk to take people to the transit station.

Beautiful house hidden. Not people know about Jim house. Its probably hidden somewhere in the lonely planet bangkok guide . Jim thompson is a beautiful traditionnal thai house hidden in Bangkok's sky scrapers.Take the afternoon to visit in order to hide from the agonizing heat, and discover the bangkok lifestyle back in the time.

Very Pleasant morning. II had no interest in visiting yet another "shopping opportunity" but it ws included on the tour one of my companions had organized so I went along. Thus, I was extremely pleasantly surprised by the lovely gardens and home of Jim Thompson, a formed member of OSS who returned to Thailand, created an internationally reknown Thai silk industry, and then mysteriously disappeared. This is a lovely, quiet, peaceful place to visit amidst the noise, crowds, and heat of Bangkok. It is especially welcome after visiting other tourist spots such as the palace, temples, markets and so on. And yes, there are many luscious silks on sale that are pricey but hard to resist.

Beautiful site but lacks info on owner. Jim Thompson's house is built in traditional Thai style from a house he bought and moved from Ayutthaya. Set in a lovely tropical garden on stilts with wooden shutters it is furnished with a fascinating collection of sculptures, paintings and furniture. He was obviously a highly successful artist and businessman so it was disappointing that this museum does not include more about the man and the silk design business he set up in Thailand.

It's great but not THAT great.. The Jim Thompson house is a nice place. There's a lot of history here, and judging from the location you can tell it's much different than anything on the block. The gardens are nice, but I didn't explore them too closely. They charge just 150 baht, However, I'm compelled to say that the restaurant next door is a far more charming place to be, even though the food is much more expensive.

Underwhelming. I can't see what people love about this place. The history of the man is dull and unengaging and this is his mansion. I am still unsure about what I was supposed to be looking at whilst I was there or what I was supposed to be amazed by. I don't usually buy silk so I can't say if the gift shop is overpriced or not but it's definitely expensive. Also, it always bugs me when properties don't allow the taking of photographs. If you're passing, drop in but apart from that - don't go out of your way.

A Must See!. I had read about this place on TA but to be honest didn't think we would go there as I didn't really know the history of this place. We met a couple who had been there earlier and explained it was easy to get there by walking from the Princess hotel. The next day we got instructions from the concierge at the hotel made our way over there. It was really quite easy to find - through MBK - across the bridge to the sky train, don't go into the sky train - just go over to the other side of the road. Turn left (away from the Paragon) and walk past about 3 or 4 streets on your right - and you will see a sign pointing out the Jim Thompson house. You go in buy your entrance ticket go through the main gate and up to the desk on your left. The staff will tell you which tour group your in and what time you are going through. We waited about 20 minutes for our tour - but that time evaporated quickly whilst walking around the lush gardens and beautiful ponds all stocked with a variety of fish. On to the tour with a very good English speaking guide - who at times had a very good sense of humour. She explained everything there was about the owner and all about the house and the changes he introduced that the Thai people were astonished by. Jim Thompson was an American Architect who loved Thailand and the people and he is the reason why the silk trade has blossomed world wide. If you want to know more about him or what became of him - don't google it - just go there and find out for yourselves - you will not be disappointed.You can buy various items of clothing etc from the shop there but also try and go there and have lunch or dinner. The restaurant there is exceptional quality - and the prices are more than reasonable. Oh and at the end of your tour and if you take in the restaurant - there is a free shuttle service which will take you back to the main road, this will probably save you about 6-700m of walking - but after eating at the restaurant you might prefer to walk to walk off the food you devoured.This is just another one of Bangkok's hidden secrets worth seeking out. I would definitely recommend this to anyone with a couple of hours to spare.

Beautiful oasis in desert of concrete. This is definitely a must see. Nthe collection of art and the house and gardens themselves are a wonderful space to go and see. Who knows what his true story is, but he certainly was a talented collector!

Don't miss out on this charmer. I chose to go by myself using the sky train instead of traveling with a private guide. It is much cheaper and easy to do alone. With a guide it is about $50 alone about $5 or $6 U.S. Including sky fare to get there and back. The historic Thai homes are well positions and gave a great history of the silk trade brought into world trade by Jim It's lovely and informative. I spent extra time there just because of the atmosphere. You just get off at the national stadium and go down exit #1 and walk a block until you see the sign to turn right. If your lucky a little shuttle goes up and down the alley like road for free transport.

NIce piece of architecture and History. Visited this place with the family because my sis being an architectural student, wanted to visit this place. Admission is 150Baht per person and there is no photography allowed within the main compound. There are guided tours (for those who paid the 150Baht) in various languages, e.g. English, Chinese, Thai which explains Jim Thomson's background, his inspiration and the beuaty of the house which he built. A nice fusion of Thai and Western cultures, it is a nice place to visit amongst the hustle and bustle of the Thai Capital. Nestled nicely in the neighbourhood of MBK Centre and Siam Square/Siam Paragon, it's a nice place to escape to before continuing on the shopping, eating journey in Bangkok.

Charming and well styled. A quiet, almost romantic sort of place. The guides are very knowledgeable and speak excellent English - it is evident that they are proud of the place and happy to share the many charming stories of JT's life and creative endeavors. The tour only takes about 40 mins, and you spend the other 15 mostly waiting around and admiring the beautiful compound. There's a posh cafe attached whose menu prices commiserates with prices from the shop. Sadly, although JT's shop is large the range is not fantastic and I can typically find better (that is broader) selections back home in KL. This surprised me. A good and restful place to visit on the last leg of your trip, or after a particularly grueling walking tour. A very short walk from the Skytrain - no taxis necessary.

architectural delight. a very beautiful mixture of Thai and European style architecture, the house is made of wood and overlooks a garden which is truly a sight in itself. located very close to the BTS National stadium station, this property is extremely easily accessible,I have visited it twice and surely recommend it.

No photos inside the house. We did a tour of Jim Thompson house. It was interesting. But just letting you know no photos are allowed to be taken in the house. The history was cool and it was interesting to look at all the artifacts. The shop is expensive. It is close to the wharf which is an easy walk the the house. The grounds are nice for photos.

Interesting, informative but nothing exciting. I found this place a little bit boring to be honest. I was in a group of about 12 and they took us through Jim Thompson's actual house and did a tour of the whole place room by room. Beautifuly Thai designed rooms, furniture and antiques all on display. The house is in a beautiful garden area with many ponds, trees, gardens and places to relax. Nothing exciting however I thought.

display of thai and european architecture. i have visited this place twice already but don't mind visiting again. it is beautiful! the garden was a sight to behold. the house itself had a story to tell. the materials used in building the house were impeccable and so were its decors. it's just sad that its owner did not enjoy his house for a longer time since his disappearance is a mystery to this day. worth spending time in checking it out.

Worth it. Well maintained house and garden. Friendly staff. Many nice southeastasian pieces of art from different periods. Jim Thompson himself also has an interesting story which adds to the interest of the place.

Beautiful Garden and wooden house. This is a beautiful Thai style wooden house and a beautiful, colourful and well maintained garden. Guides show you around the different rooms. You may also buy nice silkwear and have a pleasant meal and drinks.

Simply a delight. The Jim Thompson House is not one house but several traditional timber houses sensitively put together. The curators have managed to preserve the atmosphere of the private residence and art collection of someone in love with thai art and culture. Each of the pieces have clearly been put together, not just as individual articles but fitting in to an overall conception of style and intimacy. The guides are non-intrusive,sensitive and knowledgable. There is also a good shop showing the best of Jim Thompson silks - but for better prices just try the Jim Thompson factory shop at the Tesco MRT stop at On Nut (96 Soi Pungmee 29 Sukhumvit 93 Road). This shop also has a decent restaurant for tired and hungry shoppers,

Quite interesting.... ...the house is pretty spectacular, and my boyfriend who is a carpenter, was very impressed by the wood carvings on the furniture. It's a nice little serene place considering its location-perhaps I'm just not overly bothered about nice old things. Or pottery...

Jim Thompson tour is a great way to spend a couple of hours and the guides are really great.. Quiet and peaceful tour busy but you won't notice as the groups are well organized. Take the sky train and a short walk.
beautiful thai silks. a fascinating history of the founder of Jim Thompson Silk Emporium, given by lovely guides while touring the house(es) he combined into one in which he lived.

Also a nice visit in Bangkok. Jim thompson house is easily reachable by klong boat of Bts National Stadium. The traditional house gives you a good view about silk. The guides give a good view on silk manufactioring. A good restaurant is on site.

Great way to understand how Thai silk empire was built + the mystery of Jim Thompson. Get ready to get tangled in the unsolved mystery of Jim Thompson. Guided tours available. Easily accessible location. A must do in BKK...

A must when you want to see a lot of Thai antique art. Go during the week, the guides have more time for you, afterwards have something to eat the food is very good and the beer garden is very pleasant. Fo the more adventurous take a boat trip on the klong just a short walk away to get on

Jim Thompson House. I last visited this house in 1988. I was so looking forward to re-visiting, but the experience was spoiled by being herded 'round like sheep during the guided tour, and also having a guide whose English was poor. The house itself is beautiful, and I would have preferred to walk alone with an audio guide or signage placed by the important pieces. The shop was quite well stocked, but the book shop was closed for some reason. If you are banned from taking photos it would be nice to have the opportunity to buy postcards or a book. The cafe has been built since I last visited. The food was good and plenty of seating available, plus the prices were fair.

A Step Back in Time. Outstanding experience. Impressive garden, interesting house and furnishings, and lovely restaurant. Easy to get to by BTS. Makes you want to build your own thai home. The only disappointment was not being allowed to take pictures inside the house.

Historical Thai architecture. This is worth a visit, it is small. Very small. But nonetheless worth a visit and very interesting. I actually wandered around and took photos myself, there is an entry fee, and it is only cheap and goes toward a worthwhile cause.

Jim Thompson House. Beautiful house and grounds, also demonstration of silk being made as well as a shop with pashmina and silk scarves for purchasing. Jim Thompson put Thai silk on the western fashion map and became famous after his fabrics were used in the movie "The King and I"

Pleasant get-away hidden in the heart of Bangkok. Jim Thompson, the man was fascinating on many levels -- first as a US spy and agent during WWII, then as the "Silk King" of Bangkok who mysteriously disappeared in the jungles of Malaysia on an Easter weekend vacation, but also as an art collector and aesthetic genius who amassed quite a collection of sculptures and furniture in his lovely house (actually, there are six houses on the small property). Go for an afternoon visit and stop in the lovely restaurant on site for an afternoon tea or lunch by the Koi Pond. The Thompson House is just a great way to glimpse nostalgically into imagining what Bangkok must have been like just after the "Last Good War" (WWII) right through to the disillusionment and betrayal of American values in the tragic Indochina War in the 1960s. A great way to pass a hot afternoon in the steamy heart of Bangkok!

ah the jim thompson house!!!. along the klong (river) in bkk you can go by long boats at jim thompson house such beautiful place to relax have breakfast in amazing place with garden jim T bring the business of silk in thailand & disappear in cameron highlands in malaysia go there in a morning early is the best by longboats

The best non spiritual thing to do in Bangkok. So I'm not too much into temples and once u have seen a monkey you have seen them all, same goes for the malls.Though Jim Thompson house is a place I enjoy and recommend. It takes you through various forms of Thai architecture and gives u a story of a man that is still missing in action... It's a great experience for 2 hrs max and it sits on the back of the shopping district. This place is not fit for people who have difficulty going up and down stairs.The restaurant on the grounds is very good though a little pricey, booking are not necessary.

Interesting tour. I enjoyed the tour of the Jim Thompson house. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and had fun facts about each room in the house. The only thing I wish there was more of was the actual silks.

A must visit.... We lived in BKK for over on year. Jim Thompson House was our regular go to lunch and dinner on weekends. The house is now a museum. There is also a shop on the property. But the restaurant and beer garden are outstanding. This is the best Thai food in BKK in my opinion. The place is very neat, service is terrific and the food is authentic.

Silky smooth. Great experience. Learn the entire process how silk is formed. From those pesky little worms to the intricate processes the artisans use to create devine silk products. To top it off, you will be in the home of the very intriguing and mysterious Jim Thompson.
A must see for silk lovers. We brought a beautiful silk shirt for $AUS200 & a silk scarf as a Mothers Day gift, just delightful.. The house itself is inspiring in building our own Thai home..

Jim Thompson, the Legend, His Art and His Mystery.. Jim Thompson is a legend in Thailand, during World War II and the Japanese occupation of Thailand he worked underground as an agent for the US Office of Special Services. After the war he settled permanently in Thailand. Jim Thompson had a passion for art but trained as an architect and besides his war time adventures he was a man of exquisite aesthetic taste. When he first settled in Bangkok in the late 1940s he discovered Thai silk and instantly saw a business opportunity. Unfortunately the art of silk making was dying in Thailand but Jim Thompson was intent on reviving this ancient craft. He established silk weaving schools and workshops in northern Thailand.Like many before and after him Jim Thompson was captivated by Thailand, its people, culture and art. He was a major collector of South East Asian art; amassing an extensive collection of artworks from around South East Asia. The pinnacle of his collecting passion was the brining together of six traditional teak houses from Ayutthaya and reassembling them into one large Thai-style house sitting on the banks of a klong (canal). He decorated the house with works from his collection; from ancient Buddha statues to exquisite and delicate pieces of pottery and traditional Thai paintings. He also furnished the house with examples of Thai furniture.The garden is a restful space giving a little haven to shade from the heat of the day. It is planted with tropical plants, and shady palms and has a carp pond, it is worth wandering around the garden to admire the plants and soak up the tranquility.Jim Thompson died in mysterious circumstances. While on holiday in Malaysia’s Cameron Highlands, he wandered into the rain forest and was never seen again, he simply disappeared without trace. There are many versions of how he met his end. At the time Malaya was about to gain independence from the UK. There was a large communist insurgency that British forces eventually defeated, some believe that Jim Thompson was on a mission for the CIA and was captured by the communist fighters and killed.However he met his end in the fifty or so years since his body has never been found.

Check it Out If its Convenient. If you are near check out Jim Thompson house but I dont think that it will make or break your trip. People say the inside is beautiful and I would agree but in no way is it a "must do"

A small place but wonderful experience. I do like the Jim Thompson house, it's a small location as it was his house. It tells the story and exhibits his property beautifully. Well worth a trip. It's not that expensive and you get a guide on the way through. You can then wander round at your leisure and there is a lovely cafe there too and of course a shop displaying it's wares. It's a little surprising that the tuk tuks etc don't seem to know where it is, but it's not far off the BTS - sorry forgot the station - once you find that it's just a short walk round the corner.

A must visit in Bangkok. If you visit Bangkok you must go to the Jim Thompson House. It is a beautiful example of a wooden house of old Thailand. you can imagine the lifestyle of someone living in the house there is beautiful artwork. I would also recommend the cafe at the house we had a brilliant lunch there. We regretted not going for an evening meal.

Not so charming in real life. Although he was never rich and he spent most of his money on his works of art, Jim Thompson had excellent taste. The photos of his house, often taken at night and photos on Google images and in the coffee table book, "The House on the Khlong," looked so gorgeous (with dramatic indoor lighting showing objects of art to best advantage) that we could hardly wait to go and be charmed by the Jim Thompson House which closes at 5 pm. The complex of store, restaurant, and houses is such a small space, and there are so many people queued up to see them that everyone has to join a tour of 10-12 people. As one tour left a room, another tour entered it. Thus, at mid-day there was no dramatic lighting, the works of art were surrounded by tourists, and those who preferred to contemplate the atmosphere had to keep up with their group. Half of the complex was astir with groups stowing their things in lockers, taking off their shoes, or putting on their shoes. Although it is easy to reach the house by Skytrain, we think it is even easier to take Khlong Saen Saep boats from Pratunam to the Hua Chang landing. The house is worth seeing, well worth the small price of the "tour," but not at all as charming as we expected.

Visit to Jim Thompson House. Jim Thompson House was not on our priorities when we visited Bangkok, however, we are really glad we did visit it as it was one of our highlights.The house doesn't seem like much coming up from the road but it is really impressive once inside. The grounds are absolutely lovely. The garden is impressive and quite peaceful. We took the tour as well and loved seeing the house in its (mostly) original form. If you like history and art, then you will truly love this place. We also sat in the restaurant for a meal. The meal was good and prices were decent. Overall, I would highly recommend this sight.
oldfashion style outlet and fabrics. I like the place the building but the items proposed to be sold are such crappy oldfashion ugly and the prices are outrageous!!! Chocking! good for grannies

Worth Visiting. Visiting Jim Thompson's house is a unique experience in that one is able to get some insight into how life could have been lived. The house is an interesting collection of houses skillfully blended into one wonderful home. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and was able to answer any questions asked of her.After our visit we had lunch at the restaurant and similarly enjoyed the food and the ambiance...a modern experience in proximity to a piece of heritage.
Pretty near. Cool place to visit. Take about 1 hrs or so to walk around. I enjoyed it but won't return again. Pretty pricey for the entrance fee.

For culture lovers . This may not be what everyone likes doing.As a designer and as one who buys Jim Thompson fabrics for my projects, this was a must do.This place is not just a peek into Thompsons life but a slice of history as well. Maggie's you what Thai architecture ( residential) is like.Good personal collection and most interesting.

On the tourist path, but well worth a visit. Although the Jim Thompson house is in every guidebook and very well frequented, it is for a reason. It is one of the highlights of Bangkok and very well maintained an organized. A guide is compulsory but they are very professional. The house and small gardens are so lovely. There is also a shop and very nice cafe. Walking distance from the National Stadium Skytrain (BTS) station. Very near the commercial hear of Bangkok.
Beautiful building. Loved the place, the gardens, the silks and the restaurant. Highly recommended. Just off the main National Stadium BTS (Skytrain) Station and near to MBK shopping mall.

Touristy but nice place. Visited for the first time and found only few Thai people (guests).. I guess Jim Thompson is more well known for tourists so that's why. The house tour was ok- in a good time frame. Liked how they keep &maintain the house.

Very interesting. I like the history around Jim Thompson. I like the well preserved homes turned into museum. However I find the goods in the gift shop very expensive. I couldn't even buy a piece of hanky. :(

Great attraction . Not too far from the BTSstation and not too long to walk around on the compulsory tour. Beautiful setting in the centre of Bangkok. The garden is a great reason to visit by itself. Also, go early if you can. All in all a great tourist spot, and you can't say that very often!

Great place.. Nice garden, good guide to take you around (obligatory) and nice bar to end the experience with a good drink. And yes, we bought some things at the shop as well. I would definitely recommend this as it is an experience that doesn't feel like you're in crowded Bangkok.
A good piece of history. It's a well set up site to see. The house is very nice and well kept. The story is also interesting. I went via the canal boat from Bodega Bangkok, what a trip!!!

Amazing Story Of Jim Thompson and Saving the Thai Silk Industry. This museum/tour tells the story of an enigmatic American OSS Officer (precursor to the CIA) and Bangkok resident who lived in the beautiful home on the banks of a canal (khlong), saving the Thai silk industry and then mysteriously disappearing in Malaysia in the 1960's. Jim loved Thai culture and art and collected many beautiful items which he displayed in this house, built from several smaller Thai teak homes, using the old timber to form a larger structure where he regularly entertained overlooking the factory on the other side of the khlong where Muslim workers hand-loomed beautiful silk creations.Jim was credited with single-handedly saving the Thai silk industry, which although an exageration, the industry flourished after his silk was chosen for the sets of the film "The King and I". The house was a beautiful home to Jim's lavish collection of objets d'art and was built from many up country teak houses around 1958. The tour of the house is very informative and the groups are small and tailored to your native language, so I joined an English tour. The Buddhist and Thai cultural artifacts are quite amazing and the house is so beautiful and surrounded by verdant gardens and guest/servant homes which are smaller than the main structure.The story is fascinating and the home and gardens beautiful.A must-see in Krung Thep Maha Makhorn. I want to return again one day.

Nice to see. The architecture and furnishing of Jim Thompson's house was amazing. I liked to learn how silk was produced and processed the original way. The only thing that bothered me a little was short gaps between each group, so if one guide/group was a bit slower than the other, 2 groups bumpbed into each other. Which was a bit uncomfortable and distracting.

A glimpse into the past.. I have toured the Jim Thompson twice. Once in 1998, and on this trip in June 2015. It is vastly improved! Old houses were moved from other places in Thailand. Important point is that the house is actually multiple smaller houses assembled together. It is beautifully restored and very interesting. It is not a purely Thai home and the guides will tell you the whys and why nots. Definitely a worthwhile sightseeing spot. There is a restaurant on site as well. Which has a good reputation, but I did not eat there.

Jim Thompson House a relaxing break from temple tours. Very peaceful and cool ambiance within the Jim Thompson House compound-- very welcome respite from the heat and the seemingly-unending temple tour. Tour was very brief and while it had the basic details and information about JT and his life in Thailand, I felt it lacked depth, especially when it came to the man and his character, his passion for thai silk, etc. The boutique is extremely overpriced, although some pieces were very nice looking. Eating at the restaurant was a much better experience than the tour itself.

Nice detour from the chaos of Bangkok. The house of Jim Thompson is a oasis of peace among the bustling chaos of Bangkok. Beautiful colonial house and a fascinating story behind the man. You can only visit with a tour guide.

Nice Place.. Really beautiful home but not really what I expected. I thought I would be able to find lots of silk fabrics to buy, but there wasn't much and it was expensive. You are not allowed to take pictures inside either. But it was a very interesting architecture and art inside. The restaurant there was fantastic and no dress code.

Must See. We were a family of five. Mom, dad, three children (2 college, 1 in high school). The Jim Thompson House was easy to reach. The tour was well-organized, enlightening; but not tiring.everyone liked it. The guide took our group through a series of original Thai houses arranged around a shady garden. Antiques, paintings, furniture fill the houses and represent, not only some of the finest aspects of Thai culture but also the intriguing personal life story of Jim Thompson.There is a shop (of course) and a restaurant but we didn't eat there. Visiting these houses completed our picture of Bangkok.

Very Advisable. The tour is not long, but very interesting. The guides of the museum speak good American English. You can buy good quality silk things in its shops though in the international duty free the same things were a bit cheaper.The museum sends a tuck-tuck to the nearest station to pick you up if you contact them by phone.

Cluster of 6 traditional Thai houses. Thai Silk king, Jim Thompson's house in Bangkok. The house is located next to Klong Maha Nag (canal) and had its own boat dock. Tours are guided. Your have to deposit your belongings into lockers before the tour starts. Next door is the Jim Thompson Restaurant. Interesting house to tour with an equally interesting story of Jim Thompson.
Jim Thompson Market. Besides the Jim Thompson house building, the Jim Thompson market is also a good activity to have some pure Jim Thompson experience
oasis. An interesting calm oasis away from the constant hustle and bustle of Bangkok well preserved/restored buildings well kept grounds the restaurant serves taste nibbles and cold drinks.

Nice tour. We enjoyed our tour of Jim Thompson House. The house is beautiful and the tour guide was very informative. Not sure that it is a "must see" but if you're "templed out" and want to do something different, check it out. It's located near Siam Square, convenient to the Sky Train and they also have a shuttle. Museum shop is obscenely overpriced.

Lovely dinner place. This fine dining restaurant serves traditional Thai food. Setting is pretty...there's an air conditioned n outdoor sections you can choose from. There are other places like The Never Ending Summer at Jam Factory that serves better food but nevertheless JT is worth a try. There are Thai dancers to entertain you while u eat.

Amazing, mesmerising and very interesting. Worth a visit to the place where Thailand's silk industry took off from. A fascinating insight of how they lived in the past with several antique furniture and items all over the place. Worth visiting in the morning before it gets too hot!

A really nice museum. Jim Thompson House is certainly worth a visit. We had a great tour of the house. Our guide was very knowledgable and lovely. Jim Thompson's story (his life and mystery of his disappearance) is very interesting.Logistics at the museum are convenient, you don't have to wait long before the tour starts. You can also visit a gift shop (pretty expensive but with beautiful clothes and accessories), as well as a nice restaurant.

Don't miss. Jim thompson's house is amazigly preserved old architecture. You get to join a tour once entered (might be a waiting time though, but not much) in english or french languages.The tour tells you the story of jim thompson, which is very interesting and inspiring, and also lets you enjoy the quite peaceful area, feels like you went in time when bangkok was jus a small village.Highly recommended for culture and history lovers.Entry fee is 150 bht.Bsst way to get there is National stadium bts silom line (one station from siam) and from there it's 5-10 minutes walk.
When you are in Bangkok you should visit it. When you are tiered of tempels I can really recommend Jim Thompson house. It's lioke an island of calmness in a restless City.

Good introduction. This is a good introduction to Bangkok and Thai culture. Every visitor must take a tour, which are conducted, as I recall, in English, Thai, and French. The guides are very informative about JIm Thompson's intelligently curated collection of Thai and Southeast Asian artifacts, and provide details about the people and cultures that produced them. It is also a beautiful spot, with elegantly restored buildings.The store has lovely things, on the expensive side and rather limited. The restaurant is pleasant and restful.
interesting. A glimpse of earlier times near the center of Bangkok. Nice selection of Thai silk in the shop. If one does not have the time to visit products are available at the better stores
Worth a visit. Staff are very helpful.. Interesting tour. 150 baht to enter. nice cafe. Lovely cold coconut water. Jim Thompson's house is lovely, with lots of interesting pieces and paintings.

An out of the way gem. don't miss the Jim Thompson House. Tucked away in downtown, everyone knows where it is (at least almost everyone, we got different directions from three different people). A great tour of the house itself now a museum, a lovely place to eat or watch silk thread being spun, or spend some money in their gift shop that has beautiful silk clothes and accessories. We bought scarves, ties and matching handkerchiefs. it takes about and hour and tours are in multiple languages.

Peaceful Detour. In the heart of Bangkok lies the Jim Thompson House which gives you a pretty informative tour on the house he built before he mysteriously disappeared. English speaking tour guides are available to take you through the house though they can be a little hard to understand. A restaurant and boutique is attached for you to have a nice break or browse for good quality silks. A pleasant morning to spend if you are tired of the hustle and bustle of Bangkok shopping.

Exclusive. I go to Jim Thompson every time I travel to Bangkok because I simply cannot find anywhere else the quality I get there. I usually buy table cloth, silk gowns, frames and decoartion stuffs. It is not a cheap place, but if quality is your priority, there is no place like this. You can argue that you get the same things for a fraction of the price somewhere else, but never the same quality. Go there only if you like top quality, otherwise it is not worth it.
Lovely garden to meander through.. Wonderful guided tour full of history about the house and Jim Thompson. Learnt about Thai architecture as well as Thai superstitions.

Absolute must if you are even remotely interested in SE Asian art. This is an easy place to visit if you are in siam. It can be easily reached by foot from mbk, siam center, or siam paragon.
The collection here is incredible and the houses themselves are beautiful.
Note that the admission price increased recently to 150 baht (100 baht for students, must be under 21).
A dream house. Absolutely stunning Thai architecture, great antiques, The real feel of the Thai typical house. A must see.

beautiful house, great history. This is an old teak house, created by the gentlemen who made Thai silk famous. He has a very interesting story, it's worth doing the tour. Gift shop is beautiful, unique but pricey.

Collects a variety of interesting things. Bangkok is very fortunate for the existence of this building which collects a variety of interesting things about the architecture and culture of the past around asean. Here you can see the different collections gathered by Jim Thompson and other valuable items.In addition, we were given the opportunity to get to know how the process of taking silk thread into a high value. Highly recommended for your visit, especially for education.

Interesting Visit. We visited the Jim Thompson House after some friends from home recommended it. It was a bit smaller than I anticipated, but the tour made it easy to see and appreciate the small details of the house. The home itself and surrounding gardens are gorgeous and the staff and tour guides are kind and welcoming. Exploring the house was a lovely way to spend a morning.

very interested in colonial history.. Very interested in the history of silk fabulous building and artifacts. Found it fascinating that jim was never found. Did he turn up some where else? Good location for cheap boat ride into central bangkok. Worth a visit guides good.

Amazing property, but be prepared for bugs and heat. Great place if you have the time. At the end of the memorial stadium stop via bts. Free golf cart pickup and drop off if you need. No breeze so very hot, and being somewhat of a tropical park bring your bug spray!
Not worth all the hype!. It is not worth the money. I went there because of the ratings, it is not worth the entrance fee. I rather spend my money on other activities instead.

Went 3 times, great place to visit. Great visit , humoristic and entertaining, as well as descriptive and interesting. Free shuttle to go back on the main street.Very welcoming staff.Restaurant expensive but sooooo good !!!I always bring friends and family who come to visit le in Bangkok to Jim Thompson house.

The beer could have been more fresh. A good Thai restaurant with a little dancing shows. Good food. Good and friendly service. The beer from the tap was old, but they changed into a new Keg when I informed them.
Oasis in the concrete jungle. An amazing house created from many relocated and reclaimed houses - wonderful artifacts and a nice garden. Check it out if you go to MBK or Siam Discovery shopping malls

Expensive fabrics but very classy. My Advise is to ditch the high priced Jim Thompson House and stop making the richest people richer. Go to Chinatown and there you will find plenty of fabrics for super low prices and high quality. Get one the street sewing machine ladies to make you some nice cushions for around 100THB each..and buy your fabric of your choice.
Fascinating Life Story. Take a break from shopping and head up the soi from MBK to experience the wondrous dwellings of one of the most eccentric expat in Bangkok.

Everybody goes. So should you.. [Boast coming:] I dined here when the place was still pretty much a private residence, with an old friend of Jim Thompson's in charge of the collected art. I speak from 40-something years of familiarity with the Jim Thompson House. And I never get tired of going back.The garden is a marvel. You seem to step out of the city and into a mysteriously groomed forest. The café is dandy, one of the few remaining places in the city where you can enjoy a coffee in the open air. The staff are delightful, attentive and helpful. And the art collection and houses add up to a lot more than a collection of interesting stuff. Thompson had a remarkable touch for combining fine antiquities and revealing bits of daily life to bring a whole way of seeing the world into view. His creation here remains so vital it's easy to imagine he's still nearby, perhaps around a hidden corner of the garden. Other places (like Wang Suan Pakkad) have fine collections, but only here will you see a little girl's chamberpot helping set off a collection of fine china made to order for the nobility, or the façade of a pawnshop set into the end of a corridor. If I had just two hours to show someone the spirit of Thailand as it used to be, and still is deep below the surface, I'd take her here without stopping to consider any alternative.
Great place to visit. Lovely building and very cheap entrance fee. You get a guide to walk you around and explain what you are looking at. Takes a couple of hours all together, well worth a visit

Highly recommended!. Don't miss this spot if you're traveling in Bangkok for any amount of time! Our tour guide was funny and adorable, and the house was very neat. The tour was a little short, but our favorite part was the restaurant next door. The food was simply amazing! Expensive, especially the cocktails, but totally worth it!

A Joy. An oasis of calm within a bustling metropolis. Travel there via the canal boats and step into the past. A beautiful house and an amazing story AND I have always been a fan of Jim Thompson ties - wonderful silk.

Just with you like history. The place is very beautiful. The garden. The house.You can do only guided tour. But it is included in price. I hadn't to much time, so I started my tour with a chinese group (it was funny, and the guide was very friendly) and after 20min I went to a English group.It's a good place to understand the history of Thai Silk, but... I'm not sure if it's worth paying for it.

Not another Temple. My husband was tired of the Temples, so we decided to come to the Jim Thompson House. Nice gardens, interesting house and story. Guides do a nice job. The art exhibit going on upstairs kinda left me wondering why. Free shuttle back to the main street. Nice change of pace.
Ok. JT house was better than expected. Interesting plunge into time that was. Good guided tour, not allowed to take photos inside the main building.

Interesting. Interesting story regarding Jim Thompson and his role in Thailand - do yourself a favour and research this beforehand as it will make everything that much clearer and leave you to enjoy the art and architecture. They do provide tours every 10 minutes in various languages as part of the entrance fee.There is a free shuttle from the top of the road down to the museum - just wait at the top of the road where the signs are and there will be one every 10 minutes or so. It's not a long walk otherwise but the heat and humidity mean that a little lift is very welcome. Nearest Sky Train is National Stadium.Gift shop is gorgeous, expensive and very air-conditioned so well worth a walk around.

A Fascinating Piece of Thai Histort. Jim Thompson's House in Bangkok is not one house. It is four or five old Thai teak wood houses that this American born architect collected from various parts of the country, moved to Bangkok and rebuilt as one conjoined house. For anyone interested in Thai architecture and style, a visit at least once to JT's House is a must.Thompson, a CIA operative in World War Two, settled in Thailand after the war and lived here for 22 years until his mysterious disappearance in Malaysia's Cameroon Highlands in 1967.The house(s) still contain much of the furniture and household artifacts that JT collected during his travels in SE Asia, providing an interesting time warp back to the 50s and 60s.There is a Baht 100 fee and experienced guides will give you a fascinating 40 minute tour, after which you are free to wander around at your leisure.Unfortunately no cameras are allowed.

Beautiful Traditional Thai Residence Compound. I knew little of the Thai silk industry or it's origins. The tour of this beautifully maintained residence provided a comprehensive history of the founder of the industry in Thailand as well as the construction of his residence.

Great piece of art history in the heart of the city. We went here during our first time in BKK and let me tell you, it's such an awe-inspiring piece of history! You can see where James H.W. used to live and it transports you back in time. I didn't buy anything though as the items are expensive but the place is great to understand more about how they used to live. Really imperial and all.

adventure for couples or family. very nice house and history, feeling little like in a old James Bond movie :) worth to go, use the water channel it makes it even more exiting. restaurant looks pretty good but didn't try this time..
Very interesting. The house and museum are fascinating: the tours are excellent, good value, and there is an atmosphere of reverence and slight sadness here.

Well worth a visit.. It is well worth a visit to this famous house. Don't expect the visit to reveal much about J. Thompson life, all you will learn is really about what you see. I found out after from a friend, what a fascinating person J. T. Was. If you enjoy the visit it may trigger your curiosity to explore J. T. Life further.
Jim Thompson SilkHouse. Interesting story about this man and his disappearance, he's held in high regard by the Thais. Lovely home. Beautiful silk items in shop.

Great piece of Thai history. We have been to the Jim Thompson Estate a number of times now and still find it fascinating. The whole story of this pioneers life is remarkable and his love for the kingdom evident. Nearby small print shops sell a number of silk effects as well as paintings. Easy access via BTS, am sure we will return on our next visit to Bangkok.

Excellent!. We ate here 3 times ; twice for lunch and once for dinner. The service and food were really fantastic! Cost and value for money were also excellent?
Peaceful surroundings and very clean. Highly recommended

Not to be missed. I was impressed by the presentation and how well it is preserved. It is a great clash and merge of the two cultures - American and Asian. Guided tours are offered in EN and some languages I don't remember now and the guides are nice and answer any questions. A restaurant near the house (part of the complex) is a good choice for a quick lunch and a drink in a nice setting. As you go out a silk shop is at hand if you are a fan of this material. Plus a free tuk-tuk to leave you near the skytrain station.

Nice place but only if you have many days in BKK. I guess I expected more, but it it a nice place to visit but definetely not one of my MOST go. The waiting list is not worth it. And the place is cool, but you cannot take photos and you go all the time guided. I rather explore than be guided.

Still rocks after all these years.... Young girls (retaining and perpetuating the art?) spinning yarns as demonstrating the silk production process, and also providing a short but quite tasteful dance routine (photo op) and heavily populated and strategically placed staff that appeared to quite enjoy themselves and reverberated joy and pleasure in welcoming us to this "long time no see" revisit. It was reassuring to see that popularity and heavy traffic has NOT made the place a lesser experience, the people working there jaded nor impatient - it is well organized and a pleasurable experience benchmarking a Thai experience of high quality - designs, culture, views and vistas, structures and gardens replete with seats in the shade while waiting, lockers, refined bathrooms, taxi and tuc tuc drop off valet man, etc = go there first (early morning suggested) and early in your Bangkok visit. Quality of guides vary with the individuals but the sights and vistas make the compound simply "a must": Restaurant further delighted with an outstanding lunch experience of both comparative complexity, presentation and quality to much higher priced establishments encountered (mango passion fruit shake!) and a sans alcohol fare for two at $38 is quite "price worthy" - Boutique is the top of the line of their outlets and presents the latest of their production and gives you a taste of both traditional and contemporary wares. Had thoroughly delightful and exceedingly helpful courteous staff assisting and was warned accurately that "some comparative products could be found at outlet store but there are no guarantees" (which just so happened to be the case so one particular scarf was purchased at nearly 50% off at the outlet) You are hereby briefed - enjoy it and use, as stated: "bench mark"

Amazing designs. The house itself is quite small but the compulsory tour is interesting and informative about both the house and Thai culture. The gift shop is amazing, scarves, clothes, bags etc in amazing prints and quality, bring a credit card!

Great example of Thai architecture!. What I enjoyed the most about visiting the Jim Thompson house even more than learning about the American who revived the Thai silk industry was learning about the Thai architecture. Jim Thompson combined several (7, I think) traditional Thai houses to create his little compound. I really enjoyed being able to go through the different rooms learning about the house and where he got the different materials for it. The small air conditioned boutiques were nice to walk through after being outside in the Thai summer heat for so long. I also appreciated the ride back to the main street. Overall, it's a nice place to visit.

Jim Thompson House. Jim Thompson House is worth a visit if you have some time in Bangkok. It is a short walk via the BTS National Stadium stop. I started out exploring the beautiful gardens around the house. I then went on an English tour of the house. Our guide was welcoming and did a great job putting the house in context. The collection of houses is itself interesting, but you'll also see a lot of interesting artifacts and artwork from around Thailand and southeast Asia.

Thoroughly Enjoyed!. Was a nice tour, wasn't too long which was good but interesting. The house was nice to see and there's a nice cafe and souvenir shop there, also not far from major shopping centres. Tour goes for about 40 mins.

Worth a visit here!. Visited this historical site in Bangkok. Heard about the disappearance of Mr Jim Thompson and shown around his home, getting to know how Thai silk is produced and the life and antique collections dating back hundred of years. Worth visiting if you have not done so while in Bangkok.

Worth a Visit. I had always wanted to visit since my first trip to Bangkok in the mid 80s. The story of Jim Thompson is intriguing whether you believe the CIA aspect or not. It has a very nice outlet shop, a restaurant as well as the museum. The downside is that it's so popular with large numbers of tourists which does detract from the experience. We took refuge in the restaurant and had a very good lunch before heading back to the train.

Jim Thompson House - Worth the Look !!. Jim Thompson House is very much worth the effort - it is unreal how it is tucked away end of a lane that you wouldn't imagine a sightseeing venue lurks down there. BUT do it and take in the history that this man brought to the region. The CIA history is the lure but the silk road and the development of the raw silk business is fascinating. The house is is very good order and I would say definitely worth the few hours one morning to see it.. Better to see in morning than afternoon due to the heat

a peaceful place that freshens up your day.. I go often to Bangkok and the Jim Thompson house is one of the places that I always go back.The whole atmosphere and environment is so soothing to me that I keep returning every time. The guided tours are always so well done and interesting. The guides are knowledgeable and often entertaining. Make sure that you stops to see the silk spooling, children love that.

Great history tour in Bangkok. Jim Thompson's house is opposite the large MBK mall. There are several houses, a gift shop and a nice restaurant. The houses were taken from around Thailand and reconstructed in their present location. You'll learn lots about Thai history without having to do much travelling!

A very interesting and beautiful Thai house. Avery interesting and beautiful Thai house built by the American, Jim Thompson, who single-handedly "saved" the Thai silk industry. The house and grounds are worth a visit and the guided tour was interesting but a little pricy at 150 Baht per person. The shop selling greetings cards had some interesting things in it and I bought a few cards to be used for special occasions. The shop selling clothing and bags had some wonderful stuff but was really really, expensive - £30 for a sun hat! There is a restaurant on site but we didn't try that. They run free battery powered taxis up to the National Stadium station which saves a walk of about 300 metres.If you feel like going, read up about Jim Thompson on Wikipedia first.Note that there is no smoking on the whole of the Jim Thompson house site.

Life style of the rich in Bangkok. Very interesting look at how Americans lived a good life in Bangkok several years ago. The guided tour took about 30 mins, a small entrance fee applies but worth the admission. The story about Jim Thompson and what happen to him is a story in itself. The houses and gardens on the property are really cool. Their are plenty of other activities on the grounds. The young Thai lady spinning silk from a silkworm was fun to watch. She also danced a traditional Thai dance. Also on the grounds were a restaurant and silk store. Just a couple blocks away is a really nice jewelry store.

The making of silk, beauty, palms and silence in the capital of Thailand. Great reconstruction of wooden buildings discovered in Siam/Thailand some 60 years ago transported by boats in small canals to the brink of the estate and assembled to a fascinating home. Combine that with silk, art, tropical nature, history and the elegant and kind service by the staff of The Foundation in the memory of Jim Thompson. This was my third visit but not my last.

Unique and beautiful signature Bangkok attraction. Hidden away down a soi near the major malls, the Jim Thompson is a must-see for any foreigners visiting Bangkok. The art and architecture is beautiful and it's a hidden sanctuary within Bangkok. Many of the pieces featured in Thompson's house are many hundreds if not over a thousand years old. Felt like we were traveling back in time to the mid 20th century when walking around the complex.Only downside is that you can't go into the house (the main attraction) without a guided tour, which leaves you stuck waiting for the next tour in your language and also drags out what could be a much shorter time commitment.
Interesting museum. Very interesting museum with informative guide, located close to Skytrain station. Gardens are lovely.

Very beautiful grounds. Very nicely preserved, informative tour led by the staff, pretty good value for money (especially if you're under 22 whereby it only cost 100 baht). Interesting perspectives and historical facts. Beautiful grounds and the restaurant was excellent too. If you have the time definitely worth a visit

Interesting visit to this place. intersting place to visit but no reason to come far away for this place. Nice place interesting collection nice garden but to commercial and to touristic like i say super commercial and groeps are been used like a heard off sheeps

So much better than expected. Not a huge fan of house tours normally....this place is gorgeous. Great restaurant overlooking a koi pond when we got there. Had to wait for the tour to start and had a cocktail.
Guide was very engaging and informative. Beautiful place to go - would HIGHLY recommend.

A little oasis of peace in Bangkok. This was easy to get to on the Sky Train. The gardens are fantastic and the restaurant is lovely. Unfortunately the tour (which is given in several languages) is a little rushed and doesn't allow time to look at all of the pictures and furniture.There was a young Thai girl spinning silk and doing Thai dancing which made some lovely picturesNothing really to entertain young children or teenagers

Thai Silk . The one alongside the river has a museum and a shop, their staff were courteous and not intrusive, very helpful in advising how to get a vat refund for tourists. The items are pricey so if it's not your thing, you can just look around. The branch in Siam Paragon is bigger, prices and selections are the same.

The traditional Thai architecture of the Jim Thompson House and guided tour. A great morning with a tour of the house and gardens. a very interesting tourist attraction well worth seeing. Next to the MBK in Bangkok and on the banks of a Klong (canal). The tour was very professional and gave a great insight into the world of Silk in Thailand. Staff dressed in traditional Thai dress added to the experience

Pretty disappointing with limited insight to the man himself. Joined a guided tour around the place. While the architecture was admirable, there is a question of the authenticity of the settings after so long. Moreover, it would have been more interesting if there's more information on Jim's personal life or his motivation to propagate silk manufacturing in Thailand. Was led by a lady guide who spoke fluent English. Avoid the store as 1) It had suprisingly not as much silk products as I would have wanted; 2) Darn expensive!

One man´s genius. Mr. Thomson who was an American couldn´t get himself to leave Bangkok. Not only did he fell in love with the city but he also contributed more than many natives to the development of Thai Silk rediscovery, growth and production. He spent his life making sure that the fashion world and women and men will enjoy the fabric. There is a shop connected to the Museum and the choices are colorful and modern. Although not cheaply priced thay will last you more than a decade.

Jim Thompson's collections. This is the home of the famous American architect turned collector and textile designer Jim Thompson which showcases his collection of Thai and Chinese Artifacts wonderfully. There is a guided tour here but they dont explain the Thai Silk process and textiles which Thompson worked so painstakingly to revive. This was a big let down for me. Otherwise its a fairly straightforward nice little museum very close to the National Stadium BTS station. Visit if you are in the neighborhood and want to spend an hour. You cannot take pictures inside the house, so carry your camera only if you want to take pictures of the silk worn display outside and the gardens.
Nice half day trip but nothing spectaular. We took the tour which was interesting but you can easily get more insight about Jim Thompson's life spending 10 min on Wikipedia

An over rated site. Up to today nobody knows how he disappeared.I have read about him in the past and it is worthwhile seeing the houseThe house is very well kept and there is always a guide with youHave a snack in the restaurant

Learning about Thai silk. Very interesting to see and learn about the Thai silk business. Bought back memories of silkworms at school. Quite busy and had to wait a while to get the guided tour but interesting none the less.

Great. Tour was very insightful and house was very impressive. Very easy to find just of the main strip of Bangkok. the restaurant is also very nice and relaxing, as with the house that is a beautiful form of architecture.

Just A Beautiful And Relaxing Setting...... Jim Thompson was the innovator of silk. His home is beautiful and the gardens are gorgeous and beautifully manicured......The grounds are full of lush landscaping. The tour of the house and grounds really make you understand Jim Thompson and a piece of his life.....Really Beautiful.....

Educational. I went on a school trip a few years ago with my Thai class. We had a tour guide that was knowledgable and was very happy to answer any questions we had. I don't know how good their English was however as we only spoke Thai whole we were there. The food there was quite expensive so I suggest to not eat there. The other things on sale were also expensive however they are good quality. My mom had a Jim Thompson purse for several years, and I had a Jim Thompson shirt that I wore for many, many years.
Must see. Must see as it very good tell you history of Thai slik him Thompson was a from the USA he start that Thai slik .

Historical Gem in Central Bangkok. Located at the end of a side street near the Stadium skytrain stop, the Jim Thompson house is an interesting place to visit while touring Bangkok. Fascinating history of his mysterious disappearance and how he brought back the silk industry to Thailand. The house can only be seen via a tour, but that works well to limit crowding. The tour is about 30 minutes and our guide spoke excellent English and was well-informed. The house is beautifully decorated and a pleasure to see all of the attention to detail.Likewise the garden and outbuildings are interesting. The house itself is open to air and hence, not air conditioned, but the gift shops are! There is a free shuttle Tuk-tuk to take you to the skytrain if you don't want to walk down the alleyway tothe house.Overall, a fun place to see and worth a stop if you are in the vicinity.

Beautiful Oasis. Stunning collection of Asian art and antiques, not only Thai. Beautiful garden and grounds. Nice coffee shop next to a koi pond. Pricey, but good food. Free rotating exhibitions upstairs. Walking distance from National Stadium BTS Station and Siam Square canal boat stop.

Beauty, silk, palms, silence in the capital of Thailand.. Intelligent and kind reconstruction of buildings made of wood discovered in Siam/Thailand about 60 years ago and brought by boats in small canals to the brink of the estate. Combine that with silk, art, nature, history and the elegant and kind service by the employees and staff of The Foundation in the memory of Jim Thompson. That was my third visit but not my last.

Fun and Tasty. On our mother-daughter backpacking trip my mom and I already planned on checking out the Jim Thompson House, but while in Chiang Mai a girl we met at an elephant reserve told us it was well worth paying some money for the food at the restaurant so we decided to do both. Since I was under 25 at the time I paid half what my mom did. It was a bit pricey considering the cost for other places in Bangkok but I'd pay it again to go. Definitely recommend it. We went on the house tour and left to see Temple of the Golden Mount (we took a canal boat a short walk from the Jim Thompson House), returning for a big lunch before our overnight train to Koh Samui. The Chicken in Special House Sauce was to die for, as were the springrolls. We both wanted the black pepper steak for an entree but there were so many peppercorns that it was way too much spice! We each had a smoothie as well. Go here if you want a tasty meal with a beautiful view!

Conveniently located and well maintained. A very well maintained residence and an interesting story behind it. Do a free guided tour, should take about 20 minutes, then visit the store or the cafe. Located at National Stadium BTS station, 1 stop from Siam BTS statino - very easy to find and get to.

Must visit when in Bangkok. Right in the heart of the shopping zone, Jim Thomson's house tells not only his story, but shows Bangkok before modernisation, shows how JT developed the silk trade, has a super garden, and a fabulous restaurant ... There's always a small demonstration of Thai art, and Thai hospitality ... Good value, great hour out of new Bangkok ...I'd recommend to everyone, even families with kids.

Scenic and Historical + #Beauty. Scenic and Historical + #Beauty can be found here. Suggest arriving early morning, say 9am to beat the heat a bit. There is a fancy restaurant onsite where you can enjoy fresh, cold drinks and order food (Veg-friendly, just ask). There are ponds, gardens, wildlife, gift shop souvineer shopping and educational exhibits onsite with a free shuttle to and from the main street.

Historic place that's worth a visit. Jim Thompson House was walking distance from out hotel so decided to pay it a visit. Join the English tour and the tour guide was very friendly and was able to give us a good overview of the house. Really lovely house with a interesting history. You can see how different culture can be married together in this house. If you love museum or history, this place is worth your visit.

Art display. This is the home of a person who loves Thailand so much. Plenty of beautiful artefact with lovely decorated rooms. Unfortunately you cannot take picture inside which soured the experience a little bit.
Historic house and intruiging history. A must if you are interested in Thai Silk and traditional architecture. A peaceful haven inside a busy city.

Join the tourist experience. Jim Thompson place is nice and the scenery is pleasant, but because of the excess of tourist it's difficult to enjoy. Tours are going on and off, and before you know it you're in the shop pushed for the expensive silk. Try early morning or late afternoon, maybe it will give you the real Jim Thompson feeling!

Beautiful home. We visited the house on a wander around Bangkok today and found it to be a really lovely spot. The gardens are lush & green!! The kids loved spotting the fish & turtles in the ponds too.Entry price includes a tour which has some interesting information - it seems to be a bit of a lucky dip with the level of English & the guide you get. The leader of the group after us was much easier to understand!! Disappointingly there were a few tourists on our tour who trailed along behind and disregarded requests not to photograph objects in the house. As a western tourist it really made me cranky that others westerners would be so disrespectful!! We weren't able to use the restaurant as they were closed for a private function. There were traditional Thai dancers performing when we arrived - they were very beautiful.A lovely 1.5 hours spent
peaceful and interesting. Tours are kept small, making this little quiet museum a nice break from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok

Great restaurant on the 2nd level. The restaurant above the silk level serves wonderful thai cuisine with the best Pad Thai you could ever imagine. The numerous delicacies are just so mouth watering. All the staffs are so nice and friendly too.

Thoroughly enjoyed the tour. Jim Thompson's house was walking distance from our hotel. However on a humid day one can take advantage of the free shuttle that departs the main road to the house. The tour is must. Only a small fee payable. Our tour guide was great. She also had a sense of humour. The house is purely beautiful & so glad this has been left to the Thai people. The silk products are simply gorgeous but a little out of my price range. There is also a beautiful little garden to roam around & feel the peacefulness of this must do attraction.

A very professional and interesting experience. The story behind JT intrigued me, paid the museum a visit. It was informative and exciting to walk into the house and see for oneself how he lived, the changes me made in Thailand and how he inspired the people. Nice to visit as it entails a lot of Thai culture and way of life

Learn how silk is made..... Sad that he is missing, but what a wonderful home he built. It is obvious that he was a kind man, always giving to others. The lay out of the home is very interesting as it relates to combining his entertainment desires with privacy. Loved the home and his collections. And the gift store there was reasonably priced.

Tranquility in the Midst of the City. This Thai House was built by American Architect Jim Thompson who went to live in Thailand after WWII. He used local Thai weavers to develop he beautiful silks. The house and the gardens are so peaceful and serene and the house is filled with magnificent antiques.

Great experience. Wonderful and educational experience for our family and guest. Our 9 year old enjoyed visiting and learning about the history of the house as much as we did. Recommend enjoying great food in cafe after the tour to cool down:)

Great museum with a lot of cool artefacts. We had a spare day and after covering most of the main attractions we decided to do the MBK shopping centre followed by the Jim Thompson house which are very close to each other.Not knowing what to expect I can say I really enjoyed this museum. If you are under 25 take some ID as you will get it for 25% the admission price. You go on a tour on the preferred language you speak and are taken around this amazing house and learn about how it was built/constructed as well as the antiques that Mr Thompson collected in there. Fantastic tour and if you are near the MBK you should definitely give this an hour of your time.

Lovely peace of paradise. Great piece of paradise in the hustle and bustle of Bangkok.You have to have a tour guide first, then can walk around un aided. Very interesting tour, beautiful home. Very expensive shop though Wooooo eeeeee!

For museum lovers. Jim Thompson's house is kept in pristine condition, so visiting is truly like being transported decades. Backstory: he was an American who decided to stay in Thailand in the 1940s-50s, and built a traditional style home adorned with antiques dating 200 years ago. While there, he was impressed with the silk, started his own Thai silk company, and sold goods to the USA. This put Thai silk on the international map, and became an important export for the area.Anyway, he mysteriously went missing in the Malaysian mountains, but his home is kept as a museum. I recommend going if you're interested in antiques, traditional architecture, and museums.

Great guided tour and shop. Beautiful setting, exquisite and well kept house with a guided tour and historical presentation. Very good Thai restaurant and shop where you can buy exquisite silk products.

Dissapointed. The staff was not helpful and appeared uninterested. They were more interested that looking at their elbows rather than assisting customers. They seem lacking in social skills. Interacting with their customers in English.

a tourist attraction unlike others. First of all there are people in the street who direct your taxi to the location. This was very nice. There is not double pricing. This was also nice. The tour guides speak amazing English (mine had a relatively British accent) and are incredibly friendly and knowledgeable. The house/museum is amazing and totally worth a visit. I live in Bangkok, so I rarely go to tourist attractions, but this one was pretty awesome. You will need to remove your shoes before entering the house, and check your bag in a locker also. No photos allowed inside the house.

A spot that you could visit when you are out of option. you need to pay to get in and they offer various language tour guides at your choice.my tour guide was ok, i felt that she kept repeating the same thing over and over again.

Something differant. I have been here several times with my guest that visit Bangkok. This is a fascinating place that gives you an incite of how Jim Thompson revived the silk industry. The history of Jim Thompson and his mysterious disappearance is something to be pondered. If you have the time be sure to also visit the beautiful Jim Thompson farm located outside of Bangkok. The farm is only open to visitors two months a year but well worth visiting.
bankok trip 1. We have visited this place via water train or water taxi and its a european way of construction.nothing much
Great spot. A great stop to see history and the mystery of how Jim disappeared However, not many know that there is a discount Jim Thompson outlet store about 15 minute train ride check it out

A cool oasis in busy Bangkok. What a great place to visit. We started off with brunch in the nice restaurant. Friendly service and good food. After the meal we joined a tour of the house. They do not let you go on your own, so you will be assigned to a small group with guide. The guide spoke perfect English, and was very entertaining to listen to. There are many beautiful pieces of art and other stuff to look at.After the tour we visited the gift shop. I bought some really pretty linen napkins. They had lots of wonderful items. It is quite expensive though.Go see and take a break from the hustle and bustle !

tasted so good we had to come back!. Never heard of the place, just saw a sign on the main road just as we were getting hungry, and we couldnt have picked a better place!! Wow!Amazing taste and beautyfull thai dishes in a cosy traditional thai atmosphere. Prices were reasonable (200-450baht per dish) and service was great too..A good selection of wines too starting from around 1000baht per bottle.We ended up comming back two days later for more of the great food:)

Good local teekhouse from Authaya. Firstly I go there with our Malaysian friend and we see alot of Thai silk still in Thailand and I fell so good and then I found a lot of Thai house and Buddha who has only head on cubboard stand atleast we have them for munesiam

A fascinating glimpse into expatriate life in Thailand in the 1950s. This museum with restaurant and retail outlet within the complex is well worth a visit.The house provides a fascinating glimpse of how one expatriate lived in Bangkok into the early 1950s.

Never disappointing. As a resident, I always take my visitors for a tour of Jim Thompson's House. Central location, good food on the premises, guides in many different languages, and a good insight into Thai culture. By far the most valuable attraction in terms of combined convenience, time required, authenticity, and exoticism. Strongly recommended for any first-timer to Thailand, and even after so many visits, I am still enjoying the tour.

Interesting museum and great restaurant!. Definitely worth a visit to the museum. But the restaurants outstanding too! Large modern restaurant, with air conditioning, and extensive, reasonably priced menu. Or dine on the garden terrace. Great service and very good Thai menu!

Historical oasis in a big city. Interesting history and lively home museum in Bangkok. Refreshing atmosphere in nicely constructed wooden house. Opportunity to shop Jim Thompson products, so lovely. By the way, you can get there also with water bus, (long tail boat), the stop is right next to the Jim Thompson house.
