A bit of history of the silk trade. I loved this place. Enjoyed the historical aspect of it & the architecture of the buildings & the exotic restful garden.

A Bit Conflicted. On the one hand it's curious to see the architecture and compound of this US citizen, former NY architect and spy who settled in Bangkok, was an entrepreneur, revived the silk industry, then disappeared, but not convinced it's really a must do top attraction. It's an easy hour excursion and about a 5 minute walk from the BTS train station. The compound is small even with the added restaurant and very pricey gift shop. You are not permitted to tour the inside of the house on your own and must go on a guided tour and check your purse so be sure to check tour times to avoid extra wait time. If you have a spare hour and this interests you, go, otherwise would recommend focusing on the true Bangkok life and culture. If you do go and have more spare time there is a really good massage place at the top of the street for 200 baht (about US$7). I lucked out and there was an international Thai boxing event going on outside the National Stadium opposite side of the train station with a great view from the Skytrain platform.

Back to past with Jim thompson'house. If you want to see how Thai people live in the past, you should not miss The jim thompson's house. They are in the heart of the city that you cannot imgaine. Just off bts at National Studium station and walk a bit further. They present the old style thai house as he's lived before. The task wood thai house!! They also the guide to lead you from room to room with explanation. Also restaurant for real thai food and shop for their products too,
Over priced Silk. This is a gotcha place, where you pay far too much for the name Jim Thompson, go to MBK for great prices on silk of comparable quality

Back to Jim Thompson's year!. The place indeed was beautiful, you will divided by language you speak and there will be a guide who will escort and explain all the things around. They have shop, you can find some souvenir, mostly for woman. Me and my sister really enjoy the tour and we had a nice tour guide, we still keep in touch with her until now.Around near the place there are some local people who sell the food, of course with nice price and nice taste ( you wont know the country until you ate what local people eats everyday).

Interesting Individual. The story of Jim Thompson is almost more impressive than the house itself. The best way to understand what you are seeing is to take advantage of the tour which can be conducted in different languages to accommodate all types of travelers.

A short sidetrip away from the hustle & bustle. Enjoyed the Jim Thompson House, in that it was only a short distance away from the BTS and shopping/tourism chaos, but felt far away. The "House" is constructed of six houses, disassembled in the countryside and reassembled in Bangkok, all rather artfully. Not a "must do," but can fairly put under "worth seeing."

Thai Treasure. We did not plan to visit Jim Thompson house but had some extra time so we decided to see it. Turns out to be a real treasure. It gives you an insight into just how the houses were built. The art work was amazing. The house sits in the middle of houses on a small water way. A reall must see in Bangkok!

Another color of a cocooon. A very interesting sight- As a local on Bangkok, I was clueless of this attraction until there was an assignment on this attraction in my university, all thanks to that class. As many people would just google up information and copy-paste them as their work, I was curious what the place was all about. The House was located in a mini-street just a little further and opposite, you can get there by the BTS sky train and get down at the National Stadium Station. As I got there, the place was mainly filled with tourists and almost all the staffs, even the guides spoke English. The lunch at the Jim Thompson House was so-so. What I really liked was how they have exhibited the silk making process outside before the house entrance, there was a staff that helped explained each process of silk making along with a little illustration that was very interesting and informative. Even during the tour around the house, as mentioned before the guide spoke English so most people could understand and the information was very interesting and well pointed out that gave a better understanding of the Thai culture too.

6 stars, great place, great atmosphere. We loved it. Why? Because it is small, compact, beautiful, original. Jim Thompson had an eye for beauty and was very original, creating his own home built up from various local houses. All beautifully maintained. The dining room is just beautiful. I would love to have such a dining room at home. If only! The guided tours, only way to get around, are very informative. I loved the story about the "mice house". Which was an entertainment predating FB, TV et al. People would paint their mouse in a particular colour and let it run trough the mouse house, betting on which mouse would emerge first. Imagine painting a mouse. Flabbergasting! Yes! The small garden is a delight, providing shade as well as giving an idea what Bangkok must have looked like in days gone by. The restaurant is very good. We had lovely meal, admiring the various buildings which make up the Jim Thompson house. We also loved the little "house of spirits" as the entrance of the Museum. In order to please the spirits, a little house is constructed (looking like a little temple) and offerings are provided to keep them happy. Happy spirits make for a happy house! We went there by Sky Train and a little walk. There is a TukTuk pick up from the main road, every 10 min I believe. No bags are allowed inside, nor shoes. There are lockers, free of charges. WiFi available in the restaurant. What else can I say? Go and enjoy!!
Worth visiting. You can visit this place while you are looking at the temples and the Emerald Buddha. Again, look at a tour book or a Travel book on Thailand first.
Amazing place. An amazing place, where you can learn about the history of Thailand and Jim Thompson's, an american that has vanished in the 1970s. Admission fee: 100 THB.
Interesting. Difficult to find off a main street 300 yards down a side street. The staff do tours around a small house but it takes 45miutes and is very interesting . Well worth a visit

Nice Little Visit!. We really enjoyed our visit here. Our main purpose was to visit the silk shop and buy a scarf. The selection of scarfs was excellent. They also had purses, neck ties, and shirts. I was easily able to find the perfect scarf to bring back home. Outside of the shop, there were demonstrators spinning silk. We loved watching and talking with them on how the process is done. They even let us spin the silk. We did not talk the tour or eat there. We spent 30 minutes on the property. It is easy to get to on your own.

A traditional Thai house with a history and a gift shop. We were on a pre-planned Bangkok tour which included a visit to the Jim Thompson House. Jim Thompson was an American who re-invigorated the silk trade in Bangkok. The tour of the house was interesting but it is not much larger than a normal UK house so did not take long. I think it is a house on stilts, actually, two houses on stilts that have been joined to make one, the main rooms are upstairs but the facilities for tourists make the downstairs look sort of occupied. The house is built of wood, cleverly carved and set in the middle of grounds that include several other small (single room) houses used as guest bedrooms and studies. In the main rooms are display cases containing many significant objects (so significant that I cannot remember what - other than two childrens pottys.)There were fascinating displays of silk spinning and Thai dress and dancing while we were there which were perhaps the best part of the whole experienceThe house was approached past a Jim Thompson Shop where we could buy many examples of the silk products produced by the industry Jim Thompson had re-invigorated. My wife looked round the shop but even she could not convince herself the value justified the prices.

Interesting house and garden. I thoroughly recommend a visit to Jim Thompson's House. It is a fascinating story, The guided tour, included in the price of the ticket, was excellent and quite humorous. There is also a good restaurant which serves anything from small snacks to larger dishes, with wine or beer. The shop sells quality silk items, but is probably more expensive than other places in Bangkok. One word of warning if you are planning to go by taxi. We took a taxi there (80 baht on the meter from our hotel). When we tried to get a taxi back it was "300 baht, no meter". We declined. It's not so much the cost - it's the sheer cheek! My advice: take the free shuttle to the nearby Skytrain station, if it goes in your direction (37 baht each, in our case). It was quicker too.

Worthy visit. An amazing house with amazing collections. There is a shop located in it where one can purchase the thai silk products. Not forgetting the restaurant too. It serves authentic thai food and a must to dine in. The guided tour was slightly more than half an hour but worth the visit.

Nice to visit this different location inside the hearth of the city.. If you have time I strongly suggest to visit this nice location in the middle of the city, unfortunately a lot of buildings are closing this "pearl" but it worth the visit. The guided visit takes only 40 minutes and you can appreciate what Jim Thompson was able to collect with several art pieces from different area of Asia. Really nice.
fantastic destination if visiting thailand. excellent collection of traditional Thai houses. Beautiful set up and design and generally very relaxing environment.
Great Guide. Beautiful hose but what made this special was the infectious humor of our guide - very funny and informative

A must see if in Bangkok. Jim Thompson was an American that opened up the Thai silk market to the world after the 2nd WW. He was an architect and designer and eventually moved to live in Bangkok (hence the house) He was ex OSS - CIA and was trained in jungle survival - however after his 61st birthday in 1967 he went for a stroll in the Cameron highlands in Malaysia and no trace of him was ever found again! Big mystery. He was liberal and had a lot of political contacts in the region so did the CIA get rid of him bearing in mingd the global politics of the region maybe he was abducted by aliens we will never know.He did build a traditional house however in Bangkok by a canal and using reclaimed materials from other houses it is built in the traditional style. Thompson also collected local art and antiquities and these are on site. The guided tour in a language to suit is fascinating. There is a shop selling "Jim Thompson" silks and a very good restaurant (unusually for an attraction).The attraction is a very different experience to the Grand palace and worth the 100Bht entrance fee.Highly recommended

Get there as early as possible - very popular. We got there 20mins before the first guided tour and managed to join this group. I am told around 800 people per day in the busiest season visit. Only guided tours are permitted and by arriving early this home can be enjoyed relatively peacefully. Nice shop too.
He's not in the pond. I asked. Gorgeous home of silk magnet Jim Thompson - no pictures in the main house but an interesting and informative tour is a must. Mouse TV is something we should bring back!

Jim Thompson House. This is a great place to visit and take photos. There is a lot to see and it is old stuff that is interesting if you like that kind of thing. There are a few nice places to sit and just be. This is one of the places to visit in Bangkok and worth the time. I spent an hour here.
Very interesting tour. The visit of the house was very interesting with guides speaking different languages. The house is very interesting, beautiful and gives a good insight of thompson's style.
excellent place. the house is amazing, I love there, amazing, there is no Air-condition, but it's not hot, beautiful flowers, great taste, if you want know more about Thailand, go there!
Legendary place in town. This museum is a perfect sample of the archtitecture and furniture of an old house in Thailand, all wood made.

One of my favorite places to take visitors to Bangkok. The JT house is great for a number of reasons. The history of the man alone warrants a visit. WW2, both Normandy and the Pacific. One of the forerunners of the CIA, he was a key figure in the US involvement in SE Asia. His impeccable taste and architectual acumen make the inexpensive visit well worth the time. There is a restaurant and a large shop that sells silk wares to round off the visit. Easy to get to. I highly recommend taking the time.

A great way to spend a couple of hours. Jim Thompson was an interesting guy and his house reflects that. It is slap bang in the the middle of a very built up area but once inside you could be anywhere as it is so tranquil. It's a great alternative to the madness outside.

An absolute must for visiting Bangkok. Whether you arrive on a Klong Boat (Pier E1) or walk into the Soi from the BTS (National Stadium) the short journey across Bangkok is well worth the effort. Jim Thompson is an institution and his story is told here in a very relaxing, clear and simple way. The 30 minute tours are frequent and in many languages with well spoken knowledgeable guides and you won't have long to wait. There's also a free tuk tuk to ferry you back to the BTS but my advice is to either arrive or depart by Klong Boat where the canals will connect you to the temples around the Grand Palace in one direction or to the mega cheap shopping at Platinum Mall in the other.

Interesting Place.. The antiquities in this place are really incredible and the grounds are very beautiful. You must go on a guided tour through the house which is a pain, but I'm sure it's to protect all the valuable things as well as the amazing house itself. Definitely worth visiting, especially due Jim Thompson's interesting life - and death. The shop is very expensive.

House of Thai silk, traditional Thai architecture and unique antique art collection - must visit!. Jim Thompson House is located just 200 metres from National Stadium BTS station. There is an admission fee of 100 Baht for a guided tour (about 30 minutes). Guided group tours are available in different languages, you will have to wait your turn for a guided tour of the museum. It is quite interesting to note how Jim Thompson fell in love with Thailand, settled in Thailand and made Thai silk famous in the West. The museum which used to be the residence of Jim Thompson is made up of 6 traditional Thai houses assembled into one by Jim Thompson. It houses some unique Buddhist art collection and paintings.Photography is not allowed inside the museum, but you can click pictures in the premises. Before going into the museum, you have to remove your footwear and deposit your belongings in the locker. What I like about the place is that, in spite of being in the mid of the city, there is lot of greenery around the museum. I have been to Jim Thompson House in 2012 and again in 2015 and on both visits I found the museum to be well maintained. In fact, now they have introduced free shuttle services to the main road near National Stadium BTS stationI would suggest that it is a must visit place, you get to know about Thai silk and how Jim Thompson has become a brand and part of Thai culture.
OK. The location is OK near BTS.The Price is proper but too high For Thai People.The guide is OK. but she hurried to finish her job.The souvenir is very expensive

An easy escape..... A great excursion to escape the hustle and bustle of the city... Jim Thompson House is interesting to tour. It is not possible to visit without a guide however and the groups can be large - but is still worth it. Keep in mind that shoes must be removed so bring socks if you don't want to be barefoot!There is a nice restaurant on site with a good view onto the gardens and ponds. While it is a bit pricey... it is the Jim Thompson brand after all!

They seem to take themselves very solemn. I'm sure Jim Thompson was an important person in Thailand, but the whole set-up to see his house in Bangkok seem to be a little stretched - after waiting for a guided tour (which is only option) you are also asked to deposited your bags, belly belt and shoes and whatever when you finally are allowed to see the "house" - interesting ? - well you could poss do with a couple of pictures and then read the history of Jim, and then not waste a lot of time in the hands of people who seem overly eager to follow their rules rather than make it interesting for the visitors....
Seamless passive tour and Devine lunch. Memorable secrets at Jim Thompson House O⃣U⃣R⃣ T⃣R⃣A⃣V⃣E⃣L⃣ B⃣L⃣O⃣G⃣ P⃣I⃣C⃣S⃣ N⃣ V⃣I⃣D⃣E⃣O⃣ http://goo.gl/ehHbEU

Fun tour and beautiful silks. This is the second time I visited this house, 45 years apart, and now with a more complete tour and store/restaurant, we had an informative and enjoyable visit. It seems that no longer allow direct boat approaches, but I think there are public dock nearby. On a crowded tour day, it might be too much? Their main store is better for shopping as we as their outlet store, out of town.
A must-see in Bangkok. My wife and I visited the Jim Thompson House, and we would rate it as a must-see. You get an excellent guided tour.

Well worth a visit. Fantastic place to go on a hot day in Bangkok. Nice little restaurant a bit over priced. But the guided tour of the house was the cheapest thing in Bangkok and very interesting. Well worth a visit,

Who Was Jim Thompson Anyway?. Jim Thompson was an American soldier in WWII who served in the OSS (now the CIA) and retired in Bangkok after the war. He loved Siam (now Thailand) and settled there but never married. Jim came from a wealthy family in Delaware and introduced various kinds of silk to the Thai Royal Family, which are highly valued today. After his mysterious disappearance in Indonesia in the 1960's, his house (The Jim Thompson House) because a museum and is a popular stop for westerners who, ironically, have never heard of this secretive American.The house is a curious mix of rooms and stairs wrapped in intrigue and tales about this rich, successful American who vanished into thin air one afternoon during a hike in Indonesia.While it's worth a visit, it's more for the curious traveler who enjoys unique architecture and intrigue.Tour guides are provided. Shoes must be removed (ugghh!) and there is an admission fee.

luxury historical thai house. it's amazing and luxury.there are professional guides to lead you around and tell you the legends of the house owner.you can understand the story easily.and you can't miss the restaurant in the garden-very yummy.

Great House in the Heart of the city. a beautiful house set in lovely gardens. although busy, it does seem tranquil. The only downside was that our tour guide seemed to rush through the house. But well worth a look

Quiet Escape Removed from the Busy City. My husband and I enjoyed our visit to the Jim Thompson House and grabbed a bite to eat at the restaurant afterwards, at which we had the choice of eating in a serene outdoor setting or in air conditioned comfort. The house itself is interesting and the pieces on display inside are worth a glance. We were unaware that we had to wait for a tour so we had to wait 30 minutes upon arrival for the next English tour. The tours also take an additional 40 minutes. We were not in a rush but it is worth knowing in case you are trying to see a lot of sights in one day. I would not say it is the most breathtaking museum I have ever explored but it was a nice change of pace from other sights in the city and it had a Swiss Family Robinson treehouse feel to it. The tour was pleasant and informative, and necessary to appreciate the full scope of the home since none of the artifacts are displayed with signage. The food in the restaurant was enjoyable, as well.

Thai architecture, but not really a Thai's house. Very nice house and gardens in the middle of semi-industrial zone. Tour was informative, artwork very interesting. A good choice for half-day excursion. As typical BKK, signage to get to the place is limited, so be sure to look for street sign after exiting the BTS.
A refuge from the clamour of the city. Beautifuly preserved teak house designed by the man who revolutionized the silk industry in Thailand. In addition a lovely restaurant and gift shop.

Worth a visit. We went here after seeing most of the other major tourist sites in Bangkok. Ideal for a relaxing half-day trip. Make sure to take some extra time before or after the guided tour to walk around on your own and look at the garden and art collection. Also, look out for the two turtles in the stone pond adjacent to the museum shop.

Brilliant day out. By chance this beautiful house was in a coffee table book in our hotel room. I would have been upset to have missed out on this amazing place. Delightful staff, such good value for money, easy to find, lovely restaurant and just the most interesting story of an American in Bangkok. Can't wait to find out more about Jim Thompson
a must in Bankgkok. Loved it, just a tad expensive to buy silk there. Stunning old Thai architecture and history. A must - do while here
So So. I enjoyed the experience, however the day I visited it was very hot and humid. I recommend visiting on a cool day.

Great Food, Great Atmosphere!. The food was great, the service was great, the atmosphere was great. It's a bit pricier than other eatery in Bangkok, but expected being a touristy focus restaurant. Definitely cannot fault the food they served.

If You Like Architecture & Ingenuity. The Jim Thompson House is architecturally interesting due to the ingenuity of its former owner and inhabitant. You will see what I mean when you tour his beautiful home with a guide. This is no ordinary domicile and the story of Thompson's revival of the silk industry in Thailand combines to be a most interesting 30-45 minutes. Make time to shop in the store on site.

Nice museum for Thai silk lovers. It is nice to see traditional Thai house and furniture. The museum is walking distance from National Stadium BTS station. Museum shop prices are regular Jim Thompson shop prices.

Interesting, but it's really to sell products. Beautiful, serene place. Also has a nice store and exhibit. However, it really feels like you're guided toward buying the products. Fortunately this worked out for us because we liked the shirts.
Dresscode. Beware of "propper" dress code : no knees or sholders naked !You can not borrow anything, you haveto buy a expensive T-shirt of you want to get. in to THE museum.

Always an oasis in the midst of Bangkok. Don't miss it, still not overtaken by the overwhelming crowd seen at the Grand Palace. These houses are simply stunning and Thompson's collection a treat to the eyes.

Looking for Thai silk, it's here. The variety of clothes you can find there. Thai natural silk was sold with reasonable price. No charged for credit card and for foreign. I recommend if you come to Baiyok Sky hotel, you better walk in to the store
Art. There are many intresting paintings and art pieces here but it is disapointing that there is no description about them,

Very calm place and interesting. When you enter you walk through a very calm beautiful garden the cost is 100bht for over 25s well worth every penny,Included in your entrance fee is a guided tour which takes around 30 mins which explains the life of Jim Thompson.Well worth a visit!

A peaceful haven of greenery in a busy city.. What a fab place to visit. Loved it. Jim Thompson was an American entrepreneur who put Thai silk on the world map. The great fashion houses around Europe would sell it. He loved the idea of using local weavers and lived amongst them on one of the canals. His home is beautiful set amongst lovely trees and ponds, an oasis of greenery in a hectic city. He died mysteriously while out of the country on holiday. His nephew inherited the house and then donated it to the city to use as a tourist destination. Well worth a visit.

Excellent visit but beware of mosquitoes. I visited Jim Thompson house this morning. Went by BTS sky train and then walked to the House, which was a short distance away. Arrived at 9am. First available tour was 9.25 so took a walk around the gardens, which were beautiful. The downside is that in those few minutes I was biten by mosquitoes a dozen of times, which came as a bit of a shock as had had no issues in Bangkok until then (arrived a week ago). I suspect a combined effect of the early hour, the dense vegetation and the nearby canal.The House tour was interesting and gave a nice feel for the life at the time, a bit of history, a few bits of trivia.I found that aside from the bites, the experience was very enjoyable, and warmly recommend it.

A haven of tranquillity. A beautiful quiet garden, a haven of tranquility, and interesting tour around the house. Some gorgeous antiques. A lot of tourists, but still worth doing. Easy to access on the very fast canal buses.

Interesting historical house in a beautiful setting. This is a very interesting house right in the middle of Bangkok, but you would never know you were still in a big city. The lush tropical garden with flowers and water features made this place special. Excellent restaurant on site as well. Beautiful silks for sale in the gift shop to fit every price range. Very interesting demonstration of how the cocoons are unraveled for silk fibers. Interesting walk along one of Bangkok's many canals right behind the house.
Worth a visit. I was a little skeptical, but the visit to the museum was very interesting and worth the time. I repeat, it was a nice visit.

Well worth a visit. Loved visiting the Jim Thompson house. You see all types of Asian antiques and the art he collected as well as beautiful gardens. There are tours in a variety of languages offered and this is included in the entrance fee. We had a delicious lunch in the on site cafe and also went to the well stocked gift store.

Amazing Houses mashed up together!. This is one tour that is very interesting. Especially if you know the legend of Jim Thompson. Anyway, it is near MBK shopping mall so, go ahead and visit it. Their Resto also serves mouthwatering phad thai
Beautiful house & garden. I really enjoyed the tour here. The garden was very peaceful & it was great to see the house and collections.

For those interested in Art and Architecture. For some reason this house is listed as one of the top sights in Bangkok. The house is charming, and full of beautiful design details. However, there is so much to see in Bangkok, and this would never be in my top 10. If you are interested in art, and architecture this is a place for you.You are not free to wander around the house without a tour. The tour takes 30 minutes after which you are able to see the garden on your own. The house and garden are not that large, and tours are probably the only way to move large groups of people through the property.There is a lovely gift shop, though very, very, very expensive. Skip the Jim Thompson House and visit a wat, shop at a market, ride on the river would be my advice.

An exquisite place!. The experience at the Jim Thompson house is one to savour! The tour is excellent and well directed to enjoy the house to the upmost. I loved learning about the history, the culture and the very important mark on the silk industry that Thompson left. There is a lovely shop and a cool, calming cafe for a beer. It is easy to access by train and there is a shuttle that transports you down the long lane to meet the transportation options.The whole place is exquisite!!

Enjoyable visit. Stopped for lunch and a tour. Great guide with lots of knowledge of the interesting and highly accomplished Jim Thompson and his colorful life. Also spent some time talking to the spinners of silk and learned quite a bit about the whole processing. I found the pricing typical of any tourist place on the high side as the only drawback.

Just OK. I don’t know what I was expecting, but this place wasn’t really anything to write home about. The tour consists of a little bit of art, a little bit of architecture and a little bit of silk. The house itself was neat, but I don’t think it was worth the trip out there. If you are a big fan of Asian art, this might be a good place for you. If not, or if you don’t have a lot of time, I think there are much better things to do in BKK.

A simple elegant house. it is a Farley elegant house , nicely decorated , well kept by a capable staff . The property has evolved to a mass production business . It is losing its soul on the grounds and inside it is like a crowded subway ... Too bad for the soul of this house ....
An oasis of calm. Worth taking a 1/2 hour tour around this house, gardens and shop. Guides really know the history and happy to answer questions. 100bhat entrance fee includes tour.

A bit boring. Quiet and a little interesting but boiling hot there and not really worth the visit. The guide was lovely but there is not enough in the house to see and the items in the shop are very expensive.

A must visit. A little Oasis of beauty and peace in a very busy city.Lovely Morning tour, delightful guides show you around and explain the story of the house and Jim Thompsons life. I loved itThere is Lovely shop and good restaurant. .

Very interesting!. I enjoyed my visit here but the queues for the tours were ridiculously long, we hadn't realised that we couldn't walk around on our own and had to wait 45 mins to join a group, I found it all very interesting but also felt that we were rushed through and would have liked to have longer to look around

private property - commercial idea. A nice way to use your private property for public use for commercial gain . the café is ok- . the ambience is great as the property has a many small ponds, wooden houses - and look around show of private house of Mr Thompson -- great business idea - its good place to go for a date
Lovely tropical gardens in the middle of a city . Fantastic place to escape from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. Beautifully kept gardens with a really nice guided tour of this stunning house.
Well set up for tourists. I thought this would be a very crowded place but the set up tours with a small amount of people which made it very enjoyable

Second visit as good as the first. We went here a couple of years ago and were really happy to return with friends who haven't visited Bangkok before. It's a beautifully preserved wooden home still stacked with collectables and furniture and artworks of the late 50s. A Foundation now runs the operation and must be making a mint, it's very well done and always busy. The tropical garden is glorious, the shop is stocked with mostly tasteful - but very pricey - clothes, bags and silk products. The icing no the cake for us was that we had a most amusing English speaking guide this visit, she was full of entertaining jokes and asides.

Peaceful setting . The complex is very tropical and secluded. You pay 100 baht per person and then your directed to another area to sign up for a 40 minute guided tour. We only had to wait 20 minutes for the tour to begin.The only way you can see the complex and view the home is if you go on a tour. The tour itself was informative and brief at each stop. My attention span is short so the brief stops were appreciated! Architecturally, the home and complex is amazing. Once the tour starts and before you enter the inside of the home, be prepared to take your shoes off. It is a Thai tradition to take your shoes off before you enter someone's home. They have shelves for this purpose. After the tour, take some time and enjoy the relaxing and peaceful area.

small and compact. small place but interesting tour, shop very expensive. nice escape from the heat and humidity of the city easily accessible by skytrain and has a free shuttle but not really needed because its a short walk

Interesting Houses. The tour was informative, explaining the construction of Thai houses. There were also demonstrations of the extraction of the silk thread from the cocoons. The shop had a wide range of silk items for sale. If on leaving one turns left one can see the canal which is interesting.

Worth a look. After a long day of sight-seeing my wife and I weren't sure we really wanted to add another attraction, but in the end were glad we did. I won't go so far as saying this is a "must see"; it isn't. However, the grounds are beautiful and serene and a lush botanical oasis from the bustling city. Our tour guide was very mechanical and stayed on script, but covered all you'd want to know. The home is beautiful and for the most part they've kept it true to the way Jim apparently lived. We simply went for the tour with a brief circle through the gift shop (lots of silk!) while waiting for it to start. Afterwards we read about how nice a drink on the restaurant patio is for unwinding. In retrospect we wish we would have taken advantage - the patio did look quite inviting and the restaurant quite nice.
Beautiful Items - but expensive. Beautiful silk items but on the expensive side. If you spend over 2000 baht here make sure to do VAT forms to get a little refund

An easy place to find. The importance of Jim Thompson to the Thai silk industry is of historical significance. His home and its décor is the real reason for visiting the house though. Our JTH guide was terrific, explaining the reason for raised threshold (for child safety on canal homes), the origins of the art, and Mr. Thompson's thoughts (from his notes) regarding the house features. Well worth the time and we had no problem getting there on our own.

Cool, quiet afternoon visit. DON'T BUY A TOUR. Jim Thompson's House is easy to find off the skytrain, and it's super cheap to go in!We visited in the afternoon, and explored with an adorable English-speaking tour guide who was very enthusiastic about the museum and all that it held. She made the tour for us. It was clean and well maintained, and we learned a lot about Thailand. Definitely recommend, if you're interested in history or architecture at all!
Oasis of calm. Whenever we are In Bangkok we always visit as it is such a lovely place to sit and have a drink and a meal in such lush, green surroundings.

Beautiful house. The fact that Jim was an architect and designed the house based on his ideas with influence of Thai architecture, made me admire him even more. I personally think every details of the house is brilliant. My favorites were the dining room and his relaxing room which is located next to his office. It makes me want to stay at this lovely house for a long time.It would be better if you do some advanced research about who Jim Thompson is. I like the mystery about his life and it made me excited going here. The tour was delivered nicely although the guide's pronunciation wasn't perfect. It was really enjoyable and definitely a must visit!

More to a visit to Jim Thompsons than meets the eye. Visiting Jim Thompsons house is always a pleasure I think everybody dreams of owning. But apart from the beautiful Thai houses and their exquisite contents there are a couple of other reasons to visit. The restaurant within the grounds is a lovely place for lunch food service ambiance are worth the trip to Jims house. What is really fun is to walk out onto the Klong turn right and about 100m further down pick up the river taxi that for only a few baht will take you through parts of Bangkok that you would otherwise not get to see, it's brilliant, enjoy.
Nice and peacfull. Must have esspecially if you are sick of templates :) Guides are really friendly and speak good English. Each half an hour there is a show a thai dance.
Piece of history. After the Wats and Palace, its a great place to visit. Thomson led an incredible life and his house captures his accomplishments in the silk trade and his love of south east asia.
Lovely Thai style house. Interesting to see authentic Thai house. Worth to visit, if you want to see historic Thai style building

Nice place to visit. It is a nice house with a lovely garden. There are guides in many different languages and they are well trained. The visit is interesting and not too long, The location is great (walk 5 minutes from the BTs station National Stadium), and you can go there with a boat taxi (there's a khlongs pier 10 meters from the house). The restaurant is good and offer a great restful atmosphere. This place worths a visit. The entrance is cheap.

lovely place. I have been to Bangkok a few times and this was the first time that I managed to visit this truely lovely place. A tour will cost you 50 baht per person and is worth every baht.The man must have been very forward thinking as he brought 6 lovely old Thai teak houses together to make his lovely home.I will not spoil it for you and all I will say further is -Go there,you will be pleased that you did.

Worth your time.. If you have the time it is interesting and pleasurable to walk to this site from the Khao San area, at least one way. Early morning gives you least traffic. Also accessible by sky train.The site opens at 9am. If you arrive at opening there is no wait and you will not be crossing paths with other groups.The guides take groups with different languages so you don't need to be fluent in English.They are knowledgeable, respectful, and lovely. There are exhibits to view, a shop selling silk items, a bookstore to browse, silk demonstrations, and 2 on-site restaurants to relax in and enjoy the energy of the home. It has a jungle feel in the heart of Bangkok, the gardens are lovely.You can walk the klong next to the house, outside the site, and watch the riverboat taxis maneuver this part of the city.If you know the history of the mysterious and abrupt disappearance of Jim Thompson the tour becomes truly fascinating and will make your visit that much more valuable. You can easily spend 3 hours hanging out in this oasis wondering what really did happen to this astute American businessman who made Thai silk a worldwide phenomenon and then just simply, one day, disappeared. Entrance fee is only 100 baht. No wheelchair access.

Stunning Thai architecture. The site is easily found down a side road. Beautiful entry way and cheap entrance. Proceeds go towards helping orphaned children. The guide was extremely knowledageable and very friendly with big smiles! You can stay as long as you like and through the gardens and small houses as much as you like.

Fascinatinbg insight into Thai living. We took the Sky Train from near our hotel (Shangri-La) to the National Stadium and walked down to the House. We took the tour and waited only 40 minutes before ours started. The guide was clear and well spoken in English, and took s round the gardens and houses, ending of course with the main house where Jim Thompson lived. This was a little haven of green and culture amid the bustle of modern Bangkok, and left us intrigued by what drove this man to reside there and what the city must have been like when he left for a stroll and never was seen again.To end with a mystery like this was just excellent.Oh, yes, my wife says to say that he silk in the shop was just exquisite!

A must see architecture. Jim thompson house is a beauty, someone has really put up his best to make this house. There is a 50 baht ticket to enter, students (all younger than 25 years) have to pay 25 baht. There are no cameras allowed inside, lockers will be provided to store the cameras. There is a guided tour available free of cost with the ticket. Silk and hand bags shop is next to jim thompson house where you can find some good stuff.

The Most Fun Ever for 100 THB. I knew about Jim Thompson silk from the shop at the airport which sold pricey little kimonos. But after reading the "Top 10 things to do in Bangkok" I figured what the heck, I should check it out. My husband is game for almost any new experience so he went as well. It was very easy to get to; a ride on the BTS to Siam, transfer to Silom line to National Monument. Get off at exit 2 and walk about 2 blocks-there you are. A tour costs 100 baht pp. You are entertained by 2 gorgeous tiny women in traditional clothing performing a dance that could be cheesy but is actually quite entertaining. The tour is fascinating, from his gardens to the discovery of the canal behind the houses (4) the artwork, furniture EVERYTHING! And the story of how he just vanished from the face of the earth adds even more depth to the experience of walking through Jim Thompson's home. Highly recommended and yes, I would go back again.
A peaceful oasis. The Jim Thompson house is a peaceful oasis in bustling Bangkok. The tours are well done and very informative. Nice gift shop and cafe. Highly recommend.

Definitely worth the visit - Enjoyable. Jim Thompson was an American who completely revived the traditional Silk Industry in Thailand. This house and museum is set up to educate on the subject. I didn't have time for the full guided tour and was disappointed to have missed it. BUT I was able to see some of the displays they had set up in the courtyard showing silk in it's various forms of production from the original cocoon that the silk worm creates to the thread that is created with it. The gift shop is also a good place for souvenirs although a bit expensive (compared with other shopping in Thailand although not expensive if you compare with big cities in Europe or the US).

Beautiful home. This was a wonderful home to visit and to learn how jim Thompson revitalised the silk trade in Thailand. Beautiful home only 100 baht (50 if your a student or under 25, take id) little hard to find, but there are signs

I loved it. I love learning about the culture and daily life wherever I visit. I like talking to locals and asking all sort of things. This is possible in small cities or towns but not as easy in the big city. However, I truly think that this house museum can help to know more about the Thai traditions. House itself is beautiful and very well kept. It is obviously a house of rich people. The guide explains you the most interesting things. A few things in the house are impressive and a few anecdotes are quite interesting. The place it's very relaxing. You may think the ticket is expensive if you're in a budget but it's worth the money. Also, you can see girls doing traditional dancings at the entrance and the traditional way of obtaining silk. I loved this.

General. First we ate at the restaurant, beautifully decorated and the food and presentation was fabulous . Very clean restrooms. Then we took a guide tour of Jim Thompson's museum which we all appreciated followed by a visit to the shop. The silk products are of high quality and of course we bought hats, t-shirts, scarves, bags, etc. a bit pricy but for the superior quality of the type, I will not hesitate to do it again.

Great tour guides, interesting artifacts and astounding history. The tour guides really made Jim Thompson seem like such an interesting person! Amazing to see such an entrepreneurial spirit from a guy who was once a spy. Really great place to see historic thai statues and other interesting things

Nice house, pointless compulsory guided tour. Like most places with a compulsory tour, you don't get anything that you couldn't get from a brochure and your own exploration, but the multiple tours cause crowding at choke points and make a lot of noise. Plus you might have to sit around waiting for longer than it would take to explore the house - try to call ahead to check tour times.At least the house is very interesting and a quiet oasis just behind the shopping centre strip.

Very Interesting. Jim Thompson House is a rather unique and interesting place, and is well worth the visit. We did a tour and the lady was lovely, and the tour was quite good due to the fact it was ratherinformative and intersting

This was a beautiful spot to spend a little time.. We most liked how the architect Jim Thompson took six houses from various parts of Thailand and made them into his personal residence. It was also very interesting to hear the story of how he strengthened the silk industry.
Worth a visit with an excellent guide. We had a tour at 9.30 which lasts about 40 minutes.It was very interesting and easy reached by BTS National Stadium or by the canal.

insight into an idyllic lifestyle. Awesome house and collection that he built. Always wondered re the source of silk. Would have been good to have seen more about the production of silk after initial stages presented.

The silk house. Interesting house and gardens. Jim Thompson gave birth to the silk industry in Thailand. The house is actually 6 houses combined with some lovely artwork. Lush tropical gardens surround the complex with some nice water features. Once you pay the 100 baht you are given a time when your guided tour will begin. The tour lasts around 30 minutes.

Beautiful and calm. A very beautiful house with a nice garden. Don't expect to be on our own though. Unfortunately the house can only be visited with a guided tour which is interesting, but I would have liked to walk around on my own a little bit.

It's possible to see a treasure in valuable East Asia.. It's possible to see a treasure in valuable East Asia where Jim Thompson gathered them at this museum. A Thai contemporary history can be learned here. There are tour guides who explain by various national words such as Japanese and English. I bought the snack for gifts betrayed only here at a juxtaposed silk shop. When giving this snack to my friend, it was appreciated.

An oasis in bustling Bangkok. When holidaying in Bangkok we always head to Jim Thompson House for a bit of respite from shopping and sightseeing. I have visited with family and friends many times, and I think I learn or see something different each time. The art collection is eclectic and Jim's story fascinating. Do yourself a favour and take an hour or two out of your busy Bangkok schedule to visit this lovely site. We have also eaten in the restaurant, it is reasonably priced, menu caters to most tastes, and a pleasant environment to just chillax before heading back out to the hustle and bustle of Bangkok.
Very comfortable. Good food and a lovely atmosphere, but the service needs reviewing. We had trouble getting the correct order, although the order was placed by a Thai speaker.
Oasis in the city. Don't miss this...it shows you what life in Bangkok must have been like in the 60"s. The gift shop is full of treasures as well!

An amazing place.... This was our first stop in Bangkok and we loved every minute of it. The mesmerizing old-world charm and the tranquility is simply priceless. The tour guides were fantastic...never a dull moment on the tour. My bad that I fail to remember the name of our tour guide, but she certainly deserves a special mention for such a lively tour. This place in fact introduced us to Thailand and its culture. We arrived with our backpacks straight from the airport and the free lockers saved our day. What we liked the most: The amazing place itself, the history (I love the 50's and 60's), the upkeep of the place (just spotless), the complementary tuk tuk to and from the BTS, silk extraction and the smiles all round. Verdict: It's a must visit if u r a history buff or even if you appreciate the old-age marvels of architecture.
Great atmosphere and yummy food. The restaurant is beautiful which also brings you a relaxing feeling. Food is yummy and the staffs are friendly.

This visit was made even better by guide. Stand up comedienne in the making!. Once you arrive, you are given a slot for a guided tour. Our lady was very good, quite the comedienne. Beautiful house and interesting history. I would also recommend visiting the Muslim village across the canal. Take a left out of the J T house and left again and then cross the bridge.

Interesting Activity - Worthwhile. We enjoyed our morning tour of Jims house. It was interesting to learn about his history and see how rich people used to live in Thailand. We never went to the restaurant but everyone said it was amazing!

nothing interestin. too small place and too many people. waited long time the guide, then lost patience and walked around. if you know how to make silk, then probably will be nothing to see for you. better to spend this time in some temples or palace, more informative.

Quite interesting . It is a cute little museum showing off the house of Jim Thompson. He was an architect that made Thai silk popular by importing it for a movie, which helped the trade. Now They show you around the amazingly built house he made from classic Thai huts. The building itself is quite amazing, and the garden is beautiful. It's a cozy place to visit, and the cafe has good food for a reasonable price. It's not the most amazing thing, but it's a cute little place and I think it's worth a visit

hemingway in the East?. I was constantly reminded of the Key West home of Hemingway. The structures were indeed reverently reconstructed and the location simp,e to reach by BTS. Go, but expect expensive gift shop and touristy tour guides.

We always come back.... We have been coming to Bangkok on business and holidays for many many years. We always come to Jim Thompson House for lunch where a sea of tranquility awaits you after a boisterous morning in the shops of the MBK Mall and a ride on the BTS. (And the toilettes are both free and clean...) Over the past couple years an outdoor market has been added next door (perhaps only on weekends?), and there are also young ladies demonstrating silk weaving and Thai dancing. The prices in the shop are high, but treasures for small children can be found, as well as fine ties for Dad or a silk scarf or blouse for Mother. The lunch menu offers delicately spiced egg rolls, and both Thai and even some western fare as well as cold local beer. There is a fee for the museum and it is worth it for those visiting for the first time...

If you have time to kill. An interesting house with interesting objects but otherwise not much there.If you have time then visit but not worth any special effort although at about $3 to get in and havethe tour it's OK.

Worth a Visit. Good way to fill in a couple of hours. Guided tours are given in several languages. Gift shop and Restaurant on the premises. Tip: Take the complimentary shuttle back to the main road to find a metered taxi.
Beautiful setting. A gem of a place to visit while in Bangkok- the houses and gardens are serenity realised - the guides were excellent also.
Very lovely monument. We booked a tour around Jimthompson house, it was very nice!There is one shop for you to buy silk, souvernir which has very good quality!

Fantastic house museum. Jim Thompson singlehandedly recreated the Thai silk industry on the global market. Originally trained as an architect, he moved from the US to Bangkok after WWII and built up a compound from old wooden Thai houses which he had disassembled and moved. This is easier to do with traditional Thai houses which don't use any nails. So there is a fabulous architectural aspect. But Jim was also a noted art collector, so there's that aspect as well. Then there's the whole textile dimension. The organisation is world-class and the tour guides (in several languages) are well-informed and knowledgeable. Also visit the smaller buildings, the gallery, shop and cafe. Recommended.

My favourite place in Bankock.. A collection of antique wooden houses set in a delightful garden makes for a delightful visit. It was fairly busy when I was there, I am not sure if this was due to being Chinese New Year or if it is always like this. There was also displays of silk production and Thai dancing. Overlooking a lovely fish pond is an excellent resteraunt where we had a lovely cold drink on arrival and a good curry before leaving. The shop is full of good quality items, not cheap but of assured quality, unlike other places.

Discover the Story Behind Thai Silk. Jim Thompson was an amazing, interesting, eccentric man who re-discovered and popularized Thai silk. His beautiful house is full of serenity and Buddhist relics. Well trained and friendly guides host tours in English, French and Japanese. I was so happy to discover this little serene enclave of architectural beauty.

Wouldn't call it a must, but nice.. Interesting to learn more about the silk making process, but I wouldn't call it a must see. Felt somewhat disorganized and not sure where we could or could not walk until someone would tell us to randomly stop. Ended up only staying for 45 min. Pretty grounds in general. Beautiful koi pond.

Lovely Little Area. This is a homely establishment which Jim Thompson created. The gardens are beautiful and the houses the same. The many collections which are shown are beautiful, old and incredible.It is a rich and wonderful place. Highly recommend!

Oasis. Although a bit tricky to find if you are on food the way is well worthwhile. The house is set in a very tranquil green lush garden. Very peaceful oasis within a noisy city. Guide tours are included in the ticket price and the history and artefacts of the house are quite impressive.

Unexpected pleasure. My partner and I did this as something to do as we were in the area and were both pleasantly surprised!! The house itself is beautiful and contains some nice relics, but what makes the tour is the witty female tour guides! The tour itself lasts an hour and tells you about the house, silk and the artefacts! There is ample photo opportunity and a cafe/restaurant but we didn't try these!! The tours are very busy, but this didn't detract from the enjoyment we had! It's a beautiful setting, with witty tour guides and a bargain at 100 baht!

Peaceful and quiet. Getting here was made easy by taking the skytrain to national stadium and walking or taking a tuk -tuk to a small street to the house. Once there you can see a compound filled with tourists, gift shop, demonstration on how they make silk. Unfortunately, to go inside the house, you must follow a guided tour which caused us to wait for 30 minutes for an english tour. Luckily, our tour guide was very informative and very knowledgeable about the history of the house and Jim Thompson.

Great architecture, but poor service. The houses and grounds are fantastic, and the personal history of jim thompson contribute to enhance the overall experience, especially the mystery surrounding his disappearance. However, the forced tour, with visitors broken into groups, given numbers and led like children thru each room was a bit annoying, and felt forced. Our tour leader, while nice enough, was clearly exhausted, this probably being her 20th tour of the day! Then the gift shop, with the insane prices, led it to feel more amusement park than cultural relic.

Must see attraction!. Join the guided tour with the language of your choice. jim Thompson's house is beautiful and you can see how traditional thai houses look like. No regrets going here, we enjoyed it alot.

Jim Thompson. A place where you can buy silk clothes, bags, tie, scarfs etc.Expensive but it's good quality.Jim Thompson shops are available even in bkk city,so if you don't have time you can still go to their shops .

Totally enjoyed visiting the house. This is one of Bangkok's top rated sites, and from my perspective, well worth the time to visit. It really lived up to its reputation. Although Jim Thompson made his fortune with silk, the house is there to show visitors how people lived over a 100 years ago. The building is unbelievable, extremely beautiful in that its made out of very nice wood. The Jim Thompson guide on our tour was very informative, provided a great overview and was extremely funny. We got there early, so the wait for the next tour was only 30 minutes. Upon leaving around noon, the wait was over an hour. So if you plan to visit, go early. This place is a can't miss!
Must do for all Bangkok visitors. I didn't expect to like this, but was surprised. This doesn't take much time, but the collection of Asian art is beautiful and impressive.

Jim Thompson 1906-1967. Jim Thompson was born in Delaware in 1906 and disappeared on holiday in Malaysia in 1967.After his war service he took up residence in Bangkok and his home can be visited with a timed guided tour. You cannot view the house on your own though tours are available in many languages and the wait is not too long (you can always browse the shop).He promoted the Thai silk craft and gave it international recognition. He was the founder of the Jim Thompson Thai Silk Company and was awarded the Order of the White Elephant, a honour bestowed on foreigners for exceptional service to Thailand.The wooden house is remarkably quiet surrounded by trees and close to the Klong. It is only a block away from the National Stadium and is an oasis in the heat and noise of Bangkok.Go early to avoid busy times it opens at 9.00am

beautiful place and food!!. This is a little oasis in the centre of all the hustle and bustle, the tour is very well organised and we didnt wait that long around 15 mins. You tour the house with a guide but then you are free to wander the grounds and take photos.We decided to eat in the restaurant and were surprised by the extensive menu and quality of food includind a cocktail menu, try the thai mojito with lemon grass ! Amazing.Great presents here as well, not just in the shop but in the restaurant as well.Great story and fab bit of Thai history, worth a visit

Beauty in a bustling city. Lovely surroundings and a fascinating story lunch was excellent and the house was so beautiful. The shop has the most extensive choices over other small shops in the city.. All in all a pleasant break in the heat of the city.

Tour of house, nothing to do with silk.. Interesting and beautiful Thai house with very interesting tapestries and statutes. Entry fees are reasonable. A bit of history about Thailand that we did not learn on other tours. Out of the 5 things we did in Bangkok, it was one of my least favorite. My husband, on the other hand, enjoyed it.

Common tourist stop, well kind of mass tourism. Nice place, but hundreds of tourists. Waiting time about 30 minutes. You can not go by our own. You have to go in groups. Well, i don't like that kind of tourism.

Nice tour with guide. It is a nice place to visit and have lunch. The tour guides from Jim Thompson House are nice too. Restaurant will be very busy during lunch hour so it is better to be there earlier.

Loved it more than I expected. I have been in BKK many times but have never stopped in to see the famous Jim Thompson House until this trip. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed seeing the house he lovingly crafted out of 6 traditional Thai houses and the beautiful art and antiques collection. It is well worth a visit not only for the gardens and house but also for the great shopping. I will go back again!

Worth the visit. Having only a few days in Bangkok we were unsure about visiting but were pleasantly surprised once we arrived. Jim Thompson House is easy accessible via the MRT and a short walk. Once you arrive it's as though your have been transported to another city. The hustle and bustle of Bangkok is left behind for tranquil gardens which was a nice break from the heat! The grounds are stunning and the houses immaculate, our tour was very informative and we decided to have lunch in the restaurant after the tour which was pricy but good. The temples in the city are amazing but don't miss Jim Thompson House.

A common tourist stop. Jim Thompson created a traditional compound by relocating historic thai houses to Bangkok. JT was credited by creating the Thai silk trade. After his mysterious death the compound became a foundation, which runs the "tourist center". It is a nice place to visit, do the tour and even eat at the restaurant.

Tranquil setting in the middle of Bangkok. Jim Thompson's house is historically interesting, as well as a small slice of paradise in the centre of busy Bangkok. It's a great place to visit for a break whilst shopping in the Siam area. Do the tour, which is compulsorary, then grab a drink and something to eat at the restaurant, and relax in Bangkok's most tranquil setting, before hitting the shops again.
Beautiful place. I appreciate for his life. Easy to park rental car. Also easy to find. His house is classical and memorable. Siam square is very close to walk.

Interesting visit, worthwhile.. Having never heard of Jim before, I was skeptical about visiting his house but it was definitely worthwhile. The house has an interesting collection of artifacts on display and the story of Jim himself is intriguing. The guides spoke good English and were easy to understand. The house is a nice change from all the temples!

an easy way to spend a couple of hours. Very well organised brief tours available in different languages and at staggard times to avoid crowds. Stunning house, fascinating interior. The staff were unbelievably friendly and kept the kids enthralled by elaborate animal origami figures-very memorable and peaceful

A gem but also visit Baan Krua Mai Thai if you love silk!. Tour is compulsory and they tend to move you along to clear the way for other groups, but it is worth it. Take time to see the exhibit in the cultural center and hang about the garden. Also, if you love silk, it is well worth it to ask about Baan Krua Mai Thai which is across the khlong. I asked at the ticket desk and they gave me good directions. Khun Uud will tell you of his time weaving for Jim Thompson and welcome you into his home to look at his modest dyeing and weaving operation. He also has lovely silks for sale at less than half of what's sold at JT stores.
Wonderful house in a peaceful setting... This is an oasis of calm in a frenetic (but wonderful) city. The house and grounds are superb and the cafe/restaurant is delightful.

Traditional houses. Grateful to Jim Thompson, US-architect, who rebuilt old Thaihouses which he collected all over the country. Nicely situated in a garden on can make a tour of the six wooden houses and get an impression what it was like to live in the past in such great houses. Only to walk barefoot on the smooth wooden floor is a great experience!
Tranquil amidst bustle of Bangkok. Have quiet time away from the bustle of Bangkok. Nice to have a cuppa and relax by the koi pond garden.Bring your student card half price THB 50 for under 25.

Beuatiful and interesting. Definitely worth a visit. We learned how silk is produced, never see that on my own eyes. A beuatiful house, interesting history. A nice peaceful oasis in Bangkok, definitely worth seeing!!

Feel the spirit of Jim Thomson. The location of this place is close enough from city centre. But once we get in, we feel the peacefull surround us. Trees, green leaves and amazing wooden house and the canal make us feel so comfort and relax and want to stay longer. Beautifull dancers in thai traditional clothes will dance not so far from the entrance.We can only enter the house if we join the 45 - 60 minutes join tour they provide. We only paid 100 baht and we can choose 'English speaking guide' / 'Chinese speaking guide' or others. There is arround 15 - 16 people in one group. The local guides - mostly beautifull and friendly girls will lead us entering every rooms in the house ( two floors ), tell us the details of all rooms and tell us 'do and don't'. All of explanation they delivered make us feel that 'the spirit of Jim Thomson' is still here. This is the good way to know who is Jim Thomson, his ideas and his story of life. No body knows where is he right now, is he still alive or have passed away already. So, visit 'his house' maybe one way to remember him and - (maybe) one way to support the foundation.

Traditional teak house & introduction to the silk trade. An American who developed Thailand's silk trade after World War II, Thompson brought several teak houses to one place and connected them to form his residence, furnished with his collection of art from all over Southeast Asia. He located his home across the canal from the silk weavers. Formal tours take visitors through the buildings (no photos allowed), but the gardens are open and cameras are allowed. A shop on the premises sells quality home decor and clothing items. Thompson disappeared mysteriously in 1967 on a trip to Malaysia. The property is now owned by a charitable foundation. Plan to eat in the tranquil restaurant; food and service are excellent.

Good history. Jim Thompson House was a good place to stop to visit and we had a guided tour and saw the house. The tour took us to see the house where Jim Thompson lived. They also have people showing us how the silk was made.....also there's a silk store at the property.

Fabulous - 1.5 Hours: don't miss it!. Read about Jim Thompson and his house for some background - and then go to see it. Only 100 Bahts per head (£2), and there is even a shuttle tuk-tuk to the Sky Train station!Trained guides take you round in around 30 minutes - superb, and very informative. Have a special look at the Chamber Pots, the triangular pillow recliners, and the Mouse House!And do visit the facilities - best in Bangkok?
Loved the home. The visit to the place is so peace full and it's very well kept.The garden is beautiful ,the whole ambiance is wonderful .The restaurant serve very good food

Interesting place to visit. Tucked away at the end of a little road you will find the Jim Thompson's House Museum. For a small fee that includes a guided tour, you can enter the grounds. Our guide was a charming young Thai girl who spoke fluent English and was very knowledgeable. You learn about the history of Jim Thompson, the house, his work with silk and his mysterious disappearance. The house is just as he left it. There is a restaurant on the premises (rather pricey) and a shop selling the Jim Thompson brand. Easy to find and worth a visit.

A Lovely Oasis in the Heart of Bangkok. My wife had visited here on a previous trip and had told me the intriguing story of the western man who transformed Thailand's silk trade, then mysteriously vanished, so that was it, I had to go have a look.It's easy enough to find, off the sky train at National Stadium and down a side street nearby.When you get there and buy your entrance tickets, you will then be directed to another area to wait for the next available tour, dependent on the language that you speak (the tours are conducted in several different languages). We had about a thirty minute wait, so contented ourselves having a look around the gallery (some beautiful prints on offer) and the Jim Thompson shop - full of beautiful stuff, although mega expensive. The gardens are lovely as well, like a mini well tended jungle, right in the heart of the city, peaceful and tranquil.The tour itself was excellent. Bear in mind, in the Thai manner, you take your shoes off on entry and they are put in lockers to be retrieved after.The house is built in classical Thai style, combined with western ideas on how to use living spaces, and is absolutely gorgeous. Our guide stopped and gave a lengthy commentary in every area, talking about the design, the decor and the pictures and ornaments collected. It was fascinating.The house, the life story of the man who designed and built it, the setting - all were brilliant. Loved every minute, a great, interesting excursion.To top it all off, we decided to eat in the on site restaurant, and this was excellent as well. Lovely food, nicely presented, as tasty as you would expect and quite reasonably priced.All in all a very, very pleasant visit. Then we went off the MBK Centre nearby to shop until we dropped ......... Brilliant.

A lovely surprise!. We found the Jim Thompson house by accident while walking to the large malls in Bangkok- and what a lovely accident! We took the guided tour through the home and also took quite a bit of time wandering through the beautifully landscaped gardens enjoying the art and architecture. The restaraunt on site is very good although a bit pricier than other restaraunts, but worth the price to sit by the Koi pond and enjoy the peace and tranquility! (We shared a pitcher of beer and some spring rolls- delicious!)The history and story of this interesting man was worth the moderate entrance fee. The gallery and shop are also worth the time.

A very pleasant way to spend a morning in Bangkok. I visited Jim Thompson's House in October 2014 and enjoyed all aspects - the guided tour and the history of Jim Thompson; the relative tranquility of the location, although it is in a built-up area, with time to wander and enjoy after the tour; the shop and its products are also good quality and not too expensive, so I purchased two gifts to bring back to the UK. I have very pleasant memories of my visit.

Too much people - visit too fast. The site is very nice - All guid I saw was very nice and both of them really friendly.
The story of Jym Thompson is very nice but visit are very fast.
There is too much people. Maybe better to visit in Low saison

One of the best attractions in town. I really loved the Jim Thompson House! It was a sanctuary in the middle of the bustling city. The tour guides were very informative and they gave a lot of interesting facts about silk-making and Bangkok in general. It was an east-meets-west kind of house, and my companions and I liked it so much. Truly a must see when in Bangkok! Don't forget to bring your ISIC card or passport (if you're under 25), in order to get 50% off the admission fee.
A bit of calm in busy Bangkok. Enjoyed the tour of the house and the gift shop was really a great find and value for money. We had lunch at the restaurant which was value for money and really tasty.
Enjoyable. I take almost every guest I have that come to Thailand  to visit me. It is worth seeing. It is a glimpse into how people used to live here
More than just Thai Silk, a legend.. Its travel back in time. Recommend to read books regarding Jim as well, he was like Indiana Jones. And you will find the visit to the house more interesting!

Only for the sake of saying you've been there. If you have plenty of time to kill and are dying to say that you have been to the Jim Thompson House in Bangkok, then by all means go there. Otherwise it is just another tourist trap - an old wooden house with a few rooms. It doesn't enhance your Bangkok experience. It can take two to three precious hours and if you have only a couple of days, then Bangkok has much more to offer that is relevant to life today.. The addition of a restaurant is a plus and not bad for a meal though the service can be quite slow.

see it before going to MBK. Amazing Thai style home and compound. Easy to find, close to MBK mall. Read up a little about who JT was. Staff is knowledgeable and could answer challenging questions about the house and its construction. Beautiful Thai architecture, craftsmanship, and landscaping.

Interesting and relaxing. This place is tucked away from the main road, so it is nice and quiet. We had a lovely lunch at the restaurant, and then were entertained by a dancer while we waited for our tour. I learned a lot on the tour, both about the JT House, and Thailand. People were very pleasant and helpful.

Tranquility in the heart of Bangkok. Jim Thompson's original family home is well worth seeing whilst in Bangkok. It really is a tranquil spot and the demonstration of how they boil up the cocoons and extract the silk thread. Take a drink and snack i the restaurant and just enjoy the tranquility of the place.

Not so much. This is the house of an architect who went to Bangkok, fell in love with it and ended up staying there and making a ton of money in the process. But its just a house, okay, a big house, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it.

More Shopping. A visit to a Jim Thompson shop is always recommended on any visit to Bangkok.
The shops are always bright & colourful,with a range of beautiful scarves,bags,ladies wear & even men's wear @ reasonable prices.
Sometimes they even have a sale of some items that make a visit even more attractive.
Always worth a visit on any visit to Bangkok

Delightful. You can easily get to this museum by Sky Train (National Stadium) and walk from there. There is even a free tuk-tuk shuttle from the main road to the Museum. (I waived it off thinking it was one of those scams that take you to hard-sell places, but there is a legitimate one as well. Check the sign on the back of the tuk-tuk).The wait for the compulsory guided tour was about 40 minutes, but you can visit the café or the shop while you wait. Our tour had about a dozen participants, which was actually a lot given the very small scale of this museum. The guide was knowledgeable and spoke very good English. Unfortunately her soft-spoken voice was sometimes drowned out by an Italian lady helpfully providing simultaneous translation to her companion. Nevertheless, we could enjoy the visual impressions of this tasteful collection of artifacts in a unique house which combines six different teak buildings representing traditional Thai architecture.Thompson was also engaged in reviving and promoting Thai silk weaving. While he mysteriously disappeared in 1967, that part of his legacy is alive and well. The gift shop adjacent to the Museum is a joy to behold, even if one can't afford to buy anything...
Its Jim Thompsons House. Loved it but I know his story! Wonderful building, antiques and gardens. A shop of course! And right by the big shopping centre so easy to combine culture and shopping.

Silk Road. All roads lead to this mans house when it comes to silk in Thailand..! He was the master and pioneer of silk looms, and his silk went worldwide.An absolute stunning house and grounds, not that big but the "vibes" are really there.Great little tea room next to a big carp pond to relax...A must see when you your done with all that temple wandering..

A Must See. This was a very interesting tour, and the area is very relaxing to visit. Their restaurant is really nice. If your handicapped it will not be a tour for you, there is a lot of steps and small walk ways on the tour.

A piece of history. Very well preserved and presented house and furniture, art etc from an American who revived the Thai silk industry before disappearing,Well conducted tour. Need to be there early to beat the crowds.

Great Part of the City's History. We have seen this house now 3 times over the years and the amazement at this wonderful structure never diminishes. Apart from the architectural brilliance in its design and functionality it really is a very real part of the modern history of the city. This house is just one part of the lasting legacy that Jim Thompson left for this city and country. A must see

But where is Jim Thompson?. Read about Jim Thompson, then visit his splendid house, the gardens, and his collection of artworks. The man was an enigma, his disappearance remains a complete mystery, but his legacy is intact in this museum, its foundation, and the continuing work of the silk looms he so loved.
An oasis!. a nice bit of character in amongst the high-rises!a lovely cool place to wander for an hour and get away from all the concrete... stunning art, and architecture

Excellent tour. Very well organized and insightful tour of JR grounds. Beautiful place with a lot of history of art, culture and the gay JTRestaurant is delicious too and the store is really nice for presents

Okay, not that great place.. Locals might like the place, but for tourists I feel it is okay.
You can skip it for good as well as you will get to see Jim Thompson store in almost every mall.

Great tour showcasing Jim's excellent taste in Art and Architecture!. Wandering around Bangkok, not having much to do, visiting Jim Thompson's house was a nice stop. The walk-in tours were very professional and provided an excellent perspective to the art and architecture that Jim Thompson appreciated.
Worth seeing. This place is worth seeing if you are passing but I wouldn't make a special trip to go there all you are really looking at is the inside of his house and his furniture.

So interesting. This is a must if you are in Bangkok. Run as a charitable foundation the tour of the house was really interesting and inexpensive. Shop is expensive but overall well worth a visit. Easy to get to on sky train

Ambivalent. We went because everyone told us we "had to". Don't know why. It was interesting, but not a "have to" kind of place. It is a serene spot in the middle of hustle and bustle. As for the silks, some are really gorgeous, and I did buy some just for the bag for my mom. But just down the road at the modern mall there's more at a better value.

An Oasis. These homes that were brought into the city by Jim Thompson have been linked together to form a lovely museum and garden that provide an oasis in one of the busiest cities in the Far East. Do not miss it!

Unque place to visit. This is a great place to visit to get a taste of what it was like to live in Thailand 75 years ago. The house is unique with statues, art of all sorts. Once on the grounds, a guide will take you through the house and explain interesting details about the house and its last owner. A very good experience and highly recommended.

Cheap getaway museum. Not for children, and not that spectacular.. Our hotel was half a block away, and since this museum was rated so high on tripadvisor, I had to check it out. I like to do some museums everywhere we go.When you arrive, you pay 100 baht, and then you get appointed to a guide( this is mandatory!), they write the time when the tour starts on your ticket. The groups are about 10 to 15 people. You get an explanation of the man and his accomplishments, as well the rooms and items. Afterward you have the opportunity to stroll through the premises. And oh yeah,during the tour you have to take off your shoes to go inside the house, but there are free lockers. Don't take children to this museum, I don't think they would appreciate it. The tour takes about 45 minutes. Don't buy silk in the shop, it's too expensive and you find a shop of the brand at every airport . Enjoy.
jim thompson house. History told well. Easy to walk through at your own pace. If you want to buy silk or silk products great selection to choose from.

Piece of history. We went on a nice little guided tour of the Jim Thompson House, which shows a wonderful collection of very old Asian art, as well as some history on the house and the Thai silk industry. The house and surrounding gardens are quite beautiful to see, we even got a chance to see some Thai silk spinning, which is quite an art in itself. If you enjoy history and culture, then this is a small piece of history worth seeing.
A good attraction to visit. I havent been in a while but its a lovely house and the tour guide was very informative and funny .. nice for a half day trip

Very interesting. Guided tour around building. Very interesting and lovely to see. Nice little restaurant and shop on site. Tours can be in many different languages. Guide very knowledgeable and easy to understand and cheerful. Well worth a visit.

Too many tourists to enjoy. Nice collection of asian art, beautiful garden. But too popular to really get to explore.
