Obligatory guide tour lasted about 30 minutes - and that was all the time to be inside house museum. Restaurant and cafe were very expensive, you can get decent meal for the price of a cup of coffee. But, hey, legend of Jim Thompson, an American makes the place so popular. There are much better house museums in Bangkok!

Fun 1hr detour to see it all. Great tour was 100batt very informative. His house was cool and the antiques were super cool. The scarfs at the shop are very pricey starting at 4100 batt for the basics and up to 10,000 batt

Interesting story. This is neat guided tour of an American Jim Thompson's home. These are thai style homes that are connected. Staff gives an interesting story about Jim Thompson's life. In short; during WWII, Jim Thompson worked for the OSS(before CIA was created). After the war,Thompson lived in Thailand. It was his last assignment during the war. Thompson helped promote thai silk expanding the industry outside Thailand. In the 1960's, while visiting Malaysia, Thompson disappeared without a trace.The tour takes about an hour and costs only 100 baht (about $3.00). Tour was in English.There are some cool photo opportunities.

Very beautiful and serene. It was a year or two back 2012, I think that we visited. Beautiful house and collection of Thai antiques now surrounded by skyscrapers. If you are interested in in beautiful homes this is a MUST! Simon Tarascon
Jim Thompson. A very special Place different from all you can see in Bangkok for people who like to visit private houses, The house of a genious man with a perfect taste of fine furniture.

Worth visiting. For 100 Baht you will get guided tour(with a mini group) around the house premises and history of Jim Thompson. There is also a restaurant and souvenir shop, the first one is a little bit expensive but has some good non alcoholic drinks. Outside of the shop you may see how the silk is made....
Quiet oasis. We took a river taxi to Jim Thompson House. The grounds were busy but still seemed peaceful. The tour of the house was very good. Food in the restaurant was delicious.

Upscale silks. The clothing here (mostly silk, also some linen) is quite gorgeous and very expensive. Think New York or Rodeo Drive prices. For bargains, you need to go to the Jim Thompson outlet which is not where Lonely Planet says it is. It's a long ride on the Skytrain. I forget the stop. Google it. But even when you get off, it's a fair walk. If an Englishwoman hadn't guided us, we would never have found it. The selection is modest, but I bought a lot of presents there -- ties, scarves, and t-shirts -- and Paul found a beautiful polo shirt. There's a nice cafe too with very good food and JT foods for sale.

Interesting tour of Jim Thompsons house. This is a small gem hidden in Bangkok for those who get enough of temples, pagodas and the general hustle and bustle of this great city. Jim Thompson has a very interesting story and the house and his art collection is a must see for those who share his interests. Pro tip: Don't take the road back to the main road, but instead walk to the left when exiting Jim Thompson's house and go to the river. Here there is a small gangway that follows the river until a you reach a canalboat stop, go through this and you are now close to MBK center. It's a very nice "off the beaten track" route that takes you to the BTS.

A temple of calm and culture. Close to a sky train station and river bus stop so easy to access. The traditional houses are a delight, the collection of Asian art and artefacts is beautiful and elegantly displayed. The guides are knowledgable and excellent in style and delivery. Highly recommended.

Visit to the Jim Thompson House in Bangkok. This House - Museum is a must for all visitors to Bangkok, where you can get a first hand experience of what Thai houses were during the Twentieth Century, besides having the chance of appreciating samples of Thai culture from other regions of the Kingdom. It has a good souvenir shop, where the visitor can get excellent silk products at a reasonable price, due to its high quality and also a nice restaurant with very good thai food.

Very nice house but a bit underwhelming. This is a very nice house with lots of history, neat gardens, and some interesting artifacts. The tour itself lasts about 30 minutes, but they only stagger each tour group by a few minutes so everything felt a bit rushed and I didn't really get a chance to appreciate the house as much as I would have liked. There is a nice display of the silk manufacturing process on the grounds as well as a decent-sized store.

Interesting and Beautiful. Only a short walk from the skytrain and you enter a different world.The old wooden houses near the canal must have been a peaceful place to live in. Now they are crowded by tourists of course. The tour guide was funny and surprised us with interesting stories.The shop is expensive but we could not resist a few beautiful silk tops. The food in the restaurant is great at a fair price.Not to be missed.

Worth seeing but not for a second time. Visited the House at lunchtime which probably wasn't a good idea as it was crowded. Seemed to be a lack of signage as we had to ask locals a couple of times for directions. The tour was authentic and well organised and our tour guide was well informed and answered all our questions. We took plenty of photos externally - unfortunately you aren't allowed to take interior shots. We spent about an 1.5 hours there which was more than enough.

I could live in this house. Having never heard of the man or his work, I was excited to see what an architect, and former OSS officer who returned to Bangkok after WWII, had managed to accomplish. The house and its contents are really lovely and the tour guide was excellent. However, although a wheelchair could probably navigate the gardens, because of the doorway thresholds in the old style Thai home, access to to the rooms just isn't possible. The city has grown up around this peaceful little compound and it's watery gardens, but it is easy to get a feel for what the area must have been like when Thompson was alive. The exhibit of Thai popular music contrast nicely with the demonstrations of traditional dancing and silk production held in the courtyard. There is a restaurant and shop if you want to have a meal and/or shop. If you love art and architecture, put this on your list.

Almost mandatory to see. Certainly the most clean, organized, fairly authentic phenomenon that Bangkok can offer. Excellent guided tour in many languages and guides really know the place and what are they talking about. This is a very rare thing in Thailand. Ticket price is extremely cheap for what you see and experience. They have a very snobby restaurant bar, however it is also nice for backpackers for a small indulgence (pricey stuff). Cold drinks and garden where the bar is located are crazy.Very close are some gigantic shopping centers, that your better half can shoppbezerk while you can have a cold one.See it and enjoy it!

My favorite place to visit in Bangkok. I've heard people say they didn't enjoy this place or weren't overly moved. I could never understand why. I've probably been here 10 times. The style and collection that you can view in this home is inspiring and unlike any other kind of museum that I've ever been to. The fantastic garden, cafe, and shop are a perfect place for a date, weekend with friends, and I even took my family!
Silk house on the canal. A step back in time and such a wonderful experience. Recommend for every traveller to visit. A lovely cafe is on site in such wonderful grounds.

Unexpected joy. This wasn't on our original to do list and I wasn't sure what to expect but I'm so glad we ended up going. The compulsory tour is about 40 minutes and is really interesting. The guides provide some really cool facts about Jim Thompson and Thai life that and it gets your attention more than just reading plaques in a museum. They're also open to answer any questions. There's such a peaceful atmosphere away from the hustle and bustle of the city with staff outside doing Thai dancing and extracting cotton from plants. Oh - there's no need to use the shuttle unless you have difficulty walking. It literally takes you down a one short street.

Boring. We were taken here by our guide and wish we had not have bothered. Basically its an old house and that's it really. Compared to the other sites we had seen in Bangkok this is noting to get excited about. There were too many tour groups viewing the house at once so a lot of hanging around and waiting for a group to leave a room before we could enter.I would not recommend visiting this place.

Perfection. Jim Thompson's house is a beautiful oasis from the bustle and noise of Bangkok. You can only see the interior of the house on a guided tour, which occur frequently throughout the day in various languages. The teak houses comprising Jim Thompson's "house" contain wonderful examples of Thai antiques of all descriptions. The surrounding pools are full of fish and turtles and the cafe is great for a pit stop. Having visited numerous times without children, we were hoping our 6 and 8 year old would enjoy their visit (definitely a "look but don't touch" place). They loved it and it is one of the highlights of their trip to Thailand. Our tour guide included things of interest to them in her commentary. If you are hesitating about taking children, don't!

Wonderful place and easy to reach!. You have to buy a ticket if you want to visit the inside of the house, but it's worth the money (100 baht). A guided tour will be arranged in your prefered language and the guide will show the group around with the background and history of this house. The design of the house, the antiques and the garden amazed us especially it was built such a long time ago. Take lots of pictures around the garden and enjoy a 1-1.5hr at this spot.

A slice of heaven. This gorgeous property still holds merit today as an innovative design and beautifully created space . It is truly special because it is a foreigners interpretation of a Thai house , but done exceptionally well . Jim Thompson created a real legacy for the Thai people and his commercial success is more potent today than it was back then . I have many Jim Thompson scarves all great quality and lovely to wear.

Third visit. We were really keen to take my daughter's partner to this attraction as it is one of our Bangkok favourites. While both my daughter and I [and her late father] have visited twice before, this place does not dissappoint. In saying that, her partner was a trifle underwhelmed about the place although he enjoyed the meal we shared there.

Still Interesting. It used to be my favorite place to escape the Bangkok hustle. It is more like a factory now and instead of the maybe 20 guests a day they are doing more like a couple thousand plus. It is still tranquil once the annoying tour ends. If you have been there before, can't understand their accents, or don't care what they say I recommend taking a tour in a language that isn't yours so it will be easier for you to tune it out and focus on enjoying the place and the little heaven Jim Thompson created. He had it pretty good…enough said.

Great Jim Thompson House Guided Tour by a friendly staff. I have visited here on 3 Feb 2015, after register myself for a J group at 3.05pm for Jim Thompson House guided tour. We was greeted by a friendly staff to bring us walk around the house with details and interesting story. The session was about 20 to 30 minutes.

A bit over-rated? The thais seem to really promote this.. A nice bit of old Thai/Western architecture and worth a look if you're in the area of curious, but I feel (personally) that BKK has way more to offer to fill your day.
Fun trip.... worth making a trip to Jim thompson ..our guide was marvelous....they provide free shuttles to the main road near the train station

Fantastic experience. Great place to to visit when in Bangkok - can't recommend it well enough. Quiet and chilled out, really interesting as well. Small group tours in your preferred language. Recommended it to my parents and they loved it to.

Absolutely Lovely. OK. Didn't bother last time I was in town. This time said 'why not' and to my absolute pleasure I found an inner city gem. Buildings stunning. Gardens delightful. The best tree in bangkok in the garden. The tour (boring that I had to go with others and not go free range I thought) was perfect. half an hour with others. But ran a steady pace which allowed reflection and movement. They got is absolutely right. haven't had this experience with enforceed tours of a building before. Poor Jim. Where are you my Man???

Great to visit. It's a cute little place to visit, the entry fee is 100 bahts/person but it also includes 45 minutes visit to the house. The guides are well trained and speak fluently in many other languages (tours offered in English, French and Chinese at least). The house is not very big but very different from what we could see in Bangkok, the shopping boutique is really nice but also a tad expensive.As for getting there, we took the Khlong boats (little canal boat) and it was a good experience. There's a stop right next to the house and you then have to walk 200m following the canal (clear indications). You can also get there from BTS National stadium and walk a bit.Once you're done, the Jim Thompson house offers free bus shuttle (tuk tuk) to BTS National Stadium.

One of My Fav Spots. I have always enjoyed going to the Jim Thompson House and was happy that I got to go back during my recent visit to Bangkok. The price has not gone up since my first visit in 2008 and the tours that are included are always very good. They have tours in several languages and there is a new one every 15-30 minutes, so you never have to wait long. But if you do have to wait, pop into the silk or book shops and take a gander, they items are all lovely. The house itself is very unique as is the story of the man behind it all. Really a must....

Beautiful Grounds. Our visit to the Jim Thompson House was quite relaxing.Depending on our preferred language (the guides speak all types of languages including French, Japanese and English), we were assigned to small groups and the visit was guided throughout. The entire tour took about 40 minutes. Across the house/museum is a small Jim Thompson boutique and adjacent to the museum is a nice little tea house where you can relax and watch the scheduled Thai cultural performance in the courtyard.

Fantastic visit & lunch. Went in January 2015. Enjoyed the guided tour and learned a lot the house was very interesting and well looked after. We had lunch at the restaurant which was excellent, fantastic food and service, enjoyed the day very much, would definitely recommend a visit.

Fascinating and beautiful outing. Definitely worth making a visit to see this little gem of a house and museum and see Jim Thompson's beautiful collection of artifacts and learn about his fascinating life and disappearance. Great afternoon, lovely little souvenir shop and restaurant with good Thai food. Must do if you're in BKK.

I Loved that place, wish I could stay there for a few days.... It was my 3rd visit to Thailand and in my previous visits I couldn't go to here, but this time I had made up my mind come what may, I have to visit Jim Thompson House. The location is hustle free. just get off at BTS (Skytrain ) National Stadium station and walk up to Yamaha Car Showroom and you would see a sign board mentioning Jim Thompson House. If you are lucky enough you would find a free buggy ride up to the museum.Someone mentioned 500 baht for entrance fee, well, I think it was too much and I feel sorry for that cause we went there on 29, December and the entrance fee was just a 100 baht per person and we had to pay just 200 baht for 2 persons.. at the time of tour registration you would be asked about the tour you would take, there are multilingual tours available. The guides are very good at in the language and they have a full command in their languages, like English, French, German, Spanish, Chinese, Japanese, Korean etc... You be give a tour No. it would be A , B, C or according to the size of the other groups and every tour lasts for 20 - 25 minutes. you would have to leave your bags in a locker or shoes at the downstairs and taking pictures of Jim Thompson's belonging ( or inside the rooms) is prohibited.However you can take pictures once your tour is done. on the whole it's a nice experience and I loved my time there. There is a restaurant ,a souvenir shop and a cultural center. and if you are lucky you would be enjoying a live traditional Thai dance. Well, I think its enough to make you believe that you are not going to waste your time there. Its a must go place.

A Must See Attraction. Really loved this charming attraction. It's a small but beautiful place with a great sense of history which is explained by the excellent tour guides. An absolute oasis in the heart of Bangkok.

beautiful house, guided tour is not optional. I liked this bc it was slightly different from the other things you see in Bangkok when you're a tourist (temples and super-busy streets!). It is a beautiful house, with some beautiful art and details, and is very well-maintained. There is art from all over Asia, not just Thailand. There is also a cute restaurant/cafe that seems like a pleasant place to eat although we were not hungry. The only thing I didn't love was that the tours were not optional - you cannot visit on your own. I generally don't like being led around at someone else's pace. However the tour guides were quite good and added helpful information/background. However the pace was a bit fast given how many amazing things I wanted to see. This was a blessing for my 10-year-old nephew and 12-year-old niece, however, who would not have enjoyed anything much slower/longer. As it was they were fine and didn't seem to mind the visit.

A beautiful oasis in an urban jungle. Jim Thompson's house was a welcome break from the urban noise and chaos of the main road. It is a little oasis of quiet. Entrance was 500 baht per adult, the children were free, you then have to join a compulsory tour. These run very frequently, we waited 20 minutes for our English tour to start. There is a lovely shady seating area by a fish pond for waiting. The tour lasted 30 - 40 minutes. Normally, I wouldn't bother joining a tour, but it was great to have someone explain Jim Thompson's background and how he built the house (you are asked to take off your shoes and leave them with your bag in the cloakroom, before starting the tour). We all thoroughly enjoyed our visit and spent some time discussing the various conspiracy theories surrounding Jim Thompsons' disappearance!

Looking for nice example of a traditional house?. This Jim caracter was quite capable guy, considering what he has done to the silk industry and preserving heritage....With the entry ticket you also get a nice tour around the house, garden is SUPERB, only thing is that drinks could be a little less expensive - 4 Euro for an espresso coffe is a lot.Defently worth a visit

An little Oasis. Went here on the recommendation of a friend - free golf buggy transport every 10 mins from the sky train national stadium stop. Really sweet guide and very informative. Really interesting place- a combination of expat life and explaining why the traditional Thai houses are built this way. Amazing Jim Thompson shop at Bangkok airport and duty free there.

Must-see in Bankok. This lovely home is easy to get to and the English tour is enjoyable and informative. The home is architecturally beautiful and in lush gardens. The artwork/pottery is a pleasure to see. I'm not sure why it's happening so much here in Thailand, but there seems to be alot of getting sent around in a circles by workers while trying to just get something simple accomplished (like a ticket for a tour in English). Instructions tend not to be posted, requiring asking staff. Downloading Google translate English/Thai to your iPhone is helpful, but it doesn't always translate intelligibly into Thai. But do see this place. It's well worth it.
Tour. A fantastic tour of Jim Thompson's house. part culture, history and museum all in one. Not something to be missed. English guide spoke very well and the house and gardens are well looked after.

Not sure of the fuss. The mystery of Mr Thompson is interesting but this is a nice house not worthy of the hype. You can get there by the BTS just get off at National Stadium but I would not go out of my way to see this

Really interesting, beautiful and lovely.... Loved the decor and the interesting tale of his life and how he began his silk business that still exists til today...fascinating ambience...beautifully done...make sure to have a tea there...I thoroughly enjoyed it and always tell my traveling Bangkok friends about it...

A little overrated.. We like the collection of architecture and artifact. A little too crowded and commercial like for us to truly enjoy the old house setting. If you like old thai houses, try Kamthieng house museum ( the Siam society). We enjoy the quiet time to walk through the house and enjoy the wonderful display of artifact and artwork.

such a relaxing place. Its been a place I haven't been to in Bangkok after visiting for 25 years Finally got to visit Its at the end of Skytrain line and has a free lift to the house from the end of the soi The grounds are nicely laid out not massive but great The tour was great full of details about The great man and how the house was created I visited the restaurant Which had again great food Will revisit again Geoff

Definitely worth the visit and tour a good break from temples. The staff doing the tour were great - I didnt find them boring like some other tours - ours had a good sense of humor.Great to see how someone from the past had collected bits and piece (and saved somethings from being destroyed)
A gem in the heart of the city. Here is a calm oasis in the middle of the city. A very restful visit includes a tour of the property and history of Jim Thompson and his works. Don't miss it.

return in time. Nice old classic colonial property in the center of Bangkok. Typical wooden house on the border of the Klong, very nice restored and going back in history. Is of course commercial and promotes the Thai silk bur still nice to have a look at.

I think I was expecting more. It was pretty. But we just saw the inside of what you used to be his house. the guide did not have very good English so it was a bit hard to understand her. Pretty gardens, but I could happily have missed this out and done something else instead. But all our tours were pre-arranged. Good experience anyway. Jim Thompson was a pretty remarkable man, by all accounts.

Nice visit. This was a nice visit, if you're around the area. The house is along the river, so just check the map carefully as you might get lost. There is an entrance fee of 100 baht (adult) and a 30-minute tour is included on your language of choice. I believe they have English, French, Chinese and Japanese.Prior to the tour, I've been searching online for photos to see what I should expect. Well, I didn't find much because cameras are prohibited in the house itself. THey also have lockers for your belongings and shoes prior starting the tour. I don't want to spoil the tour, so I'll just say that the compound is owned by Jim THompson, an American who fell in love with THai culture and who revived the silk industry. Being an architect, he built houses in Thai tradition and in total he had about 4-5 houses in the compound. Your guided-tour will be in his main house, and I'll let the guide give you information about the decors and the architecture.There is a lovely garden, a nice pond, a bar/restaurant (which is highly-recommended by reviews though we didn't have time to eat there) and a shop which sells their products (mostly silk).THere was a free shuttle service to transport you to the main road or to the train station. Tip: wear long pants, the area is mosquito-laden. it could also get a bit hot, so bring a fan

An OK Sight. We visited this sight when in Bangkok and I found myself just saying ok to everything related to it.The visit did come a day after a visit to The Grand Palace and Sao this seemed tame by contrast.It was worth seeing but I would only say go out of your way to visit it if you are either in Baangkok for a long period of time or if you have time to kill.Whilst interesting it was somewhat uninspiring.

A lovely little distraction. We were so pleased that we decided to come here since we had started to get a mixed impression of Bangkok. Big, busy cities aren't really our thing so to find this beautiful place tucked away in the heart of the city was wonderfully refreshing and really lifted our spirits. It was fascinating to find out about how Thai silk is made as well as Jim Thompson's role in reviving it as a product. The garden, the house and its contents were all beautiful and the guided tour was both informative, humorous and just long enough (30mins) to be interesting without dragging on. I would recommend a visit particularly if you need to see a little green in a big concrete jungle.

Excellent tourist trap. Visited early New Year. It's run like a well-oiled machine. To go on the tour you have to wait at least 30 mins which leads you into the café/restaurant. The tour is good and informative - the house is interesting. And then you go to the high class shop and pay top dollar for souvenirs. But its all really well done! Enjoyable!

Go back for dinner!. I had a nice time visiting this house / museum, the guides are friendly and their description brings the home to life, the gardens and koi pond are nicely cared for. My hotel was along the road near Siam square, so I returned in the cool of the evening for dinner at the restaurant. Very nice.

I want that house. The staff was really nice. The tour was 30 minutes. The guide told us to look around a room for as long as we like and would move on to the next room... The garden and house are stunning. Get there as soon as it opens before the tour buses arrive. Bring a camera. I forgot mine. The shop is nice. The bar is nicer. Have a drink (the Bangkok sunrise is quite nice) or food by the coi pond before venturing off for more. Take a skytrain from there.

Worth seeing, different and excellent organization!. We went to see this, not so sure that we'll like the tour according to reviews, but happy to have done it, because it is an excellent organized and a very interesting tour, a great green oasis in the heated Bangkok..recommend it :-)
Thai Architecture. A treasured collection of Thai art, architecture and silk making. The tour guide was quite good. Be prepared to take your shoes off.

Good Experience. Easy to reach. The tour guide was informative. The antiques are interesting and beautiful. The canal that flows along the house is scenic. Do spend some time looking around after the tour in the garden and outer area.

Beautiful traditional Thai house. This house is built of teak and is like nothing I've ever seen before and full of interesting Thai furniture and artifacts. In the grounds were displays of Thai dancing and silk making. The gardens are beautiful. We had a guided tour of the house but were free to explore the grounds at our leisure.
nice "fresh" place. very interesting visit to this house. Nice comments in several languages starting every 30 minutes. Allow 1-2 hours to visit this place with a nice restaurant inside

Great place really worth a visit.. Interesting guided tour of this fascinating property with an insight into traditional housing in Bangkok. lovely setting for a good restaurant and shop. Traditional arts within grounds. One of our favourite trips whilst in the city.
Beautiful. Very well kept, very good guided tour, lovely setting. Combine this place with BACC and you could feel like Bangkok has more to offer than shopping malls and bars.
Beautiful experience. A wonderful way to spend a couple of hours. Jim Thompson's story is interesting and his house is filled with his beautiful collection of antiques. The guide was superb!

Jim Thompson House a view of culture and history. Six of us visited the Jim Thompson House in December 2014. We enjoyed the tour of his custom build home, enjoyed learning of his history and seeing his beautiful designs.

An American in Bangkok. The owner worked for the precursor of the CIA and liked Thailand so much he returned to build this spacious Thai style home with many interesting western twists. There are wonderful Thai paintings and examples of fine Thai and Burmese sculptures of a museum quality level. The restaurant has good food and it makes a relaxed half day to spend time next to the fish pond while eating good Thai and Western food.

Beautiful serene experience. This is a great insight into traditional Bangkok and its history. I loved it. The tour organisation was efficient, the environment beautiful and the cost worthwhile. I loved it.

Don't waster your time (and money). Unless you're stayinh in siam and have nothing else to do, don't go there.
At the end of our guide tour into the house you still won't know who he was and probably won't understand why there's a museum for him.
Buut, there's a great restaurant. Overpriced, but great food.

great place to see. I believe when going overseas it is important to learn about the history of the location to understand how it has evolved and the values of the people. This person was well known for his achievements and respected for his contribution. Do go and see.
A very interesting visit. An oasis near the shopping area. The tour was very interesting and the house and garden beautiful. It evoked a real feel of the time. Lots of lovely artefacts too

Do not miss out.... Visited here on our last day in Bangkok, although it is recommended in all the guidebooks but I have never really though about visiting Jim Thompson's house. It is definitely worth a visit as your entrance fee includes a 30 minute guided tour to tell you about the history of the house and Jim Thompson. The house is situated close to National Stadium BTS, around 5-10 minutes walk.

A place of tranquility in the bustle of Central Bangkok. Very central (you can walk there easily from Stadium Station on the Skytrain and there is a free tuk tuk service from the main road to the house). The house is a beautifully maintained museum to the explorer who died mysteriously many years ago and is filled with his belongings and collection of far eastern cultural items. Well worth a visit
Interested in enigma of the man. Lovely gardens and makes you think you he both very talented and wealthy to indulge his tastes like this. Excellent pieces in art collection
Overrated. Unless you like silk, You can learn about silk and how it is made. Prices are rather expensive, however, if you like silk, money isn't a problem

Thumbs up!. I really enjoyed this place. Not a huge "wow" factor like Grand Palace etc. but a quiet respite from the frenetic pace of Bangkok. Good tour guide, lovely home, and a small eatery where I enjoyed a beer with a lovely British couple from the tour.

A Must See. Fascinating history and mystery. Knew nothing about it beforehand but now appreciate the origins of the popular Thai silk industry. Even bought a shirt!And the coffee at the restaurant is really good!!

Tourist attraction without tricks. After a day of temples and some shopping, this attraction gave us an hour of rest from the big city atmosphere, constant string of people trying to coerce us into their shops, vehicles, and various river cruises, and heat. I didn't feel like I learned as much about the owner and the silk factories as I'd expected but it was nice break for my sister and I and our husbands, as we wanted to make the most of Bangkok but just weren't up for the seedy areas or tourist traps.

the legend lives on.. The Jim Thompson story is fascinating. What did become of him ? A trip around his house with the photos, furniture and all the history attached to this man is well worth it. Of course you are encouraged to purchase some silk item afterwards but if you do, it will always remind you of a place and person that history will not forget.

Interesting story, ok house and garden. We were in the last couple of days of our very good tour of Vietnam, Cambodia and Bangkok with Gate 1 Tours and had free time so, after previously researching the Jim Thompson House on Trip Advisor, we went.Firstly, you can't get to the house from Phayathai Road like some maps indicate. We crossed the Rama I Road on the pedestrian bridge from the MBK Center. Then turned left (west) on Rama I Rd and walked two blocks (don't count the driveway just off the corner) to Kasam San 2 Alley and turned in (right, north, and there was a sign) and the house is near the end of the alley on the left.You can only see the house as part of a guided tour and they have them in several languages. Backpacks and cameras are not allowed and they provide free locked locker storage. We walked the garden while waiting for ours to start. Not much, but pleasant.That pretty much says it for the house itself. However, art work throughout the house did deserve attention. The house was nice, but not as interesting as so many have indicated.On the way out there was a gentleman pulling threads from a silk worm cocoon over a pot of hot water. That was interesting! Jim Thompson's life was interesting and I'll find reading material to learn more. The tour barely touched on it.
Extremely interesting.. Good guided tour (can't go without). Take the BTS to Siam Stagtion and than walk the RamaV wetwards, un til you see the sing on your left.

Dreams House. Beside the story of this place and everything... I will put the things very simple: if I was rich, my dreams house will be exactly the same as Jim Thompson House, both from the outside and the inner decoration and furniture.

An oasis inside Bangkok. The Jim Thompson's house features the said house of Jim Thompson, a shop and a restaurant. It is located in a lush garden. Visits can only be made in small group tours. Guides are available in most languages (English, French, German...). There are also some attractions for tourists (dancers, silk yarning...).If you are interested in silk and art (Jim Thompson's house also features an interesting collection of art) this place is for you.

Oasis. An Oasis of calm in a very busy city. Very interesting visit to this traditional Thai house. Saw traditional dancing of the hoof by the girls working there. Nice explanation of house and Thai culture. Restaurant by lovely carp pool nice and relaxing. Shop very nice silk goods expensive for Thai standards but exceptional quality.

Worth a visit. Full of traditions, nice decor, goods from China, Myanmar and Cambodia, nice tour but very tourist place on weekend. Wonder why they don't have an area to demonstrate its silk factory / how their silk is produced :POverall, a nice historical building worth a visit for a few hours.
Silk histoire. A must visit while in Bangkok. Amazing house with the histoire of Jim Thomson aventure in Thailand. A visit is a must if time allows you to visit.
Don't know what all the fuss is about. Yeah it's a teak house, yeah it's the home of silk production, but you can get better products nearby at better prices...shop around and don't be suckered

Wooden floor heaven.. If you're into wooden floors, you'll love this beautiful collection of teak buildings, a glimpse into an extraordinary life. Our tour guide's English wasn't too readily understandable - nor is my Thai - but much of what you see speaks for itself. Perhaps with the exception of the ceramic chamber pots which I'd never have guessed the purpose of in a million years! Beautiful things in a beautiful place.The shuttle service down to the main road is a good thing as the lane outside teems with death-wish drivers on every conceivable form of transport.The bar/ restaurant was, we found, very good indeed as were the loos.Removing one's shoes to access the building is necessary, lockers are provided, but I was a bit squeamish about quite so many bare feet. Not suitable for people with limited mobility.

a bit boring !!. for BHAT 100, They told us to wait 40 minutes for the tour to start !!?? so we simply blend with other trours that they already started, we took some nice photos, we did some shopping from the shop and we left !! we didn't wait for the our, it was waaaaaay too boring :)

As a Bangkok residence, I totally missed out this gem!. I have heard about this place but never really or actually made it until last two weeks. I was really nice place to watch up with friends. Many tourists and expats but not so many Thais. We were a group of four (All Thais) with a few other Thais. I really like the atmosphere and the place. Should visit when you get a chance, they offer foods and drinks and take an extra tour in the house around 45 minutes with, of course, extra fee. But I would say, it was worth it.

Fantastic!!!!!!!!!!!!. Just a wonderful experience a must to see whilst in Bangkok.The guides were well versed on the history of the property and where easy to understand and happy answer any questions.Beautiful groundswell kept and tranquil in sudh a busy metropolis.

Don't be in a rush. My visit to Jim Thompson house was interesting, but average for a few reasons.The main reason for our visit was to take the tour of the property. While this was enjoyable and informative, it was disappointing that we were asked to wait 50 minutes for the next tour. We asked about an earlier tour, but advised there was no (English speaking) tours any sooner. Despite this, we noticed a tour was just starting, so tried to (cheekily) join it. After a few minutes, the guide asked us to leave the tour and wait for the correct one. I don't understand why - this tour had less people than our 'proper' tour, so it wasn't like they were full. The cynic in me wonders if they just wanted us to spend money at their restaurant while we waited. When the tour eventually started, it was pleasant. The guide was knowledgeable and informative.The restaurant (where we killed some time) was nice, but a little overpriced in my view. I guess they have a captive market, waiting for tours...The Jim Thompson store contained nice products, but I couldn't justify the prices. You may be interested in catching the BTS several stops to their factory outlet (153 Soi Sukhumvit 93, Bangchak, Prakanong, Bangkok 10260). The prices here were more to my liking, and my girlfriend spent up big. They will also help you with claiming back the tax, if you're leaving Thailand soon.

Awed. Awed by Jim Thompson's vision about reviving silk. I still wonder how he could easily blend into the South East Asian culture. This was reflected in his collection of memorabilia, and the house architecture!

Just about ok. I'm surprised it's listed in the top 10 visitor attractions in Bangkok because it not overly interesting. We went trying to keep awake to stave off the jetlag, and I could have fallen asleep half round round. Pleasant staff and experience but nothing to write home about.

Fascinating. The Jim Thompson House is a beautiful interpretation of the traditional Thai house. I loved the layout and decor and the grounds were a tranquil oasis in the city. His collection of treasures and immaculate taste and attention to detail are beautiful. His taste was exquisite. What is more interesting is his actual life and mysterious disappearance. Our guide was knowledgeable and interesting, and the tour was well organised, allowing for browsing time afterwards. I liked that belongings could be securely stored.

Must see!. The Jim Thompson house is beautiful! Great piece of history in Thailand.The staff is also super friendly and knowledgeable with many languages available for the tour.Must see while in Bangkok

Interesting but overrated. Well organised tour of a complex of old Thai houses, 5 put together by the American Jim Thompson after the Second World War. Learn more about the silk industry and how these old houses were constructed. Gift shop a serious rip off with extremely high prices.

Excellent example of architecture . Second time I've visited and still great. Very interesting collections of Chinese and Burmese crockery and pottery as well as the house itself. Its also a nice break from the busy streets of Bangkok. If you like architecture then highly recommend.

Interesting but again spoilt by commercial interests. A canal public boat trip, only a few Baht is more interesting to see the real Bangkok. Access is deep into the soi and the traffic can be very bad so getting there is best by BTS but then there is a long walk.

History of Thai Silk. Actual house and compound of Jim Thompson who developed the Thai Silk business.
The grounds are immaculate and the house next to the canal is fascinating.
You're taken through the house in small groups.

Enigma Wrapped in a Mystery. The tour of the beautifully preserved Thompson House revealed the mysteriously-vanished farang-father of the silk industry's enthusiastic appreciation of eastern art pieces. The American architect transformed the wooden structures into a flowing house, displaying his wide choices of objects to furnish the house, and the tour guides offer fascinating details about the man's career and contribution to Thailand's growing attractiveness for visitors from the west. Well worth a ffew hours spent in enjoying the cool and quiet retreat from frenetic modern Bangkok.

Authentic example of expat living in Bangkok. I really enjoyed the visit to Jim Thompson's house. His story is extremely interesting and his home very well-preserved. I enjoyed the tour of the house, which was most informative.

Fascinating story. Worth visiting , a little piece of garden paradise in the centre of bangkok. The story of his life is fascinating and well told by the guides. Very cheap at 100 badt including the guided tour.

Students and <25 years gets 50% off. French, Japanese and Mandarin tours have shorter que :) English tours will have to wait a lil. You get a comprehensive tour. Sometimes there is guest performances too.

a traditional thai house turn a Museum. Jim Thomson has a great taste for Thai Artifacts, the house is a good sample of the Thai Architecural housing from the Central Plain of Thailand . The house has many part that connect to each other. It house many interesting exhibitions as well as Life of Jim Thompson. The House is located near to Saen Saab Canal and it has a good setting of tree and bushes.

Oasis in the middle of Bangkok. Walked there from my hote in the hustle and bustle, then all of a sudden turned the corner and there it was, a high fence and then a lush tropical garden with fish ponds and little walks and amazing buildings. The artwork, paintings and sculptures are not to be missed. Really enjoyed the little oasis in the city, really took you away from the madness and gave you time to relax and reflect. There's a lovely coffee/tea shop there too. Found a brilliant little coffee/smoothie stand in the street just up from Jim Thompson, fantastic banana smoothie.

Worth seeking out. Jim Thompson was an American silk merchant. His old house, down a back road in Bangkok, is an oasis of coolness and calm. Take the skytrain to National Stadium station and walk eastwards 100 metres. There you will find a golf buggy service that will take you down a side road (free of charge) to the house.

Excellent historical house. The Jim Thompson house and grounds are a wonderful setting in which to explore the history of the man who revitalised the Thai silk industry and also mysteriously disappeared during a foreign trip.The whole residence is a delight to view and tour, classic Thai style with Western comforts, and plenty of information is provided by the guides.As essential part of any tourist's introduction to Bangkok.Highly recommended.
A must visit. Even if you don't know who he was his work and the way it is getting preserved will tell you more about him. The house is well kept. His work is well preserved. One should not skip it.

A pleasant place to visit, but restaurant is a must!. I’ve visited here twice, once independently and the second time as part of a 7hr stopover when I came again with my wife as she has missed it off of her previous Bangkok itinerary. This is a charming house to visit, full of lovely things – do wish that you could take photographs in the house though. By coincidence I’ve eaten at the attached restaurant both times I’ve come. The food is superb, we were in South East Asia for a month and the meal we had for lunch here, on the stopover on the outward journey was one of the top 2 we had!
Good story behind the man. Worth the visit for a first timer to Bangkok. Easy to reach by sky train and fairly good value to walk through the house lived in by a most interesting character.
Enlightening Tour. The tour was well manage. My guide spoke perfect english and was so informative.I can feel the passion and love that jim had for thai culture in this house.
Very charming. Loved the tour. Friendly staff. They take the time to answer any questions you have. Easy to access from the train. Has a cafe and restaurant on the premises.

Great start to Bangkok sightseeing. We started our Bangkok sightseeing here. Beautiful house and grounds. Very knowledgable guides. This is a very green with standing water so wear mosquito repellant.

Arts, Architecture, History. If you're into or able to appreciate any of the above, then it would be nice for you to visit this place. Entrance fee is B100 which include a guided tour and a pamphlet. Tour is available in several languages. We came early so there were not many people yet. I think this is a factor since they have tours simultaneously and you may find it hard to understand the guide if it's noisy or you hear several of them talking at the same time. It has a wonderful collection of art, and the architecture of the house is explained somewhat. As with most Thai houses, shoes should be left out before entering the house.There's supposedly a free shuttle service to and from this place, to and from the nearby BTS station, or Siam Paragon. We didn't take it so I'm not so sure. We were just told by our hotel receptionist about this and saw a shuttle upon leaving the place. It's just about 15mins walk from National Stadium BTS station. You could also ride a taxi boat if this is the more accessible form of transport where you're staying.
Oh, how beautiful. This house is perfectly preserved to a lost period and time. Well worth the visit. I would recommend this to anyone.

Don't miss this treasure.... I spent three wonderful stress free hours here; it was relaxing, cool, and not too big. I took the skytrain from Sala Daeng to the National Stadium (28 baht). Then it was a short walk.The English tour was starting in twenty minutes, so I had time to explore the beautiful garden, watch an employee shred leaves to feed live silkworms in three gorgeous large bowls, photograph a cute little girl and a beautiful Thai woman on a platform weaving silk. Next to them was a display showing the unwinding of silk in the traditional way, with the cocoons boiling in a pot, and the silk being pulled into a wooden structure, coming out as a thread.The tour was short and interesting, and it was fun to step over the raised thresholds between the joined houses (according to Thai belief, they prevented evil spirits from creeping in at night to disturb the sleeping inhabitants) Our guide spoke in a musical way, and was quite humorous. She pointed out things I would definitely have missed, like the lamp shades made from drums turned upside down; chamber pots - one shaped like a cat for little boys, and a frog for little girls; the very short bed in the guest bedroom, for Thai guests; the window frames inverted, so that the decoration faced inside instead of the traditional way on the outside.She also explained about the spirit house, that Thai's believe that when you build a house, you disturb the spirit in the ground, so you build a little house for him, and feed him breakfast and decorate with flowers to appease him.A highlight was the 19th century Chinese mouse box in the main bedroom; a large wooden maze like box, with a glass front, she explained that it was used to house pet mice, and the Chinese painted different colours on two mice, and placed bets on which one would reach the bottom first.But what really blew me away was Jim Thompson's good taste; every item in the house was exquisite, wooden Burmese statues, Chinese porcelain, the wall hangings, and my favourite, a tiny statue on the study desk, depicting the creation of life. The window frames on the walls between the houses he joined together are used as alcoves to house beautiful old artefacts. Everything was very understated and tasteful, no glitter or kitsch.After the tour, which lasted about 30 minutes, I went to the restaurant overlooking the koi pond, and had a delightful meal, noodle shrimp salad which was delicious, and the best yoghurt mango drink of the entire Thailand trip (160 baht each). The service was a bit slow.Leaving the cool of the garden it was really hot outside, and I was pleased to discover the free shuttle service (it leaves every 15 minutes, to and from the skytrain)
Interesting. Interesting to learn about some history about which I would otherwise never know, and some nice silks to see and buy.

Enjoyed and disappointed at the same time. Thoroughly enjoyed the visit however if they had left a couple of rooms in the original form (as if he had just left) then the experience would have been better. The guides were excellent and a must to have when you visit they know all the details.
Very interesting.. Awesome place to visit, very interesting history. Loved visiting and learning about the Thai silk industry and its revival.

Go only if you have spare time. Jim Thompson House is actually Jim Thompson's house which has now been converted into a museum. they give you a guided tour of the whole house, but unfortunately for us it was very difficult to understand our guide's english. Her accent was so Thai, that everyone in the group was a bit lost. The best part I enjoyed was a small display at the entrance where a man was taking out the silk threads from cocoons.I would not recommend this place to someone who is visiting Bangkok with a tight schedule or to someone who is thinking to travel all the way to this place.

Elegant insight into traditional Thai living. We were just as beguiled by the house and shop as when we visited 5 years ago. Lunch in the restaurant was very good, the house(Jim was and architect and it shows in many places) is very interesting and beautifully kept and shop has many temptations - beautiful silks and printed cottons that are good ambassadors for Thai design.

A unique house of a great man !. Magnificent house , built in tek wood, with a particular architetture , unique forniture , vases, statues by a man Who really loved Thailand and worked to make textile industry one of The most important of The whole world . A place NOT to miss in Bangkok!

Beautiful house. Not knowing anything about Jim Thompson or the silk industry in Thailand my husband and I went along to Jim Thompson's house just to tick off an attraction on our list of things to do in Bangkok. In fact we were bowled over by how beautiful his house was and how interesting the tour was. The tour is only 30 minutes long but is very informative and let's you explore his house. We would both recommend this trip epically as you don't feel like you're in bustling Bangkok!

Good Thai Insight. Jim Thompsons House was right around the corner from our hotel so we paid it a visit. We took the tour at 100Baht. Tour went for 40 minutes and it was well worth it. The house is interesting but the commentary is the most benificial part of the tour as you learn much about Thai customs, history and beliefs. All in all well worth a visit.

A beautiful house museum. if you look for a beautiful place and love antiques,it's a place you must see.the legendary Jim Thompson and the mystery around his disappearance attracted me to see this place and I'm glad I didn't leave Bangkok without seeing the house of the man who is known for developing the silk industry in Thailand and his artistic taste.

interesting visit but. Beautiful colonial house in a lovely location. The guided tour was interesting but felt a bit like being processed on a conveyor belt. Would have liked to have known more about Jim Thomson the man and the silk trade

A must see if you enjoy architecture.. This is a stunning collection of four or five ancient houses that were moved, connected, filled with magical artifacts of the area and reconfigured into Jim Thompson's person residence back in the fifties. A docent will take a small group through, pointing out must sees followed by unlimited time to wonder around on your own as well as take photos (no photography inside). There is also a restaurant that looked like a nice place to lunch. This is a must do in Bangkok.

Interesting. A bit secluded, you have to walk and know your way when you get off the public transport. Although to me it remained unclear what the fuss was all about - a man introduced silk, and then he disappeared - I accepted the fact that Thais decided to make a brand of it all. So I gladly visited the house. The garden is small but pleasant to be in, the houses are interesting, there is a restaurant and you can also see how the silk is actually made. There are some posters and articles about it. The guide was really nice, although her English was far from perfect. You will not miss a lot if you visit it, but you will most likely enjoy if you do. Fee is not really on the cheap end. The way the house was made and how it looks is maybe the most interesting thing in the whole story. You have to take off your shoes and leave your belongings in the locker (someone allegedly broke something expensive with her hand bag once). Photography is not allowed inside the house.

Worth a visit. Step back in time and enjoy this beautiful piece of history in the middle of Bangkok. We found it easy enough with a map, not too far from National Stadium station on the SkyRail. After a very informative 20 minute tour with a local thai guide, we were able to sit down and enjoy a delicious lunch at the restaurant. The food was very good and a reasonable price. We only had 2 nights in Bangkok but made it a point to visit this tourist attraction and found it to be worthwhile.

Good clothes but not food. I returned to Jim Thompson House to buy some silk pants as the ones I bought four years ago finally gave up. I was lucky to buy the same type, plus another pair. My wife bought a nice bag and the service and quality of goods in the shop is great. However, the food seems to have gone down hill as it was not as good as the last time we visited. Overall I love visiting this place as it is a haven from the madness of Bangkok.

Taste of Thai. People who travel to Thailand can be deceived of what Thailand is about, particular to those who aimed at the street shopping and and shopping mall dining. Spend a few hours to visit Jim Thompson House, look around the traditional Thai House garden, get a ticket to tour the house museum, best to have also a Thai lunch or dinner there, and you can claim that you understand Thailand a bit!

House tour and river taxi. Great guided tour of the house, not too long. Reasonable at 200 baht each. Gardens are beautiful. After the tour we jumped on a river taxi with the locals back into town, recomended if you want something a little different, you have to be quick though as it doesn't stop for long!

Visit Jim Thompson. we have visited this site a number of times over the years and it is always a joy to see how he use to live. It is a quiet area in a bustling city. The guides are always good. The silk is nice but expensive. There is a seconds shop which we found and bought some material for my wife to have made in a dress. More economical that way.

Must see place in Bangkok. The Jim Thompson is very legendary person and reputation of the Thai silk is mostly because of him. The house is amazing feat of architecture and it contains rare art and cultural pieces from the region. I wont tell the whole story here in the review since you will hear it there by excellent tour guides.Jim Thompson is located near the shopping attractions such as MBK. The nearby skytrain station is BTS National Stadium from the exit 1 you walk to next "soi" (side road) Soi Kasem Sam 2. The Jim Thompson house is at the end of the road, at the left side. It takes about 10 minutes from the BTS station.When you arrive there, there is fancy restaurant at the right side and silk shop at the left side. Behind the silk shop there is counter where you "have to" get the the tour which is mandatory but only 100THB per person. There are several different language options what the guides are able to speak. You will receive small paper about the history of the place and the man itself along with the number of the tour. After a while the number will be called and the tour starts. The tour takes about 20-30 minutes. Please do note that you have to take the shoes of when entering the main building and photographing inside is forbidden. The toilets are near the restaurant, be sure to visit them before heading further. Overall I highly recommend visiting this place.Remember to click "helpful" below and see my profile for more reviews in Bangkok and ASEA.

Ok if you have the time. Good way to get out of the heat, beautiful garden, informative guide and some interesting pieces. Not sure why it's such a tourist attraction. Felt like they were really stretching the details so people could felt that they got value for money.

Beautiful Venue for a Wedding!. We have visited Jim Thompson House several times in the past and enjoyed the beautiful building and ambience of the place, so decided that we would like to hold our wedding there.We spent many months organising with the events team at the House, which culminated into an amazing, magical wedding day and evening. We hired the Ayara Hall and adjacent bar for the ceremony and reception and included Thai dancing, museum tour for our guests, full Thai dinner and evening of dancing. The food was superb and service impeccable.We had the opportunity to have photographers follow us around the house and lovely gardens having photos taken and even had to stop the tourists from entering certain areas so that the perfect photos could be taken (so apologise to them now if we affected their visit).Our wedding was the first western wedding (we are both from England) to be held at the house. The house and events team were faultless throughout and we would recommend it to anyone considering an alternative Thai beach holiday.

Interesting slice of local history. I thought we would pay our money and just wander around but it was an organ sided tour that we had to wait some time to start. It was worthwhile though and the guide was up to speed with the history of the house as well as the Jim Thompson story. They offer a tuk tuk back up to the main road but it's not far to walk from National Stadium BTS. Hide your credit card if you don't want to spend as the luxury items are beautiful but expensive. Lovers of history, architecture and antiques should not miss this one.

Nice tour and great restaurant. Tour is very casual, can be done in one hour, and have a nice feel of last century. The place is tastefully decorated with a nice garden. Excellent restaurant on premises

Unique house with a mysterious past. Actually the mysterious past is that of the late owner, Jim Thompson. I have always thought what he did to revolutionize the silk industry in Thailand was fascinating. His home has a lot of lovely old antiques and the grounds are lush and beautiful. The Jim Thompson Store, which near the house, in my opinion, has some of the nicest silk products I have seen. Beautiful linens, home décor, scarves, accessories. Very high quality and for what you get, reasonably priced. You won't find anything like it in the markets.

Very Pleasantly Surprised. 100THB per person for a guided tour and helpful information was great value. Interesting piece of history and a lovely place to enjoy. We stopped for lunch as well whichwhile not cheap cheap, was fair value in what is a top touristy place. 5 minutes stroll from National Stadium Station and MBK. Really glad we went.
Understanding Thai Silk industry. Beautiful architecture plus learn about how silk threads are harvested. Easy quick tour (plan about 1.5 hours).
Not so impressive. I found the house and the guides tour not so impressive. It's nice to see, yet with limited time there are nices things to see or do.

Worth it!!. Like the Bangkokian museum, this is a snapshot from earlier times. At least for those who had $$$. But it has significant historical value. It also happens to be a beautiful oasis away from the omnipresent Starbucks, McDonald's and 7-11s.Don't listen to the naysayers. You have to question their reason for coming to Thailand in the first place when they visit a site that the local Thai people love, that the local Thai people benefit from, and the guy "Jim Thompson" is revered for what he did for the Thai silk industry and in saving Thai artifacts, but it's the tourist who doesn't get it.I would admit that it should not be in your top 5 for Bangkok. But after you finish the big Wats and start to wonder, what at least part of Bangkok used to look like, then paying a visit to the Bangkokian museum and Jim Thompson house is worth it.

Interesting place. its good for those whom like to see how did jim thompson comes about and his abode as those are preserved well and on a side note, there is a space on showing all those old poem songs there too that is very interesting and informative of the people in the past!

An interesting house. In brief, this is a Thai house designed by an American with goods from China Town and a few other places. The most interesting furniture I saw was the mice model house; essentially people put a mice in the model and see which hole it came out from (entertainment before the invention of TV). I would go there once to see how objects and concepts in different cultures blend together, but I am not tempted to go there again because the house was just a house - nothing really grand or spectacular. Good thing is whenever you go, you join a guided tour; that help understand the house a bit more.

Charming Tourist Spot. This was the first stop I went to with my boyfriend after we arrived in Bangkok. The houses were beautiful and we took some great shots. If you go you absolutely must enjoy lunch in their restaurant and try one of their cocktails. Sign up for a quick tour of the house and after make sure you stop at the massage shop on the corner of the street for a full body thai massage for only 250 baht. We made sure to get the massages side by side in the back room and we were not disappointed. The tour, the great food, and then the Thai massages really helped us relax after the long flight from New York City.

A Gorgeous Attraction!. I mistakenly thought this house will be more about how silk is made but it is really more of an architectural sight where the East meets the West. Guided tour is a must since you'll miss a lot of subtleties around the House without it. I recommend visiting the cafe as well; it is pricey but the decor is beautiful! Don't forget to drop by the gift shop as well and be careful, you'll want to buy the whole store!

A lovely attraction. I love it here, a quiet little oasis and a small taste of a life in ages past. The house is stunning and the guides offer a lovely little tour. Pass by the shop or even better the factory outlet out of town for some great little items.

Tourist Trap. I'm really not sure why this is even among attractions worth seeing in Bangkok. It's just a not so impressive house. The personal history of Mr. Thompson did not really interest my friend and I (that can be a personal thing...). And it is not worth the price. Knowing what I know now, I would visit this place once if it was free but I would not pay to see it.

A little oasis of calm in the city. We arrived early morning for the tour of the house and it was a virtual oasis of calm. The ticket price includes a guided tour in the language of your choice (I noted Mandarin, English and French tours). We had to wait about half an hour before our tour started - perfect time to explore the gardens, take in some of the art collections and browse the store. Our tour guide was very well informed and approachable - answering all our questions with ease. You are unable to take pictures inside of the house but there is a lot to snap in the gardens. You do have to remove your shoes before entering.

For architecture and cultural buffs. They do really well accommodating hordes of tourists. I was really impressed with the level of organisation. However i did find the amount of people off putting. Too many, way too many. Is it worth the visit? I am not sure it is. Better off going up to chiang mai where you can see plenty of Lana style houses that still have life in them and not just antiques.

A very tangible memory of JIm Thompson and his home. Stepping into Jim Thompson's home you cant help feeling he must have just stepped out for a while! The house conjures up a very rich insight into the man and his life.Seeing the treasures he collected in his home he had built in the traditional manner set in a beautiful tropical garden, make this house well worth a visit

Really interesting!. This was a surprise to us. The hotel staff recommended it and we thoroughly enjoyed the tour and shop. The history and mystique is intriguing and the tour guide was very knowledgeable and added a bit of humor to hold our interest. It's a sort of "East Meets West" story.
Great location for a wedding. We were lucky enough to attend a wedding here.With traditional dancing, museum tour. Great food outstanding service. The tour was interesting. A great location.

Very interesting historical site. Visited this attraction which is down an alley near all the large malls. Amazingly well run and pristine. Very good tour thru this man's home/museum which was funded thru the silk trade. In Bangkok this attraction is it own "brand" with merchandise at stores and the airport.
Fascinating. Very easy to find, amazing insite to the silk trade and the effect on the architecture from Jim Thompson

Better than I expected!. For 100 baht, you get a tour of the property in either English or French. The tour was very well-done and very interesting. Although you can't take pictures inside the house, there are still several good photo ops. There is a large gift/souvenir shop, as well as a free shuttle that goes from the house to the main street close to the BTS station stairs. :-)
too long wait. We tried to go three days in a row, but the wait time for the tour was an hour. Were too many people to enjoy, so we never actually viewed it.

Worth a trip. Really nice Thai house which you get a guided tour of. Interesting to hear the Jim Thompson story during the tour. Quite a shaded area with really nice garden and shrubs ( which is rare in Bangkok). Nice gift shop and coffee place to relax for a bit in after the tour.
Well worth a visit. Very reasonable price for this tour, well presented by a very good guide. Many interesting artefacts. Don't miss this tour.

An Urban Escape!. Hidden in the streets of Siam Bangkok, this place is worth making a trip to if you're in the area. The delicate interior deco, coupled with the historical artefacts gave this place a very zen feeling. Guided tours are recommended (pay a small fee) as you'll get to find out more about the story behind the place, as well as visit the museum within. Fret not if you can only understand Chinese as I went through the Chinese guided tour, and I have to say the guide could speak fluent mandarin despite being a native Thai. Alternatively, you can choose to explore the area on your own without accessing the museum and this option is free of charge. Lastly, drop by the gift shop near the exit and you might chance upon something you like. If you spend above 2,000 Baht as a tourist, you can claim the VAT at the airport before leaving Bangkok, just remember to get the Claim Form from the counter when making your purchases.

A nice restaurant there. The museum was closed when we visited it. So, we had dinner in their restaurant, which serves nice traditional Thai food. The tom yum goong soup, rostiserrie roasted chicken and green curry were delicious. Getting there is easy as it is just 5-10 minutes walk from BTS National Stadium Station.

Worthy site?. Boy, I had some level of expectation here but you can keep this place off my list. Just a wooden house with little significance other than this American started some silk trading. With all the temples around Bangkok, I would not waste my time here. Guides difficult to understand also.

Excellent Tour. Third time to Bangkok and I'm glad I visited the Jim Thompson house/museum. It is highly recommended and do join the tour which costs 100 Baht. I had a lovely time too after the tour exploring the compounds.

expensive substandard tourist junk. What a lot of expensive poor quality rubbish. Stories built on myths !!!What they don't tell you is what the employees get paid who make the goods they sell.... Virtually slave labour.

worth visiting. we visited Jim thompson's house and Museum in the afternoon before they close at 5:00 p.m.There are free tours in different languages at certain hours.Shoes should be taken off when visiting the house which Jim Thompson combined from six teak buildings.He was an American Architect and military officer who as a designer and textile colorist , he contributed substantially to the industry's growth and to the worldwide recognition accorded to Thai silk.The distinctive thing in many of Thompsons antique collection is they are either missing a piece or broken,he could easily buy them because Thai people think they were bad luck.The restaurant overlooking the pond is very nice and worth trying.After the guided tour one can wander in the garden or go to the souvenir shop to buy beauiful silk products ,t-shirts,books,prints ..etc.Also you can see how silk is made.Three hours are enough for this visit.

Well worth a visit. Generally we are put off guided tours but here the delightful Thai women keep it short and interesting. A delightful example of its kind with a very good on site restaurant for lunch. Highly reccomend.

Nice place to visit on your own. Jim Thompson was an American you start the silk trade of Thailand. The tour of his residence is interesting and beautiful. This one tour you can do on your own with a guide, it located right next to the sky train.

Historic right in th heart of the city. Jim Thompson was an American so it was neat to take a tour of his residence. His story is an impressive one, and the tour linked the style in the house to his personality. It was neat to learn about an American who had a huge impact in the silk trade of Thailand.

Great house. Somewhat pretentious place. Overpriced. Interesting house though.
The restaruant was excellent. The tour worth doing.

nice. Not super exciting unless you are interested in history and traditional Thai architecture. This is just a nice house built by an American architect and business man who helped develop the Thai silk industry.

Thompson and the silk industry. This site was easy for us to get to via Sky Train from our hotel and was a great way to begin our stay Thailand. The house and grounds tours were very interesting and not overly crowded. We had lunch at the restaurant which was delicious but a little pricey by Thai standards. A nice, easy first day when dealing with jet lag, too!
Interesting place. But don't go out of your way to see it. Very cool architecture, grounds. Great tour. However, it didn't add much to my overall experience in Bangkok.

This is a beautfiul house steeped in history where entertaining went on in a grand style. I. A beautiful selection of Jim Thompson's scarves, shawls, 't' shirts, books are available on site. Pick up the book detailing the mysterious disappearance of Jim Thompson and read it at your leisure in the close-by JT restaurant.

Not sure if this is worth it. This place has some interesting history in terms of an American who moved Thailand and started a business but felt it was just something to pull in the tourists like me. It was a bit of track for us to visit and would say it was not what I was excepting. I thought it would be about the details of how the silt trade was established but limited detail on that and more about Jim's Thomson's house. Wasn't my type of attraction.

A beautiful compound of traditional Thai houses. A place to learn about how silk making was revived in Thailand by an outsider. Mr. Thompson collected several teak houses, and had them reconstructed together to make a compound. Beautiful antiques, interesting structures, and informative displays about silk making in Thailand. This is also a wonderful place to buy silk items for gifts or memories.

Unique in Bangkok. Beautiful ensemble of old Thai houses in the middle of a beautiful garden. The feeling that somebody is still living there. Average collection of art but full of taste and personnality. Not to miss the Restaurant overlooking a splendid pond with huge koi fish.

It was OK - tour was quick.. It was OK - a bit of a money grabbing attraction. A person could easily do the tour on their own with head phones...or with the information on the wall.
The grounds are beautiful.
I enjoyed the beautiful thai dancer.

Interesting Tour and great place for Lunch. The tour of the house was very interesting and provides an interesting view of the country 50 years ago. The garden which we had seen on a TV show was very peaceful and zen like. Also you get some background on the silk industry. It is also a cool peaceful place to have lunch in the otherwise very busy downtown Bangkok.
Well worth a visit. Very well managed. A beautiful locations, good guides, interesting history and a surprisingly good cafe.

A bit fast but very interesting. The visits last about 30 minutes. Since there are many groups, it is quite fast and I would have liked spending more time looking at all the art objects showed here. A place to see in Bangkok.

Over rated. In this amazing city I was surprised to see this house built by a Westerner to be a must see. If the house was spectacular in and of itself I might think differently but it is not. You are required to use an onsite guide - the one we had seemed mildly bored. The highlight for me was the getting there in the longboat in the canal - otherwise a bit underwhelming

A surprise delight beautiful interesting house. Worth going. Beautiful garden and the house itself with the architecture Also how he decorated inside the house. Many treasures. The tour guide had important information and interesting. The gift shop had good quality Thai silk. Easy to get to off the train.

an oasis in a bustling city. What a lovely oasis in the heart of the bustling city. We'd been to the Grand Palace the day before which, whilst amazing to look at, was not exactly relaxing. Hordes of tourists in very large groups and little respite from the blazing sun.The Jim Thompson house, by contrast was relaxing, unhurried, cool, and though small, quite beautiful.If you'd like a break from the big city rush, this is your place. We were there early November, so can't comment on later on in the season :)

All in One: Museum, Restaurant, Shop. Had a delightful afternoon here after enduring the noisy hordes at the Palace. Good Thai food in the attractive restaurant, informative tour of the historic houses which were moved here from other parts of Thailand, and a shop with handsome, if expensive, clothes and accessories. The stylist has veered away from traditional Thai design which makes the merchandise less appealing to some of us shoppers....but this complex is well worth visit for the peace and quiet and exceptional taste exhibited in the house and gardens.

Small but perfectly formed. The Jim Thompson house is surrounded by lovely calming gardens, which you can freely photograph. Coming from England, I especially appreciated the huge pots full of orchids. Inside the house are lots of interesting objects, artwork, and furniture, which you can't photograph. Timed tours are relatively frequent - we only had to wait about 10 minutes for ours to start. The young Thai lady guiding us spoke good English and made the tour engaging and fun. As other reviewers have said, the shop is expensive; I left without buying anything, although there were lots of beautiful things. We didn't bother with the restaurant.

Antiques Museum in a Private Home. Each time I visit one notices more and more. Assembled from old houses all over Thailand, this impressive "mansion" organized by the promotor of native Thai silk had most of its décor accumulated from local secondhand markets during the 1950s and 1960s. In only keeps getting better with every visit.
Nothing There.. There was nothing there. Silk was expensive. Never Visit There again. No one was there. Have to say more, Never Ever
Really small. Had to wait for at least 20mins for the guided tour, you cant just go in by yourself. The tour itself only lasts for 15 mins. The house is great, worth a visit tho.

The Jim Thompson Legacy Thrives, But What About The Tribe That Created His Hand-Woven Silk. The picture perfect estate is, indeed, a fairytale come true. Notable works of architecture, indigenous decor, dated landscaping - all reflects a style that is traditional and yet appropriate today. An eclectic blend of culture that suits the purpose.The live silkworm weaving show, featuring a traditionally garbed Thai man, plus its labelled displays of white cocoons, spun and coloured raw silk is a crowd puller.I asked for direction to Baan Krua, where the Baan Krua community, the original creators of JT's hand-woven silk, were and how can I go there. I never got a proper reply. Maybe all the staff were stressed out by the frenzy caused by X'mas shoppers. I was there on 23/Dec/2014!JT's House, proper... is interesting but not worth the admission fee (no photos allowed). Likewise, the Thompson Cafe. Exorbitant pricing is the order of the day.The retail complex is on the ground floor of another house. The 2nd floor is a para-museum, depicting pictures, photos and featured screening of films where you sit on bales of hay blocks with checked seat covers. One of the halls had an extensive collection of Thai vinyl records.The balcony is spacious and boasts tables and seats to rest God's Weary Gentlemen... while their spouses and partners decide All They Want For Christmas.I spent 10,000Baht on shirts and wallets. How do I go about getting VAT refunds? " No problem, just go to airport, you can easily get it done" the sales staff promised. Can I get a VAT refund form so I know what I need to do? "We don't have it here. Only airport got"On Christmas Day, no less, I went through Immigration at Suvarnabumi Airport for my SQ979 flight due to take off at 6.45pm Bangkok time.
