great tour. really good tour of an interesting house and some very good antiques - bit of an oasis in busy Bangkok

Pretty house, not much else. I didn't really get the big deal. Beautiful house but really not a whole lot more it. Got a short walking tour with a guide around the 3 or 4 small rooms. The story of his life is kind of cool, but i wouldnt recommend that you go there if it's out of your way. I thought it would be filled with curious treasures from all over Asia and there really wasn't that much to see. Some furniture, a couple of supposed Buddha statues. Some tapestries in the stairwell that were interesting. I wouldn't recommend it unless you have a big thing for either the guy himself and the whole myth of him disappearing or if you are a fan of his textiles.

Oasis. It's the nicest place I've been to during my short stay in Bangkok. Lovely teak houses surrounded by a wonderful garden which seemed to me to be like an oasis on a hot as hell desert.It was also interesting to hear the story of Jim Thompson, which was new to me. Entrance fee (including the guided tour) was 100BHT and it was absolutely worth the money.

Worth a visit but pre book your cab home. A good way to sped a quiet morning looking around the house and area, and useful to pick up presents from the shop, but you will only need a couple of hours. Getting a cab afterwards was not easy.

Amazing traditional thai house in the heart of BKK. This house is truly wonderful. You are in downtown Bangkok but you feel in the middle of the Thai countryside thanks to the calm environment. The house itself is beautiful, in the traditional Thai style and furnished greatly with many rare pieces. If you do not have the chance to visit a traditional wooden Thai house, you must go to Jim Thompson's. Access is very easy through the BTS (National Stadium station).

An oasis. Bangkok is a very busy, noisy and fantastic place. The Jim Thompson house is a delightful break from all the mania into a green, traditional oasis. Touristy yes but we'll worth one visit if it is your 1st time in the city.

A Solace Place to Go to Escape the Busy Bangkok!. Very near to Mercure Siam Bangkok Hotel.Free cart ride from the left of the hotel, enter the 1st street.Entrance fee is 100 Thai Baht.After going to the mall shopping and experiencing the busy street of Bangkok, it is a different experoence to go amd visit tjos Jim Thompson House.

Must Visit!. I really think that anyone visiting Bangkok should visit this location. The shop is fantastic and the products that are produced are of the absolute highest standard it is brilliant. The house itself is a breathe of fresh air from the madness of Bangkok. A tranquil oasis it is beautiful and the art and culture that is available to see here is just amazing.

Beautiful house and interesting history. It's a bit of walk to find this place and especially in the Bangkok heat you'll arrive soaked wet! But it is worth visiting. The house is set among a beautifully landscaped garden - almost feels like a jungle. Very interesting to see the original house and artifacts.
Amazing. Great understanding about not only Jim but also about asia culture. The house is really beautiful but the best is the guide ( you dont need to pay extra) that shows you all the details.

very good. this is the best architecture in town.This former home of an American named Jim Thompson, who started the Thai silk industry after World War II, houses a magnificent collection of Asian art and many unique displays

Better than expected. I was expecting a dreary house, but actually it is a wonderful house, full of Asian furniture and items of interest. The house is not far from Rajathevi BTS/Skytrain station - and there's also a shuttle that runs between the house and the station. If you miss it on the way there, wait on the way back. It lingers at the entrance. There's a good restaurant too, and of course a very good shop.

Silky smooth tour. The Jim Thompson House is very well managed and the tour guides, available in many languages, are knowledgeable and articulate. Thompson collected vast array of artifacts from South East Asia and many are on display. The Teak house, built in traditional style, is beautiful. Of all the tourist spots around Bangkok, we especially enjoyed this one.

Really interesting, but the shop will bust your credit card.... Fantastic guided tour of the house, which is genuinely beautiful and interesting. The gardens are similarly Zen. Just don't expect any bargain silks in the shop!

Exquisite historical respite - a must visit. The design of the historic home and the way they present and conduct tours is wonderful. This is MUST visit for anyone visiting Bangkok. From an up-close viewing of a silk worm making silk thread to the amazing home, antiques and grounds of the home to the opportunity to shop for exquisite silk items in their shop to the lovely, charming (yet, very slow service) on-site restaurant. A real respite from the otherwise bustling Bangkok streets. I bought several amazing garments and toys in their shop.
Great Thai history. Great respite in the center of Bangkok. Enjoyed the tour of the different houses, very different from Western homes. Some nice quality products for sale in the store.

Recommended everywhere, but a bit of a disappointment. The Jim Thompson House is recommended practically everywhere - in guides, on internet sites, blogs... - and so we believed this would be a really great attraction. Unfortunately, it fell short of our expectations (maybe they were too high?) - we toured the house and gardens with a tour guide lady, who showed us various items in the house, explaining "this is the vase he brought from...", "these rooms used to be one building", "here he put the window sills inside the house", etc. - but practically no info on the man himself! The only really cool part of the place is the store, where you can buy beautiful (!) scarves, shirts, bags and other pretty souvenirs. If you're in Bangkok for a week or more - why not, if for 2-3 days - there are plenty other attractions to see in this city!

Tranquil oasis. I went because I was intrigued with the John Thompson story. Its a cool and calming house, a welcome relief from the sometimes frenetic pace of Bangkok.
To sit on the verandah and soak up the atmosphere and wonder about the man who lived there is blissful.
Good for Thai and farang. Very nice old house from old bkk. Make you think about old bkk and life everyday. Can have lunch and walk in garden too.

Remains a Calm Oasis. Returned after many years, and while there's been significant development in the area, just as across the city, this remains a leafy enclave along the klong. The tour moves you right along apace, so take time to wander about afterwards and spend more time in some of the outbuildings. They have a restaurant, but the food is tailored to western tastes and very pricey -- especially for what you get.
Tranquil Thai House. This feels like a tranquil oasis in the midst of bustling bangkok. It gives an insight into what Bangkok living would have been like. This is a great place for lunch

Interesting, but a little disappointing. It's absolutely beautiful there. We took the tour, which was simple and nice. An interesting view into the past. I would have loved to hear more about Jim Thompson's interactions with locals, rather than just hearing how his business flourished. I also was surprised that there wasn't more about the silk making process other than a funny cartoon drawing on one of the walls. I would have loved to learn more about that.That being said, it was a lovely spot and it was very different than the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. We did not eat there, but there seemed to be a very nice dining room.

Unexpected Tranquil Tourist Site. Visited Jim Thompson House after a busy morning navigating crowds of fellow tourists at The Grand Palace and Wat Pho. After a hot and crowded morning, Jim Thompson House was an unexpected, lovely treat. Accessible by subway (the BTS at National Stadium station), was immediately relaxed by the tranquil setting of the home and courteous staff. The guided tour was informative and surprisingly fun to interact with other English speakers (tours are given in many languages, you can request upon arrival). A short 1 hour visit is plenty of time, and a nice break from hawkers and crowds.Pros: Accessible by subway, interesting history, tranquil settingCons: None

Interesting Glimpse into the Past. Great to see some the of the traditional Thai architecture re-purposed into a beautiful house. Jim Thompson had a lovely collection of artifacts, too.The whole experience in very regimented. You must see the house with a guide, and you go in a group, and you can't take any photos of the interior. Everything is very tightly controlled except the gardens, which you are free to wander around.
Learning about original Thailand and Silk. And it seems Silk was not that famous! Interesting visit, beautiful wooden house. Sometimes the guide talks to low and too fast, so stay close to her!

Very nice, but overpriced for what you see and buy. This is a beautiful, tranquil collection of original houses tucked away in a small back street in the shadow of office blocks, flats and hotels. The guided tour (which is included in the ticket price) is interesting and explains the history of the site, and you also get to see some of the furniture and ornaments that were in the house whilst Jim Thompson lived there.Overall its worth a visit, but gifts, food and beverages bought inside are all a bit expensive. You should also be sure to apply your mosquito spray before going to this attraction, as the mosquitoes seem to like the houses, gardens and restaurant too.

Interesting story behind the house.... Jim Thompson's house is a great way to see a bit of traditional Thai housing. The story behind the house and the work that he put into revitalising the Thai silk trade is a great story. The tour is only around 35 mins and for 100 BHT (£2) entry, it's well worth the trip.

Calm and peaceful. Such a gorgeous place. They offer a guided tour for about 100 baht and it helps bring this place to life. We took a lot of pictures in here and none can capture the serenity and calmness we felt while here.

Very Interesting. I have read and heard about this for some time so thought it would be a must see, while it might not be everyone's idea of a great time in Bangkok, it was better than I expected, a very good tour by a English speaking guide and for only 100 baht.

Love this place. It is a very green place in the middle of Bangkok. There's also a cafe there and a gallery, and of course the Jim Thompson's store itself. It is free of charge to visit the gallery. Overall it is a very nice house!

Always worth a visit for your first BKK visit. This place is like an oasis in the hustle of BKK and you learn a bit about the revitalized silk industry in Thailand. The complex of traditional old wooden Thai houses is very beautiful and worth a visit anyway. The food in the restaurant is rather expensive but very very good too.

Serene Spot in the Middle of Bangkok. This is a great way to spend a couple of hours while in Bangkok. The Jim Thompson is about 3 blocks from the BTS stop and very convenient. The home and antiques are absolutely amazing, whether or not you are someone who enjoys looking at antiques, and the gardens are straight our of a magazine. The story of Jim Thompson and the mystery of his death add to the intrigue of this house. So glad we took the time to visit this beautiful home! I just wish the prices of silks and other goods in the store were lower. We did not eat the restaurant, but others who did told us it was delicious.

Must See. A tour of the Jim Thompson house will give you a different perspective on Bangkok. Although you can enjoy the tour without any background, you will get more out of it by reading up on Jim Thompson before your visit. In any case, you will get some Thai history, art and architecture in one visit to the Thompson house, plus a little mystery and a glimpse into the world of this enigmatic collector. The house itself is beautifully preserved, and the guides are very well prepared and knowledgeable. You will not be disappointed.

A respite from the crowded city. Down a narrow alley/street, it contains a beautiful garden and much of his work on display. There is also an excellent gift shop. Take a break from wandering. You can actually get a free tuk-tuk from the main street down the alley to the house where he lived.

Fascinating: A Good Addition To Your Itinerary While In Bangkok.. The Jim Thompson House and Museum should make an excellent addition to your itinerary while visiting Bangkok.It's located just a few blocks away from the BTS Skytrain stop (National Stadium terminus) in the center of town. Entrance fee is a negligible $3/100 Thai Bath (as of this writing) and includes guided tours that are conducted in English and French. The former house of American Jim Thompson who's popularly known for helping revitalize the Thai Silk industry. It's exemplary of what an upper class Thai home would have resembled in its day -- complete with rare collector pieces. It's quite impressive. Mystery still shrouds Thompson's final days. No one knows what happened to him precisely. Makes a visit to this museum all the more fascinating. It was doubly special for me as I happen to have paid a visit on March 21st, which was coincidentally Mr. Thompson's birthday.This premises is a complex of sorts -- housing a couple shops and onsite restaurant (which happens to be quite decent - if a tad pricy relatively speaking of course). Alternatively, if you'd like to grab lunch after your visit, hop back on the Skytrain one stop in the other direction to Siam. You'll be exiting right at Siam Paragon--Bangkok's mega mall. Descend to the food halls (lower level) for a massive (and relatively inexpensive) assortment of scrumptious delights.
Beautiful house with a lot of history. A beautiful traditional Thai house. Really interesting history about Jim Thompson. We all really enjoyed the tour. A haven in Bangkok. Recommend.

An oasis in the middle of Bangkok. Dont miss coming here. Was one of our favourite places to visit. Only 100 baht to get in and the guides are informative and keen to share Jim Thompsons story. Its so peaceful and calm right in the middle of this busy city. There is a restaurant there to eat or just a drink. Lovely to watch the Thai dancing too. The tuk tuk is free and will take you to the top of the road to the sky train. Loved it!
Historical house. Nice bit of somewhat recent history that includes an american architect and OSS agent?!? that disapeared in the 60's Old Teak everywhere and amazing fabrics.

Serenity amidst the surrounding ruckus!. Just in the middle of Bangkok, a city of nonstop commotion, is this gem of a place. Beautiful and serene. The visit was a soothe for the aching muscles and ringing ears. Its beautiful courtyard, small ponds with fish and turtle, thick-green yards, all-wooden wards and a large collection of valuable antiques is a must visit place.Info: Just 5 minutes walk from the BTS National Stadium and a kilometre from Siam Square. Entrance ticket is 100 Bahts and include a guided tour (available in 4-5 languages) and free shuttle from BTS and back.
Awesome Thai Silk. Love Thai decorating inside the store. Love Thai silk scarves. The service is fast and efficient. The price a bit too high!!! and less selection for colors.
Must see in Bangkok. For me this is a must see in Bangkok. Not much authentic architecture is left in downtown Bkk, so this complex is a true jam.

Mysterious Jim Thompson. Jim Thompson's story is very compelling and casts a mysterious and adventurous haze over the museum, which was Mr. Thompson's private home in Thailand. Tours are guided for the most part so you can't really wander around some areas. There is a restaurant there and a gift shop filled with beautiful silk creations.
Interesting place to visit. Great tours with excellent guides focus not only on Jim Thompson but also on Thai culture and customs. Inexpensive.
truly a neat experience. wonderful english speaking tour guides too! a great site to see. we fit into one of our lazy days. got a massage before and after the tour!
Interesting. Nice collection, interesting but is in the form of a house tour, good & friendly but no time to stand and look.

Jim Thompson House Bangkok. This was a highlight of our very quick trip to Thailand. A beautiful house full of amazing ceramics and artefacts from Asian countries. Our guide was very informative, gracious and easily understood. ( The guide is compulsory and comes with the BHT100 entrance fee). The gift shop was full of beautiful pieces but I checked the price of a small item I purchased there at the airport Jim Thomson house and it was the same. So definitely no bargains. Afterwards they have a free shuttle bus to the end of the street where it is a five minute work to the big shopping mall MBK.

Well worth a visit. I was fascinated with this house. I had purchased the book of his life and disappearance so I was interested to visit his home. I was not disappointed. Beautifully built to his design, and wonderful arts and treasures he had collected. Very good and informative tour guides. Well worth a quiet visit away from the usual sights and sounds of Bangkok.

Jim Thompson House. Because I'm a bit of a conspiracy theorist, I just had to visit the Jim Thompson House Museum. Such a pity that to this day after disappearing in the Cameroon Highlands in Malaysia on Easter Sunday 1967, Jim is still out there somewhere. He was 61 years of age when he went missing. I am 61 years of age now but I'm still here. Maybe it's because I don't work for the CIA. You do the maths. Anyway the house that Jim built in Bangkok is a fascinating place but it would be much more fascinating if you knew a little more about the man himself. I did notice that some of the staff there were not as informed about the man in question. Perhaps I could be your tour guide next time you are in town. I personally don't believe Jim will ever be found and certainly not in our lifetime. Nonetheless yo need to go check this one out for yourself. There's also a restaurant on the property should you want something to eat while you mull over your thoughts.

Wonderful tour guides. They were great with our toddler -- offered her all kinds of origami, plus smiles. Lots of hidden gardens and things to see here, from the turtles to the silk spinning to the Thai dancers. Really fun and easy to reach via skytrain.

Peaceful oasis in Bangkok. Lovely spot with an interesting history. A peaceful, tranquil place in a bustling city. Watch out for 'rouge' tuk tuk drivers who will try to take you to jewellery outlets. If they offer a 'too good to be true' fare then politely decline.
Jim's House. Spent an interesting couple of hours here one afternoon. Our 10 year son was very intrigued to hear about poor Jim's mysterious disappearance and the surrounding conspiracy theories!

Peace in the City. This place chronicles the mansion where Jim Thompson, the man who revitalised the silk industry in Thailand lived in. It's an amazing piece of work, with distinct Thai & Western influences.Getting there was quite easy as well, and most importantly, it's a bit of a reprieve from the hustle & the bustle of Bangkok.

Good to see a part of Thai Culture. One is given a guided tour of the House, and the guides are very good, there is a lovely restaurant where one can sit and have a cold drink and something to eat. It is interesting

Decent way to pass an afternoon in Bangkok. If you are interested in textiles or Thai architecture this is a nice attraction in the city centre. I feel like this is actually a better attraction in terms of architecture rather than textiles (although Jim Thompson made his fortune in the Thai silk industry). Its a nicely kept compound with gardens and an old Thai style home. It also has a nice restaurant with accessible Thai options (if not the most challenging)
Fantastic. Just a really nice place to visit! Do the tour and have lunch there,it was great and good value! Try the coconut ice cream served in the coconut !

Interesting. The house is very cool, and filled with lots of antiques. Kinda tricky to find. The tour was very good. The place really is beautiful to walk around. The gift shop is very good if you are looking to get some silk. It doesn't take that long, so it is easy to fit in.

Bit of peace in BKK. Really nice to get out if the hustle and bustle Bit if chill time wandering around the house and gardensChill on the terrace at the endThe shops pretty good as well . Definitely worth a visit and very reasonable and so easy to get to by BTS

Well organised attraction. If you like a challenge, try the Klong Taxi to reach this place. It is very well set out with Thai buildings and a collection of artifacts from the region. There is a free tour in English which lasts about 30 minutes. If you have not seen Thai silk spun before then this is your chance. Chances are it will be hot and the restauarnt in the complex is very nice for a drink or something more substantial. A good half day visit.

Good way to Spend an Hour or Two. The Jim Thompson House Tour is fairly interesting...the house is rather odd and quirky, as is the collection of religious art Thompson amassed, but it's a pleasant way to spend part of an afternoon. The gardens are lovely and the overall atmosphere of calm is a nice break from Rama I Road and the whole MBK scene.

An American in Bangkok. Went there for the 2nd time with my parents. This is a great place to get inspirations in home designs for those who love Asian details but with an American twist....I would love to have a home like Jim Thompson's House!

So glad we went to this wonderful museum. Loved the tour, loved seeing the house Jim lived in. It was easy to get to, on the train route.The house was so amazing, and the tour explained a lot about Jim's way of life.

busy and well organised. an interesting place to visit, good toilets and catering, run on timed system for the guided tour but pleasant courtyard and gardens to sit and wait in. An American businessman that fell in love with the area and filled his new home with local products. Photography allowed the grounds but not in the house and all bags & shoes left in lockers

Well worth a visit. Nice place to go to get an idea of Thai architecture from back in the day. The houses are well kept, the guides spoke surprisingly good English and the shops, although a bit expensive, have some pleasant gifts to take home. Also, there's a restaurant/cafe that's quiet and cool (with toilets). The whole place is good for a short break before getting back into the thick of things. Oh, they also have a free ride to the nearest train station - useful if one has problems getting about.

Tired by here.. After the Grand Palace and other sights we probably did not do this place justice we just wanted the tour to finish so we could get the air conditioned shop! Interesting as it was we could have left this out of the itinerary

Lovely oasis in a busy city. Enjoyed a recent visit to Jim Thompsons House. I first visited here many years ago and was lovely to return. We arrived early and went on the first tour of the day. The house is preserved well, the gardens flourishing and all the staff wonderful. They were very kind to my little girl, talking to her and getting them to help feed some fish. Her smiles showed how much she enjoyed this. The tour was very informative and at around 30minutes, well timed.We had drinks at the cafe, and whilst a little over priced, the setting made up for it. The shop is just beautiful and we all indulged in a little something to take home. The transfer buggy back to the Main Street is a welcome addition.Well worth the visit.

Another Must Do In Bangkok. This for us, was the best thing we did whilst in Bangkok. Our guide was english speaking and gave us lots of information, not just about the house, but things in general about the beliefs of Thai people that we had been wondering about, such as the shrines you see everywhere.The house was a lovely example of Thai Architecture. The objects in the house were very old and the guide gave you a very in depth talk about most of them.This was only 100 THB, and well worth it.
outstanding. best part of Bangkok. Sorry that the hotel had not knowledge of this amazing place. the tour was informative. The quality of food in the restaurant was scrum-diddly-umptious!

If you love art & antiques this is the place to go. Exceeded my expectations! Super well organized place, wonderful garden, amazing house and great collection of paintings and Chinese antiques. If you love art you should go here.
Fantastic getaway in the center of the city. It is a great quiet and green place in the middle of loud Bangkok. A perfect getaway for a bit of history and great lunch.

Not much to remember about this place. We (me and my wife) wisited the Jim Thompson House in our last full day in Bangkok (meaning, we had seen the most important sights already). It is a teak wood house ... but ... quite small. You pay 100 baht for the entrance (which for what you get to see seems expensive in comparison with the temple of the Reclining Buddha, for instance) and you have to take a guided tour to get into the house. If you have visited any of the temples before and had already a guided tour, this tour won't be of any interest to you as the guide talks mostly about Buddha figures and not much about the life of Jim Thompson and about what he did in Bangkok ... Of course, there were some interesting bits, but ... probably not worth the visit. If you want to see a really good teak wood building in Bangkok, you should visit the Teak Mansion instead.

A lovely trip but beware Mosquitos. A great history to this collection of art and houses with an interesting man behind it all. A short tour with a lot of info. Watch out for the very mean attacking koi fish and the turtle who lives in one of the water pools on the grounds. Also wear lots of insect repellent as it's beside the canals I I got eaten alive which was the only time in 4 months in Bangkok!

Don't miss the restaurant!. To be honest, most history or information of Jim can be easily found on internet (such as wiki), but the excellent food just can be found at the house, don't missed the "Yum SOM-O" and "Phad KEEMAO", the hamburger was delicious also.

A very interesting diversion in Bangkok. Is a 2-3 hour visit to the Jim Thompson House. This was my second visit to this museum and it is a very interesting insight to the silk industry in Thailand and Thai architecture. It is a short 10 minute walk or so from the National Stadium BTS station. A guided tour is mandatory and very informative. The gardens and house are really beautiful and worth a half day visit.
Nice Place, shame about the prices. Really nice place to visit and window shop, but the prices are very expensive. But hey if you want the genuine article this is the place to come.
Fantastic. Absolutely perfect beautiful house. Great architecture, furniture and fabrics. Well worth a visit or two!!

worth a visit. Have been in Bangkok several times and not visited. Wish I had gone sooner, informative guided tour included in the 200 baht admission fee. A calm oasis in the midst of frantic Bangkok.
Such a quiet place. I like the guided visitsThe one in french was full of humourThe restaurant is quite good too excellent fruit juices!

Oasis of calm. Great place to visit to slow down and experience Bangkok living in the sixties. Beautiful house with some lovely artifacts - you get a guided tour included in the entrance price of 120 baht!!! Restaurant by the koi carp pool well worth a visit - the food is excellent, and the coffee the best we had in Thailand. A real oasis of calm in the middle of the craziness that is Bangkok. Easy to locate by sky train - get off at the national stadium, then a very short walk. This was recommended to us on our 2nd visit to Bangkok and makes a welcome change to the temples, beautiful as they are.

Lush & Beautiful. Pricy silk scarves and clothing (especially compared to the Gem Mart), but the house was a treat to visit and the tour is very helpful in explaining his life. I am still in disbelief that he disappeared and, to this day, still has never been found.

A nice place to visit in the heart of BKK. Jim Thompson house is a must see. Easy to get to on the sky train as well,Look for the shuttle golf cart as u r walking down the block twards the house hop in if its empty.The resturant has a great lunch, try the mango smoothe as well!!

Beautiful house. A beautiful house and an interesting story. It's taken me many visits to Bangkok to actually get around to see this and I was impressed, as much by the property, as by the man and his story. And a bit of mystery always adds to the intrigue. It's well maintained and presented, with some spectacular individual pieces of south east Asian art in there, so all together it's quite a fascinating piece of fairly recent history, inma very old city.

Nice for a change from the wats. This house, made from several traditional Thai houses joined together, and set in a peaceful garden is a nice change of pace from the bustle of Bangkok and all of the wats. It is very professionally set up and well organised. Once you have bought your ticket (100฿ each) you will be assigned a time for the guided tour - when we visited it seemed to be within 20 minutes or so, so not a long wait. The guided tour around the house took about 35 minutes. Our guide seemed very knowledgeable and was able to answer questions which were off script, her English was also very good. I think that tours are available in several languages - I definitely heard French spoken as well. I understand why they need to take people around in groups as the house isn't really big enough to accommodate the number of visitors all walking around on their own but with 12 in our group it was difficult to get a good look at everything - maybe going first thing might be less busy and result in smaller group sizes? Bags are not allowed in the main house - lockers are provided and are monitored so I think quite safe.
expensive. Although they really have nice silk staff but compared with otherstuff in Bangkok their shop is too expensive.

Merits being higher on the list of attractions.. If you have become templed out and want to see something that resonates of old Thailand yet hidden in the city, this is the place for you. It is easy to get to - follow the excellent instructions in the review a few before this and it is a 5 minute walk.We arrived midmorning and it was not overrun. The tour lasted 40 minutes and was interesting. The star of the show was the house, contents and it's luuriant garden.

Dont miss it!!. A litlle oasis in the center of bangkok.Cheap entrance with excellent and friendly english and french guide included.Very good experience.Also try the cafe and the restaurant inside its delicious.

A Bit of History. We took th Skytrain to the Jim Thompson House from our hotel--a fun adventure. The house was a beautiful example of old Thai construction and colonial living.No open access, we had to go in a group with a guide. All belongings were locked (safely) in a locker--so don't bring big bags. The rooms were blocked so you looked through a narrow doorway--which provided limited viewing. I would have loved to tour at my own pace and look around a bit more.The museum display rooms were interesting. The store contained silk and cotton, things for kids and adults. Prices were over the top.It was interesting, but I would not put it on a must stop for a Bangkok trip.

An Oasis of Calm. We were sceptical but in the end very glad that we came. There is an obligatory guided tour around the house - pleasant but too reverential about Jim Thompson. You can then wander around the gardens and the smaller pavillions at will. The house is architecturally beautiful and a good example of traditional design which you may not see otherwise. Set in very pretty gardens with a lovely cafe, it is a relatively cool and relaxing stop on the Bangkok tour. Easy to reach by skytrain or canal boat.

Cool retreat. Enjoyed the lush garden setting. Jim Thompson's timber home is awash with beautiful antique porcelain and sculpture. A peaceful place to visit on a hot Bangkok day. Lunch in the restaurant was a tasty end to a worthwhile visit.

Don't miss it. While Thailand's glittering temples are perhaps the country's best-known icons, Jim Thompson House is also worth a visit in order to admit the beauty of Thai architecture. The interior of Jim Thompson's House is beautifully decorated and gives visitors a glimpse into the artistic taste of the silk entrepreneur who mysteriously disappeared in 1967.

Arrive early if you can. We decided to start our day with a visit to the Jim Thompson House and from there head to the BKM. We took the Skytrain to National Stadium (the last stop) and exited left using Exit #1 to get to the street level. Heading left again it is only a five minute walk...follow the blue signs. Protesters were camped along the way but security is tight. Turn right on Soi Kasemsan Song #2, pass the Jim Thompson Restaurant and Wine Bar and down just a bit further is the house. It opens at 9:00....consider getting there early and then have a nice lunch or snack after the tour. It will start crowding up around noon. The tours last 35 minutes and you must take a tour to see the inside. You are allowed only water and a camera (which can not be used inside) on the tour and keyed lockers are provided for your other items. The home is a wonderful oasis of peace...except when the long tail boats zoom by in the canal next to it. The shop offers up exquisite silks of a quality you won't find in the markets but at a price you won't find there either.

A must see. This is a wonderful tour that provides a glimpse of old Bangkok. The architecture and creativity of his home is amazing! There's a very good restaurant on the premises. They also provide tuk tuk service to the nearest sky train station

A little slice of interesting history.. We went to visit the house on advice from friends and were delighted we made the effort. It is a short tour but very interesting and the antiques and layout of the house made doing the tour worth it. Also, the gift shop here had the best, albeit more expensive, silk products we came across on our trip to Thailand.
Take a canal boat to get there. Really worth it. The houses, art, and furniture are beautiful. Take a canal boat to get there, its also an experience in itself!

Fascinating Collection. The Jim Thompson House is not to be missed in Bangkok. It is unique in the city as it is run by a private group who took it on after the eponimous founder disappeared in mysterious circumstances about 50 years ago. He has assembled a fabulous collection of historical artifacts from various different periods of Thai history. Good restaurant there too.

Very interesting. We thoroughly enjoyed visiting the Jim Thompson House Museum. The grounds while not extensive are beautiful. The artifacts in the house are wonderful. There is also a shop with Jim Thompson merchandise and a restaurant where we ate delicious coconut ice cream. I would recommend taking the time to visit the Jim Thompson House.

Hidden gem. I have visited Bangkok many times but had never been here so I thought it was about time. Very interesting, and offers some respite from the chaos of Bangkok, albeit briefly. Well worth a visit
Well worth a visit. Jim Thompson's house is well worth a visit. There are beautiful artefacts from various sources, as well as an interesting demonstration of silk-making.

Oasis in the middle of BKK. Great experience, wonderful architecture and an insight into old BKK. Well organised, cheap at 100 baht (shame the "student" in front of me used her 12 year old student card to get a 50% discount), guides are offered in many languages. The English guide was fine, and the tour whilst brisk and weaving in and out of other tours taking place, was very interesting. After the tour you are left to wander around on your own. Easy to find from the National Stadium BTS (the staff there can point you in the direction), this is a must visit.

Absolute oasis!. Whever you're a lover of silk, architecture, home decor, gardening, artifacts etc, Jim Thompson House is well up your street. I walked from the nearest BTS, which was a small 5 minute walk. Easy to find.  Each room in this spectacular heaven is worth a visit. I'v never walked into someones dining room and fallen in love with the table. Which as I recall, is apparently a Chinese ping-pong table as eating at a table wasn't the norm in Thailand. As silly as it sounds, I could quite easily pack up my things, and just squat in this oasis till I'm eventually kicked out with force. For anyone who's passion is creativity, this is a gem.  The guide spoke good english, french, and spanish as I recall. She was knowledgable about Jim Thompson and his home, and was happy to answer any question I threw at her! She had a smile on her face all throughout the trip, which added to the grand experience. Price was good, 50B for under 25s, 100B for over. Which is well worth what you receive. Restaurant prices were good, depends on your taste. Try the mango and lime smoothy, its by far the most delicious drink to grace my lips. I ordered a Thai Tom Yum Goong and was a delight. If I could have finished it all I would have, but it was so filling and the portions were a little too big.  The on site store was full on things for everyone. For those with a bit more walking around money will be in for a treat, with some lovely hand crafted bags, scarves, and sarongs. Overall, a definite visit if you're in Bangkok. More informative and beautiful than fun, not sure if it's good for children. Heaven!

A wonderful oasis of calm.. This was a delightful stop for a very interesting insight into Jim Thompson's life and home.The site has some lovely buildings and artefacts. There are some interesting demonstrations of silk thread production and Thai dancing, and a charming restaurant.There is a free shuttle by Tuk Tuk from the nearby nation Stadium BTS station.

Colors and silk. This is a espetacular opportunity to see the history of someone who felt in love with Thailand and changed the course of history. Jim Thompson showed Thai silk to the world and gave opportunity to develop another market inside the country. His house is very creative, he was also a kind of architect and have lots of curios histories and handcrafts. In the end it is a sad history but he's part of the city history. All the employees that work for this foundation talk about him with passion and love. It's wonderful.

The art in the house is better than the tour. Jim Thompson seemed to be an interesting american in Thailand. His house is now a museum and tourist attraction. The tour guide mostly spoke about how the house was built. There was little mentioned about his life. That's a shame because he obviously had quite an extraordinary life. Also, there are several historic art pieces in the house but the guide had very little to say about them nor the history of the silk trade. Her English was not good either. The gift shop is where you can buy silk items made by locals on the premises. The prices are a little higher than what you can find in other sections of Bangkok and but the workmanship is very good. There is a small restaurant on the grounds but we didn't eat there. The tour lasted slightly more than an hour. It was a fun way to spend a couple of hours as part of a day trip and the grounds and gardens are very nice. It's easy to reach via the sky train National Stadium stop. It's only a 500 yard walk down a small side street to the location.

A worthwhile trip. I really enjoyed this visit and it was an extremely quaint and pleasant environment away from the hustle and bustle of central Bangkok. It was good value for money at just 100 Baht, the tour guide spoke excellent English and was very informative, and the numbers per group are just about right.The only minor issues I had was that the tour felt like a slightly rushed whistlestop at just 30-35 minutes and there were no opportunities to take photos in the rooms, just in the garden, but I guess you have to respect that.Still, a must see attraction in Bangkok.
Beautiful. A step back in history especially as it is disappearing fast in Bangkok.A little Oasis of calm & greenery.Easy to get to

Shirts and silks. The tour of the house and gardens was excellent and very informative. His story is very interesting. Getting there was easy using the sky train and the people are very helpful if you miss the signs. We did not dine there but did shop in their lovely store. My husband bought a linen shirt and liked it so much he wore it out of the shop. This turned out to be an error as he was allergic to something that was used to set the design. It had to be washed first -- but it was such a beautiful shirt! They could not have been more helpful in answering emails in our search for the allergen that caused his contact dermatitis. We bought another linen shirt at the airport and this time washed it before it was worn. Lesson learned. My silk kaftan is one of my favourite garments and my best purchase of the trip. But the painted cotton sarong was very lovely too. Not to be missed.
Well worth visiting. Interesting story of an American who rescued the Thai silk industry. Old Thai buildings and antiques.

Tranquil haven with delightful food. A reliable standard and a must visit for first timers in Bangkok. Serene garden set with traditional Thai wooden houses. The unpretentious cafe is set by a carp pool and you can eat on a shady terrace or in a fabulously coloured interior replete with JT silk soft furnishings. Mixed Thai and European menu with a reasonable selection of lunch and tea time (only) fare. Nearby a fashion shop to be avoided at all costs, unless you want to look like you just stepped off a golf course in Florida sometime in the 1960s.
Magnificent collection. This house exposes a really magnificent collection of old and ancient objects, furniture and art. It gives a good overview of Tai culture.

good place to see. The place is not easy to find,there is many group guides in different languages,round the clock.
There is also many artistic pieces inside.
Well worth a visit. Lives up to the hype, we were really pleased we made the effort to check it out! Lovely to get some pics of yourself there, really iconic.

Thai Experience. This was the highlight of our visit to Bangkok. You can reach it by boat or train. once you are here, you can see how silk can be made using rustic methods. You will fall in love with this adventurer by nature and feel it's spirit within his house. I felt completely adsorb at his studio, there is a MAP!! done like 100 years ago... oh I cannot imaging the feeling of discovering the jewel named SIAM! Don't hesitate to visit this house...

A nice tranquil place. The house is well looked after and it's an oasis in a bustling city like Bangkok.The house and grounds are very well kept and the place will take you back to a more quiet and relax period of the 50's and 60's.I would have given 5stars but for the shop selling silk items in the grounds, which I suppose it was inevitable as he was credited with reintroducing and reviving the silk industry in Thailand.

Enjoyable but a little light on detail.. It is a pleasant way to spend an hour, but I do wish they'd have entered into more detail about the life of Jim Thompson. He's a fascinating character, and they could really utilise the property in a much better way in order to tell his story.

below average. I heard a lot about this place and got a chance to visit this Silk House this time. However, I was not impressed at all as the place is over priced. Variety is not upto the modern designs. Will not visit again as just a waste of time

A perfect place for dreamers!. Perfect in every way.Beautiful gardens, excelent products in the store, best food I had in Bangkok and our guide provided by the " House of Jim" was a perfect Hostess any good museum could ever have.

An oasis of Thai living in a city. The 6 teak houses brought to the site have been skilfully made into a wonderful home by this man who fully appreciated Thai craftsmanship. His collection of art, ceramics, statues are arranged beautifully in the rooms and demonstrate the beautiful creations by Thai artists. Jim Thompson's story is intriguing, his achievement in making the This silk industry so established in only 12 years was amazing. His disappearance is still unexplained but it's good that his house has been retained for people to visit and appreciate.The restaurant serves wonderful fresh food and has a welcome cool interior when the temperature outside is high.

Nice relaxing place in the middle of busy Bangkok. It was a time nicely spent in a place that offers peace and relaxation in the busy Bangkok. Tour around the house is nice, the food in the restaurant was delicious.

Interesting and peaceful break from the vibrant city. To get to the house we took the SkyTrain to the National Stadium station, and from there it was a short walk. The house actually consists of a cluster of traditional Thai buildings surrounding a small but well kept garden, which overlooks a canal. Viewing of the house is by guided tour only, and on our visit the guide was a very knowledgable young lady. The tour includes a history of Jim Thompson from his involvement in the silk industry through to his connections with the CIA and ultimately his disappearance in the jungle of Malaysia. The tour makes a very pleasant break from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Last day in Bangkok. At the end of a whirlwind holiday in Bangkok we decided to go to see Jim Thompson house because we couldn't get into the Grand Palace (after 3 attempts at different times & days). It's the best thing that could have happened! They also provide guides in your preferred language as part of your entry ticket. I learnt more about Thai culture in 30mins than the previous 3 weeks I'd been there. Visit if you want a cool oasis of calm. Even though the restaurant is a bit pricy, the menu is excellent & food is great but we were happy to pay for the ambiance.

I could live there. Stunning! Maybe worth reading up a bit before going as the tours are fairly quick as they want to get groups through, but stunning house in design + with all the artwork inside its incredible! Such a treasure of a place amongst a big city! You can tell though that he never had kids!

Visit If You Have Spare Time. This complex of houses was interesting; however, the need for a guided tour and the wait for one's group made more of the museum than warranted by what one saw and heard. Worth visiting after you have already seen more important sites and done other things that interest you.

A neat Suprise. This Place was better than I thouhgt it would be. An intersting look ata how Jim revived the hadwoven silk industry some demostration on silk making and the house was pretty cool with interesting antiques. I think the silk they sell is overpriced but it is unique.

A MUST VISIT attraction.... This is a must experience attraction. We spent a few hours here and were anything but bored. The tour was not only informative but enjoyable as well. The store here is quite interesting and the restaurant offers a wonderful lunch at a very reasonable price.

Peaceful oasis. This was recommended to me or I could have passed it by. We enjoyed a cool couple of hours here, with a guided tour led by a beautiful young woman with a gorgeous smile and a cheeky sense of humour. I had hoped to see a bit more of how weaving is done but it was lovely seeing the house and decor.

Very rich collection. Perfect organisation. I had to wait for a few minutes, and then the visit started.Very rich collection, and professional guiding. I was relectant to go there, I am not a big fan of museums. But I really enjoyed it.

History of Thai silk industry. This is another must see in Bangkok. This is a great tour and a history lesson of the revitalization of the Thai silk industry by Jim Thompson. I loved touring his Balinese open air style home full of wonderful artifacts. Bi lingual tours are available in many languages. Don't miss out on a visit to the tea room or the gift shop on your exit.

Jim Thompson House. This was an oasis on long hot day. After visiting the market I stopped here. There are golf carts that pick you up off the main street or it is a short distance to walk. I walked down and rode back. The house is beautiful. There are lockers to put your "stuff" in. The tour was excellent. The shop is very nice but is like the ones at the airport. They have a place to eat and the food was very good. I do recommend this as a stop. It did not take long and was very interesting!!

good selection but more expensive than other places. You can get big selection but the prices are abit more expensive than other places compare to other places.But if you want Thai Silk you can go there
Beautiful. Love all of the antiques and the home itself is beautiful. Gardens are lovely and the tour is very informative.

Not what I thought. Everyone said to visit this place, I wasn't so sure. It is definitely a gem in this crazy city. What Thompson developed is beautiful and historical. There is also a great deal of information on the cottage silk industry in Thailand. A defiinite must-see

Even better. I last visited Jim Thompson's house about 5 years ago. This time I was even more impressed. The guides (included in the modest admission fee) were polished and professional answering even completely inane questions from one of our American cousins (they don't get out much!). The gardens are very well kept and I had one of the best coconut ice creams and lime juices I have had anywhere in the world here. The toilet facilities were clean and modern.

Lovely home, tasteful gift shop and restaurant. Our local friends brought us here for both the tour and lunch in the restaurant. Food was reasonably priced, as was the tour - they offer English guided tours throughout the day so be sure to time it right. If you want a really special Thai silk scarf souvenir, the gift shop has a beautiful but expensive selection. As my friend said, yes you pay more than the market stalls but you know it's authentic and the designs are unique to the Jim Thompson House traditional designs.

A tourist spot. When you’re in Bangkok with you family never forget to visit the Jim Thompson House. It’s not much from the look of it but it’s part of Bangkok’s Culture and History. The house was named after its primer owner whose name was Jim Thompson. He was also the one responsible for the beginning of the booming of the Silk industry in Thailand. This is a nice place to stroll around with the kids, especially the garden. There is an entrance fee of around a hundred Baht.

The man who single handedly put what was a cottage industry onto the world map. It was walk back into history. The house and grounds were well worth exploring. You can take a long tail boat along the river right within a 10 minute walk to the Erawan shrine where the Grand Hyatt Erawan hotel is located.

Intriguing. It was intriguing to hear and see the history of Thai Silk and the importance it had and has in the Thailand economic structure. The house is a museum of his actual home and also includes a restaurant and store. Jim Thompson also has an outlet store near the Bang Chak BTS Station on 93 Soi. I was told that it has the same grades of silk and patterns as the store but not the same year of fashion. In other words depending on when you go to the outlet you will find last seasons accessories.

Good way to spend an hour. I went to pass some time and had no real interest in Jim.The house and gardens are of course beautiful, but the stand out stars here are the guides that take you around the place and give you a walking narrated tour.They are available in many languages. You sign up when you get in and they are frequent enough so that you aren't waiting too long to get started.Cheap entrance fee. If you like architecture or silk then you'll love this place.If you are in Bangkok and looking for some things to do, you could do much worse than here.There is an on site restaurant too which gets good reviews, although I didn't try it.

A great story during interesting times. Definitely worth the visit to help you understand a little about Bangkok during the 60s. It's very near a Sky Train stop so easy enough to get there, You can only envy the life Jim Thomson lived. I was hoping to buy some shirts in the gift store but I found it rahter under stocked particulary with men's apparel.

Jim Thompson House and great lunch.. We went to the Jim Thompson House and ate a fantastic padthai lunch. The grounds are very peaceful with ponds and groomed landscaping. There was young Thai lady spinning silk. Occasionally she would dance a Thai song which was a special treat. We fell in love with her as she was an example of the silk industry Jim Thompson apparently loved.
Very interesting. Loved the house and the guided tour was very interesting and informative, great sense of history which I would reccomend to any visitor to Bangkok

Worthwhile house museum. This museum includes several original Thai homes combined into a home by American Jim Thompson. The beautiful home has many Asian treasures as well as architectural details created by Thompson. You take a guided tour. Photos are not permitted in the house but you can photograph the gardens and exteriors. A beautiful garden surrounds the houses and there is a large shop of textiles. This is not the number one attraction of Bangkok, but if you have a few days in the city, this museum is easily reached by Skytrain and a short walk (they even have a free shuttle down the street from the Stadium Skytrain station).

worth a visit. While this is a quote tourist spot, it is quite beautiful and the story and information terrific. Their silk stuff is at the highest and expensive level but you will not get this quality for much less anywhere. Even has a decent eatery. You can go via an in city khlong and get off right there. Boat is 14 baht depending on start. We went from Asok one stop on the metro where we could get the boat. Really should go.

Interesting history of the silk trade.. To reach The Jim Thompson House, take the BTS skytrain to the National Stadium stop, it will be the last stop. Exit where you see the Ibis/Mercure Hotel. At the bottom of the stairs of the BTS, make a U-turn and walk up to the next corner, turn right and go all the way to the end of the soi. The entire area of the grounds is not very big, it is rather compact. But what you will find is a number or original Thai houses the Jim Thompson moved to this site for his home. Once you purchase a ticket, they will put you into groups based on your language, and give you a time for the start of the guided tour. They will ask you what language tour you want to join. English or Thai will be the most featured. The tour guides are very knowledgeable and will give you a complete history of Mr. Thompson and how he developed the silk industry in Thailand. Also on the grounds is a Jim Thompson store and a Jim Thompson Restaurant. The canal runs right by the property, so take a look at that also. Restrooms on the property and seating around the grounds also. It is a great tour to learn about some history of the silk trade and the American that developed it for Thailand.

Lovely place, great guide. Liked how you get a tour rather than just looking yourself. Guide was really nice, clear to understand and very informative. We enjoyed the stories about Jim Thompson, humourous mentions of his chamberpot fascination etc. Really nice attraction - highly recommend.

Inner city sanctuary. We were staying at Evergreen Place just over the road so it was in our neighbour hood. Very good value at $100b each including a guide in your native language. Tour took about 35 minutes. A n interesting insight into this American man who revived the traditional Thai silk industry. If you are coming on the sky train only few 100m from the national stadium and a courtesy cart collects you if you are lucky as you approach it. Great value.
Interesting stories about a great man.. The tour in the house was really interesting. The guide was perfectly spoke english so she was telling every stories crystal clear I really enjoyed it.

Interesting glimpse into the life of Jim. Jim Thompson is a legend in Thailand. He developed and promoted the export of Thai silk. His mysterious disappearance has never been solved. His home is a tribute to many of the Thai traditions, and has been kept as a museum/visitors centre.
Tasteful design, beautiful place. Enjoyed the peace and quiet of the place, very nice cluster of traditional Thai buildings in a beautiful garden. Very tastefully designed.
Impressive and Inspirational. Had a great time there, and learning about someone that did what he did is rather inspirational. A fantastic house next to one of the canals in the heart of Bangkok

Quietly Grand. Enjoyed going through how such a famous personality lived in Thailand. It was beautifully layed out and functional.
It was a short travel to reach the place, but well worth it especially if you enjoy history.
The house speaks of a time of tranquility in this city.

Lovely afternoon at Jim Thompson. The house is wonderful and shows how they were built on the last century. He bought two or three old houses and put them together to make this one. Jim collected art and there are amazing pieces of furniture, sculptures, paintings. In the premises there is also demonstration of how silk is produced, as he was the person who made Thai silk famous out of Asia.Very nice place to spend an afternoon. There is also a tearoom and lovely gardens.
MY Third Visit and Still Special. This is a relaxing stop in a chaotic city. The tours are inexpensive, frequent (reservations not required with a tour starting every few minutes), and educational.

Interesting sanctuary in the heart of the city. Really enjoyed a visit here. It's an oasis of calm away from the hustle and bustle. The gardens are gorgeous and thoughtfully laid out,you won't believe you're in the middle of Bangkok! The tour departs every 20-30 minutes and lasted for about 45 minutes,which was just right. The guide had great English and was informative and funny. The house itself is beautiful, lovingly restored and a pleasure to step foot in. The gift shop had some nice silk scarves and other bits and pieces, quite expensive (as these places always are) but nice all the same. Great way to spend a couple of hours and learn some facts about silk production and a bit of Thai history.

Now for something completely different. After traipsing around the concrete city that Bangkok has become, Jim Thompson's House takes you back to what the city must have looked like years ago. My wife and I took the tour on January 19, 2014. The tropical gardens were a respite from the nearby mall land (which at that time was surrounded by the protests from the Bangkok Shutdown). The house is a beautiful wooden house built on stilts like the traditional Thai houses to protect the living quarters from the floods in the rainy seasons. The tour was very informative, explaining such things as why all Thai houses (and our hotel room) have a beam at the bottom of the door to prevent evil spirits from entering. In addition, we found the people spinning silk from the silkworm cocoons outside the house fascinating.Only lacking was a discussion of Mr. Thompson's mysterious disappearance in the highlands of Malaysia. Was he "disappeared" by the CIA? Or did he stage his own disappearance so he could sail away to a mysterious island a la Captain Nemo? All and all, a very nice way to while away an hour or so in Bangkok.

Hidden Attraction In The Middle Of Bangkok City. When we heard about Bangkok tourism then it will pointed to spend whole time in the cheap good market,like Chatucak or Pratunam market. But surprised on the middle Bangkok city we can found thi Jim Thompson House attraction, very secluded and nice location near National Stadium area. Just use BTS/Skyline using Silom Line and drop in National Stadium BTS, then down to street and walk about 500M, you will find this attraction inside small alley.And it's run very professional. Some staff in welcoming us and deliver us to the receptionis area. Entrance fee is 100 bath and they provided guidance tour in some language,like English and France. Very good so every visitor can enjoy the house/museum with good information. As the guide tour explaining every detail and aspect reason Mr. Jim had when he created the house. So when you enjoy the decoration, architect and the philosophy behind it, this is the place you should go to see. Very recommended

smooth as silk. i liked all i saw specially the tie-die section the color used in different items is very eye catching. They have a large collection of scarves and ladies top. But i fill the men section is the most rich part of the store i am sure no men can live the store without one silk shirt it is a collectors item.

Culture in Bangkok City Centre 4. An beautifully preserved traditional wooden house from the 40s, lived in by an American thai silk manufacturer at that time.If you are comfortable using the Skytrain, it is easy to get to. Alternatively jump into a metered taxi. There is a silk shop on the premises which will give you the opportunity to buy presents to take home (or for yourself).I spent a pleasant hour and a half here, although you could probably get around in about half an hour if you are pushed for time.

An eye opener. Apart from the commercial aspect of this business the house is really a window into a past era I was fascinated by the history of Jim Thompson and what he helped to achieve for the silk fabric industry in Thailand. Well worth finding and visiting. The products are also worthy of purchase as the quality is good and the range diverse.

Worth the hassle of finding it!. These are truly worth a visit if you are at all interested in the 'old' Bangkok, or architecture, or interiors. It is a wonderful group of buildings, beautifully maintained, set in a wonderfully lush and well-maintained garden. The interiors are stunning, with some exquisite furniture and 'objets'.There is also a delightful cafe, and a lovely shop with high quality goods for sale. It is a haven of peace and quiet after the hustle and bustle of urban Bangkok.However, they only offer guided tours, and our guide was not very good: rather a wooden presentation, with no feeling to it. Obviously learnt off parrot fashion. Otherwise an excellent visit.

An oasis. This was a lovely peaceful restaurant in the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. Good food excellent service and the fact that it was full speaks for itself. The tour around the house was sensitively done by enthusiastic, linguistically excellent Thai guides

A decent change of pace.... The story was interesting but the scenery was average. You are not allowed to take pictures on the tour. I found the women appreciated the tour more than the men (my personal take)....

Below average. I have been there a couple of times but the quality and service is below average. It's mostly for foreigners and not for locals. Prices are expensive and quality of service is not very good. Not worth going there as it's just the name what is selling

Quiet oasis in the middle of bedlam!. We had an extra day in Bangkok and were very pleasantly surprised to find this piece of history buried in the hustle and bustle of the city. Peaceful green oasis and a wonderful gift shop. Two others gift shops at the airport.

An insight into another part of Bangkok. My daughter (20) and I visited here, walking through the protesters' barriers from our hotel. It is an easy walk from National Stadium. We were met by a small vehicle (golf cart) which took us the short distance up the road to JTH. We took a tour in English with a knowledgable local guide who gave us great insight to the man, his business and the environment he lived in. The tour took us into his house and through the beautiful garden. Well worth a visit and if you wanted something special to take home, look in the shop on-site for silk items. I am looking forward to the cooler weather to wear my new scarf.

An insight of old Siam. this was a highlight to see the traditional Thai houses . it was very interesting to see the silk being spun from the cocoons and to hear how JT revived the Thai Silk Industry. I recommend the Tour and the Shop has lovely things.

Nice. Jim Thompson house is actually six old Thai houses dismantled and brought to this site. They are beautiful buildings, furnished simply but wonderfully. The whole setting in the middle of Bangkok is very tranquil.

A slice of history. Definitely recommend this to anyone visiting bangkok. It gives an interesting look at how life was back in post war bangkok for one of its most famous uinhabitants, the guided tour at 100 baht is a steal. Have a drink in the on site cafe and make sure to walk around the gardens too. No lady would fail to be impressed with a silk scarf from here too (although they have a stall at bangkok duty free so save your purchases until there)

Great place to visit for Thai traditions, history.. Definitely worth a visit if you would like to see some Thai history and have two hours to spare in Bagkok. The tour is very well conducted and makes you aware of Thai traditions.

Magical glimpse into another time and an intriguing man.. This house museum is worth visiting... without hesitation. The Jim Thompson story is fascinating, the place is magical, the shops are super, albeit expensive, the restaurant serves great food. Read a little about Jim Thompson first. The guided tour (efficient and interesting) speaks more to Mr. Thompson's house and not so much about the fascinating man. Go!

Beautiful. We stumbled upon the house on accident and were so happy that we did. Beautiful gardens, beautiful house and professional staff. It was fun seeing the silk being hand woven and shopping in the store.

Very spectacular grounds and houses. This is a stop in Bangkok that is well worth taking. It shows a side of the city that one would not normally see. The grounds are quite lovely and the buildings are very impressive. Also impressive is the extensive antiques collection in each of the rooms of the house. A trip well worth taking.

Thoroughly enjoyed this house tour!. If you like architecture and home & garden design like I do, you will thoroughly enjoy Jim Thompson House. He was a fascinating man and very important to the revitalization of the Thai silk industry (and this is fairly recent history). Don't miss the cocoon spinning demo in the entry garden. I loved seeing this attraction and later going to the Queen's museum at the Grand Palace where you see her silk gowns on display. It totally enriched my experience in Thailand.

Beautifully re-built. Some of the house was original and that was very beautiful. You can't take photos inside which was disappointing - you can buy the post cards! The newly built sections were also quite lovely but not being original didn't have the same feel. right on the canal and near a canal stop and the sky train it is quite easy to find.

Small But Beautiful Place. This is a small but beautiful place near the heart of the shopping area. You will learn about the how an expat American developed the silk trade for Thailand to the western world. You also get a guided tour of the old fashioned Thai style buildings he used to live in. Beware of scamers on the road down to this place for all it is open all day they will tell you it is closed for lunch and take you to buy something expensive (common scam and happened to my sister here).
A little bit boring. The house and grounds are lovely but the guided tour is compulsory and is a bit rushed and boring to be honest. The prices in the shop are extortionate!

Visit if you have time to kill. Compulsory 40 mts or so "tour" inside the building is rather rigid especially if you visit in peak season (maybe not much of a problem in quiet or less crowded time), and one probably cannot pick a guide to go with, or know the time of tour to take before arriving at the premise, or seeing the place at your own pace, so one's luck in finding this place interesting depend on them. We were made to wait for about 30mts (being encouraged to spend time and money in adjoining shop and or cafe restaurant). Before applying for a tour, we had a lunch at an adjoining restaurant because there were not much place for stopping by from the BTS station to the house. With like-minded visitors, the place was busy and orders came late for pad thais (which somewhat tasted ketchupy?!) and drinks. It seems there are guides on volunteer and professional basis, and fluency in language and art/architectural/historical interest/knowledge vary per person. Don't go with a limited timeframe thinking you could breeze through this premise.

Intersting history. Jim Thompson is well repected in Thailand and it is helpful to know a bit about his history before you visit his house. The grounds and house are worth seeing. The restaurant is convient and the food was good but a bit pricey.

Awesome teak house. Should go there to visit the real teak house and see it's decoration. It is astonishing. Lot's of antiques!The local tour it not that good cause they keep saying: afterwards you can tour again by yourself to see this and that... But the only way to be inside the main house is with them...so go with them to see inside and forget "them".afterwards you can visit the store and buy high quality silk and wool pachminas.

Interesting story but that's about it. Our guide was lovely but we couldn't really understand her English. The bits we could understand were fascinating. It's basically a walk through Jim's house and a chance to eat and buy stuff at the end. We enjoyed the lunch break for a rest but if I would have preferred a DIY walk through rather than a guided tour.

A thoroughly enjoyable attraction. Tour is compulsory, but is really enjoyable and quite reasonably priced (50baht I think for students). The house itself is pretty amazing and has some fantastic artifacts and pieces of art within. The tour guide made the tour really interesting, and told the story of Jim Thompson really well. Also quite funny, surprisingly! Among the most enjoyable things i did while in Bangkok. Would recommend to all

so much history. well organized, you move in groups and you have a guide who can speak French, English, Japanese, german, etc..houses (many) have a story to tell. you can also spend time looking at the way silk thread is extracted from cocoons. AND take time to enjoy the dessert at the café. ask for sticky rice and mango- the best dessert I have had anywhere. worth the money and you can in turn tell everyone else about it.the gift shops is beautiful, but expensive. if you need to get quality items and unique this is the place... but be forewarned, it is not cheap!(both monetary and quality wise)

A wonderful surprise. After being advised by the hotel tourist information to stay out of the centre of the city, we decided that Jim Thompson's House could be good. I admit we both did not have high hopes for this place, but we were extremely surprised how great it was. It was a little bit of peace in a hot, humid and bussling Bangkok with a great story and architecture to boot. I highly recommend a visit. It is not far from MBK shopping mall, say about 5-10mins and down a side street (there is a shuttle from JT house to the main road). We ate at the little cafe there and it was very good.Definitely a goer if you are nearby in Bangkok.

Touristy, but good tour and intro. to Bangkok and silk industry. They hold frequent group tours, which were good, though came across as "canned". The grounds and buildings are interesting to see and to learn about mid 20th century Bangkok and the development of the silk industries in Thailand. The store on premises is lovely to view, but all products are extremely expensive even for the high quality. The setting of the café is lovely. Upstairs from the shop is a museum of textile arts -- I liked this the best of our visit to Jim Thompson house.

I'd Live Here In A Heartbeat. What a fabulous attraction. The house JT built is absolutely amazing and beautiful. It was my wife's favorite place we went to in BK. And the attached cafe actually had great food and drink - totally worth staying for a refreshment.
Surprise. My surprise was that I actually enjoyed the tour and visit. See how the retrieve the silk from the worm was fascinating. I even bought a shirt and thought the prices were okay.

Great to see a typical Thai House. If you are looking to see how they make silk... this is not the place. However, it is great to get more insight in the Thai culture, traditions and Jim Thompsons life. There is an admission fee but you do get a 40min tour. You're not allowed to discover the house by yourself so I would suggest to be there early so you don't have to wait too long for the tour to start. 40 minutes was in my opinion not enough time to discover all the art in the house but if you are in Bangkok for a few days this is a must-see!

Great place in central Bangkok. Very nice place, with a rich culture. The architecture is quite impressive and the tour guide are very knowledgeable. It is very close to the sky train and so of easy access.
Interesting. Interesting place to visit to see old Thai style housing and to learn about the story of this intriguing man. Worth a few hours but no longer.

Fascinating home and more fascinating story. The Jim Thompson house is a bit out of the way but worth the trip. Gives you an idea of what life was like at the middle of the last century. A guided tour is obligatory but informative so well worth it. Make sure you sign up for a time before enjoying a meal at the pretty restaurant. of course, the shop is well stocked with top, top quality items that reflect a modern sensibility.
Classic part of Bangkok. A 200-year-old house from Ayutthaya that was dissasembled and reassembled in Bangkok for Jim Thompson, who reinvigorated the Thai silk industry.

An oasis in Bangkok. Beautiful garden, a real oasis in Bangkok. Nice to see the traditional houses and the collection of historic art. Would recommend going in the morning, as it is not too crowded, they open at 09:00. Before of after take a walk along the river, head left and there is a bridge that will take you across.

nice, but you need to wait over 1 hour for tour to start. This place is worth a visit. It gives a nice introduction to what a traditional Thai house looked like. If you're just visiting Bangkok and then going to the beach you will not get any other opportunity to see this.On the other hand this is a very commercialized place with an expensive gift shop and expensive restaurant. The tours start very often but you will still have to wait over an hour for yours to start - very convenient for the owners because you will be compelled to eat at the restaurant or visit the gift shop (I felt that the delay was on purpose).Just to let you know - this place may seem to be a national museum but is in actual fact a privately owned business.

Interesting - and architecturally very impressive. I've been to the Jim Thompson house twice, and it's very interesting to hear the story of the silk merchant who vanished in the Cameron Highlands of Malaysia. The house itself is beautiful, all wood, and a very surprising sight in the middle of Bangkok, especially at the end of a grubby street. The house also has a lovely gift shop attached, which is pricey by comparison with other silk products you can buy in Bangkok/ Thailand, but you're paying for the name. I'd say the quality of the items is probably better than many of the other items you can buy in the city, and particularly much better than anything you'd get in the markets - the silk is finer, the detailing neater and the finish better. They keep a lovely range of items including handbags, purses, ties, dressing gowns/ robes, soft toys, and household items like placemats. A lovely place to visit for some respite from the craziness of the city.

Thai Teak house with furniture. The guided tour is given by them. I felt rushed. They kept us moving. They had a lot off groups. The furniture was nice. It was very peaceful in the garden. Loved looking at the paintings. The silk shop was very overpriced.

If you like the Thai teak houses, dont miss this. I ran out of time on my last trip to Thailand and did not get a chance to see the Jim Thompson House. Even if I had seen it then, I would returned and seen it again on this last trip, it is that remarkable. Yes I admit I am a lover of Thai teak houses, but this place was truly exceptional. Jim Thompson was an American who slowly rebuilt the Thai silk industry, generating publicity for the product in Europe and America. He found 6 old teak houses and brought them together in this complex, some of the houses merging to form his main house, others changed to form other outer buildings such as his study. Set in a lush tropical garden, right on a klong (canal), it is easily found in the warren of streets surrounding it, just ask any friendly local for directions if you get lost.The house has been kept as Jim Thompson left it, furnished with the antiques he found all over SE Asia, his favourites seeming to be Buddha statues that had been damaged in some way. There are frequent guided tours, very informative, but remember once you are inside the house you cannot take photos. There is also a terrific restaurant and a gift shop inside the complex. Hard to believe you are in the middle of a bustling city while you sit relaxing with a Thai iced coffee, in the beautiful surroundings of the house and garden.Make the time to visit it, the extra bit of allure being that Jim Thompson disappeared in the jungles of Malaysia in 1967 while visiting friends there. No-one knows what happened to him, and his house was left to a foundation for the people of Thailand.

Aussies Abroad. Having read the reviews and LP entry, I could see that this must be worthwhile, but for anyone interested (even remotely) in finding an oasis of calm and tranquility so close to the hustle and bustle, this is a must do activity. We were travelling as two families with teenage kids, and all loved it. The architecture, design, art collection and JT's story all made this a great visit.

A must see. Beautiful Thai Teak House, and a great story. The mystery of JT keeps people enthralled but his re-energizing the Thai Silk industry is his biggest contribution. The JT goods are pricey if you're buying. There is a shop in the Oriental Hotel and at the airport as well.

Well worth a visit. When I first read about this attraction I did not think it worth a visit, especially as it was a distance away from where I was staying. A friend recommended it and I am glad he did. It turned out to be a very interesting visit. When in Bangkok don't miss it.
