They have a good air conditioned gift shop with much higher quality tourist merchandise than most tourist stops we visited. I have been to 25 countries and seen many amazing places so I guess I am getting hard to impress. An hour was enough for us. I wouldn't send my friends there.

INTERESTING AND EDUCATIONAL. Beautiful peaceful setting - beautiful orchids, garden, and furniture in the heart of Bangkok. Reminder of an earlier time. Worth a look. Learn about silk processing and see a graceful Thai dancer. Shop is too expensive though - better value can be obtained at markets.

GREAT - worth a visit. We visited Jim Thompson House a few months back......didn't know what to expect because we felt it was too hyped up and must be touristy...But once we got there we loved walking about the lovely Antique teakwood home.....Jim Thompson basically collected old antique teak homes from different parts of the country and had them brought to this site in Bangkok by the river where they were re-assembled and arranged so as to make the most of what must have been a charming and uncluttered view of a (at that time) serene and unpolluted river...the atmopshere inside the home is so charming and elegant.....the foundation has managed to maintain everything in pristine condition and the young guides who take you around the complex speak good english and are very friendly...They have a lovely landscaped garden with a big Koi pool right next to a cafe that serves up excellent Thai food, so this can be a lovely half day excursion right in the heart of the city!! They also have a shop here selling all their lovely items, so that's another plus.....This place is acessible by the BTS....just ask at the information counter of any BTS station and they will let you know which station you have to get off at for coming here....

Unexpectedly Good. Excellent for seeing how the upper class lived in Bangkok 60 years ago. The house is wonderfully preserved. They also have demonstrations of how silk is processed and a nice shop for high quality scarves and shirts.

An enjoyable tour. The English-language tour guide was very good. The tour is an excellent value, especially for students! It contained lots of interesting information. The house is really interesting to see. I didn't know much about Thai culture but this tour surprisingly provided a lot of information on this end as well. It's unfortunate that they do not allow photos inside the house, but I found that it's fine to take photos from inside the house out the window!

Beautiful Home. The tour and history of Jim Thompson was very nice. The house is very pretty and it is interesting how he was an American but fit into the Thai culture so well. I wouldn't say it is a must see if you don't have that many days in Bangkok. We were there 5 days so we were able to fit it in.

A good morning spent. A good morning spent away from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok public transportation mayhem. We enjoyed the guided tour of Jim Thompson House. Its great for giving you ideas for interior decoration. There was a beautiful Thai dancer demonstrating the culture of traditional Thai dance.A free shuttle bus to take you back to the station or main road.

A little bit of tranquility. This little piece of tranquility in an otherwise cramped over rated city is well worth a visit even if only to restore your belief that your visit to Bangkok was worth it. When all around there is poverty and vendors are grabbing at every crumb from tourists, whilst others gorge on designer outlets and trivial possessions this place takes you away and restores your belief that the world should not just be about greed and possessions.I am not sure why Bangkok has been so highly rated, away from the temples and Jim Thompson's house it offers little of attraction.The Thai lady weaving silk and performing a traditional dance were also nice to see.

Definately worth a visit. Beautiful house away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Really nice was to spend a couple of hours and hear the interesting story of JT. Restaurant is lovely, beautiful, reasonably priced food, served in an elegant location. Definitely worth a visit.

Nice House and Professionally Trained Guide.... Very impressed with the preservation done and the stories told by the guide was excellent! A nice place to visit to learn more about Jim Thompson and his collections of antiques. Entry fee is THB100 but worth the money!

Thai Silk Industry Revived - Must See. This was perhaps my favorite museum tour. The 1/2 acre property is well preserved and a very peaceful, tranquil space to visit. Our tour guide (English speaking) was delightful and funny with the stories. We also stopped for lunch and it was wonderful also. I highly recommend anyone visit this beautiful property and museum to hear more about Jim Thompson and how he revived the Thai Silk industry and increased awareness of these beautiful silks after supplying fabric for the movie The King & I.
Go for tour and lunch!. Antique collector, businessman who revived the silk industry after WW II designed a beautiful residence and gardens. Stay for lunch in the restaurant.

Worth the time. If you are interested in history you'll want to visit the Jim Thompson House and learn about the silk trade and living the Thai way. Thompson was an interesting man and his contribution is important. His home is now a museum that you tour with a docent in small groups learning the culture of living in Thailand, how and why certain constructs are used in homes. Well worth your time to go here!

Cool exhibits. Nominal admission fee required but it's worth it.Guided tour for all visitors.Tour guide speaks good English and gives a entertaining story about Jim Thompson's life in Thailand.Has a nice gift shop and restaurant on property.Has a good collection of artifacts.Takes about 1-1.5 hours to enjoy the place.
Oasis in a busy city. We spent an amazing couple of hours here. Fascinating, this is a time capsule. Would definitely recommend a visit.

A house with a few buildings and bunch of broken Budhas. This is a small villa with a few wooden houses (one of them bigger than others , i.e. 150m^2).It is not a historical place (has been built after the WWII) and contains a few broken Budhas and personal collections of this normal American who has been disappeared in Malaysia (killed? died?). I saw nothing special or historical about the place. There are tens of thousands of older and nicer houses in Thailand than this.More than 20-30 ladies work in the place but in fact 5 of them would be enough to show a house to tourists. The guides have memorized a 2 pages paper (which is also passed to you) and they will circle you in the rooms and tell stories! about the magical American that has disappeared!!Good job making a scam and creating job for all those people (similar to Taxi and Tuktuk drivers in Bangkok). I also suspect some of the excessive positive reviews here are fake.

great retail therapy. wonderful retail therapy and a great place to buy gifts in the famous Jim Thompson silk designs. lovely calm surroundings as well which are welcome after the bustle of Bangkok's streets

Great place to visit. While I hadn't heard of Jim Thompson before, I was reluctant to go here fearing another touristy trap. I was definitely in the wrong. Not only did I learn a little bit more about the role and vision of Jim Thompson, I really appreciated the architecture, art collection, and ambiance of this well preserved house/museum. Definitely worth a visit on a trip to Bangkok.

A must see. For anyone interested in architecture, house styles, interior design and garden layout this is a gem. Thompson obviosly had good taste and flair and the whole set up is beautiful and serene.

Amazing architecture. This home sits on a small ravine thru the city among a midst of concrete structures. The history of the Thompson center is in itself an amazing journey thru this gentlemans life. His entrepreneur thought not only brought the Thai people an economy it made him an humble contributor to the greater mankind. The home is simply amazing and forward in thought and structure. It's art can be adorned in anyone's perspective. It's use of bringing nature inward is clearly accomplished in the foot print of the homes design. For a couple hours one can indulge in pure genius while exploring the perfect place, in the perfect setting of a traditional modern Thai Home

Stunning and tranquil. The Jim Thompson is a lovely and peaceful oasis in the middle of the concrete jungle. Whenever friends are visiting one of the first places I take them is here. Also very enjoy the restaurant and have some great meals here.

Try giving your finger to the large big headed fish in the second pot (lol)!. I visited JTH for the first time after many visits to Bangkok. I must say it was well worth my time. The fish I spoke off residing in a large garden pot, tried to bite my finger off and would have have if it had teeth. The friendly gardner watching my silly endeavors was laughing at my misadventure. We both had a jolly good laugh.

Well worth a Visit. Tucked Down by the Cannel behind national stadium BTS, This Museum gets you away from the hustle and bustle of BKK. Nice quiet gardens and a beautiful house. The Tours are in a variety of languages, and the guides are very Polite and Knowledgeable, happy to answer any questions you may have about the buildings or antiques on the way round. The admission Fee was minimal although the gift shop was excessive (as you would expect). (Bring your student card for a 50% discount)

Free shuttle from skytrain . Make sure to get free shuttle fromSky train exit otherwise confusing on how to grt there. Pleasant house. The shop is somewhat of a tourist scam. . From house take a left and hop on water taxi back into town. Interesting insight into locale
Well worth a visit. Lovely old Thai architecture and an oasis in the middle of a busy city. Well worth a visit. Interesting piece of history.

An oasis in the city. Jim Thompson House is a great oasis in Bangkok. The Museum is worth a visit not only to admire the plants like in botanic garden or old wooden house but also to learn more about Jim Thompson who had very interesting life and lots of secrets. Visiting his house would definetely take us back in time.

Do not miss this. Absolutely incredible and so cheap at 50B entry for under 21 and 100B for 21+. Great tour around the beautiful house, in English and French. It lasted about 40 minutes with stunning gardens to walk around in afterwards. Also has a lovely restaurant next to it, prices abit steep however. Free taxi runs from train stop every 15 minutes.

Amazing place. A wonderful site to see. So interesting tucked away. You have to be taken around with the guides and initially we were not too happy about this, however, the guide was very informative and the tour was so interesting. We learnt a lot about Jim Thompson. Worth a visit.

Begin Here. I've found that the Jim Thompson House is a terrific way to begin a visit to Thailand in part because of its beauty and serenity but also because it doesn't require a lot of time and effort to reach or tour by a jet-lagged traveler
Get out of the concrete city!. We visited this on our first day in Thailand, with a jetlag …It was a great way to get out of the busy city! Beautiful place in the center of a concrete city!

Overrated as a "Must See" attraction. Ok – I’m going against the grain of other reviewers, but I saw nothing special about Jim Thompson house, Yes, it is quaint how he put several wooden buildings together and it is a relaxing place. If I had only a few days to spend in Bangkok, I would skip this as a stop. As other have stated, it is not a “must see”.
Only checked out the. Restaurant and shop but I would recommend a detour here to get away from the samey busy concrete streets of Bangkok.

Serenity in the city. A trip to Jim Thompson House is a little bit of peace within the busy city of Bangkok. Worth the trip - didn't eat at the restaurant but it looked like a nice place to enjoy a meal.

Wonderful! Don't miss it. The store is so delicate. Wonderful property, a must in Bangkok. The guide was very kind.
At the end you should visit the store. Amazing ties (italian quality for 1/4 of the price), great pashminas and handbags....Very very stylish. You will buy something!

great to see and shop. This is a great place to break up your shopping day and still shop. Seeing around the house is lovely as it is a view into how Jim Thompson lived and he had great style, but the shop is set out beautfully and the restaurant is cool and has a great mixture of meal or snacks which ever is what you are looking for, I had a lychee drink which was delicious

If you have time, check it out. We enjoyed the visit to Jim Thompson House. We were skeptical and didn't see the appeal but we're glad we went. They give mandatory tours which is great and the guide answered all our questions. We don't think it's a must see as many guidebooks say, but definitely worth checking out if you have time.
An oasis in the city. This attraction is a must see. It was only 100baht and you had a well informed guide showing you around.

Escape the crazy city. Beautiful place, tour was excellent, learned a lot about Jim Thompson and his life. We also ate in the restaurant, the food was excellent, if a little bit pricey! Well worth it though.

It is OK but not a must see. I enjoyed and was glad I went but would not say it a must see place (compared to the many other places). If you are looking to buy very nice silk items there are other places that are Jim Thompson stores. The coffee shop up stairs in comfortable and very nice. I would have given a rating of good (it is better than average) but not very good.

Gorgeous oasis in the hectic Bangkok travels. Yes, this place has an interesting history and the tour is informative and interesting. Above and beyond that I think this place makes westerners feel comfortable with the combination of Thai relics and architecture and Jim Thompson's push towards comfort. I went there twice with two different sets of people. On my second visit, I just sat in the garden enjoying myself while my friend took pictures. We paid the 100 baht for pictures and sitting. LOL!!! Also take time to order a drink and take a seat in the bar. It is very relaxing and calming.

A great way to see old Bangkok architecture up close and well preserved. The art in the house is beautiful - try to take some time to look at the pictures, which, unfortunately, are hard to see. The house is made of beautiful teak. If you want to splurge on silk, this is the place to do it. Because it was raining (buckets of rain), we stayed a bit longer than planned and visited the textile museum above the shop - it was quite an interesting exhibit of contemporary textiles.
Fascinating. A fascinating view of a part of Bangkok history. The house is lovely, the guides knowledgeable and a mystery to end on, what more could you ask?

If you have 2 days or more in Bangkok, stop here. Nice retreat from the frantic pace of Bangkok. Extensive gift shop, helpful tour guides. This attraction really does pull in mostly American and other western tourists. This is a good slot on your schedule assuming you are in Bangkok for 2 or more days.

A house of outstanding beauty. A great place to spend an afternoon. The house and its beautiful gardens are well preserved and the tour is very interesting. The house is close to the BTS station, National Stadium. Easy to find. I would definitely make this place one to visit.

Really worth a visit. We were not sure whether to visit the place or not, but are really glad that we finally did. The House is much more than just a house indeed. Surrounded by a garden full of exotic plants, it was built in traditional Thai style, yet equipped with some modern amenities. The house’s mysterious master, who was, among others, a CIA agent and famous silk maker, was also a collector travelling through Asia and gathering works of art and craft. In what used to be his house, you can now see plenty of really interesting items, including furniture, sculptures, paintings, fabrics, jewellery, pottery, etc., some of them rare and historical. We also found all the things related to silk very interesting – you can see not only accessories, but even silkworms, and actual silk making process. If you are in Bangkok just for a short while, you could perhaps skip this place; but if you spend a few days in the city, do not forget about it!

Jim Thompson, an effort to preserve the old arcitecture of thai. It is like an oasis in the middle of the Bangkok`s hectic centre. A quiet and calm place to visit and be guided in. Interesting history of the thai silk, about Jim T himself and also about the houses he has rebuilt here. A nice restaurant and a good shop with all the products from the brand Jim Thompson. You can also find them out on the airport.
Shopping. Overpriced, you can get better elsewhere. Same old same old, needs to update, service is also very slow, look elsewhere.

great architecture. a fascinating insite into a man with a full and varied life a beautiful house spotlessly maintained also got a nice cafe, bar, restaurant not the easiest place to find but worth it when you do

A must see when touring Bangkok. The history of Jim Thompson and his disappearance and the beautiful legacy he left behind...in addition to the incredible house on the river is worth seeing and understanding. An American who moved to Bangkok after WWII and then disappeared into the Malaysian jungle, he is credited with getting the Thai silk industry off the ground. The tour of his home is a lovely way to spend a morning followed by lunch at the on-site restaurant which is reasonable and very good. I think the best souvenirs of the place are the reproduction paintings of Buddha's life. But, you can drop some coin in the over-priced silk shop if you prefer...things are lovely and the t-shirts wear like iron so you are paying for and getting quality at every step. Do it!

Jim Thompson Off The Mark. We took an out of the way diversion to visit Jim Thompson and we naturally had high expectations. We were shopping for soft furnishings for our newly renovated home and we hoping we could find the latest designs and styles for table linen and cushions etc. There are four floors, each one dedicated to different items. Unfortunately, probably because it is a popular tourist destination, many items were out of stock and there were not enough items. We were disappointed and only managed to purchase half of what we planned to buy. It would have been better if they were better stocked and with greater varieties of designs which would make it more worthwhile and more attractive than the overseas smaller outlets.

Very touristy but worth it!. As a young backpacker i would have avoided this sort of place. In fact, I did! only on my 4th visit as an older chap did I go. I was missing out. This place was a quality experience. The houses are a great insight into a previous era and our young guide was exceptional (12:40 english tour 7th Oct 2013 - Im sorry I didn't write down your name) The shop had high quality goods that my wife enjoyed and the restaurant was really great value. Back at the hotel (Anantara riverside) we bought more Jim Thomson clothes as the shop had a good selection as well. I even bought a Paisley patterned shirt for about the same price as you would buy a quality shirt back in Perth WA.
Fab. Well worth it fab tour house is great.... Location by the rivetr makes you feel like how it was living in bk in the 60's great foundation keep it up staff great, restaurant great....

oasis in the city. A very pleasent surprise in the heart of the city, relaxing stroll around the garden and house, very good food to enjoy and superb silks to admire and buy, A guide will take you round or you can stroll on your own.Well worth the effort if you are fed up with shopping.

A good place to know about the history of Thai silk. It's a museum about the famouse thai silk brand-Jim Thompson and the story of its creator-Mr. Jim Thompson. It can tell you how the thai silk become luxury material from normal one. It's close to MBK, very easy to access.

highly recommended. 100 baht /person and a private tour guide of a small team!
great place to go~ they have French ,English, Japanese guide that are very nice and friendly.

Different but a must see. I found my dream home here - v beautiful and a collection of nice stories to go with it. V close to National Stadium station, and a handy shuttle golf cart to get you down the road every 15 minutes. Tee it up with a visit to the Bangkok Arts and Culture centre.

Jim Thompson House. I have been here several times and am always delighted by this little part of old Thailand in the middle of this great modern city. It's a peaceful, tranquil oasis that gives you an insight into the life of this extraordinary man who disappeared in mysterious circumstances. The house is divided into various pavilions, filled with beautiful antique furniture and art. You must join a tour in a language that suits you and remove your shoes before entering. Its not expensive and after be sure to have a meal in the excellent restaurant which sits at the front of the property opposite the retail outlet, which is also worth a look. It's central location makes it very easy to get to.

Beautiful Thai house on stilts. I really enjoyed visiting this house. It is a blend of Thai with western done beautifully. I am always glad to see when people does the effort to keep a piece of history alive, and Jim Thompson certaily did it.

Really interesting. A great place to visit, the house is situated along the klong, with lovely gardens and ponds. We found wandering around the house very interesting and our guide was most helpful. A great place to go to have a break fromall the noise and chaos of Bangkok. Inexpensive to visit.

Lovely, quaint and quiet. Visiting the Jim Thompson House was a highlight of my trip. I bought a fabulous hat...they only had one displayed, and great gifts for friends back home. There is also and Outlet store at Sukhumvit Sol 3 where I bought yards of silk fabric for curtains in my new home, the price was a fraction of what I would have spent in the US. They even packaged it nicely so that I was able to bring it back on the plane. Very nice service.

Combinations of architecture, antiques and legacy. It was a pleasant visit to Jim Thompson house. The architecture of the house is impressive, the antique collections is also another 'wow'! Porcelains, paintings, furniture and many more. There's also a souvenir shop for Thai silk retail shop and Thompson restaurant for local Thai food :)Entrance ticket cost Thai Batt 100, you must have a tour guide, who speaks either English or Japanese. (The English tour is usually much more occupied :D) You will also got the chance to see silk reeling from cocoon, as well as watch a Thai traditional dance.

Well worth seeing this spectacular house. When I first visited Jim Thompsons house I couldn't believe the serenity of the place. It was fantastic and lovers of Thai architecture will fall in love with this place. I did.
visit this beautiful house. A peaceful beautiful teakhouse in a nice garden in the middle of Bangkok. amazing story, nice purchases, good guiding tour.

An interesting life. We visited Jim Thompson House in May 2012. We had previously been to Bangkok, in January 2005, but missed out on going to this attraction, so it was a must for the next trip to Bangkok, which, I must say, is probably my favourite city.Walking from National Stadium skyway station, many touts/drivers greet you with the message that Jim Thompson House is closed on a Monday or doesn't open until 1.00pm. Once you get over this and arrive there, Jim Thompson House provides quite an amazing insight into the life of a very interesting man.The guided tour shows the splendour of the architecture of the house which feels to be an oasis in the middle of a vibrant, bustling city. It is not difficult to imagine having guests for a dinner party and being in an escape from all outside pressures.The life of Jim Thompson which ended with his disappearance in the possible context of being a spy, is fascinating.The most interesting facet of his life was that he revived the Thai silk industry.I purchased a Jim Thompson tie designed with outlines of hundreds of elephants. Every time I wear that tie, comments are made and a story begins.I think that once is enough for a lifetime memory but definitely include Jim Thompson house on any agenda to visit Bangkok.John & Pam WillisBeaumaris,Victoria,Australia

Jim Thompson House, well worth it!. One of the best attractions in Bangkok. Fabulous house and wonderful back story.Take the tour and grab lunch in their lovely restaurant.Truly a break from the chaos of Bangkok!

A trip to the past.. Well worth a visit even if a little tricky to find. The property itself is worth the visit and the guided tour is very informative. Sad ending in terms of Jim Thompson's fate. An unsolved mystery with plenty of conspiracy theories,

Historical and Interesting. I love Jim Thompson House tour. They organized the tour well. We entered in group and were accompanied by a beautiful guide. There were also store and restaurant that provide you with Traditional Thai foods or simply to enjoy coffee and drinks.Yet, it's too pity some area are closed for public.However, overall is an interesting place to visit and giving some historical information about Thai Silk.

Thai silk weaving. Nice house right near the river system , guided tour was a bit hurried and the english was a bit difficult to understand, but the house itself was really nice with lots of nice furniture and furnishings.
A waste of time. A waste of time.Nothing much to offer.A lot of hype about an average place.The products on sale are very expensive and notall that unique too

Silk House in Bangkok. I went to visit the Silk House, I felt it was not good in the sense of a History lesson on Jim Thompson, but a nice way of learning how the silk is founded and woven. Making lovely silk items at a fair price. Still worth going for the shopping.

One of the places of attraction should visit whilst in Bangkok. It was an enjoyable and satisfying visit to the Jim Thompson House. Besides viewing the gardens,Jim Thompson's house and his museum collection,there is a restaurant in the premises serving authentic Thai food. Admission fee is BHT 100 per person ( for both locals and tourists ) .For the first part of the programme visitors are given a guided tour of Jim Thompson's house.The guide walked us through the house and explained the history behind the various rooms as well as the antique collections.At the end of the tour visitors are free to walk around the gardens, I would strongly recommend not to give this place a miss.

a welcome calm. I went because I was intrigued with the John Thompson story (he disappeared without atrace). Its a cool and calming house, a welcome relief from the sometimes frenetic pace ofBankok. to sit on the verandah and soak up the atmosphere and wonder about the manwho lived there is blissful.I went by tut tut and left by canal boat, two quite terrifying experiences but it made my visitso much more enjoyable, if you have the time allow yourself the opportunity to relax andcontemplate the home of a man who loved the land and its people

What a little gem. Very easy to find just a short walk from the skytrain stop at the National Stadium. We had a coffee in the little cafe sitting by a pool full of koi in the pleasant garden and then a full tour of the house with English speaking guide. It was a lovely insight into how people lived in traditional Thai houses.

Tranquil house in city centre. Historical home of Jim Thompson who helped globalise the Thai silk industry. His collection of Thai artifacts is like a small museum and the interesting wooden buildings are set in peaceful gardens near a canal. Easy to reach via Skytrain to Stadium then a short walk. Don't believe conmen at end of soi who tell you it is closed !!
The restaurant. Lovely food, quite a difficult menu to work out!! Be careful or you will get one small dish, you need to choose several dishes

Don't Get Your map out. A word of warning. Do not get your map out to look at while on your way to Jim Thompson's House. We were stopped 3 times by various men who came up to us from nowhere. They start off by asking where your from and can they help you. When you mention where your going they tell you that it's closed. No matter if it's JT's House, The Grand Palace, The Temple. We did a test and said we were going to Tescos. You know what they said ........... it's closed on Monday's. So head straight to where your going. When we got to the Lane of JT's house they have a big notice up saying 'We are open every day". So many people must end up hopping into these touts tuk tuks and missing the most beautiful peaceful place. The juices in the restaurant are freshly blended and can be had beside a gorgeous pond full of beautiful fish. Lovely relaxing pace to go to. Enjoy!

A typical Thai style house. Besides the story behind it - Jim Thompson, the American so much involved in establishing Thai Silk business - it illustrates the Thai country style house in case you do not have the opportunity to visit up-country. Rather small and not very elaborate.

a pleasant place - fascinating man. The rich expat life is fascinating and Jim Thompson's house evokes a past time. Thompson obviously loved Thai culture as he help revitalize Thailand's silk industry. He built this house in Bangkok by combining 6 tradtional Thai houses together.It's a short walk from Nat'l Stadium BTS. There is even a golf-cart shuttle for the lazy or exhausted. I arrived, paid the entry fee. There were women in Traditional Thai garb demonstrating silk production. One woman was spinning silk from the worm cocoons - really cool to see this even if it is just a staged demonstration. Once it was time for the English tour, 20-or-so of us were taken through the house by a pleasant guide with good English. The house is really unique and it's cool to imagine Jim Thompson building it, furnishing it, and living there. After the tour you're free to wander the grounds or visit the restaurant or bar. (restaurant is recommended in my guidebook, but it was a little over my budget)A little silly is the Jim Thompson gift shop where you can buy Jim Thompson shirts, Jim Thompson ties, Jim Thompson wallets, Jim Thompson scarves, Jim Thompson Limited Edition Silk Boxer shorts - - you get the idea.the house makes a nice, chill visit. the house is an oasis of calm and beauty in the urban jungle of Bangkok

Must see museum. A fantastic trip to the house and museum. The compulsory guided tour was perfect and the guide spoke very good English. Also explained about the history, after the tour you could walk round the grounds and experience the atmosphere for yourself.All for the bargain price of 100 baht per person.The best experience we have had so far in Bangkok.

Jim Thompson boutique. I visited Jim Thompson Boutique and buy some things Very good silk product such as Neck tie, Shirts, Dresses , Polo-shirt and fabric for hom decoration .In First floor they have also the cafe and cake for tourists

Well worth a visit. Well worth taking a half day to escape the bustle of Bangkok and visit this little oasis of tranquility. Lovely architecture and pleasant greenery. Interesting history too - both of the Thai silk industry and the businessman / CIA agent who lived here.

Thai house. We visited the house in September. The guide was excellent in giving the history of the house and Jim Thompson. Was a lovely house with some really old antiques set in a nice garden. The tour lasted about 40 mins and was interesting to see how he took Thai house and connected them for his own use.

Nice but overrated. I went to JIm Thompson house on the basis of the reviews on Tripadvisor. The house is rather small and not that much to be seen. The guide was not very knowledgable, she said she was new, which I do not think is an excuse. If you have not been to Thai countryside, it gives you the feeling about their dwellings, but not much more.

Interesting, beautiful house_gardens. English, 20 minute tour of the house was very informative. Gardens were lovely. The ladies were carving vegetables & fruit - what an art. The silk spinning was fascinating. Came back one night and had dinner in the Restaurant - delightful and came back another day for lunch with some Thai friends. We were fortunate to see a Thai wedding reception on that day - bride & bridegroom were beautiful and wanted photos with some of our party. The house, garden and cafe / restaurant have a wonderful welcoming feel - really loved the time we spent there. We were staying close by (Siam@Siam) so were very drawn to the House.

Secret Scuttlebutt. Easy access by the Thai Rail system just a few baht ( US$3) and just 100 Baht entry (US$4). Great atmosphere with loads of antique furniture, personal Jim the CIA Spy died mysteriously in a Malay jungle Thompson memorabilia in genuine situ. Guides were good and the jungle garden beautifully preserved with exotic plants and animals all around. The commercial and bathroom facilities along with the free shuttle to the railway station entrance were much appreciated. A not to miss and very accessible essential piece of Thai history and culture.

Worth taking kids. We came last minute on recommendation from a guest staying in same hotel as us. I am glad we did - gorgeous property and tour guide spoke english very well and very informative on life of Jim Thompson and his love of Thailand. My kids enjoyed it.
Beautiful house. The house is very beautiful, all built in Thai style. And it has a great garden. Easy to get through sky train (National Stadium station).

Jim Thompson - an American, but embraced by the Thai's. I liked this visit, and it was very interesting that the Thai people spoke so fondly of Jim Thompson, an American. The house is pretty awesome and the antiques and artifacts are also very interesting. There is a cafe on site and if you are calm and skillful you can even pat / stroke one of the fish in the big pots.

A wonderful place to visit. I took a party of colleagues here for a tour of the Jim Thompson house and museum, finishing up with a dinner at the on site restaurant.Although we had to plough through the Bangkok traffic, we had earlier been in Mueang Boran about an hour or so drive away, it was well worth it. The guides provided an excellent tour of the house, gave interesting and entertaining facts about the houses, history and artifacts on display, and the visitor team supported the event very professionally.The dinner was excellent; great food, terrific service from the friendly and attentive staff, and my guests were totally enchanted by the experience.For tourists, Jim Thompson House is easily accessible by the Skytrain system, alight at National Stadium and follow the signs. It is a mere 5 minute stroll from the station.Also on site is a shop selling Jim Thompson products, wonderful colourful designs and a nice souvenir of Thailand.

Worth visiting (if you can find it!). Although slightly difficult to find (our taxi driver seemed to have no idea what or where it was) it's definitely worth seeking out if your around Siam Square. The buidlings are beautiful and have been very sympathetically preserved and converted into what is now clearly a popular tourist attraction. You have to be part of a guided tour to look round the main house. Our guide was very knowledgable and sweet. The tour takes around 40 mins, during which time you learn more about Jim Thompson, his life in Thailand, his business and of course the house he built in Bangkok. He had great taste and the house is full of wonderful antiques and statues. Only criticism is that you don't get to find out that much about the traditional technique for silk production, although on the way out a chap was doing a demo using traditional apparatus which was interesting. We had lunch at the cafe which was very tasty and a lovely spot to sit and relax. Well worth it.
The missing architect. JIm Thompson went missing, it was a mystery! I suppose it adds interest to his fantastic house which is a must for a visit. The delightful guides are also an added interest.

Not to be missed experience. Jim Thompson Museum/house is not to be missed and advisable to do the tour. He designed 3 Thai style houses in a lovely garden alongside a canal. He collected beautiful artefacts and there are some ancient buddha figures plus beautiful Chinese bowls. You can watch silk being spun and buy silk products in the shop there. Also a good cafe for a light lunch etc. The intriguing mystery as to what happened to Jim Thompson when he went missing in the Cameron Highlands remains. Very high quality products and quite expensive.

One of the wonders. This was an amazing presentation. Before the show, there was some shopping, Thai boxing,and elephant show. They had also created a small village like that you can go around.And before the show, the buffet dinner was amazing. We ate lots of food particularly fresh rolls and Papaya Salad. They also had some Indian food which was great.The show was mesmerizing. The choreography was amazing.Must see.

Breathtakingly beautiful. It's obligatory to join one of the guided tours, but it was worth it. Our tour guide was very entertaining as well as informative. You start in the gardens which are lovely before moving onto the residence. Shoes have to be removed so wear socks if you don't like going barefoot. The dwellings are amazing, the detailed carving of the wooden walls is stunning as is the eclectic collection of Asian artefacts. Fabulous artwork, porcelain and statues, all beautifully presented. It was like stepping back in time. I really enjoyed this trip.A word of advice for getting there, take the sky train to National Stadium stop to beat the traffic, then wait for the complimentary buggy service that runs from the sky train exit. This service runs non stop about every 15 minutes
A must. What an interesting place to spend a couple of hours.Very good tour and reasonably priced. Highly recommended.
A must for every Bangkok visitor!. I love this place ! A very interesting place to visit & escape the loud, busy city for a short while. Suitable for all ages.

Interesting, quiet oasis. Not at all what you'd expect to find down a nondescript side street off a busy road in Bangkok, but a very pleasant surprise. The houses are incredible, with really interesting furnishings and small gardens. The tour was well worth doing, and the price was very reasonable. The attached restaurant was good, but by Bangkok standards is pricey.

A slice of paradise right in the middle of it all!. I'm so glad I visited Jim Thompson House on my trip to Bangkok. Its super esay to get to (right around the corner from MBK and Siam Square). The tour was fantastic, and very reasonably priced. The house is amazing, and hearing about all the history, the people who have passed through its halls (celebrities, world leaders, etc.) was very interesting. The most interesting part is learning about Jim Thompson himself, how he moved to Thailand, and basically founded the silk industry, and then mysteriously vanished. If you have an extra hour in Bangkok, this spot is not to be missed! The only shame (for obvious reasons) is that you can't take photos inside. Not to worry though, there is tonnes of opportunities outside to take some really beautiful shots.

tranquil afternoon. a visit here is such a peaceful, tranquil experience. the gardens are beautiful and the history is amazing. a bonus is a ride on the klong by boat. we enjoyed afternoon tea at the restaurant and the whole ambience of the place.

Silk. If you have ever wondered where, how those silk products you enjoy came into existence, this is a MUST visit for you. The House, gardens, and Boutique for you to secure a Memory purchase are all there to enjoy. A guided tour is made available to all and most informative. You may then revisit points of interest after. The restaurant for refreshments afterwards not to be missed...Poe swimming around in the pond, next to the restaurant, giant banana plants etc, very nice and peaceful.

Jim Thompson House Tour good. interesting to see the art collection and hear of Jims life. Beautiful place to visit and eat, plus shop. Although you can pick up most of the items tax free at the airport.

Worth a visit. Very interesting visit and learnt a lot about the silk trade and Thai history.
Took the motor water taxi afterwards - best value in Thailand 20 Baht!!

Beautiful place but information could be better. Its a beautiful location and very well maintained. The guides are lovely and quite informative. The tour of 30min is quite interesting however they could do a much better job by telling so much more about Jim Thompson, his life and the company instead of explaining every potty

GREAT PLACE TO VISIT IN BANGKOK WHEN IT IS RAINING! . It was a rainy day in Bangkok we searched for something to do! We came across Jim Thomson house and decided to go! It failed to disappoint! We have a 13 & 15 year old children and they both enjoyed it! The tour gave you a great insight into the Jim Thomsons philosphy and the architecture of the house! It is a real oasis in the busy city of Bangkok! I would recommend this sight! Dont forget to go to the cafe after for some delicious treats!

The story of a mainstream destination gone tragically corporate. You’re given a half-page informational sheet with your receipt. This receipt must then accompany you and your traveling partner(s) to the entrance, where it’s checked by at least one staff member, who then walks you 10 meters to an information desk, where it’s checked by at least one other staff member, then given to another staff member behind a desk, who writes a time and a group letter on it. Let the record show that I saw at least 10 staff members, all presumably on-the-clock, before our tour even started. It’s nice to know that 100 baht admission is going towards keeping the unemployment rate low.Our tour group was not scheduled to depart for about 20 minutes, so I meandered through the Jim Thompson bar / restaurant, used the Jim Thompson bathroom, walked through the Jim Thompson souvenir shop, and pondered why a short sleeve shirt with blue elephants and a Jim Thompson logo cost 2,400 baht (about $80 USD). A Jim Thompson silk neck tie, at 2,100 baht (about $70 USD), made me want to use the man’s name as an expletive.The tour itself is efficient enough. A Thai woman (apparently all the tour guides were Thai women) introduced herself, and started talking about “Mr. Thompson” in an almost deified way. From memory, she told the story of the man’s life before and while in Thailand, replete with details that weren’t on the half-page handout. It was clear from the first few moments that the recitation was just that, seemingly involving few actual emotions for a man from another country who had lived and died before she was born, yet was the reason she had a job.

History and a mystery. Like many converts, Jim Thompson appreciated something (in this case, Thai culture) more than many people who are born into it. The house and grounds are an oasis of calm in a bustling city. Take the tour, and you'll see the antiques he collected and learn about the many theories of what became of him.

Interesting and worthwhile. This is a very cheap thing to do in Bangkok. We stayed at Siam@Siam so the Jim Thompson House was just around the corner. Small fee to enter from memory AUD 2. There is a display at the start of a Thai man or women spinning the silk and a lovely dance by the Thai women. You then join a tour with an English speaking guide, there is other languages available if needed. The guide was informative. You must again take your shoes off to enter the house. You can take photos from outside the house but not inside. The grounds are beautiful and well kept. There is a shop to buy the silk from (very expensive though) and a nice cafe too.
Beautiful. A real taste of the Bangkok of yesterday. Lots of shade on a sunny day. Truly unique and beautiful. The Koi pond was a highlight.
Good visit. It was an awesome experience to visit this place. Learn about silk and Jim Thompson history. Something new and unique for the foreigner that come to visit this place.
Oasis of calm. Exquisite art collection housed in delightful garden setting. You have to take the guided tour but this is regular and available in English or French.

nice place to visit. If you want to get an idea of how the foreigners used to live in Bangkok during the war period, this is your chance. They have a guided tour explaining each of the romos in the house and the mistery about Jim Thompson
A must visit. Brilliant story and history, lovely gentle stroll around, a must if you have time. Such an amazing Oasis in the middle of Bangkok. The restaurant is very good too.
Incredible. The Teak houses are incredible as is his collection of Antiques. The Koi pond and the Koi were amazing. Some of the most gorgeous Koi I've ever seen. Loved it.

Enchanting. Good to visit if one is interested in Jim Thompson's legend, and the tour gave some introduction to Thai culture, religion and architecture. This place is tourist friendly, with shuttle service provided between the museum and National Stadium BTS station. Tours were conducted by good foreign speaking tour guides (they are locals but speaks clearly the foreign language), and details were given about Jim Thompson's life, his antique collections, and the architectural details of the house.

Wow! - This is an amazing place!. Well worth a visit. Such an amazing Oasis in the middle of Bangkok. This guy had some serious taste and has inspired me for my own house in Thailand. This house is the real Thailand. Food was good too

Good to Visit. This is a surely a good place to visit. Its basically a well maintained house of the late Jim Thompson which you can have a close look at..Right from the paintings to the furniture ,they give you a full detailed tour. In the beginning itself they ask you for the language preference for the tour guide. Then they group you into arounf 10 people and start off.If your interested , you can even purchase a few good at the pricey Jim Thomson boutique.And I must say , very clean toilets !Also you can find a place at the bar /restaurant when you wait for the tour to start!
Nice point of interest. Definitely worth a visit, it's calm and relaxing in a crazy city and the story behind it is interesting. Guides were also good

I was a bit jealous!. What an amazing place yhat this guy had constructed for himself. An absolute must see. Try to eat the restaurant. It is excellent. And if you have the money buy something at the boutique. Excellent!
Something different. Was ok. Better than the usual temples. Guide was a little bland though. Gardens are really pretty. Thought there would be more on the history but, no.

Ok if you have an hour or two to spare. For thb100 admission fee, this is a good spot to spend an hour or two. The free guided tour is informative. Before and after the tour, you can roam around the garden or sit on one of the benches at the courtyard or check out the shop. The staff is very helpful too. I was alone so I asked a staff by the gate to take my photo and she happily obliged, and even volunteered to take more photos on different spots (thereby leaving her post for a while, haha). Anyways, it was a nice morning spent here, before spending the rest of my day shopping in nearby MBK.

Oasis in the middle of the city!. PROS: The house and grounds are beautiful. A very natural & peaceful place to visit. There are pretty gardens, fish ponds, brick walk ways, restaurant, bar, gift shop, etc. You do not have to book in advance. Just show up and they place you in the next available tour. Very fair price. Many attentive employees to assist you and point you in the right direction. There is a free shuttle that runs from the main road down the alley to the Jim Thompson house and back. Street alley is safe and clean. Traditional Thai dancers on site for short performances while you enjoy a drink or relax near the fish ponds. I would go back just to enjoy the ponds, gardens and get away from the city a bit.CONS: Our English tour guide had a very thick/heavy accent and I couldn't understand much of what she said so I got bored. Tour is quick and very basic info provided. Wish they provided more details and a deeper history on who he was or how he turned the Thai silk industry around. The house is on a canal and the boats that drive by every few minutes are SO loud and disrupt the tour.

Interesting and cultural. A great way to get to the Jim Thompson house is to take the canal boats that run through Bangkok. The canal boat will take you directly to Jim Thompson house. The house and grounds are a nice way to gain a perspective into the silk trade and magnificent architecture of the Jim Thompson. Highly recommended

An oasis in the heart of Bangkok. Weren't sure whether to come here with two teens, one of whom 'hates museums' but we were glad we did. Not only is his life fascinating but the house itself is too with so many bits and pieces (the chamber pots come to mind!) that you feel he's probably about to come back! It's also so green and beautiful with bromeliads on the trees and orchids; a great place to breathe and relax away from the hubbub of Bangkok. All of us enjoyed it and would return. Oh yes, and the restaurant is lovely (didn't find it too expensive) with a wide range of food and drinks and it's conveniently near the Skytrain (a member of staff took us to the station from the house in a golf cart!)

inspirational!. The ambience is incredible and the tour is worth every baht paid. The story is very intriguing and genuine. To think that he was a tourist in bangkok to begin with!The restaurant is expensive but excellent. The shop is not to be missed. The gallery upstairs seemed like a happening place too. Please take the slytrain and do not ask tuk tuk or guide to take you there, they give wrong information. Best to check their website.

Worth a look.. I had heard much about Jim's place but was not that thrilled but still glad I went. I think the story about the guy makes the house what it is. Other than that its just another nice old Thai home. It's always better to go into an old house that someone is actually cooking dinner in.

Pretty house with a fascinating history. This was a little oasis of calm in the madness of Bangkok. It is a very pretty house set in tropical gardens with some interesting artifacts. The guides are very knowledgeable and tell the story of the house with some verve. Jim Thompson's story is intriguing but they tend to gloss over some of the theories of why he disappeared!The cafe is very pleasant for a cool drink after the tour.

Impressive house and history. We took the sky train and were there at the right time to hop on the shuttle to the house. It is a fair hike down the road in hot weather and a shuttle comes every 10 minutes or so. The tour of the house was extremely good, very informative. Restaurant provides delicious food and drinks. The shop is good, providing all the usual Jim Thompson wares that can be found in any of his shops. A good trip.
Must Visit. This is a great little museum. A walk back in time to how the wealthy Thais lived not so long ago. The history of the silk trade in Thailand is interesting. Stop for a bite at the cafe.

Cool house worth exploring. A bit out of the way, the Jim Thompson house is very cool and worth spending some time visiting. The tour is informative and provides a cool glimpse into the uniquely designed house. We found this to be a nice break from all the temples we were visiting.

House of Silk. The tour was about 30 mins with the guide going through the house of Jim Thompson. We were given the history, which was great. The downside, it can be very hot going through the rooms in close quarters with other people. There is no A/C, only in one room. We were provided lockers for our belongings, no bags, purses or any kind. We were able to bring our camera but can only take pictures of the outside area.

Very interesting and restaurant good too.. Loved the finger eating fish on the beginning of the tour. The house itself is very nice and interesting. The tour lasts about 45 minutes. They of course have a store there where you can buy the silk. Lovely items. Worth a couple hours of your time.

Enjoyable house with rich history. We noticed that over the years the Jim Thomson House area has been expanded to accommodate big tour groups. All is done without disturbing the “special” atmosphere around the house; on the contrary it is done with great taste and makes a visit even more enjoyable. Visits to the Jim Thompson House are done in small groups and a guide will show you around the property while revealing the rich history. There is also a big shop, a restaurant and silk making demonstrations on the premises to enjoy the peaceful atmosphere a little longer.

Jim Thompson house. Well worth spending the time to explore this beautiful place! The staff and guides are all very well trained and extremely helpful. We spent a very relaxing couple of hours and would recommend this peaceful place to everyone.

Jim Thompson. Pricy for Thailand standards but quality. The handbags are very well made. The products made with material all have the unique Jim Thompson designs. There are products for the home and clothing for Men Women and children.

Interesting history. Jim Thompsons was just up a back lane from where were staying and we found that the history of the silk worm interesting in the fact that Jim Thompson reinvented the producing of the silk. Only a shame he was never found after his disappearance.

Amazing History lesson. I liked the ability to tour the house and gardens and view the history of the house and Jim Thompson artefacts up close. The Guides were very knowledgably and approachable. Watching the silk spinning was most interesting and the café was great next to the carp pond .
Seems a bit of a cheek. Great chap; however, I feel that the Thais took advantage of his fame- leaving it all a bit distorted and Disney like.

Interesting place. Very interesting place to visit and see the house and all the things he did. A snapshot of life in Bangkok in the mid 1900's.Just to see the house is worth the visit, it is so beautiful.A must see when you are in Bangkok.
Wonderfully architectural Gem in the heart of Bangkok. Everything... must see when you visit Bangkok. Superb Buildings and the Jim Thompson story behind it.

Good way to spend a spare afternoon!. The house is beautiful, with some really charming artifacts and construction. The guides are well informed and courteous. The tour is compulsory but once that's done you're free to explore the gardens.Close to the National Stadium BTS so no hassles in getting there.

Gorgeous Thai artifact. The gardens were stunning, lush and well landscaped, wonderfully verdant and beautiful. They framed the whole setting of the house and other wooden structure in a dream like atmosphere. There were one or two craftsmen working on the grounds for the tourist' interest but their presence was not jarringly out of place.The grounds had a huge shop for Thai silk products which were somewhat pricey although of high quality. I prefer the old Jim Thomson grounds where there was a good coffee shop serving coffee, cakes and sandwiches. And a small shop to offer its Thai silk products. The new grounds though grand seemed to have lost that intimate feel of a Thai traditional house.

Great way of getting some history and local culture. Was close by to our hotel. We thought it worth a look, based upon trip advisor reviews. Was very interesting and worth the price of the guided tour.
Nothing interesting. My friend took me there, because it was on his list. i live in Thailand for 10 years and never been there. Glad i haven't, nothing to see and nothing to remember

Historical Teak House in Bangkok. We visited the Jim Thompson's house ,museum and silk outlet several times.Jim Thompson was a former soldier, who had a great contribution on introducing Thailand , and its culture to the world.Especially Thai's silk products.In this house, we can visit the old Teak house of Jim Thompson, experience the way the man lived his lifestyle,the history of his residence ,post World War II.Walk and enjoy the beautiful garden and ponds.The Teak house was nicely decorated with artifacts that Jim Thomson used during his life, resembles a small museum. But be careful ,because there's a lot of stairs to be climbed.Careful of those door barriers below, dont trip over.We can reach the Jim Thompson's house by any method of transportation available in Bangkok like taxis, rented bike ,cars ,BTS, tuk tuks or even you can try the cheap Khlong water taxi.The Jim Thompson House is located on Soi Kasemsan (2) Song, opposite the National Stadium on Rama I Rd.Opening Hours : 09:00 to 17:00 everyday, with the last Guided Tour at 17:00, enterance fee including the guided tour is 100 Baht,students can present their student card to obtain a 50 Baht fee.Usually a lot of tourist visit here , they will gather a number of people so the tour can be started, several languages of the guided tour you can choose.In here you can buy high quality of silk ( expensive of course !), but you can rely on their quality.Overall ,its a nice visit .

Pretty Fascinating. I wasn't too enthused about it, but once we arrived we had a great time. You walk in seeing people spinning silk, then take a compulsory guided tour around the house and are allowed to walk around the smaller rooms and the garden by yourselves afterwards. The garden is serene, cool and filled with pools of goldfish. The English speaking guide was clear, friendly and knew plenty of little things about the house's design, Jim Thompson himself and how he brought the house together. It was fascinating to hear about how he spent his time and how he disappeared. For 100 Baht it was a great place to go. Even if you're not into architecture or museums, give it a chance. And if you're tired after the tour there's a free shuttle that takes you to the end of the street.

Serenity and History. An oasis in bustling Bangkok. I try to come to Jim Thompson House every time I come to Bangkok. It's easy to take the Skytrain and walk. You'll be rewarded by serenity and beauty. Take the tour and learn about life in Bangkok before it became such a crazy place. Buy high quality (but pricey) silk items. You can also just enjoy the gardens without paying for the tour, and have refreshments or lunch in the cafe. A hidden gem in the city.

Jim Thompson, Teak House. This house and grounds and gardens are just beatuiful.Has a fascinating history. The houses are made of teak and they were shipped in from various places including Ayutthaya. It is certainly worth a visit.

a relaxing break. I visited on a Saturday afternoon in late August while in town for work. The entry price was 100 baht which included the (mandatory, I think?) guided tour in English. Our group was about 10 and the tour lasted 40 minutes, starting 15 minutes after I arrived; the guide was fine/good - explaining bits of the late owner's life as well as information about the architecture and art around the house. The house itself is beautiful and, as people say, has a nice forest-like garden. There are stairs, and there's a fair bit of climbing into rooms (there is a slightly raised barrier at each doorway - we were told its traditional, and helpful for keeping evil spirits and babies - respectively - contained in one room) - something to know if your mobility is impaired.You have to leave your bags locked up (in CCTV-monitored lockers, which only you have the lock to.) Some people seemed freaked out at the idea "but I have my passport in there!" - so either wear something with pockets big enough to hold your wallet, or be comfortable locking your stuff. It seemed very secure and our group had no problems. A little wilted after a day out (there are fans in the house, but it's still warm), I ate at the restaurant. It was reasonably priced (180 baht for chicken and cashew nuts, 30 baht for jasmin rice with it), quiet, nicely decorated and cool. There is a American food on the menu as well. There's also a bar area if you want to side outside. Shop is full of beautiful, higher-than-you're-used-to-seeing-priced things (probably very good value for money - I don't know the price of quality silk!) The company appears to be a well-run brand; you get Jim Thompson branded bottled water in the restaurant, and the shop feels quite posh.Very easy access to the National Stadium station. I was dropped off in a taxi (200 baht from grand palace in traffic) but walked the 5 minutes back to the BTS.I would 100% recommend it as a relaxing, interesting place to spend 2 hours. Don't bring your kids - I think they'd be bored.

Interesting look at expat's life. Jim Thompson was an American vet who made his fortune marketing and promoting Thai silk after WWII. He built a unique home in Bangkok by moving complete traditional houses from the countryside onto his property. The tour of the houses is interesting, but photos are not allowed at all inside the homes. The museum shop offers silk products and photobooks of the homes.

It's a house very nice house but a house. JT was the saviour of the silk trade in Thailand, and American that made a fortune out of the trade. He built his house out of numerous old houses he found about the country. The gardens and house are lovely, I would gladly live there but it's only a short tour with many people bustle lying about. It's worth a visit but I wouldn't go back for a second visit.

Beautiful. A lovely, interesting paradise in the heart of the big city. A guide takes you around the house, providing insightful information about Jim Thomson's life and his house. The gardens are very pretty to wander around. Not expensive and they offer a student rate/ young persons rate. Didn't eat in the restaurant but it looked very nice as did the gift shop. A must see place!! Can walk to MBK mall and Siam Square from here.

Beautiful. What a lovely place hidden in the middle of a busy city. It is like a green oasis and quite. The house is on several levels and staff take you through explaining about all the houses and the rooms. It is a wonderful story.There are shops to buy silk from but you don't have to. We walked to it as it was not far from our hotel.
Well worth a visit. It is a rare possibility of witnessing a view of old Thailand. One has to be careful though as our taxi let us down at the wrong place: a silk shop of the same name!

Cool architecture, pretty foliage. This house is a hidden gem in the bustling city. The tour guide was very nice and informative. I loved all the foliage around the house, and it was interesting to learn more about Thai architecture and culture.

Beautiful and peaceful. Lovely to see a real piece of old Bangkok.The guided tour, included in the price, was interesting and informative.A beautiful and peaceful oasis hidden away in the middle of a busy and bustling area.
Lots to choose. There was lots of items to choose from (silk) and other things. There was also a good coffee shop. It was a about 5 floors and the staff were very helpful.

Beautiful. What a wonderful oasis of calm and tranquility in what can be a manic city of hustle and bustle. Really worth a visit to this beautiful place, lovely gardens and a wonderful insight into the cultures and history of thailand.
Interesting. Great place to visit & find out about some Thai history. Worthwhile to take the tour which provides you with more comprehensive information. Restaurant there was also good.
OK for a morning. Interesting. There is art work to see and the gardens to look at. A small restaurantIt was OK, nothing wrong ,but I will not visit it again
It's nice.. I was actually impressed to see this is one of the top things to do. It is a nice house, but is just that. There are better things to do out there.

Tranquil retreat feels far from the bustle of Bangkok.. The Jim Thompson House offers a glimpse into another time, before air conditioning and other modern conveniences changed the way people live in this tropical climate. While visitors can wander the gardens freely, you can only see the home with a guided tour, understandable because Mr. Thompson was an avid art collector and many of his treasures remain throughout his home. There is an large shop offering beautiful, albeit pricey, silk items. A relaxing way to spend a couple hours while in Bangkok.
Smooth as Silk. To my surprice the place was crowded with tourist,with wide varity of silk from curtain, bed cover,shirt, dresses and by meter.The price was very competetive too.

Very Nice oldThai House. Now it difficult to find nice old thai house in Bangkok. I have been there with my family. For the admission 100฿ for adult people younger than 25 or student .please show id card 50฿ Thai people and tourist the same price. There have restaurant and jim Thomson shop and Souvinier . Here have 6 thai old house . Jim thomson move old thai house and old thai stuff from ayudthaya and many place in asia. Here have free guide :) you can take photo only outside thai house and garden . I am very suggest here if u will been Bangkok. My favorite thing is the mouse house from chiness. Its like a tv in the past.

Unexpectedly brilliant. I only came here because I had time to kill but it was brilliant! You have to walk around with a guide but there are frequent tours, and only 100 BHT entry. Beautiful statues, authentic furniture and the story of jim Thompson is amazing.

A little calm in the middle of Bangkok. For a tourist attraction that isn't all gilded this is lovely. The antiques he collected and the thai house you get shown around with a tour guide is a nice way to enjoy a little thai culture. It's right off the bts sky train and a 5 minute walk. They even have a courtesy tuk tuk to ferry you back to the station. A very nice way to spend a few hours without all the crowds.

A place of great interest. A tranquil environment located at the end of a soi minutes away from the bustling commercial district. Entry was reasonably priced ( no foreigner price :) and the tour (included in the price) was interesting and well communicated by our guide. Jim Thompson had great style and taste and this was reflected in his home. A charming way to spend a couple of hours. The shuttle service would have benefitted from being more frequent.

A must in Bangkok. Jim Thompson's House is a must if you are in Bangkok and offers a great trip which is different to all of the other tourist attractions in the city. It's a little jewel in the city which is hidden away but should be sought out. The guided tour we had was excellent and is available in Thai, English and French and the group sizes were not too big. Our guide (sadly can't remember her name) was superb and knew her history and information and was able to answer all questions thrown at her. It was surprising to find out at the end that she is a trainee so I'm sure the more experienced guides would be even more knowledgeable. Jim Thompson played an important role in Bangkok's history so unless you are just in the city for the night life and to create your own Wolfpack, it's worth learning about the man and visiting his stunning home.

Jim Thompson House is not to miss!!!. Jim Thompson House is one of the best sites we have visited during our stay in Bangkok.The House is amazing and the tour guides are all very professional!Jim Thompson House is not to miss!

Nice garden, architecture and history. Nice refugee from Bagkok city. Take the tour and get a historic perspective of a foreigner who adopted Thailand many years ago. High quality souvenirs. Nice gardens with fish pots. In the way back, don't miss the tiny shops in the street. Best icy juice in town.

Relaxing Half Day Tour. Having visited this Bangkok "Must See" place on several occasions with family and friends, I can only say it is worth the time and effort. Located near to MBK, Siam Centre and the shopping belt, it is very convenient to start your day at Jim Thompson before heading over for lunch.If you like to know more about the Thai silk industry and how Jim Thompson helped its revival, this would be an excellent place to do so. There is a 1 hour guided tour (paid entry) and a silk house to buy finished quality silks. For those of us who have seen it before, there are photo oppotunities to see how silk is unravelled from cocoons and see Thai dancing. Or you could partake some refreshments at the al fresco restaurant near the entrance.

Dodging the Traffic. Since I first visited Jim Thompson's House in 1995, tourist traffic has increased ten fold, and this popular Bangkok attraction has developed into a far more sophisticated site, with a smart gift shop, a bar and restaurant, and entertainment in the courtyard in the form of Thai dancers and weavers spinning silk from silkworm cocoons. The queues in the height of the European summer holidays are astounding, but it was still only a twenty minute wait, and well worth the effort. (although be advised to take a fan and plenty of water). Jim Thompson's House is a museum of SE Asian art: Bencharong & Ming porcelain, Burmese and Thai sculptures, a Belgian chandelier, and a dining table once used by King Rama V of Thailand. But for me, the most beautiful artefact is the house itself, which he constructed from six old Thai teak houses just across the klong from where the Thai silk weavers worked on their looms. Over 200 years old, the wooden floorboards are worn but polished. Surrounded by a dense garden, it is a haven from the hustle and bustle of the huge city behind its walls.Jim Thompson, godfather to the Thai silk industry, was an American architect who first came to Thailand during WWII. When he left the army he returned to Bangkok, where he became fascinated with the locally manufactured silk, then a flagging industry. He took samples back to the States and had soon established a thriving business in Thai silks, now recognized and adored around the world. Take a look!

Absolutely wonderful. This wonderful hideaway, just a block off the busy streets of Bangkok, is an oasis and true treasure. The price of entry is very reasonable (around US$3), the staff is very well-informed, courteous, and yes, even willing to crack a few good jokes (a guided tour is included), and the onsite restaurant is excellent (consider eating lunch or dinner there - we unfortunately only had time for afternoon snacks!). You'll see a hodge-podge of Thai art and architecture here. It may not be for the purist (it was assembled by an American businessman, after all), but it's very interesting. We capped the tour with a visit to the onsite store, which may be a tourist trap, but certainly sells some high-quality merchandise.Overall, highly recommended as a break from the big temples, big malls, and busy streets of Bangkok.

great gardens. The tour gives you an idea of the Thai silk industry and Jim Thompsons contribution to it. The gardens we fantastic a nice place to sit for a while. The restaurant was pricy but the food was amazing the green papaw salad is the best I had on the trip. There is a free shuttle service to and from the main road by the MRT station.

Unique and fascinating place to visit. Jim Thompson House is a very fascinating place to visit. It is a traditional thai house built in the 1950s but also has its own unique western changes the American owner made, making the place probably the one and only in the world. You are taken on a scheduled guided tour and you walk through the garden and the house. The garden is very beautiful and zen. Inside the traditional house are collections of art works as well as some of the furniture Mr. Thompson used. Our guide spoke good English and was knowledgable and humourous. Our visit lasted about an hour. 40 minutes for the tour and 20 minutes for walking around. This place is very close to MBK and I recommened it.

Beautiful cultural house. I really love the way jim had designed the house, and how each area was interconnected, it was really beautiful, and well maintained, very relaxing place to go and nice to see his collections and know the history and how he had upgraded silk manufacturing and introducing to high fashion. I do recommend everyone not to miss this beautiful place. The garden was so relaxing and had nice plants and lotus flowers,,,,awesome...

Excellent Thai wedding venue. Absolutely the highlight of the day with a beautiful setting, excellent staff and good food.Price is on the high side - almost doubling most of the top hotels but worth every penny.Special note must be made to the team who managed the Thai ceremony, who were extremely knowledgable, practical and most of all patient.
A good, well maintained teak house. Like: easy to find, nice atmosphere, great service, very clean, not too crowded, got many insight about Thai culture, free tour, free baggage storageDislike: none
Interesting insight into life of Jim Thompson. Tour only takes about 40 minutes so easy to keep children interested and interesting things for them to see.
If you have extra time to spare, this is an okay spot. It bears interesting history but put it on your itinerary on your second or third visit to Bangkok. It can wait.

Life in Thailand in the past. This is worth seeing as it gives you a glimpse into life in Thailand in the past. The guides are very good and the gardens are lovely. If you are short of time then see the Grand Palace and Reclining Buddha instead.

Lovely tour and house. Easy to get to Jim Thompson House on the sky train - get off at National Stadium. You can walk up the soi or there are frequent Jim Thompson buggies operating up and back.The garden and buildings feel a world away from the bustle of Bangkok and the mandatory tour is offered in several languages. My guide was knowledgeable and able to answer questions about Jim Thompson living in the Thai context.The Restaurant offers 2 for 1 drinks between 4 and 8pm and is a tranquil place to watch the sun go down with the fish pond and see some Thai dancing. He has some amazing historical artefacts, including a seventh century ( i think) buddha statue which had been damaged.
A worthy high end tour.. The western influence mingled with traditional Thai construction is very cool. The restaurant is good as well.

Short introduction to Thai culture. We were recomrneded by friends and were not disappointed. I was afraid to get a lecture on on Thai Silk but we were pleasantly surprised. The guided tours give you a great inside on the Thai way of life and the architectal beauty of Jim. So sad that this man disappeared and never found. Thank god he left this legacy.

One of the highlights of Bangkok. Jim Thompson was a man way ahead of his time! To see now what he created in his home back in the 50's and 60's when he must have been surrounded by some pretty bleak housing and land, is truly astounding. The House and its collection is simply breathtaking. The owners are now milking the brand for all it is worth - and who can blame them. there is now a Jim Thompson cafe, restaurant, wine bar and someone said a hotel! when you book your (compulsory) tour, it inevitably does not start for half an hour so off you go to the JT cafe for a drink etc.despite the commercialism this is still a really special place

Restaurant is terrific. We did not tour the Jim Thompson home. Instead, we went to the retail shop--pleasant, but small-ish and average for a store, but the restaurant adjacent is great. Great food at a good price. The sticky rice with mango is a terrific dessert.

Worth a visit for the very low entry fee! (£2). It is a lovely house in the middle of a busy, bustling city and worth a visit if you have the hour to spare. The tour lasts 30-35 mins and you are free to wonder around the gardens before and/or after the tour.The shop is very expensive but does sell lovely items. The restaurant / bar has a great atmosphere but we decided to eat lunch somewhere else.SUMMARY. Worth spending 60-90 minutes there.
very interesting. this is well worth the tour, very interesting about mr jim thompson and at the end of the tour you really want to know what exactly happened to him. the silk shop is gorgeous

Pleasant but not essential. I wouldn't rush to add this to your itinerary, Its a teak house with a handful of interesting antiques within a nice garden with a very expensive gift shop and some beautiful Thai dancers and silk spinners. The most interesting bit is the journey along the canal on public transport to get there.
Peace in a bustling city!. This is a lovely tranquil place to visit. They have guided tours which are informative. It's nice to see a traditional Thai house in a concrete jungle. Would defo go again.

Beautiful, tranquil place. An amazing oasis of tranquility right next to the sky train station and bustling streets of Bangkok. The house consists of 6 separate traditional Thai buildings, brought from their original sites and joined together to make up the home of Jim Thompson, next door to the factory where Thai silk was originally woven. We enjoyed wandering around the cool, jungly garden, complete with ponds and wooden outbuildings and then took a tour of the beautiful wooden house. Make sure you leave time to visit the shop selling silk goods and, more importantly, the superb cafe. After visiting the house, I would recommend you walk towards the canal, turn right and head for the water taxi stop along the Khlong Saen Saep. A real highlight of our day was to leap onto the boat, as it whizzed up to the stop and then shoot off down the khlong to Phan Fa pier for the Golden Mount and Wat Ratchanatda.

Plenty and Quality. If you looking for nice, classy and quality silk and other Jim Thomson house would be the place that you can find it all. Top quality a lot of selection good to be select as a gift for special friend or family. Little expensive but it worth with quality. Very very nice place

For the love of Elephants. I've been collecting ornamental elephants for years and when this brand was introduced to Malaysia many years ago, I fell in love with its simple motives and designs depicting these animals. It was such a pleasure to have had a chance to visit the HQ and had a lovely afternoon meal there.The tidbits, clothes, silk are cheaper than any Jim Thompson boutiques out there.

Beautiful House. Lovely tour of a beautiful house, lots of information about the antiques given by the guide, a shame though that they did not speak about the silk making or weaving process. The items for sale in the shop are good value too. Well worth a visit if you like old places.

Mr Silk. This the Famous house that Jim Thompson an American who did much to restore the Thai Silk industry built for himself and lived until he dissaoeared from this earth in the Cameron Highlands of Malysia and was never found or seen again. The Thai government has turned the place into a museum of silk with a gift shop cafe and guided tours. certainly worth a visit
