Not to be missed. Not to be missed if you want to understand what Thailand is about. It's a compound of 6 Ayuttayya houses gently put together byt the late Jim Thompsaon, full with artifacts. Nice and informative

Okay. The house and gardens are pleasant and interesting for a spare hour and you see a bit about silk worms. It is well organised with little waiting for a group and guide. There is a restaurant and shop though it is a bit pricey.

Beautiful Retreat in Bangkok. The Jim Thompson House is a definite-must for anyone traveling to Bangkok. With a variety of interpreters and tours, you will be utterly fascinated by the teak home and the story of Jim Thompson. The National Stadium Skytrain station is nearby and easy to locate. There is also a wonderful restaurant on site which is great for lunch or an afternoon cocktail.

Beautiful!. Jim Thompsons house is a really nice place to visit in Bangkok. Like an oasis in the middle of the crowded and noisy city!It gives you a nice perspective of a home that combines Thai and American styles. Plus you can se the complete silk process, from the worms (alive) eating the leaves, till the silk scarf ready to use. Wonderful! Nice to visit with kids also!

Interesting place. We were passing the house and decided to visit, it was worth a visit to find out more about this house and see the valuable treasures inside. It left us wondering what happened to Jim though...

Intriguing story. Really interesting house to tour with an intriguing and mysterious history. Easy access from the Skytrain. When you come out turn left and walk 20m to the klong. An interesting area to explore.

A good appreciation of some history of this venue. Right in the city centre and easy to access. Golf buggies are available to give you a ride from the main road to the venue further inside a small road. Excellent restaurant and good value for a nice quiet meal. The museum tour is just the right touch with a beautiful guide and informative commentary of the house. The shopping was good although prices appear on the high side but then you are assured of quality. A must visit, good for 2-3 hours.

A Must with a capital M. Serene peaceful setting along side the beautiful house of Jim Thompson. I always visit here when I'm in Bangkok - it is a must. Watch the dragon flies swoop over the lily pond and revel in the peace only a stones throw from chaotic Bangkok.

Nice woodwork and art collection. Close to the city center, you can find Jim Thompson House, among the nice garden and beside the river. The free tour is included in the ticket price, which is really cool. Not a big place but very intertesting.

lovely place, overpriced shop. This charming house is magical. I had never heard of Jim Thompson before visiting; his story is very special. The art collection alone is worth a visit. It was also lovely to watch staff spinning silk. The store has beautiful things, but check the prices and do the currency conversion before buying anything. There is a lovely restaurant, which is a nice place to stop for a cool drink while looking out at the garden. It has clean, modern bathrooms.

Worth the 100 Baht. What an incredible house in the middle of Bangkok. It is only 100 baht to go and I probably won't go again. But if you are looking for a temple break, it is a nice stop. 100 baht gets you in and a 40 minute tour. The art pieces in the house are worth the trip. Just a heads up, no photos in the house so don't carry you camera with you like I did :-).

Really lovely house and gardens. Very interesting experience viewing the traditional Thai houses that Jim Thompson had brought from other parts of Thailand and adapted for his own use. Lovely setting in a peaceful side road. We enjoyed a quiet coffee in the restaurant afterwards. It cost Baht 100 to visit, and you can see them spinning silk from the cocoons. This visit was a great change from the crowded temples and other tourist attractions.
Beautiful Place. Loved walking around the grounds. Very green. The house is beautiful. Lots of great art. You should check it out if you have time.Cost: 100 B.
Too commercial to me. It was very good place to visit years ago, but now becomes too commercial and has lost the character. sorry to say.

A great tour. A friend and I did this tour on a whim, but I am so glad we did! The home itself is really lovely and full of artifacts and art, but the best part is all of the things you learn along the guided tour (which is mandatory). The tour guide tells you so much about the Jim Thompson story, Thai architecture, Thai culture, and you even learn quite a bit about regional art styles. Really great tour - I totally recommend it. Beautiful and very informative! (If you want to buy a souvenir or something, check out the outlet stores instead of the gift shop!)

Nothing special to see. I didn't learn much about Jim Thompson or the silk production during the guided tour. The most interesting informations were on the booklet we all received before the beginning of the tour.Too many people in our tour group, sometimes we didn't fit all in the room.The house, art collection and the garden are very beautiful though.

Tranquility in the midst of chaos. It's located in pathumwan,very near to the busy Siam Square.But it is very quiet and really interesting.Looking at how to create the silk threads from cocoons.The house itself is old and built on a huge land.

View old-style Thai architecture at Jim Thompson House.. Jim Thompson's House is very easy to get to. Just take the Silom Line Skytrain to it's terminus at the National Stadium, walk down the right-hand side staircase onto Rama I Road and turn into Soi Kasem San 2 - it's well sign posted. A short walk down this soi (lane) will bring you to the Klong (canal) San Saeb where the house is located on the left. Jim Thompson resurrected the Thai silk industry and his weavers were housed on the opposite side of the klong. He was a great collector - in fact the House is a collection of smaller houses and buildings which he purchased and transported from upcountry to reassemble as a whole in Bangkok. He also collected many examples of Thai art and crafts which form a wonderful museum today. This house provides the visitor the chance to visit an old traditional Thai house right in the middle of the city. Jim Thompson disappeared without trace whilst on holiday in the Cameron Highlands, Malaysia. This remains one of Asia's greatest mysteries still today. Books on his life and disappearance are on sale in the souvenir shop.

Lovely place to visit. We really enjoyed our visit here.It was early in the morning before the crowds and we loved seeing all the artifacts and orchids in the house. The tubs of lotus were gorgeous. We went back in the evening for dinner which was the best we had in Thailand!
Historical House. A beautiful house. Every aspect in this house carefully handled. Easy to find place. Very recomended to visit.

It is a rich man's house that is all!. It is a common businessman made it big in Thailand, build a nice traditional Thai home put many expensive antiques in it and that is it. I think the name Jim Thompsanis is just a way to make it sound spécial. Thé house and antiques do worth a visit but Jim Thompson to me is just another white guy made it big in Asia!

Real thay house. Absolutely cute. It's a very comfortable and relax guided visit to one real thay house, where its explained some typical and interesting arquitectural features of thai houses.For me BKK is very stressing, this vist was paradise.

Little Oasis. This house is tucked away in a side road not far from National Stadium BTS station. It was interesting to see all the different teak buildings and try and imagine what it would have been like when it was first built. We had an English speaking guide that showed our group around the garden and the house. I loved the rooms and the artifacts in them. The garden was very tranquil and backed on to a canal. There's a gift shop but I thought it was expensive. You can get a free shuttle to the main road which was nice on a very hot day. There's also a restaurant but we didn't used that. Worth a visit.
Silk and stuff. You were able to buy gifts that will wow your friends! History of silk as well as actually seeing how it is made. Interesting!

Interesting. The Jim Thompson House is so interesting and the story of Jim Thompson's disappearance is fascinating. This house was Jim Thompsons when he was in Thailand and it is beautiful, well worth seeing.

Peace & Tranquility. Most amazing experience.Most peaceful and tranquillity place I've been to. Very humble to visit, the items for sale can be expensive but you pay for what you get. Exquisite designs and quality of perfection.

if you have 1-2 hours to really kill go here. Quite Boring, if you have nothing and I mean nothing else to do then visit this place. You have to pay a mandatory 200 baht per person to have a tour. the ladies who work there memorize a script my guess is as there is joked interacted into the tour but they seem very artificial. I mean its not that much of an amazing house, it has a bedroom a living room, and some random statues which are half broken. The stuff you can buy is good quality but I mean do you want to spend 13 000 baht on a scarf?I would recommend spend your time and money better, bangkok is the epicenter for food and shopping and this place is not worth a visit I think unless you really have a lot of time on your hands and don't know what to do with it

Crowded sightseeing. We've been to this spot just this afternoon to see how beautiful it is.Unfortunately, a lot of tourists visited that place at the same time.The place is Jim Thompson's House and I guess this house should have been very peaceful many years ago.Taking pictures inside are prohibited.When you go inside the house you have to leave your slippers outsideFurthermore you have to step over the lower part of the door to go into each room that has been protected against bad spirits.Thompson"s body has never been discovered after his death.

Normal time killer . If you don't know what to go like me, this place is ok. The tour takes about 35 minutes und they have reduction for students (start is every fifteen minutes). The female guide's English isn't that kind of easy to understand when it is your second day in Thailand but the buildings are quite interesting. To summarize: only go if you don't care about that hour.

good for something to do for a couple of hours. old colonial house were you have to have a tour guide, small entry fee. lovely shop with fantastic air conditioning. fair priced restaurant with amazing cocnut icecream! locals will tell you its not open every day to try to get you to go else where with them but dont believe them it is!!

A must. Jim Thompson house provides a fascinating and important insight into the silk industry in Thailand. The house in located in a lovey quiet lane. The compulsory tour is excellent, the restraint also very good. Well worth a visit.

Way better than temples.. Totally tired of the temples and this house was amazing. Beautiful woodwork, an amazing story of a fascinating person behind it. Jim Thompson had an impressive collection of artifacts that would be worth viewing on their own, but when placed in that amazing house with that beautiful garden...it was my favorite stop in Bangkok.
Good quality Thai Silk products. Nice building at the beginning of Suriwongse road.Not a place for budget spenders but if you want topend products with mothern design this is your place

A beautiful Thai-style house made by a Westerner. It's interesting to see a Thai-style house reconstructed by a Westerner (and compare to the Western-style building of the Vimanmek Mansion built by a Thai king). Beautiful house and interesting tour, highly recommended if you need a break from all the temples!

A view into another life!. I have always been fascinated by the story of Jim Thompson and was very excited to visit his house. It has been kept exactly as he left it after his disappearance and his eye for detail was amazing. It is a beautiful house and gives you a glimpse into a time gone by. The gardens are also gorgeous and it was a lovely morning out and about.

Lovely Teak House. As other reviewers have said, it is a quiet and elegant oasis in Bangkok. Lovely gardens. You must take a tour and the guide was quite good. I enjoyed the art that Jim Thompson collected. I had been to his silk factory 30 years ago so was interested to see his home. It's easy to combine this stop with the MBK shopping center and the Snake Farm. The shop is expensive but air conditioned so nice to stop in and look.
Quiet near shopping. A quiet getaway near the shopping district. Beautiful examples of traditional Thai houses and furniture. Cafe in the courtyard serves simple fare and ice cool drinks.

Even in the Rain. We visited J T House in an absolute deluge and it was great. The staff had ample supplies of umbrellas and the House and gardens were so atmospheric. The tour guide in the House was very knowledgeable, had excellent English and great patience. The obligatory JT shop is very well stocked and you will buy something that is beautiful, novel and useful.

Jim Thompson House is good if time limited. If you are only in Bangkok for a day or so and need to have lunch during that period, then Jim Thompson house is good either just before or just after lunch. Very nice food and tour does not include much walking. Also close to MBK Shopping mall where you can buy cheaper versions of just about everything they have on sale at the House.

Change of pace in high energy Bangkok. My husband and I spent a lovely couple hours at the Jim Thompson House this morning, which is luckily within easy walking distance of our hotel. The story of JimThompson is very interesting, and his asthetic taste was exquisite. The visit makes me want to know more about what he accomplished and how. The tour guide was charming and informative, and we also had plenty of opportunity to explore the garden grounds on our own.

Worth a visit. This is a great morning out. Its next to the National Stadium BRT. For 2 pounds you have a 40 minute tour.Outside there is a dancer and silk weaving. The cafe offers great food and the gardens are well kept

Interesting and quick quick visit to learn a snap shot of Thai history. Jim Thompson House is an easy to find destination to fill a one hour tourist window. Very easy to get to as it is a few minute walk from the National Stadium BTS station and the massive MBK shopping centre. BTS was a better option than taxi as we found it difficult to find a driver who knew where it was.  Admission is 100Baht which includes a mandatory guides tour. The 30 minute tour provides an interesting snap shot of how this one man, an American, restored Thai silk production from a cottage industry to a global export following WWII. His very interesting home contains some very beautiful historical Thai artifacts. The gardens are also very beautiful to walk through. There is a nice shop you can purchase silk and cotton fabrics and merchandise as well as a small bookstore and a restaurant.

Really interesting. Being quite sceptical about visiting a house and museum named after a Jim Thompson, I followed the family somewhat reluctantly and was pleasantly surprised. The home is a peaceful escape right in the middle of the city. The home is a number of Thai homes which have in effect been built as an open plan home for Jim Thompson who was involved in the silk industry. Tour guide was full of information and the home had many interesting items collected by Jim Thompson over his life. Certainly worth a look and easy to get to by public transport. The shop whilst not necessarily on the cheap side had some gorgeous items such as makeup cases bags scarves and other goods made from silk. Nice way to spend the morning.
Most interesting. A great way to spend half a day. Nice gardens interesting artefacts in the house and very good guides.

Beautiful and Excellent Value!. This is a lovely little museum that is a real oasis of calm away from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. The guide who showed us around was very knowledgeable and definitely gave us a better understanding of the museum and its importance. The gift shop is also a great place to stock up on presents.

Peaceful. A lovely house that is actually a combination of 6 teak wood Thai houses. Beautifully furnished, traditional with an authentic feel, this house, situated on a canal, is very peaceful and a nice break in the heart of the bustling city. You can only go around the house with a guide, but that is no problem as our guide's English was excellent and she was very knowledgeable. Afterwards you can wander in the gardens at your leisure. There is a restaurant and shop on the site.

It's Silky. The setting for the restaurant is grand especially seeing the extraction of the silk from the pods. The food is presented well but above average in the price. Service is very good along with the atmosphere.

Must visit for museum lovers!. I am such a sucker for such museums and imagine that I was thrilled there was a guided tour to bring us through the different houses within the complex. The english speaking guide was charming and ever so helpful in answering the tour groups' questions. The artifacts and the structure of the house itself was amazing. I thoroughly enjoyed the visit there before hopping on a cab to Chatuchak Weekend Market. The impressive thing is that this is not a tourist trap: Nobody ushered us into the shop to try to get us to buy some Thai silk or tried to get us into the restaurant to patronize the restaurant; everything was at a leisurely pace.

Interesting but a little overpriced. The museum itself is a decent tribute to a man who seemingly contributed a lot to the financial growth of Bangkok, and Thailand in general, but it stops short of providing much insight into his life and the mystery behind his disappearance. The restaurant/bar is also quite pricey...

Great house, Insight into Thai superstitions. We took the BTS (Silom Line) to the National Stadium station and walked a short distance through a narrow Soi (street) to the Jim Thompson House. I was impressed by how organized and well-staffed the place was. There were people to greet you, to show you where to go next and to give you a tour of the place. We arrived at 915am and we were included in the compulsory tour (available in English, French and Japanese) at 930am. We were joined by 4 adults and 3 toddlers. The guide first showed us the exterior of the house then we left our shoes and bags in secure lockers and toured the interior of the house. The guide spoke okay English with a light Thai accent so she was understandable. She did not just point out the sights but gave us an insight on how Thais interpret them (ie. the broken antiques JT collected were seen as bad luck). She was able to entertain us and the curious toddlers at the same time so kudos to her skills:) It was a short tour, around 30-40 minutes and you have time to stroll around the grounds afterwards. There is a bookstore and a gift store but the items were mostly out of our budget so we just looked around. Since it was drizzling, we availed of the free shuttle service (golf cart) that took us back to the BTS station where we took a taxi towards our next destination.In conclusion, it was a good tour in a beautiful house surrounded by mystery and superstition (did i mention that accdg to JT's horoscope, he was supposed to be extra careful when he is 61 years old... the same age he disappeared?!). The tour guides were experienced, the staff courteous, the location accessible and the price reasonable (100 baht). I highly recommend this to visitors in Bangkok.

Excellent history of Thailand.. Hello all,I had a wonderful time at the Jim Thompson house. The collection of Thai cultural artifacts and blended architecture were amazing to see. I also thought the tour guides were most gracious and inviting. All of my questions were answered promptly and everything that was told to me by the tour guides was easily and quickly corroborated by the information in both the Lonely Planet and various other notable sources (Architecture Digest, Harvard Magazine, etc). I was really impressed and would recommend that all go see this splendor. It is not the most exciting and riveting part of Bangkok, but it is certainly worth a visit.

Beautiful and Nostalgic.... I was wary at first thinking this might be justbone of those boring museum visits, was I very wrong. I really love the place. Had a great time. The place brings you way back to what Thailand and it's people used to be. Our guide very nice and She knows what she's telling us. And you can feel the love and pride by the way she conveys it.

The House of Silk. We spent a lazy Sunday morning admiring the house of Mr. Jim Thompson, the patron of the Thai silk industry. An American who became a permanent resident of Thailand, his house is a lasting reminder of the man who did what he can to contribute in the preservation of Thai art and culture. The structure of the house itself adheres to traditional Thai architecture, and the interiors are finished and decorated using pieces salvaged and bought from old Thai palaces and houses. Also within the grounds of the compound is a small garden and a couple more smaller structures housing some Thai artifacts; there is also a restaurant and a boutique selling silk products (clothes, bags, accessories) carrying the Jim Thompson brand. 100 Baht entitles visitors to an English guided tour around the house; our tour guide was a pleasant Thai lady with a genuine smile. Thai folk dancing is also performed outside and the traditional way of spinning silk threads are shown to visitors.The Jim Thompson house can easily be reached via BTS. Take a train and alight at the National Stadium station. Get out via Exit 1 and walk towards Mercure Ibis Hotel and Lub D Siam Hostel. The street towards the house is immediately right after this and will take a couple minutes walk.

Informative guide but expensive stuffs. Like: quite a lot to see there; the interior of Jim Thompson house, the surrounding garden and demonstration of spinning silk thread. The area behind the house smelled horrible. I think it came from the murky color. canalHowever the stuffs that are sold at the shop are expensive.
Just okay. I figure you must really have a thing for silk to rate this place high. They are just too costly for what you get

Thai Silk Traditions revived. Preserved Thai house with a touch of western influence and flavor, beautifully maintained and guided tour of the house is a must, silk worm spinning is demonstrated in the garden and a pleasure to visit
Interesting tour and pottery.. Expensive but interesting. Be prepared to take off shoes. Restaurant looked busy but didnt eat there. Closes at 5pm

Don't miss. Jim Thompson was an art collector and he built his house putting together 6 thai houses from the old capital Ayuttaya. The result is very nice. If you want to start understanding thai culture you must see this house. We spent quite some time there, it's quiet, nice and peaceful. Their restaurant near the pond is just beautiful. Don't miss.
Interesting. This was a nice way to spend a couple of hours, was interesting to learn about Thai silk history. My wife enjoyed it more than me.
Jim Thompson House. Not what I thought it would be. Its like a very up market shop especially for Bangkok. Good for a look and maybe a purchase but as a guy not what I was expecting.

Definitely unique museum and well-managed. I've always wanted to visit the Jim Thompson House Museum in Bangkok but in my last few trips there, I couldn't quite find it. I knew it was within walking distance from the infamous MBK but only until I stayed at the Holiday Inn Express was I able to find it (it's right behind the hotel).Jim Thompson is a famous American credited with bringing renown to beautiful Thai silk. After the second world war, Jim Thompson made Thailand his home until his mysterious disappearance at Cameron Highlands, in Malaysia. There definitely is a sense of charm and mystery to the legend who is Jim Thompson and his beautiful home now turned into a museum adds depth to his tale.At 100 baht, a visit includes a must-do guided tour with some free time to explore the gardens. There's also a shop and restaurant, and a free art gallery if you're not inclined to tour the home (though really it shouldn't be missed if you've never been). The tour takes around 45 minutes or so and is quite nicely done. What we see as one house is really an assemblage of various old Thai wooden houses combined. The guide will point out the unique architectural details, and provide a sneak peek into traditional Thai living blended with Western creature comforts.I definitely found the visit to be insightful and interesting. The objects and artifacts left behind speak volumes of the life of Jim Thompson. His flair for art and beauty is evident and you can't fault him for falling in love with Thailand. Photos are not allowed in the house but can be taken outside and in the gardens.

Great place, poor service.. I am a lover of design and this house is wonderful. Such a shame the staff don't try harder to look after customers. They really just don't want to communicate it seems. But loved the inside out house! LOL

Interesting Stop. I will say that I was skeptical before going to tour this house but I was pleasantly surprised at how interesting the story and the house really were. We have two teenagers who seemed to enjoy it as well.

The story of silk.... The house is tucked down a side street but if you have a spare few hours in Bangkok well worth a visit. I found the whole story of Jim Thompson really interesting and his house and silk shop is amazing. Tour guides spoke very good English and we're passionate about their subject.

Great experience and worth the visit.. Been to Jim Thompson's before, but came again with some friends. Had lunch at the restaurant which wasnt too expensive but the food was good! For those who would like to see how beatiful Thai houses can be in an extraordinary way, Jim Thompsons is the place to be.

Top quality tableware. We always visit Jim Thompson House when in Bangkok and usually purchase table napkins for ourselves and as gifts for our family and friends as they are so beautiful and excellent quality.

nice one. A traditional house in bangkok just next a canal. You can go there by boat from the golden mountain temple. They work with silk farm and they make silk. You can get a guide in your language for the visit, that's rock and its not so expensive.
Surprisingly Good. We didn't know what to expect, but this place was great, the kids loved it and the staff were wonderful. Recommended.
Okay. The house itself is fascinating but you couldn't take pictures inside, you had to be with a tour guide for most of the tour. The restaurant was good but not outstanding. Service was very good.

A House with Beautiful Objects. Read a book on Jim Thompson before going to Bangkok. This is a beautiful teak house with all the beautiful objects he collected during his life. It is right near the National Stadium and the Sky Train. There is also a Jim Thompson Store and a silk making demonstration. No pictures are allowed and there is a place to put your shoes as they are not permitted as you tour the house. The tour guide was very knowledgeable. The tour groups are timed and small.

Hidden gem of a museum. Yes, it's the same man who disappeared in Cameron Highlands in Malaysia. The boutique store is overpriced but has a better selection than the outlets near Silom Road or in the Peninsula Hotel.
Interesting visit. a good break from the hustle and bustle, and shopping of bangkok. some of the guides are very entertaining.
Well organised profession tour. It was interesting and well organised. The price was fantastically cheap too. I love architecture and although it was a brief tour, I am glad I went.

A very beautiful place. Such an interesing visit! I really appreciate it as it represents a mix of occidental and thai culture, it is interesting to see the work of Jim Thompson. Moreover, you can have an english or a french guide tour. The french guide was really nice and was extremely willing to answer our questions.If you go by walking, the museum is located at the end of a little street so go straight ! i was worried that i went in the wrong direction but it is a little bit far. And another thing, the girl in front of the museum sometimes dance so wait a bit to see that :)

International man of mystery. Really enjoyed the tour of this ex-pat American who revitalized the Thai silk industry after WWII. Beautiful, authentic Thai home. Liked seeing the silk worms and cocoons and demonstration of how silk thread is pulled from the cocoons. Excellent restaurant on site with great salads. Also enjoyed the gift shop (the factory outlet store is soooo worth going to--it is easily accessible by Skytrain and has excellent prices for both fabric and gift items).

Oasis in the heart of Bangkok. Well worth a visit to this place, and hard to believe you are still in the middle of Bangkok. Take a trip back in time and take a tour thru the old two storey house set in lush gardens. Then visit the gift shop for some real Thai silk. A short walk from MBK.
Boring. Smart place with some nice old fashioned things but quite boring if you are not into architecture or silk history.

Highly recommend visiting this attraction. If you are anywhere near the big MKB shopping centre, then definitely visit this attraction. For 100 bahts, that's around $3 aussie, you can have entry and a 40 min tour in a variety of languages. the history component of the tour is pretty light on as the house really isn't that old. But to just get out of the crowds and somewhere relaxing I would recommend visiting this house.

interesting and fascinating. very good tour guide was well spoken and very knowledgeable the restaurant was fantastic. The tour guide hinted at much mystery and spoke with a fond irreverence of the gentlemen whose home it was

Beautiful, serene, interesting. The Jim Thompson house is a great place to go to get out of the crowds of Bangkok and to see an authentic Thai-style house (even though it was built by an American). Jim Thompson did an extraordinary job piecing together and constructing the house, which is truly beautiful. The guides did a good job showing it to us and explaining the story behind the house. Worth a visit for anyone who's staying in Bangkok.
Beautiful. An interesting place with an interesting story - loved the ambience and the shop. good guides with good english. - Value for money
Staff need some customer service skill training. Staff are really quite rude which is a shame as this is a great tourist attraction worth seeing in a city which needs more than shopping centers!

Worth a visit. A very interesting museum with beautiful, tranquil gardens. It is focused on the life of Jim Thompson and the architecture and art of his home rather than on his role in the Thai silk industry

Family vacation. We loved the way that Jim Thompson's house was like an oasis in the middle of the city. History was preserved in an unusual way. We had the opportunity to learn about his life story and his contributions to the development of the Thai silk industry.

informative & peaceful visit. i loved the fact that they had tours . Myself & my family loved Jim Thompson house & found it very peaceful ( a nice escape from the hussle of Bangkok) , a beautiful setting , with a fabulous guide, who was so humble & so professional ! Don't miss out on this.

Must see in Bangkok. What a pleasant surprise to walk into the Jim Thompson house compound. A small oasis in this bustling city. We really enjoyed the tour, gave us a feeling of old Thailand . Our tour guide was very pleasant and spoke English very well. Highly recommend a visit.

Highly recommended - a gorgeous sanctuary in the middle of the city. I kept seeing reviews recommending this place before we went to Bangkok and was kind of sceptical as I couldn't work out what it was (clearly I should do more research, but still...). The house belonged to an American artist who collected Thai art and has been preserved since his mysterious disappearance as a sort of museum. It's made up of various traditional wooden houses and gorgeous gardens, and it's like an oasis in the centre of the city. Very peaceful and just what we needed after a morning of Bangkok traffic! The cafe did some good desserts too - the cheesecake was great!

Well worth it. Walking distance from MBK, or for more adventurous spirits, check out the canal boats. You join a small group to be led around the gardens and buildings. You learn a lot not just about Thompson but traditional Thailand too. The shop is beautiful, great traditional and modern designs on excellent quality fabric - a good break from the markets. You can rent out the restaurant for private functions, when we were there last a very hi-so Thai wedding was taking place - beautiful pristinely made up Thai men and women juxtaposed with happy snappy sweaty tourists (me being one). Very entertaining.
Love this museum. You should see this place at least once, especially if you are into old Thai Architecture. I just like walking around the old teak home and enjoying a taste of old Siam.
beautiful mansion. situated in the middle of buzy bangkok, but looks like an oasis. beautiful garden and the mansion itself is a must for all visitors. the decoration and statues are wonderful

Jim Thompson was a visionary man. This house is worth seeing for the sense of style this man had. Also, the tour is excellent and well conducted by the most exquisite Thai girls who speak excellent English

Good tourist attraction for older people. I took my parents and mother-in-law here, they loved the history and the gift shop. I found the gift shop to be very expensive but the stuff in it was beautiful and high quality. Nice cafe. A little boring for younger travellers.

An oasis in the city. Like other reviewers I didn't expect this place to be so peaceful and amazing we loved it. however if you press with time visits the top three in BKK first. Otherwise it's well worth coming here for a break from the busy city.

Excellent way to start my Thailand experience. A short walk from our hotel, sounds a bit odd going to an Americans old home, I am not one for art galleries or museums but this was easy to digest and enjoy. The tour was well organised and not too long (30 mins). We were free to wander around the gardens and visit some of the smaller houses after the tour. Also enjoyed the demonstration of silk spinning and the small exhibition of a contemporary Thai artist upstairs above the shop
Surprisingly Wonderful. I wasn't really sure what the hype was regarding this place....until I went. It's just beautiful. Trust me, put it on your list.

Old time glamour. I love this place, mostly because Jim Thompson shared the same taste with my late grandfather. They both collected and studied ancient arts and crafts so it was like a visit to my own grandfather's house. Everything was so familiar. I simply adore all the house's details and the collectibles. And after you finished the house's tour, you could spend a lazy afternoon in the restaurant or you could indulge yourself in the glorious colours and textures of Thai silk.

So-So. I was bored actually when we went here. I just chose this place since it's among the top 10 places here in tripadvisor. But maybe others would appreciate it since it's more of antiques and history if the house which I am not really a fan of.

Worth a Visit. The house and grounds of the Jim Thompson house are very much worth a visit. The grounds are lovely--maybe someday my garden back home will look this nice. The house has been beautifully maintained and gives the visitor and good impression of what Thailand was before the city built up around it.
Very much enjoyed the visit.

Teak wood and a great atmosphere. A little paradise home of Jim Thompson in the middle of Bangkok! easy to get there via Skyline, get off at "Nation Stadium" stop. the house is open everyday from 09:00 - 17:00, take the guided tour - it's included in the ticket, you will not be able to get into the main rooms of the house without their guide! Lovely art that Mr. Thompson collected. The house is located next to the river, with a beautiful garden and a nice little restaurant (did not eat there). There is a Jim Thompson store on the premises, prices are not cheap - but beautiful silk work!it's a nice place to enjoy an hour or so away from the busy city for 100 BAHT ticket fare.

Antiques and architecture. The Jim Thompson house is a fascinating place to see Thai architecture re-interpreted by a foreigner. Thompson collected an impressive amount of antiques and collectibles. The collection is displayed using the house like a museum. In order to see the house you must join a tour. I luckily arrived right as one was leaving so didn't need to wait, but if you are on a time schedule or if you need a particular language it might be worth calling ahead or checking the website. The tour is slightly rushed, but very interesting, There are two gift shops and an art gallery that are worth a look.
Nice and interesting. Very nice house in a beautiful setting. The mandatory tour is informative and takes about 40 minutes which is just enough. The guide was competent.

Easy to find, nice break from the city. This was so easy to find, I can't believe people say they can't find it! Exit 1 from the sky train at the national stadium, follow the signs - first street on right after ibis/mercury hotel.Lovely to look around the arts and curios collected by Jim Thompson before his mysterious disappearance in 1967.Beautiful gardens, house and great value for money - 100tb inc tour!

Jim Thompson : Silks, Spies & Speculations.. Mythic man ..architect /OSS pre CIA spy "our man in asia " during WW2; created Thai International silk industry ; divorced linked to expats and fame and fortune . Unsolved disappearance. When is the film being made? it has everything and the milliions who've traipsed like we did through his fabulous former house now museum in the city of Bangkok, would be drawn to see it. The house is a great view of life for the times he lived and his contribution to Thai silk industry enabling women to sustain role in the home by cottage industry approach.They says designer for " King and I " used his Thai silks in the film which kicked off his international business. His art collections and furnishings & courtyard gardens are glorious .Watching silk spinning and silk worms was a treat at the entrance Shopping on site for silks or fabrics using his old designs or new ones was fun. Really good outing ++++
Just Beautiful. You must see this wonderful wooden house & stunning gardens a little paradise amongst the madness ;)

A tranquil relief from the city. The Jim Thompson House is tucked away at the end of a street opposite MBK and other landmarks. They have a buggy service to drive you from the main road in though the walking distance was rather short. The admission fee was reasonable. ISIC card holders & those below 25 get 50% discount off. We were assigned to a group with other visitors for the tour conducted in English. You can't wander around the higher level of the house without being accompanied by a guide. The tour takes you around the entire house & the guide assigned to our group spoke very well. The guides are well trained & do not hesitate to ask them any questions should you have any. The entire compound looks beautifully preserved & there are lots of photo taking opportunities at the external compound. Once inside, they are extremely strict on enforcing the no photography rule. A korean couple was berated for flouting this rule. The guide will explain the origin of some of the artifacts stored in each room and comment on the inspiration for the design or layout of particular rooms. Mr Thompson infused both elements of western & thai culture when he built the house. I recommend a visit to this place if you are spending more than 3 days in bkk. Otherwise, I think you may want to give this attraction a miss in favour of others like Wat Arun and Siriraj Medical Museum.

Relaxing Place at the City Center. I love the feeling when we arrived at Jim Thompson House. The restaurant in classy and cost around 120- 180 bath per dish, not so bad and it is really nice. I enjoyed the lady dancing and the guy making silk. It is nice to see hot Thai Silk is made. Just bring mosquito repellants and while waiting for your tour (100 Bath) walk around the garden area and it has a nice souvenir shop. Our tour guide speaks english well but with a heavy accent so, we can't understand her that much. I like that we can take picture around. There is also a shuttle to BTS station which located at the end of the street.

An interesting cultural spot. This a place to visit on your second stay in Bangkok. It's a typical Thai house with a nice pond, a lot of vegetation and many cultural Thai elements, paintings, furniture, decoration objects and so on. Very nice place to visit!

Interesting take on Thai style. An interesting collection of Thai houses with an array of antiques set in stunning tropical gardens right in the middle of the city.Well worth a visit, even though this was designed and built by a westerner, and therefore has more of a foreign take on Thai.Of course the brand makes some stunning silk items, with the most beautiful cushion covers, table clothes, serviettes, table runners and so on. Also some clothes, but probably more suited for women.

Pleasnant diversion. We enjoyed our visit - a quick tour around the house that Jim built provided a fascinating insight. We couldn't decided if he exploited the silk industry or did an amazing job in boosting the local ecomony and bringing lovely silk to th world. He certainly made a lot of money whichever way you look at it. There is a restaurant and shop on site and we found it a pleasant diversion for a couple of hours.

An oasis of charm. A great place to visit for an hour or so. You must join an organised tour - a guide then takes you to a number of rooms in the houses of Jim Thompson - explanations of the style and decor are given. This tour takes about 30 minutes. The staff are friendly and knowledgeable. There are two gift shops where you can purchase literature or silk products. There is also a cafe on the grounds. The house backs the klong, or canal - where water taxis stir up the murky water. I suggest you go earlier than later in the day - we arrived in time for the 10 am tour - after this time things got really busy.
Very nice. It just seems to be one of those things you have to see. It was interesting and the guide was good. Glad I did it

The perfect Asian arts`collector`s house. Beautiful house, made of several small houses. Jim bought various houses in the Isan region and had them moved to Bangkok and rebuilt. He accumulated an impressive collection of South-East Asian art pieces (sculptures, manuscripts, pieces of furniture,...). Also arranged the decoration of the complex. The history oof the former owner is different as well (ex CIA agent).
tranquil. Very tranquil visit here, and relaxed. Very hot, as you are inside for part of the time make sure you have water with you.

a must see place in the bustle of bangkok. fair to say the jim thompsons museum and house is small, but perfect. no great effort to get to using the skytrain, just a few hundred metres to walk or use the golf cart shuttle. guided tours only inside the house, but be warned you have to take your shoes off to go inside, i am unable to walk without shoes so missed this part, but i loved the photo opportunities in the garden as i waited for my wife to complete the tour. the tours are in thai or english, specify which you prefer. the guded tour lasts about 25 minutes.

A Solid Wooden House!. Wonderful, cosy and airy house! Beautiful and well planned garden leading to it! The house is elevated as it is on stilts. The chandeliers inside belong to the 18 th & 19th century. This house is a lasting reminder of Jim Thompson's creative ability!

Interesting experience. When you enter the place you can see the nice garden. It was good to walk around there before the house tour started (the tours are compulsory in the house).At the garden and at the beginning of the tour our guide showed us the process of the silk making.The interior of the house is very nice, the guide told us interesting stories about them.At the beginning of the tour we had to leave our bags at the locker room, we could carry only our photo camera and wallets. But please note that during the tour it is prohibited to take photos inside. If you would like to take photos about the half way open air porch you can do it from outside (the tour at first shows the building from outside).

Traditional gem. The Jim Thomson House was such a delight to visit! The cheap price (100THB) supplied us with a gorgeous English speaking Thai guide. Breath-taking structure and design was unexpected but pleased my friends and I. Afterwards, we decided to sit down in the restaurant for some coconut icecream which was delicious!

Calm place to visit in hectic Bangkok. After herding around the grand palace and temples in Bangkok, we went to Jim Thompson house and it was an amazing visit of calm.
Beautiful traditional built houses - time to ask questions about them, enthusiastic guides, beautiful gardens. I can't recommend a trip to this museum highly enough.

Wonderful Viet Houses - Great Story. Jim Thompson was an interesting character. A throwback to the times when the aristocrats of the north east found their way into the intelligence community of the USA - and then went on to other things. JT is a legend - but do your own research - all is not what it seems. The building of this home from the many smaller houses that were moved here is testament to the unique persona that JT wove - and it is fascinating. The silkworm demo is fascinating, the gardens beautiful, the tour well performed and the remaining artifacts interesting. This site has everything, art, horticulture, architecture, intrigue and mystery. If you let it, it will draw you in and make you want to come back for more. Or it is a welcome diversion from the madness that is Bangkok!

Don't miss the silk worms by the entrance!. We enjoyed the tour of Jim Thompson's house. It is a great chance to see traditional Thai architecture and also to ogle at all the wonderful items he collected.The compulsory tour was very good - the guide spoke good English, the group wasn't too big and the pace was spot on.The highlight for us was seeing the silk worm cocoons outside in the garden area, being steamed (or so it appeared) and then the silk spun from them. Fascinating!
Worth a look. Interesting and authentic , well worth a visit and not far from BTS. Fees a bit expensive and shop was overpriced.

Interesting architecture. Interesting tour and the tour guides there are friendly with a good sense of humor! Be prepared for a 5-10 minute walk down the street to JT house, but fret not about walking out. There is a free buggy ride service to national stadium BTS and this service runs every 15 minutes.

Worth a visit. After reading reviews we decided to take a look at the house. Yes, Jim Thompson did an incredible job. There is no denying the house is beautiful and interesting. I found the tour guide to be pleasant and have a good understanding of Jim and the house. A quick walk through was just enough for us.
Great tour of JT house. I loved this visit, the tour of the house was well organized, interesting and was a pleasant thing to do in Bangkok.

Interesting. Jim Thompson house is actually six old Thai houses dismantled and brought to this site. They are beautiful buildings, furnished simply but wonderfully. The whole setting in the middle of Bangkok is very tranquil.

A nice history lesson. We had heard the story of Jim Thompson and thought it would be nice to go and see one of his houses, which is now a museum dedicated to him and his work while living in Thailand.Allow a few hours to look round the grounds and the house, you are taken round by a guide who is very knowledgeable and gives a bit of the history of this famous man.The Thai silk made at one of his silk farms is sold on site as are many other souvenirs.A good way to spend an afternoon.
An experience. This is a must for all tourists to Bangkok it has been around for so so long and probably my 5th , his shops are also scattered all through Bangkok
Wonderful House, Avoid the Gift Shop. Interesting Story...of course they leave part of it out, do your own research. The Gift Shop is overpriced!!!

Must see in Bangkok!. We loved coming here. Our tour guide was very funny telling us all about Jim Thompson and his life, as well as about the house and different Thai customs. Ask for a map of the outlet stores -- one of them sells discounted scarves and accessories, and though it's a BTS ride away, it was well worth it because I stocked up on awesome gifts for my friends/family for great prices, rather than buying all the crap at the night markets.The restaurant is really very good and not badly priced. I ate a lot of mango sticky rice in Thailand, but this was by far the best one!

Take the National Stadium train or water taxi. This was worth the trip, because it was quick and easy. This may seem way out of the way, but its easy to get to and is a good trip. The house, art and story is very good, but watching the silk worms produce silk and the native dancers gives it a little extra. It's an easy walk from the National Stadium, elevated train station (the last train stop) or if you are traveling from the Palace area walk to the canal river taxi station (about 10 blocks) and take the river taxi.

Nice house, interesting tour. The house is located not far from MBK, so it's great if you want a break from the shopping in Siam area. The purchase of the ticket includes the compulsory house tour. The tour is quite fast but you cover all rooms and the two small buildings by the side that you skip you're allowed to visit after the tour at your own pace. There is a Jim Thompson silk shop, a small bookshop and a restaurant on site as well.Overall a pleasant experience and an interesting insight into Thompson's life in Bangkok as well as his antique collection if you're in the area.

Lovely retreat in city centre. The price wasn't cheap but I had already planned to visit this to find out more about Jim Thompson.You don't actually get to find out that much but the tour guides are slick with good English. Was lovely to see traditional Thai houses and the artifacts are interesting. I can appreciate why people may be disappointed with this but we also liked it as it was a quiet, calm retreat with lots of shade on a hot day in the city. There's a cafe/restaurant on site too where we had a beer.

Nice house, but overall dissapointed.. The house and history of Jim Thompson is impressive. But the guided tour around the house is fast, the staffs english is really poor and you're nearly running it all around just to see everything. Glad to see it, dissapointed in the way i saw it.

mystical house. A breathtaking design and a very good taste owner. This house was built years ago and seemed to have mystical aura in it. The guide will tell you story regarding Jim and every room's purpose, to have a great guide is a bless! The decoration is very well collected and i dont think you can see other countries having this kind of house!

Very interesting.. This is a nice tour, with an amazing story. The house is beautiful to see, and it is interesting to hear how an American helped to re discover the lost art of silk making.I am also a fan of midcentury architecture, so this was even more interesting for me.

Historical location, nice ambience. Every visitor to Bangkok seem to be drawn to this place. It's a nice quiet charming place in the heart of Bangkok and yet away from it all. Surprising to find a nice little quiet enclave in the heart of the city. It has a museum and a shop. The house itself has a little bit of history. The meals were surprisingly not that expensive for such a place. Service is good. Choice and variety excellent but I can only say that the quality of food is good but not the best you can find in Thailand.
Interesting. Take the tour for understanding everything about the house. It is great and the garden is incredible nice. A must see for Bangkok travelers

Cool House Worth a Visit. As an American, the story of this American who fell in love with Thailand -- and made a difference here -- resonates strongly. The house is tranquil and interesting to explore. As others have commented, the contrast with the surrounding city adds to the experience.While pleasant, our guide seemed one step up from English-language students practicing their new-found language. Though we could understand her sufficiently well, I overheard another guide who I would not have been able to understand consistently. Acknowledging that this is not an English-speaking country, nonetheless, at a well-established attraction on the upper end of the cost spectrum, I'd encourage improvement in that area.Kudos to the sweet girl manning the shoe lockers who gave our son an origami-style paper top she had made. Then, after we expressed interest, she spent nearly an hour showing him and my wife how to make them. Other guides wandered over during their free time (the attraction was not busy) and joined in, with one making a nifty paper elephant for us. Very charming people and a nice place to visit!

An interesting story with a great collection of Thai art. My husband and I had been to many "Jim Thompson" stores in the past, but didn't really know the history of the company or this man. What a fascinating story to learn about, and a beautiful collection of building and art to explore. Our tour guide spoke good English and was friendly. Other reviewers mentioned that they felt rushed, but we felt that the 40 minute tour was perfect in timing and we were able to take everything in. There is time after the tour to continue exploring on your own. We stopped by the cafe prior to our tour, and enjoyed some nice thai iced tea drinks there, so consider this for a short break from a long day of touring Bangkok. Would highly recommend a visit to this site.

Pleasant break from Bangkok. My visit to Jim Thompson's house was good. It wasn't as good as the number 7 ranking on tripadvisor for Bangkok but I did enjoy it. The English speaking tour was good (around 30 mins in length) and she was able to answer the few questions some of the others had on the tour. The gardens were beautiful. You cannot take photos inside the house, only on the ground level and within the gardens, which is fair enough. The architecture is fascinating and despite being fairly small, the garden was dense with beautiful flowers, fish ponds and palms. I read a couple of review from people who couldn't find the house! bizarre really as it's around a 3-5 minute walk from the BTS station (national stadium) Take exit 1, turn round and head back along the road. Take the first road on the right and the house is at the end of this road on the left hand side. No problem!It cost 100 baht for the entrance ticket and guided tour, which I think is a great price!

Rich Thai Culture building. I'm great I'm here today. The house is so beautiful and relax. With 1,000 batt including tour guide as entry fee it is quite cheap compare to China. My husband and I enjoy the tour very much. We also have our lunch there overlooking the garden. Great place.

Interesting but limited - a report. I have been to Bangkok before and seen the major sites. This is in the second rank but very easy to reach in the centre. The Skytrain line that ends at the national stadium station is just 5 minutes walk from this attraction. As you depart the station go west towards the end of the line staying on the north side (right hand side as you look west). Once you are down on ground level you turn back on yourself and will walk along Rama Thanon and after a minute or two will see a small sign on a post in the pavement pointing to Jim Thompson's house.As you walk into the side street (Kasemsan 2) you may see a small shuttle buggy (just like a golf buggy) that will run you to the house but it is under 3 minutes walk up the street to the attraction on the left hand side.Entry fee is 100 Baht for adults and 50 for students and certain others. Perhaps the most delightful part is the yard. Do not miss the Koi in the pond and there are some other ponds too.You will be allocated a time for a guided tour (40 minutes) in you language. All major languages catered for. Frankly it was informative but a basic tour. In retrospect I would have got almost as much out of it by wandering unguided.No photographs allowed inside the buildings but allowed in the gardens which are small. Now do not miss the large plant pots filled with water and tiny goldfish and a few with lotus plants (in bloom) when we visited.The design is a teak wood shell to columns made of 'tende' which is apparently a very durable and longlasting hardwood that forms the structure being constructed in a slightly inward angle from the perpendicular. The artefacts on display forming paintings, statues, spiritual guardian statues, and tapestries are few. If you have already seen the inside of a temple in Thailand then do not go. I have yet to go to Vimanmek Palace and that I am sure will outclass this attraction. The guide's accent was average and whilst could be understood you had to concentrate hard to get the information. The guides talk was interrupted by the tremendous noise of adjoining water taxis every few minutes which blotted the tranquillity of the attraction and hence the experience.Particularly if you are from north america you are naturally inquisitive of Jim Thompson's life but i doubt you will be better acquainted with the details when you leave and I think this attraction misses the point. J T commercialised and exported the natural silk trade but there is very little in this museum about this process. You have to take shoes off when inside the building on tour so wear socks for this experience. You are give a locker and key to put bags inside also for the tour so make sure you do not take valuables that will not fit in your pocket.On the positive, the attraction is easily accessible in the city centre and the pier for the water taxi route running between Mahakan fort to the west and an indeterminate point east stops immediatelly outside, hence the noise.My question for you is, how much time have you got sightseeing in Bangkok. If there are other major attractions you have not seen, choose them rather than this one.Open apparently between 9- 5pm every day (www.jimthompsonhouse.com). This attraction is not for wheelchair users and there are plenty of steps and room seals at ground level so it would be unsuitable for the walking impaired. Remember it is a teak building and lacquered so very dark and a challenge for photographer even outside in parts. No aircond understandably but some fans which you should position yourself next to when the guide stops to give the talk.Regards.Chris & Ashley (son) (Anna did not come)

Beautiful place, especially the restaurant terrace. Exhausted by the heat and a day of visiting Bangkok, we decided to stop for a lunch in the Jim Thompson House. Didn't have the courage to do the museum. I still haven't forgot the delicious starter we had. The terrace is lovely with a small fish pool and palm trees. You will easily forget that you are in the middle of a busy Bangkok.

Stunning Oasis away from Bustling Bangkok. After reading the reviews on this site and recommendations from our host - I decided to head to the Jim Thompson house.It is easy to find from the National Stadium BTS, in fact the Jim Thomspon house even has a golf cart shuttle every fifteen minutes if you don't feel like walking (walk is about 5 - 10mins).For 100Baht (50 baht if you are under 25), this is well worth it. The house itself is stunning, you get a free included tour which is very informative and takes around 35 minutes. Then you are free to wander around the grounds. It is nice and quiet despite being off one of the busiest roads in Bangkok.Go, you will love it.

Hard to find but not a bad visit. It was really hard locating the place after i alighted at National Stadium BTS. Went into MBK to ask counter staff and then walked to the opposite side like she told me to. Then again, lost.The map tourists have isn't helpful in locating the museum. Fortunately, a local gave me directions and so all in all, it took me more than half an hour to walk there! I liked the tour given by the staff there. Found it informative although sometimes i could't understand what she said due to the Thai accent. The shop is ridiculously expensive and i was mad enough to buy 2 cushion covers at 900baht each!

Check it out. It's is a great tour, but brief. Our group was small but a large group was behind us and I felt sorry for them because the rooms are small and you could miss something if you do not hear everything. They offer English guided tours and end with a very expensive gift shop. It is a tourist attraction but interesting and I am so glad we went!Beware, you can not take pictures inside and must leave all purses, camera bags, etc in their lockers before the tour.

Beautiful Architecture. This is a 100 baht per person guided tour through 6 thai houses. These houses were lived in by an American who fought in World War II, Jim Thompson. The tour took approximately 40 minutes to complete, and is available in 4 languages. Make sure to explore some of the other buildings that aren't a part of the tour after your tour is completed. The wood work in the buildings is beautiful. They also have some older buddhas on display. You do have to lock up any purses before you enter the house, so you may want to avoid taking valuables. Your purses go into lockers where you take the key, and the lockers are video monitored.

Nothing special - a lot of hype!. This is on every tourist list, but it is just okay. Really nothing special to see. Nice house, beautiful landscaping, but just a home where he lived. Spend your time on other attractions. This is a "d" list - "I have a spare day" type of venue. Nice, but not a must see.

Enjoyed my second visit as much as my first. There is something quite enchanting about this place. I thoroughly enjoyed my second visit to the house. The tour was interesting and I learnt more things i didn't know. Have lunch at the restaurant there. Food is good and the surroundings are lovely. Word of warning. It is hard to get a taxi with a metre. The house is an easy walk to the Sky Train (National Stadium). We only realised this after a frustrating time trying to negotiate a reasonable price for a taxi and decided it was easier to walk.

Must visit. Great place to have lunch. The restaurant had some excellent choices. The place where they make silk is very interesting. You can watch. They also have tastes of the Thai culture including dancers on the ground. There are no bargains to be bought but a good selection of silks

Good to fill in some empty time. Interesting tour through some lovely old buildings, while imagining what life was like in Thailand in the 1950s. Unfortunately because of the number of tours being pushed through, we felt a little rushed. The shop has some lovely items for sale, but the prices are very high.

Beautiful break from the malls and traffic of Bangkok!. June is hot and humid in Bangkok and the Jim Thompson House is a fabulous piece of calm in a bustling city. Take the Skytrain to National Stadium stop and follow the signs. The Jim Thompson House is at the end of the little street. Admission is 100 baht. The tour is approximately 30 minutes; not all of the guides speak perfect English and you will or can feel a little rushed through the house but you can return to the gardens at your own leisure. There are free lockers for your bags and you will remove your shoes when you enter the house proper. Inside the house you will see Buddhist artefacts, lovely paintings on cotton of the Buddha's previous lives and much porcelain as well as some Chinese furniture. Be sure to get a good luck at the 'mouse' game - a labyrinth game to entertain children which had one time held a real mouse. The trip contains some stairs so it would not be good for someone with mobility issues. There are two individuals doing demonstrations of silk weaving. There is a small shop to purchase books and reproduction prints (100 baht - they are small) and postcards, etc. There is also another shop with silk scarves, ties, place mats, purses, etc. 2600 BTH (roughly $85 CDN) for a beautiful scarf. The patterns are endless. Cotton scarves are half that. Yes, they are cheaper at the markets! But I didn't find any with the amazing patterns at the Jim Thompson House. There is also a bar and restaurant. The food is utterly picturesque - and delicious. They allow you to linger all you want. The fruit smoothies are refreshing as is the iced tea. Thai and Western dishes are quite good and a nice break before heading back into the heat and crowds!
Amazing place. This is a very interesting musuem where you can also buy fine Thai silk. It is too bad that the owner is not around any more to enjoy his achievement.

Nice history. Nice to see some history being preserved and good value for money in my opinion. I especially liked the relevance to Bangkok and commercial trade and how it changed some attitudes but kept some character.

No Service. We came here when it was raining and when we entered they took our umbrella and showed us around, we purchased some cushions and 2 blankets at more than $400 Aust and all was good, but as we were leaving I asked for the Umbrella which belongs to our hotel but it was gone.Then I was told we arrived with no Umbrella, I said we did and it did not belong to me and I would be charged if I did not return it to the hotel. I was told by the assistant store manager I was a liar and I was trying to de-fraud them and they would not pay for the Umbrella. I decided to forget it and leave and as I left the Assistant manager said if I come back he will get the police. So I will never go there again
Sightseeing. A small quite place in the city. Nice museum and opportunity to buy some of the nicest ties and silk in town.

An oasis in the middle of the city. The old Thai wooden house is beautiful to see, the garden offers a welcome relaxing break in the middle of the noisy city, and the story of Jim Thompson is interesting and intriguing.

A nice getaway from the craziness. I'd give this a 3.5 - visiting the Jim Thompson House is good if you have some time to kill or just want to get away from the hustle and bustle for a little bit. Wouldn't put it on my top 10 list, but it is a nice way to see a traditional teak house. Upon paying, you will be assigned a group tour, which is the only way you can get in (you can't walk around on your own). Basically, it's a beautiful old home with regional antiques. Glad I went, but wouldn't return. We went with a couple friends from Bangkok and they hadn't ever been (or really heard anyone talk about it). Definitely for tourists.

Very educational and beautiful. Wow, what a beautiful oasis in the middle of a bustling city. The tour was very reasonably priced and offered in English as well as many other languages. I highly enjoyed learning about Jim Thompson and his life and business in Thailand. Plus his house has a great collection of Thai art and Buddha images! Make sure you use the free shuttle cart from the BTS to cut down the walk in the humid air of Bangkok!

Not up to the expectation. I visited this place in March as heard a lot about the name. However, I was not very impressed with the out comed. Their prices are very expebnsive comparing to the other shops in the market who sells Thai Silk. I oprefer going to the other silk shops who cater to the local people
Beautiful Bargains!. A great place to shop. Lots of lovely cloths and accessories. Styles to fit all figures. Beautiful silk. Not to be missed on a shopping day in Bangkok.

An oasis in the city. I stayed in Bangkok for 3 days and I can tell you that this is definitely worth your time! The Jim Thompson house is well kept/preserved and beautiful both inside and out. The staff are extremely courteous and knowledgeable. It's cool and clean and definitely serves as a lovely respite from the hot stuffiness of the Thai streets surrounding it. I highly recommend going here! I also ate at the restaurant there; while it is highly priced for Thai standards it was about average for an American meal (~$11 for meal and a drink). I got the red curry with duck, grapes, and pineapples. Delicious!

Great Thai Art Collection - by a Westerner!. Lovely and tranquil, maybe slightly overrated?Excellent historical look into Thai art, ironically collected by a Westerner.They seem to revere Mr Thompson here as some kind of demi-god and was a little underwhelmed at some parts (but very impressed at other parts), but it's worth a couple of hours and the tour guides are very good (tour comes included in your admission price, you cant just explore the inside of the place by yourself)Got here via a Klong boat - worth doing if you're feeling slightly more adventurous!

Very Interesting & Beautiful Grounds. This was our second visit to Jim Thomson House. On both occasions, we found it extremely interesting and an oasis in the middle of Bangkok. It is very well organised with a guided tour leaving every 10 minutes or so. There is a buggy which will pick you up from Rama 1 Road and will take you to the entrance and back. Also, there is a display at the front of the actual silk process. This is also a must see when in Bangkok.

Surprised at how great this was.. This was not a "must-see" on my list, but it was very close to my hostel and I had a little time so I decided to make the trip. I was pleasantly surprised. The grounds are beautiful and the tour is very interesting. It does not take a ton of time (maybe an hour) and it is beautiful. I would definitely make it apart of your trip to Bangkok.
Fabulous Afternoon spent. Excellent Introduction to Thai Silks & fabrics. Lot of stuff to shop around. A tribute to a Man who did so much for highlighting Thai Traditional craft.

Must visit if u really love Thai. Walk from my hotel (Holiday Inn Express) about 10 mins, beautiful Thai house fulled of antiques sculptures, buddha, vases, painting, furniture and many more. They have English guide to bring and explain to you, will take about 35 mins.There is a showroom+boutique, Jim Thomson Thai style restaurant, well, will try the food in my next visit, saw the menu price is reasonable.

Oasis in the city. I loved this traditional Thai house in the middle of Bangkok. Jim Thompson collected some magnificent antiques to put in his Thai home and the museum seems to be almost as he left it when he went missing in the Malaysian jungle some 40 years ago. Well worth the visit. It also contains a very expensive Thai silk shop, the product for which he is famous.

Perennial Favourite. When you live in a city you are usually bad tourists. However, when we have visitors from overseas, we look forward to taking them to Jim Thompsons house as much as the do.Well presented and unique insight into an interesting man and a great city.

A ancient style thai house impossible to find surrounded by ugly high rise buildings. If you can find it, this house complex is a nice but small complex of ancient style thai house, with some kind of museum and a restaurant(expenseive) and a SHOP (most important for thai people as money is the only thing which currently interests them)..did i mention the SHOP??? Nearly impossible to find in the middle of the worst polluted area of bangkok, filthiest, noisiest and hot like hell...but it is actually EVERYWHERE in Bangkok like that...!! Now, as generally thailand has gotten more agressive, people are less interested in tourists, only money seems to count anymore, smiles are NON EXISTANT most of the time and beaches are filthy almost everywhere, full of russians and their mafias unless you go in the extreme south national parks. Go to Laos instead for nature, Cambodia for smiles, Myamar for buddhism and maldives for clean beaches!
Living in style. A wonderful slice of a past life lived in great style and comfort.situated in an exotic garden ,in the middle of theIs heaving city. Don,t miss this place

Tasteful and elegant residence. Jim Thomson's house combined the best of Thai design with a North American twist. It was a delight to go on the tour and see the impressive rooms and the furniture and art Jim Thomson had collected.

Probably one of the best spot in Bangkok. I've been to the museum a couple of time. Jim Thompson is a legend among the thai silk industry, an american which then dissapear misteriously - the museum is Jim's house. You can learn alot about the Thai culture and the thai silk history in this place. Not to mention that Jim himself is a collector of cultural artefak that decorates the house.Located around the museum are the jim thompson store, the jim thompson restaurant (which is actually good! read my review on this restaurant) and an art space / function hall.If you're a architecture lover and art lover, this place is a must visit! It's also quite easy to reach. Walking distance from National Stadium stop.

tranquil place in the city. Jim Thompson house is an interesting diversion from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok City life.As the guide takes you through this Thai style house you see how he has incorporated some western style to the traditional thai way of living. You can imagine how he entertained many western guests in this beautiful home.The mystery of the final days of his life make it an intriguing tour. Our guide was very informative.Restaurant on the premises is very nice, good value and pleasant garden surroundings.Shop is expensive by Thai standards but Jim Thompson merchandise is renowned for style and quality.

Just lovely. The houses and landscape are beautiful and well kept. The tour is informing and interesting. The story is charming. The staff are well trained. The ONE dislike is that because it is located next to a small canal it's a bit stinky...but then again Bangkok is a bit stinky. I still would highly recommend going!!

Love how we can see the traditional Thai house in the city. A good visit to see what a traditional Thai house looks like, without having to travel to the suburb. I took my 3.5 year old son with me to Jim Thompson House and he loved the 30 mins tour to the house. We wanted to lunch at their restaurant but too bad we went there too early, the restaurant wasn't opened yet. People there provide excellent service with a smile; they even have a golf cart taking you back to the MRT station after the tour! $100 baht per adult admission fee is very reasonable.

A gem in the middle of the city. Jim Thompson House is a a 2-3 minutes walk away from the BTS National Stadium. They also have a shuttle every few minutes to and from the house if you wait at the start of the street. The house is surrounded by greenery, and they have maintained it very well. It was very interesting indeed to hear about the history of Jim Thompson and how he worked to revive the Thai Silk industry. They have tours in English, French, and Japanese. Not sure if they have other languages available, but while I was there, these were the 3 I heard at least :)Entry is 100 Baht, and includes the tour. No pictures can be taken while inside the house.

Outstanding Lunch Venue. Everything about this place is pleasing. The restored Thai houses are exquisite and the food is serious. The sales room is totally interesting and there is no hard sell pressuring by the staff.

Get a feel for old style Thai luxury here. Located steps from the National Stadium BTS, you have to see it at least once while in Bangkok. I got a feel for what it must have been like to have money and be in Thailand "back in day". Great place to visit with no high pressure sellers hanging about. Quick tour well worth the hour or so to tour. If you get to the MBK to shop, check this out too.

Delicious Restaurant. I had heard all about their famous silks but didn't realize they also have a delicious restaurant that's reasonably priced as well. The silks are beautiful but they're kind of pricey. However that didn't stop me from bringing several back for souvenirs. A very nice quality shop and restaurant.

good. the tour is good, venue is nice. shop is great, only the price is a bit high. I like their tie. why does it have to be fifty words or more?The only recommendation is that I think they should provide more language tour.
Awesome place. Very tranquil place with a great tour in English, A beautiful setting and great silks on sale in the shop as well.

Cool tour, really hot inside. This was a cool tour with an interesting backstory. The tour got a little boring after awhile, but mostly because it was ridiculously hot and we just wanted to get out of there. There is a shop that sells silk products but it's so overpriced. I would recommend this as a tier 2 attraction. Not a must-see in my opinion, but if you have extra time it's cool.

Beautiful "traditional" house and top quality garnments. Located in a side street next to a BTS station (National Stadium) and overlooking the river, this house is truly a gem. Well preserved, it has an original flavour, even if it was adapted to suit the taste (and western background) of its owner. There are guided tours in several languages that take you through the whole compound. Definitely worth the visit. At the entrance a local guy is showing the traditional procedure to get silk, by boling. Interesting, despite the added heat of the boiling water. The shop is also worth a visit, selling top quality garments. Prices are not much lower at the airport Duty Free shop, so if you want to buy you might as well do it here, as they have a much larger assortment. Free "shuttle" to and from the BTS station.

have to see this house. it really gives you that feeling of old Siam. The house is so beautiful. It's much better than the opulence of the Grand Palace for seeing the real luxury of Siam. It is one of our best memories of Bangkok.

Exotic living. This is a nice and relaxed tour. It's a beautiful house and takes you back in time to an era of exotic living by American entrepreneur . I would loooove to live in a house like that!!!! I wish they had more silk there for sale tho...but I guess that's what the factory and the outlet are for and they are in a different location.

Loved It. My family loves visiting historic homes. We try to imagine what it would be like to live, in this case, like an American lived and worked in Thailand after WWII. The tour is 30 minutes and not at all expensive. We thought it was well worth it - and after guests can spend time in the gardens and look at the other homes Jim Thompson built on his property. There are tour guides who speak different languages. Our tour guide spoke English very well.
