We learned about Jim Thompson, his art collection, how the homes were constructed just 60 years ago, which of the home's attributes were taken from Thai design v. western design, and about Thai culture. The gift shop is expensive but I read another review that shares there is an outlet with his products for sale. We didn't get the chance to go there. We also didn't have time to eat in the restaurant, but the atmosphere was very nice. Everything was well done.

Serenity in the city. I really enjoyed this beautiful house and garden. The guide was hilarious and really made the tour come alive. I didn't go into the souvenir shop or restaurant but both looked to be of a very high standard.
Very nice tour. We took BTS to Siam Square and walked from there to Jim Thompson House. It is a great tour. Nice restaurant and fish pond too. Well worth it.

Dream yourself away. If you are somewhat interested in shopping and fashion, you will stumble upon the Jim Thompson name approximately 15 minutes after you enter Thailand. The renowned silk company does not only offer beautiful scarves and garments, but they actually run the original founder's house as a small museum. You will have to join a very interesting guided tour to see the premises, and approximately 5 minutes after the start you will dream yourself back to old times, thinking how you could have lived here yourself... it is stunningly pretty.The only thing I was not so keen on where the live silk worms... but if you are curious, you can even touch them.

The silk developer in Thailand. It is a historical visit with a refresment of good view, design and environmental points.The visit is very well organized. It costs 200 THB and there is english explanation. After visit the house I suggest to have lunch at the restaurant located at the entrance. Very good food (international and thai), average cost of 250 - 300 THB, cold beer and very good ambience.

Inspiring. This attraction demonstrates what can be achieved when someone is passionate, focused and sticks with a belief in the potential of something for some decades. If you like design and architecture, you don't have to fancy silk to appreciate what Jim Thompson achieved by dedicating himself to one industry with potential in a country that was "poor" developmentally at the time (post-WWII). The shop is expensive, but that's optional. The guide was good, with excellent English. You are left with the discomfort of the mystery, "What really happened to Thompson?". What more might he have achieved?

Interesting recent history. Thompson is considered the father of Thailand's modern silk trade, having pushed and promoted it in the late 1950s and early 1960s before disappearing on a hunting trip in 1967. His home is a beautiful example of a well-to-do dwelling from that era, adjacent to a Bangkok canal and on "stilts," like most houses. It has a number of buildings and gardens, giving quite an airy feel. A good step back in time.

Interesting glimpse of older Thai archtecture. Much more interesting if you learn a bit about the late Jim Thompson, the most famous American ever to live in Thailand. He helped make the Thai silk industry what it is today. Also visit Jim Thompson stores in upscale hotels, downtown Bangkok or airport.

Neat place. Beautiful houses and grounds in a quiet neighborhood. This was the home of an american who spent most of his life in Thailand developing the silk industry before his mysterious disappearce while hiking in Burma. Nice gardens and beautiful art collection with paintings, ceramics and antique furniture. Live people performing silk weaving and Thai dance. Good tour guide who spoke excellent English (tour guide is manadory and included in entrance fee) Nice shop and restaurant. Also near a canal where you can get on a ferry after visit and head back to city center. This is a MUST while in Bangkok!!!

I wish my husband would have joined me. My husband is not so happy about silk as I am. I really think this is a place that can be worth seeing even if you are not interested in Jim and his Vogue-model girlfriend. The guide also talked about his connections to the fashion industry. Speaking of the tour guide I think her English was easy to understand and she told us little stories that might not be in wikipedia. I also think that the garden is lovely around the houses. I did not shop here which I also have to admit because I researched it and there is an outlet in Bangkok for Jim Thompson products.

What happened to Jim?. Learn about Thai silk, Jim and see the house complex of 6 buildings. The story is he revived the Thai silk trade. They have numerous stores around Bangkok and maybe other places where you can purchase, and of course one can buy while viewing the house complex. Worth a visit and easy to get ot.
Loved it. Lovely place with bags of character and plenty to keep you g children interested..highly recommend an hour or two here

Antiques,Silk & beautiful gardens. Being a silk lover, I was glad I took the time to spend some time here. As soon as you walk through the gates, you'll notice what a pretty setting it is, great for photos. The tour of the houses was interesting, full of beautiful antique furniture & homewares. The tour costs 100 BHT (3.10 AUS$), you are provided with a locker in which to place anything you don't wish to carry with you throughout the tour, you cannot wear shoes inside the houses (they also provide a spot for you to leave your shoes), you are not permitted to take photos inside the houses but, can click away to your hearts content in the grounds. There are many tour guides who caters for every nationality. There is a restaurant if you get thirsty or peckish. Don't for get to buy some silk in the gift shop, We bought a coin purse for 390 BHT (12.09 AUS$) & I picked up a silk napkin I intend to have framed for 520 BHT (16.12 AUS$). A touch of the silk trade history in a lovely, refreshing setting.

Beautiful architecture..... ...but a rather boring tour. The tour could have been so much more interesting, but it is all very basic. 'This is a lamp made from a drum, this another Buddha head, this is the bedroom...' it is all very much stating the obvious and not much is added to the experience by the guide.

What a peaceful retreat. Although I didn't get to see all of the interior (arriving just as it was closing after a 5-hour tour of Wat Pho, What Phra Kaeo, and several hundred photos), it was like an oasis from the heat and crowds. Traditional Thai houses from long ago, build by the entrepreneur Thai silk businessman from the U.S., it's definitely a place I'd return to. Not to miss - either a drink or a meal at the restaurant. The mango lime smoothie helps rejuvenate after an afternoon of 95 degree heat and high humidity!

A fascinating experience. To say that the home of Jim Thompson, an American citizen formerly employed by the Office of Strategic Security (now CIA) during the Second World War, is unremarkable would be rather fatuous. Almost everything about this figure is intriguing, from the fact that his 'house' is constructed from six different authentic Thai houses dismantled and brought from Ayuttaya and BangKrai to be reassembled in the current location, to the man's mysterious disappearance in the Cameron Highlands in 1967.Couple this with the legendary quality silk products, also on sale here in the gift shop, and not forgetting the cafe and restaurant, and this becomes an ideal place to visit and while away some time.I have been here several times with visitors and always recommend it. Unlike a growing number of tourist traps in Bangkok, Jim Thompson's House does not charge exorbitant entrance fees, and provides interesting and entertaining guided tours. Of course, if art and architecture, mixed with a bit of intrigue, doesn't interest you, you're not in the right place!

Unplanned visit was a nice surprise. We had never heard of Jim Thompson before, so we weren't too sure why we were going. (We actually went because it was walking distance from MBK and we didn't have any other plans.)But this was a fascinating and well-organized tour. It only a few dollars and well worth it. The story of Jim Thompson is interesting and surprising. Read up on him and go check it out.

Beautiful house, interesting exhibition about silk making. The house and history of Jim Thompson are very interesting. The exhbition is much smaller than expected but worth seeing. The garden is very beautiful too and you can stay as long as you want. The restaurant is mediocre and relatively high priced. As Jim Thompson House is quite close to the big shopping mals you might want to combine the two activities. There is a shuttle service to the BTS station.

A must see !!. This was definitely a highlight of our trip to Bangkok. It cost a mere $3 pp for an English guided tour of the estate. There are several houses on the estate with the largest one being that of the late Jim Thompson, who re-introduced the silk trade to Thailand boosting their economy.The gardens, artworks and surrounding area are beautiful, the house is typically Thai with western luxuries including a toilet !!! At the end of the tour there is a gift shop, unlike trashy souvenirs, the products for sale are truly worth the high prices.It was so interesting and peaceful that I would highly recommend it to all age groups.

lovely. this was a well maintened place, though very touristic but very organized. a historical and homy place . was inspired by the story behind this beautiful house of Jim Thompson.must see when in Bangkok

An oasis in the middle of Bangkok. We visited this house in the morning and only had to wait 20 minutes to join an English speaking guide who took us around and explained the fascinating history of Jim Thompson. The guide was exceptional! The tour took about 30 minutes and it was well worth doing. Read up on Jim Thompson before you go as the story of his work in Thailand and his disappearance is intriguing. Afterwards we had a pleasant, cool drink in the cafe next to the pond with the very large gold fish in it. There are very clean rest rooms. We were also lucky enough to see a man spinning the silk thread from the cocoons. We would really recommend this tour to anyone interested in seeing a beautiful Thai home with lots of history. It was one of our favourite things in Bangkok.

Cool dude, cool home. Jim Thompson will be your hero after visiting his home. It's a very neat story and the home is well-preserved. With your 100 baht admission, you receive a tour (Eng or Fr) which is about 35 minutes and it really makes the experience. The shop is fairly priced and there are some absolutely beautiful silk scarves and pillow covers. DIRECTIONS: with the Siam shopping complex behind you on your right, walk up Rama I and you'll pass the Bangkok Arts & Cultural Center...its the 2nd right after that. They run a golf cart every few minutes from the house to the main street though it's a fine walk down.

Old Thai architecture/ nice gardens. If you are sick of shopping, this is a nice detour. I was skepitcal to go see an American guys home in Thailand, but the home is a beautiful home comprised of pulling together multiple old real Thailand homes into one keeping a real feel of old Thailand. Lot so Thailand art and beatuy w/o feeling like we were just looking at a American home abroad. Nothing to do with silk manufactoring, except the expensive silk gift shop.
The mystry man.. Fantasitic - if you like this sort of thing.It needs a bit of time and background reading to get the full benefit from this type of visit.
Loved it. Beautiful Thai house , lovely gardens and amazing interior. Easy walk from National Stadium BTS station. If you like thai decor this place is a must see.

Worth a visit. Heard about this in Lonely Planet. A totally unique experience. The guided tour tells you all a lot about Thai history and architecture which I found very interesting. A very beautiful setting.

Really?. It's hard to see how this unremarkable house on a grotty klong with its unremarkable collection of wonky artifacts described by tour guides who are justifiably bored to tears gets such high reviews. I guess if you're on a package tour, getting out of the hotel and out of traffic is a thrill. Otherwise, give it a miss.

Spend time with the art collections. Be prepared to take your shoes off while touring the house. No pictures allowed inside, so they have keyed lockers for you. The tour is well presented with all the basic details, but I recommend you visit the web site before or after going as some of the tour guides may be hard to understand. Also, after the tour, circle back around to the buildings with the art and scroll collections and spend some time looking at the details. Some of the paintings have depicted ancient daily life and there are some funny scenes. Don't miss the display of Montien Boonma's unfinished works. I learned a lot about his life and inspiration for his works in this exhibit.

Interesting. If you like architecture and interior design than it is splendid. Be prepared for crowds a sit seems to be on everyone's list of must see sights. It is right beside the klong as take a water taxi there and see the back of Bangkok as a contrast to the serenity of JT House.

Very Interesting man. Jim Thompson fell in love with Thailand at a time when the country was very undeveloped & built a very successful business...a true adventurer. The house & art he bought & left are amazing.

Must be visited. I am not a fan of Jim Thompson's silk print, too conservative for my taste. When a group of fellow expats friends invited me to visit JT's house I was not thrilled but I joined them anyway and luckily I did. It is a beautiful Thai house built in teak wood and finely decorated with sculptures, paintings, porcelains. It is ‘centrally’ located (where the center is the main cluster of shopping malls) located steps off National Stadium BTS Station. Highly recommended to all ‘farangs’ visiting the City of Angels.

rich old Thai house. simply the most magnificent Thai house I have never seen, a perfect blend of western and thai culture. Great!
Do not forget to buy some items in the shop, certainly the best quality you can have in Thailand.

This is my fav. Brilliant, this is now my fav garden! Beautiful place and there is a bar and restaurant next to the House. I love the beautiful gardens and ponds and those Kois in the ponds are just fanstatic and serene to look at.
Jim Thompson House. Very interesting place. Beautiful architecture and artifacts. Watching the raw silk be woven was fascinating. The store was a little pricey but had nice silk items.

Jim Thompson House. The story of the commencement of this company and the mystery of the man's disappearance are intriguing. Further, the house in fascinating in style and full of fabulous articles collected by JT. It is an example of building style of a bygone era, 6 houses joined and 2 were 200 years old when moved to this peaceful spot. Items for sale are best quality - but beyond my meagre funds!

Cute little house with history of the silk trade in Thailand. Loved this little get away from Bangkok, but in the heart of Bangkok! Step into a little piece of quite away from the bustle of Bangkok and explore the garden and house of Jim Thompson. Take the free guided tour - worth the time and better to understand what's going on. I really enjoyed this place!There is also a shuttle bus that takes you back to the main road every fifteen minutes.
A tranquil haven in the madness of Bangkok. The Jim Thompson house is a beautiful place to visit for a couple of hours to escape the rat race that is Bangkok.

Interesting History and Beautiful Silk Products. The historical home was within walking distance of the BTS - National Stadium stop. The entrance fee included a guided tour which was very informative and interesting. The home was well preserved and the tour provided listeners with a detailed overview of the owner, Jim Thompson and his tragic disappearance, the construction of his home, the silk trade and the antiques preserved in the home. A restaurant and store which sold a variety of silk products were on the site. Tour groups were a good size and the guide had a good command of English. Photographs were not allowed within the home but could be taken outside.The tour will give you an opportunity to learn a great deal about the role that Jim Thompson played in the rejuvenation of the Thai silk industry! The silk products available for purchase were of a very high quality. I recommend this attraction!

Still a peaceful venue. I have been before , you are more restricted and guided now than in years past but it is still a great place to see. The house you tour round is so lovely as are the ornaments in it. It is amazing how cool and calm it feels inside.
Really good visit. Lovely old house built by the silk baron. Tour is informative and fun. Really good store attached to the house and restuarant is really good too!

What a surprise. I didn't expect much but we visited the Jim Thompson House as it was very close to our hotel and we wanted to fill in half a day as we had arrived at lunchtime. Beautiful old place. Wonderful tour guide that was very fluent in English and she managed to convey everything to us wonderfully. Lots of things to look at here and learn about traditional Thai living Though I suspect this traditional house would have to have been for the affluent Thais. I especially loved looking at the Silk Weaver who was happy to answer any questions. There also was a Thai dancer I. think depending on what time you go depends on what performances are there, with the exception of the weaver. I think he is always there.

Good for tourist to visualize Thai life years ago. Great to see the local architecture (old style thai house), chinese pottery, serene garden.. You can explore the first level by yourself, but to entering second level of the house you need to join the tour.. This tour inclusive in admission cost.. My group tour leader is quiet funny and speaks english fluently
Nice museum. I love this museum, coz i can learn how to make silk from cocoon. Very traditional method so make me very appreciate for silk.

Beautiful house to live in. The tour is quite short and enjoyable starting with a stroll in the garden. The displays are interesting especially the mouse doll house. You cant take pictures inside the house. It can get a little warm in the house during the afternoon.
Shuttle is provided to go to the nearest BTS.

More than i expected. I did not have must expecations for this as it was booked in advance for us....
It is a great visitor attraction about the life of Jim Thompson.. The staff are well informed and polite...

Great shopping for silk at reasonable price.. Please note that not all items are made of silk. Some are of cotton.
Great variety of silk items though and I was in there for almost an hour choosing gifts for friends and family.
Nothing fancy. Nothing much to see here and its not worth it. The tour by the guide was boring and it takes half hour to see the house, nothing special.

Worth a Visit. Include this one on your tour. We walked however it was very hot so maybe a tuktuk. Tours are organised from the area. They are wall organised an timely. Good quality Tee Shirts in the shop. Machine wash well.
Beautiful Garden. Tour of the house and grounds well organized and informational. The surrounding gardens are beautiful. Plan to have lunch in the restaurant. DELICIOUS!!!!!

An oasis in the middle of the city. A very nice place to visit close to the shopping area and skytrain station. Only a short distance walk. The guide showing the group around was inspiring and kept the visitors attention. A wonderful selection of artifacts in a real home environment - not just showcases in a museum.The architecture, plants and even the frogs in the pond were nice! Shop and café a bit too expensive.

a bit hot, but worth it!. The house is so well-maintained, and the guides really know a lot about Jim Thompson. It was really fun, and well worth the $200b we spent on admission. Only downside is we went in April, and as the house has no air con, it was unbelievably hot.

worth a visit. A very beautiful home. I enjoyed the tour - it was very informative. I hadnt heard of Jim Thompson before, but was very interested in the history. The house is gorgeous, and interesting to imagine living there years ago.

Jim Thompson was a visionary. If you have any interest in design and aesthetics make sure you go to the Jim Thompson House. It is a very interesting tour, and a beautiful place to spend time.He had so much style and was such a clever businessman. The interior of his home could be taken from the pages of a top design magazine today, however they are about 50 years old. True style never fades.

Don't miss this piece of history!. This compound in Bangkok is a must see for those wanting a look in the past. The setting is very soothing and the house he created using his architectural skills is brilliant. The art collection is fantastic and tour was very informative. Lovely guide.If you are interested in how the Thai Silk industry was taken to the rest of the world do visit. Get there on opening for a relaxed visit.
Right Man, Right Place at The Right Time. Jimj Thompson's story is worth knowing. An educated man with spirit and an opportunity. The place is beautiful and the story worthy of a latter day Kipling.

Jim's place. I'd never heard of Jim Thompson before we went to Bangkok, yet so many people said "you must go to Jim Thompson House"...and you know what? You must.Historically this tells a story. A fascinating story of an American man who changed the future of the Thai silk industry. Culturally it's a masterpiece of Thai architecture and furnishing.The garden is an oasis in the middle of the city.Just a few hundred metres walk from National Stadium skytrain stop, it's easy to get to.Our guide (compulsory & included in the ticket price) had great English & was very knowledgeable.Well worth the visit.

A lovely spot in Bangkok. The Jim Thompson House is a wonderful place to visit while in Bangkok. Thompson was an American who relocated to Bangkok and was active in reviving the silk industry there. His story is very interesting. His home is beautiful, filled with incredible art work. The gardens are lush and lovely.
silk paradise. Just go there and look around. The JT house is beautiful and worth a visit. The shops is good fun. They also serve good quality food.

Fun tour, great food and good shopping. We spent a couple of hours here taking the house, tour, having lunch and purchasing some items. The tour itself is very cheap and only takes about 45 minutes but seems to fly by. The tours are timed so we had to wait 20 minutes. We visited the JT Store while we waited. I noticed they did not sell any postcards or a book with photos of the house which seemed odd since photos of the interior of the house are not allowed. I picked out some items to purchase and then had the store hold them while we went on our tour. Our guide was excellent and very bubbly. We put our purses and any bags in little wooden lockers. During the tour it is hard to tell where one building ended and another one began. Mr. Thompson was a very talented designer and had exquisite taste. I did snap a couple photos even being trailed by a young man who did not report me! The simplicity and elegance of the house was surprising. Following the tour I went back to the store and made my purchases. I bought some pillow covers, 2 scarves and little silk boxes that snap together. I had visited the Jim Thompson store in Singapore a few days before and thought they had a better selection of some items. However, the main store where the house is certainly was larger and had tons of items. Lastly, we had lunch which was good and reasonably priced. The restaurant is open but it was not hot inside and was very pleasant. To leave the JT House you can take their transportation to the Skytrain, a taxi or a tuk tuk. I had been advised not to take a tuk tuk in Bangkok but he was parked right in front and the men working at the building said it was fine and safe. Our hotel was very close and near the Siam Paragon. The tuk tuk was fun and it only took about 7 minutes to get back to our hotel.

Interesting. Although very difficult to find on your own as few people in the area spoke English and they kept pointing us to the Jim Thompson stores, we eventually made our way there. The tour was our fist showing silk production so we found it very interesting. His home was quite beautiful and the stories of his life led me to do further research on the man.

Interesting but not mandatory. Getting to the museum was easy through train with plenty of signs to guide you. The museum itself was interesting. You must have a tour guide with you which was cheap. Our guide however had a thick accent and was hard to understand at times. But it was enough to get the gist. The tour was fast too, so it's perfect if you just want to glide to the next attraction. It's just nice to see the Jim Thompson brand around the world and be able to say you've been to his house. Plus, our toddler loved playing in the courtyard and watching the fish in the pond.

An informative and inspiring hour or so. We found this to be a very enjoyable hour or so – the actual tour takes about 50 minutes. In fact we wished we’d allowed some extra time just to walk the grounds and take it all in after our official tour was over.We learned little about how the silk trade worked but a lot about the amazing Jim Thompson who, single handed, created the industry that exists today. We enjoyed walking through this huge visual aid as our guide told the story and answered our questions with ease.An unexpected bonus was the insights into Buddhism, the dominant religion of Thailand, that sprang from the context of the tour. It was a particular relief to be assured that spirits can only travel in straight lines. And interesting that those who find a gecko lizard in their home believe it is one of their ancestors. The Jim Thompson House is easy to reach on the BTS and is easy to combine with a visit to the massive MBK shopping centre that is almost next door.

Quick, pretty, inexpensive, friendly tour - recommend it. I didn't know what to expect, so this exceeded my expectations. The tour is very cheap (100 baht or so), and the tour guides are great. The house itself is simply lovely, and it's a great way to spend an hour in Bangkok. The tour went by very quickly. Young children might be bored, but older children (and adults) would probably like this. The art and other pieces in the house are original and beautifully presented. It's like visiting a museum, but somehow much more fun seeing the pieces in a house.
Great short Tour. Thoroughly enjoyed the informative short tour of Jim Thompson Museum, a peace of paradise in the middle of the city. Well worth it the quality o the merchandise is beautiful.

Dream house .... You should take time to visit Jim Thompson house. It's right by MBK so if you are in the area why not stop by. The guided visit is only 45 minutes which seems more like 15 minutes because you will find this visit surprisingly interesting. You can take the visit in many different languages (amongst them French and English). It's very educational and the house and garden are very beautiful! If you can try to get there by long-tail boat; It enhances the experience.

Lovely museum. Jim Thompsons House is an oasis and a fantastic insight in the Thai culture which has sadly nearly disappeared. Do yourself a favour and have lunch in the restaurant. Food is great and views better.
A Must See!. The house itself and story of Jim Thompson are quite remarkable. The store on site has some lovely silk items. Though pricey, the quality is very good.
Not all that great. We went here as this being our 4th visit to bangkok we hadn't been here...... Not a great attraction = won't go again. Not good for young children.

A quiet sanctuary in busy Bangkok. Almost as soon as you enter the grounds a sort of quiet comes over you. That is no small feat, considering you come from one of the busiest shopping areas in Bangkok. But the beautiful layout of the house with it's added restaurant and silk shop is secluded and peaceful. The tour of the house costs admission, but is well worth it, to see some of the incredible antiques collected. The house itself is a merging of four wood houses transported from other regions and it is amazing with which architectural feeling Thompson created one house from them. The garden, which you can visit before or after the guided tour of the house features interesting silk related exhibits, such as live worms and cocoons, a loom and also a demonstration of silk thread collection.

Relaxing and rewarding. I am not one for guided tours, but the entrance fee for the Jim Thompson house includes a 40 mins tour which is great. The place is an escape from the noise and heat of Bangkok - you really feel as if you are in remote village area. There is a great restaurant and the gardens and buildings are amazing. Well worth a visit.

Art in a domestic setting. I love art that is displayed in a residential setting and find many art galleries and museums a little sterile. the house is actually a collection of buildings and the small complex almost creates typical Thai village atmosphere. Guided tours (in various languages) are compulsory and well worth the 100 BHT fee. There's also a good restaurant attached, serving Thai and European dishes.

Histrory of Jim Thompson House !. you will not disappointed to visit the old pharang house faced to the river. the atmosphere in the middle of crowded will tell you something about Mr. Thompson. the lady guide speak very good English and detailed about the history and make you surprise about business and his wooden house.

Pretty interesting and beautiful place. The guided tour (40') is very interesting and the whole place with its houses, interior and items would not be understood as such without the enthusiastic local guide. Atmospheric place which tells quite something about Mr Thompson but also about the time in which he lived in. Just next to the muslimic quartier of Bangkok. I recommend early morning, before the place gets too busy. Take anti-mosquito lotion with you.

Interesting but not amazing. I thought this place was quite interesting. You can only enter on a tour but it wasn't too expensive. The guide was very nice and provided alot of insight into the man and the architecture. We also had a bite to eat in the restaurant which suprisingly was really really nice and not too expensive - normally restaurants at toursit attractions can be rubbish and expensive but this one was great. The place was like a little calm oasis in Bangkok so we really enjoyed it.

Oasis in Bangkok. Good straightforward place to eat with a wide variety of food at a good price. The shop is competitive when compared to the airport or shop in Raffles Singapore. Not too impressed with the tour with too many restrictions & too few facts re his life.

Hidden treasure. Love this place & love bringing friends here, it's such a different slice of Bangkok. Serene gardens, a lovely story, antiques & heritage, it's all here & well worth the 100 baht entry. There's a new cafe that looks good - next time!

Worth a visit. Very enjoyable tour. It also gives one some knowledge of Thai culture. They have shuttle service to the station but we actually didn't know about this until we got there. They have a restaurant and the mango and rice cake was deliciousl.

Oasis in Bangkok with an interesting tale to hear..... Jim Thompson's house in Bangkok is definitely worthy of your time. It is a fascinating and peaceful place right in the middle of the city. An older home that was built in the old way and out of some absolutely beautiful woods. During the tour they tell you the tale of an American ex-pat who is credited with reviving the silk industry in Thailand. On the way in the door we were greeted by traditional dancers, music and a person spinning silk. If you have the time, go to Jim Thompson House...
Загадочное жилье загадочного человека. Must see. Very old colonial house with real interior and private collectibles of famous person who disappeared in mysterious circumstances.

don't go unless you have time to spare. The only thing I liked about this was a very tranquil restaurant to unwind after the heat which is located next to a karp pool. The house itself, although made of teak & only if you are very interested in silk production, is not worth the long walk to get to it - it's rather off the main tourist route

Interesting. The house itself is beautiful and the construction is very interesting. The back story is intriguing as well. The gardens are luch and inviting. It seems like a small oasis in the middle of a crazy city.

peaceful and interesting. love this place very relaxing and good place to eat, the Jim Thompson story is fascinating, house is amazing, garden small but fantastic.. plus learn about silk and there is a traditional thai dancer who performs from time to time

Very Informative. The tour conducted (in English) was very informative and also very clear...a place that's rather interesting....make it one of "the" place to visit should you have time...BTS service is nearby and it's best visted in the mornings or early afternoons.....best to view the suroundings at this time. There's a restaurant within the house, we did not know as we went after lunch elsewhere.....had a look at the menu...was a lot of their local authentic choices...will give it a try the next time around....Not a place for children as they may not enjoy the historical side of things....a lot to soak in the architecture, the artifacts, the setting of the house etc etc...Did I enjoy it? Absolutely!

Flavour of the East. Jim Thompson's House is worth the detour. The idea of a wooden structure in the tropics is as beautiful as attractive. Thompson must have been a man of impecable taste. To our surprise, the store had a wide variety of silks and fabrics, and many of them at reasonable prices. We definitely recommend a vist.

Beautiful house, but underwhelming tour. After reading about Jim Thompson's history, I thought it would be great to visit his house and learn more about his life. The grounds were beautiful, especially his main house. That said, the tour was underwhelming. I already knew the information about Thompson's life. Also, while the Thompson's art collection was nice, I'm not sure if it merited a tour of his house. I would have rather spent time at an museum to see examples of Thai and Chinese art and pottery. Also, skip the gift shop, because there are outposts of Jim Thompson at the Bangkok Airport (duty free as well).

If you like tropical architecture, you'll love the Jim Thompson house.. We've been coming here for years and the place just gets better. Even the restaurant isn't bad for a tourist spot. Sit next to the Koi pond if you don't require A/C. Tropical, lush and always a great Bangkok stop.

Authentic East West history. Well paced 45 minute tours of these traditional Thai houses with delightful guides are included in the entrance fee. Beautiful setting with free shuttle from nearby BTS National Stadium. Good, well-priced Thai food in restaurant. I enjoyed prawn green curry (as it was my first trip to Thailand I realised that the green curry I have back home in LDN is also pretty good!) my partner had lovely open tacos with fresh salad and fried snapper fish. Later catch the canal narrow boat back to the river for a fast fun trip!

Oasis in the heart of the city. I always like coming back to the Jim Thompson House as it is so tranquil, beautifully designed and filled with impressive art related to silk making.Taking the tour is very informative and you only get to enter certain rooms with this tour. Always very impressed.

A cool escape in the heart of the city.... Located very close to the Siam Central area, this was a lovely cool escape in the middle of the day. The tour was informative and it was great to see the design of traditional Thai houses and gardens. Moreover, the gift shop isn't to be missed.

Polished tour in different languages. You wait for your time slot which depends on the language of tour you want. The guides take you around the house and tell you some fascinating stories of the architecture and Jim's life. The house is beautifully preserved. Though bear in mind you can't wander freely and tours are obligatory and cater for the tourist. There is the obvious gift shop and restaurant on site as well as a small museum. But I would like to have seen more demos of silk making and less merchandising personally. Worth saying that my husband really liked the whole experience though.

As many have said, a peaceful oasis. A very mellow tour with some very interesting artifacts. Our tour guide (mandatory) was not great which made it a little less interesting. Worth a visit and the other attractions in the area make it a day.

Beautiful traditional Thai architecture. I love the Thai architecture and this doesn't disappoint! The tour is only about 30 minutes however you can wonder around or have a drink by the coy carp pond. It will not take up too much of your day but a must see whilst in Bangkok!
Cool place. Mr Thompson mysteriously disappeared and left behind this rather cool wooden-framed villa with a lovely garden and impressive art collection.
A peaceful oasis. Quiet break from the madness of Bangkok. Calm and serene. Great guides and lovely cafe. Recommended.

Absolute Serenity In The Heart Of Bangkok. Before you go, and you must go, read about Jim Thompson (suggest Wikipedia), and you will get a better feeling about his house and why he built it. The house, now surrounded by high rise buildings, is so peaceful it is hard to believe. The internal workmanship and works of art he collected are beautiful, and the house has been superbly maintained in his memory. If you are near Siam Square, and have a couple of hours available then go and experience his house, and for whatever reason you will never forget him, his house, and the Thai silk industry.

house of silk. if you are into silk and bkk past.take a visit to jim thompsons house.it sells silk and has many photos round the house of old bkk.not many house left like this in modern bkk,so you can see what the old houses of bkk looked liked.put that on your list of things to see in bkk if you like silks aor looking at bkk past

Well worth a visit. We loved it and so did our 8 and 4 year old daughters. It was a very hot afternoon and the lemon juice before the visit started is highly recommended! The Thai guide spoke good French and she was very sweet. A bit short on her explanation but I am guessing it's a language barrier. Only need two hours total including the compulsory visit to the shop which has a very nice selection of gifts and objects. Made us want to know more about the man and the silk trade as well!

What a fantastic place. This guy was way ahead of his time and did Thailand a big favour by saving the silk industry. His forethinking behaviour was brilliant and I am so pleased that he had the presence of mind to make a will and leave his home to the people of Thailand as a museum. It would have been fantastic to live in such a place as he did back then and he is sadly missed. Reading about his life I can't help but feel that the CIA had something to do with his demise, but there again he coukd have just been eaten by a tiger!

Interesting, but a bit rushed. Guide's English could be better, but an interesting site. Certainly a glimpse into the re-awakening of the Thai silk industry and the impact that one person can make in the world. The house is beautiful and you can clearly see Mr. Thompson's love of Thai culture.

Superb design- inspiring!. This visit was a high point for me, my husband & our 14 year old son. What an incredible man Thompson was- a gifted US architect who fell in love with Thailand and its people and who revived the Thai silk trade. He built his home from 6 teak houses he found in Thailand, dismantled and brought on site. The layout is wonderful, the design detail amazing and the use of colour perfect. Obviously I'm a huge fan- the house had a profound impact on us all. Don't forget to buy a silk scarf or any other item from the store before you leave the property. The Jim Thompson House is a must on your priority To See list for Bangkok!
Jim Thompson House. Easy to find in Bangkok, rail transport and a short walk.Lovely museum of old style Thai house, beautiful garden and a peacful retreat from busy Bangkok

Great Educational Historical Outing. Learned a great deal about Jim Thompson and his importance to Thailand. His house was architecturally very interesting. The information about silk production was fascinating.

James Bond abode in Thailand. This is the home of an American Spy who lived in Bangkok. He built an exceptional house with great artifacts. All important people visited him there. His body and death was never confirmed which makes one believe he was a spy when killed.

Authentic Thailand in amidst the hub bub of the city.. Easy to get to from the Sky Train stop. Beautiful setting of Thai houses re erected by Jim Thompson in a tropical garden with trees, plants and ponds next to a canal. Thai lady dancing to music, another spinning silk and a man unravelling silk cocoons. Very peaceful and a lovely restaurant to cool off in with a cold drink or meal. Tour of Jim Thompson's actual house very interesting and not expensive.

relatively interesting..... I've been here twice most recently in 3/2013.It's a bit tricky to find but worth the walk.The restaurant though is nice is 100% for tourists and more authentic and better priced food can be had elsewhere.... The story of Thompson and the quality of products he inspired is indeed a nice thing to see.The museum is interesting to see....Overall maybe worth 2-3 hours max.Be sure to watch the thai dancing if you're lucky enough to be there then as it's very up front and close which is nice to experience.
So interesting, quick aside. Take a hour to visit this beautiful house in the middle of busy Bangkok. We had a superb English speaking tour guide.

Don't miss this Bangkok landmark. This is a must see on any visit to Bangkok. The Jim Thompson story is so interesting. The house should be on everyone's list. There are several stores around BKK selling gorgeous silk and silk blend items to be treasured forever. There is an outlet store on Soi 93 where better prices can be found. Once a year there is a big sale at one of the local arenas - something to look out for. Even at regular retail, Jim Thompson stores offer real quality items to be treasured forever.

Beautiful place. During two days in Bangkok we explored the surroundings and also shopped at Jim Thompson House. They offer exquisite silk products and the art and furnishings in the house were so beautiful.

Okay if you have a spare hour. Visit predominantly offers tours of the houses at the site which were transferred there by him and furnished in the style he liked. Interesting, but in my view not a Bangkok " must".
Don't go to Bangkok without seeing this place!. Lovely gardens, wonderful house(s) and fascinating history, as well as first-rate textiles for sale.

Glimpse into the silk magnate's life and history. Beautiful teak home with an amazing collection of art, collected until his mysterious disappearance. Well done tour and gorgeous museum shop. Very enjoyable experience.

Educational Visit. It was a place of history. If you know what he stood for before he was so well known then you will understand the respect of his lasting influences on fashion/fabrics and the people of the area.

Well worth a visit. A great place to visit for many reasons.. the historical aspect, the beautiful traditioanl Thai House.. the guided tours are only about 30 minutes long so you dont get bored or too hot. Also great if you are pushed for time but want to see something of interest. The admission fee is very cheap (only 200 baht per person which is about 4euro),

revival of silk industry. Interesting architecture and story of Jim Thompson who, after the second world war, devoted himself to reviving the craft of hand weaving silk. There are demonstrations of the techniques, tools and finished product - available to purchase of course.

Good place for quality stuff. Many braches now in BKK selling quality silk and Thai artifacts. Service is always good and friendly. Prices are on the high side but this is what you would expect. Worth checking the place out.

Great respite from busy Bangkok. I spent couple hours here to visit and also dine with mum. This was my second visit and first for mom. The food was for Western taste buds but still well presented with good ingredients. The tour itself is not too long but just enough so that you won't melt away in the heat. the house itself is lovely and one of a kind. Highly recommend!

Great morning visit. Arrived mid-morning and loved visiting the small garden before the start of the tour. Wished there had been even even more information on some of the beautiful art and furnishings. Maybe a brochure. Great to see insde a traditional Thai house and garden. Had lunch on the patio of the restuarant then enjoyed seeing the Thai dancers and the weaver demonstration.
Touristy but worth it. We did not manage to find it on a previous visit but this time we succeeded, and it was worth it; great to see a "historic" site such as the Jim Thompson House

What's so special?. We went here after reading reviews on Tripadvisor and also because the hotel concierge said that there it has a lot of Thai silk items. Frankly, we were disappointed. Yes, the houses are traditional Thai. yes, they are filled with artefacts. Yes, it is nicely maintained. yes, you get a guided tour of 30 odd minutes. But is worth the time and effort? Is it unique? Is it unusual? In my opinion, NO.So I wouldn't go there again. What I mean by that is while I would go to Wat Arun or Wat Pho or the Grand Palace again, there is nothing in the Jim Thompson house that will me attract me again.We were also disappointed by the merchandise in the shop. It was nothing but a shop that you can find anywhere - there was no exclusivity of the merchandise either in terms of design, styles or even origin - items were not exclusively of silk or Thai . We saw made in India, China labels.Sadly, to us, even the quality could have been better. Sorry - but we had seen some really lovely silk stuff at Artisan's de Angkor in Siem Reap 3 days ago and this was nothing in comparison. So in my book - there is nothing special here.P.S. We asked to spend more time in the houses to get a closer look at the artefacts but were told that it could only be done with a guide - and guide were in short supply. So we simply left.

Enjoyable!!!!. This was a very enjoyable experience and it was not too pricy if you are a child it will be 50 bhat and adults are 100 baht, there is a guides tour which you have to take, the tour guide is very friendly, and the story of how Jim Thompson went to the Cameron Islands in Malaysia is very interesting, and how he took a walk and was never seen again and was pronounced dead after being missing for a long time, the story is amazing but believable, also how he introduced Thai Silk to the Americans.

Old Bangkok with history. The Jim Thompson story is a real mystery but you can imagine what it was like when he lived there. The rooms even in their older minimalist style are very well designed and in their own way very comfortable. The cafe and restaurants are well worth visiting, especially booking an outside table...delightful.

Unmissable. This is an excellent place to visit in Bangkok. The house is incredible, though not quite as incredible as Jim's story.
You got a real feel of Jim's love of Thailand.
The garden was a thrill and there was a silk spinner in the courtyard.
Great value at 100 baht

Nice and crowded short visit. The visit was really nice though the small area was very crowded. The tour was professional. Quite crazy: the guide allowed us to bring the cameras inside but then you are not allowed to take pictures!?

one of the gems of BKK. Been numerous times (a must for all my visitors) and always enjoyable--tour is not too long but gives a unique experience of a place, time and perspective. Lovely houses, garden, and art collection. Restaurant is also very good and in a great setting. Highly recommended.
A bit of old Bangkok. Jim Thompson was an amazing man. He floated 3 separate homes down the canal and merged the three to create a comfortable home. We worth a visit.

Nice short visit to learn about Jim Thompson House...... Been to Bangkok umpteen times but never had a chance to visit the museum. No regrets for visiting the house , only if you have extra time to spare. The tour is conducted very professionally but I like the Jim Thompson restaurant better, nice place to chill out for a drink after a hot tour.

Amazing. Don't think twice. Spend a morning here. It's a great place to visit. The location is close to the shopping Mecca of Siam but a really quiet oasis. There is a guided tour but the guides are very knowledgeable and attentive. You need a second mortgage to buy silks in the shop however!
considered expensive by some but very reasonable by international standards. high quality merchandise with a distinctive style. great place to stock up on all the shawls you will ever need.
Nice short visit. The visit was really nice. The tour was professional. Pity it is not allowed to take pictures inside the house.

Interesting but not worth the waste of time. Yes no doubt this place has an interesting history, however had the guy not disappeared in 1967 then this place would be like the many more thousands of homes just like it dotted around Thailand. It is well preserved but very boring to be honest. There are far more interesting things to visit in Bangkok to be fair and most people are only passing through for a few days. My daughter nearly fell asleep. Best thing for us was to make an escape without the tour guid noticing!!

Interest to visit, but should be low on your list. Unless you're in Bangkok for five or six days, this attraction shouldn't be a priority on your list of places to see. While very clean, and filled with beautiful Thai art, it is basically a series of traditional Thai houses that Mr. Thompson combined to make a more western type dwelling. His story is interesting enough, and it is probably worth the price of admission, which is pretty cheap, but only if you're in the neighbourhood (an easy walk from MBK mall), or if you have an interest in the history of Thai silk. The store does have beautiful pieces, and is nicely air-conditioned, which is great, because there is not much air circulation on the grounds. One thing that I must compliment this place on is the availability of multilingual tours, at no additional charge. Nice to see that they have made the effort to accommodate as many people as possible. Also, the place is spotless, including the public bathrooms. There is also a nice restaurant on the grounds. We didn't try it, but the menu looked interesting.
Jim Thompson house. Well worth a visit to see how the houses once looked - added bonus is it is across the road from MBK - shop till you drop after getting your fill of culture - good mix!

After a hectic day in crowded Bangkok, this is an oasis I like to go and get a peaceful drink. I like to go and see what new exhibition they have. And have a drink at their cafe. Next week I'll take my friends who are going to Bangkok for the first time
Very well run museum. Very informative and quite an intriging place. He has lots of artifacts and an amazing collection of statues and other things.
Nice. Nice place to spend 1 or 2 hours. Canal boat pier is just 200m away, so you can return to city with a cheap and fun canal boat trip.

Nice place to relax. We had a quick lunch there and visit the house. Heaven of peace in the hustle and bustle Bangkok. A must see. Shop also have wonderful items at not so wonderful price. But so nice...

Spend some time in old Bangkok. This home and gardens are completely surrounded by skyscapers. However, once you walk into the garden, you are transported to another time. The place is always busy but you will not be hassled.The gardens are simply beautiful and can be wandered at your leisure. Do visit each of the small huts to see some exquisite art. The entire setting was designed by Mr Thompson to celebrate Thai art and architecture with his own person stamp. It is unique, though not necessarily, the most authentic example.The tour of the house is guided and takes about 40 minutes. If you have any interest in art and Thailand, you will love it. Jim Thompson knew what to collect and how to display it. The stories behind the pieces are worth the price of admission.This place is a must see and I will definitely visit it again. Enjoy.

Great examples of old Thai houses. Great side trip. Takes about two hours. The houses are interesting and you learn a lot about traditional Thai architecture and tradition. Of course, the story of Jim Thompson is also fascinating. You can buy the book Unsolved Mystery about Jim Thompson in their book store.

Nice but very busy.. We went here on our last day as we didn't want to spend it walking around the many shopping malls and we had already done several Temples.Unfortunately we went to this on the one of the hottest days in Bangkok! However a Jim Thompson Tut Tut will collect you from the end of the road and take you to the house for free. Entrance fee is only 100bht per person and you get a guide to tell you all about Jim.I have to say that the house and grounds are very nice, however I didn't leave thinking "Im glad I did that"..

Art and Architecture. I've been an admirer of Jim Thompson's exquisite taste in his putting together his esoteric teak timber framed house made up of 5 or so 300 year old traditional Thai houses he purchased and dismantled in Ayutthaya and moved down to BKK to rebuild in his own design when the city was still a provincial backwater town back in the late 50's. He also had great taste in collecting various art and artefacts of Thailand well before they became in vogue later on. He didn't have to tread the minefield of proliferated fakes that now dominate Bangkok's antique market. Beware River City you are warned.The guided tour is very well done with very charming hostesses. Kind of like a small version of Hearst Castle Thai style. This man had taste and class. Too bad he disappeared in 67 never to be seen again. But the house remains and it is one of Bangkok's treasures.

An oasis of tranquility amidst the hussle and bussle of Bangkok. We visited this place last year with my two boys who were 9 and 10 at the time. The guided tour was compulsory but was interesting and not overlong. The house and surrounding tropical garden was beautiful and so peaceful we could have stayed longer had the children not got restless for more excitement.

A gem within Bangkok. Jim Thompson House is a must see if you're interested in a bit of history regarding the Thai silk industry. The tours were very informative and the home and grounds are beautiful. There is also an art gallery upstairs above the store selling Thai silk. This is the closest you can get to a traditional Thai living experience. The only problem we had was that the taxis had no idea where Jim Thompson House was located. We had to stop at least four taxis before finding one that said they knew where to go.
Nice backyard. Nice houses in a nice garden, interesting history, good service and well organized guiding. Cheap. I can very well imagine that Jim Thomson fall in love with this place.
Great little attraction. Nice little oasis in the middle of the city.Well worth a visit. The guide we had was charming and entertaining.
A place to return to.. A haven in busy Bangkok, the well-run museum boasts a wonderful restaurant. A bit pricey, but every baht is worth it.

Always Great. Have been here about six times now as I always take first timers to Bangkok to see it. Doesn't matter to me as I always thoroughly enjoy the atmosphere and as an added bonus we catch the Canal Taxi from the back door for a ride on the LAST WORKING CANAL SYSTEM

Oasis. Hidden oasis of calm in the big city! A must visit to see a traditional style Thai house and gardens, the restaurant was great too and good value. Tour guide very knowledgeable and many historic artefacts on display.

Interesting and calm. A visit here entails paying the cheap entrance price (i believe it was 100 THB/person) and getting a tour through the house with an English or French speaking guide. It was a very calming hour, and the food in the attached restaurant was not too overpriced, and very tasty.

You may want one. Our tour guide had stilted English so her scripted jokes ran out without much of a punchline, but going around the house and learning somethings about Thai silk, and the mysterious Jim himself were good. I just wanted a house like this at the end - every Westerners dream of a paradise city house in Asia.

Teak House in old Thai style. Jim Thompson was an American who loved Thailand and revitalised the Thai silk industry when nobody was interested. He had a Thai teak house shipped down from Northern Thailand and filled it with Buddha images, antiques and other artifacts. This is now a museum which is well worth a visit if you have a spare couple of hours in Bangkok. The museum has some nice gardens and there are regular tours in a variety of languages (you are not allowed to tour the house independantly as the exhibits are valuable). We were lucky to visit on Jim Thompson's birthday (he disappeared in Malaysia in the 1960s) and the staff had put an amazing fruit and vegatable display in the grounds in his honour). If you do want to visit to the Skytrain to the National Stadium and the signposts in the station will tell you which exit to take. The house is about 600 yards from the station and be sure to ignore the people on the end of the Soi who tell you the house is closed but they can take you shopping. The house should not be confused with Jim Thompson silk shops as, if you catch a taxi or a tuk-tuk, you are likely to be whisked away to the shop, where the taxi driver may get commission, rather than the house.

A break from bustling city of BKK. You can reach via National Stadium stop (silom line) of Skytrain. Walk down the exit and if you can see a shuttle tram with JIm Thompson name just hop on it as its a free shuttle service to the house.Its is nice place to relax and walk through old times.Guided tours are available in different languages,it costs 80baht per person ( i think ). Before the tour starts you are provided with lockers to store your belongings like camera and bags,no photography inside the house.Have to take off your shoes too just before entering the main house.There is a nice small garden,a resturant and Jim Thompson silk shop.I enjoyed my visit.

It´s cool and relaxing, but not really a must see.... I wouldn't consider it a priority during a visit to Bangkok, but if you have plenty of time, it's worth going there. The atmosphere is great and the whole place is very well maintained, but it can get a bit boring after one hour in there.

Mind blowing. This guy was really avant-garde--what a design master. I always knew that he was talented in the realm of textile production and design, but I had no idea he was such a resourceful decorator and designer. The house will take your breath away and fill you with inspiration. Definitely pay for the tour--the guides are very professional. You can't take photos inside, but there are books for sale, which we bought. You'll love the shop, and you'll enjoy the little silk-making live tutorials on the property. I also hear there is a shuttle that will take you to a big store. There's an outlet somewhere in Bangkok as well. But the store on the property is fantastic if you just want souvenirs. Enjoy!

Gorgeous trip back in time. Likes: almost everything. Beautiful house, clear descriptions by the guides, pace was good and place well-maintained.Dislikes: Silkworms were falling out of their pans and I was picking them up because I didn't want anyone to squash them. Something must be done to stop them from escaping the pans!!!

Definitely worth a visit.. An oasis of calm amid the madness of Bangkok traffic.The house is set in its own grounds and built in traditional Thai style.Guides show you around the house and explain each room as they go, so makes this all very interesting.We saw a demonstration of silk spinning and weaving.

Interesting history. It's a beautiful traditional Thai house built in teak. The antiques have a good history as well. The American Jim Thompson fell in love with Thailand when sent there in WW11 & returned after leaving the army. He revived the Thai silk industry which is still prosperous today. He disappeared on a trip to Malaysia in 1967, which gives it another kudos. The silk products available in the shop are beautiful, but very expensive.

Loved this place. Can't believe how beautiful this place is great for some garden inspiration, fantastic restaurant ,we had the signatures fish tacos,beef curry ,prawn balls,and mix ape riser plate all really good get there early s it fills up .we had a great foot neck nd shoulder massage on the way back to the station the curtesy tuk tuk dropped us off gold hand massage 200 bht very good .

It's Just a House - a Really Awesome House!. I'm thinking, I come all the way to Thailand to see some American guy's house? Really? But Jim Thompson's house is truly beautiful, and you learn about silk production too. Absolutely recommend it. Also, make sure you stop by the restaurant for a drink or a meal - it's a beautiful spot and very relaxing.

Interesting tour and great place for lunch. Took the BTS to the National Stadium stop and walked a few blocks to the Jim Thompson House. The house and gardens were beautiful and we enjoyed the information on the guided tour. Thought everything was well presented and organized. Had lunch at the restaurant after the tour and the food was good-the menu had both Thai and Western dishes available. As we were leaving the JT House we saw there were motorized carts available to take people to the corner where the train station was located. Not sure why we didn't notice them when we arrived at that corner on the way to the House, but it was a nice treat to get a ride.

Historic House. Step back in time and see how Jim Thampson lived way back when. You feel like you are in another very exotic time. The house is built out of teak and has been restored to a high standard. You could spend quite some hours here enjoying the house and gardens.
Love this place. If you're on holiday in Bangkok .Have been to Flow House Bangkok regularly. I had a great time here, everyone was friendly and smiling and seemed like they enjoyed being there

Jim Thompson House. Take the free tour and it is a good break from the shopping.
The House is beautiful with many interesting artifacts.
My girls who are anti- museum, enjoyed the trip cos the guide was entertaining.
Worth the trip!!

Worth a visit. We enjoyed our visit; do this if you have plenty of time in the city. Not on our "best" list, but enjoyable. Good to know and learn the history of silk in Thailand. An oasis in the city; beautiful and tranquil. Know that you have to be on a tour, will likely have to wait a while for this.
Enjoyable visit.. Nice way to spend an hour out of the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. Only 100 bhat entry with a 35 min tour.

Worth a visit. We travelled by canal taxi and found it easily What a beautiful house Exquisite setting beautiful decor and a very informative tour by a lovely Thai lady The coffee shop was great too fab souvenirs After a 3 week tour of S E Asia it was a little light relief after so many temples and tours of a sombre nature
An Oasis in Bustling City. The houses are beautiful and garden is very nice. The restaurant on the premises has decent food but the ambience is great after going through the tour of the JT House.

Jim Thompson House. Very interesting....but be warned no pictures are allowed inside. No pictures of the flowers outside either. The history behind the house is interesting as is the life of Jim Thompson

Like stepping into some sort of Asian fairy tale. 6 Soi Kasemsan 2, Rama 1 Road, BangkokIf you're coming from the National Stadium Skytrain station try to make sure that you exit on the right hand side of the road. If you find yourself on the same side as the national stadium you're on the wrong side. Don't worry though, there's a footbridge that takes you across the busy road to the otherside. If you exit on the left - national stadium side of the road - be aware that the sign pointing you in the direction of Jim Thompson's House, is misleading and if you follow it you'll end up walking past its location and it will take some time to figure out where it is. The key thing to remember is that it is really not far from the station and is in a road that is almost directly opposite the stadium. It's not sign-posted that well, but if you can spot Soi Kasem Sai 1 you should be able to find Soi Kasem Sai 2 very easily and both streets are just outside the Skytrain exits. If you've been walking for some time you've overshot it.As for the museum itself, it's a definite MUST for any westerner visiting Bangkok. You honestly have never seen such a beautiful home before and you are unlikely to see one like it again. His vast art collection alone is enough to make you drool but the buildings and the garden setting will make you positively green with envy. Honestly, how is it possible for anyone to live in such an enchanted place - it is like stepping into some sort of Asian fairy tale! As you walk in you know you have arrived somewhere very special and in the hurly burly chaos of Bangkok, Jim Thompson's Home is a lush paradise which you are more than happy to lose yourself in. I was there in January and it was busy. But no matter how full it seemed, the feeling of tranquillity and calm that settles over you as you enter the property is something to experience. The tours are conducted in French and English (and possibly other languages too) and there's a cafe and souvenir shop where you can happily stock up on gifts either whilst you're waiting for your tour to begin or once you're done (be careful, you will find it hard to part with these some of these gifts once you return home). You're not allowed to take photos once you're inside the main house but can take them from the outside - you have to choose your moment carefully and be quick as there are constant tours in progress - however there are some exquisit books that have pictures of every nook and cranny of the property and they are well worth buying. The story of his life and disappearance is also fascinating and makes for great aeroplane reading. When I was there they had two young people demonstrating how silk is boiled and 'unravelled' from the cocoons and turned into silk thread, as well as how it is then woven - both picturesque as well as informative. My guide was fluent in telling the story of Jim Thompson's house, but questions wern't fully answered - whether this was due to lack of knowledge or lack of understanding is unclear. Which is another reason why the books are useful as they tend to answer most, if not all, of the questions you are likely to have.All in all it is definitely a tourist destination you should make time to visit.

Interesting little oasis in the city. This is well worth visiting. You walk in to a courtyard and are helped over to the tour area.They had a lady playing traditional Thai music and you sit in a cool area by a pond until your tour guide comes to collect you. You are then shown all over the house which is Thai but with western twists and houses lots of art ifacts. The tour lasts about 40 minutes and then you can wander round the gardens. We had lunch at the restaurant there and it was reasonably prices and very pleasant. This gives you a few hours away from the full on tilt of Bankok mixed with an interesting bit of history.

Shady Respite in the Bustle of Bangkok. Love this place. Jim Thompson was an OSA officer at the end of the war and stayed in Thailand. He was instrumental in the marketing of Thai Silk to the world. He disappeared mysteriously in the Early 1960's. his home is unique and an amazing interpretation by a western architect on traditional Thai homes. The furnishings and art work are amazing.

Really cool tour!!. The Jim Thompson house is kind of hidden in the middle of a crazy part of the city!!! It is a beautiful spot along a little canal with absolutely spectacular gardens! Take the tour of the house and learn some really interesting and fun facts!!

Go for a long lunch. We got there tat 430 in time for the last tour. The tourist crowds were gone , back to their buses and hotels, so we had the place tou ourselves... Wished we had planed to have a late lunch instead of street food in Chinatown! This is a must do if you love interior design and antiques. Jim T had a great eye.

An oasis in the middle of hectic Bangkok. No place to go when you're in a rush; the only way to visit the house is with a guided tour. However, they do provide that in several languages and it didn't seem that anyone's waiting time was very long. When you buy the ticket (that is relatively expensive) they cannot tell you when the next tour in your language will be, so make sure you have the time to sit and wait for a little while. The tour is interesting as is the house. But if you don't enjoy historical houses, obviously, don't bother! Oh, and of course, as you're in Thailand, be prepared to take your shoes off when entering the house! I think it is a shame they didn't go deeper into the architectual aspect of the house and how it compares to 'regular' Thai houses of that time (of which I know nothing!). But all in all an interesting sight to see.

Enchanting Experience. Nestled in the hustle bustle of a crowded neighborhood, this is an oasis of peace, calm and tranquility. Right on the edge of a canal, this is a must visit for the sheer experience of a low key yet imposing residence of the man who revived the silk weaving in Thailand and brought it to the forefront of the world business.
Pleasant afternoon. Enjoyed the tour- lots of neat facts. Loved walking through the old teak house. The cafe has delicious shakes.

Silk in Thailand. If you want to learn about the history of silk weaving and understand what you look at and buy go to this place. Back in time, you see the Asian style that made Thompson fall in love with the country and the craft of silk weaving. A oase in the city. Articles are expensive even thou beautiful. Might you decide at last moment to buy something they also have a shop at the international airport

A welcome Oasis of calm when visiting Bangkok. The Jim Thompson house is just a 5 minute walk from the Siam Square area of Bangkok which is one of the busier shopping areas bursting with traffic, noise, and heat. when you enter the Jim Thompson house you immediately feel a calmness. the grounds have been beautifully maintained and you will be taken on a tour of the house and grounds which display an array of artifacts collected by Mr Thomson. there is also a reasonably priced cafe on the premises which is well worth a visit for lunch or just a drink. it will take 2 hours maximum to see everything, i would recommend googling Jim Thompson before you go as his story is quite interesting.

Touristy but interesting.. I'm not a big shopper, so Jim Thompson silk product did not interest me. But since I'm a tourist in BKK, decided to visit JT House. It was located next to river and short walk from National Stadium skytrain station. Cost 100 baht entrance; includes guided tour in English. Story of Jim Thompson and the House are interesting; had silk weaver and traditional dancer at entrance. Has free Tuktuk to Skytrain station. Visit time: 1-2 hours, longer if you want to shop for overpriced but nice silk products.

Love to shop at this shop. Not cheap but really nice things. I always buy too much stuff there. The museum is wonderful and very interesting, never get tired of it. Everytime I go to Bangkok I go to a Jim Thompson store.

Nice way to pass an afternoon. I have to be honest, I had never heard of Jim Thompson but a friend recommended this as something to do in the afternoon since we arrived too late to visit the Grand Palace. This is a beautiful house with a really beautiful garden. The tour was really good. I'm the kind of person who normally skips the tour and wanders around by myself, but the house is only accessible by tour group so I went along. It was actually pretty interesting and the tour leader did a great job. There was lots of beautiful details in the house and some really beautiful artwork to enjoy. I was pleasantly surprised and took some very pretty pictures in the garden. You are not allowed to take pictures in the house and you also have to lock your bag in a locker before going inside. It seemed pretty safe, though, so I don't think there is anything to worry about. There was an attendant there and you are able to lock the locker and take the key with you. You also have to take your shoes off before you go in the house, so you might want to wear socks if you don't like being barefoot in a strange place. All in all this is a nice way to spend an afternoon.

Charming house. The house itsself is a typical Thai architecture example. I was impressed by the plankings of the floor they were extremely long.Well conserved garden. The back side leads to a canal with much traffic.Since J.Th. helped for the development of silk industry in Thailand there is a shop also selling silk and cotton souvenirs of fine quality.Pleasant visit.

Excellent service. We had a lovely time here. The tour is so informative and the guide is very attentive to the numbers of people she's guiding. We went for the lunch at the restaurant and the food is excellent and not to be missed. There's another Thai classical dance at the front hallway is entertaining as well. This place is not to be missed if you happened to drop by bangkok.

Great selection. We loved the attentive yet unobtrusive service, something we do not hget in Switzerland where you are really fortunate to receive service in a shot at all. The prices are reasonable for the qyality. So much choice did not know what to buy, but bought some nice silk ties and my wife boughs some nice scarfs.

Take a tour, stay for dinner. We had such a nice time, we visited twice. We took the very informative tour: be sure to walk around the courtyard on your own. We stayed for dinner, lured by the 2-for-one drink special. Dinner was excellent, and the entertainment (Thai classical dance) was very nice. The staff are very attentive, and the atmosphere is relaxing. Brink mosquito spray if you eat outside: it's near the canal, and there are several water features on property.

A tranquil place amongst the bussle of Bangkok. A quiet place to relax and get away from the Bangkok rush, enjoy the tour, history of the place and JT, tranquil setting for the cafe adjacent to a well stocked pond.Tour was good if a bit short, but you are free to go back and take in more.Shop has lovely fabrics, scarves, clothes etc all in silk, at appropriate western prices!Did not know about the restaurant outside the grounds.
Very nice museum. Very organized tours offered in different languages. The store is also very lovely. I went in the morning and it was great.

Takes you back to the past. Anyone who has read one of the many books about this remarkable man will appreciate his home. Sitting there sipping tea takes you back 50 years to when he was entertaining everyone from celebraties to just about anyone that wanted to enjoy his affable company. you can shop or just look at the amazing array if coloured silk... Then have tea and snacks in this lovely peaceful place.... Imagining you were there sharing with Jim.....

Interesting place. I learned about Jim Thomson and that was intersting story. The wooden building brings calmness and is very soothing. The guide's voice was a bit too quiet/week and the accent was not easy to understand, but was alright. There was a silk making seen and there are silk samples and that was interesting to see. The cafe/restaurant was very relaxing with a pond rignt next to it, but we had some drinks, but the staff was not friendly and even sometimes slightly rude. Anyway, it was good that we went to the place.

Jim's place is worth a visit.. After the frenetic excitement of Siam Square, Jim's place is a calm oasis in the centre of Bangkok. The 100 baht fee gets you into the beautiful grounds where you can see silk spinning and traditional Balinese dance. To view the inside if the buildings you must take a (free) guided tour) which we found quite good. Gardens and koi and tortoise filled ponds were lovely and we enjoyed a very tasty lunch at the restaurant in the gardens. The gift shop was very expensive.
Interesting tour. The house is quite interesting and tour was just the right length. They also have a lovely (not cheap) gift shop.

A Cool Oasis. The house if filled with antiques from Thailand and beyond. The marble floors, ancient, are imported from Italy. No photos may be taken in the house, so buy the book in the gift shop. Stop at the restaurant after the tour for a cool coconut drink before heading back out into bustling Bangkok!
A must to see in Bangkok. If you come in Bangkok for tourism do not miss this place along with the Grand palace. you can buy a visit package including both. A good idea
cheap ticket, artistic and nice tour guide across the house. The shop offers exquisite silk fabrics. The house is very artistic and contains a lot of old days memory.
relaxing retreat. Superb calming atmosphere-difficult to realise it's in the middle of Bangkok. Add in nice restaurant and you have an excellent visitor experience.
Lovely. Lovely oasis in the middle of bangkok, the cafe is great for relaxing drink, and ice cream. Good place to recover on your travels
A great little outing. Nice outing. Very interesting house to visit. Have a drink outside beforehand and sit by side of koi carp pond. Never seen so many colourful koi before. Worth the visit.

Lovely & peaceful - escape from the hustle & bustle. This was a great excursion. There is a free tour, starting every 10 minutes or so, and our guide was great (reading other reviews, it seems it's the luck of the draw). The facts about the architecture, and interior design were all new to me, and really interesting. The house, and contents are actually quite eclectic, and draw upon many Asian cultures. Silk shop was pricey, but there are outlet stores elsewhere in Bangkok if you have time, and if you ask one of the shop assistants she'll give you a map of the outlet stores. Stay for food by the fish pond, another very relaxing experience, and you can get real wine!A lovely and relaxing escape :-)

Over Rated. A nice old typical thai home. The success of the place is due to its name and the relics from J. Thomson. Nothing more. Disappointing. A visit to Jim Tomson shop in Suksawat is more rewarding (might also become more expensive).
