a pleasant couple of hours. Different to most places in Bangkok. When we arrived we booked a tour then had a pleasant lunch in the restaurant. We all enjoyed the tour - the stories were better than some of the exibits!
A pretty trip down the history lane. The tour is short and informative, the house is fascinating in its decor and history. It was a time well spent and an experience thats leaves you smiling.

Beautiful gardens, art and architecture.. I loved the dancers and live silk spinning presentation. This is an exquisite spot and well worth visiting. Do take the tour. It's very interesting learning about the architecture and the man behind this amazing collection of art and buildings.
Pretty. A handsome building with beautiful greenery. A nice respite from the hectic streets and afternoon heat .

Charming spot. Loved the ambiance of Jim Thompson House and the gardens were a delight, its a beautiful Thai house , fully furnished so sympathetically. A great way to get there is by boat on the nearby canel - quite an experience to catch and ride one of the boats
Impressive house. I'm not a fan of organised tours but the best thing is having the chance to walk around the house on your own. I loved the free ride from the main road and back on the golf carts

A nice stop-off if you have the time. This takes you back in time to a wonderful home set in beautiful gardens in the heart of the city with a history behind it. Easy to find, small entrance fee, guided tour (1 hour) with very nice cafe/ restaurant/silk shop on site. Nice, shaded stop if you have time.

Interesting, esp if you're a fashion fan. The house and garden are nice enough, but what I liked best was the silk spinning demonstration, which makes you appreciate just how special silk is!The entry fee includes a compulsorary tour, it's fairly interesting, not very long, and (the English language version) seems to run often.There's a shop on-site, it's very expensive compared to nearby MBK (which has a great selection of skirts and scarves labled as silk which really feel like silk) but that's what you pay to be sure of what you're getting!There's also a cafe on-site, it's okay but nothing special.It's less than 5 mins walk from National Stadium BTS station (which adjoins MBK) but there's a free golf cart transfer if you don't care to walk.

Not to be missed. The Jim Thompson House is a calm, cool, beautiful respite from busy Bangkok. Walk the gardens, enjoy the rich interiors, and be sure to have lunch or dinner while you are there. The food is excellent, as well as their shop full of lovely silk and cotton garments.

Loved seeing this beautifully landscaped house. This was one of our favorite activities in Bangkok. So amazing how Jim Thompson had a vision for reviving the silk, and for creating his home out of 6 authentic wood houses he brought in from a number of places. Lovely lunch here too!

Was not worth the time and money. Nothing here wowed me :( Except for the rat house, that's the first time i saw one of those, quite interesting! I felt sorry for the guide; she was just vomiting out a speech that she seemed to have memorized very hardly :( And it was pathetic to see some actors boiling cocoons to get silk at the entrance. Not worth the time and money.

Quite a story. Thai dancers in the courtyard on arrival, and then allocated to an English-speaking tour guide, who walks through each room explaining the layout and obejet d'art in some detail. The JT story is also told, and is quite facinating. Free trolley service from Nationlal Stadium BTS station.
home sweet home. well designed for the climate, would be very happy to stay there. Obvious he was an architect. Thinking more into the complex because of Jim Thompson fate.

A countryside in Bangkok. This is my 2nd visit. The first one is on Oct 2010 and I took french guide (since I went with 3 friends who's francophone) and this Feb 2013 I took english (since I went with my mum). The great thing is... the price ticket hasn't change!! still 100 bath (This is great since the other places I went this time has rise their price) and there's a golf car that can drive you to the end of the street now. the place is as lovely as before. My mum said she feel like she's in countryside and think of changing my grands' house garden into something like JT house. The house is in great condition despite the age. There are some furniture change but the guide explain that it was always not the original furniture that belong when JT still live there. The artifacts are well maintain, the wood are still very strong. If you can't go to Ayutthaya where JT bought most of his house (he turn 6 houses into 1 connected house), then this place is a must visit. I didn't go to the shop though cos I remember it was very expensive for me.

An oasis in the heart of Bangkok.. Jim Thompson house was very beautiful, I previously didn't know who he was but enjoyed the tour & walking around the grounds of his stunning residence. The tour guide was very knowledgable & they cater to a few different languages to suit everyone. The art & traditional architecture is definitely worth a look even if your not familiar with the man himself.

Just give me one of everything!. The famous Jim Thompson's is better than ever. There are now many locations and don't overlook their outlet; easy to reach on the BTS and has two floors of fabric, though better for upholstery fabrics than for clothing, which is on the 4th floor. The shop in Siam Paragon is wonderful: with very well made cotton T shirts in tempting designs, as well as a large range of items for men, women and children. Not cheap - which is why I mention the outlet!

Nice house, bad tourist trap. Were it not for the low 100 Bhat ($3.33) admission fee, the Jim Thompson House & Museum would be a waste of money. Instead it is a waste of time to get there and to ogle with the hordes.Tours begin every 5 minutes with tourists sorted by language. The problem with that is because there are at least 4 or 5 tours in addition to yours, it is difficult to get pictures of anything other than mobs of tourists blocking the view of the house. Pictures are not allowed in the second (and most interesting) floor but all you would capture are mobs of tourists. Pictures are not allowed in the sale area, not even of the brief sign explaining Thompson's efforts to revive the silk industry (For retribution you can sit on a outside bench and quite well telephoto the inside of the sale area.). There are many more worthwhile ways to spend your time; give Jim Thompson's 100 Bhat to the driver who takes you there.

Interesting. Until visiting there House I knew very little of Jim Thompson and the mystery of his disappearance. It was an amazing visit and his home, which is now a museum, is so peaceful ... Well worth the visit !!
Great experiance. Very interesting tour. Something i never knew exhisted and still wonder what happen to Jim Thompson on his trip to Malaysia, never to be seen again.

Tranquility. Amongst the shopping area near the MBK and Siam Square Jim Thompson's house is a lovely little bit of tranquility. For your 400 THB entrance fee you get a tour of the house and a short introduction to the life of Jim Thompson. The tour isn't too long that you get bored but contains just enough information to make it interesting. There is also a nice restaurant located near the entrance which you can visit without going into the house itself.There is a gift shop at the entrance to the house, again you don't need to pay the 400 THB if you just want to visit the shop/restaurant. There are plenty of other "Jim Thompson" silk stops all over Bangkok and a few in the duty free area of the international airport too, so you don't really need to come here just for the shop.Getting there is easy, either take a taxi, the BTS to National Stadium or you could try a Khlong bus boat to Hua Chang Pier on the Golden Mount line. For the Khlong boats check out http://www.transitbangkok.com/khlong_boats.htmlYou can't take photos inside the house and free lockers are provided to store your bags in during the tour. Shoes must be taken off and stored on shelves. Tip: hold your nose as you deposit/collect your shoes!!!!.

Interesting. There's a guided tour at a stipulated time. We only waited for about 5 minutes. The tour was interesting. However, the tour guide was rather soft. We were required to place all our things in the locker.

really interesting museum. lovely life story to be told of Jim Thompson. Good tour of his house which is really interesting. Usual gift shop on site selling quite expensive silk products (although very beautiful stuff). Walkable from National Stadium skytrain station

Dont miss this.... this will be one of your best visits in Thailand, promise......it's an amazing place and to be honest won't say too much as it will spoil it for you....just be careful when you visit the shop as you'll be sorely tempted to spend too much money as so much lovely stuff..We even loved the coat hangers in the toilets, that's how cool a place it is...( or maybe that's how uncool we are..)The restaurant is nice.....but why do the staff in these places have to be so snooty? You are a waitress, that's it.....it's a tough job we know and respect to you for doing it, but cut the attitude please!

Calm and elegance. This is a beautiful house indeed, built in the traditional Thai manner but also innovating a bit. The interior decoration is wonderful, all in stunning wood and showing a great collection of mainly ceramics.Nice little garden by the khlong.There is also a snack bar that I did not use and two well-stocked shops, where one can buy silk in all forms and shapes. This is not their main store though.A young woman will show you how to spin silk and she will dance every now and than.The way to the house is well indicated as soon as you get out of the BTS station.

Fascinating history and architecture.. Terrific boat ride to get to the house. Short walk from the boat to the house and a short wait for the guided tour. Sadly you're not allowed to take photographs inside, but it was beautiful to see. The restaurant is very very good.

Must See in Bangkok!. This house/museum is definite must on any list of things to see in Bangkok. It is beautiful. Our guide spoke excellent English with a beautiful Thai accent, was very knowledgeable and made the tour very interesting and fun. If you love traditional architecture, furniture, sculpture, pottery, art, beautiful tropical gardens and a bit of mystery you will love this place. Oh and the bathrooms are very beautiful, modern and clean - worth a visit also.

Iconic visitor attraction. Jim Thompson rediscovered Thai silk-making and created a whole industry for the nation. His wooden house is breathtaking, full of antiques and period furniture. Lovely gardens with pools for of koi. All of this surrounded by bustling, towering downtown Bankok.

Go for a fabulous lunch. Take the short tour & shop!. We were tipped off on Tripadvisor to have lunch at Jim Thompson house and to try the smoothies. Great advice on both counts. I believe the lunch I had may well have been one of the best in my life.Jim Thompson house is a wonderful small museum and we enjoyed walking through it with our guide and the rest of our group.Our advice? Spend some time in the gift shop. Wonderful selection of items all made from silk. This is not cheap stuff, but it is not excessively expensive either, and great quality.

Beautiful!. This is such an incredible experience to visit while in Thailand. it's even better when you visit the shop to be able to purchase some of the (although current) silk fashions and accessories for both yourself and your home . The home is just lovely with every element being pure and authentic Thai in sensibility. A must for any visitor to Bangkok.

Wonderful tour, crazy expensive gift shop. It's a little hard to find this place if you're coming on your own but just get off the Skytrain at National Station and look for the small signs. You might even find a little tuk-tuk style golf-cart ferrying visitors back and forth for free. The tour of the house is good--only about 40 minutes long--and very informative. The silk in the gift shop is crazy expensive though, I mean even higher than what you would pay in the west. You can't take pictures inside the house which is too bad--you'll want to--but they have some nice entertainment out front that you can take shots of. This would be a great place to come with family or just on your own. I don't think you need to book a tour to get there, though people will try to convince you otherwise. It really is cheap and easy to get to on your own. Oh, and while the shop is expensive, the tour is only 100 baht per person, roughly $3.

Surprise in a backwater. You don't expect this oasis of interest in this location of roads, shopping complexes and skytrain track, but once there it is like passing back in time. The buildings are well maintained and show how Jim Thompson lived, but is is short on memorabilia. The guides are friendly and the tours frequent. The shop is expensive!

Take the time and Go. I almost skipped this place, and i am so glad that i did not skip it! The tour is very informative and it is definitely worth it. There is even a little golf cart that can help get you from the sky train to the house if you time it right.

Interesting place to visit!. Saw the reviews on TripAdvisor and decided to visit Jim Thompson House as it is not too far from MBK and we thought it will be refreshing change other than shopping and the usual activities that we do in Bangkok. The guided tours are very well delivered and gave us insights into the life of Jim Thompson. Great collection of antiques, a lot of them are very intricate. The house is a museum by itself!

A calm oasis in the centre of Bangkok. Jim Thompson's house is beautiful and a lovely calm oasis in the centre of Bangkok. The history is interesting. Not a place for small children, they would be bored, not even sure if teenagers would appreciate it. We left our teenagers at the hotel pool and enjoyed it child free. Easy to find. Highly recommended.

Great trip and tour.. This was an interesting place to visit and kind of an oasis in the middle of the city. The tour is guided and it reminded me a lot of visiting Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater in PA. Recommended.
Quite interesting. Fun to watch the people here. Thompson must have enjoyed collecting the inside and outside of these houses. His silk is very nice too.

Great Tour. I really liked this tour as they told us details about the house and it was info that carried over to the rest of our trip. It was very informative about a bunch of details about Thai living that we would have been left wondering about during our trip. It was great! Def recommend it if you have time. Quiet and serene setting with the koy ponds. English tours frequently.

Although commerical very worth while. I had always wanted to visit Thompson's House, which has now become basically a museum. The complex consists of his home, a store to sell the lovely silk goods (of course) and a restaurant. The house includes six homes that Thompson, an architect, bought in the late '50s and made into one structure. Although the place has been commercialized to accommodate the number of visitors, it seems calm and agreeable. Tickets for the house tour are sold on a timed basis so there are never too many people walking through his house at one time. There is a shuttle to take visitors the short distance from the MTV Station.

Worth a Visit. I recommend visiting the Jim Thompson House if you visit Bangkok. The tour isn't very long and its easy to get to using public transportation. At first I didn't really want to go because it didn't look interesting to me, but it was nice and my wife loved it. You'll learn a little something about silk and architecture and how they relate to Thailand.

Good Tourist destination. Nice sanctuary away from the chaos of Bangkok. It gets hot here so bring some cool water. Tour is included and is good. Lovely air conditioned restaurant when the tour is over. Shop has all the JT products but is very expensive.

lived up to expectations. The architecture, antiques and beautiful silks made this a worthwhile visit. The guide spoke English clearly and tried to make jokes frequently. The beautiful buildings and the way they're combined in harmony made the tour very enjoyable.

Always beautiful. This was probably my fifth visit to Jim Thompson house. We can't seem to come to Bangkok without visiting. Even when it's busy there is a wonderful serenity about the place. It's worth the trip just to get ideas for the garden. Love the free shuttle service down the road to the BTS.
Excellent. Just a passage back in time with wonderful artifacts. It was rather busy so try to pick a quiet time.
Interesting look at how a rich foriegner lived. Really a museum. Has some fantastic pieces but you are shepherded through with not much time to look. Security very strict and no photos in buldings

It s nice but too busy. It s still one of the place to go in Bangkok but it s sometimes look like a factory! So many people that it s even difficult to hear the tour guide! I recommand to go early morningto avoid this problem and to visit this amazing place Mr Kukrit House on sathorn Soi 3.

Mobbed. This must have been a lovely place back in the day and the small house is quite interesting if you can see it through the hordes from your guided group. Basically it's a large slick gift shop (no Jim Thompson brand cigarette lighters yet but it can only be a matter of time) filled to overflowing with hot tourists and there's no real reason to go there unless it's on your bus tour. However if you are there at lunch time and can get a seat, the restaurant is surprisingly good value for very good Thai food.

A nice getaway. The Jim Thompson House was a nice change from most of the other activities in this part of town (shopping, shopping, and shopping - yawn). The grounds are well kept and beautiful. There's lots of interesting art, and the guide explains most of it pretty well. It was a little hard to understand her accent at first, but after awhile you get used to it and it gets easier. Fascinating story, and I wish we were allowed to take pictures inside the house. In the courtyard, some staff demonstrate how silk is made, and some of the females take a break every once in awhile and do some traditional Thai dancing. There's a restaurant that's not bad for the price, and two gift shops. On is an overpriced shop full of Jim Thompson products. Be sure to check the materials of what you buy because not everything is silk - lots of cotton and manmade fibers, but with the prices, you'd think you were buying silk. The smaller gift shop has a decent selection of cards, postcards, books, and so on and reasonable (for a museum shop) prices.

A oasis of calm. This is a great place for a short visit. Not large, but the house is beautifully laid out. Him was clearly a discerning collector, including collecting the actual rooms of the house from various provinces in Thailand. The gardens, whilst small, are lush and filled with an amazing collection of plants. All in all, a great place to visit.

A nice respite from the big attractions. I enjoyed a quiet and pleasant tour of the Jim Thompson house. It was a nice respite from the bigger, busier attractions of Bangkok. There's a 45 minute tour guided tour of the house and its grounds. You have to take the guided tour which makes perfect sense to me. I'm sure the foundation doesn't want items damaged or stolen. The guide I toured with was good. The information was humorously imparted in an interactive manner. I thought the entry fee (100 baht) was a little expensive. The silk products in the store were way too expensive, but the restaurant was reasonably priced for western food and the food was good. It's a few blocks fromt the subway, but you can get a free ride if you want it. I don't think it's necessary, but it is nice. I recommend it around day 3, or whenever you get 'temple-ed' or 'Bhudda-ed out.'
Yawn. It's along a side turning near MBK. I went there and I thought: "Is this it?" It's tiny and there's little there. What a waste of time.
guided tour only. Nice to see free shuttle from the main street. Could not hear or understand tourguide very well. Had to wait 1/2 hour for our tour. But government run and cheaper than most things.
Great piece of Bangkok business history. This is a place to have rare glimpse how Bangkok was 50 years ago. On a channel, walking distance from Siam. Definitely worth a visit & guided tour.

Beautiful house, not very informative tour. I thought that because a tour was required, that it would provide more information than that I could find on my own on the internet. Although his home was absolutely beautiful, the tour was weak. Our guide was very nice, but she made very lame jokes and told me everything that was on the wikipedia page for the house. Kind of disappointing.

Tranquility among mayhem.. What a lovely place to visit, hard to believe you are right in the centre of one of the worlds major cities. The guided tour was very informative and at time quite light hearted, the guide spoke perfect near English. Very reasonable price for the tour 100thb. We did not eat in the restaurant, only had a drink, but the food being served looked verry good.

Surprisingly worthwhile. A little jaded perhaps, we decided to finally hit Jim Thompson House. What a great surprise. Really really worthwhile. If you into architecture and looking ideas for back home, this a not to miss. Our expectations were fairly low, our experience was far, far above that. Go!

Lovely traditional Thai homes brought together to make one. The beautiful home of an American spy who helped saved the Thai silk industry. Very interesting tour of the home. Expensive but beautiful silk items in the store on the grounds.

Good for a relaxing day if there's time. This is the type of thing, that after visiting, makes you want to read more about when you get home.Interesting story about an American who fell in love with Thailand and revived their silk industry. The house and grounds are lovely and the background story is intriguing. Save this for a quiet day if you're in Bangkok for more than a few days. Otherwise if you're in Bangkok for 2-3 days leave this for another time; it'll be worth it.Tour guides in several languages, gift shop selling silk and graphics (all high quality) restaurant. They have their own free Tuk Tuks carrying visitors from the house to the end of the street (Tuk Tuks are clearly marked as Jim Thompson House - so don't use any others)Time to read up on this guy.

Must see the house and antique masterpieces. You can imagine the 1960's with Jim Thompson still living there.Nice garden and little canal in front .He had bought beautiful scuptures (some of the IXe century) and other masterpieces and decorated his living and dinning room with great taste.
Has potential. I was a little disappointed by this place given the cost of the entry ticket, limited time/limited access, and the forced tour. The proximity to the canal is a big plus.

A little piece of Old Bankok. Take the skytrain to National Stadium, and, if you're lucky, step into a buggy that reduces the 10 minute walk to the Jim Thompson House. The guided tours (no other way) are informative and the House is full of interesting artefacts. Well worth a couple of hours of your time. There's a reasonable, but crowded, restaurant and the inevitable Jim Thompson shop selling very little in original or interesting Thai silk.

Nice place to visit in Bangkok. Really wanted to visit this place as have a interest in design and fabric. The house and museum are well worth a visit as the guides explain the history of the house and the story about Jim Thompson who was famous for bringing a lot of Thai silk to the west. The restaurant was also a nice place for lunch but the service was little slow at bust times.
Boring. Who is Jim Thompson u ask? Who cares I say. No seriously, not that interesting, either visually or story wise

Don't miss this gorgeous oasis of beauty!. There are endless things to do in Bangkok, but this place is special... It feels like you are stepping back into time. Easy walking distance from the frenetic pace of the malls, it is like an oasis of peace. Jim Thompson had exquisite taste in decor and it's fascinating to go on the 30 minute tour of the haven he created (tours are offered for a reasonable price in various languages). The grounds and the art are extraordinarily beautiful. There is also a wonderful restaurant that we adored with both Thai and western options and you can dine inside or out (we had two delicious fruit drinks and some great Thai dishes). It's a wonderful glimpse of what old Bangkok must have been like...

Worth a visit!. Went there on midday. A really tiny but tranquil place to beat the noises and heat on the busy city streets. Saw real cacoons and learned how to get raw silk out from them. Guided tour with English and French language only.

Great Insight Into Times Past. I love history and Jim Thompson's house certainly had it. The place is truly beautiful and amazing. The food at the restaurant whilst waiting for the English tour was also really good. Definitely worth the visit.

worth the visit to see the spinning process. The tour through the Jim Thompson House was very sterile, our guide was difficult to understand and you are often waiting for the previous tour group to finish in a particular room. That said, the house is interesting, the art is remarkable and the whole concept of this guy settling here and developing an industry without any knowledge of Thai, is amazing. I loved watching a man spinning silk from a boiling cauldron of silk cocoons. Hypnotizing. I had no idea this is how one gets silk from the cocoon.Treat the shop as part of the museum. The products are probably first rate but the prices are sky high

A must Visit!. Another great tour to do when in Bangkok is a visit to Jim Thompson House and Museum.We had an English speaking guide who explained how Jim Thompson, an American Military Officer came to Thailand and fell in love with the country and its people. Soon after WW2 he decided to live there and went back to Bangkok. Thompson was very interested in the long neglected craft of hand weaving of silk and he was convinced of the exceptional quality of this sort of fabric. So he started to rebuild the whole industry and made it to worldwide success with his Thai Silk Company. In 1967 he went for holidays to the Cameron Highlands of Malaya where he never turned back from a walk into the jungle.His house in Bangkok didn’t change much since the day he disappeared. Our guide showed us around and gave us, a brief talk about the architecture of the six teak wood buildings that came from all over the country and were reconstructed here in Bangkok. The design is an interesting combination of Thai Style with European influence.Outside the buildings there were examples of silk caterpillars, how to make the raw product and how to spin the threads.Attached to the museum you will find The Jim Thompson Art Centre with changing exhibitions that is also worth to have a look at (admission is free).If you are hungry, there is a wide choice of food & beverages at Thompson Bar & Restaurant.Overall, a definitely worthwhile tour as the Jim Thompson Foundation is also committed to the preservation of Thailand artistic & cultural heritage.Info: Opening hours are daily from 9 am to 5 pm with hourly guided tours, admission fee is 100 Baht per adult, you can get there by Sky Train, taxi, Tuk tuk or Klong Boat, however have a look on a map before, than it’s easier to find.

A must see sight. We had great difficulty locating this place but it was worth the walking around. The house itself has group tours starting every 5 minutes. This meant that you were constantly coming across another tour and having to wait whilst they passed. This did not detract too much from Jim Thompson's house. The garden was interesting and provided a shady spot to visit. The inevitable showroom of silk products was air conditioned and although the items were fantastic they were very expensive.

A Silky Place!. I am a designer so I love Jim Thompson products....The Silk Shirts for men, T-shirts, scarves and bags for women. Uniquely Thai, yet was conceived by an American named Jim Thompson who went missing in 1967. The house is very accessible since it is walking distance from the train station...which is a stop away from Siam Central. The tour only cost 100 bht and is well worth knowing Jim's passion for design and his lifestyle. It is a peaceful sanctuary for creative people as well as educational. They even show how silk are made from silkworms! Like they say...smooth as silk!

Experience the Enigma. Jim Thompson, who mysteriously disappeared and is known to revive the Thai silk, his leagcy lives in the form of the house he lived in.Good place, nice displays and a very quiet peaceful atmosphere. You are taken on a guided conducted tour of 45 minutes.The souvenier shop inside sells quality products, but the prices are high. Still for the sake of the silk industry, worth spending a few more ... well, it is entirely upto you.. a personal choice.All in all , a great place. Should visit if you have time on hand.
Best service in Thailand. There is no place I have seen better service than in the Jim Thompson house. The tour is interesting, free and not too long, which is good.
Nice quick visit. For a free tour, nice to check a Traditional Thai house. Try to make to the other JT store, 4 floors, different location from this one. Also JT outlet closer to the 4 floor store.

Very disappointing. I was so looking forward to this visit, what a disappointment, so much so that we did not do the tour. We had a meal in the restaurant first and the service and attitude of the staff was appalling. The begrudgingly served you and we're surly in the extreme. Whilst the food was fine, the customer service left a lot to be desired. We complained at the entrance desk and even there the woman was disinterested.

Interesting hideaway. The Jim Thompson house is a gorgeous house tucked away down a street in the busy downtown area of Bangkok. It has stunning grounds and the house is impressive. There are guided tours that are part of your admission, the English tour is good and informative. I have been twice with friends and the two tours haven't been the same, which was nice. You cannot take pictures inside the house which is a shame but it still is a gorgeous home to look at. There is also some small museums on the grounds as well as an art gallery above the store. It is a good way to kill 2 hours of your afternoon while in downtown Bangkok.

Charming and informative. A nice stop on any BKK sightseeing trip. One learns quite a bit about the region's silk weaving culture as well as elements of traditional houses. Get a nice silk-work present or two, or three, for someone or, indeed, for yourself in the shop and taste an absolutely divine fresh mango with sticky rise and some lemongrass tea on the terrace by the fishpond. One of the quieter and slower-paced oases in the otherwise bustling city.

Dont miss this place of history.. Who is Jim Thompson? Why would you want to go there?Why is a farang(white man) so famous in Bangkok? All these can be answered when you visit his huge house. His house in fact is unique as he actually collected different houses of different designs from across Thailand brought the houses to Bangkok. With his collection of antiques, this place is a museum of sorts.Nice but expensive silk items can be bought from the gift shop at the entrance. Oh did I forget to mention, Jim Thompson was the guy who rejuvenated the Thai Silk industry.Enough of my rantings, go there and find out yourselves! :-)

Who knew. Who knew that an American opened up the thai silk trade! The people of thailand seem to really respect his work and they have kept his original house as a museum and all proceeds go to his foundation. beautiful house - fusion of Western/Thai decor

Nice time and lovely garden. It was a great place since we were traveling with 1,5 yr son. NIce garden (not too hot) and a house, very lovely staff - playing with our son while we had a drink in their restaurant.I recommend it if you want to have a relaxed time.

interesting but skippable. Perhaps it was because this was Day 23 of our trip, but this just wasn't as fascinating as I might have expected. Thompson was an American who revived the Thai silk industry. This is his home. Interesting but no critical to see. Stop in at one of his stores around town; expensive but high quality goods.

Only If You Have Spare Time. This is a "top ten" site in so many travel guides, and it is quite unique. However, it was not amazing. If you only have two days in Bangkok it may not be worth it, but if you have a few extra days it would be worth going to. It is old thai style houses linked to one another to create a airy, but western style home for a currently missing American. If you like architecture it might be worth going to.
Amazing. A trip back in history....Deffenitely worth a visit.............Take a tour guide to show you around.

Not what I expected. Located just off the main national stadium bts station - well signposted and they do a buggy back to the staion free. You can not go round the house on your own and have to be part of a tour - all languages catered for. There is a shop and a great rerstaurant on site. you are allocated to a tour when you pay your money.
Great attraction. This is a must see for all visitors. Also a nice escape from the more chaotic parts of Bangkok. Great shop as well

An Excellent Place to visit. Jim Thompson House, the museum was an excellent place where one can see the traditional Thai house, silk manufacturing, plus can make some shopping. The shops located in various parts of the city worth to visit as well. My wife felt like she was in a candy shop!

Buy your silk here. After traveling Thailand and Myanmar nothing else seems as nice as JT silks and designs. Overpriced but so what....very unique and quality is high. Some nice stuff elsewhere but this was the best.

A lovely place. I have been to Bangkok several times, and Jim Thompson House is at the top of my list of places to visit. Everything about it is beautiful and serene -- the house itself, the furnishings, the gardens. It's one of those dreamy places where you can almost imagine yourself living there. Tours are well-organized. There's no pressure to buy anything in the shop. I can't think of a single negative.

Quiet Oasis, in a busting city!. The House is incredible, and the story behind the man is fascinating! It was a welcome respite, in a sea of cars and people that make Bangkok a buzzing metropolis! The gardens were beautiful and serene! The silk worm show, the weavers, gift shop, and restaurant were a bit touristy, but we did appreciate the ice cold beer on a warm day!

Textile lessons. It was unique to learn about trade style of silk. This house was unique and in a strange location in the city but fun getting there in the process. It has a unique style to see the way the teak of the house that is not made as much as it used to be made.
tourisc place. A really tourist place, the guided tour was interressant but not passionant. Just to do if you have spend enought time around the city and enjoy the more interresting street live

For All Interior Decorators & Dreamers. If you ever dreamed of Thai antiques complemented with luxurious silks from the East, this is the place. To witness a traditional, if not extravagant, Thai home at its finest, spend a leisurely morning at quiet retreat.

First Time visit. Always meant to visit, this place in the many times I had been in Bangkok, finally got round to doing it. Well worth it, the tours round it are well organised and individual groups are done by language, whether in English, French, German, Japanese or Chinese are all catered for.Guides very informative, a little thing to do in the middle of Bangkok.
Worthwhile Tour. Beautiful house, fabrics, furniture on display. The tours are not rushed and it's interesting to hear about the life of Jim Thompson.

Another must see-the Bangkok before moderizaztion.. This complex is a walk through recent history. Our guide was excellent and informative. You will truly appreciate what this American accomplished in a short period of time.

unexciting museum,with a few interesting pieces. The teak houses are alright,Myanmar has much better ones.The art collection is nothing special,seen a lot better...I f you have nothing else to do,maybe a visit .A lot of restrictions...no photos inside/no money belts/purses/back packs etc allowed ...shoes off if you please.rather boring.

See silk being created!. Ok his house is very interesting along with his story and he is the father of Thai silk in that he restored the craft....the shop has great pillows etc for souvenirs......restaurant is quite tasty and washrooms clean. THe most interesting is seeing the silk worms eating and cocooning an then seeing the silk thread being made...wow

You get what You've heard about: a man's house. 100THB ticket equals to value of sights but You get a professional guided tour in a garden and a house of a man and his wife who loved Thailand and collected some treasure of this country like nobody else. House was interesting and interior is beautiful. For us to see the house it was a must because our hotel was in the next street.

Relaxing interlude in the city. Jim Thompson house is like a small oasis in the heart of Bangkok. The tour guides are unfailing polite and knowledgable about the history of the house and the man behind it. You can't take strollers in for practical reasons but we found the guides and the guards went out of their way to make getting around with our baby as easy as possible. Lunch was yummy - we stuck with the Thai options and couldn't fault them.Great way to catch your breath in the city that never sleeps.

Simply beautiful & Zen. An oasis of calm & beauty in the heart of Bangkok,a must for any visit,with a free tuk-tuk shuttle to the nearest BTS station,late afternoon is the best time to visit,(closes at 5pm)
Very interesting. A must for all tourists. The tour is nice, a bit slow but worth the wait.Highly recommend a smoothie at the restaurant near by

A beautiful little oasis in the big city. I was expecting the Jim Thompson House to be crowded with and hawkers and tuk-tuk drivers telling me it's closed. As with other Bangkok attractions, the city seems to have been cracking down on scammers with signs that clearly say it's open every day. It's located on a quiet little soi (side street) not far from the National Stadium skytrain stop. There is even a free golf-cart / clean, large tuk-tuk shuttle service from the main street to the house, though I didn't use it. Tours are available in English and French and total admission was 100 baht at the time ( about US $3). I am not a big art fan, but the house and grounds have lots of beautiful Thai art pieces collected by Mr. Thompson over his life, lots of ponds and urns with fish, frogs, and turtles, and jungle-esque vegetation. The house itself is gorgeous and was built in a traditional Thai style. It may be hard to find other examples of this kind of architecture in Bangkok, so if you want to see some old-style Thai houses but won't get a chance to go the countryside on your Thailand trip, then this is the place to go. It is next to a narrow canal, which used to be the main entrance of the house, but the fence is high and there is no danger of falling in. The only way to the second floor is by stairs, so if you have trouble walking you may have to skip that part of the tour. As with many Asian houses, you must remove your shoes before you enter the house, but the floors are quite clean. Tours are well-organized and guides knowledgeable, and this is not an overcrowded, harried, noisy place like the Grand Palace. There is, of course, a Jim Thompson silk store on the grounds if you want to buy some silk, a cafe, a small art gallery with free art/photo exhibits (at the time), and some traditionally dressed silk weavers / dancers demonstrating their skills.
Peaceful place in bangkok. If you are in Sukhumvit area and want some peace......had here.Easy to find and has a great tour. I stayed for a couple of hours...had a drink a took in the atmosphere
Not to be missed!. A very interesting trip back in time to the lifestyle of a thriving american entrepreneur and lover of thai culture. You must try their thai restaurant with the most amazing food.
Silkkkk....... This is the place to go...if you dont wana get bluffed by the street hawkers selling cheap silk...This is one of the oldest and best place to buy your silk...!!!!

interesting place to visit. We really enjoyed visiting Jim Thompson's house. It was very interesting to learn a bit more about how Thai silk is made, and early ways the pattern was printed.It was also very interesting to get a small insight into Jim Thompson himself, and his time in Thailand, and understand the way he sympathetically built a house blending both Thai and Western architectural features to build his home.Well worth a visit to get a glimpse into the public face of Jim Thompson, but if you want to learn more about his secretive side, or his strange disappearance, don't expect any real insight, that's for the conspiracy theorists!!
wow!!. Great visit! It was a nice piece of heaven in a large city. Wonderful tour and gift shop. Nice reminder how much it takes to get 1 silk scarf. A little hard to find but well worth it...
Outstanding. Is a very good place to know something else about thailand history and traditions, and its a very beautiful place

Oasis. I visited this place every time I go to Bangkok and I love it. Restaurant there is very good. Can be crowded at lunch time but very good to enjoy a coffee in the afternoon. This place is unique. Shop is wonderful too. We do have a Jim Thompson in Singapore too but be sure that buying stuff in Bangkok is much cheaper...

Nice place, good tour. Been here twice now, greatly enjoyed it both times. The tour takes about an hour and guides you through the house. During the tour, you get some nice insights into the history of Jim Thompson, the house, and Thailand in general. Also nice to learn something about Thailand and Thai culture.

Worth a visit. I have not been to the Jim Thompson House for many many years so was surprised to see how well the whole complex has been done up. There is now a beautiful shop there and great restaurant as well. It is slightly annoying that one cannot just wander around and you have to wait for a tour of your language so if you are short on time, call in advance
lovely Thai silk. Very Expensive but i think worth it to buy to take home as the colours are fantastic and the range on offer is with in my budget I like the Ties
Really Nice. We got there late, so only walked around the grounds / building a little. Then we had a drink at the restaurant. But it was a place we wish we were able to go back and see more of.

A lovely quiet spot in downtown Bangkok. Quite enjoyed this lovely place and the story of Jim's love of Thailand and the silk trade. The tour is very popular and well run, however I don't think it's an amazing place and certainly shouldn't be on any top 10 list . However worth a look if looking for an hour or two out of buzzing, lively Bangkok .

Extremely good offers, specially for women. Good service.good selection in womens fashion clothing, also scarfs, bags and accessoires.Main problem for European women is the lack of actual sizes.For men mainly ties (which we hardly use these days) shirts in silk and cotton, but for silk unfortunately not the very thin ones, - a good selection of classic polos, and soilk boxers

Out of the Past, good family outing. A visit to Jim Thompson House is a great way to spend a few hours if you are in the MBK area. Down a quite leafy soi it’s well worth a visit. The architecture is fascinating the guided tour or the interiors also well worth a look see. I recommend visiting the shop, but to be honest the silk and Linen goods are way overpriced in my opinion. The restaurant is pleasant some tasty foods. All in all an ok place to take the family for a few hours. Enjoy hope this review helps Cheers Phil

Interesting perspective. It is a beautifully maintained place, true to its origins and pedigree, and in very pleasant grounds. It is very popular so there might be a slight wait for the tour (you cannot see it on your own). But it is worth it. Even if there is a wait, there are many other things to while away your time, including silk weaving, dances, music, art gallery, shopping etc. The wood Thai architecture is just awesome.
Really Cool.. Nice escape from the city in the middle of the city. The Jim Thompson house is a good way to see traditional Thai architecture in a nice setting.

Okay, but surely not a top 10 thing to do in Bangkok?. We were in Bangkok in Jan 2013 and Jim Thompson House was ranked 6th or 7th on Trip Advisor for "attractions in Bangkok", so we went to check it out. It was okay, easy to find, pleasant staff, nice house, but I can't say I really understand how this has become a top ten thing to do in Bangkok. As some of the other reviewers noted, we didn't leave with an understanding of why this man and his house have become so venerated. A pleasant thing to do if you have the time I guess, but if you leave Bangkok having not been to Jim Thompson House, I don't think you are missing an essential Thai experience.
Nice tour. We actually didnt know much about who Jim Thompson was, but after reading about this tour, we decided to give it a go. Nice experience to a traditional thai house.

A beautiful gem. I loved it here, the tour is quite quick but you can then explore the house on your own afterwards.The tour guide we had was very good, spoke english well and answered questions when asked.The house itself if beautiful and really sends you back in time, it is full of antiques and pictures.Whilst we were there, there was a chap actually spinning silk which was fascinating.There is also a JT shop and a cafe, a really pleasant place to go away from the hustle and bustle just streets away.

A nice break from the heat. There is certainly an oasis feeling in the place. It is a very nice break from the heat and craziness of Bangkok. I had high expectations on the compulsory tour but I feel that the tour could have been better. They focus mostly on the house disposition and decoration and they barely reveal any details on Jim Thompson's life or the role of silk in Thailand's economy. I was hoping to learn more about this. They provide free shuttle from the metro station. It is only around 300/400 metres but with the heat is appreciated. They also have a store and certainly the marketing around JT is overwhelming and in my opinion a bit exaggerated. I had the feeling they had more merch than the Tate or the Louvre.

American in Thailand. Jim Thompson dedicated his life - well the last years anyway - to Thai silk, managed to create a business empire and a splendid home to reflect it. A guided tour is a must, so reserve time. And as in all the other Bangkok musts, have shoes that are very easy to take off and put on. The bar there has a surprisingly nice happy hour!

Great Experience to understand a little Thai history. The Jim Thompson House gives you a glimpse into how living in Thailand was in the not so distant past. Very enjoyable tour and provides just another insight into the mysteries of Thailand and it's people. Not geared for younger children but middle school age and above. Nice little tea house/restaurant right on the grounds to enjoy before or after the tour. And sometimes they have a special exhibit in the space above the gift house.

Interesting house and story. Jim Thompson house was really beautiful. Well worth a visit. The guide who took us around the house was very difficult to understand, but the house was outstanding. The shop is worth a visit for the lovely range of men's and women's clothing and household furnishings.

Splendid buildings. Not to be missed if you want to understand what Thailand is about. It's a compound of 6 Ayuttayya houses gently put together byt the late Jim Thompsaon, full with artifacts. Nice and informative

A beautiful refuge within a concrete jungle. We were amazed at this little patch of greenery in tthe middle of the concrete jungle. It is so pleasant walking in the shade of the trees, with a number of pools of water no doubt helping to keep the temperature down, and admiring the traditional Thai architecture and various historic items scattered about the place. The tour is short, but is done in other languages too, for example the one before ours was in French, so we had a 20 minute wait before our tour started but we used the time to look around the shop and visit the bathroom. The tour was very informative and the collection of items is small but very varied, from old Buddha statues to old pictures, to items used by Jim Thompson himself, such as a large block used for printing onto silk. He combined European and Asian elements in the houses; of particular note was the Italian marble which was so to walk on when the temperature outside was so high - shoes cannot be worn in the buildings in the collection. After we finished the tour we visited the shop which has a good collection of items for purchase, though admittedly pretty much the same as is available at the airport. Then we had a lunch at the restaurant, of which the highlight was the dish served in a carved-out pineapple. Fun to get served and very tasty too. When we left there were two golf buggies running a shuttle between the entrance and the end of the laneway near the stadium, with no shortage of choice for transport to the next destination. We're both happy we took one afternoon out of our stay to visit this attraction.

Bangkok Gem. Well worth a visit, contrary to other postings quite easy to find as it is marked on most tourist maps & is very close to the shopping centres at Siam Discovery & Siam Center.If you time it right there is a golf buggy providing a free shuttle from the main road or alternately on the way back from the House. Our taxi from the hotel had no problem dropping us at the entrance.Entry is cheap at 100 Baht & that includes a guided tour with English speaking Thai guide which you will find charming & an informative insight into the collection of buildings & antiques built up by Jim Thompson. IIt is a peaceful spot occasionally disturbed by passing boats on the waterway which runs alongside and the collection of wooden traditional Thai houses and gardens gives you an insight into how things were before the advance of modern day Bangkok.We finished our visit with a very nice lunch of local dishes in the adjoining restaurant which was very well served and good value.

A must go. This was one of the best places we visited. The story of Jim Thompson and what aspired him plus the design of the house was fascinating.I thoroughly enjoyed the museum and the good at the restaurant. I would recommend going for the vegetarian option which was more delicious but aware of the hottest chillies hidden in the lettuce.Overall an excellent experience and a must for all visitors

Very interesting and full of antiques. We throughly enjoyed our experience and tour of the 200 year old houses which were brought here by Jim Thompson to make up his home complex. It set in small but attractively laid out grounds next to a canal.The tour is very good and everything is explained very well.It was our first morning and set the holiday off with a very good start

Oasis of peace and tranquilty. Along with a ride on the river, I rate Jim Thompson House as the best attraction in Bangkok. Just getting away from the chaos of Siam Square is worth the price of admission here. Visit a few simple Thai-style houses on a guided tour. See simple, but elegant furnishings, or shop for the best silk in Southeast Asia, but don't miss this attraction. Highly recommended.

Well preserved. This was one of the last things I visited in Bangkok during my two-days stay. Thanks to a good taxi driver I was there quite quickly and joined an English tour guides (you cannot walk freely in the house and no pictures allowed inside). The tour was very interesting and took around one hour. Because it's nearly all inside, you should better visit it at the warmest moment of the day.

Really nice visit. We didn't expect to enjoy this site as much as we did! We were in Bangkok for 5 days and on the last day just wanted to relax and this place was close to our hotel so we thought why not. It was a short ride on the sky train and a short walk from the station. Once you arrive and pay for your entry you go to the back area and sign up for the mandatory guided tour. If you have to wait you can go back out to the shop which we did - lots of lovely silk scarves and shirts, purses, and housewares - not cheap but beautifully made. Our guide did a fantastic job of going over Jim Thompson's story and various points of interest in the different parts of the house. A lot of thought went into creating this home. We had to take off our shoes to enter the house. Afterward we could wander around on our own and take photos (except for the interior of the house, and no photos allowed there). We then decided to have lunch at the restaurant on site and it was absolutely lovely as we got a table by the pond and the food was delicious, in particular the green curry. I also tried the lemongrass juice which was really nice; it comes with a tiny pitcher of sugar syrup which I added to sweeten it up.

Interesting story, but not much about making silk. This house is close to the canal boat stop and the big shopping areas round Central World. The guided tour round the house takes around 30 minutes (no photos allowed) and may be of more interest to US citizens than Europeans. A lady was spinning silk when we arrived, something we have never seen before, but more on making silk would have been good. Clothing available in the shop can be purchased at several outlets in the airport, surprisingly at 10% cheaper.

We went to a large store and then, his house. Cab drivers are not sure, have address written down. The 4 story store has lovely merchandise, well priced for the quality, then we went to his actual house..very interesting to see Thai architecture

Much More Interesting Than It Sounds!. Before visiting Jim Thompson House, I wasn't too pumped to go since I had heard that the silk was more expensive than it is in other places around Bangkok. I went anyway and was not disappointed. Beautiful architecture! Lovely grounds! Lots to see! Interesting story! Worth the visit.
A must see!. Well worth visiting. The guided tours are interesting and done in different languages. Tranquil setting.
MUST SEE. this is amazing. the layout, the garden , the location, the house, the antique, the guided tour......if only you could stay there for a few nights. wow!
Silk!. You think of Thai silk, you think of Jim Thompson. Named after the famous promoter of Thai silk, the museum housed in his house built in the unique Thai style, all of seasoned teak.

Wonderful museum. This is an exquisite house filled with great antiques and artifacts. The docents/guides are multilingual and the tour is most informative. A must see for those interested in traditional Thai architecture, art and furniture, although the Thompson house mixed European/Western elements with indigenous architecture. Beautiful. The tour takes about an hour. There is a very high quality gift shop, too, that is worth checking out.
Hidden heaven in the center. quiet and lovely place in the heart of bangkok. the guided tour is very interesting, so as the food at its coffee.

Interesting story. I visited Jim Thompson's house in March 2010 with my husband. Due to the riots in Bangkok at the time, it was one of the few places we could go although I had friends who were there a month later and they couldn't even go here! Knowing nothing about Jim Thompson, I found the tour very interesting and his disappearance intriguing, although I'm pretty sure he just wandered off into the jungle, fell down and died somewhere. The house has been kept just as it was when Mr Thompson lived there and his collection of artifacts were fascinating. I enjoyed the gardens. We finished our visit in the gift shop where I spent a happy hour browsing before making my purchases. The cost of the tour and the prices in the gift shop were reasonable I thought. My husband also enjoyed the tour although he found the humidity in the gardens pretty unbearable. (The gift shop is air conditioned!!) I would recommend this as an interesting break from the temples and crowds in Bangkok and somewhere to spend an hour or two. Removing shoes and leaving bags behind (securely) is just one of those things one has to do as a tourist and I respect the hosts' rights to request this and did not object.

I want to live here. Bangkok is not my favorite place, but I visit Thailand once every few years to see a dear friend, so I end up flying into Bangkok. The flight is so long that I've started booking a hotel for a night or two to sit by the pool and recover.However, I love the Jim Thompson House and tell anyone I know not to miss it, so I will tell you. I bring a book and stay there all day enjoying the quietness and beauty of the gardens and perfect aesthetics of the homes. Don't come here to shop. Come here to hang out with beauty, read a book, have lunch in the lovely cafe, watch the fish, and generally retreat from Bangkok.

Travel back in time. Get an idea of how old Bangkok looked like. An amazing and charming assemblage of old Thai houses stuffed with an arts and crafts collection, inspiring interior decoration in a beautiful garden setting. And it awaits with a mysterious story about the disappeared owner. You may only enter with a guide but it is interesting. Several languages provided. There is also a shop selling Jim Thompson silk products and a restaurant.

Great visitor attraction. Not all that easy to find but well worth the effort. Lovely, quiet oasis in the middle of bustling Bangkok. Very interesting guided tour. Lovely restaurant. Whole place had a nice atmosphere and I'd definitely go there again.
eh. We were all disappointed in this sight. The area and the gardens are pretty, but the main area is just fair. The largest part of this sight is the retail store.

Sorry - it was dull. It was quite amusing, because there is not much of a story, other than he set up a great business and then disappeared - but you have to endure a really long tour, looking at artefacts (sorry it was really dull and quite stuffy with the rules about bags and shoes)

A well hidden jewel!. This is a well hidden jewel of a place with all the grand nuances of Lanna building styles and beautiful garden settings. Gorgeous antiques and silk tapestries not to mention the wonderful silk scarves and more you can purchase in the gift shop! ...also a very nice place to have lunch!

Turned out to be good. I was dragged here by my girlfriend kicking and screaming but it was actually quite interesting. Mr Thompsons story was really intriging, especially his still unexplained disappearance.

Great museum!. We went to the Jim Thompson's house without any expectations and were pretty surprised how nice, interesting and different this visit was! It is also home to the Jim Thompson store where you can buy silk scarfs, clothes, etc... There is a restaurant on site. Visits are about an hour and are given in many languages... English, French, German, etc... Definitely worth the visit.

Beautiful home. The home is beautiful. The story of Jim Thompson was interesting. They make you lock your bags, purses etc in a locker prior to the tour. Additionally you will need to leave your shoes behind. The home is beautiful & the tour was interesting. Its only about 30-40 minutes long & they offer the tour in 3 languages.I had a small appetizer at the restaurant which was ok. The gift shop is very pricey.

Must see when in Bangkok. A really beautiful old Thai house built by the founder of Jim Thompson silk. The house is now a major tourist attraction and the obligatory guided tour is rushed and impersonal. Still you should see the house once to appreciate perfection in interior design
It is a MUST in Bangkok. What a nice Thaihouse in the center of Bangkok. A wonderful Thai building with a nice and friendly coffee-shop at the entrance. Reasonable price and beautiful settings.

Great insight to a by gone age. This is a great little gem.You can access via the sky train about a 400m walk from stadium station or via th can ferry similar walking distance.You can wander around the gardens for free, or take paided guided tour up to you. Great place to relax if you have been temple treking all day.

It was nice. the stores and the restaurant was the highlight. they make the best ice thai tea here, and so the rest of the food was a delight. price was decent, its not over expensive.the boutique was nice too, but they dont have much stock, and the one in the airport has more collection. the house? it was nice, but not for touring around.
Fantastic designs. The Factory outlets offer significant discounts on a comprehensive range of JT items, including fabrics by the metre

great collection in an extraordinary setting. located right off the canal and the national stadium BTS it is easy to get to. The collection of budhist art and thai collectors shows a refined taste. A chance to experience traditional thai architecture and furnishings in a relaxed atmosphere. The tour guides are knowledge and proficient. We weren't hurried, and enjoyed our lunch our lunch overlooking the fish pond.

Nice house, but.... We ended up here because our moms were visiting Thailand and wanted to check it out. The home is a decent museum if that's your thing, but I don't feel I learned anything of interest or importance. Jim Thompson was a CIA guy, but they don't even mention that on the tour, yet they act confused as to why he suddenly disappeared one day. Definitely stay out of the gift shop and the restaurant. Super expensive. We had a few 100 baht coconuts (standard is 30 baht) and left before we ordered an overpriced lunch.
Interesting. This hose is interesting and allows a glimpse at the inside a thai houses. The guides are very informative. If you hang out downstairs you can see thai crafts and music during he day.

Great tour and GREAT break from the heat.. We really enjoyed our tour of the Jim Thompson house. It's set in a secluded location, so you feel like you are given a break from the crazy city.The house is beautiful and there is a little cafe set next to a koi pond that would be great place to have a cool drink before your tour. Even our kids ages and 9 and 11 really enjoyed our time at the house.

A wonderful peaceful retreat.. Although in the centre of the city, this peaceful retreat was a remarkable place with water features, fish and luxuriant gardens.The house complex itself was explained by a thoughtful and intelligent member of staff bringing to life the poignant story of Jim Thompson and his legacy.The silk shop was full of beautiful items, although many of them were very expensive.The restaurant/coffee shop overlooked the pool and provided good food and drinks at a reasonable price.A delightful place to retreat to from the bustle of Bangkok.

Beautiful grounds. I expected more and was disappointed. The houses are beautiful and the grounds are very nicely planted, but the gardens are small. I thought I would learn more about the Thai silk industry, production, marketing, etc., but other than a few baskets of silk worms, and a few cocoons, little was said about this industry that Thompson developed. It would have been nice if people were demonstrating the ancient crafts, especially doing some of the weaving. I also would have liked more information about the contents of each room as we moved through the house. Little was said about many of the artifacts.
A bit of peace and quiet in Bangkok. A very enjoyable afternoon - nice to get away from the manic streets and have a relaxing tour. We had to wait ~ 1 hour for the guide but it was worth it.

Worth a visit. Pros. Interesting place, go in the afternoon for less people, beautful garden, the restaurant in the garden has a killer lime mint iced drink It is F-in awesome.Cons: Girl tried to make money for herself at the counter: here's how. Two tickets pls. She give you a receipt, Go to the tour counter. When we decided we would choose a different day and tried to get the money back, it turns out she put one adult one student on the receipt, which is a lower price. I paid 400 for example she puts 300 on the receipt. Get it? I got the money back after a small but firm standoff. I think that was pretty stupid since it was obvious she worked for her pocket. This is Thailand.

Good, but a little too touristy. A great teak house in the heart of a Bangkok with a fascinating owner and history. The (slight) negative aspects were how busy the place was and the wait for the official tour - in hindsight I should have looked a little off the beaten track.On a big plus side was the fantastic restaurant with amazing food and great service... Their Pad Thai was well worth the trip!

Interesting but nothing spectacular. We decided to head to the Jim Thompson House museum seeing it was close to our hotel and we wanted to fill up the morning. Pros:- it was very easy to get to -just a few hundred meters on foot from BTS National Stadium and down a narrow side street- very orderly and frequent individual tours with guides catering to a number of languages- cheap tour (299baht p.p) lasting 35mins- beautiful grounds including onsite restaurant with various fish ponds full of coy, goldfish and even some rather large turtles!Cons:- our guide, while she could speak English, didn't speak it very well so made it extremely difficult to understand what she was telling us- I think the tour could've been done in half the time- the house is very small and full of antique ornaments and furniture hence their need to split out into small groups and take everyone around in an orderly fashion. Personally I would've preferred making my own way around and reading about the history via plaques etc placed around the house - just like they do Japan. That's just my personal preference - we decided to eat at the onsite restaurant as our tour ended just after midday and we were keen to get the kids back for a nap. Yes it's convenient but be prepared to pay for it (1700 baht) for 2 entrees, 1 risk dish, 1 (tiny) noodle dish and 3 drinks. Food was ok (yes, just 'ok') but the mango smoothie I ordeed was completely bland.

A calm shady oasis in middle of the city.. Just a few minutes walk from the Skytrain National Stadium, MBK, along a quiet lane brings you to this peaceful shady oasis,. The 100 baht entrance fee includes a tour of what are really six teak houses joined together plus other teak structures now used as a museum and shop all hidden in the tropical garden of about half an acre right in the centre of Bangkok.Jim Thompson's House contains lots of antiques and broken buddhas, wall hangings and porcelain, but it is the shady seclusion and bowls of floating lotus flowers that work their magic - a welcome break from the heat of this pulsating city.

Amazing food and good service. Thing you need to do when you visit Bangkok is going to eat at JIm Thomson, food here is premium with best quality and taste fine. They tastes like orginal Thai cuisine. Ialways order pomelo salad, papaya salad, grilled chicken. Padthai here is great too. When you finish your meal, you can go shopping silk next door and also visit Jim Thomson house to learn about silk history and JIm Thomson's background.
Worth A Visit. Very interesting to learn about Jim Thompson and his life. Good shop for buying silk items. The highlight for us was the cafe, the food was amazing, you must eat here.

Garden access only without a tour. Easy to get to off the SkyTrain, and pretty from the outside, but the combination of a 90-minute wait in 90-degree weather for our mandatory tour proved too much. We gave up after 60 minutes and were cheerfully offered a full refund. Pretty place from outside, but waiting 90 minutes for a tour when we only had 3 days in the city wasn't what we had in mind. Certainly would have taken a self-guided tour, but that option wasn't available.

yep, a must in Bangkok. I have this place in TA when i depature to Thailand, and it's really a big surprise for me. The Thai traditional buiding, the varied collectibles in the house. Really Really amazing, and there are free guide interpreter if you book the ticket, and the price is about 50B.
Hidden Gem. Great to see how silk is 'made' and to hear his story. Beautiful place. A little out of the way. restaurant expensive.

Amazing House & Great Staff. The house and story of Jim Thompson was really wonderful. It was amazing to see how silk is weaved and learn about the process as well as Jim Thompson. Amazing tours from great staff at a very reasonable price.

Hidden gem. Well, not really hidden if you take a guide or simply look it up, but amazing to find such a place in a small street just next to some residential buildings. Interesting tour and great shop. Ties are fantastic, bought some as they are fantastic quality at reasonable prices.

A must-do in Bangkok. A unique site. A superlatively beautiful property dome by an arcitect in love with Tailand, its material, its historical "savoir-faire". Well worth the detour. And a beautiful souvenir shop with very high quality textiles and silks.

Worth an hour of your time. If you've got an hour to spare while in Bangkok, this is a great tour. It's a nice presentation of the history of Jim Thompson and his contribution to the silk industry.You'll also see some beautiful artwork and antiques. Personally, I preferred the textile museum at the site of the Grand Palace to really appreciate the contributions of the Thai people to silk and weaving. The tour is nice, though, and it only takes about 35 minutes for the tour and you'll still have time to shop! A nice sidetrip from a busy day in Bangkok.
Well worth the trip. Taking a tour of Jim Thompson's House was an amazing lessen in architecture and history. The house itself is a marvel and the coconut ice cream served at the cafe was delicious!

Must for Bangkok. A 45 minute tour was well worth 100 baht each. Right by the national stadium sky train station so fantastically convenient. The place is stunning, and from leaving the MBK centre to heading straight to Jim Thompson House, you feel like you're in Chiang Mai or back in time. It really is beautiful. If we visit again, we will definitely try the restaurant which looked amazing.

A must see in Bangkok. Great tour around what was once Jim Thompson's house. This is the second time I've done this tour and enjoyed it just as much second time around. The restaurant is a pleasant place to finish the tour at!

Not sure what all the fuss is about. I'm not quite sure why this is touted as a must-see attraction in Bangkok. Jim Thompson might have been an interesting character, but the significance attributed to him and his house is quite disporportionate compared with other sires of historical interest.Architectually, the house is interesting but it's by no means unique. I was also annoyed that the staff made a fuss about carrying even small bum-bags into the bulding. If you're interested in the silk industry and want to pay inflated prices for the (very nice) branded products, then maybe it's worth it. Personally, though, I think it's over-rated and the most interesting part was the free art/documentary exhibition above the main shop.

Worth a Visit. Amidst the busy city of Bangkok the Jim Thompson House is definitely an island of "relative tranquility". We liked the guided tour through the house - it gives you a glimpse of JT's fascinating life. We recommend to go straight to the counter upon arrival and check when the next tour in your language starts. Waiting time can be nicely bridged in the restaurant where you can relax at the Koi pont - the food is OK. We got there by boat via Khlong Saen Saeb - the boat stop is a five-minute walk away.
Interesting. A great way to look back at history, and understand more about the impact Jim Thompson made on the Thai silk industry. This is the house I would have loved to stay in!

East meets West. We visited here during our stay in Bangkok. We travelled to the site by Tuk Tuk. There is a fee to tour but it isn't expensive. The site is very beautiful and I found it interesting to see how Mr Thompson adapted the Thai style architecture to suit his Western background whilst managing to keep the beauty and style of Thailand. The English-speaking guides were very good and knowledgeable. The art collection alone makes it worth a visit. My kids (9 and 13) enjoyed the demonstrations of silk making and the silk worms. There is a restaurant on site which is reasonably good and a bar area that overlooks a lovely Koi pond - very relaxing. The shop has a wide selection of silk products of very high quality (and price) and a range of nice souvenir items and books. Definitely worth a visit.

Good Tour! Beautiful Products. Came here as it was on the top to-do lists and we wanted to do some silk shopping. The tour was informative and the house had a beautiful collection of antiques. Our tour guide was also really funny and entertaining. Not sure if she was adding her own flair to the tour, or if she had a set script. For shopping, we actually ended up not going to the gift shop, but went to their factory outlet. It is at the almost end of the SkyTrain and actually off most of the tourist maps of Bangkok but the prices were worth it and we dropped a fair amount there (and they give VAT back)
Well worth a visit. Loved the guided tour and learning about Thai silk industry and the spinning demonstration in the courtyard.

Very Good. Well worth it , very intresting , guides are good and speak good english , learnt alot . as well as seein this beautiful house
Shop is good - expensive

Asian Art & Architecture. From the Skytrain stop at National Stadium keep your eyes open for the signs and you should find Jim Thompson's House at the end of Soi Kasem San. It can be popular and although tours go every 20 minutes you might have to be prepared for a wait. The house is an eclectic mix of Thai houses furnished with exquisite products from around Asia. The tours are informative and the benefit of being in smaller groups means you can hear your guide and get to see everything about this American silk entrepreneur before he mysteriously disappeared.

Great Tour. A must see if you are in Thailand. Ill break it down into pros and cons as usual. Tour time is approximately 35 mins.Pros:- Admission Fee: Only 100 baht (for a guided tour), and children were free - I think it was under 12 years old(?)- Very enthusiastic tour guide, she was very passionate about the history and had deep knowledge.- Beautiful property- Easily accessible by the train- Nice shop- Cafe was a bit above average pricing e.g. around 100-400Baht a dish, but the food was excellent! Service was so-so, they seemed to be very busy and the food came separately rather than at the same time!Cons:- Be prepared to walk bare foot, as it is custom in Thai houses. So if you have sweaty feet, this is a warning!- Not really a con, but the tour talks a lot about Jim Thompson and everything related to him, but I didnt really learn much about SILK itself. I think this place would benefit a lot if they created a new section to educate tourists more on how silk is made, etc.- we had to place our bags into a locker, but it is completely safe so thats not a problem.

The home of an american who did a lot for thai silk industry. Jim Thompson is long dead - he disappeared in some Mountains in Malaysia in 1967, and was never found, nor was the cause of death.However, he left a home in the centre of Bangkok which is worth a visit. Nice art, beautifull garden and a fine wooden house.A guide is included in the entrance fee which is as low as 200 Baht.And there is a small cafe at the place where you can enjoy light dishes and a small beer or alike.Visit will take a couple of hours, but it is absolutely worth to use the time.Sky Train station close and the Jim Thompson House offer free shuttle service from/to the station.

"Ms.Mintra". I hv visited yr property last December, Ms.Mintra is xtraordinary tour guide. She is professional career manner however i xperienced poor service at yr shuttle cart section.Due 2 when i finished a trip and requested shuttle cart service. He ignored service render.I hd been waiting around 10 minute 4 his service even though i was yr first visitor on that day.Then, May i suggest yr management team provide Hard training 2 Him. He is Xtremely worst Attitude. Finally, BIG thanks 2 Ms.Mintra. Very impressive on her.

Peaceful and pretty. The tour was nice and informative, and the house and grounds are really pretty and well-maintained. I think only Westerners come here. It's a little pricey but they offer student discounts.

Really need to visit. Gardens are spectacular and house is beautiful and full of history. The guided tour through the house is not only interesting and a sight to see, but the guides themselves are extremely well informed about the history of Jim Thomspsons life and business, the numerous artefacts and treasures, the process of silk making and its history and his reasons for building where he did. Thoroughly recommend a visit.

If You're interested in Textiles or History. Great opportunity to see beautifully maintained orginal style Thai wooden housing with antiques collected by Jim Thompson. Interesting tour available together with demonstrations on how to produce the silk thread from the cocoons. Beautiful shop although the goods are not cheap. Very interesting & easy to get to. Mainly suitable adults only. Also good restaurant/cafe next to Koi filled ponds - very relaxing & peaceful.

Great Atmosphere. Jim Thompson did great things to revive the traditional Thai silk industry, created this house in Bangkok out of 5 historic buildings, and then mysteriously disappeared in 1967, while out walking. So the story of Thompson alone makes this visit worthwhile, but the house and artifacts are great.

Jim Thompson House. We had been here 5 y ears ago but tour is one you always learn something new about and shopping in the store always has something new they have designed. Prices are not cheap and I would suggest a pillow case as an excellent purchase

Interesting bit of history. If you're an American you may enjoy this. It was interesting to see the techniques of silk making live. Great gardens, nice architecture and nice antique collection. The restaurant and tour guides were very busy. Had to wait 1 hour to get a tour.

Impressive Antiques. Nice House!. How cool to imagine myself living the same way how Jim Thomson lived. It blew my mind to see all his antique collections. He was an architect, obviously his taste with the materials, furniture, porcelains in his house is stellar.
