Not all that expensive. The designs and styles you find are unique. Excellent quality. Jim Thompson has surely done some good in his life, and we appreciate it.

A must do. The Jim thompson museum is a definete must visit. The house is beautiful & an insight into traditiona Thai ways of living & arcitecture. The garden is a veritable feast for the eyes. The restaurant is un necessarily expensive though.
Unreaklistic requirements. We had thought of visiting the house but upon arrival found that our bags and cameras needed to be left. On that ground alone we chose not to pay the admission fee.

Neat and clean but a tad too expensive. I went with great expectations of buing myself a Jim Thompson tie as a Birthday gift for myself. While there I noticed that the designs and the prints were good but a bit overpriced. I also got the feeling similar designs were available in India in good Indian silk for a fraction of the cost. So personally I felt it was a bit of a rip off with a tie being priced at THB 2000 a piece.

Interesting diversion. My son loved this place, I was less overawed. The collection of houses is interesting, the whole place is very well put together, we had a 'monk' doing spinning demonstrations which was enlightening, and the cafe is conveniently Western/American. But the cynic in me is not convinced that Jim Thompson wasn't just an American that got lucky with the silk and wanted to create a Western Style house, which meant he had to buy a few Thai houses and group them. If he had been British or had not disappeared in unusual circumstances, I am not sure this place would be as popular. For me it is only a 3, but I think Americans and my son love the place, so I have rated it 4 out of 5.
A oasis of calm in a hetic city!. Great tours guides, almost Spa like. I really enjoyed it and would go back if I were to find myself in Bangkok again.

Interesting from a historical perspective.... and as always, a great place to shop. I enjoyed learning about the role Jim Thompson played in the development of the Thai silk industry & bringing their beautiful silk to US fashion. Also there's a lot of Thai cultural information is on display here.

Great History Beautiful House ...Amazing Food In The Restaurant. We visited during September whilst stating at the Vie Hotel .. A great way to spend a couple of hours .. Great little factual tour and it pays to do a bit of history research before coming here ... There is a restaurant on site which does amazing Thai Food as good as I've eaten anywhere .. We came back in the evening to enjoy the full menu and reasonably priced good wines ( for Bangkok that is)... The restaurant is open during the day but the evening menu and setting is just superb and they are open till 23:00... We sat out next to the pond with all the Koi Carp .. So good we came back twice... If your feeling adventurous after busting the house daytime ..on coming out turn left towards the canal then turn right and follow the pathway up next to the canal , you'll see all the boats passing you taking people home.. There's a drop off point for the boats just before the road bridge and just after this you'll find a little make shift bar selling beers and soft Drinks where the locals grab a cold one on the way home .. Have a beer here it's bear right and continue under the road bridge then turn right and you come out on the main road towards MBK and Siam Paragon
A beautiful place to visit. It's well worth making the effort to find this house. The guided tour is good and it gives you a real feel for traditional Thai architecture

Good attaraction. Intersting Silk making demonstaration as well as photo gallary. Grounds are beautiful and the free golf cart to the airtrain is a big plus. Very convenient location near the airtrain National Stadium stop.

Very interesting place to visit.. I loved Jim Thompson's house. We did the tour of the house with the guide for 100 BHT each. It is interesting to see how he joined the several small Thai houses together to form one large home. The decorating inside with the fab antiques is beautiful. Unfortunately it was raining the day we attended so couldn't look around the garden afterwards. Great souvenir shop with very well made clothing,ties,scarves etc. When you get to the soi where the house is located look out for the Jim Thompson transport to take you to and from even though it is a short walk. Apparently they have had to start the transport as you will get told the old line of "it's closed today"!
Great museum!!. Lots of history about Jim Thompson who helped Thailand become well known in silk business. The house is in excellent shape. Worth a trip to go there.

Beautiful architecture. It is a good tour...the guide is friendly and funny. The tour guide is included in the entry price. The house is beautiful and it the landscaping is beautiful. The story of Jim Thompson is interesting. The restaurant food is pretty good. They have demonstrations of silk spinning and a store that sells an assortment of expensive silk and cotton products.
Lovely area. We went here a couple of years ago. Lovely home and amazing silk products (what he is known for) The tour was very interesting learning about his life in Bangkok.
Interesting and beautiful. A very interesting look at the residence of a mildly eccentric silk dealer who disappeared during a jungle expedition in the 60s. Our tour guide was fantastic.

Really interesting and lovely things to look at. Really enjoyed our visit here. Our English-speaking guide was very pleasant and really informative and it was a very interesting little tour. A nice way to spend an hour or two. The house and gardens are very attractive and the collection of artifacts had some beautiful and fascinating highlights. There's a good giftshop too. I'd definitely recommend it as a break from the hectic urban sprawl of the city.

Little Oasis in middle of Bangkok. Found Jim Thompsons house to be a peaceful garden setting with a nice collection of Thai/Asian antiquities (not huge, but interesting). The 40 minute tour with guide was informative and she spoke excellent English, but I would have liked a bit of time to browse afterwards. Also ate some really delicious Thai food in the restaurant afterwards. Felt like my mouth was at a dance party.

Worth Visiting!!. I lived in Bangkok as a child in the 60s and around the time that Jim Thompson disappeared. Have read books about him, so I found visiting his house fascinating! Walk through those gates and leave the hustle and bustle of a huge noisy city behind! It is a beautiful house, and if you like gardening...it is a must!!
Interesting story of his life. Short tour of the house with a good guide providing information of his life, but there was not a great amount to see when there.

Yawn. I went here since this was listed as a 'must do' in the Lonely Planet guide to BKK. It's a few small houses crunched between more modern apartment blocks, backing onto a smelly canal/sewer. After a 30 mandatory tour, I can't say I learned much more than what was in the guidebook - Jim was a US soldier I. WW2, fell in love with Thailand, and reinvigorated the silk trade by doing all the costumes for 'The King and I.' Unless you're really into the small collection of art he had, skip the admission/tour and jump straight to the surprisingly well-priced souvenir shop for some silk wares.

Very interesting and worth visiting at least once.. The guides gave a very good commentary on the difference buildings we visited. However we were disappointed we could not take photos inside the buildings.

Beautiful, fascinating.. The house itself is lovely, furnished and decorated with all manner of antiques. The tour was short but thorough, informal and relaxed, but still very informative. Our guide was sweet and confident, and spoke very clear English. Thompson was a fascinating character, and this was well worth the visit.

One thing you must do. This is a collection of old Thai houses which Jim Thompson moved to this area in Bangkok. It is just lovely, mostly teak with many antiques.Absolutely lovely smiling Thai staff who can't do enough for you. There is a restaurant which is also open at night, and was great.Its down an alleyway but there are security people all over the lane and the premises itself, and there is a free ride to the main road for your safety.There is a also a shop there where you can get genuine Thai silk products.Very atmospheric, and a piece of old Thailand which is fast disappearing.

interesting. We visited the Jim Thompson house for something to do for a couple of hours when we were in Bangkok on business. I did temples and palace on a couple of previous trips. The house and garden were interesting. We had to wait around 30 minutes for an English tour which lasted around 30 - 40 minutes. Strangely they hardly touched on the silk trade in the tour. It was mostly about the house which was very nice and interesting.

Beautiful traditional architecture. Beautiful home of Jim Thompson who disappeared never to been seen again. Lovely furnishings. Informative tour. No shoes allowed on tour to protect wooden floors. Nice gift shop selling Jim Thompson silks (and cotton shirts). Worth the visit.
Nice place to visit. A wooden traditional house in a wonderful garden.The restaurant is good and you can go back down town with boat. An interesting experience

An oasis of calm. When you tire of noise, crowds and litter that permeate Bangkok, this oasis is a lovely escape. It is a bit hard to find, but it is worth the effort. The house is lovely and is very well kept. The gardens are delightful. The only downside is that tours are mandatory, and sometimes there is a wait. Our English speaking guide did not speak English particularly fluently.

Great House, but its just that. A house, you get a 30 minute tour with 12 other people and then get to roam around the gardens. Its all very nice indeed but its a little dull and i would only go here to fill a few hours. Including travelling there and back.
Beautiful home of the silk king. The grounds around the house offer a lush garden and the inside of the buildings are beautiful. We enjoyed the guided tour.

jim's house is beautiful but.... cross the canal and visit the old neighborhood with the original (muslim) weavers. It is fun to see the real thing, in the real environment! And yes their handwoven goods, freshly made, are two-three times cheaper as at Jims place, and soo much more authentic!

Very interesting. A 45 minute tour of this classical Thai architecture buildings. Tour guide was very good - interesting and considerate. Beautiful but small garden. A nice little cafe for a cool drink.

Very boring and high price. This was sold to me by travel agent who said it would be an amazing museum talking about the history of Thailand but really was just an old house with some fancy scarves for sale. The tour was really boring and I am not sure why they charge so much.

Very nice silk, but not so nice customer service. I bought 4 silk scarves, very pretty, spending about 6ooo baht. I made my purchases in transit at Bangkok airport, which was the first of 3 stopovers before arriving at home! An 18-hour journey around!The ladies in the store were very "forcibly" gentiles, making me feel embarrassed. I understood that their "look at me from top to bottom" (proposal always linen scarves, reporting that prices were very expensive everytime I was wondering about), was caused by my clothing.A simple jeans, a sweatshirt and sneakers are certainly not a guarantee of good shopping, for those shallow!And embarrassment grew even more so when I pulled out the boarding pass in first class ... Since then the annoyance was clear from them, became false kindness..The scarves are very nice, but nowhere in the world have been treated in this manner and amazes me that happen just in a nice shop and especially in Thailand, where hospitality and kindness are one must!
History & Art. We visit the Jim Thompson house every time we visit Bangkok as each guide points out different pieces of art to emphasize. The restaurant is a nice addition.
Shopping for silk. You could call it the birthplace of the Thai SIlk trade: a gorgeous house, and some lovely items to purchase.. if you like the gorgeous silk and all the fab colours!

Beautiful House. This is a great stop if you are interested in seeing an mix of American/ Thai architecture. If this sounds remotely interesting then make it a priority to go. The tour is a perfect length and we really enjoyed our time there.

The Silk handicrafts at Jim Thompson are recommended as souvenir.. A quite big complex filled with museum and handicraft shop. Many silk or cotton merchandise are available here with reasonable price and great quality.

Welcome change from Thai history. The Jim Thompson House is well preserved and offers a lot of history that is different from that of Thai history given that it is the story of an American who moved to Thailand and was successful in the silk trade.

The Houses that Jim Built. Jim Thompson was the gay American who saved Thailand's silk industry. As you might expect, the place where he lived is very special. Three traditional Thail buildings were literally turned inside out and attached to create a rambling mansion, which he filled with an eclectic collection of beautiful furniture, oddities, curiosities and pieces of art. Consider Jim Thompson's house an essential stop in a first-time visit to Bangkok. However, give their restaurant a miss unless you like Thai food that has been stripped of any discernible flavor.

A man and business with a interesting history. The 100 baht ride or $3 US in the Tuk Tuk delivered us close to (too smelly to pull in) the famous Jim Thompson house which has a great history of a mysterious entrepreneur. Jim Thompson was a World War II veteran who started a silk business in Thailand after the war. Thompson seemed to have a love for the Thai people and the Thai people clearly love him today. After he made his fortune in the silk trade, he built the “Jim Thompson House” using his American architectural background and with a Far Eastern influence, he created a unique residential compound that is open to tourists since his unexplained passing. The story that we heard in Thailand is Jim Thompson was out for a walk in the jungle and maybe a tiger ate him since his body was never found. However, since Thompson was ex-CIA (if you’re ever “ex”) and he prepared a “paper” leaving all of his possessions to the Thai people, I get the feeling that he might not have been “ex”.  Regardless, it was a beautiful compound with much priceless art, a cafeteria, and of course a gift shop. I was so taken that I went over budget and purchased a Jim Thompson silk tie and pocket square with elephants for 2000 baht = $78 US which was non-negotiable unlike the tailor shops.If you enjoyed the blip you will find more travel detail at the dog’s biog check it out:http://shoethieves.blogspot.com/
will be back. spent a few hours at JTH and did the guided tour. Will be back to have a longer look around and have lunch next tome and wil also buy some silk.

a very famous house in Bangkok. The house is another interesting spot for tourists beside Grand Palace and Thai temples. For Thai people, the house is historical because it represented how foreign people fell in love with Thai culture so they embraced it. In this case, Jim Thompson was one of the farang who deeply appreciated Thai culture so he also acted locally despite of his background as a foreigner. If you like people history, I recommend u to visit this place which is easily accessed by any public transportation.
Nice piece of architecture. Tour is interesting and not too long. An interesting collection of traditional thai style houses joined together.

Definitely worth the visit. We weren't sure what to expect but had heard about Jim Thompson house, his work, dissappearance and the work of the foundation to keep the house and gardens in their original condition. As part of the entry fee of 100 BHT we were given a compulsory english speaking guided tour who provided us with insight into the life of Jim Thompson, but most of all the architecture and individuality of the houses he created from different styles of Thai homes. The collection of art, ceramics, scultures and furniture are truly beautiful and have been carefully maintained by the foundation and staff. Only a short walk from the National Stadium MRT station and at the end of a dead end street - it is an attraction in Bangkok not to be missed.
Great place to relax. Total opposite to hectic BKK. Very easy to find. Do not hesitate, there is story to hear, things to see (and buy ;), nice restaurant to eat, and just relax...
Worth seeing. The tour is not very long and the house is beautiful. Great way to see what houses are like. The store is great. The products are beautiful and not too expensive.

A piece of American quality in Thailand. The fact that Jim combined several houses to his one house reminded me of Hearst Castle, but this time, it was done with taste and continuation in style. It was well maintained and the hand of the American organization was well felt in its management of the grounds and the commercial attention it generated.

Worth the visit!. For the fee you are paying, it's worthwhile coming to this place for at least once to learn about the Thai culture as well as the history of Jim Thompson. It was a very enriching experience and I did enjoy myself. The guide was also very friendly and approachable. You can actually come here first thing in the morning prior to shopping as it is quite near to the Siam shopping area, roughly 5-10 minutes travel time by cab.

Thai tradition and quality silk. Visited the JT house twice and both times I enjoyed the experience. It feels like an oasis of calm and tradition in the middle of a bustling city. The house and garden layout, antique furniture and art is authentic and gives you a glimpse into early 1900 lifestyle though it was built in the 1950s. The shop has some very good quality pashminas and other silk products, I purchased one for about £40 and received much pleasure out of wearing it back home.You must try the lychee smoothie at the restaurant, it's so refreshing !
peaceful and soulful. not a place everyone might like,....nothing jazzy or glamorous BUT...perfect for HISTORY lovers + people who like to discover the unknown..this place is for you ...

Convenient Location and Good Tour Guide. Walking distance from National Stadium station. Tour guide elaborated the background of Jim and the various hybrid of culture seen both in and out of the house. Not a very big place, a good way to spend a fun short afternoon before heading for a high tea or dinner.
great to visit. very good place to see a part of bkk heritage enjoyed it more than expected . one wonders what happened when he disapeared on holiday
Interesting and quiet place. Nice if you want to have a break from shopping and all the noise. Interesting tour through the old house of Jim Thompson.
Worth going. value for money, tour guide at the house was excelent. There is a restaurant there which is great. I enjoyed it.all.
Beautiful garden. The garden is awesome, the antiquities collection is even more, the house design is worth the visit, definitely tour the house is a must in any visit to Bangkok

oasis in bangkok. Beautiful traditional house and interesting story of Jim Thompson. Well worth a look. Go back to the restaurant for dinner - great meals and they had a '1 for 1' (2 for 1) drinks special.
Beautiful teak buildings and lovely gardens. Beautiful building worth the tour. We also were able to see the tedious silk making process which was very interesting.

Nice house. This is a very nice and very old house, which is quite unusual now in Bangkok because nearly all buildings are very new. This house they did good job to keep it old style. I thought the tour was a little bit boring but maybe interesting for older people.

2nd visit, rather more regimented now. My 2nd visit here, the first 10 years ago when visitors could roam freely with camera in hand. The beautiful buildings are still the same, the interiors are magnificent, all well kept, but must now join a scheduled guided tour with shoulder bags locked away securely beforehand & photos (of interiors) forbidden. Worth a visit.
An American-asian fusion. I found the house to be awe-inspiring and the guide spoke excellent English. The restaurant, although a little pricey by Thai standards cooked absolutely delicious food
nice house. nice house and heard a lot about him and his brand. I bought two scarves and compare to other stores they have more color selection and better quality but the price is lot more though.

Peaceful place to visit. Our second visit to Jim Thompson"s House.
Beautiful Teak House full of antiques and art works. Relaxing Tropical Gardens.
Quite a story about Jim Thompson.
Small entrance fee and you get a guided tour with interesting commentary. Tours go at very regular intervals.
Then have a cup of coffee at the lakeside Restaurant.

Fascinating Story. For background read a biography Jim Thompson: The Unsolved Mystery by William Warren. Thompson, an OSS agent, stayed behind in Bangkok after World War II, and became the worldwide marketing genius of the Thai silk industry. He disappeared from a Cambodia Hotel on Easter Day 1967. Theories abound. His house is lovely, though I couldn't imagine living there. The gift shop is full of lovely Thai silk.

An oasis. Lovely gardens and interesting architecture. The tour felt a little "stretched", but it gave a pretty good view as to how he would have lived.Nice demo of silk works going on and the restaurant was nice. No idea why they don't let you take photos though - the elements seem far harsher than anything your camera could do.

Unusual aspect of Thailand. It's stepping into a different world, and Thompson's life was fascinating. An impressive collection of Asian art in a real setting. My son, who had been a few days before, convinced me to go with him a second time - it's that good. Our guide (on this second trip for my son) was extremely difficult to understand; her accent was way too thick. I noticed some of the guides are understandable and some are not.

Easily accessible, more like a boutique with historical displays. A very unique place, a good way to learn about the traditional architecture of Thailand. A great collection of antique displays, also good and very polite tour guide during the presentation of the house. The only complain is lots of mosquito and it was really hot and humid. Anyway, this is Bangkok. Also, their restaurant serves good food.Some tips for muslim traveller, on the opposite of the river live a large Muslim community. There is also a mosque for praying purposes.

A nice place. This is a perfect visit if you are tired of seeing temples.You discover a place full of arts and typical thai pieces of history. It gives you an idea of the will of Jim Thomson to gather all these precious items such as statues, paintings, furniture. 100 baths entry the tour takes 35 minutes

Great tour guides. I wasn't expecting much when we came here. I thought we'd end up walking around, checking out the silk store, and leaving within an hour. I was pleased to be wrong. After paying 100 baht per person, a pleasant English-speaking Thai guide led us around and discoursed knowledgeably about Jim Thompson, the house, Thai traditions, and silk productions. There were lots of interesting things to see, like ancient buddhas, fanciful chamberpots, and even an intricate mouse-house. Unfortunately, it was raining hard at the time, so weren't able to explore as much as we wanted to.

More of a shopping destination than an tourist site. This is a fine example of what a teak house looks like. Have fun looking around. But overall, it is a shopping destination with many fine silk garments. If architecture is your thing, head south on the skytrain for an all day visit to Muang Boran, a 5 star historical/architecture destination on the edge of Bangkok.

Brilliant tour!. Jim Thompson's House is beautiful & well preserved. To walk round the house, you must book on to the tour. which is reasonably priced This lasts just under an hour. Our tour guide was great and very funny - I wish I could remember her name. Impeccable English and interesting stories. The gardens were lovely and lush. The shop had loads of great gifts in it.I would highly recommend a visit if you have time in Bangkok (after all, there is so much to do).

A unique historical site. This house is a hidden gem, a lovely, quiet aside from the hectic pace that is Bangkok. Regular tours of the traditional Thai houses Jim Thompson modified as his home are held in a variety of languages. The rooms are furnished and decorated as they were by Thompson. The entry fee is modest. The gardens are lush and tranquil. There is a lovely restaurant and coffee shop and, of course, an extensive Jim Thompson Silk Shop, which also includes silk making demonstrations on it's verandah.

Beautiful Thai houses. It is located at the center of Bangkok, walking distance from National Stadium BTS (Sky train) station. The staff were friendly. The English-speaking guides were nice and provided good information. The houses are very beautiful and impressive.

Thai history. Really enjoyed visit to Jim Thompsons house. Loves learning more about the culture and heritage as well as the investment in Thai silk. Shop was beautiful but expensive. Just round the corner from our hotel so easy walk.

Bit of a Tourist Trap. Worth a quick stop, but if you have limited time, I would drop this from your list.A series of old, traditional Thia houses put together to create a home for Jim Thompson. Mr. Thompson is credited with reviving the Thai silk trade after WW II.

Surprising. The museum we wanted to go to was closed so we ended up here. Actually it was amazing as there is alot of thai architecture and art. Despite being a silk merchant there is not just loads and loads of silk as I thought there would be. Really worth the visit and the tour guides (which is included in the price) are really lovely and willing to answer questions.

A Surprise. The Jim Thompson House has been described in many travel guides as a must-see attraction but quite frankly, the descriptions were quite boring. Still, I made the trip and certainly was not disappointed. His house is beautifully designed with antique buddhist art and furniture. The guided tours were well informed and eager to answer questions. Not to mention, there is a small art gallery featuring Thai artists to the left of the entrance, near the gift shop, which is easy to miss but worth a visit!
Brilliant Place. Loved this place. A quiet oasis in a very busy City. The house and gardens are both interesting and tranquile

Stunning place. If you love timber and silk this place is definetely worth a visit. You need to take the house tour to see how he lived and the silk display is fantastic and Im sure you will come away with a few pieces to give as gifts

Good for adults and kids alike. A tranquil setting, well organised place, frequent guided tours in English and French, good for kids too (they can play with the turtles under supervision of one of the staff), nice shop and cafe with very good baby changing facilities in the ladies loo! Free shuttle back and forth from the BTS, they have thought of everything.
Lovely. We really like the ambience and atmosphere. A great day to spend an afternoon. But the price ticket was a bit high.

Very professional. If you visit this "museum" you will be taken on a guided tour of the place. The guide we had was excellent in explaining the history of both Thailand and Jim Thompson. The "house" is very interesting.
The store at the house is very well stocked and priced to market; not a ripoff.

A must see in Bangkok.. Every time we visit Bangkok we always make the trip to this place, yes sometimes the group tours can be a little overcrowded however just being in the peaceful surrounds of this place is more than enough to escape the bustle of Bangkok and for 100 Baht it really is worth the visit. The cafe serves beautiful food and all the staff are extremely friendly and helpful, yes the gift shop may be a little expensive however it does help the foundation so like any onside gift store prices a always going to be a little higher.
A great value tour. This tour is cheap and very interesting. The house remains much as it was when Jim disappeared. A fascinating insight into times gone by.
Charming, see a time and place. Loved the shaded gardens and Jim Thompson's impeccable taste. Worth the hour or so to take you back in time to Bangkok of yesteryear...
Wonderful experience. Loved the history of this beautiful place but suggest they include some information on the actual silk and the silk making during the tour.

Interesting, but a bit overrated.. The tour of the house and the live display of turning raw silk into yarn were interesting, but I wouldn't call it a must-do. The lunch at the restaurant was quite tasty and relaxing, and we found some good gifts at the shop, though they are a bit pricey, even for t-shirts. You can do the tour and any additional walk around in under an hour and a half. I'd recommend not spending much more time than that and allocating more to the flower market or Chinatown, which were much more interesting to us (and FREE!).

A great place to visit.. Jim Thompson is a good place to visit. They have this private tour in this place so you dont need to book in your local tour.This place is a relaxing place to go. Considering we came in this museum after all the temple trips. Its really odd though that he just disappeared out of now-where (dadadadaaam!) And the silk quality is really something to try on.
Happy Jim. It was house of silk dealer - Jim Thompson. The design is the combination between Thai traditional house and modern style. The garden is manificient!
a nice place to visit. a must for those into interior design amazing teak house wit alot of history behind it Very ice tour we enjoyed it

This is where you should head after the heat and craziness of the Grand Palace. After visiting the crowded palace, this is the perfect destination to get some energies back: fresh air, no crowds and a nice restaurant.
Besides, the house is actually very beautiful and it has some very interesting pieces.

Thai Silk & Artifacts. There is a half hour tour that you can take around the house. Inside you will see many of the statues and cultural artifacts Jim Thompson collected. There is a lot of history in those walls.

Good Products;Uncertain Prices. The product range and quality of the items sold are good.The only problem is the non uniform price policy.At the Jim Thompson shop near Marriot Pattaya the prices were the lowest.Though claimed to be tax free,the prices at the airport are either equivalent or more than those in the city.

I love the ceramics. Jim T was a visionary who not only had an eye for true Thai form.. but also did a great job to preserve a piece of history. I know he pioneered silks - but really he also made his mark in preserving a wonderful collection of old buidlings and beautifully decorated them.. plan 2 hours here.

Very small but nice old Thai house and antiques, plus a cute garden and some silk. The main interest of the visit is to admire the old Thai houses bought and reinstalled along the canal by Jim Thompson. They're fully furnished with antiques, including some very beautiful Buddha statues. You're compelled to visit with their guides, who are very friendly and educated but will not let you wander too much, except in the small garden. The place has partly built its reputation on Thompson's mysterious disappearance, and the bookshop offers biographies that attempt to solve the mystery. While I'd not describe the house as a priority for people visiting the city, it's still a very nice, atmospheric location. The easiest way to reach it is to ride on the SkyTrain till 'National Stadium'.
Beautiful house. Beautiful house and gardens, comprehensive guided tour. Any European would love to live here. Very expensive restaurant and had better meals elsewhere.

An interesting peep into an intriguing life. The 45 minute guided tour of the house is very worthwhile, my young guide was very sweet and funny, although stuck to her script in her charming accent. The old, traditional houses (he joined 5 together) are filled with antiques, paintings and sculptures, he collected over the years and left much as Jim Thompson had it, before he mysteriously disappeared. This is a little oasis on a canal near National Stadium station on the BRT, the museum has beautiful gardens, a cafe and shop. Great place to relax and get away from the retail frenzy nearby.

Don't feel the need to disappear into Bangkok to see this. First off--make sure you get off the BTS at National Stadium and not at Siam. The maps make it seem like you can walk from Siam, but unless you want to walk around motorcycle taxi drivers gambling underneath bridges and through people's homes, you are much better off walking a short distance from National Stadium. When you arrive at the Jim Thompson House you'll pay 100 baht and be placed into a group for the compulsory tour. We had about half an hour to kill before our 12:15 tour started and it was extremely hot outside and we were being eaten alive by mosquitoes and pesky flies. The gift shops aren't good time killers unless you want to pay 2,400 baht for a small handkerchief sized silk scarf. You'll have to put any bags in the provided lockers which is a pain (and I saw several people on the tour that didn't actually follow this rule) for the half-hour tour. Our tour guide spoke excellent English, but she didn't tell me anything that I hadn't already read on Wikipedia. The actual tour only shows you a few rooms in his house and you can't take photos inside the house. I had high expectations for the Jim Thompson House but after my visit I know I'd be better off doing my own research by buying a book than relying on this tour.
Very nice house with an authentic feel. After visiting Wat Pho and the Grand Palace this is a quiet oasis within Bangkok. The house is beautiful and the tour (30 mins) was very good.

Interesting Architure, worderful Silk. If you like Hermes Silk products, you will adore Jim Thompson,
as the quality is similar but much much cheaper.

Nice. Jim Thompson house is a nice traditional Thai style house made with teak, with pretty gardens that are nicely presented and maintained, although none of these things would make me come back. There is obviously some nice silk here too and if I was interested in silk I probably would have loved it, but I don't so I didn't.

Interesting to know about the antiques kept in that attraction.. Went to this recommended site of interest, it is not a big attraction that requires u long hours but a short trip after ur shopping adventures from the main street of Siam . There they show u the antiques kept by Jim. The interesting building that was build with river transport and the mix of culture in the way the house was furnish and design. Silk is not the main story but u may catch some glimpse of silk making in the process (not in the mass scale method). U could either join this attraction after ur shopping or vice versa. It is near to RBK and Siam discovery. Accessible thru BTS.

A bit of a tourist trap. The place is really nice but not worth the time or the price. If you are in Bangkok for a week or so then by all means stop by and check this place out. But if you are here for a short time then go somewhere else and give this place a miss. The tour that they give is kinda long and boring. They just show a nice house and several nice pieces of artwork. Honestly my favorite part about this place was feeding the goldfish in the pond outside.
a quiet area to spend time trying to look for old bangkok. you can imagine how Bagkok was 30 years agio and it is like another tripo in Thailand. Expensive shop but easy walk around the property

The Teak House of Bangkok. Wonder whether it is the only remaining Teak House of Bangkok. If so, in one sense good, since too much teak has been logged, but sad if other old ones had to go to leave space for shopping
A Must Do. Great Athmosphere, Interesting architectur and a nice Cafe to have a fresh Coconut or an Ice Cappuchino. Takes around 90 mins to fully appreciate.
Dull. Maybe I am just not sophisticated enough to appreciate the wonders of the silk here but for me it was not an exciting experience and not cheap either.
Really boring. One of the most boring places I came across in Bangkok... not really sure what the big deal is about this place, didnt excite me at all.

One of the musts in Bangkok. Nice to see this fantastic villa in combined western-Thai style. Antiques collection is impressive. Pity that the canal next door smells like an open sewer and high rise flats make the place feel a bit cramped. Also watch the very slick "Bangkok jewelry scam" operators that approached us as we left the museum to head to the sky train - there are no government owned jewelry shops nearby, and the one-off reductions these shops offer still leave their wares way too expensive.
full of atmosphere. A great option to see one of the mainstays of Bangkok lore. Lots of beautiful items available and an all around great place to spend an afternoon.
love it. one of the best places to see a traditional thai house. and the very interesting story of jim thompson is worth some reading

...nice silk. Obviously they have some nice silk here and the house and gardens are quite beautiful but I got bored after half an hour, so wouldnt consider as being a must see attraction but somewhere to go if you are really into silk or just in the area looking for something to do.
Great attraction!. It was good value for money, really intresting house, our guide was excellant and told us lots about thai houses and their lifestyle. Well worth a visit!

Stunningly beautiful. I just found the tranquility and décor of this house, so close to the chaos of Bangkok, a total pleasure. Some of the antiques and pieces placed around the house are just exquisite. I would happily like to have them in mine!

okay. It maybe a novelty for some but I did not find anything exceptional. It is a well appointed house, a cluster of small cottages actually built in Thai/oriental style, made of wood. But frankly don't expect much or else you would be disappointed like me.

I wish I had found this place sooner.... Throughout my numerous trips to Bangkok I have never been been here, until now! Gorgeous architecture and intriguing story. if you are a big textile lover like me, someone will have to drag out outta here. Awesome restaurant... and I wish I had found this place sooner! Will be back... (*^-')/~☆♪

Very interesting. One of the few places in Bangkok which you can go via Skytrain. The place is quiet and very well kept, again like most attraction and monument in Bangkok they are quite full of interesting things to see and quite big, so it will take at least half a day to visit. Also you need to wait for the guide tour on your own language in order to start the visit.

An oasis in the city. This is a little oasis in the city that has great historical value. You can only visit the buildings by going on a tour which takes about 45 minutes but gives you the information you need to appreciate the place. The grounds are lovely and it is an easy place to find if you are near MBK.

Delightful docents provide an enlightening visit. This is not a massive site but it is packed with many artifacts. A short walk from the Skytrain downtown, it's down the soi (lane) in a quiet enclave. The guides assemble small groups and lead you through the restored Thai houses. There are works of art, household items and the structures themselves. Allocate about 90 minutes once you begin the tour. There's a cafe but prices there are a bit high compared to local alternatives. (Start with lunch at MBK and then walk over here.)

Peace in the concrete jungle. I strongly recomend a visit and guided tour of Jim Thompsons stunning timber house. Very tranquil and full of treasures PLUS the guest lavatories are very clean ! Jim Thompson silk ware can be bought at the adjacent shop. It is expensive by Thai standards but it is special.
A nice house. A verry nice house of Jim Thompson. Wood is the word for this house. The rooms are verry nice and for each room, he had a vision that we can look at today.

Great classic architecture. Pure Thai classical upscale house of all teak full of Asian treasures. Go to Siam Skytrain station and take the stadium train to the end and go one block North. There are signs.

Still loving that Lemon Grass juice. wish more places served it! delightfully fresh, light and delicious. heaven in a glass. and a nice accompaniment to fragrant or spicy Thai food, when it's too early in the day for a cold Chang beer. too bad the servers are so uppity.

Interesting place to visit in the middle of Bangkok. Been to Bangkok several times but first time to visit Jim Thompson's House. Was not disappointed. Tour guides were knowledgeable and gave a detailed story of Jim Thompson.The house itself was just beautifully made in teak wood. Lighting was dramatic but guests can't avoid the smell of the canal which is literally beside the property. So the odor might turn some people off but otherwise, enjoy the visit.

Ok. One of the main reasons we came here was due to the high scores on tripadvisor. Have to admit I am not really into the history of fabric in Thailand which didn't help, although if you are into that kind of thing you will like it as it is well -organised and they do have some beautiful pieces.

Worth seeing!. Would recommend this to anyone who likes nice houses/homes. Very peaceful place, superb teak house, lots of antiques, lush greenery. I was sorry we didn't have enough time for the restaurant, it would have been a lovely place for a meal.Easy access by BTS; good value!

One place you MUST see in Bangkok. During more than six years living in Bangkok, this is the one place I could always take visitors to WOW them. A collection of six traditional teak houses assembled in unique style by the American who revived the Thai silk industry after World War II, this is truly an oasis in the city. It is a true gem -- a small glimpse of the Bangkok and the Thailand that once was. If it's your first visit to Bangkok, beware of the touts at the top of the street who will tell you the house is closed just on the day you came, and try to steer you somewhere else. It is open 364 or 365 days a year.

Informative as well as beautiful. Jim Thompson's House was the first attraction we visited on arriving in Bangkok and I was not disappointed in the slightest. The house was not only beautiful, showcasing fantastic architecture and interiors, but the tour was also informative about the house itself and Thai culture and home life. I really felt it was an excellent way to begin our explorations around Thailand. The admission fee was a snip at just £1 each (student fee for me) and £2 for my partner (general admission). Our guide spoke good English and was very friendly. The restaurant, where we ate lunch, had a good selection of tasty Western and Thai dishes. Considering it was situated at a main tourist attraction food prices were reasonable. The gift shop was a little pricey, but then I suppose that's what you pay for Jim's own quality silk!
Great restaurant and lovely old home.. The Food is super in the restaurant and it is fantastic to see this old home and its great design and features.

Excellent tourist destination. This was an affordable and beautiful place to visit, with extremely efficient tour guides taking us all around the compound and through the house. No photos are allowed within the house, all baggage is to be stowed in free lockers before the tour starts and shoes have to be removed before ascending to the second storey.The store is lovely, but there is an outlet located close to a Skytrain station. Lots of good gifts there on the fourth floor.The demonstrations of silk threading and weaving at the start of the tour were also fascinating, and the tour itself was most informative, if a tad terse.

Great "quaint" experience.. A must for visitors to Bangkok. A visit to the famous Jim Thompson house will reveal traditional Thai architecture with a touch of western influence. Beware the Tuk Tuk drivers claiming "the house is closed today"... they just want to rip you off, the house is open 365 days a year.

Oriental fairy-tale. If you're looking for some "old Siam" atmosphere this is the address for you. Charming house, amazing history of the owner and the great cafe with fishpond to restore after the guided tour.

Interesting tour. Visited here whilst in Bangkok on 9.8.12. Fee was only 100 baht per person. On the way there we were told by two people that the house was closed - do not believe them - it appears to be a scam so they can suggest somewhere else to take you!The young girl who took the tour was very willing to answer any questions and added lots of additional information. Well worth a visit. Very peaceful surroundings.

very well presented history and tour. A nice slice of Thai history involving an expat (CIA?) american who revived the Thai silk industry to internetional trade, Thompson collected a series of old style teak houses and built a larger interconnected residence and gardens on the canal. Very informative tour, many language options, pleseant guides and staff, a small imtimate look into an expats experience in Bangkok. Plan 1 1/2 - 2 hours minimum, and located near the National Station BTS. Worthy of a nice, relaxed break from hectic Bangkok.

Not a must, good second option time filler. It iwll not make you understand better the Thai culture. It is quite a modern house from somebody who even installed air conditioning in his office... Teak red painted house. Well organised guided trips, 35 minutes. Good restaurant in the premises. Enjoyable though.
Good but over priced. Great selection of silk and probaly the best in BKK but if you search the city you can find better prices
Worth a visit!. We really enjoyed this visit and exploring the house! Amazing to see the house and the details in the rooms. Beautiful garden area surrounding it also.

really cool stop off in the middle of the city. So interesting to spend an hour here and see this house and sit in the garden. they have a nice restaurant there too. With plenty of shade trees around and places to sit in the garden it's a nice place to get out of the city heat and see a traditional style home.

Nice house in the middle of Bkk. It's just around the corner from Siam Square and MBK indoor market. A real oasis of calm in Bkk. The house itself is beautiful but what made the tour for us was the guide - she was very funny and told a lot of interesting stories about Jim Thompson.

Curiosity Factor. I had no idea who Jim Thompson was before going to Bangkok. His disappearance intrigued me and that is why I wanted to visit his house. The house has some beautiful pieces of artwork as well as Burmese buddhas. There is also a nice restaurant and gift shop on the grounds. However, if your time in Bangkok is limited then the Jim Thompson house is something you might want to omit from your "to see" list. Please note that we had difficulty finding the location itself - the tourist map was not accurate and the locals had difficulty giving us directions. You can take the BTS to the National Stadium. It is within walking distance from there.

Something different. Nice relaxing place that is completely different then everything you will ever see in BKK. If I liked it? Yes and No. So if you have time and you're done with all the typical thai stuff, i would recommend going there. if you are on a tight schedule, i would skip it

Very nice building, very professional staff. The house and the garden are very nice and like a small oasis in the city. The staff is very professional and charming. It is possible to see the worms producing the silk which is nice for children to see. The house is not easy to find but is worth visiting.

An interesting man's extraordinaire house. Conveniently located by the National Stadium BTS station stands what is (or what used to be) Jim Thompson's home. The house's unique architecture and history that lies beyond it makes the Jim Thompson's house worth the visit.Adult's pay 100THB and students pay half the price for the guided walking tour in English/French. The tour guides and staff are friendly, welcoming, and very hospitable. See and listen to the stories of Jim Thompson and learn a little about the Thai culture.

An amazingly beautiful house, right in the heart of Bangkok. What an amazingly beautiful house; even in its current central Bangkok location it feels very calm and serene. I had the misfortune of timing my visit during a sudden monsoon shower, but the staff were on hand to tackle this minor inconvenience with umbrellas. All visits are guided (30-40 minute tours) and you will need to book yourself on one in your language once you arrive there but they are very frequent. Entry costs only 100 baht (£2) per adult and it is easily accessible from the nearby Skytrain station. Unfortunately no photos are allowed to be taken in the magnificent interior, so you will just have to come and see it for yourself!

Must see attraction. I think the Jim Thompson house is a must see if you have a few days in Bangkok. Located 3-5 minutes walk from the National Stadium (Silom line) BTS station it's very easy to get to. The house is actually not that old but the buildings were built with traditional Thai techniques and style. The architecture, art, and gardens are beautiful. I have been twice and both times the guides spoke excellent English and the tour proceeded smoothly but did not feel overly rushed. That's saying a lot for me because I worked in a museum and like to read every label so basically all tours are "rushed" for me! There is a wonderful shop with Thompson Thai silk items and books on site but bring your pocketbook, the silk is high quality (I think, I'm not an expert) and prices are not cheap. The profits go to the museum though so it's well spent.

Can't miss. The visit to the house-museum can be more or less interesting, according to what you already know about Thailand... but the restaurant is great. You'll be able to "safely" try some Thai dishes with a spicy level adjusted to an average Farang taste. For shopping, this is just one of the many JT shops in town and airport.

Nice house. Nice visit. Nothing special. Good to spend 3 hours. Lunch and a quick visit. All visits are guided. You need to book once you arrive there. The restaurant is good. Worth the trip. Very relaxing (after 2 pm). There is a pond with fish and turtles for kids. Great to keep then busy.
Beautiful piece of architecture and interior design history. Absolutely worth a visit, especially the shop where you can find the most beautiful and good quality silk cushions, ties, linens, etc.

Interesting. Nice to see an old style Thai house in the middle of busy Bangkok. Originally 5 houses which were re-assembled to create on large house. Admission price reasonable and frequent guided tours.

A small quit heaven in Bangkok. This is a very place to visit and certainly do not forget a stop over at their restaurant! One of the best Thai restaurants in Bangkok. Their mango juice is just Jummy!

Interesting. We did not really know much about the man before coming to Bangkok. The tour if the house was good value and the guide was very friendly but the level of detail provided was very low. The house was interesting and we spent a fortune and the Jim Thompson shop. We had lunch in the restaurant which was also good quality.
Worth a visit. An interesting guided tour of the property and antiques of Jim Thompson. Beautiful setting and gardens. Well worth a visit, only 100 Baht entry per adult.

Exceptional. Great venue for events and invite your visitors to Thailand. Food is good, more geared towards the foreigners but Jim Thompson has a history and the magic to go along with it.Worth the visit.

Very interesting, and an oasis of calm in busy Bangkok. We enjoyed our tour around the house, gardens and of the antiques collected by Jim Thompson. Our guide was very knowledgeable and polite and the house and collections are beautiful.

Fun and relaxing. If you loved touring Hearst Castle or the Winchester Mansion (I'm a Bay Area girl), you'll love the Jim Thompson House. It's on a much smaller scale than the two homes I just mentioned, but it's a sweet little tour and the gardens are incredibly beautiful. It's right off of a Skytrain stop, so it's easy to get to and they have tours in several different languages. Try not to read too much about it ahead of time, as you'll pretty much know the entire tour guide script! Enjoy!

A unique sight in Bangkok. Come take a look at how life was in Bangkok a century or two ago. The setting is pleasant the estate is gorgeous. Linger, have some tea, snap some photos. This place is a five minute walk from the metro stop. If you have the time, come spend an hour here.
Glimpse into history and mystery. The Thompson house is full of wonderful antiques. It's presence adds ambiance to the mysterious disappearance of its owner.

great for a few hours away from the pool.. jim thompsons house is beautiful and for a few hours of something different a must while you are in bangkok. you can go by taxi and it is just 100bt for your entrance. you are taken on a very interesting tour then you can stay as long as you wish to visit the store and relax in the lovely cafe on the lake. your trip can last for 1 hour of 3 or 4 hours , its entirely up to you.

Interesting, informative.. The house is not especially grand, but the structured tours are really interesting. Jim Thompson had a beautiful collection of art and antiquities and the house is architecturally quite unique. Taken together this gives a real insight into Thailand's past.

Interesting.... but worth going? Yes. Interesting but some might find it boring. Nice to learn about Thai houses and what JT did when building his own and how he changed things. Only 100 baht so worth the hour if you are in the area.
One of the "things to do". A pleasant outing and good spot for a light lunch. I suggest looking thru the exhibits first and then must take the guided tour of housing complex.

Beautiful House. We arrived at Jim Thompson's house in the rainy afternoon, yet The rain itself gave the space more aymosphere. Unfortunately you're not allowed to browse around the house without a guide, which we thought was a bit annoying seeing as our guide spoke English with such a thick Thai accent it was hard for us to understand her. However it's a nice way to spend an afternoon and the restaurant server tasty Thai food too.

A haven in the middle of Bangkok. This place is a little haven in the middle of the madness that is Bangkok. The tour is a must just to see the beautiful teak construction and find out more about this amazing man.
Beautiful.. A lovely little oasis right in the heart of Bangkok filled with antiques and artwork. Very interesting tour and historical information.
Well worth a visit. Stepping back in time and great overview of history and events. Enjoyable and well recommended for anyone visiting Bangkok.

Great selection of silks ,,lovely Thai style house to view ,good restaurant. If it's quality silk you want ,,with nice styles and selection of silk made items ,,they have it here,,while there visit the teak woodThai house ,,and stop for a snak at the restaurant ,,clean ,,simple creative menu ,,everything was tasty ,,it made for a pleasent afternoon ,,with friends a little,,more exspencive,,,,but quality is excellent
you should go. The price of B100 for what you get see is amazing. A tour guide and gorgeous grounds. Jim Thompson collected many artifacts that are on display.

Finest quality to a fixed price. Jim Thompson house is definitely a must see for fine silk and unusual clothing. As a small size modell:) I must warn you the sizes are American sizes, and those are as well known in an "S" simply not available. However go and breathe the time where the fashionable 50's have started the world's sapidity of fine quality Asian fashion silk hand - made craft.

Good if you are bored. Jim Thompson was a transformative character in the silk trade for the Thai's and for his own pocket. He took a variety of homes from around Thailand and reassembled them in Bangkok. They are interesting to see, but not one of the major attractions in a city of much. It feels as if the Thai government is somehow behind this whole experience.The food is pretty good at the restaurant, though overpriced. Overall if you are bored and want to see how an American in Thailand lived, go there.

Must See - The Mystery. Check out the history...take the tour....look across the klong (canal) to see the still alive Muslim community who helped JT develop the Thai silk industry....In the house, imagine the dinner parties with famous people Jim entertained....How, why, and where did Jim die?

Really valuable. Interesting and beautiful.
Of course silks is expensive in this place, but nevermind you will find other places for cheaper offers.

Well worth a visit. Jim T created this house from several other, traditional, wooden, Thai houses. Well worth visiting to see the style and learn a little about this mysterious man and his even more mysterious end ...

Imformative Tour. Very interesting tour of the Thompson House. Shared a lot of inforamation about the silk industry and the history of the artwork. I enjoyed it very much. We had one of our best meals on the street near the Thomson House. Spectacular!

beautiful place and interesting visit. Absolute must on a visit to Bangkok. Ineresting place, full of curiosities. The house and the gardens are in perfect condition and allow the visitor to imagine why Jim Thompson fell in love with Thailand. The staff are delightful although not always understandable. The fact that the house is on a canal has the negative side effect of producing some foul smells.
Wow. Highly recommend as the house is a wonderful blend between asian and western design. Fusion pioneer. The collection is really interesting. I just wonder what happened to Jim when he disappeared.
Nice old buildings but martinets showing you around. The kind of place I would rather wander around at my own pace rather than be obliged to take a guided tour. Buildings and decor lovely though.

Experience the traditions of Thailand. This is a great attraction and very cheap to visit - only cost about £2.50 each adult and this includes a tour around the house as well. The guide was very friendly and answered questions on request. You can choose what language to have the tour in and then are given a time when this starts. We were only waiting for about 10 minutes for an English tour. The tour was very informativeOnly down side is you can't take any photos inside the house. You can take them around the outside of the property though and it is lovely to experience. There is a quaint restaurant which is at the side of a pool filled with fish. We didn't use the restaurant as it was close to closing time so not sure what it is like.Staff are very helpful. You are asked to store your property in a locker (free of charge) when you are taken around the tour but you can take cameras/cam corders with you but cannot use them. You also have to remove your shoes when going inside the house (Thailand tradition). We were there in total for about an hour - very nice to see a real Thailand house with a twist and hear about the reformed silk industry.
Quiet paradise. What a gem. Nestled in quiet lush gardens, this place is a must see. Have a meal by the pool and just enjoy.

Nicely preserved and excellent tour guides. Very interesting place and incidentally its walking distance from MBK Mall, if you exit from the side of the mall that has the basket ball courts (there was a flea market on the courts the day we went). The property is beautifully preserved and is a memorial to Jim Thompson, an enigmatic figure who contributed a lot to the development of the Thai silk industry. We took a guided tour of the place, I think the admission charge was 60 baht per person (dont remember exactly). The tour was really enlivened because of the excellent guide who had a brilliant sense of humour that helped us appreciate the tour better.

Elegant calm and bygone beauty. Our last bit of sight-seeing was a visit to this beautiful oasis amid the hustle and bustle. Beautiful artworks and some quirky things as well - we enjoyed the chamber pot for little girls. An excellent exhibition above the store gave some indication of contemporary art in Bangkok.

Worthwhile. You'll get to see and learn a few interesting things in this neatly kept house museum: To juxtapose the traditional Thai residence structure/architecture to the western influence Thompson incorporated; Fine decors; Extraordinary life of Thompson.You have to go on a guided tour to see the place, but English ones start frequently. Just walk in and get a spot on the next available tour.
Real tradition. The guy who set up this venture must really had unusual vision. What a great work he started and those after him have done. The silk design and products were just fantastic .

Worth visiting. A nice place to visit and interesting. Here you visit the American architecht who build his house using a mix of Thai and French style (i think). You are shown around the house by an English guide (can also be Japanese and French language) and given information about the rooms and about Jim himself. Entry fee is 100 baht per person. Worth visiting.

Surprisingly tranquil in the heart of busy Siam. This is a lovely place to visit, if only just to get a bit of peace from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. You can't wander around on your own unless you do the tour. Our tour guide was lovely and very informative. Not really suitable for kids, they'd get bored easily and you'd get sick of telling them not to touch anything.... Nice thing to do for some time out.
Well-curated and really worth it. The house is spectacular, and the exhibition space well worth visiting. A tranquil spot with loads of history, well worth visiting.

A lovely peaceful place. It's worth taking the trouble to find (walking distance from National Stadium skytrain stop) as this is a lovely place. You have to go on an organised tour to see the house, they do them is various languages. After the tour you can wander around the garden which has a lovely fishpond and luxuriant vegetation. It is a very peaceful place full of interesting objets d'art. The gift shop has some exquisite but expensive items for sale.

A Traditional Thai Building. What a guy Jim Thompson must have been, a superb teak house transported into the centre of Bangkok. Well managed and organised tours and all just off the sky train. A must visit in Bangkok

Okay but nothing spectacular. This was highly recommended to wanted to experience it but was just a very average tour. Jim Thompson's life wasn't that spectacular and his property isn't even particular Thai as he merged different styles. The cost is reasonable but the tour didn't hold my imagination at all and would definitely not be something for younger children. I think if you aren't Thai then there are much better things to see that help you understand and love Thai culture; this is a nice collection but for me seems strange to see a house of a successful expat while visiting a country.Jim Thompson's personal story is not interesting at all.

Fantastic Thai home. No, most Thais never lived this way. Yet if you wander down Soi Kasemsan 2 away from the National Stadium (a SkyTrain station) you'll find the modern compound (enormous in size for central Bangkok - think Dumbarton Oaks in Washington DC) of seven traditional Thai hardwood (teak like) homes Thompson purchased, dismantled and reassembled without nails (wooden pegs etc) to form his extended home next to a canal from which he hosted the best dinner parties in Bangkok in the 1960s while he built the prosperous silk textiles and clothing business that still bears his name. Enjoy the gardens and the extensive collection of art and Buddhist statues. Regular tours in Thai, English and several other languages are available as is a nice gift shop. Relax in the bar/restaurant for good food and drink and don't miss the 5-star restrooms.
great. Great place to visit if you want something without hassle.It was a friendly place and the attraction was great

Interesting house. we went to see the house. and must say were impressed by the architectural and the lush garden and pond.
as for the shops i prefer the one near pat phong better. more interesting.

Nothing much at all. This is nothing but a sham.A run of the mill place which must have been good a few decades back.there is nothing of interest and even the products are very average and when considering the price of a tie, the quality is abysmally poor as you can get a tie at at quarter of its price or lesser in the footpaths (sidewalks) or pavements of Pratunam or the numerous shops which are dotted down Sukhumvit road.A waste of time for a tourist!

Too much hype. Went there because my wife wanted to go. They Have silk there that you can purchase but it is really over priced, it is more of a tourist trap. Maybe trap is not the correct word. I guess it is mainly there for the torist. I'm glad of the experience to go there but once is enough for me. Some people will love it, me not so much.

Very Cool Place. This was my favorite place to visit while in Bangkok as far as sights go, the architecture is amazing and the building were very neat. The background story was very interesting and it was great to see. It was easy to find and is in a cool area. The food at the restaurant was also very good, and I highly recommend eating in the beautiful restaurant after the tour.

Very worthwhile. Jim Thompson, acknowlledged 'father' of the modern Thai silk industry, created an idyllic home from three lanna-style traditional houses and packed them with regional museaum-quality treasures. Close to MBK shopping centre, it is a tranquil haven of calm set in beautiful gardens. You can buy items from the JT shop - usually rather costly - or just enjoy the great surroundings. Worth a visit.

Boat away from there. Nice, well looked after, a bit touristy, but he, what do you expect. The restaurant is a bit on the pricy side, go walk out of the soi, turn left, better deals allready. For the more adventutuas ones, take the boat on the left, dir. Ban Kapi, almost every stop is more Bangkok then when you left it. 20 Bath to go all the way to the bigg shopping mall in Ban Kapi, then go 'happy land' for outdoor restaurants, thai music and more 'thai'fun. (is this 50 words already?. hope so hope so hope so. Thia is silly, but very reconizable!)

Sad that Jim disappeared in the peak of his career. Thailand wouldn't be what it is if not for the famous house of Jim Thompson. It's very charming and very traditional Thai. The man disappeared for unknown reasons and he put the lowly Thai silk as a tourist product to reckon with.

great value for unique Thai produce. gorgeous scarves and pashminas and wonderful liitle containers for cosmetics, glasses, jewellery, tissues etc that are great gift ideas with fetching patterns and wonderful gifts

Go there!. The silk producer's house is a special corner of bangkok, probably the one I liked the most.It is an elegant, refined place, where you can find quietness and fresher air than elsewhere. The silk shop is expensive but worth the money.

Favourite attraction. I absolutely adored the Jim Thompson Museum. Not too expensive and you get a guided tours in small groups, available in multiple languages. Breathtakingly beautiful, delicious little restaurant at the museum. The staff was just so friendly; my friend had a weakness and they all took care of her, finding her a place to sit with a cold towel to put on her forehead and cold water to drink; we were very impressed and grateful!A Must.

Interesting history. Apart from the beautiful silk that is produced & sold thru this outlet.The house is so beautifully kept & is a showcase of old architecture.The story behind Jim Thompson is very interesting.Certainly worth a visit.DON'T be put off by the people,who tell you it is Buddhas holiday & house is closed!This is i am sure a ploy to get you to go elsewhere!

Architecture and Art. This is a great museum to see an up close example of traditional Thai style - with eclectic us/euro mix. The story of of Jim Thompson is interesting and the museum's small size, small fee of 100baht and well organized tour is relaxed experience in the middle of a busy shopping district...on site restaurant is a nice place to cool off, too.
Interesting place. i find this place very calm and fresh...its a little green sanctuary in the middle of a hustle bustle city.Lots of antiques to admire
great place to by souvenirs. They have a great selection of good quality silks here and it makes for a good place to buy gifts and souvenirs for friends and family back home .

Puts some context to the famous brand. I have visited the house three times.I want to rebuild a timber house like this somewhere in thailand..without any nails...The house is about the core vision of Jim Thompson and his desire to preserve the best of thailand culture and handicraft. I definitely recommend seeing it.
Very high quality. as a textile technician - I can say the quality of their textile is high. Their silk is great
Idol house. Thanks to our young age that we were able to get a discount. What a save! The house was fantastic, every little detail was well thought. The tour guide was very knowledgeable.
Love going back.. Sometimes we just go there to eat and hang around, and of course we loke the t-shirts they sell.

Peaceful and pretty, well worth a visit. A most enjoyable place to have lunch, the tour through the buildings with their beautiful and unusual furnishings was very interesting, as was the chance to see silk being spun from the silkworm cocoons. The shop had some beautiful items for sale. Over all thoroughly enjoyed the visit.

Beautiful and interesting. A lovely was to introduce our children to Bangkok. Traditional house with sublime furniture and antiques. The guide was incredibly informative. Great value and a wonderful way to spend a few hours away from the busy Bangkok streets.

A hidden gem. Hidden away downtown but well worth the effort to find it. Traditional Thai house and lovely lush gardens. Very good guides, beautiful setting, quality venue. Restaurant was lovely and stylish. Shop was pricey as they didn't sell tourist nicknacks but lovely silk items. By a canal which was a bit pungent on e afternoon we visited but that didn't detract from this being a calm, oasis in the centre of Bangkok. Provided golf cart to take us to the stadium train stop.
A beautiful respite in a non-stop city. What one would imagine old Bangkok to be like, some excellent antiques and the guided tours are very informative. Stay for lunch to extend the tranquility.
Thail Silk. The quality is really amazing .. price too! Did not purchase anything but the sales people there still serve u with a smile.

Faaaascintating. This was an exceedingly interesting place, the life story of Jim Thompson and the house he assembled really caught my imagination. Not only that but the architecture, furnishings and gardens are all gorgeous.

Nice way to spend an hour. Easy walk from National Stadium sky train station. The mandatory tour is efficient and nice. The house itself is very nicely designed and enjoyable to visit. His collection of antiques sprinkled around the house is pretty impressive. The garden and the grounds are maintained very meticulously. The art center is quirky and IMHO missable. There is an attached restaurant though I did not eat there.
Tranquil spot - interesting architecture. Nice Escape from the heat of Bangkok . Interesting tour, very good cafe and store

Well worth a visit. Had wanted to visit this on 2 previous trips -finally made it and loved it. The tour is excellent and cheap! Do not be put off by the taxi drivers and shopkeepers who tell you it is closed until lunchtime and try to recommend other places to visit.

Nice afternoon. Tour is good and lunch at the cafe is relaxing. The site gives you an interesting perspective on Thompson and the silk trade. If you like to shop for silk the store is great. For men, the ties are outstanding.

An interesting place to visit.. Jim Thompson s house was interesting and the free tour was excellent. The gardens are also beautiful. We also had lunch here which was very nice and at a good price. I wouldn't bother doing this as an organised tour as it is only 100BHT to get in and then you get an English speaking tour included. The shop is worth looking at too! You could easily do this attraction in 1 1/2 hours.
Beautiful. Learn about the olden days of beautiful Jim Thompas house and culture of thai antique. The surrounding is beautiful a different from the bust and busy Bangkok.
Lovely historical houses.... The serene setting in the middle of Bangkok gives you a taste of the past in an oasis..
A gem next to a busy canal. Perfect example of Thai living and architecture. A tour through all the rooms gives a good feel of the time Mr. Thompson lived there.

An interesting slice of Thai/Foreign history. I had read much of the intriguing story of the life and mysterious disappearance of Jim Thompson, the man credited with modernizing and internationalizing the Thai silk industry. Due to his OSS/CIA connections, conspiracy theories abound as to what happened to him. That we shall probably never know, His legacy is rich though and we can get a sense of it in the superb Jim Thompson house with its unique architecture and many antiques, a beautiful tropical garden that he loved and of course the company that bears his name, with beautiful silk products. My parents were here on holiday, so we thought we'd check this out. We thoroughly enjoyed it, especially the English tour that gave many insights both interesting and amusing into this remarkable character who chose to make Thailand his home, whilst bringing great benefits to the art of Thai silk making. Our tour guide, a very sweet girl called Ben, spoke good English and was very kind and helpful, helping my Mother (who has knee replacements) over the indoor steps at the entrance to each room.The only downside to an otherwise very interesting experience was in the restaurant, where the staff were both miserable and inefficient. The food itself, though not cheap was very tasty and well presented. It is very unusual in Thailand to encounter such sullen service and it is the only time in any restaurant where I left no tip at all. Despite this, I thoroughly recommend the attraction, you just might want to skip the restaurant and find somewhere you can get food served with the famous Thai smile!
A building on its own. Love the closeness of the boutique to my hotel however could not find anything to my fancy over there =(

Interesting Thai architecture. I can see why Jim Thompson decided to live in Thailand and promoted Thai silk. It's exotic colors and vibrant culture makes all of Jim Hompson's products world class. His house is a must see because it's authentic Thai and it's beautiful.
Architectural Marvel. This is a beautiful house. The architecture is marvelous. The guided tour is interesting. Must visit.

The King and Us. Too bad Jim Thompson disappeared lo the many years ago, though I guess he'd be dead by now anyway. After constant badgering from my sister I recently toured the Jim Thompson House in Bangkok and found it to be wonderful. Mr, Thompson is widely credited with saving Thai silk production by commercializing it after he moved to Thailand in the late 40's. His silk was used for the costumes in the 1956 film adaptation of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "The King and I." A professional architect, he designed and built his house using a recombination of six or so old (100 years) traditional Thai houses. It is a truly beautiful spot.He famously vanished in 1967 while on a visit to the Cameron Highlands in Malaysia and has never been found.

Relaxing sanctuary in the middle of the busy city. We visited on our own after taking the train to the closest station. It was beautiful, the guide's english was great and the information really interesting. Exquisite silk items to buy if you have the dollars! Had lunch sitting by the pond and enjoyed every minute. Everyone should take the time to enjoy this place.

Gorgeous house. Really beautiful house in the heart of Bangkok, although the surroundings make it feel like you're in the middle of the forest. Guided tours in many languages (included in the entry free) and a lovely shop with silk products. Gorgeous on site restaurant but a bit pricey. Small lockers available before the guided tour.

A lovely place to visit for an hour or two. Jim Thompson House can be a little difficult to find even with all the signs but friendly locals will always show you the way. If you get their by Klong take a right turn when you alight at the closest ferry stop and walk along the canal for 100 metres or less and you're there. If you come by trian bring a map. It is a series of lovely, old buildings with the most beautiful art treasures, magnificent furniture, and of course the finest silk products available for sale. The guided tours run every half hour or so and the 100 baht fee per person for the tour is mandatory but necessary given the number of people visiting the house. Well worth doing for any one interested in interior design, architecture and the like.
Great Insight. Visiting the House on the Klong gave great insight into the mystery surrounding Jim Thompson. His contributions to Thailand were so much more than simply reviving the silk industry.

Beautiful home. Tranquility in the heart of the city. Just toured this home last weekend. Arrived just in time for the 5PM (last) English guided tour. All tours must be guided. The cost was 100baht per person for entry and this covered the guide. She spoke English very well, and provided information on virtually every artifact throughout the home. The tour lasts for 35 minutes. No photography is allowed inside the home, which is kind of a bummer. All-in-all it was a nice, quiet afternoon stroll through a lovely home, filled with interesting objects. A must see for visitors to the city.Photos are allowed in the garden, which is amazing.
good to do if nothing else. good for a look see interesting if nothing better to do
Good tour Great food. The food is great. The tour is very informative and interesting. Nice peaceful setting

A nice little trip back in time. It is hard to believe that this residence is in the middle of a bustling city. The life and disappearance of Jim Thompson is extraordinary, and how this residence came into being is full of history. Well worth a visit.The store is full of magnificent silk items, but has a price tag to match - better to visit the factory outlet if you are after a bargain.

We want to live here!. We loved this house! We took the Skytrain (we rarely take taxis!) & walked to the location.
