I borrowed this description from the website… “The house consists of a complex of six traditional Thai-style houses, teak structures that were purchased from several owners and brought to the present location from various parts of Thailand. Construction of the Thai house was completed in 1959.”. When you turn onto the street/alley that takes you to the museum; you will pass a couple little shops along the way… we did our shopping on the way back! The prices were fair & they were friendly! (visited Mar 2010)

Beautiful silk products. This is a great place to brouse, perhaps purchase... but pricey. However the collection of neckties... hard to resist. Also toys for children, lots of scarves, purses... not a bargaining market, but high-quality at high prices.

Something to do. My family and I really enjoyed the JT house. The tour was informative and it was a good pace for a rainy day and the guide spoke really good english. after living in thailand for 2 years i even learned a few things! the restaurant had really good food for a reasonable price (not as cheap as on the street, but not as expensive as a 5 start restaurant). The shop has some merchandise, but if you are looking to get gifts their stores and outlet stores have more selection.

An excellent place to visit. I loved this oasis in the middle of the city. It was easy to get to and find. Just near the National Stadium BTS station. 100 baht entry fee was very reasonable. You have to take a guided tour but this was very informative and available in Thai, English or French and then were starting every 15 mins or so. The house is really amazing and there are so many artifacts to see and most are just out as they would have been there when he lived there. You have to lock your possessions in a free locker but that was no hassle so you can't take bags etc in or take photos in the house.As a 40 something traveller this was one of my favourite places to visit in Bangkok - a taste of what life would have been like in the past. Well worth a visit.

Must see. We love Jim Thompson silk, so this was a must see. It was great to wander around the beautiful house and museum, and see how he lived. Situated on a canal, you could imagine what it would have been like 50 years ago to live here and what Bangkok must have been like all thos eyears ago.There is a restaurant and shop.It is easy to get to, just a short stroll from National Stadium BTS.Go and see it!

Nice House with good restaurant. Jim Thompson's House is unique and well kept. If your expectations are not too high you will enjoy the visit. There is not that much to see, but it gives an idea of how life was in Old Bangkok. Unfortunately the House is next to a very smelly Klong. But inside the restaurant you won't smell it. The food is good but on the expensive side, as Jim Thompson in general.
A Jewel. A must see Bangkok treasure.A lovely restaurant and super atmosphere. Well worth a visit.

More than just silk. This is a place where you can take alot of time or just a little. After a day of active sightseeing, I took a small group of high schoolers there and we spent several hours thoroughly enjoying everything. Take the Sky train, its easy. Get your time pass and go enjoy a drink around the fish pools. Walk the compound, realize that you are on a canal, see the spirit house, watch them dye silk. Eat at the restaurant, the prices are reasonably good. Then if you must, go buy something.

a great man. in my opinion, this is probably the best place in bangkok to see,particularly for people who wants to know about thai lifestyle.jim thompson was an american but loved thailand and its culture.it is fully reflected in this lovely house museum. this is very well kept and maintained.it needs more promotion as most tourists do not know about it.the attached shop in the compound is very good.

Beautiful restoration and preservation... A real step back in time. The house has been preserved and in parts, restored to it's former elegance. It evokes life in a time gone by and is definitely worth a visit. Give the cafe a miss unless you just want a re-energising drink.

Well worth a visit. The Jim Thompson house is a window into Thai culture,ad a definite MUST VISIT site for all tourists who wish to get an insight inot Thai culture and tradition.The silks and artefacts on display are awesome.
Well worth a visit!. Very beautiful, interesting and such an unexpected pleasure.

good museum. excellent well laid out museum situated in the centr of bangkok - 5 minutes from the national stadium skytrain. It is laid out in traditional thai decor and the informative guide adds to the experience.

Slightly boreing. The visit to the J T H was not what I expected I found the tour was very short and not worth the entrance fee there is really not much on view and frankly I would give it a miss as there is better attraction to see in Bangkok

The most beautiful place in Bangkok. If you can only visit one place whilest you are here, then this is where you need to go. I have been here six times with visiting friends and family and I am just as amazed and impressed every time. It really is the most beautiful place in this town, a piece of history and harmony in a fast growing, ever changing city like Bkk.

If you are plenty of time you could visit it. But if you do not have time I do not thing this would be something relevant to see. Beautiful, well explained, well displayed, but Bangkok offers you a lot more things considered relevant to a traveller

An often forgotten about attraction but a Bangkok must see!. We visited the Jim Thompson house following a recommendation from a friend, we didn't know anything about it but decided to give it a try. It's easy to find and get to from both the Sky Train and in a taxi. The house is in the middle of the city but it feels as though you're out of the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. You can take pictures from the street but if you want to walk around entry is extremely cheap (about £1) and this includes a tour, which appeared to be offered in a number of languages. The house itself is home to a some of the Jim Thompson collection of Asian antiques/furniture. Our guide was fantastic, very knowledgable and happy to answer many questions. We enjoyed this place so much we also visited again this year. Do not miss out on this when you're in Bangkok and take your camera as the house is set in stunning gardens for you to have a wander through.l
Enjoyable Tour. This was a very nice tour and a way to see some more traditional architectural styles. The kids enjoyed the tour as well. Nice break from shopping and temples!

Explore BEYOND the Jim Thompson House. This is a lovely traditional Thai house museum, with an interesting back story. But walk along the canal behind the house, go through a waterside restaurant and over a bridge, and you'll be in the Muslim section of the city, a unique Bangkok experience.
Fantastic. Took a meter cab from hotel and what a great place super guided tour saw Thai dancing and silk being spun plus nice shop.

An oasis of tranquility in Bangkok. The tour through the house was interesting and gave one a very nice glimpse into what life was like in the past. Not really a tour for kids though; as lots of verbal information and beautiful artifacts to look at, but nothing of real interest to children e.g. to do; and touching is very strongly discouraged. Guides are beautifully dressed, well prepared and courteous; albeit their patter is a little roboti and over-rehearsed, and - while questions are answered - they are very good at keeping all on track as per the scheduled tour times etc. Also, one goes through the tour with a guide, at her fairly fast pace; and then are not encouraged to go back and look at anything again on your own and/or in your own time. But set in beautiful and tranquil gardens, and was nice to take some time out from the busy city.
An oasis of calm. Just what you need, when the traffic, noise and bussle of Bangkok is getting to you. A calming oasis, with the added bonus of great food, and a cultural time
Boring.... It's an very well preserved ancient Asian house with lots of antiques.Nice to see when you're in closeby but slightly overrated.

Really interesting experience!. After living in Bangkok for over 3 years I finally made it to the Jim Thompson House after recommendations from several friends. It is located right off the National Stadium BTS. The guided tour is informative. It was a nice break from the noisy Bangkok traffic. It was almost like a little oasis in the middle of a giant city. Well worth the visit for expats and tourists a like. The story behind Jim Thompson is quite fascinating as well.
Informative tour. The tour of Jim Thompson's house at 100 baht was great value. Our guide was knowledgeable and spoke very good english. We learned a lot about Thai culture and beliefs on this tour.

Loved it!. The tour was okay, lots of info but nothing really amazing about it. The food at their restaurant however was absolutely phenomenal. The prices are also very reasonable. I really loved the ambiance of this place.

Really interesting. This was a nice place to visit. The tour was interesting, the house and gardens are kept very well. The highlight for me was seeing the process of silk making and the cafe does fabulous drinks to sit for a bit in a nice tranquil setting.

Nice short tour of the beautiful house. The house is visited by guided tour only which runs about every twenty minutes in English and lasts about 25 minutes. The house is quite pretty and has interesting and pretty artifacts. The tour is informative and basic. Nice to see traditional Thai teak wood homes and local historical artifacts. Enjoyed the short visit (we spent about 1.5 hours there in total editing for the tour, exploring the garden, touring, wsyching a silk weaving demonstration and looking in the small shops onsite (postcards and card store and silk shop). The house is pretty conveniently located near national stadium stop, exit 1. Down the stairs from the station there is no sign which way to go, but if you stand facing the street/traffic, go right, within about 15 meters you'll see a sign post directing you to Jim Thompson house (you'll be turning right into the small soi). If you exit the bts station exit 1 and go in the wrong direction you'll end up at siam discover/mbk area shortly. So a visit to Jim Thompson house could easily be paired with a visit to this area as well, as it's only about a 15 min walk away.

Fantastic guide. Lovely grounds, like an oasis in Bangkok. A dream home of a very fascinating man. The guide was very funny and informative, making our visit a joy.We also had lunch at the bar and everything was delicious, not street vendor prices, but we thought everything was fairly priced.A must see in Bangkok.
Beautiful Haven in a manic city. A lovely house and incredibly cheap to have a look around (100baht pp). Lovely little cafe/restaurant if you're finding the city a little overwhelming.
Quaint. I loved the story of Jim Thompson, very sad that he went missing, he had done such good work here. I loved the little shop for postcards and prints
You love silk. you like to know more about Thai silk - go and visit the Jim Thompson house
Calm in a hot city. Well worth the visit, tranquillity, cool & a very interesting story.

A man ahead of his time. Jim Thompson was a visionary, and built this house with local architecture yet influenced by western ideas like an attached bathroom and western style windows. The house showcases glimpses of his life and his impressive antique collection. Well worth a visit.

Enjoyable tour. Really glad i made a stop off in this area of Bangkok to see this house. Its abit awkward to find from the skytrain station but worth the visit and good value. You have a guided tour round the house and its intertesing and informative about Jim Thompson, the silk industy and about ornaments in the house. After you can enjoy the gardens or have something to eat in the cafe onsite. Its a nice break from the hustle of the city and the house is like an oasis amongst the skyscrappers of the Siam area.
Neat little place. Interesting to see Jim Thompson's house, preserved as museum. The house also has a very large shop and a restaurant.

House tour. Didnt like our intital welcome to the house. Staff very abrupt in disinterested.Our tour guide for the house was a delight and very knowledgable. Enjoyed the history and contents of the house were amazing.

Oasis on the canal. Took us awhile to find this place but was pleasently surprised when we walked through the gates. The buildings are beautiful and the gardens very cooling and lush. The tour we did was cheap and very interesting through the main houses showing where this amazing man lived.The art gallery upstairs was lovely and the shop selling all the beautiful silk products was not cheap but with gorgeous fabrics and colors. It is right on a busy canal with long tail boats rushing past and the entrance is off a long narrow street off the busy main road.A real little oasis in this busy part of Bangkok.
Fabric Heaven. Beautiful products, but service could have been bit friendlier.

Oasis in the Sprawling City. Located on a canal just a few minutes from the most hectic centers of Thai shopping, JT House offers a romantic taste of the way things used to be. Enjoy the quiet and relaxing atmosphere of the dwelling of the Thai Silk King. Items offered for sale, while not cheap, are still very reasonable and some of the most beautiful available in the Kingdom.

must go place: restaurant wonderful and great value. It is one of the places you need to go when you visit Bangkok. Difficult to get to from Sky train..easy to loose..and lots of touts outside to make things uncomfortable. Inside it is so well organised. the restaurant is one of the best in Bangkok and very good value. The trip around the house is interesting but rather hurried. go there for the food..and atmosphere.

Organised guided tour. Ticket fee of 100 baht includes the guided tour - really worth it and good. Our guide is a trainee on her 2nd day and although she may have problem articulating certain words, we do not mind at all because of her humble, demure attitude. We understand perfectly well.
Worth a visit. Easy walking distance and well presented. Many things to purchase but not as cheap for some things

Definitely underrated. ~2-3 hours.. I thought it sounded a bit dull (just an old house, right?) but the guided tours were really informative, and the guide was happy to answer any questions and explain anything. The house itself was really gorgeous and unlike anything I had ever seen. It was a nice, calm vegetated oasis next to either a stream or canal. The food in the restaurant was good (though, being a tourist site, more expensive than outside) and the art in the gallery was neat too.

An Interesting Tour. If you like Jim Thompson products, you will find his guided tour worth the effort. His home and artifacts that it holds makes for an interesting tour. After this you can browse through their shop or wander around the area.
great stop in bkk. well worth visiting - a quick walk from the river taxi stop.

Better than I thought. How interesting can looking round someone's house really be? I thought. But actually it is a beautiful old teak house and the guided tours are great for providing information and pointing out detail that you would otherwise have missed. Easy to get to on the sky train or by boat.

An island of calm in a mad city. When you want for peace in a mad world this is the place to go It is a stunning building in lovely gardens Our guide was charming and the restaurant is a great place to relax They sell some nice (but expensive) silks too

Nice house... this is it. The house and the garden were really nice, you will love to live there. The visit takes around 20min all languages are available. However I did not feel really exciting visiting this house. I will don't avise you if you don't have many days to spend in Bangkok to visit this place.
100B/person

A must for fabric and style lovers. Eat at the restaurant then do the tour. Its interesteing and enjoyable, short but enough.
The food is great, we had lunch which was perfect.
Old world charm. Good for buying genuine Thai Silk and it is a great museum telling the story of how an American revived the Thai silk industry. Nice cafe too.
Lovely original Thai house. The man behind the beautiful silk prints you will see all over Thailand. Went for a afternoon, small but beautiful old teak house :-)

Beautiful Thai House with History and Mystery. What a delight! The story of Jim Thompson is a true Thai legend and the house is special and a unique place to visit and learn. Very atmospheric and many clues about a " ferang" establishingt himself and living in Bangkok. Good shop and pleasant cafe/restaurant too.Well worth a visit.
nice silk. it is nice to see products made out of pure silk but the entrance is i think a little expensive for the place unlike the other attractions in thailand.

Nice House and good restaurant. An Oasis in central Bangkok. Nice museum very well explained (they should have a Spanish speaking guide!) with lots of art pieces. Very nice restaurant with good food and very relaxing atmosphere.

This place was something to do, but just okay.. It was interesting to tour this house and get a feel for how an American mixed western ideas with Thai ideas to build his house. The story of his disappearance is really amazing (while they don't talk much about it on the tour - you can find lots of info on wikipedia).I had never heard of Jim Thompson, but then again, I'm not an expert on the Thai silk trade, so maybe that's why.It was nice they had an English tour for no extra charge. The tour was just the right amount of time, not too long, not too short.I wouldn't put this on a MUST SEE list, but it was something to do. Don't eat at the restaurant, the food is bad. BUT the mango passion fruit shake was delicious and perfect on a hot day.

Traditional ?. Beautiful house made of three traditional Thai houses, in teck. The interest of the visit is both the discovery of old Thai houses, and the art collection gathered by Mr. Thompson. The visit are guided, in several language and offer a glimpse of what was the Thai housing, the traditional art in Siam, and the life of Mr. Thompson who helped the silk industry in Thailand. It is somehow strange to visit one house that has been creating in damaging three traditional one (but it allowed the preservation of it). The deception is that the silk sold in the shop are not all made in Thailand (some are made in Italia), and not all traditional.

Another piece of culture. A nice visit to a very cool house. It is amazing how much thought was put into building this house. Mandatory tour in english/french/jap and I think Chinese. After a short 30-45min tour around the house, you can visit the other smaller house-turn-mini gallery, as well as take photos around the place. There is also retail shop right at the entrance, with a good selection. But I think there is an outlet store somewhere, and you can get the information here as well.

House of Silk & Where is Jim Thompson??. This house honours the story of Jim Thompson and his silk empire which is a mgic place to visit right in the middle of the city accessible off the trains. The museum visit through the complex is very worthwhile and a memorable place with great collection of Thai art and relics of the past. The story, the displays, the wonderful timber home, its shop and the displays of gathering the silk from the cacoons and how it ends up in the shop is a gem and one of the wonders of nature. Jim thompsons house should be a must on all itineries when in Bangkok even if it is a short visit, I would like to see more forensic resources allocated to find the remains of Jim Thompson with a reasonable reward with more effort to find the remains of Jim Thompson and close the chapter to honour a committed person who has given so much to his adopted home in Thailand.

A beautiful home and estate, but.... If I had one week or less in this city, I'm not sure I would invest time or $$ here. The tour was short and sweet, and the English/Japanese/Thai speaking guides were knowledgeable and friendly.I am glad I saw the place, because I was interested in the story of Mr. Thompson. This is presumably why people visit in the first place. The visit did help put a visual to the story. So, it is probably worth seeing, especially if you are either a silk industry buff, an int'l trade buff, a local Bangkok history buff, or some combination of those!One thing that I was put off by was the *very expensive* gift shop, which sold silk products that were labeled "Made In Italy"! Ironic at best, shocking at worst.

Not as good as it used to be.. The trip around Jim thompsons house is informative and interesting , you gotta do it the once.I actually went there 3 seperate visits for the food....which started as totally amazing and finished as quite dissapointing.They took most of the food items off the menu and ended up with a very short and very simple menu with not a lot to choose from.I bought the cookbook and most of the food in the book was served at the restaurant identical to the book...not any more.WARNING - ive been three times and every time on the way down the road to the jim thompson house ive been told that its " closed today " by some tout or local on the street. In the end i just told them " you talk bull$hit" and found out five minutes later all is open as usual.So skytrain to National stadium , get off , down the stairs and look for the signs to the house....ignore anyone that tells you its closed.
Bangkok Oasis. Very interesting house, garden and architecture. Learned a lot and enjoyed the beautiful lush gardens.

Worth a visit. I had not visited this place on previous visits to Bangkok - but it is worthwhile visitng. Tours are mandatory, but you are free to wander about a bit after the tours are finished. Felt there was a bit more quality Thai art on display at this house than at other locations in Bangkok
Hiding gem in Bangkok. Loved this house and museum. Exhibition was extraordinary!

Thai Textiles. If you really need to purchase some Thai silks and clothing then this is the place to go. Really like the long groovey table runners - can also get cheaper knockoffs at the markets and there is also a Jim Thompson outlet at the airport for a last minute gift.

Original Traditional Thai House. its close to our guesthouse, and its really represented the original traditional of thai house, very interesting and beautiful things inside the house complex. Beautiful souvenir shop too, but the price too expensive.
Gorgeous buildings. Really glad we went to see his compound of several teak wood thai houses. Better than any others that we saw and lovely collection of things displayed in the houses.

Back in time. The Jim Thompson House is definitely worth a visit. The serenity and the classic charm of the old houses is worth seeing, and, though some have suggested there wasn't enough to see, there was plenty so observe on the short 35 minute tour pleasantly presented. While obviously a commercial venture, we found the 2 hours spent there a welcome break from the incessant clamor of the city.

Interesting place!. How the place came about is such an interesting story. The place is near the National Stadium station and isn't hard to find. Entrance is at 100 Baht and open daily from 9am to 5pm. Tours take about 30 minutes only since the place isn't too big.

Creepy and sad. This house has been preserved exactly as it was at the time of Jim Thompson's sudden death. I am sure that you will agree, when you have a look at his bedroom and the adjacent room, that it has not been kept as he would have wished it to be left.

Calm oasis. This attraction is not only interesting historically but is a wonderful green oasis in this busy city. A small cafe next to a pond is a great place to recharge. One note: we have been coming here for years and we walk from the BTS station. When you leave the main drag and enter the smaller street that leads to Jim Thompsons house without exception someone or several someone's will tell you it is closed today. This is a ruse to get you into a tuk tuk and take you somewhere else. If you are there between 10 am and 5 pm don't be fooled it has always been open when we have been there - just keep walking.

A look into Thailand's cultural past. Whilst the house isn't terribly flash to look at, it is what's inside that counts. Great artworks and statues from Thailand's past, some going back before the 17th Century. The guides speak excellent English, and the tour is quick whilst providing information on Thailand's history and Jim Thompson's involvement in the silk industry.

I Want to Live There. An oasis in the middle of Bangkok. Thompson was a genius at getting Thai village homes, clustering them and creating a wonderful home. Great silk shop, kind of pricy, but you get the Thompson name.

Worth visiting. A very good tour guide made this experience come alive. We were too late for lunch and too early for dinner, but the restaurant looks inviting. The adjacent cafe was fun. Allow at least 90 minutes and visit the art gallery. An oasis in this populated city.

Our favourite place to visit in Bangkok. My husband had heard about Jim Thompson and what he brought to Thailand's silk industry but I hadn't. As it was close to MBK shopping centre, we walked over to have a look and I loved it. The tour was very interesting and the house sensational - beautiful carved wood with the most fabulous antiques. If only they could have turned their backs for a moment I would have snuck away with everything. The gift shop is exceptional too. I got most of my presents here including the scented candles. For the quality of the stock, the prices are quite reasonable too. I bought lots of the cards which are gorgeous and cost about AUD$1 each - a lot less than the $5 we pay at home. So I stocked up. Whilst we visited there was a huge down pour which made the tour very atmospheric - you could almost imagine living here in the 1950s with the luscious tropical gardens and ponds. I really enjoyed our visit here - more than the palaces and temples. Well worth a visit.

A charming glimpse of the silk industry. A glimpse of a brilliant man who revived the silk industry in Thailand and then mysteriously disappeared on a walk. Guided tours are good. Pretty garden and excellent cafe. Don't miss the shop which has very good silk products and a really good map of Siam
interesting. a real experience, giving a feel for Thailand. The story of his experience and the building it self was fascinaating.
Interesting. Bit of history of silk trade and chance to view timber house

Very interesting - like stepping back in time. Have been to Baangkok many times, but had never taken the time to see Jim Thompson's house until our last trip when we ended up with some time to kill. So glad we did, the architecture and gardens are beautiful, abd the tour guide very infomative. Highly recommended if you have a couple of hours to spare. So easy to get to as well via the BTS Skytrain.

Jim's house. This is a great place to visit and a very nice feel to the place a lovely atmosphere. There is a lovely gift shop and restaurant. The guide who showed us around was wonderful and very knowledgable. I really liked this house and it was not a comercial money making taky experience that i thought it might have been it was really a lovely place to visit

Nothing extraordinary!. I guess that if your staying in bangkok for 2 weeks you could probably visit Jim Thomson´s house and check it out. But is not worth it to loose 2 or 3 hours, having so many cool, interesting and cultural places to visit around Bangkok.The store is nice, but there are some Jim Thomson outlet stores in the city and some other shops at the duty free.Staff does not speak any good English, so you might not understand anything from the tour.The river next to the house smells worst that the sewers.
Calm setting. Nice place to unwind mid-afternoon with an iced tea.
A fine collection of history and art.. The house and the art collection are both exceptional and the tour was very well conducted.

Beautiful home and gardens, terrible cafe. Jim Thompson's home is beautiful, it's just not run very well.The tours are every 10-15 minutes or so and it seemed to be pot luck whether you got a guide who enthused about the subject matter, or one like ours, who recited learned paragraphs in broken english. The tour was difficult to follow as a result and we found ourselves drifting off a little. In order to preserve the house, it's shoes off, no photos. This is all very reasonable and you find the same in many restored houses all over the world. Unfortunately, for some reason, JT's house was as a result, a little joyless, taking itself very seriously.We ate at the cafe for lunch - the service was appalling (we waited 15 mins for menus and then a further 30 for food - cold salads - and drinks) and the selection a little dismal compared to real Bangkok.If you are really interested in the history of JT, worth a visit, if not, just go to the large shop - we had far more fun there!

smelly but nice. The house itself is great to see but the smell that wafts in from the nearby canal can be a bit annoying. It is within walking distance of the Pathumwan Princess Hotel and the MBK centre.

A bit touristy but worth a visit. It's almost amazing that such a nice, low building has survived in the middle of all the high rises. It's an 'historic' house (though less than 100 years old) that shows how teak buildings worked. It's quite a lovely building, set in a peaceful garden, with lots of antiques. Unlike the average museum, the antiques are where they would have been located in the house and aren't behind ropes or glass. Because of this, you have to take a guided tour and can't just wander by yourself. It's very popular but was really well organised with tours in various languages running every 10 minutes or so, all precisely timed so groups never ran into each other despite the relatively small size of the house. My guide was very knowledgeable and able to answer a wide variety of questions.The shop on site has some nice silk products, but they're quite expensive because they're 'Jim Thompson' silk. The entry fee including the tour was something like AU$5.It's easy to get to - only a block from MBK - and right on one of the klong stops if you're travelling by canal.

A legend's house - gotta see it. It takes a bit of walking to get there (at some point you think you're lost walking down the Soi / small street after you get off the skytrain), but it's well worth it. You can actually see the complete "contents" of Jim Thompson's house, buy books about him and go broke buying the beautiful silk products they have, and then have some lunch! The whole Jim Thompson story is fascinating, so it's good to read something about him before going, know how the house was brought from different places, get to know everything about his visitors, the food he prepared and his commitment to the Silk industry in Thailand. Really truly beautiful place. If you can get there on a klong / canal boat, even better (you have to get off at a not-so-nice stop, but it's ok.
A quiet and very interesting place. You may buy some extraordinary silk scarfes which you will not find in Jim Thompson shops in Malls or Duty Free. Unfortunately, the price is also extraordinary.
Wonderful. It was great to see the architecture and artifacts.Enjoyed the Thai dancer and silk worm demonstration

Serenity in the middle of bustling Bangkok. For more photos, you may visit my blog at http://PAOtotheLO.wordpress.comAny lover of the Thai Silk would definitely know who Jim Thompson is!Nestled in the bustling city of Bangkok, near major shopping centres, the Jim Thompson House Museum transports you back in time with its tranquil atmosphere and very traditional architecture.His house was maintained and opened to public as a museum and a reminder to what he contributed to the industry.The Jim Thompson House Museum is open from 9 am to 5 pm everyday with guided english tour every 30 minutes.
I didn't expect to like this. The collection of teak houses and antiques at Jim Thompson House are amazingly lovely. The restaurant was also quite good.

Beautiful design and style. If you love design, history, architecture, and/or textiles, this should be on your visit list. It was a little far out from where we were staying but we easily caught the Skytrain and walked.The house and surroundings he designed from traditional Thai homes is exceptional. The tour was interesting and there is a shop and pleasant cafe if you need a little water or beer to cool off after.

Interesting place with a great story. You can either take a long tour which will take a few hours or just a short intro with the tour guide. Either way you can´t get in without a guide. I´d say the short tour is enough, since I didn´t get the feeling that I missed out on most of the stories.Also go there for the restaurant, it´s really good!

An oasis of calm in bustling Bangkok. This is truly a spot of calm in a crazy city. Jim Thompson's house has been made into a museum and it is worth a visit just to see the gardens and ponds. Of course there is a shop and cafe, which you can visit or not. The house is series of buildings and the history of the man himself is interesting. It makes a change from the shopping malls and street hawkers, so worth a visit. It is easily access from the sky train.
Very interesting. It's nice to see all the antiquities being well kept in the gorgeous teak buildings
Our favorite site. Great guided tour, very doable, and such an interesting story. Plus, great gift shop!

Enjoyed a bit of history - gift items are a bit over priced. We enjoyed our visit, its very calm and relaxing after spending time in the city.Tour guides are very knowledgeable, no shoes are photos are allowed in "Jim's House".Really interesting to see a real Thai house and why certain things are designed the way they are.Grounds are beautiful and well looked after.Gift shop is over priced and no photos are allowed.

Visit to the Jim Thompson House. This was extremely interesting. Thompson was an American that settled in Bangkok and established a batik business. His house is filled with art collected over the years. The guided tour was great.

interesting to visit. Interesting to learn the story of Jim Thompson and walk through his home. There's a store where you can make purchases and learn more about the silk industry. I was just in Bangkok two months ago, but visited this house on a previous trip (Nov. 08).
Quite and good food!. yes, it is a quite and good place for eating. People usually come for visiting the house of Jim Thompson, but I prefer to make appointments with friends in this corner of BKK.

Well organized tour. I went on this tour 10 years ago and the structure has remained the same. The tour guide with the Jim Thompson foundation was lively, informative and has planned jokes. A nice addition this trip is the restaurant and bar. Another 2 restaurants are also at other locations in Bangkok.

Very interesting history. All of the temples were closed due to a Royal funeral, so we ended up searching for alternate excursions. This was very interesting to learn the history. The tours are well organized and very informative. You don't need much time here, maybe 1 hour.
Great way to spend a morning. Excellent look at a traditional thai house with a great story. Antiques every where and loverly guides make it special.

Intriguing story!. It sounds so dull.... Jim Thompson's house.... but the story behind it is fascinating.... well worth a bit of reading up before you visit. Lovely cafe and charming pond which we could have spent longer beside!

Lovely and informative. The entry is 100 bath and includes a tour of the house Jim Thompson lived. The tour was very informative and we have learnt more about silk and Jim Thompson's life. We were allowed to wonder around the grounds and the surrounding little houses. There is a nice shop where you can buy silk products and also a display how silk is made.

Worth finding.. Travelled by sky train, not well signposted but worth the hunting. Go out of sky train exit signposted jim thompsons, come down stairs to street and keep walking away from station/staircase. You will shortly see signs. Beautiful tranquility in the manic city of Bangkok. Lovely cafe!

House is Beautiful. Would recommend riding the water klong "taxi" boat that is available outside the house. It isn't a tourist taxi boat, but rather a local service. It is quite an experience and well worth the "not knowing what you are getting into feeling". A great way to get to the Golden Mount from Jim Thompson house.

Something to see. The Jim Thompson House is something I would recommend after visiting all your must see items in Bangkok. Take the tour, the history is very interesting. The house is Beautiful and there is a gift shop and restaurant on the grounds. Lots of interesting and probably overpriced items in the gift shop. Save your dining for one of the other wonderful restaurants in Bangkok.
Silk is beautiful. The Thai silk products are lovely. I didn't like being led around like a child during the tour.
old and new. Good to see the Thai colonial past and influence in this place. Nice teak wood.

A must visit!. I enjoyed entering the quiet paradise of Jim Thompson's house in chaotic Bangkok. Jim Thompson was an American Architect who settled in Bangkok. His house is a reassembly of a number of Thai houses and also displays his Asian art collection. Thompson is credited for bringing Thai silk to the attention of the world and their is a shop on the premise that sells some of these products as well as prints of old maps and horoscopes and cards.

Oasis in the City. I have been to Jim Thompson house on a couple of occasions, this time was to show family this great oasis right in the middle of a bustling Bangkok.The shop is great to have a little look around and to grab some well needed air con. The tour is great, it's very cheap THB100:00 pp which is really cheap for a great little tour.The restaurant is also great and sitting outside and enjoying a nice ice cold beer and trying some lovely food is highly recommended.It's a 5 minute walk from National Stadium, dress lightly as its hot (really hot) but great.
Nice retreat in the heat. Good tour, nice Restaurant, nice tropical garden to cool down in the heat of the city,

Okay - the teak house is nice but the tour is a little long for all their is to see. The best thing about this place were the spontaneous demonstrations - the gentleman getting silk form silk cocoons and the lovely Thai girl making traditional flower art.

Definitely worth a visit. We went to Jim Thompsons house one afternoon, on the recommendation of a tour guide from an excursion we'd been on. I can't say im particularly interested in silk or in Jim Thompson but the house and grounds are very pretty and worth a visit and the tour is actually quite interesting. It has a nice cafe where you can sit outside right by the koi pond. Everything is very clean and well maintained and the staff can speak many different languages. The only difficulty we had was actually finding the place, as its not signposted and its at the end of what looks like a small side road. We decided to get a taxi there but the taxi driver didnt know where it was so we ended up walking from one of the shopping centres and following our map. If you can find it its a great way to spend a few hours.

an interesting side trip. This busy tourist stop with informative guided tours in several languages gives visitors an intimate peek into a "real," non-commercial Bangkok. Surprisingly, little of the tour relates to Thompson's textile works, but the shop is a wonder.
Very interesting. A visit here will leave you with the feeling that you have gone back in time. It is very well organised and very informative as well as being a lovely place to be.
A Must. The history and architecture makes this the best secular attraction in BKK?
Exclusive Brand in Bangkok. office entitle is here, casual is here, bags, baby clothes...with good quality and in branded..this brand you only able to get it in Thailand.

If you want to see a traditional Thai house with museum pieces and shop for silk, this is a must see. I enjoy seeing Jim Thompson's House every time I go. It is a very short tour, but it is worth it to kind of magically step out of modern Bangkok into a more simpler time. Basically, you will be taken on a guided tour of his small house that still has most of the original furnishings. You will also get to tour his small yet lovely garden. You may have to wait if there are a lot of tourists there, but the times I have gone I have not had to wait too long. TIPS:1. Take the BTS and get off at National Stadium which is across from MBK. Go down the stairs that are the opposite side of the skytrain from MBK and then take your first soi (small street) on your left. Ignore the touts that may be there trying to tell you that Jim Thompson house is closed. You will have to walk about 100 meters down a less than appealing road, but the attraction is at the very end of the road. 2. Visit the Jim Thompson silk shop that is right on the premises. There is also a small coffee shop as well if you want to pause after your tour before heading back into the noise and excitement of Bangkok.
J T house. Nice interesting house to visit, great mini museum by itself.great silk shop

Interesting look at Thai silk history. Very interesting tour - available in several languages. Wee maintained site. hard to find down narrow side street. Locals couldn't point us there. Take the street address with you.
unforgetable place. Don't miss this place when you visit bangkok and enjoy drinking the fresh coconut juice in the restaurant...

Interesting, unusual old Thai style house. The historic house once owned by the Thai silk baron, Jim Thompson. Very cool to see the old teak wood interiors -- amazing its still here in the middle of bustling metro Bangkok. Some of the doorways are very small, so not advisable for big and/or tall people....
Put it on the list. A beautiful house in a great garden setting. Worth a look.

Really cool look at fascinating man's life. The Jim Thompson House is part architectural tour, part historical tour and amazing trip back in time to the height of the life of the man who popularized the Thai silk trade to the west. Take the river boat out the back rather than a taxi or sky train to get another look at Bangkok.
Amazing Silk. The best silk products in Bangkok. The tour throughout the grounds are truly something you don't want to miss.

Restful setting. If you want to get away from the hussle and bussle of Bangkok and like to learn abit about an American with taste come to this museum. Jim was a memebr of SS who returned to Thailand after the war on helped the Thai silk industry re-develop. Lovely selection of traditional Thai houses in a small tropcial garden full of bits he collected from the region during his life. Guided tour of museum offer for 100 baht and nice restaurant for a snack or drink afterwards by a small pool with Koi very restful

Nostalgic and Smooth as Silk. Jim Thompson was a bohemian who lived in pre and post war Thailand. He is known to have revived the silk industry of Thailand and is famous for supplying the silk used for the costumes of the original King and I movie. His great place in Thai history is mirrored in the house he built out of the original 6 traditional Thai houses. I was amazed by how preserved the house were. You can see Jim’s collections of silk paintings, buddha statues and much much more. At THB100, there is a 45-minute guided tour available in English, Japanese, French and Thai. A visit to Bangkok is not complete without buying a Jim Thompson silk creation. The house has an extensive shop housing the company’s newest and most classic products.

old colonial. A fascinating and very well guided tour very reasonably priced around the 1960s home of the "Thailandophile" Jim Thomson. His contribution to the development of not only the silk industry, but also tourism in Thailand, cannot be underestimated.

Great and off the beaten path. No trip to Bangkok would be complete without seeing this tiny gem! Definitely worth going out of your way to see this lovely museum and learn about it's interesting original owner.
Cool oasis and interesting house. Cooling oasis from the Bangkok heat and interesting tour of the house and a nice restaurant

Tucked away gem. Very easy to get to from the skytrain. Tours follow a script but informative non the less. Everyone on the tour wanted to live in this house. Prices high in the shop - go to the outlet instead

A peaceful haven. We spent a peaceful few hours at this tourist attraction. The tour was very good and informative and the gardens are wonderful. Do stay and eat at the restaurant. The food was excellent though servings are small. The exhibition was disappointing. There are a number of Jim Thompson locations in Bangkok and we really enjoy the architecture of the house as well as the shop in Silom. The products sold are of good quality but do not vary from year to year.
Wonderful and unique silk items. A great place to visit, walk around and admire the unique silk products. It is tucked away in a quiet spot but well worth the visit.

beautiful architecture. it was pretty near from National Stadium station, walk around 15 minutes lassing thru alley.. entrance fee with guidance tour cost thb100 per person, 25 years old and below can get a 50% discount for children price (have to show your passport)the 30 mins guided tour was good, though can tell that the guide telling a memorized story using a fluent english. I find the this place relaxing and comfortable.. May walk around and take picture..Had our lunch there at Thompson's Bar and Restaurant, the food was expensive as compared to other restaurant in bangkok, and it doesnt taste good. i ordered the same dish as i have ordered few days back in siam paragon and Siam Paragon Asian Kitchen Restaurant is way better than the thompson's.for this attraction, you may fit it in your itinerary for a quick visit and photo taking ..

A great side trip in BKK. The JT House is an historical marvel. You can see all that this impressive man collected and build during his impressive career in Thailand. Easy to reach from the National Stadium Sky Train stop. Allow about one hour.

Portends to be Siam -- But it Isn't. The Jim Thompson house baffles me. I don't understand why tourists flock here, request silk from here, or spend the time. I traveled with friends who insisted on visiting this attraction. I endured a boring tour through houses made up to look "authentic" Thai -- but they were not. The guides did a good job of talking through a practiced script, but ask a mildly complex question and you discover that the English is memorized not understood so much.Somehow this attraction has gotten the reputation as having great silk products. There are many other places you can get these products, of equal or better quality, at prices 70% or more below what you'll pay at the Jim Thompson House. I think there is a mystique about this place because of the oft told story of how the owner disappeared. Beyond that there isn't anything here to see. It's more of something people do to tell people back home they did it.I'd recommend you skip it all.Want a surprisingly good Jim Thompson branded event? Less than 10 minutes walk from the BTS Saladeng train station is the Jim Thompson restaurant -- down a confusing set of streets whose route is difficult to explain. This place had fantastic Thai food -- shockingly good -- but the prices were designed for Westerners only -- no Thai person I know would pay this much for Thai food. But it was one of the best sets of food I've eaten in Thailand.
Fascinating. The guides have great knowledge and make the story so interesting.

An interesting visit. This house was near our hotel and if you are interested in silk products it is well worth a visit. The house is a serene place in the city centre. The guides provide an interesting commentary as they take you round the house giving you a better idea of how some people lived in Bangkok. If you go to the shop make sure you have your credit card with you!!
This is a must when visiting Bangkok. A jewel in Bangkok. A shame they didn't allow you to take photoes inside his house.
Beautiful. Dont forget to visit the Jim Thompson House and then buy the souvenirs form the Shop ... they have very good pareos for the beach !

A must way some say. You pay 100 THB and that includes a guided tour for about 40 minutes. There is a restaurant there as well. We did eat there twice at lunch and once for dinner, at lunch is it okay, but at dinner is it too cold inside as to the air condition is set to a freezing level. During the dinner there was Thai dancing.

Great experience. I wasn't sure what to expect but was pleasantly surprised by how interesting and beautiful this attaction proved to be. It was a lovely place to while away a couple of hours on a very warm afternoon in Bangkok. Staff were so kind and informative. They even made origami cranes for our 6 year old boy to play with as we toured the beautiful garden and house.
Jim Thompson House worth a visit. Guided tour gave a good background of the house and the man. House and garden are very attractive. Oasis in a busy city.

Worth it.. Gorgeous relaxing space inside Bangkok. Nice cafe for a cool snack.
Note the shop here offers more products than the airport stores so buy what you like here.
Out of the way and only a small portion of the house is viewable. We were required to walk through in groups and purchase sarongs!
Great tour, very peaceful. Inexpensive very informative tour. Lovely peaceful location surrounded by the bustle of Bangkok. Bought a few bits in the shop on site.

Nice stop. Just as you think you took a wrong turn you're there. At the end of a cul-de-sac Thompson House is a real nice max one hour sightseeing stop to be squeezed in. The entrance fee includes a tour giving by well trained staff. Afterwards you will be tempted to by some silk products in the shop.

Worth a visit. Not only is the house itself, and the grounds it is on, quite a unique and impressive sight, but it also has a fascinating history and some beautiful art displayed around the various rooms of the house. The house is made up of a number of traditional Thai buildings put together and it is surrounded by some wonderful plants and vines. It makes a bit of a change from all the temples and Buddha statues you'll be seeing, definitely worth a visit!
Most Interesting. Read up on Jim Thompson before you go to Bangkok, it will make the tour more interesting. Our English tour was really well done. History, architecture, intrigue - it's all here!

Finally. We tried to visit Jim Thompson House on our last visit. We're both really glad we made it this time.The house is a five minute walk from the BTS. It is an oasis amidst the craziness that is Bangkok although the ferries zooming past on the bordering canal are a constant reminder of that craziness.The gardens are beautiful. The guides are well informed and beautifully spoken. The house itself is very interesting and I'm glad we finally made it.

An art museum and traditional Thai houses. Another must see stop. Has art and fabric history in Thailand. Changing exhibits, sales area and cafe. A great way to see a very good neighborhood in Bangkok as well.

tranquil. Beautiful silk abounds at theshop next to the home built by Jim Thompson.Lovely building on different levels next to the canal ,allowed an indulgent but relaxing lifestyle while revamping the silk making industry

An interesting reminder of an interesting man.. Jim Thompson House is an oasis of calm in the vibrant city of Bangkok. The wooden house is well built, diligently maintained and contains a wide variety of items collected by Jim Thompson from all over Asia. The entrance fee is reasonable although the cafe is expensive. The guides speak a variety of languages, and the tour takes on average one hour. After finishing the tour instead of heading back to the Skytrain, mix with the locals and take the water taxi on the Klong canal.

Interesting!. I am obsessed with Jim Thomson stuff. Went berserk and bought a lot of cushion covers, scarfs and little cosmetic pouches as gifts. Lunch at the restaurant there was pretty good. Not to mention, the tour of Jim Thomson's house was really interesting.

Interesting place to visit if you have spare time. Very easy to get to as the skytrain takes to within 3 blocks of it's location. Just look for the exit marked #1, when you get off the walkway to the street make a sharp 180 degree turn, then pass the small mini-mart, almost immediately you see see a sign that points you the a narrow street to the right. take it to the end and will encounter the Jim Thompson House.One thing you will notice right away is the over-priced shop neaqr the entrance. Not to worry, there is a Jim Thompson Shop across town. Tours are offered in a variety of languages at regular intervals by some lovely ladies in traditional outfits who very knowledgable.

Ok if you have not seen it before. There is a regular "tour" with guides speaking in English and French. It was relatively OK but once you have seen it, you have seen it all. At the back of the complex there is a river which unfortunately can be quite smelly.
Lovely oasis of calm. Brilliant tour, by well informed guides and a bargain at only 100 bahts each. Nice cultural end to a good saty in thailand, restaurant was also very good.
great place to pick up curios. very good stuff. great place to pick up gifts for friends and family . prices are reasonable

Very informative. Beautifully restored and with good multi lingual guides, we spent an hour here and thoroughly enjoyed the "mystery" around such an interesting man. The gift shop is over priced in our opinion

Underwhelming. My wife and I visited in April 2012.The houses are beautiful and the gardens are fantastic. It is worth visiting just to stroll around. However the tour felt like a real waste of time. To my mind there were three things that should have been covered in the tour: Jim Thompson the person, the architecture/artefacts and the silk industry and how he saved it. The tour largely ignored the person (a brief history was given because one of the customers asked) and the industry. It gave a very basic introduction to the artefacts he collected, but didn't put any of them in context. It would have been nice to know why the style of statue changed or what was happening in Thailand when the statue was created. The tour guide was lovely, but saying Sawa dee hundreds of time didn’t make up for the lack of substance.Go in with low expectations and the house and grounds will impress you. If you expect to be educated maybe stick to Wikipedia.However, given how positive the other reviews are we might just have been unlucky with our guide.

Interesting Site to Visit. I love the Jim Thompson brand and products so of course was very interested to see where the man lived and created the brand. His life and story is quite fascinating and his home and museum is amazing - really like stepping back in time. Its a nice quick little trip just steps away from the major shopping areas in Siam and a great place to grab an afternoon refreshment away from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok.

Classic and Worth the Visit. This was our second time to visit the house which is a museum to an Asia of the past. Easy to reach from the BTS National Stadium stop. Nice gardens and a new restaurant as well as gift shop and a smaller JT shop to purchase silk goods. However, if you visit the Jim Thompson outlet store on Sukhumvit soi 93 you can save a lot of money on your gifts. Take the BTS to Bang Chuk and walk back two blocks to soi 93. The outlet is about 100 meters from the corner on your left.

Gorgeous. A visit to Bangkok is not complete without a visit to the Jim Thompson House. Everywhere we go in the malls in Bangkok, we always saw their beautiful shop, so we thought it's best to visit the Jim Thompson house. It's so unique and exotic and if you're into architecture and design, it's best to visit this place. I think Jim Thompson has revolutionize the Thai silk industry and has great influence on Thai interior design and architecture.

Worth seeing!. We have been to Thailand many times, but never made it to Jim Thompson House! We did this time and would recommend it! The story of silk manufacture and sale internationally, mainly by the efforts of this man is an interesting story.

A classic site. No trip to Bangkok is complete without a visit to the Jim Thompson House. Our whole family loved seeing the property and listening to the guided tour in English. Our twelve year old son loved the historical significance and bought a print that is now hanging in his room.

Something different to see in Bangkok. The Jim Thompson House was worth checking out if you're a bit over visiting Wats and seeing various Buddhas. It wasn't my favorite place, but it was interesting enough, and not too expensive (100 Baht/person). It was neat to see some old Thai architecture, and Thompson's various collected antiques from around Asia. Our tour guide spoke English and did a super job displaying her knowledge.If you're hungry, the restaurant has a great outdoor terrace and good Thai dishes.
very interesting. in secluded Soi in the centre of Bangkok this House describe the life of Jim Thompson. Also great silk shop attached, fantastic to bring back souvenirs and presents
Excellent. My number one in Bangkok. Not too crowded, amazing house, lovely artifacts and nice staff. Pleasant cafe but the shop rather over priced
Delightful shopping. Silks and cottons. Great gifts and value for money

A beautiful house and interesting tour. The Jim Thompson story is compelling; his house is beautiful and the design elements of it fascinating. It is a real insight into some Thai homes and the gardens are lovely too. The tour is only about 30 minutes which is perfect, and the shop is excellent (and very cool which is very welcome).

Just Beautiful!!. Jim Thompson lived in Thailand for 25 years and was the founder of the Jim Thompson Thai Silk Company which has become famous worldwide and revitalized the Thai Silk Industry. He was awarded the Order of the White Elephant, a decoration bestowed upon foreigners for having rendered exceptional service to Thailand.  Sadly in 1967 Jim Thompson disappeared while on holiday in the Cameroon Highlands in Malaysia which is another story which is covered well in numerous books. It was after reading some of these books that I decided I wanted to see the house he lived in plus the beautiful jungle gardens, which were designed by William Warren who also designed the stunning gardens at Mom Tri's Villa Royale in Phuket! This magnificent house is actually 6 different old Thai houses that were bought in and reassembled from various places around Thailand to make one large beautiful house, no nails are used and Jim also reversed some walls so he could see the beautiful carved woodwork from inside his house. The house is built on Klong Maha Nag and everyday Jim would row across to see his silk weavers. Now there is a large fence separating the house from the Klong, but it is easy to imagine what life use to be like along this waterway. Jim Thompson loved entertaining and there were dinner parties nearly every night.Jim Thompson was also a collector of beautiful painting, statues and antiques from all over South East Asia and many of these are on display at his house. No photos are allowed to be taken inside the house.There is also a lovely restaurant and bar here plus a small shop selling books and various silk products.Being here was an absolute highlight for me, I have been a Jim Thompson fan for quite a few years and to actually visit his house which has not changed much since he lived there was such an experience, it is a beautiful oasis from the hustle and bustle of Bangkok.The Jim Thompson House is on Soi Kasemsan (2) Song which is opposite the National Stadium on Rama I Rd. It is open everyday from 9am – 5pm and the guided tours are 100baht.

Nice attraction away from hustle & bustle. We went here as part of a day tour around Bangkok and was really pleased we did. The guide we had spoke good English, but was a bit quiet so couldn't always hear with other people in the group doing their own version of the tour! It was an interesting place to visit especially when you learn about Jim Thompson's interesting life & disappearance.
silkorama. to visit this house and see the materials and silks and coulours is something ,I am a knock about and i did not think i would like it .but it makes my eyes open.
amazing!. nice posh decor and it has a peaceful and beautiful surroundings
Make it a must on your to see list!. Amaaaaazing!! Everyone should see this! I could have spent a fortune. If you like fabrics, clothing, purses etc. your are going to fall in love here!

Amazing house!. If you want to learn about thai culture and want to see a traditionnal house, this is the place to go. The guide will tell you Jim Thompson story and some thai culture, very interesting, close to national stadium station.

A beautiful Thai house. Since it was located right behing my hostel, I went to the Jim Thompson house even if it's not necessarily the kind of place I usually go to. And honestly I liked it a lot. It's a beautiful typical Thai house with great items collected by Jim Thompson.You have to take the tour to visit the inside of the house but it's definitely worth it.

A small oasis in the madness of Bangkok. We really enjoyed our trip tio Jim Thompson's house. We travelled by water taxi on the canal which dropped us almost right outside for just 20 baht each. The house and gardens and a lovely green tranquil oasis in the madness of Bangkok. The tour guide was really good and spoke very good English and the house and contents were beautiful.We were so relaxed we decided to stay for a drink and lunch at the restaurant and had really nice food at not too bad a price considering this is a tourist haunt.

a different place to go.... Didnt really plan to go but I want to check out the small muslim village behind the house so i went there anyways! The house itself is a good place to see, it's not near the city centre and not a super popular spot so here i had some quiet moments. I like the house, the shops selling souvenirs & postcards and the art exhibition at the period. Everything was perfect except the very nervous tour guide, not sure if she's new but the way she talked wasn't very natural and it seemed to me she was forced to smile every 3-4 seconds.

Top class Thai silks and cottons. The Jim Thompson house is a timely piece of architecture that marries traditional Thai with a modern western design. The fabrics are beautiful , I am a bloke who would not be so fussed but the quality of the whole operation deserves credit. A classy product line sold through a few franchises from airport to major hotels. Sure you pay more but it still is great value. Thailand is a beautiful country and not everything has to be bought through banter at market stalls , this place is easy to shop in . If you want to claim the 7 per cent vat back. Take your passport or photocopy of it with you. Make sure you thoroughly understand the process of claiming the vat . The govt doesn't really want you to have it ,so, they put some admin hurdles in the way

An authentic attraction. A good way to spend a few hours. The House complex is as authentic as it can get. The tour guides are pleasant and well trained. I can't help but wonder how Jim Thompson would have reacted to having so many thousands of strangers touring around a very personal home in which he clearly took great care and attention to build and furnish. The opulent, eclectic, and personalized house is the perfect insight into who and what Jim Thompson was all about. Indeed, the house and garden fit into the 'Jim Thompson' brand perfectly. The accompanying company silk shop on site is as large as the house. Just be sure to bring your credit card, stuff is pricy in there! ;)
Zen and quiet. A little bit of safe heaven in the middle of the craze of Bangkok.
Great time filler. Spent a morning there, pleasant guide, good cafe and quality clothes, at a price.

Hidden Jewel. This one of the last things on our list to see but I would make it one of my top 5 now. The property is well maintained and beautiful and I seriously wanted to live in that house. The tour guides spoke the best English of any Thais I met and were very kind and open to questions.

Weren't going to visit...but happy that we did. We were debating whether or not to visit the Jim Thompson house, but are happy that we did. It's a small little relaxing oasis hidden within the larger, craziness of Bangkok. Very serene environment, gorgeous scenery, and they even have a nice guided tour through the house. The restaurant is also well-priced with delicious food.

A must see. Take the BTS to national stadium. Exit opposite side to stadium and take left stairs to footpath. Second lane on right. Two thirds down lane is the museum. 100 baht entrance. Tour groups over charge to get you here. BTS is quick, cheap and half the fun. Marvel on a conducted tour, take a break for a snack or meal and support this foundation in the shop. Another must do destination
a place to see in Bangkok. The place is beautifully maintained. The story of Jim Thompson is fascinated. The restaurant is a fine place for lunch. Do not forget to stop at the shop before leaving.

A true gem tucked away amongst the sprawl of shopping Centers and towers of glass.... A short walk from National Stadium BTS station and MBK, visitors can find the Jim Thompson's House tucked away down at the bottom end of Soi Kasemsan 2, just on the right as you are walking away from the National Stadium BTS station. Great care has been taken to piece together, renovate and a preserve a lovely collection of traditional Thai houses right in the heart of the city's shopping district. I have had the chance to visit on multiple occasions and the tour guides (available in multiple languages) are always professional and interesting, making this remarkable house/museum a must for any visitor. The museum has a lovely collection of antiques and artworks from all over the Southeast Asian region. There is also a cute little Thai restaurant/cafe on site that serves nice food in a very pleasant atmosphere (albeit a little over priced). ALSO.....if you are in the area searching for the location BEWARE of Tuk tuk touts that stalk the area looking for victims. They can be very aggressive, but DO NOT agree to go anywhere with these scam artists. One of Bangkok's notorious Gem factories is one soi over, and they will try their best to get you through the doors to get the commission for serving you up on a platter....so, do yourself a favor and make sure you walk away!

A worthwhile visit. The house has been upgraded with a Jim Thompson store and restaurant added. Admission is Bt100 per adult, which is not bad given the interesting narrated tour. The house is decorated with old statues and right on a canal, so we heard boats roar past frequently. The tour guide told us that Jim Thompson liked old artifacts that were broken, so most of the statues were headless or missing a few arms. According to the Thai people, broken statues brought bad luck, so that is why he disappeared . . . The house was only two floors and seven rooms, so it was a short tour but very charming. It made one wish they lived in Bangkok in the 1950s.

beautifull garden with old wooden houses. It is like stepping back in time to visit Jim Thompson. You have to join a guided tour to go inside the buildings. Behind there is a klong with a boat travelling through Bangkok.

Interesting and relaxed. Location, buildings and tour all interesting plus a bit of commercial history. You can buy silk items at the shop. There was a historical exhibition there about the country's "saga" narrative, when we visited.
Nice gardens. Took a guided tour, well worth the money as the guide explained all about Jim Thompson's life and his disappearance.Gardens are a tropical oasis in the heart of busy Bangkok
Worth a visit. You will get an excellent feel for Thai architecture and design in this well preserved home. It's walking distance from downtown.

Beautiful House, Spendy Silk. This is, first and foremost, a store for gorgeous but very pricey silks. The building is quite lovely. It's not very convenient if you're staying in Banglamphu Khao San, but if you're nearer to the house it's worth doing.

Thai Days Gone By. This is an excellent attraction if you want to see what it was like to live in Bangkok 30 or 40 years ago. On top of that is the story of the enigmatic Jim Thompson, ex-CIA, rescuer of the Thai silk industry, and disappeared person in the Cameron Highlands. Afterwards, a refreshment in the cafe is nice, as is an amble in the silk house.
So Peaceful.. This place is a haven of tranquility in the midst of all the craziness that is Bangkok. This man had some amazing taste!

Interesting Story. You should go to Jim Thompson's house that they've turned into a museum. He had an interesting story about his life & his silks. Beautiful gift shop. The tour was great. You have to take off your shoes to walk through. Gift shop has shirts, place mats, pillows, kids clothes, ties & handbags made from his silk.

Interesting to see some traditional Thai architecture. We arrived by water taxi and that was very easy. A guided tour of the houses is obligatory but you can return to the garden and wander around on your own afterwards. The main house was very interesting. We only had time for a drink in the cafe: very pleasant but a bit expensive but you are a captive audience and it is a lovely setting!

Great attraction. I love visiting this beautiful teak house and being immersed in the mystery that is Jim Thompson's life, Make sure you have the time to dine at the lovely restaurant on the property. This is a relaxing attraction in a busy city. You can catch the skytrain to nearby and walk up the alley to the house. We usually take a taxi back to our hotel, though.

Great place to visit with a very good restaurant.. This place is accessible by skytrain with a short walk from the station. This is a great example of a typical Thai house with modern amenities added by the owner. It is greatly situated with the river running behind it. You can buy stuff from the shop and eat good Thai food in the restaurant.
Interesting. Awesome story. Maybe you will not take your best pictures but the Jim Thompson's story is absolutely charming. Cannot be missed!

Very interesting story, with an anthropological view. You should go and see how life in Thailand and learn some more about Thai culture. Very interesting for children but also take in mind it's a very hot there and organized accordingly.

Fascinating house built by a curious man.. Our previous visit was 20 years ago. It has changed with the addition of an art gallery, a bigger shop and a restaurant , all in the style of the original house. Tours with an English speaking guide (English skills vary) are allocated after you get the tiickets. The original house is still fascinating. The curios, antiques and style of the place are really interesting. The tour is about 30 mins and in the house no bags (safe lockers provided) and no shoes. After or before there is plenty time for individual touring of the wonderful garden and in the garden and outside the house photography is allowed. The ponds are fun - fish of all sizes, even turtles. The restaurant serves food slowly and even with a photo book of available food gets it wrong. It has an outside deck but the inside has AC. It is close to the National Stadium station of the Skytrain but choose the right exit
Very informative. Informative, english speaking guides, and not extremely crowded as other tourist attractions in Bangkok. Worth seeing!
A cool part of Thailand recent history. Great story and a must see if you are shopping for quality silk and cotton products in Thailand. I love the house and the gardens as well.
Interesting. The house is worth a visit if you have time. It's an interesting peek into the life of this fascinating American.

Interesting visit. Great restaurant. Easy to get to with Sky Train.. My girlfriend and I enjoyed visiting the Jim Thompson House. All visits are done with a guide which we liked because she provided a lot of interesting information that gave us an insight into the Thai culture even though the house belonged to an American.We had lunch at the restaurant and found it to be very good. The food was good and the venue was quite chic.It's is about a five minute walk from the National Stadium SkyTrain (BTS) stop.Enjoy!

An oasis in the big smoke. A great place to visit. The guided tour is a bit of a history lesson on Thailand - our tour lady was excellent. The garden is really beautiful and provides a relaxing atmosphere after trekking around the city. Highly recommended. Easily accessible by train.
Worth visiting. He built a wonderful house- complex with forward thinking features..like indoor plumbing

Interesting little oasis. Jim Thompson House is a beautiful house in a little oasis in this busy city. It's interesting to see all the things that he collected, and the way he had developed the traditional Thai style of house. I could imagine living there! Tours are well organised and guides are lovely, but it's a shame you can't just wander around. Restaurant is lovely - we only had a drink there but the food looked really nice. Worth a visit

nice but you woudln't miss it if you didn't go.. It was interesting to see the house, get a tour, and shop, But really there wasn't much there but a few nice antiques in the house and the teak structure of the house itself. Interesting but only if you are near there. It woudl have been more interesting to actually see the silk production!

Down memory lane... If you are in Bangkok and keen to see something else, other than shopping complexes, drop by Jim Thompson house. The house has an incredible story where it used different Thai style houses and combined in into a majestic but cozy abbott. I can imagine what it would have been like staying in this house, with a canal linked next to it. The guided tour cost 100Bht and it was worth it. There is a shop with the complex that sells silk products but I personally think that it is very expensive. Don't miss this place.. you may take the skytrain and stop at Ratchathewi station. A short walk from the station towards the housing area and you will find it.
Calm mids madness. Have been a few times to this gem, and love sipping a cold drink in the cafeteria. They have great products, so definately worth a visit!
Traditional Thai House. But not for the majority of people. Very interesting architecture.and antiques.
Go. The guides are wonderful, house is interesting to see and the reastaurant is good.
The one thing you should not miss in Bangkok!. Lovely museum, with an amazing collection of asian antiques. This place is really an oasis in busy Bangkok.

Thank you Mr Thompson. For saving the Thai silk industry and being an all around interesting character molded in that exotic SE Asian mystery aura. It you don't know about this man look him up on Wiki. He lived in a Bangkok that is was still the ancient orient some places were a step back into the past. His house has a wonderful cross section of art and buildings from the various periods in SE Asian history. He understood the nuances of Thai culture and designed his house accordingly. It is easy to reach by water Taxi or just walking along the canal from Siam Paragon. The price for silk is high but it is a great place to see superior quality textiles so you know what to look for when you can hit the markets. The trick with silk is more cross thread the better. It also burns like human hair.

Peaceful, serene, beautiful, and interesting.. For a very low price, you get to see the house of Jim Thompson (by guided tour) and his story and purpose of how it came to be. They offer tours in an array of languages, Thai, English, French and many more specifically for the tourists there. The staff was incredibly knowledgeable, helpful, and happy to be working there.In the center of Bangkok the house is hidden down an alley and surrounded by beautiful gardens to stroll through while you wait for your tour of the house to start.A must-see for Bangkok!!!

Beautiful old building in the middle of a modern busy city. I stumbled onto this hidden lite Jen during a day of shopping in BKK many shopping malls. It offered a great respite in the middle of the hustle and bustle so I warmly recommend a short detour.

Nice to try. Interesting place to tour the House of Jim Thompson. Our English speaking guide speaks well and able to share the lifestyle and thinking of Jim Thompson. It is a very nice place, greens, garden and interesting antiques and artifacts. Jim Thompson was a very clever architect. You can see how he "modify" his house to fit to blend into the mixture of local & foreigner style.

ULTRA QUALITY. For silk there is no better quality...robes, shirts, ties, and fabulous bow ties...everything in the finest silk and beautifully made. just up the street from Tarntawan Place Hotel across from Boy Street.

Fantastic!. A beautiful house, full of history and meanings, with a wonderful garden! The house is nice, the service is organized and kind. The store is beautiful too and offers a lot of high quality products, as clothes, accessories and home furnishings. I heard from an outlet store, but I could not visit it. I totally recommend this place.

An Interesting Oasis. In the midst of central Bangkok, surrounded by towers and busy streets, the Jim Thompson House is fascinating.You pretty much have to do the tour to really see the place and learn about Jim Thompson (a character who might have stepped from the pages of a Graham Greene novel).The architecture is noteworthy. The gardens lovely. And there's a small gallery featuring works by contemporary artists that is the icing on the cake.Well worth the visit. And an escape from the nearby mammoth shopping centers!
Back in time. Well preserved historical place. Full of culture and glamour. If I'd built a house in Thailand, it will be something like Jim Thompson House.

Good example of traditional Thai architecture. This is a very well-preserved and well-presented house and a good example, to anyone who hasn't seen one before, of traditional Thai-style house, albeit a very luxurious example.It also tells the story of its original owner and his love of Thai will weaving.Well worth a visit.
JimThompson's House. Interesting place and great to learn about the man. You will not be bored
very interesting. I enjoyed the house and compound as much as the story about jim thompson
