A journey with Jim T. Much more interesting than I had expect - he was quite a bohemian - I've been researching him since. A great way to spend a few hours in town - very relaxing and interesting - restaurant looks nice and reasonably priced. Put it on the list if you are visiting.

Worth a mornings visit!!!. History of missing Jim thompson and his dissapearance remains a mystery.... which will never be solved. His collection of antiques are priceless not to forget his promotion of Thai silk in the early ages. The shop is also fantastic and worth spending your Baht in.
Great Oasis in the City. Went here, learned a bit of history and enjoyed this little Oasis in the city.

old wood house and his story. i have visited 2 times this old wood house, it is romantic and step your foot on this woodden floor thinking about Jim Thomson with his thai culture love ...it is a romantic place

An interesting short tour. The house itself as an interesting piece of old wood construction and has a fascinating collection of artifacts from around Thailand. One part of the fascination is how some foreigner could get away with the equivalent of snatching holy relics from European churches and collecting them in his own house. 8-o The tour was well-organized and the guide quite easy to understand. The adjoining Jim Thomson shop has also many beautiful silk products, but I feel them to be poor value. However, if the wife wants to get a special handbag that her friends won't have, does the price matter. :-D
Just okay. Had lunch and found that the service was lacking. The food was extremely greasy and just not that good. Expected more.

Don't go for the clothes. This old thai house containing beautiful artworks and antique furniture and adjoining an ornamental pool, is an oasis if elegance and peace. The Jim Thopson organisation however seem to have lost something of their old style and flair. This year we thought their designs were quite tired, with far fewer elegant silk garments. and more cheaper linens, which seems to somehow miss the point.
Colonial experience. Beatiful house, professional guides. After our visit we had a nice lunch on the terrace of the restaurant.

lovely. i have been to Bangkok so many times over the years and I cannot believe I never made it to um Thompson house before. It is lovely. It is also close the the the MBK shopping centre - so when you get sick of shopping go accross the road for some culture in the calm oasis.

Interesting insight to the past. Interesting good value tour of this house. The quality of the finish to the building is amazing and the story behind the life of Jim Thompson and his disappearance fascinating. We had a great guide with a good sense of humor and spoke clear concise English. Well worth the visit. I have a disability but still managed to navigate the house including the stairs with ease using a walking stick.
the well-beaten path to Jim Thompson. you may feel at moments like you are in a tourist processing assembly line while you are here, but apart from that, it is a very worthwhile spot.

little oasis of calm. What a place! how we`ve missed it before I don`t know.Not just a "house" like a living museum set in beatiful gardens.Guided tours are very informative about the life and times of Jim Thompson.Well worth a visit even if the shop is way over priced but nice to look in
so so. Jim Thompson was included in our tour so we have seen it, but it is nothing special, the original Thai house is nice, the guide was OK, but there is nothing special that I can recommend

Style and Intrigue on the Klong. This place has echoes of Yves St Laurent's place in Marakech: a stylish abode amid the modern utility and relaxing peaceful garden. The Thommpson story is ripe for conspiracy theorists and worth looking up when you get there. Entry is 100BHT for a half hour tour of the house, very interesting, audible and easy in a shoes off way but there are a few stairs if that's your concern. There's a restaurant and bar but way too pricey for my modest budget - Coke 60 BHT here or 17BHT in the 7/11. For the wealthier traveller or those looking to splash out on some lovely gifts, there's a swanky silk shop on site with items for men women and home. We arrived by water taxi - the only way to arrive m'dear! It's one stop from Siam Square (if memory serves correctly) but there's a sign on the jetty anyway and people are very helpful with a nod or a no. What I really like about these sorts of houses though is that they fire your imagination, give you ideas for your own place and for 100BHT, I think it's worth a look and a pleasant way to spend an afternoon in this full-on city.
Ok - bit tourisity. They'll graciously relieve your wallet of lots of cash for beautiful silk items that won't look as good in your UK home as they did in Thailand

Better than expected!. i have never heard of him before, but what a fascinating life he had and lovely house, even by todays standards. It was a lovely compulsary tour and lovely house. I recommend buying some of the silk from the shop as a nice momento. There is a lovely ware shop 50 yards away, we brought some lovely statues from there that were stunning and not seen anywhere else as they make everything themselves. RECOMMENDED!
Tranquil. So lovely..... The gardens and house are sublime. It's tucked away in a side lane and is a great relief from the bustling and congested city. Bliss

Back in Time. This is one of our favourtie places to visit in Bangkok as it really is like stepping back in time. The house and gardens, though not large, are very tranquil and atmospheric, and you can understand why he wanted to build this traditional Thai house here on the banks of the Chao Phraya river. It's full of unusual objects and antiques and worth having the guide to fill you in on the history of this amazing man who came to a very mysterious end! One of his impressive lagacies was to restore the Thai silk printing trade, creating his famous patterns, that you can see so beautifully reproduced in the shop that's on site. Definitely worth a visit!

Good Value in a Lovely Setting. Took some business partners for a visit to the store and we decided to have lunch in the restaurant.We were pleasantly surprised at the quality of the food. It was good and the portions were reasonable.The service was decent and definitely recommend it for more upmarket Thai cuisine in a tourist attraction.
Must see. This is one of those places one has to see, I was a bit disappointed but glad I went and it did explain a bit of history....

A MUST SEE. If I had only a day in Bangkok I'd be sure to include Jim Thompson House. It's easy to get to on the Sky Train. Take the Silom Line and get off at National. The tours are frequent and not expensive and it truly gives you a feeling for the cultural of Thailand. The tour is not too long and is conducted in a variety of languages. The groups are not too big and the guides are knowledgeable and easy to understand. I've personally done this tour at least 5 times and learn something new every time. I've taken all who has visited me here in Thailand and everyone has enjoyed it, even those who didn't think they would. Of course, if you're interested in Thai textiles, Jim Thompson House is a must, but it's also a tresure trove for anyone interested in ceramics and architecture.Also, the Jim Thompson Cafe, right next to his house is a great place to take a break, or have lunch is a lovely setting either outdoors or indoors with air-con.There is a smaller retail shop on site. Larger selections can be found in the main retail shop on Surawrong Road and there's also a nice shop in Paragon.

A little history in town. Just off Sukhumvit Road, the house and compound of the late Jim Thompson is nicely laid out, beautifully maintained, and brings a little of Thailand's recent history to life.Good opportunity to purchase silks in the adjacent gift shop.
Well worth the visit. The whole complex was a joy to visit although the shop is way too expensive.
Good short trip and meal. Loved the tour of the house and the history of Jim Thompson.Had meal after tour and it was excellent

One of the 5 top sites of Bangkok. A wonderful small museum, located next to the National Stadium Sky train station (use the north westernmost exit), and across the street from the MBK shopping mall. This private house is built by combining six traditional teak Thai houses, and exhibits wonderful art. The tour inside the museum is only possible with a guide, so arrive, book a tour and then while waiting (it was about 20 minutes for us – a tour leaves every twenty minutes) – check out the gardens and the shops (expensive, but has quality goods). The photography inside the museum is not allowed, but the guide explains where photography is allowed (in the gardens) and how to take pictures from the outside in.In my view, one of the 5 top sites of Bangkok.

fascinating look at old teak houses. Wonderful recreation of antique houses with appropriate furniture in a stunning garden which makes you feel miles from the centre of the city. The restaurant is expensive but beautifully situated next to a koi carp pnd and has fantastic home made ice cream. The shop has silk objexts but they are very expensive and you will get much better prices elsewhere.

A traditional Thai house to visit. It feels like Jim Thompson had just left for vacation, the whole area and of course the house are completely furnished and ready to move in. It is interesting to see how an immigrated and rich Thai lived in the middle of the 2000 century. Old art, many Buddha statures, old furniture and porcelain are shown. After the tour you can shop in the store.

I love this place. I visit Jim Thompson's house most times I come to Bangkok. It's a serene little oasis in the middle of a bustling city. Located near Stadium MRT station and MBK shpopping centre it is easy to get to. The house is left much as it was the day he left it. His beautiful collection of furntiure, antiques and art work are all still there. The guy had a flare for decoration and beautiful things. Do a little google research on the life of Jim Thompson before you go and you will enjoy the visit even more. There is a lovely cafe there beside a beautiful Carp pool.
peacful. its very peacful get away from hustle and bustle small place though
Nice house. Please visit the Jim Thompson House to see and buy the Thai silk here. Very good quality...

Read up about the man before you go.. A beautiful oasis in the middle of Bangkok. Take the tour, it's lovely. Have a nice lunch at the charming restaurant and pull out the credit card for some fantastic silk everythings. Classy, classy.
Worth a visit. Fantastic to visit Jim Thompsons House - as it was when he lived there - beautiful grounds also and good cafe
An oasis of calm in a buzzing city. Such a lovely calm, green oasis. I am glad we visited, we did some shopping too! this ended our trip to Thailand on a good note.

A nice place to rest in the middle of busy Bangkok. A nice complexe of old style thai houses with a restaurant and a silk shop. a nice oasis in the middle of this busy and noisy city! Not far from Siam Center and MBK, about 5 mns walk
Fun way to escape the city congestion. Enjoyed the tour very much but was a bit dissapointed in the dining. We found it a bit pricey and not as cozy as we had hoped.
Historical House in gardens with cafe and shop.. Lovely way to spend a couple of hours. The house and interior are beautiful and guides are very knowledgable. Lovely cafe overlooking water gardens.

Beautiful interiors in a serene environment. You actually don't need a tour group to visit Jim Thompson House. Simply exit National Stadium from BTS then its a comfortable 5-10 minute walk.The place has a calming effect on people - its as if everyone talks in whispers when they come here. The house of the person responsible for making the Thai silk industry renowned the world over is inspiring. The interiors are tastefully done and gives you a flavor of how Jim Thompson embraced the Thai culture.The actual tour is quick but you can actually roam the grounds after the guided tour. I like to sit by the gate by the river and watch the river taxis float by.
Go. An interesting free tour with ticket purchase, beautiful sculpture and design, worth seeing. Walking distance to MBK.

House visit. Took a Tuk Tuk from near the hotel rather than outside, much better price negotiated. Loved the house and its history, the tour guide was entertaining and very knowledgeable. Enjoyed the freedom to wander round after the official tour.Whatever happened to Jim?
Not Exciting. Had to join a group tour to see the house. Would be better if you could view on your own at your own pace.
Beautiful original interior. Just as I had imagined, virtually untouched; gives a good impression of how Jim Thompson lived there and developed gorgeous textiles

A haven in the centre of Bangkok. Having watched a BBC programme about the house and the garden, we had this as one of our musts at our Bangkok list. We got there after a hectic visit to the Grand Palace, and it sure was a change!Located close to MBK and other shopping centres, this little garden with it's quiant old Thai houses will show you a glimpse of a Bangkok that no longer is. There is a nice restaurant, gift shop and the tour of the main buildings is included in the modest entrance fee. It was a break in a hectic Bangkok visit.Do go!

Peace in the middle of a big city !. Easy to get there with the skytrain , its just a walk away .Very good guides tell you everything you want to know , with a lot of respect for the men whom build up the silk industry for the thai people .Saluut !

Step back in time. We had a lovely guided tour (included in the admission price) of this fascinating, former silk grower's home. Watch out for the beautiful carvings and cool garden. Has a lovely restaurant too with reasonable prices.

High Quality Silk Products. Great location to buy a quality Thailand gift or a silk item for yourself. Expensive but enough of a selection to find something for most budgets. Very nice packaging. The original location near Siam Square is the best for selection and history but found in shopping centers and the duty free shops at the airport.

Nice to see if you have time. it is mentioned as a must see place in Bangkok so went there. it is a house built in Thai tradition and it is based on 7 houses brought from different parts of Thailand and re-built in Bangkok. the ticket includes a free guided tour and you are told a lot of interesting things about Thai houses and the way they are built. the tour takes appr. 1 hour.

A lovely tour of a traditional house. The house has been kept as a museum and the grounds are lovely and peaceful though I would wear mossie guard for the bugs. The tour is about 45 minutes and seeing a traditional wooden thai house and learning about the customs surrounding the design and use is interesting. The food in the cafe is delicious and quite reasonably priced and there is a shop on site selling lovely silk gifts. A very relaxing place to spend a hot afternoon in the city.

stay for lunch. the tour was very interesting and the linked buildings wonderful. Stayed for lunch too which was very tasty and good value..almost worth going just for that.Footnote. dropped my credit card without noticing at one of the tills....realised about an hour later after lunch . After the inital panic rush went back and asked if they had seen it....checked my name and passed it over.
Get down there. Beautiful museum in the house lived in by Jim Thompson. A must on any visit to Bangkok if you can find it.There could be a larger sign at the end of the small road to the house.

Not what I expected. I don't know exactly what i expected, but I was disappointed somewhat. But it might mean a lot more to others so go & have a look & don't be detered by an indecisive (& maybe fatigued) opinion.

Interesting architecture. Well worth the trip. Easy to get to via th Skytrain and it's a piece of calm and tranquility in the city.The buildings are lovely, the compulsory tour (Thai, English or French) OK.Take note in the shop though...linen shirts made with Irish linen, scarfs made from Italian fabric.....hardly supporting traditional Thai manufacturing
Great little treaure near National stadium. A short walk from national stadium, a nice visit to pass time in the morning or afternoon.

Exquisite. A visit to the Jim Thompson House is a must. He created a magnificent home using traditional Thai materials. He revitalized the Thai silk industry. The cafe serves good Thai light meal and the shop is full of silk clothing, handbags, scarves. Wonderful fabrics with modern design.
a quite place to go and eat. this place is good if some one stay more than a week in Bangkok it is a build place and not original thai to see
Silk like nowhere else. The Jim Thompson House is a great place to shop for top quality Thai clothing and hand bags - magnficiant handbags
Different look. It was interesting to see what a house from the area looks like. He was a very different person.

Gorgeous and peaceful. Wasn't high on our must see list, but we are very happy that we did. The tour was fun and informative and the property is beautiful and very peaceful. It is a great way to spend an hour and right on the canal boat line.

Give it a miss. Visiting this house was disappointing. The information given on the tour was no more than we had read on the leaflet they gave you on entry. The tour itself was also lacking on info, Could not hear the tour guide unless you were standing on her toes. While on the tour we had to wait on three occasions for the tour in front of us to move on. Then when our tour guide started speaking you could not hear her over the other tour guide. The items in the house had no information accompanying them nor had the pieces in the houses in the garden. The only thing that I was impressed with was the old floor boards. Entry fee is 100 baht per adult and 50 for children.

Interesting house, nice garden.. It was an interesting house to see, very open with Buddhist artifacts, situated on a klong with a small but beautiful garden surrounding it. As Jim Thompson revived the Thai silk industry and disappeared without trace in the 1960's, it has a significant historical aspect as well.

Interesting and Beautiful. The Jim Thompson House was an hour long tour through his former home. Beautiful architecture and antiques. The guides are all very informative and it is a small glimpse into the life of an interesting man.

Worth a visit!. We had never heard of Jim Thompson or his house but if you want to see a glimpse of old world Bangkok this is a must see. The tour is excellent and the house and garden so lovely we could have stayed hear all day.

beautiful, relaxing and well restored. The house is set away from the main roads, backing on to a klong. The moment you walk up the drive you enter a beautiful peaceful world of wood, nice furnishings and tranquility. The cafe is excellent and a great setting, the guided tours are really interesting and of course the shop is a real indulgence. Don't miss it.

Both mystery and fantasy. If you know anything about the unusual life and disappearance of Jim Thompson (who vitalized and globalized the Thai silk trade in the 50's and 60's), you will truly appreciate visiting the museum that was once his house (before he disappeared without a trace in 1967). The house is exquisitely Thai with touches of the West. The guided tour is under an hour and well worth the time. The cate, also on site, serves an excellent lunch (try the pompelo and prawn salad and mango / lime smoothie). Finally, the Jim Thompson store is filled with beautifully designed products (I had to make to make a return trip the next day).

Diverting. An interesting morning/afternoon sight. Worth a visit to see the lovely architecture and interior decoration.I would have liked to have been told more about both Jim Thompson himself, and about the Thai silk industry, both of which seemed to be a little absent from the (included in the entrance fee) tour we did.
Interesting glimpse into the past. Better understanding of Thailand life in those days and Jim Thompson in particular.

An oasis in Bangkok. I suppose it can be tricky to find, but you can actually walk here from MBK, Siam Discovery Center, or Siam Center. The smell from the Klong (canal) that Jim Thompson's house sits on can be bad, but otherwise, this is a beautiful place and a nice into to Thai art and style. I've visited here many times in the last 20 years. The main change is the very yummy restaurant on site. Great gift shop too.

Well worth a visit. Attended The Jim Thompson house at the weekend, while the tour group was probably a little on the large size the guide took care of us all showing us round this beautiful house. A must visit for anyone coming to Bangkok
Decent Thai cuisine in the house of a legend.. Liked the crab cakes with mango sauce!!! Yumz. Had pineapple rice, char grilled half chicken, brocolli with prawns in oyester sauce, so-so.

A lovely peaceful haven to learn of the mystery surrounding the disappearance of Jim Thompson.. I loved the peacefulness of the gardens, the architecture and the the guided tour telling of the history. It also has a great shop for handbags and scarves and the outdoor restaurant for lunch or a drink over looking the goldfish pond was superb and very reasonably priced.
Interisting stop on the Skytrain and on the Canal.. Very nice oasis in the city. Accessable from the BTS and the Canal San Saap.

Okay, if you have extra time. Nothing really wrong with this place, but I wouldn't put it in my top 10 in Bangkok as most of the travel books do. If you are in that area (near the MBK) and you time to kill, then go. It is a peaceful little place in the midst of crazy Bangkok. Know this - you will find silk there and silk isn't cheap even at this place.
Price is Never Lie. Good Quality Silk, awesome stuff.You also can find a nice caffee in second floor of the building, located not far away from Dusit Thani Hotel. very friendly staff

Silk lovers. This is the place to go to if you fancy Thai silk. Very high quality silk products but prices on the high side. Lovely designs and wide selection of clothing, bags and assessories. One of our normal stops whenever we are in Bangkok.

Don't miss this. This is an amazing structure with amazing artifacts and furnishings. I am blown away by the fact that this house is constructed without the use of nails. The house has been beautifully kept; it is in excellent condition. The tours are well-conducted and very informative. I also found the silk items in the gift shop to be of excellent quality.

JT disappeared in Malaysia. Never heard JT before until I visit Bangkok. Jim Thompson’s 'House on the Klong' are magnificent, amazing, huge and classic . You will have chance to learn about his legacy and about the house. Recommend to those who wanted to see something different other than temples in Thailand. Tips: Look into wikipedia for information about him before you visit the house.
Amazing bit of history.. Hidden in a side soi, I found the information fascinating, from the architecture to the relics to the story of the man.

Really not very interesting. Unless you are really into Thai architecture, I cannot imagine you will have a great time on this tour. You simply walk through his house, an impressive house to be fair. But just a house. There were so many people--our tour frequently had to wait for the French tour to finish--and everything just seems a bit rushed. If you are in the area, maybe you should check it out. A fun thing to do would be take the canal taxies and get a quick view at local life and then head over to the house. It's really easy to find the house from the river. Also, it is very hot.

Better than expected. Sounded boring reading about it but it's worth a look. Amazing house inside and out in a pristine location close to skytrain, Tour was very interesting. A great way to spend an hour away from the hustle of Bangkok
Interesting but of minor importance. They were capitalizing on the shop. This is all I have to say

Jim T. The Thai people believe that Jim Thomson invited bad luck by keeping damaged and broken articles. It seems to be their good luck that he did. It is one of the prime attractions and a pleasant experience. Our guide's English was excellent and she had a pleasant sense of humour.

Thai house in a tropical garden. Overall this is maybe not one of Bangkoks most spectacular attractions but it still is a beautiful spot worth to visit.A compound of nicely renovated Thai style wooden houses set in a lush green tropical garden. A guided tour is included in the entrance fee and will take you to the museum inside the old houses (no tripods to be use inside, you can't go alone indside). After the tour it is worth to hang around in the beautiful garden and enjoy the setting.The restaurant is OK, nothing special, a bit on the pricey side, but that's compensated for due to its beautiful setting besides a pond in the garden.Over all worth to visit and recommended
Don't go out of your way. It is a nice house but nothing super special. If you're nearby it can be worth a visit but no need to go out of your way to see it.
Interesting, combined with decent store.. Interesting house, interesting people, and pretty educational overall.
great, relaxing place. The whole experience is great. I loved the house and surrounding buildings. The restaurant was good, nothing amazing, just good.

Fascinating and fun. I have visited the Jim Thompson House Museum on multiple occasions and loved it. Very nice setting and gives you a sense for real Thailand. Very interesting story about Mr. Thompson who reinvigorated the silk industry in Thailand. You'll love the gift shop and they have a fabulous cafe on the premises as well.
Nice and Quiet. Great quiet place to learn about Jim Thompson and how he lived. The restaurant is also great, a nice retreat.
Thailand History-Must See. Tourist spot but a definite part of Thai Anglo history and silk trade. Interesting artifacts and interesting part of Bangkok. Worth the time.

Fascinating story. The Jim Thompson story is fascinating, but I especially liked all the different houses, built in traditional styles, that he had imported to his estate. And the gardens surrounding them are beautiful -- a nice shady oasis.

Jim Thompsons house. Very interesting both architecturally and historically. Many different types of buildings in lovely grounds- tour guides very knowledgeable about the statues, porcelain and the furniture,the shop was full of beautiful things [too expensive for us though] Very glad we went

A view of BKK before skyscrapers and shopping malls. Even if you're not into Jim Thompson's products...they're a bit stale and stodgy even if the quality is excellent... you must go and see this compound. Beautiful old teak structures and coi ponds. A perfect respite from uber modern BKK.

Interesting but not a highlight. I was sent to do this attraction as a first stop during my visit to Bangkok. It's interesting to see the houses Jim Thompson connected, and it is definitely beautifully done. But to be very honest, I didn't think it was worth waiting over 20 minutes for a compulsory guided tour...it's nice to walk through if you're in the neighbourhood, but it's a little overrated in my opinion.
Short and sweet tour. Perfect tour, you won't lose interest. Lots of cool factoids and artifacts there. I found the place pretty inspiring, only wish I could have photographed inside the house.

Quite good. Interesting place to learn a little about Thai culture. The guides are not that good in speaking english, and speak very low. A must if you with to buy sillk of any kind, incl. childrens cloth.
Take the tour. Fascinating explanation of Thai silk industry and customs as well as the design and purposes of homes and rooms.

a different kind of experience. Much much quiter than everthing else we have seen in Bangkok. Very interesting tour that is not too long. Great little restaurant as part of the complex, Nice contrast to visiting the temples.

Entertaining tour. Great tour taken by very well-spoken guides through a particularly beautiful home. Somewhat detracted from by the mandatory overpriced shop attached to it. But then Jim Thompson was always a seller of silk so it is fairly defensible. The restaurant is well worth a look-in.

Legacies in Wood. The houses are just gorgeous and the way in which they have been displayed gives you a sense of gracious living in old Thailand. The museum shop and the cafe are also nice places to rest and relax after the tour.

OK. Very nice and they tell an interesting story but boiled down, he set up a business selling silk, went exploring (business trip) and disappeared, obviously killed or died in jungle. House is nice, but over egged relics, and actually an amalgamation of various houses. Nice shop!.

Fabulous place. Appreciated it more the second time. My wife and I just read the new Jim Thompson biography "The Ideal Man". It piqued our interest and we went to visit the Jim Thompson House which we had seen on a previous trip to Thailand about 10 years ago.We really enjoyed the tour, and we had a snack at the restaurant. It turns out that our hotel was close to the canal boat and we took the canal boat to the Jim Thompson House. Something we had not done before. My wife also did some shopping at the Jim Thompson store on Surawong Road.Definitely recommend the Jim Thompson House.

If it's boiling outside, an OK place to stay cool. The grounds here are very beautiful and serene and you will learn about Jim T and a bit about Thai history. It's easy to get to via Sky Train and if you have way too much money you can unload a boatload of it in the store here. The items are gorgeous, but you will pay through the nose! (Visited October 2010 - never reviewed)

Interesting Architecture, Intriguing Story. Jim Thompson collected original Thai houses and reassembled them on his property in Bangkok, modifying them to add his own western touches. The result is an elegant mix of styles and an interesting insight into Thai architecture. The personal story of Thompson's life and disappearance just adds mystery and intrigue. Guided tours are provided at regular intervals in a variety of languages. There is a beautiful garden and a lovely restaurant, and of course, a shop of Jim Thompson silk products. This is a good place to spend a couple of hours..
Thanks to Jim Thailand is back in the silk trade. Be sure to book a guide (I think they're free and depending on your language of choice, the tours could run as frequently as every 15 minutes).

OUTSTANDING. The price of entrance (~$3) also entitles you to a tour. Tour groups of 12 or so, not overrun, and the tour guides are very nice and informative. Art collection is amazing, stuff from the 7th century on up. You'll spend about 45 minutes to 1 hour here, deifnitely worth it. One thing, like all of Bangkok, the signage is poor. This place is open 7 days per week, and people outside (scam artist) will tell you it's closed. This is not a rare/sometimes thing, the BKK police are worthless and let this stuff go on non-stop. Walk by these idiots, feel free to yell at them if you like, I did, it feels great. They're hurtingh their own country by pushing tourists away from great exhibits like this, don't let them get away with it.

strange but easily accesible location. This attraction can be found down a street (Soi) just below the national stadium BTS or a short walk from Siam station. It is like a cutural oasis in the midst of the extvagent Sopping centres in the area. worth the pice of admission . There is a complusory tour and then you can just hang out in a very peacefull ares

Serene spot in the middle of Bangkok. The house is absolutely beautiful. It includes many artifacts from all over Thailand. I really enjoyed the tour and learning a bit about his life. They have an excellent gift shop as well.

Best in bangkok !. We went to every tourist sight in bangkok and this was our favorite. The story and house were interesting and the tour well organized . Also the restaurant was beautiful and the food top notch. Also bought a nice shirt and book in the shop onsite. Great value for money and time well spent. Too bad all the sites in bangkok wernt run by these guys...

Even if you don't have a Jim Thompson cushion you'll enjoy this. Loved the small groups, learning about how his house was constructed and his life story. Love the fabrics. There is no hard sell, but challenge you to leave without buying something! Didn't like turning down the wrong street only to get to the very end and realise!

did not like it. The house is nice, but is not worth the time spent in visiting it. The best of the place is the shop, even though is very expensive. However, you may find one of this shops in every shopping mall you go.

Great gem to visit. We decided to go here on a whim after visiting one of the Silk Shops. Beautiful house and gardens. The tour guide was lovely and knowledgable. Had a beer in the Restaurant before jumping on one of canal boats to head back into town.
Interesting house. Interesting house and story. Very pretty place in the middle of a bustling city.

An American's love for Thailand. Committed guides who take you around and describe the details of Jim Thompson's property. Amazing to see how an American got adapted to the Thai life style.The shopping arcade next to this property houses some of the best Thai silk produces. They are a bit expensive but worth the quality.

I wasn't expecting much but was really pleasantly surprised. This was a fun diversion. The house is beautiful. There's actually a canal with a long tail water taxi stop right behind it so it's great to visit by water. The gardens and house are quite lovely and well worth the time it takes to explore. Plus several malls including Siam Paragon are literally around the corner so you can combine with a visit here.
easy to walk from skytrain stadium. gives a fantastic impresssion on old houses on the klongs. Nice atmoshere inside and a fantastic coffeeshop nextdoors

Interesting history. Tucked down in a deep soi near National Stadium, we waited only 5 minutes for the next guided tour. Interesting design of houses, with the windows back to front, and the mystery of Jim Thompson's disappearance.Recommended!

Beautiful, historically interesting.. Jim Thompson revitalised/created the Thai silk industry and this was his house... Guided tour is very interesting. The house is lovely. You can arrive/go using the commuter canal boats. Worth a half day.

peacefull and interesting. jim Thompsons house is lovely and basically the same as it was when Jim went missing. It is fully furnished as it was originally. beautiful construction and a place of interest, be sure to get a guided tour as you would miss a lot if you werent given the information.

Great success. This place is such a success story of a foreigner coming to Thailand and saving their silk industry. The house is beautiful and during the visit you kind of think Jim Thompson will walk through the door.Buy the book at the house and you will know the real story with it's sad ending.The restaurant is good and the clothes and items sold are a little expensive but all are of very good quality.I have a beach wrap purchased several years ago on an earlier trip and it still looks as good as new.A wonderful place to sit with a drink or a meal and imagine the great life Jim Thompson had in the house..

Lovely little museum. The entry fee was 100 baht when I visited in Jan 2012. You are not allowed to take bags or cameras around the actual house and need to deposit them all in lockers at the house. You are however free to take photos in the gardens. With the entry fee you get a 30-40 minute guided tour around the premises. You are assigned to a group depending upon the language you select to have your tour in. We had a lovely guide who provided information on the various parts of the house and a bit of background about how it was all put together.Definitely worth a visit if in Bangkok. It is down a little side street just by National Stadium skytrain station and a short walk down the road from all the shopping malls in the Siam square area.
Lovely place in the middle of the city. Loved the guided tour.. Very informative and worth while

Another Bangkok Icon. This well worth a visit for those who enjoy design and history. The story of Jim Thompson is most interesting and it is a pity that his disappearance takes precedence over his designs. All part of the legend, I suppose.

A beautiful rural style house in central Bangkok. Jim Thompson made his money in the silk trade in the 60s. His extraordinary house is a combination of several rural homes put together into one large home in the center of Thailand's biggest city. It is part museum, part architectual showcase and part shop. While it is right in the heart of the city, it is quiet and could be far from civilization.

worthwhile. My friend decided we should go, its not the sort of thing i would normally do but i must say i thoroughly enjoyed the visit. I wish i could move in to this beautiful traditional thai oasis in the heart of busy Bangkok.

A small oasis in the midst of busy Bangkok. A calm, peaceful location in busy Bangkok. We walked from our hotel, The Pathumwan Princess and it was very close. Best way was to walk along the canal. The guides are very informative and their english was very good. There is a shop there to purchase silk if you want but there is no pressure to buy.

Hidden garden in center of bangkok. Very interesting to be able to look around a genuine Thai house and hear the history of Jim Thompson.Gift shop in gardens has wide range of silk goods, and not too expensive.
interesting, good guide, near MBK. it is a calm museum in the middle of Bangkok (near Siam centre). Nice cafe also. Good for a couple of hours.

Special. Jim Thompson's house is a must see while visiting Bangkok. Do not let any guys on the street tell you it's closed today - it is open 365 days a year.The entrance fee includes a 20 minute tour of the house, guided by knowledgeable and skillful ladies - a pleasure to participate in.After your visit, walk to the nearest canal pier to take a taxi boat to e.g. the Golden Mountain temple. The boat ride gives you a nice view on local city life in the city.
Splenid House And Shop. This was Thompson's house before he disappeared in the bush. Now a museum of sorts and shop of Thai silk and other items. A nice stopover
Dont miss this!. A beautiful creation of an American ex-pat with a fascinating history. A lovely way to spend 2 hrs getting away from the chaos of Bangkok. A feast for the eyes.

Well Worth A Visit. I must admit that my wife talked me into going to this Bangkok attraction & I am glad that she did. The entrance fee is 100Baht per person & this includes an excellent guided tour of the residances, which takes about 30mins & is really informative. Great shop with some really nice items & there was an art exhibition on when we went. The gardens are also very lovely & you would not think that you where in the middle of Bangkok. The restaurant is also very reasonably priced & we had some lunch there. I would certainly recommend this attraction.

Okay if you have nothing better to do. When you walk down the lane to get there beware a man will tell you it is closed today. Do not believe them when they do this, did not stick around to find out his motive.The house was okay, beware they make you lock up in their lockers your purse that has your passport and money. I' did not like this at all.It is a guided tour,takes about 30 minYou see it once and that is enough.

A peaceful oasis in the middle of Bangkok. This is a beautiful spot to spend an hour or so. The gardens are beautiful and the tour with the story about Jim Thompson, his collection of antiques and his home is most interesting. The shop and cafe, whijlst pleasant, are very overpriced.

Good place for lunch. While visiting the Jim Thompson house in Bangkok I ate lunch at their restaurant. The food is excellent as is the atmosphere. I also returned there on another visit to Bangkok and they allowed me to just eat at the restaurant without visiting the Thompson house itself again. Recommended.

Great visit. Love this place. Often return. Fine ambiance. Easily accessible. The restaurant is ok too, but the shop does not offer anything special above average Jim Thomson stuff for fairly high prices. You come for the house and its interior decoration really.
Good food. The Jim Thompson House has an excellent restaurant. Everything ordered was very very good.

Nice detour from busy BKK. If you have a few hours to spare during your time in BKK. I would recommend a trip to Jim Thompson house at the end of National Stadium sky train station. After get off from the sky train continue to walk for a few hundred meters. The house offers guide tour around the property where the late Jim Thompson used to live before his disappearance. ( wear shoes that easily come off because you have to take them off once in the house) or you can shop at their silk shop for great souvenirs. And enjoy Thai food while you are there.
Get a guide!. Interesting place, which shows a bit of each part of Thailand. Get a guide, and they will tell you all about the small things.
Wonderful traditional Thai house. A wander round the house in the company of a guide (mandatory) was a very pleasant experience. The shop was very expensive.
Must c JT's house!. This house is an anchint house that's really worth seeing if u come to Bangkok
Yummy food, beautiful atmosphere. A lovely place to visit - on the pricey side, but worth it.

Haven. A small haven in the middle of mad Bangkok. Situated very close to a sky train terminal. When entering along the driveway it is so quiet its hard to believe where you are. Taken around by a tour guide you learn some very interesting facts about Jims life and the way he lived.
Would well recommend a visit.
Chic Lunch. Love the house, very unique and beautiful! Excellent range of thai food menu....had a great lunch!
Thia silk. Unless your into history of Thia silk and its origins Jim Thomson house is disappointing and items we found expensive.

Lovely place to be visited in Bangkok. I found very interesting the visit of J Thomson house and its garden in the heart of Bangkok city. The house represents the traditional Thai living style with great paintings, fornitures and several decorations. In the garden there is a coffe shop, J Thomson silk shop and a souvenir shop where you can find books and art replicas of the Jim Thomson House. A great place to visit !

Life, once lived, in Bangkok. This glimpse to what living was like, at one time, in Bangkok, is very interesting. Granted, Mr. Thompson lived a privileged life, but the design, Asian antiques and setting make it worth a visit. If you are interested or involved with interior design, it is a must see.

Fascinating. I had thought of this as a "touristy" kind of place and thus had skipped it on previous visits. A friend told me it was worth the stop and that turned out to be exactly true. The tour is well done, the home is fascinating, the art and architecture is gorgeous. Truly worth a visit!

Interesting and relaxing little tour.. I had been to Bangkok 20 times before I got around to dooing this. After I finally went I regret not going sooner. The house is tucked in a very quiet (for BKK) location next to a canal. If one knows what they are doing with river taxis you can actually float all the way there. The house is beautiful, the collection of things more than interesting and the Tour is fun. There is a beautiful fish pond to relax by while you wait for the tour to start. And if you are a male,, the tour guides are an attraction themselves. I highly reccomend checking this out. I took my young daughters and older sister and everyone enjoyed it.

Amazing House & Garden. If you want to get away from the hustle & noise of Bangkok but still be in Bangkok I would recommend Jim Thompson House. Great history of how the Thai silk industry became what it is today and the house is amazing, the gardens are very tropical and you wouldn't know you were in busy Bangkok. Take a tour here it's priceless.
Nice. Interesting about Jim Thompson History. But it is one of the places, you see it once, that is all you need to see.

Beautiful traditional house. This a really nice place to visit. It is close to siam square. The house and garden are beautiful. It has a serene atmosphere. It is nice to see how the wealthy people lived in the early days.

An intersting and informative place. We did not know what to expect at the jim Thompson house. We knew that Thailand was known for silk but we did not know that Jim Thompson wa responsible for reviving the silk industry here. The museum and grounds were excellent and the staff and merchandise is excellent. We purchased many differnt silk items for gifts and everyone who received them loves them.

First class attraction. Again ger there early, do not believe anyone that comes and says its closed there are plenty of touts around the start of the street. Great food and drinks in the cafe. Shop is a little expensive for those on a budget but worth a visit.

Real quality thai food in hygienic setting. One of the best meals we had in town - fresh produce, amazing taste combinations. As to the price, some dishes on the menu you can find much cheaper in a street restaurant if you don't mind the plates to be washed in a bucket by the side of the road.
Who Killed Jim Thompson?. It's still a mystery! But if you are into design and the history of this silk mogul then do yourself a favour and visit his house. Great afternoon of history.
Definitely Consider If you have time.. We really liked this. Do some reading and give this consideration.

Something not to be missed.. Jim Thompson House is situated just off of Sukhumvit Ave, not far from the Skytrain. It is best done in the early morning and it is a very brief but enjoyable hour or 2 spenyt at very little cost.
American Comfort Food. A welcome relief to have simple American comfort food, that you didn't have to worry about the spice level. Great panini and fries with a nice cold beer.
Old Bangkok. This lovely set of houses on the klong are beautifully restaured and give an impression of what life may have been in Bangkok previous to the highrises

I tell everyone I know passing through Bangkok to visit the Jim Thompson House. As someone who has a second home in Koh Samui, Thailand (I also live in LA), I tell everyone passing through who has a few days to sight see to visit Jim Thompson House. When you read up about Jim Thompson, you will discover that he has a fascinating history----both when he was alive---and an amazing story re: his disappearance. But his house is exactly as it was when he left---so---when you take a house tour you will experience Thailand as it was many years ago. Every person who I have sent to see the Jim Thompson House (they offer a house tour which you will take) has THANKED me for the this recommendation (my other two are the Grand Palace and the reclining Buddha---plus a Canal tour) as "must sees. And they have a great gift shop. So--don't think twice---go visit.
One of the places you should visit in BKK.. Great history here and classic Thai architecture.
Beautiful old style interiour. Very intriguing story and nice tour around the house, worth a visit!

Surprisingly interesting place with unusual story. This is a classic Thai home designed and lived in by Jim Thompson who did much to revive the silk and clothing industry in Thailand. He was an American who moved into the house in 1959 and disappeared without a trance in 1967 at the age of 61. You can tour his house by means of a guided tour and see his collection of Thai and Asian art and crafts there and in smaller buildings that house more of his collection. Entrance fee is 100 baht--about $3.33. There is a lovely garden cafe that serves good food in a relaxed, covered area. The house is near the S1 stop of the Skytrain, near the sports fields. Signs showing directions to the house are good.
Go. I had no idea about this guy´s life and i was taken by it all. From the house you can take a boat to get to Golden Mount, if working.
Quiet corner of a busy city. Beautiful house and garden away from Bangkoks hustle and bustle.Tour was engaging and interesting.Restaurant was fantastic!

Well worth the visit. I found JTH to be a great glimpse into a part of Thailand's recent past via the experiences of a Westerner. Jim's contribution to Thailand is worth learning about and the home is exceptionally well maintained. A joy to view for architectural lovers. Passed on the silk products as they are not really my 'thing'. Products are expensive, but you are paying for the brand, so it's sort of like complaining about the prices of handbags in a Louis Vuitton store!!

A Place of Heritage. A wonderful tranquil place full of history and heritage.The service was wonderful. Liked the first part of roaming around the beautiful garden before the guided tour started.Guided tour was also nice, full of information. We came to know lot about Jim Thompson and his silk.After the tour we had our lunch at Jim Thompson restaurant. Food was awesome!! While exiting, don't forget to buy souvenir from the wonderful shop. Overall, a must visit place of Bangkok.

Ok, but not great.... One of the most well-known tourist attractions in Bangkok is Jim Thompson’s House. Thompson was a U.S. soldier stationed in Bangkok during World War II. After the war, he decided to stay and revive traditional Thai silk making. Thompson did really well for himself, and his textile company still bears his name today. Architecturally, his house is interesting because it was constructed from parts of six old Thai houses. It’s also filled with many prints and statues that Thompson collected over the years. Jim Thompson disappeared in the Malaysian jungle in 1967; no one knows what became of him. I wonder if his house would be as much of a tourist attraction if he died in his own bed at the age of 90? The intrigue of Thompson’s disappearance seems to be what fuels tourism at his former residence.

Make this a stop on your tour. Beautiful teak home with a great history. Jim Thompson was an American who revived the silk trade in Thailand. He is revered there. He was also an architect. His home is worth visiting.

Stylish and Serene. Nice garden & beautiful house in an intersting area. I would recommend taking a brief stroll behind the House, turn left as you exit the main gate where you'll see the canal and the Indonesian districe for a flavour of local life, worth a stroll along the canal
Very nice. A nice and quiet oasis. Absolutely worth a visit. Access is by guided tour only and tour guides were friendly and knowledgable.
Absolutely worth visiting. Having visited Bangkok several times, I finally made it to Jim Thompson's house and found it to be gorgeous, tranquil and fascinating.

Lovely, tranquil place to visit. You will be taken round this typical Thai house by a guide and just listening to the commentary will make the visit worthwhile. A great place to visit (if your taxi driver can find it). Don't confuse this with the Jim Thompson shop as we did.
Beautiful House. Really beautiful colonial house set in really nice gardens.Thoroughly enjoyed the tour of the house but... I think children under 12 would really be bored.

LOVE THIS PLACE. The house, the silks, the garden all are wonderful. I didn't go into the cafe due to the prices (I travel on a very tight budget) but the menu looked great. I had never heard of this man until I got to Bangkok but was very impressed with the beauty of the place, the story of the man's life and his disappearance and the garden. We were there for about 2 hours and enjoyed every minute. I think I had a smile on my face the whole time. The shop is lovely - a bit pricey for me, but the quality is very high.
Wonderful house. This is a bit of old Bangkok. Extremely good value at 100 Baht for a tour of this magnificent house. The restaurant is also very good. A good place to visit.
A lunch time gem!. Although "touristy" this place is an absolute gem! Great service, great food, beautiful ambiance!

Beautiful and Historic Home (NOT HANDICAPPED ACCESSIBLE). We spent a few hours touring the Jim Thompson House. I must say that the history of Jim Thompson in Thailand is intriguing. I had never heard of him before this visit. The story of how he brought back the art of traditional Thai Silk was interesting, but more interesting was his vanishing act. What happened to him still remains a mystery. His home is now a museum of his private collections of art, pottery and furniture. There is a beautiful (quite small) garden and a very very expensive shop on the property that sells (cotton) t-shirts for $35.00 and a variety of expensive purses, neck ties, scarves, fabric, etc. Reminded me more of Macy's than a gift shop. There are no photo's permitted inside the house and no postcards (that I could find) of the inside of the house either. You must remove your shoes to enter and they have lockers available with video camera's pointed at the lockers and two attendants on duty. There are lots of steps to climb and each room had to be stepped into and out of. Try to educate your self a little about Jim Thompson's history before going and maybe you will be more impressed than I was.

A lovely house with a lovely cafe. It is easy to combine a visit here with either Siam Paragon or MBK shopping mall.I like to bring my visitors here, although not everyone appreciates it (the children tend not to enjoy this place as much). You have to join a 35 minute tour (also available in French, Japanese & Thai apart from English) which takes you around the house Jim Thompson used to live before he disappeared mysteriously in 1967. Jim Thompson was a famous American who helped revive the Thai silk industry. His house was made from teak wood (which is too expensive to use nowadays but good to ward off termites) in a traditional Thai style, albeit with minor changes made to suit his taste. There are lovely artefacts which he collected from different countries over the years. You have to take your shoes off and leave your valuables in a locker before entering. Photography is not allowed indoors.There is a Jim Thompson shop selling products (handbags, cushions, clothing etc.) made from Thai silk and cotton etc. next to the house. There is also a cafe, both outdoors and (air-conditioned) indoors, if you need to rest and have a bite before moving on. My visitors love the fresh coconut juice served in a coconut.Tickets: Baht 100 per adult and Baht 50 per child.Take a BTS to National stadium, look for sign leading to Jim Thompson House. After comingdownthe stairs, doubleback (i.e. do 180 degrees turn) and turn right at Soi Kasem San 2 street. Sometimes there are tuk-tuks that take you from this point to the Jim Thompson house which is at the end of the street. Only a 5-10 minute lesurely walk though.

restfull place. In the heart of busy Bangkok you will find this jewel, the house nof Jom Thompson. Beautifull house in a beautifull garden en tastefull furnished with oriental antiques. You can take a tour and shop for silk or just have an drink and bite in the restaurant.Walking distance from MBK shoppingmall

well another expensive shopping ecperience i think. better to view the history on GOOGLE and see other things. You will be told the qulaity is BETTER here but... having done 15 trips to Bangkok, I know there are good qulaity items everywhere. Use your own taste and eye and you will get bargains everywhere. if you are BOREd and pray help me if you are in BKK, then pop along.....

Great place to chill out. Very nice and well maintained Thai house. Nice cafe and shops. The Silk products here is high quality and reasonable price. They also have a factory outlet in Sukumvit 93 - easily reachable by Skytrain (Bang Chak station) and few hundred meters walk.
A little oasis in the centre of Bangkok.. Very interesting, a little oasis in the centre of Bangkok. It was good value and a nice way to spend a couple of hours.

Great excursion. Being a huge Jim Thompson fan it was nice to finally get to visit the house where he used to live. Close friends of mine have been recommending this excursion to me over the years, and was pleased that I finally got around to visiting.The house and gardens are very well maintained and thoroughly enjoyed the visit. The tour was informative and the guides very knowledgeable on the history and life of Jim.

Fabulous, serene spot in a bustling city. Loved the whole thing, the art, the house and the integrity with which it has been preserved and curated -- the time they allow you to visit on your own after a short tour. And then, of course, is the great story of Jim Thompson. . .Americans who are history buffs or who love great silk should not miss this spot.
Thoroughly enjoyed the tour!. I loved touring the Jim Thompson House. It was very well maintained and organized. Loved the gift shop!

An oasis of calm within the chaos that is Bangkok. Beautiful peaceful oasis that is far removed from the hustle & bustle of the city, but only steps away. Tuk tuk from central world took 20 mins, walking back through shopping malls and Siam Paragon took about 15 mins.Very interesting and informative tour, well organised into small groups. Gardens cool and relaxing. Gave a good incite into life in 1950/1960's Thailand.

Beautiful Gardens and Informative Experience. I really enjoyed the visit to Jim Thompson House. The house/museum is situated in a beatiful garden and you get an informative tour of every room of the house and the history of Jim Thompson...Worth the visit...

Great Thai food. Great food, good service, reasonable prices.
Very good Thai menu and nice setting inside

Best attraction in BKK. Jim Thompson is a mystery man of the American OSS/CIA and his house harkens back to the Cold War. It's truly an amazing home with terrific antiques, artwork and and architectural design. The tour gives you the whole story. I've been there three or four times and still don't get bored. Do not go to BKK on holiday and miss this gem. You'll regret it...

A Taste of Orientalism. Orientalism has a bad name amongst academics these days. They view an epicurean taste for things 'exotic' as just another species of racism. Out in the real world people like Jim Thompson have helped generate interest in the arts and culture of other countries, and a visit to his beautiful, old teak house beside a canal in Bangkok is recommended. The guides are well-trained and you will learn such little-known bits of information as the fact that Thompson created a market for Thai silk on Broadway.
charming, refinement, don't miss it.... A small paradise where you will discover an unique collection of best quality asian art. You will find the same enjoyment at the restaurant...

Nice shop/restaurant. Great place for a causal afternoon meal, was there with friends and kids and the staff were so greg in helping look after the kids too. Great Thai food in a very relaxed atmosphere where you can also do a spot of shopping too.
Very worthwhile. beautiful and interesting insight into living in thailand at another time
beautiful antique house. great beautiful antique house - nothing s wrong with this house.

Quite oasis. Got there first thing and it was really interesting to see how he assembled the rooms. The tour (in English) was quite informative and understandable. The gift shop had nice products but was a little pricey. Cafe was good for drinks aftewards (or before).

Saved from redevelopment. This old Teak Thai house has been slowly renovated, and as such saved from the same fate as most others in Bangkok. The whole place is stuffed full of Jims antique collecting, including some of the oldest works of Thai art remaining. Well worth a visit to get the idea of how the design of these houses works, and especially if you like to get some high quality Thai Silk from the shop on site. Dont forget to stop for coffee and cheese cake, i dint know whether to frame the cherry cheesecake and use it as a work of are or eat it. I did the latter and it was probably the bast flavoured one I have had for many a year.

Nice house. It's a lovely house and a nice tour they give, but it's never truly impressed me. I always want to wander around on my own, but you can only go in the house on guided tours. It's a pretty place, but not all that exciting or impressive.

Better Things to See. I know this is one of the top places to visit in Bangkok but it was a little dull. It is a beautiful home in Bangkok but I would have been fine missing this site. There are more exciting things to see.

Was really impressed and amazed!. I wrote about my experience here in my blog
http://rambomadonna.blogspot.com/2012/01/sawadee-ka-bangkok-2012-day-1.html

Something different in Bangkok. The architecture of the house is very interesting - all teak. Thompson's collections are very much worth seeing. There is a tour (English or French) included in the price of admission.
An Oasis in the middle of Bangkok. Five traditional Chinese houses and lots of antiques in the middle of busy Bangkok
Jim Thompson House. A fascinating place to visit, you need to go on the tour to get into the house. The house is beautiful.
Stunning home, great history, Go see it!. Definitely worth while, fantastic history of Jim Thompson himself, the home is also stunning, and his silks are a superb addition for the home. Check it out!
Great tour. If you are into architecture and history at all, then you should visit the Jim Thompson house. Good tour and a nice little oasis in Bangkok.

Much better than I expected and more interesting too. Don't know what I expected but had a lovely morning here at the house. Tours were held often, like every 15 minutes or so, a locker to put your things in for free so you hand nothing in your hands, Jim Thompson's house was like an oasis in a desert.
Lovely setting in the urban bustle. The house is always a pleasure to escape urban life. The cafe serves up nice drinks while sitting next to the garden. Admission goes to charity.

WOW!. This jewel box of a house contains some outstanding pieces. It's hard to say what's most impressive: the rare antique pieces that are beautifully displayed, the house itself with its stunning and well-preserved architecture, or the quality of the guides that walk you through the house(s).Our guide spoke perfect, barely accented French, and from what I heard from other groups, the English and German presentations were just as good. The explanations given were concise, interesting and relevant.Overall, it's a stunning yet peaceful experience and also a nice retreat from the urban madness that is Bangkok. The gift shop has a few interesting books, cards and posters as well as generally higher-quality silk products, but no statues, carvings or tapestries (which I thought would have been a nice fit).Definitely a must-see if you're in Bangkok, even more so if you're wat-ed out.

An aweseome design. The house created by American business man Jim Thompson is a wonderfully atmospheric place. The house is inspired by Thai architecture and design and yet is original to Jim Thompson. He placed incredible antique furniture, sculpture and paintings that he acquired in Thailand and other parts of Asia.

Little known to most Americans. I had no idea who Jim Thompson was before going to Bangkok. After I took the tour of his house, I knew much more. Tours are offered in English, French, and Thai and although you cannot take photos inside his house, you can around the grounds. The tours are well-done, although sometimes you can feel a little rushed because they have the tours so close together. You cannot see the house without a tour, but you can explore a bit on your own after your tour has ended. A little different, but it seems to work for them.The store on the grounds is way, way too high priced - I should not have been, but I was shocked when I saw the tags on some of the items (I ended up buying my silk in Chiang Mai). Overall, well done - a pleasant way to spend an hour or so in Bangkok.
an oasis. An awesome place to have lunch and do some shopping. Its like stepping into a cool oasis after the hustle and bustle of the city. The food is excellent, i recommend you try this restaurant.
well worth it. If you like design and architecture do yourself a favour and go

A Favorite in Bangkok!. Be sure to visit the Jim Thompson house for a unique excursion in Bangkok. Located off a tiny road near the big Siam Paragon Mall - this is a beautiful museum, garden and restaurant. What a surprise to see how stunning the grounds are kept! The teak thai mansion was incredible - a short 30 minute tour and then you can explore until your heart is content. We didn't try the restaurant but it looked wonderful!

Seemed very expensive to me and despite trying bought nothing. I landed here by accident, as I was dispatched here by someone trying to help me find the right Thai silk to buy. It seemed very very expensive to me and the designs on the scarfs etc, rather old fashioned. I really wanted to spend money but came out empty handed

Interesting and well kept. Tucked away in a back alley, but many tourists still seems to find it. Very well maintained and well organised tours. Good range of products in the shop, but dont expect lower prices than on the high street. Go to one of the factory outlets instead which also have a much bigger range of products.

Take a break at Jim Thompson. When you've had enough of crazy Bangkok, take the time to walk yourself to Jim Thompson. The guided tour is interesting and the guides are charming. the cafe provides a cool place to relax and recharge your batteries.

a little piece of history in the centre of bangkok city. If you are in Bangkok this is a must see - it is amazing to see the beautiful antique house with the lush gardens & all the Thai antiques right in the heart of Bangkok. The tour was great & just being there & seeing the history was fascinating. it was easy to get to & the tour wasn't expensive. There is a shop & restaurant there - we only went on the tour.

An unexpected treat in Bangkok. The Jim Thompson House is a little bit off the beaten track, but very easily accessible via the Skytrain. Walking into the grounds was like leaving Bangkok and entering a different world. Lush gardens, clear pools, and a very noticeable... quiet.When you purchase your admission you're assigned to a tour group and time based on the language in which you want to hear the tour. There are a couple of shops and a bar/restaurant on the grounds where you can kill time if necessary. The tour itself is pretty interesting, as you get to walk through the various rooms and the guide explains why things were built or laid out a certain way, or the significance of certain pieces throughout the house. And of course Jim Thompson's biography has some interesting chapters, too. The tour is fairly short (you're just going through a house, after all), so you're not going to become bored or tired before it's finished.The Jim Thompson House doesn't have the allure of the Grand Palace or the various temples, but it's a wonderfully refreshing change of pace after you've spent a day in the hustle and bustle of Bangkok. If you have a couple of hours to kill I'd recommend a visit.
A must see in bangkok. The jim thompson house is a must see for any visitor to bangkok - beautifully restored and maintained it lends itself to a relaxing hour or two close to the busy shopping area.

Peaceful. We enjoyed our afternoon around the Jim Thompsons home - it was such a contrast to other parts of Bangkok - we did find in difficult to find initially but it is literally just by the skytrain - we were accosted a number of times by local people telling us the house was closed which we suspected they were doing for their own amusement as this is meant to be a well known scam - we didn't fell threatened. The house was interesting and I really enjoyed the quite time walking around
Great little snapshot of life in Bangkok 60 years ago. Jim Thompson house, great little tour, wonderful house, well worth the visit to see how expats lived in Bangkok 60 years ago.
Worth the visit. This was the first time I had been to this very cute little museum which offers a great insight into the recent history of Bangkok. Not far from the hotel either.

A beautiful house. Seeing the house and hearing the history was an excellent way to spend an afternoon. It is very beautiful and particularly interesting to hear about how Mr. Thompson assembled it. There is also an excellent gift shop where you will want to buy souvenirs for yourself as well as everyone back home!

A must for Thai culture lovers. This is one of the most interesting examples of Thai culture and Art. You may go there several times and still find it as interesting as the first time. The architecture is exquisitely traditional. And there are superb examples of Asian Art. Besides, the garden is also worth a visit: lush & tropical. There is also and adjoining café and restaurant, and of course a shop that sells Jim Thomson's products although the Silom branch looks better and has more variety of silk products for sale.

Great atmosphere - good cafe - silly shop. This is a lovely place A definite must to visit and Thompson's collection of antiques (building, pottery, statues, everything) is fascinating. The grounds are also really beautiful. We had an enjoyable drink and snack lunch at the cafe which was very good and sited on the edge of a carp pond. The only negative is the shop with silly fashions and high prices. I have a picture of the JT artistic director - a middle aged Italian wearing white trousers, a yachting blazer and cap, white slip-on shoes with gold buckles and an 18 year old girlfriend! You get the idea - but you can always skip the shop.
A must see. This attraction may not be an obvious one and some may not find it as interesting as I did.

Some say Jim Thompson was an Ideal Man. FYI - Jim Thompson was an American living in Thailand circa 1950's - some say he was a spy. He revived the Thai Silk industry, and his silk business survives to this day. His house is now a museum. It's preserved in it's original state, located just a few minutes walk from the Sky Train station. There is a small fee to take the guided tour. Do the tour in your bare feet to feel the warm teak floor under you. There is a Jim Thompson Silk store at this location - so you can buy something that is easy to take home.

Ehhhh.... This is a nice pleasant space to be in, very calm and the buildings are beautiful. tour guides speak excellent english and old jim does have a fairly interesting story i suppose, but i still found the whole thing quite boring.go if your passing by, or are really into antiques and collectables, otherwise don't be too sad if you miss it, i did a 1hr cross-town trip for it and was quite disappointed.45min tours are cheap though 100bht or 50bht if your under 25 or a student

Worth a visit. The history and mystery of the man and his life is worth seeing a take the 35 min. tour.His shops and stores will be hard to visit without purchasing something for yourself and or a gift for a friend.
Thai silk. My wife spend a lot of money at Jim Thompson House
super nice. Beautiful home and story. A place to take photos, great food. This must be on your list of places to visit. Very well maintained.
A lovely quiet oasis. This popular and well known complex of houses is quite easy to find, near the BTS station. Its a quiet oasis in the middle of the busy Bangkok scene and well worth a visit.
Fascinating. Well presented and interesting tour of this old house and gardens, a lot of history in a well told account of Jim Thompson. Walking distance from MBK/National Stadium down a quiet ski

Hidden Gem In Bangkok. Compared to the hustle and bustle of Bangkok, Jim Thompson House is an urban oasis of tranquility and civility. Hard to find it's at the end of a posh quiet street, near the chic Siam@Siam hotel ask them for directions. We arrived on the backside by river taxi, which is a fun inexpensive way to get there. Again consult an expert before you head out, there are signs but you may miss all the markers. You have to sign up for a guided tour in your specific language. Well worth it!!! After an hour relax by the koi pond in their restaurant for a snack or drink, apparently they have a wine restaurant as well. If you have time venture over to this attraction!!
Worthes a trip. It is a genuine example of a thai house. It is beautiful and one could not go to Bangkok without vising it.

Interesting history and catch the canal boat. Expensive entry fee but an interesting sight for one to see an important part of Bangkok's history. Try getting to Jim Thompson's house using the canal boats as there is a stop just near the house - that is an experience.

Best Museum in Bangkok. Great museum to visit with lovely artefacts and objects. This museum creates a good story about Jim Thompsons life in an atmospheric and compelling way. The tour was a bit rushed but I can see why its necessary and we were able to go back and look at some things. Good cafe. The gallery could be better with more showing, perhaps higher profile art and better publicised. Overall and excellent museum one of the best anywhere, well worth a visit.

Unexpectedly fascinating. We did not know what to expect when we visited the Jim Thompson house, but it provides a fascinating window into 20th century Bangkok history, not to mention the intriguing American who built the house. Credited with helping to revive the traditional Thai silk industry, Jim Thompson's legend appears to have been burnished by his mysterious disappearance in 1967; happily, his hand-built house carries on, as does the excellent collection of antiques and art he assembled. Don't miss a lunch in the beautiful restaurant, either; we had one of the best meals of a two-week trip here, and the delicious fruit drinks alone are worth lingering over.

Wish I had a house like that.... Love to just look at the beautiful furnishing and love that he used some typical Thai architecture inside the home. Goods in the gift shop are overpriced but high quality--I lived upcountry and could get handwoven gorgeous silk and other handmade products for less. I am not much intrigued nor interested in the man himself but love his house ;)

Fascinating. Entrance was a reasonable 100Baht a head, which includes a guided visit in one of five or six languages, Take the Skytrain to National Stadium and walk back a few yards before plunging into the unlikely looking Soi Kasem San 2. Visits in your langagew take place about every 30 mins or so and last 35 minutes. The guide we had was friendly and knowledgeable and spoke fairly good English, answering our questions well.Well worth the visit to see the teak houses that Jim Thompson had re-erected there.
Lovely Oasis in Bangkok. Take an hour or two to see the home of the man who helped revive the Thai silk trade.

Cool place in the middle of huzzle of Bangkok. Place was really nice to see, altough understandin thaienglish is a bit hard to me. Unfortunately, you could not take any photos form there. I would recommend this place to Bangkok visitor. :)
If you're stuck for something to do. It was interesting looking at the house and collectibles, but I wouldn't plan my trip around the visit.
Silk musuem of Jim Thompson. I like the wooden style house for the museum building only. There is nothing, just good for restaurant.

I will someday have a house like this!. The Jim Thompson house is of Jim Thompson - American silk trader in Thailand. It is absolutely gorgeous! The house is very peaceful and has some very beautiful art. The tour guides are informative and very pleasant. It is amazing that it is within the very busy city of Bangkok! If you want a very nice and relaxing afternoon, then you definitely have to go!

Such a hidden gem!. After you've already stopped at the Grand Palace, and Wat Pho, and Wat Arun, I highly recommend taking a trip into this residental alley of Bangkok where he built this architecturally amazing house.

Oasis in the middle of the city. When you visit Jim Thompson House you could easily be forgiven for thinking you were in the countryside. Incredible buildings in the Thai tradition in lush gardens. High quality silk products for sale.A great way to spend a couple of hours.

Gorgeous Teak Building, Wonderful gardens. A bit of a hike after the bus or sky train lets you off, but well worth a visit if you have exhausted all the more important land marks. A few taxi drivers on the walk down the street tried to convince us that it was closed, so that they could take us elsewhere. But this is a common happening in BKK.
Interesting. The Jim Thompson house and story was very interesting the way he incorporated 5 traditional houses into one large complex and the gardens are very nice.

Interesting. Found this place with some difficulty as not well sign posted. The tour guides here are enthusiastic and tell the history of the owner and the house very well. It does feel a little short (about 45 mins) but sufficient if you have young children.
The original expat. Takes about 45 minutes, very well worth it. Interesting story ... beautiful house demonstrating what an American architect in the 40's can do with Thai housing.

Where the silk industry took off.. Jim Thompson saw the potential with silk and made it an international product. His house reflects his love of Thai culture and style. Lovely. You can also buy various high quality silk products but they are also highly priced.
A wonderful experience. Don't miss this if you like atmosphere and wonderful artefacts. The M.B.K. centre nearby is also well worth visiting-excellent food at the food court on the 5th. floor.

Traditional Thai Style. Good place for looking around traditional thai house - calm and quite greenery. It's a good choice for breaking from a long day trip around the busy city. Jim Thomson is also very popular in good quality Thai silk and other Thai souvenirs - recommend to look around their shop.
Lovely place. will come back, really peaceful, took a boat in the khlong behind the ouse to head back ;)
Don't miss this fabulous site!. Beautiful architecture, gardens, and antiques. Cool, quiet, inexpensive, guided tour. One of the best things we did in Bangkok.
Thai traditional house. This is the sample of Thai traditional house in the past also ..many products and life style show you here.

Exquiste house. Really enjoyed visiting the house and looking at the antique china and the shops nearby. Wish photos could be taken and be posted on the Internet. Maybe add something fun and free for the young ones here. Also, make admission free.

Beautiful Thai Architecture. The Jim Thompson House is definitely worth a visit if you are looking for something interesting to do and you have seen all the other "bigger attractions". It is very close to the Siam shopping area and only a couple minutes walk from the Klong Baen Sap canal stop of Ban Krua Nua (which is an adventure in itself!).
