When you arrive, buy your ticket and the nice ladies will walk you to another counter where they will sign you up with a tour in your language. Be prepared to wait 10 - 30 minutes for you tour to start. While you wait, there is a very expensive gift shop selling Jim Thompson silk, a beautiful garden to explore and a restaurant, there is also an art gallery. You are not allowed to enter the main house without a tour guide but the outside houses are open for you to explore either before or after your tour. Jim Thompson's collection is very impressive and the house is beautiful but I would not take the time for this unless you have several days in Bangkok.

Stunning architecture in a beautiful setting. The tour guides are very good and made the experience more interesting with their ability to go off of their script and address all questions raised about the purpose for specific Asian Art exhibited, the unusual construction of the house and the life of Jim Thompson's and the silk industry.Their shop has beautiful high quality items that are pricey. The restaurant is lovely with beautifully prepared food and drinks. There was also a seperate gallery upstairs from the shop.

Must c. This is probably one of the best places to visit in Bangkok. The house is a real gem and the whole setup is quite good. The history behind this man and the mystery of his disappearance are quite fascinating. If you are in Bangkok for more than 1 day, go. it is worth it. The restaurant, I found ok. Nothing great. Finish your tour and go get a bite in one of the food outlets in Siam Paragon (which is a 10 minute walk away) you will enjoy an excellent meal for a reasonable price.Toilets are spotless clean.Staff are extremely efficient and helpful.Aside from the restaurant, this place is a must c in Bangkok.

A tranquil break in the middle of the madness of Bangkok. Beautiful old teak house full of lovely Buddha images and other Thai antiques. The story of Jim Thompson himself is fascinating, too. Lovely green and cool gardens surround the house.There's an opportunity to buy Jim Thompson silk (naturally) and food is also available.Well worth a visit.

Interesting man. Hard to find and most taxis will struggle to get you there, but a haven in the midst of crowded, dirty Bangkok. Interesting story on Jim Thompson and the little restaurant there is very, very good. Worth a stop after you've toured the house, which only takes about 30 minutes. You can shop there, too.
Good, short stop. We did this the morning we left...it was serene and pretty and glad we went but not a "must see" in my book.

Thai Style Museum. If you are into history , culture etc... then u should surely visit Jim Thompson House. JT is famous for Thai Silk and you will never be disappointed by the products you buy for them. They are surely expensive but worth it. They have couple of showrooms to buy silk in the City.

Jim Thompson. I was dragged here and not interested...but i enjoyed the house and surrounds. The history and how this place was put together is really quiet amazing.Good tour guide had heaps of info on the house.

well worth a visit. This is an interesting tour. The guide was obviously well educated on the history surrounding this beautiful and historical site. She also conveyed some passion and seemed proud of the story she had to tell. This made the tour even better and held our interests tightly throughout the tour. I have no trouble recommending this tour. Easiest way to get there is by taxi or BTS.

A glimpse of a well restored Thai house. Jim Thomson is credited as the founder of the Thai silk industry. His house, which is a collection of several old Thai houses relocated to Bangkok on the edge of a klong, is well worth a visit. JT house is walking distance from National Stadium. You do not need to get a tour to visit this house. Except for monks holidays it is open every day. You buy a ticket, leave your shoes and bags in a personal locker that you hold the key for and take a tour - a few languages are offered. There is a lovely coffeeshop on the grounds as well as the shop where you can buy beautiful JT products of silk, cotton, etc - this shop is expensive but superb. If you have time to go to the JT outlet - (see my other review) you will find cheaper items but it is a fair way out of town on the train or 20 minutes by taxi (off peak).Combine this visit (you need approx 2 hours) with lunch and shopping at MBK (see my MBK review)
GREAT PHAD THAI. Well, everywhere you eat there is a great Phad thai but at Jim thomsons--it was well designed and plated. so if you are eating with your eyes aswell, this is great!
Wood experience for oldies. The houses that JT took back to Bangkok are a blast of the 40s or 50s. Lovely but will not appeal to all.
Fantastic day. Culture and peace with a lovely shop to spend the holiday money in
Still well worth a visit. Returned after many years to find the tour just as great as it had been so long ago. The shop and the cafe were a surprise and a bonus.
Arty. Tours are a bit quick and to large to hear well but it's a beautiful part of the overall Thai theme.

Well worth a visit. This historical house is lovely, and houses lots of authentic antiques. The grounds are wonderful, and very well-kept, making for some great photos. I also recommend making a trip to the Jim thompson Store (look online). There you can buy the wonderful silks mentioned in the tours, which are still the best quality and highest selling in Thailand.
Old-world class and great atmosphere. Well organized (busy) tour of this landmark home.Now if only our Bangkok hotel was like this !!Memorable visit, would like to know more about the man.
Beautiful. Take the canal boat there and have a banana shake in the sublime garden.

A peaceful experience. This house is definitely an oasis in the middle of Bangkok's concrete jungle given that it is only 3-400m away from the main shopping mall strip on Rama 1. The house is very beautiful and the tour (compulsory) is informative, although you are not allowed to take photos inside the house. There is a small cafe/restaurant that also does reasonable food and coffee, but you could also walk up to Paragon or Central World after a visit for a feed just as easily. Two tips for a "real" Bangkok experience: 1. catch a khlong (canal) boat on the Saem Seap canal to get to the house (the actual pier is about 200m walk from the house, but easy to get to after getting off the boat); and, 2. find the pedestrian bridge near Jim Thompson's house that takes you across the canal to the neighbourhood called Baan Khrua where the old silk workers still have looms etc.
Very Interesting Story. Beautiful little house - interesting story, nice restaurant and gift shop

Can we move into the Jim Thompson House?. The house is lovely and every detail was clearly taken very seriously by Jim Thompson and the managers of the site. Where else would you get to see a cat-shaped chamber pot? The only glitch was at the cafe when the staff got flustered when a celebrity walked in. So flustered that they forgot our order and that of others around us. Minor glitch, though. Go check out the stuffed elephant-shaped toys at the shop!

beautiful little musuem. Cant praise this place enough. They dont have many items on display, but every one is exquisit and the service and staff available in this beautiful setting are simply tops.Do remember to cross this little bridge of the adjacent canal and meet one of Jim Thompsons original silk workers at Bann Krua silk who now has her own place, weaving beautiful pieces of cloth for sale at a fraction of the Jim Thompson shop prices.
a pleasant surprise. I didn't think I would like it, but in fact, loved it!

Beautiful and Different. I didnt know what to expect but heard this was a must see. They provided tours in a few diff languages which was great to learn the history behind Thai Silk and Jim Thompson. Beautiful house and grounds and very different which was a nice change and very relaxing. Worth the trip.
interesting. Great history of the silk trade. Very high quality silk.
cool place. being in central bangkok it feels like an oasis. also the food in their restaurant is one of the best i ever had

wonderful oasis for lunch. We were quite hungry and the restaurant provided a wonderful setting for a late lunch. It was a little more expensive than typical restaurants in Bangkok, but worth it. The tour of the house provides insight into how traditional Thai houses used to look. Very pretty. The gift shop has many beautiful items. And although more expensive than what you'd find in the markets, nice quality.

A little commercialized but interesting. So many people visit this attraction, they have organized tours every few minutes. It was fascinating to learn how these people lived in such a relaxed, natural way years ago. The house is very interesting and you learn quite a bit from the guide. Of course, there is a store on site where you can buy most of the same things you see at the Jim Thompson retail outlets, really beautiful and colorful scarves, shirts and much more.

Ok, but not awesome like everyone else claims. The house is nice, the tour is very solemn, almost like being in a church and the story is somewhat interesting. It is definitely not the best thing to do in Bangkok, however, and I'm somewhat surprised that so many people are blown away by it. It's cute, its nice... but that's about it. If you have an hour or two to kill... go and visit it.

A Hint of What Bangkok once was.... Although it has become increasingly a tourist attraction rather than a peaceful retreat in the past couple of decades, you can still get a sense of the enormous love this foreigner had for his adopted country in this initimate dwelling. Hard to imagine that the whole area was very much like this (low key wood dwellings along canals) only 50 years ago.

Well worth the visit. Highly recommended. Quiet oasis in the middle of busy Bangkok. Excellent history of the Thai silk industry developed by Jim Thompson, along with artifacts and the traditional Thai house. Guided tours are well done. Definitely worth seeing instead of your 3rd or 4th temple.

Interesting day trip. Jim Thompson stores are all over town and it is worth a trip to his 'house' to get the back story. For a small fee, you get a guided tour of his actual house, as well as having access to a lovely cafe and the shop. Worth a visit.
Amazing place. A fantastic building with a fantastic story. The shop is over priced but you can always go to the outlet shop.

If you have extra time.... The cafe was very relaxing yet overpriced as well as the gift shop. You have to go on a tour as you can only see the grounds otherwise. We had to wait 25 min for our English tour so we took some pictures in the small but green garden. The 40 min tour was okay with a quick walk around the garden and somewhat traditional/non-traditional Thai home. Nice artwork from china and around but really nothing amazing. There are other things to do that is more exciting in Bangkok. Yet if you have extra time and 150 baht, check it out.

Interesting and beautiful house. We went in expecting a historical guide to how Jim Thompson revived the silk trade in Thailand. It turned out to be guideed tour of his house. Very beautiful place surrounded by a garden on the river. They also have a shop on the premises where you can buy the products. A bit on the expensive side

Very nice visit. Very nice visit to special teak house well decorated and interesting,we did visit eith private guide a few days in bangkok and reserved on ten net at thailandvoyagecom a serus cie installed everywhere in thailand
Silk.. The home of silk everything, the best display of Thai culture

Beautiful Home, Good Tour. Jim Thompson's House is easy to get to just off National Stadium BTS. The house and grounds are beautiful. The tour is short, but very well done. It is definitely worth a visit.
This was Bangkok 30 years ago. Time machine...... beautiful and simple. It was Thailand at its best

Bring your wallet!. personally, I found this to be cash excessive. I wanted to purchase a tie but not for $40. This is a high end establishment, honestly, I've never heard of JT until my visit to Bangkok.

Gem in Bangkok. This is really a very interesting place to viisit. A beuatifull wooden house, where Mr. Thompson used to live. The story of his life is quiet something special, it is still not known how he disappeared.
An escape from the city. Seemed like it was somewhere else when you are right in the heart of the city. Short but interesting tour - good cafe

What a pretty place!. I really enjoyed my visit to Jim Thompson House. The house is impressive and you get to learn many details about Jim Thompson. The gardens are beautiful and the restaurant in the premises quite wonderful!

Oh My, Don't Miss It. The Jim Thompson house is a study in the lovely indoor outdoor Thai architecture and living. Both the house and the gardens are smack in the city but once inside the walls you feel miles away in a garden retreat. Besides his love for silk, Jim Thompson loved and collected asian art some of which is displayed in the house. We love it and will visit it again.

Nice place, most definitely worht a visit. Appart from Jim Thompson's romantic story, I appreciated the traditional Thai luxury villa for its architectural value. Nice caffe, if not to crowded. Go early.

Incredible Teak House. One of the most beautiful homes I've ever seen, this is the home of the American who revived the Thai silk business. The house is amazing as are the furnishings. The tour guides, which are given in several different languages, are outstanding, but these young ladies are so soft-spoken it would be wise to stay very close to them during the tour.

I find this house boring.. I don't know why everyone loves this house? I have been traveling on vacation around Asia for years and it is just like any other nice Asian home? Has stilts for cool air flow....gardens like they all do, perhaps it is the lore of the missing Jim Thompson? For me, it was a snoozer....and hot!

Like travelling back in time!. A few hundreds meters away from ultamodern Bangkoks shopping malls and skytrains you walk into a small street and there you are! At the Jim Thompson House. It is a tropical garden with old wooden Thai houses filled with antiques. Feels like travelling back in time from the modern city. The old houses and the antiques all have an interesting history but there is also modern history to be learned. The very interesting history of Jim Thompson. The café and restaurant is also very good and relaxing. If you like shopping. Go to the malls in after breakfast. When need a break for lunch. Leave the malls and have lunch here instead. Much more relaxing! After lunch and a sightseeing tour of the grounds your batteries will be recharged for more shopping!

Didn't go in.. Went to the trouble of finding this place and then they wanted to retain my bag with passport, camera etc. I am not that trusting so got a refund and walked away. JT silk is quite dear too.

Worth a trip. We weren't that excited to have this included in our tour but is is worth it. Tucked away down an alley is a garden oasis. The tour of the house is more about traditional thai houses than silk. The guides are brilliant and the story of JIm Thompson is very interesting.

Bit of Serenity in Bangkok. The house itself is beautiful, filled with Asian treasures and with a lovely garden. We also ate in the restaurant, in the outdoor section overlooking the koi pond, which was also lovely.

Beautiful, tranquil, interesting. This was a surprise highlight of our time in Bangkok for me. The house is viewed as part of a guided tour, very interesting and the house is absolutely beautiful. The Thai's obviously have a lot of respect for Jim Thompson and he clearly respected the Thais when he built the house. Set in beautiful gardens it is a photographers haven. The small gift shop is good for cards and postcards, the larger gift shop more expensive fabric items. There is a cafe by the pond and they serve delicious and beautiful food at reasonable prices - well worth a stop to cool down before or after your tour.
Simply amazing. One of the best place to see around the area of Sukhumvit.

Interesting, but not a must see. We visited this house because our guide book called this a must see in Bangkok. You get a short 35 minute tour in the language of your choice. You can wander around the small garden by yourself, but you can not go into the house without being in a tour. We spent about an hour here. I don't think I would see it again.

Wonderful Jim Thompson House. Feeling slightly overwhelmed by Bangkok, we spent a few hours at the Jim Thompson house - we had an excellent guided tour and loved the feeling of being in an oasis in the middle of a really hectic city. My favourite sight in Bangkok and they do really nice silk scarves etc as well.Most highly recommended!
Unique, interesting, and a piece of Thai history. Authentic house in the middle of Bangkok, filled with an intriguing story of an entrepreneur who came and flourished and then disappeared.

Interesting piece of Thai silk's history - worth a visit. Jim Thompson house is ideally located and very easy to get to. The house is quite amazing and the items inside make it even more interesting. You can wander around the area freely but you can only get inside the house in a guided group. Our English speaking guide was very informative and her English was good. Did not check the restaurant or the shop but we enjoyed the visit very much. The toilets were certainly one of the best maintained ever. If you want to see some history while in Bangkok I can warmly recommend the Jim Thompson House!

A favorite place. One of my favorite places in Bangkok. A cool, lush, piece of old Bangkok in the middle of the city. We always have this on our schedule when entertaining visitors from the US. Very interesting tale about the adventures of Jim Thompson, with gracious Thai guides.

High taste, good quality. A visit here gives you a glimpse of the traditional Thai house. This is a rich man's house filled with antiques. The tours are short and informative. The souvenir shop offered items of high quality but on the expensive side.
Interesting piece of history. Interesting piece of history that has been well preserved. The tour was very good here and gives you some perspective on Thai life and how it has evolved.
Nothing special. More of a ode to Mr. Thompson and a sales point, the restaurant was very good...
worth a look. It isn't an expensive entry and an interesting house. the cafe facilities are good worth eating their.

Oasis garden in BKK. Located In Rama 1 Road, ( at the end of the 1st soi in the right hand side) 10 min walk from BTS national stadium. It's really a smala paradise in Bkk down Town , oasis garden , and olé Thai wooden house. The rate is 100 bath/ pers. To have a visit with private guide ( englishbor french speacking, 30 min). With explain Jim Thomson live and private collection of slik painting and Bouddha collection. Thérè is olso restaurant and boutique.
Good Cultural House. This was a very nice, quiet place on how Jim Thompson lived and a brief history of his life with a display of his work and collections.
Worth a trip. Beautiful house, nicely restored, right on a canal.
Beautiful house and gardens. The house is impressive and Jim Thompson's story is fascinating. The garden is beautiful. It's worth going.
The founder of Bangkoks tourism and much more. This was a well organised attraction and with charming guides.

Very stylish, interesting. This place is an oasis in bustling Bkk. Don't believe the hustlers who tell you it's closed! Nice restaurant, reasonable prices but small portions. An interesting slice of history.

Developing beautifully. First visited 25 years ago. The site has been evolving ever since but I think Mr Thompson would approve. The restauant is worth the visit in itself and on the last couple of ocassions that's what we've been there for. You can access the restaurant without paying to go on the tour around the house.
Mid twentieth century first class life. This was a great window into an interesting persons life from when Thailand was still very far off and exotic.

A typical Thai house. Supposedly the house he lived in before he disappeared. He re-invented Thai silk, before being lost in the village. Nothing really exciting and they want you to buy cheap nasty trinkets. Having said that - its something to do if you are bored and walking down there the little stalls at the side of the road - some sell fantastic old fashioned hand painted Thai paintings. They don't look much, but put them in a black wood frame when you are home and the look fantastic. And they only cost 100Bht. We bought 10 of them for us and they look superb.
Must see. I've been there numerous timesLove the silks though very expensive compared to markets
Cool place to visit. Great history and architecture. Gift shop was good, too. Definitely worth a visit.
beutifull old teak house. history was great lots of silk for sale thai silk not the cheap stuff but still resonable

THe mysteries of Jim Thompson, on view. Jim Thompson's story and mysterious disappearance is one of legend, so visiting his home, inspired by a love of Thailand and Thai architecture, make this a worthy visit. Thompson (mostly silk) products remain inspired and his legend kept alive in excellence of design and quality production. If you appreciate viewing personal historic sites and seeing how (well-to-do)Thai's lived in years past, this really is worth the time.

Not to be missed when in Bangkok. Luckily friends told us about Jim Thompson House when we were traveling to Bangkok. The house is beautiful and the landscaping gorgeous. The guided tour is just the right length to be able to appreciate some of the features of the house without dragging on. Now we are keen to read more about this interesting man and the mystery surrounding his dissappearance.
Outlet has good buys for those who can design their own. Apparel on top floor discounted from all the other mall stores and other floors have bolts of every imaginable silk color and weight.
More a store than anything else. We enjoyed seeing it on the outside, but even though they say you can walk around it for free, you can't. They ask that you buy a ticket just to walk the perimeter.
Worth spending your time. Interesting and somewhat unsusual attraction in Bangkok.Nice to escape the crowds and the vendors you usually find at Grand Palace etc.

Like National Trust on holiday. With the absence of anything like the National Trust this is the nearest you'll get. It's a fascinating home of grand traditional architecture amidst beautiful albeit small tropical gardens. One of the highlights for me was spotting giant flower pots which housed populations of tiny colourful fish - wonderfully creative urban ponds. The artefacts gathered by this American entrepreneur are incredible - from traditional stone buddhas hundreds of years old to intricate furniture. The dark panelling of the wood offers a warm, soothing sanctuary that acts as a welcome escape from the bustle of Siam only a short walk away. The staff offer tours in a multitude of languages and although not always easy to understand they are very enthusiastic.A couple of words of warning - the adjacent canal stinks!! I mean truly truly stinks so be careful if walking next to the fence in the garden so as not to get splash by the fetid water. Also you'll need to take your shoes off to walk around the house so be prepared to have clean socks ;o) Also no photography is allowed in the house which is a shame. I was dubious about visiting an attraction that was in effect based upon a westerner's ideals - however Jim Thompson (though no longer with us) has done a tremendous job of preserving and combining a small slice of Thai culture amidst a bustling modern metropolis.
Must see. Lovey setting, very good restaurant, peaceful, informative - a must see
very good an nice food. i really enjoyed the tour and also the restaurant services good and tastefull food and a very relax atmosphere

Jim Thompson's House. Nice house with some nice bits in it, but what's the point! Jim who? ...who cares! Do yourself a favour and avoid this over hyped American fad. Stick to traditional sights much more interesting :)
OK, but. a little tacky, and surrounded by sky rises which makes look a little outdated and false

Must See. The Jim Thompson House is a very cheap and very interesting destination in Bangkok. The english speaking guide was great and very informative. I would highly suggest anyone to go and check it out for under $4 (Dollars U.S.) You get a tour around the gardens and the house.

Nice place and lovely garden. Really interesting house and history. Husband took about 1000 macro shots of the beautiful garden. Shop is really overpriced, but well worth a visit. Great to take a canal boat back to the hotel, too!
A bit of history , a bit of mistery. Excellent value, top guide ( excellent English) and fun - looking back into the past

Fusion architecture at its best. Come to see the wonder of how Jim Thompson, the king of Thai silk transformed an old Thai house into a lovely sanctuary of peace and charm, lovely use of western and Thai furnitures and tasteful decor everywhere. The whole house is like a treasured piece of art! The gift shop is wonderful too, with great selections to suit every budget. If you are a fabric lover, you will fall in love with thai silk after this visit. A visit to this place should be essential for any first time visitors to Bangkok, just like the Grand Palace, and many other beautiful and well known temples dotted around Bangkok.

Worth a visit. Makes a nice visit for an hour one afternoon if you are in the area , beautiful canal fronted old teak house , multi lingual guide give all the history,,,,would be lovely to have a house like this!!
Interesting and worth a visit. A charming place, with the mystery surrounding Thompson's disappearance adding to the allure. Pleasant staff, items in gift shop expensive but of good quality.

Enjoyed this.. Lovely Oasis in Bangkok. Fish ponds and a good restaurant. Enjoyed the tour and the Jim Thompson story, and I really wasn't expecting to. It was a very pleasant couple of hours and we got back into the city via the canal bus.

An informative and peaceful experience in th city centre. This is well worth a visit. The guided tour focusses primarily on the house and lifestyle rather than on Jim Thompsons contribution to the Thai silk industry, but is nevertheless very informative about his life, Thai traditions and building design. After the tour you can relax in the gardens - surprisingly tranquil considering it is in the heart of the city, and browse the shop - high quality products to suit most pockets (you can buy similar stuff outside more cheaply, but not of the same quality)Easy to get to (National Stadium BTS station and MBK centre clos by), and you can fit this attraction in with a spot of shopping in the many malls in the vicinity.

A deservedly classic stop on a tour of Bangkok highlights. Have been here many times. Whenever friends visit we put this top on our list of tour destinations. We let them go on their own to the Grand Palace, but escort them here every time. Foreigners and Thais alike are interested at the perspectives on Thai housing design and life presented here. Don't forget to visit the exhibit gallery upstairs to the south of the entrance. A stop at the cafe-restaurant can also be enjoyable.

Not worth the visit. We didn't find this place as interesting as the reviews made it out to be. Its all about the house itself and nothing to do with what Jim Thompson actually did for Thai silk. We didn't really understand the underlying objective. Not recommended and not worth the price and effort of going there.

A special , tranquil experience in Bangkok. I loved my visit to the historic Jim Thompson House! It provided a wonderful and interesting break from Bangkok's busy and exciting street scene. The garden is lovely and so is the cafe by the beautiful fish pond. Our tour guide was extremely informative and "Namita" and "Mint" were lovely and helpful Garden tour guides.
Love wood house. it is very interesting story about Jim T. and the house is wonderfull. all wood in teak beatifull feeling walking without shoes ...

Gorgeous and Fascinating. Jim Thompson lived a fascinating life and befell a mysterious death. The home itself retains some mystery. It is gorgeous--lots of teak wood. It was assembled by putting together various old Thai homes. You really get a sense of Thai life in the 19th century. Our tour guide spoke of Thai superstitions and how they played into the architecture of traditional homes (areas for good spirits, barriers for bad). Thompson's collection of Burmese antiques was particularly interesting.

one of the few places worth going to Bangkok to visit. Unique and well worth a visit. It's also very easy to find near MBK shopping center with a sky train stop a the end of the soi. The only negative is the way over priced silk products on sale, cheaper elsewhere.
Beautiful affordable products. Worth the visit and lovely gifts for friends and family.
Quiet oasis in a busy town. Don't miss this collection of old lana houses, the gardens, and silk store. Mr. Thompson a CIA affiliat left a great legacy with his museum.

Jim Thompson House. A tranquil oasis in the heart of a concrete jungle. I was captivated by this beautiful Thai home, which is actually a number of traditional wooden houses cleverly joined together and was the home of Jim Thompson, "Mr Thai Silk" for a number of years. It is a bit off the beaten track, but well worth a visit.

expensive. very expensive plenty of other places to buy silk however within walking distance about 400m of MBK shopping plaza much better go to 3rd floor and a nice young thai lady selling silk scarves

little hidden but worth visiting. different piece of history I liked a lot
shop is not cheap but there is also an outlet in Bangkok which I didn't visit so can not say if the prices are really cheaper
what an amazing house. Absolutely worth visiting, the tour guides are very knowledgeable and add humour to the 30 minute tour. Beautiful garden. Amazing shop with silk products.

A gorgeous environment frozen in time but with a living buzz. Jim Thompson house is both beautiful and historical.It is like a mini museum with fine collections of pottery and furniture collected by the great man. The wooden houses are original and beautifully maitained and the evnue is a must see for any visitor.You can obtain the best quiche for lunch overlooking a beautiful pool full of carp.Atruly lovely afternoon out.a great place to take a girlfriend/boyfriend/husband/wife for lunch!!!
Living up to it's legend. Wonderful Thai silks from shirts, tablewares. ties, cosmetic bags to everyday and evening bags. Helpful staff.

an interesting tour. I travelled with a friend and his young daughter to the Jim Thompson house on the Khlong Saen Saep Express Boat from the pier at Asoke (great fun in itself) and then enjoyed a very pleasant guided tour around the Jim Thompson house. Very good value and well guided.

Do not miss. We had such a wonderful time at the Jim Thompson House. It is such a nice home and we really enjoyed our tour and learning more about the Thai Silk. Afterwards, we enjoyed lunch at the cafe on site. It was good food at affordable prices, I would definitely recommend it.

One of the best examples of great design in the world.. This is a magical place if you enjoy feeling like you are peeking into someones house while they are away. Jim Thompson had amazing taste... the grounds are immaculate- gorgeous gardens and lots of buildings to walk around and inside. Really one of the best examples of great design in the world. Pay for the tour so that you can go into the houses. If you cannot afford/or don't have the time, you can still wander around the grounds (even though it looks like you can't). This place captured my imagination sort of like the Swiss Family Robinson at Disneyland in the 70's did. This would be post rescue and large family inheritance, and some schooling in architecture, oh, and they became art collectors. There is also great store here, and what looked like a nice restaurant. Note: Save your money and shop across the canal at the Baan Krua muslim neighborhood where the original silk weavers lived and worked. You can still find a couple here today. Really cool to see them making the product from end to end and being able to purchase at a great price. I love this place so much that I purchased a book about the house and all of the collections so that I could study further.
Very interesting. Jim Thompson was quite an interesting man. His home is amazing.

Interesting house, but not a must see, if you don't have the time. I'm glad I stopped by based on what Jim Thompson did for the silk industry in Thailand. Interesting architecture (or course) and lovely gardens. However, guided tour itself was just so so. Not much depth - didn't learn anything. They could've made more of the history of the country at that time, the adversity that JT faced, the lack of accessibility JT had to overcome, etc. Also, left me wondering why someone would want to live with all those mosquitos and chamberpots in the 20th century.

Worth a visit, lovely traditional Thai House. Beautiful traditional thai architecture on display, some really gorgeous artifacts from the Jim Thompson collection. English guided tours are held at very regular intervals throughout the day. You will be asked to leave your shoes behind when you enter the house. Nice Jim Thompson restaurant to have some lunch or a snack while you wait for your tour (worth booking as it gets busy if you go on a weekend) and large shopping area to purchase some silk bags, scarves etc. The tour is not long (30 mins or less) so its fine for children.
Beautiful home and a piece of history!. One of my favorite places to visit! It's a beautiful traditional Thai home with incredibly history. A must see when in Bangkok. I've visited several times.

Great house shame about the shop. Really interesting morning spent here. The guides are very informative and you are able to wander around the exterior to take photos.The shop is very well stocked and very overpriced.

A memoir of tropical garden. Entering Jim house, is more like walking into the memories , a bangkok living in the past where the air still fresh. Its very quiet and tranquil place in bangkok. Jim collection of antiques is also worth to appreciate and we can also buy his silk design here.
not bad. Jim Thompson house is quite interesting, worth at least one visit.
Interesting. A nice afternoon can be spent here. Interesting insight into traditional houses, handicrafts and the influence of foreign visitors.

If you love home decorating, go!. Interesting history, great decor to view and to buy! Skipmthe cheap silks at the night markets and buy yourself quality silk products here. I promise (based on multiple trips experience) that in the long run, the pricier Jim Thompson stuff will be the better buy.

Where is Jim Thompson??. Jim Thompson Silk House is a gem of a place located right on the klong in central BKK. Easy to get to (just head to MBK shopping mall on the SKytrain and cross the road). Jim Thompson's House is an oasis in an otherwise frantic part of BKK. I have been three times now with different groups of travellers and they have all come away enjoying the trip. It costs just 100 baht (thai or foreigner) to get in and certainly well worth it.
Worth a visit. Only 100 baht to visit and the included tour was very informative.

Intersting place!. If you have an hour or so to spare, I recommend visiting Jim Thompson House. It's hard to believe you're in the heart of Bangkok once you enter. The buildings and gardens are quite beautiful and tranquil. The guide provides a clear and informative introduction to the house and its history. Interesting place!
Shoes off entire tour. Walking tour approx 45 minutes. Bring a fan and be sure to remove shoes. Beautiful house/property...end of tour at shop. better when it isn't blazing hot outside.

What a great place!. I've been here about 4 times and never tire of going through the house, having lunch in the wonderful restaurant and shopping in the store.It's so very easy to get to this place. A five minute walk from the sky train station and the people who work there could not be any friendlier. I always pick up great ideas for decorating and buy gifts to take back to the states. Put it on your "MUST VISIT" list!!!!

Inspiring and Beautiful. An inspiring story and a beautiful house and gardens. We had curries for lunch at the restaurant and it was the best meal I had during my week in Bangkok. Save some spending money to purchase some of the special thai silk products especially cute makeup bags and purses.
nice surprise. nice visit with guide! an amazing house.Don´t believe when strangers say it´s closed...
Lovely and must see. If you want to see the real thaï art and architecture, this is the place to go.

A fascinating glimpse into another world. Well worth a visit - and not just for the quality of clothing found in the shop (they have two more at the airport). Jim Thompson reintroduced silk into Thailand and in the process collected a wide range of interesting things. Guided ours are provided, followed by time to just soak in the atmosphere in the garden.

Traditional Thai teak house with exotic garden.. Jim Thompson is a legend in Thailand for his contributions to Thai silk industry and his reassembled teak house on a Bangkok canal.This is one place to experience the Thailand of the past.the gardens are beautiful and the house has an amazing collection of artifacts.The guided tour is both informative and not too time consuming.I would also recommend a visit to the Jim Thompson shops which are world famous for many decades.

Exceptional Staff and great place to visit. The house by itself is a great place to visit. The guided tour (included in the fee) is very nice. However, I wanted to write about the staff, who were truely extraordinary. When we reached this place, we realized our cab had left with our camera bag. We reported this to the staff at the Jim Thompson house and they immediately swung into action. They called my hotel and found out the number of my cab (the hotel had reserved the cab). Then they called the cab company and got the cab driver's phone number. Then they talked with the cab driver. They did all of this when we were looking at the house - so when we completed our visit they had already worked out a date and time when the cab driver would meet with us and return us our camera. It took a few more phone calls to the cab driver to get everything straightened out, but the staff took care of all the conversations to help us with the language barriers. The staff at this house were really very helpful and went out of their way to talk patiently with us, find out where we were staying, what our plans were for the day and the next day, and when they should advise the cab driver to bring back our camera. Lesson learned - write down the number of the cab you drive in, so you can get back in touch if necessary.

Brilliant.. This is the place to go for quality, unique silk products. Remember, there are also outlets, so if you are a budget traveller, or just want to get the most for your money there are (to my knowledge) 2 outlets in Bangkok.

Good for a morning or afternoon. I read about this place in the Rough Guide and as it was within walking distance of our hotel we decided to go. Its only 100B each so it wont break the bank.You have to go on a guided tour, which they offer in a number of languages. Its good that they make you do that because if you just walked around yourself you would be done in 10 minutes flat and wouldnt see or learn anything. It was quite interesting to learn about traditional Thai houses and also Jim Thompson himself. The gardens are pretty nice to. They had a little free art exhibit as well which was worth a look round.The gift shop is typically overpriced as is the restaurant. We didnt eat anything there, why would you in my mind when you can eat better and more authentic food for a fraction of the price in any number of local places. If you are in the area then its worth popping in but I wouldn't go out of my way to get here if you have to pay for a taxi / tuk tuk.

5-star!. Jim Thompson house museum is a collection of Thai traditional houses that were acquired by Jim during his residency in Thailand. When one enter the complex; Jim Thompson store was directly located near the entrance. The second floor was used as exhibition hall. Across the store; another building houses the ticket booth and the restaurant and bar. Price to enter the museum is THB100 per adult with students only need to pay half. After buying the ticket, you will be greeted by the museum attendant and brought to the briefing center and assigned your guided tour time. You can wander around the ground, but to access the inside of the houses; you'll need a guide. There is no option to wander around inside the houses on your own. My tour guide was Ann, a Thai with Chinese descent. She was witty, informative, yet cheerful bringing the tour in lively manner. She claimed to be a newbie, but the way she conducted the tour is just as smooth as professional guide. She tried to become a good host on showing around the house without making the session too monotone and yet still managed to capture all the details. Tour began with exploring the garden and passing around few smaller pavilion such as printing house, rice storage, spirit house, etc. Then before entering the main house (few Thai traditional houses connected into a single house), one needs to take off the shoes. Ann later mentioned one of the reason was because traditional Thais do many activities on the floor, so it is preferred to be bare feet inside the house. Inside the house; the tour began at the bencharong room which houses the former store, then continue to dining room, main hall, study room, guest bedroom, and Jim's master bedroom. Along the way, Ann was describing every details of interesting facts and demonstrate some interesting ideas behind the houses. The tour ended just by the staircase leading to the shoe storage. Afterwards, you are free to roam around the garden once again, take photos, or shop at the souvenir store inside the museum complex or Jim Thompson boutique in front. However, no photography inside the main houses. Access: take BTS to National Stadium and take exit 1, walked pass the shophouses until you reach Soi Kasemsan 2 (there is a big signage in Thai and English pointing to Jim Thompson house museum), enter the narrow lane and walk around 300m until the end of the lane. The museum is directly to the left by the canal. Verdict: the success of the tour depends greatly on how your guide takes you on the tour. My tour session was nonetheless the best part of the whole visit to Jim Thompson house museum thanks to the great guide! A love/fascination in architecture, design, arts, and culture will also help to enjoy the whole experience. Will I recommend to others: absolutely!Will I return again to Jim Thompson house museum: definitely!

Interesting Museum in the Midle of City. Incredible history and I loved visiting Jim Thompson's HouseBefore the tour start we have to wait 5 to 10 minutes depending to the number of guests who are visiting the house. The tour takes about one hour and our English speaking guide she was delightful and knowledgeable. We learned a lot form their culture. , it has a beautiful that you can wander around in while you are waiting for your tour. it is a lovely place to sit with a lotus pond and plenty of fish.  The house is full of beautiful antiques and paintings and decoration with some other sandstone statues, I especially liked his bedroom which has a lovely view of the garden and the drawing room which is so tastefully decorated
Loved it!. Fantastic house, beautiful gardens, good knowledgeable tour guide, lovely shop and lunch, pond side was a lovely experience. Highly recommended!

A SO SO ATTRACTION. I enjoyed the tour of the buildings and looking at the interior art works but would disagree with other posters about this being a 'must see' whilst in Bangkok.The guide was good at her job but became very repetitive with the phrase "That's right" with an amazing American twang. It is a pleasant spot to go too but unless you have won the lottery, any purchase at the shop will cost you an arm and a leg.If you having nothing else to see and do in Bangkok you may consider this place worth a visit.

Not to be missed.. A beautiful conflation of different traditional Thai houses achieved with great sensitivity. Set in fine, peaceful gardens with fishpond to amuse children and a history of the house and its former owner to fascinate adults. A fine collection of mostly Thai antiques. One of the best things in Bangkok.

oasis of calm in Bustling Bangkok. We visited and enjoyed looking through the gardens = beautiful, with pools and fish, lush tropical plantings. The staff were helpful - giving my daughter student rates with no ID. The guides English was excellent, and the group was not too large, nor did we have to wait too long for the tour, and anyway you can browse the gardens whilst waiting for the tour. The commentary was informative ( if slightly reverential to Mr Thompson)- the background to the house etc. We also heard the muezzin calling the faithful to prayer on the other side of the river, which all added to the experience.We enjoyed a drink in the cafe after the tour, but thought the prices for the silks a bit high for us anyway - although they did seem like excellent quality.

Tranquil haven in a busy noisy city. I loved visiting Jim Thompson's House, it has lush gardens that you can wander around in while you are waiting for your tour. The tour takes about a half hour and our English speaking guide was delightful and knowledgeable. The house is full of beautiful antiques and paintings, I especially liked his bedroom which has a lovely view of the garden and the drawing room which is so tastefully decorated . It cost 100 baht for the tour, 50 baht for students/ under 25s. After our tour we had a fruit smoothie in the cafe, it is a lovely place to sit with a lotus pond and plenty of fish. There is also a Jim Thompson silk shop on the premises, I found the prices were the same at each of the outlets including the airport (minus the tax of course). Well worth an hour or two of your time.
SO BEAUTIFUL. Great place to vist! The tour was very interesting and the gardens was beautiful. Easy to get to yourself,

Worth your time to see this beautiful house with traditional decor. I wouldn't put a visit here at the very top of your list while in Bangkok but it is certainly worth your time. The traditional decor is beautiful and the visit is very relaxing.

Beautiful house / museum. Wasn't particularly interested in visiting this, but then we ended up there and I was so glad. Beautiful house and gardens and so many interesting and beautiful artifacts. Excellent tour.

A beautiful peaceful place in the midst of Bangkok craziness!. We were first accidentally brought to the Jim Thompson store by our cab driver, but eventually made it to the real deal.The cab drove down a small street, and we were convinced that we were going to end up somewhere random once again, but at the end of the street we finally saw the sign.Ticket entry is about 100 Baht (or 50 Baht for under 25s) and gives you access to the actual house where Jim Thompson stayed and a tour (I think languages were English or French). The actual house was a wonderful example of a mesh between Eastern and Western sensibilities and was filled with many antiques that Jim Thompson had collected throughout his stay. The house was surrounded by a beautiful garden that was nice to walk around in while waiting.The tour guides were funny and informative, and the Jim Thompson cafe served lovely food if you wanted a lunch break!

A quiet Oasis. We visited this house at about 9.30 in the morning. At that time it was very quiet; we only waited 3 mins for a tour that was in English. The tour of the house was compulsory, we had to leave our bags in lockers and remove shoes when entering the house (so make sure your socks do not have holes on the day you are visiting). The tour guide was very pleasant and knowledgable, and after she had finished speaking, we had time to look around each room on our own before moving on. It is a relatively small house (even though it is actually many traditional Thai houses that Jim Thompson connected together to make his home), though we did not bump into any other groups when on our tour. You cannot take pictures inside the house, but it did not bother me as that is something that is very common in old houses in the UK.We were free to wander the cool and shady gardens at will. It easy to forget that you are in the centre of a busy city when there. At only B100 (approx £2) entry for an adult, I thought it was very good value. The house is a westerners interpretation of tradition Thai living so is not for those who want an authentic Thai experience.There is an exhibition centre, that shows the history of post WWII Thailand through newspaper articles, and an film about Tim Johnson. It is in English with Thai subtitles. The film looked as if it had been made in the 1970s, and though not modern was quaint. It did focus a bit too much on his disappearance for my liking, and there were too many melodramatic scenes and music towards the end.It is very easy to get to, being an only 5min walk from National Stadium skytrain stop. I would not recommend a visit for wheelchair users as there are steps into all buildings except the shop and restaurant. We were there for a couple of hours, and by the time we left it was becoming more busy. I would therefore recommend an early morning visit.

A small oasis in the heart of Bangkok. I am not a big fan of Jim Thompson's clothes and accessories but a couple of people had recommended going to the house and I am glad I did. It is easy to get to, near National Stadium BTS, and is a cool and shady place to spend an hour. The house and its contents are as they were when Jim Thompson disappeared in the 1960s and the guided tour of the house, which took about 35 minutes, was very interesting. There are a couple of other small buildings to explore separately as well a shop and a cafe. Well worth a visit.

Surprising beauty in the middle of Bangkok. Jim Thompson's house was a great escape from the crowded streets of Bangkok. Tucked away in a street near the shopping centers, Jim's house was serene and peaceful (I wanted to stay and take a nap). The gardens were beautiful and the architecture and history of the house was amazing. We were so hungry we decided to eat at the restaurant, our original plan was to eat street food. We ordered the Pad Thai, it was just our 2nd day in Thailand, and it was amazing! It was wrapped in a thin egg omelet, which was a nice surprise. The food, house, and silk scarves you could purchase at the gift shop were all great.

Getting to be quite the enterprise. I have visited several times over the past 20 years since I love Thai style and Jim had it nailed down perfectly with impeccable taste. The house is still worth the visit if you like art and architecture but you will not be alone. This has become a huge attraction but it really is only a few rooms, so you will be running into other groups all the time. The gift shop, silk shop, museum and cafe have all been added over the years so there are literally hundreds of people on the grounds at any given time. The cafe is nice if you can sit beside the koi pond for the view; otherwise it is pretty pricey for what you get.

One of the must do's on in Bangkok. We've been here twice - once in 2002 & once in 2010. If we ever return - we'd see it again. Beautiful teak mansion is so stunning - if you appreciate architecture, art, eastern culture or just love a peaceful day away from the hussle of BKK - please visit!!

if you like antiques you'll love this!. Hidden away down a lane not far from the concrete jungle, this is well worth seeking out. Its easy to reach by Skytrain. The tours are compulsory and bags must be left in lockers but then its easy to stay a while and browse through again. The artifacts, porcalaine and fabrics are fabullous and its facinating to see now the original houses were fitted together. Indeed the shop is pricey but high quality, but the cafe by the pool is charming.I loved the Spirit house by the gate. Just outside the site its possible to see the Klong on which the house was built, at the end of the lane. One day I'll work out how to get there by public longtail, it must be possible.

A Glimpse of an Extraordinary Life. Loved this tour. Having read a biography of Jim Thompson prior to our trip, this tour was a must-do. This intriguing character blended several traditional teak houses into a splendid residence in the heart of Bangkok. Great collections of porcelain, antiques, sculpture displayed with exquisite taste. Very well-organized tours stagger the groups so you get to see everything without a crowd.

Interesting Western perspective of Thailand. You'll love it or hate it.. Visited on 15 Sept 2010. Overall, the tour and Jim Thompson’s story turned out to be much better than I expected because am not usually interested in silk or fashion. In one of the major Bangkok malls, I had wandered into one of the Jim Thompson stores. Based on the cover notes of a biography on display, I made the decision to take the extra step of visiting the museum. His biography is one that lends itself to a Hollywood movie. Cost of the tour is 100 Baht. You are placed in a group based on language, and wait time for my English tour was about 15 minutes. Learned a little about Thai architecture, history, superstitions, etc. For me, it was a pleasant change of pace in comparison to the high rises of Bangkok. In my opinion, this is a “love it or hate it” kind of tour. First, study a map because the location is tucked away and is not well marked. Its GPS coordinates are N 13 44.954’ E 100 31.692’ Second, the tour is not designed for the disabled. There are a few flights of stairs and door ways with relatively high thresholds to step over. Third, be prepared to remove your footwear upon entering the home—ie make sure your socks do not have holes in them and/or your ultra white socks may get a little dirty. Fourth, you are expected to lock you handbags, backpacks, etc in one of their free lockers. Fifth, taking photos is not permitted within certain locations.Would recommend to others visiting Bangkok.

Perfect Afternoon Outing. When people ask me the one 'must-do' in Bangkok, I always tell them about Jim Thompson's house.I'm not going to explain what it is - that's in all the guide books. Just trust me... go about 11am, have a coffee or smoothie and buy tickets for the tour - a paltry 100 baht for a 20 minute tour in half a dozen languages. Watch the koi carp while you wait for the tour.Don't miss the pond on the 'other' side... it looks empty, but go closer and you can see some huge fish and a monster stingray on the bottom.Then enjoy the tour and wander round the gardens for 90 minutes or so. Take some photos and then have lunch in their adjoining restaurant. I never buy souvenirs here - they seem a little overpriced and... unauthentic.But everything else is perfect.

Disappointed with Staff. We enjoyed the tour through the beautiful grounds and house ( I would love to live in it)Had a meal before hand which we enjoyed and drinks afterward the tour however we be came to leave my husband asked the girl in the ticket office to ring a taxi for us and she refused. Every other tourist site had been happy to ring a taxi, we are in our 60's and I find walking challenging, so we had to hobble down to the main road and a policeman hailed a taxi for us.IVery disappointing particularly as another taxi dropped us off at a Jim Thompson outlet by mistake and that shop offered to call a taxi to take us the Jim Thompson House.

Sorry Jim Thompson. Our five star hotel referred us here for Thai Silk. When we arrived I found silk scarves for thousands of dollars and up. As much as I enjoy Neiman Marcus from time to time in the the United States, I didn't come to Thailand for those prices. You can find a few simple items for a couple hundred dollars there and they have a nice cafe. I recommend going to see what the high-end looks like at Jim Thompson, then heading to Silom Village for a 90% discount on very high quality silk.

Mini Oasis in Bustling Bangkok. Set in landscaped gardens, are six Thai Teak houses that was once home to the legendary American businessman who rejuvenated the Thai silk industry in the 1950’s & 60’s. The houses are filled with priceless collections of Asian antiques, paintings, carvings etc: and stone sculpture found within the gardens. A lovely Oasis in the heart of bustling Bangkok, so go along and enjoy! Once you have bought your entrance ticket, you will be asked to wait about 10mts to join a guided tour (inclusive of your ticket price), around the complex of houses (afterward, you are free to walk around the landscaped gardens at your leisure). The guide we had was very informative and engaged us in what we were looking at and enjoyed hearing about Jim Thompson’s life style portrayed through items in the houses. You are asked not to photograph the inside the houses, but free to do so from the outside, and there are plenty of great shots to be taken. There are terrapins and various fish in the ponds, set amongst the jungle like flora and fauna, quite a variety to be seen.The shop on site sells a variety of silk items from handkerchiefs and clothing to wall hangings and other novelty items. There is a restaurant on site that seemed popular, but since we were in the heart of Siam and spoilt for choice of where to eat, opted not to eat here.Open daily 09.00 a.m. - 05.00 p.m. Admission 100 BahtGet the Sky Train to (W1) National Stadium Station (Silom Line). Take Exit 1, walk straight ahead and take the 1st side road onto your right (Soi Kasemsan 2 road) - Jim Thompson's house is on left side at the end of this road (5mts walk, if that)

Loved it. I can see why this place isn't everyone's cup of tea. It doesn't have the dazzling extravagance of the Grand Palace and it's not exactly high on most tourists to-do lists. But its elegance and tranquility are a real plus. I thought the compulsory tour was very well organised, professional, and informative. I only had to wait 20 minutes for the tour, during which I wandered around the gorgeous gardens. Yes there are lots of tourists walking through the house, but the tour groups are staggered so you're not in the same part of the house at the same time. I found the whole experience insightful, peaceful, inspiring and beautiful.

tranquil. We came here on our first day in Thailand as something easy to start us off, we were a bit dubious as we're not very good with tourist attractions, especially with the kids. Our hearts sank further when we found that the guided tour was compulsory, however, they were so good with the kids - each part of the tour started with something for the kids & they were presented with little origami nik naks, as well as the house & artifacts being stunning, we spent a very happy couple of hours here. The restaruants a bit pants though. (Liz says I should qualify that - its expensive & westernised & of average quality)

Too Crowded. This is a pretty house, but not worth the time and wait for me. You have to go in a tour group, no photos allowed, the tour groups kept stumbling over each other, and the narration was minimal and repetitive. If you only have a couple days in Bangkok, spend more time around the river and the wats. Over-pried gift shop. If you're a real architecture and history buff, then you would probably enjoy. If you have several days in Bangkok, then I would recommend.

Worthwhile Exhibit in Bangkok. Our first trip to Thailand and elected to begin in Bangkok, to include making some passing observations of the seedier environs that are easily stumbled upon. Given the time, the Jim Thompson House is worth a visit, especially since it is so convenient to the Sky Train. The home itself is conceptually unique and memorable, moreso for the construction and overall design, bearing in mind that this was one man's personal residence. The 35 minute tour itself is somewhat superficial and rushed, but spending the extra time alloted to enjoy and photograph the small gardens and how they were incorporated into extensions of the living areas was a pleasure. Not recommended for children, as they'll be bored, restless and distracting, but worthwhile for the mature visitor interested in a unique exhibit.

not neccessarily a must visit. I didnt particularly want to go to this House - although the thought of seeing thai silk imprinted or being fashioned into something caught my attention - unfortunately there was none of this. It was a tour of his house - which is fascinating and hearing his life story also fascinating. the grounds are lush and right on a small river. go if you have time in bangkok

worth a look. I can understand how a few reviewers were not all impressed with this. Its interesting if you find silk fascinating and want to learn about clever Jim. The mouse house is fascinating and the gardens lovely but its not really a must see. Get your shirts made by the local people, they need the money and do a brilliant job and you get a real bargain.Jim's tragic story is quite moving.There is also a bit of humour if you can pick it up. At one point our lovely guide who was rudely corrected by some horrid tourists because of her accent. Did they forget they were in Thailand? It was awful.She threw in a little joke for some of us.She said poor Jims marriage did not work.He had to live all alone in this house with his young house boys.We were trying not to laugh and the guide winked at us.None of the others got it.Poor jim? I dont think so.

Very interesting and well organised historical insight.. Preserved history. Teak houses on the old canal with original contents and collections of old artefacts gives a real sense of the past, although it s one rich mans past. Organised tour allowed reasonable flexibility and you can wander around some of the property at will. Much more interesting than seeing stuff in glass cases in a museum, and better than some other highly rated attractions. Shop has some good silk items, price reflects quality.

Does anyone care about silk?, thought so.. Don't bother going here. The garden is decent but the house is totally average. You are forced to go on a tour with a bunch of ritzy people who want to pretend to be sophisticated and interested in silk. I can't understand why anyone likes this place so much. I have never met anyone under 30 in person who considered this place a must see attraction. My girlfriend, Natasha, also found this place to be very boring and she likes everything. If you insist on being dragged around in a group, the Vimenmek Mansion is much better. Also, there is a zoo and another building in the area that is cool but the name is impossible to pronounce (it looks like the Capital in D.C.) In short, you're not sophisticated and Jim Thompson's house is crap.

Sad decline in level of 'enjoyable-ness'. Ok, so I'm gonna join the ranks of 'I remember Asian when...'. Sorry to say last time I visited Jim Thompson's House I adored it. We spent several hours there appreciating it's incredible contents and lovingly photographing in detail. I went back this year with my new digital camera. I was HORRIFIED that it's become a total tourist 'head 'em in, move 'em on' experience. It is COMPULSORY to join a tour group, which descends to toilet humour and lowest common demoninator jokes. The guide we had was a little under-informed about some of the cultural backgrounds of items and I did not want to listen to her innacurate rambling about inconsequentialitiies. I loath being hearded around like sheep. But the worst insult by far is that you are not allowed to take photos. I said ' but I won't use flash' and was proceeded to be told that flash had a negative impact on the antitques. I know that, and respect it, but as a high end camera user I had NO intention of using flash. Simply put, they want to rush you through with the quickest, dumbest 'tour; possible to move as manh people through as possible in the shortest time possible. Sad.

Educational and interesting. We walked there quite easily (about 4 mins) from the National Stadium BTS station. The guided tour lasted about 35 mins and was educational and interesting. Eg the “mouse house” which served like a TV. The teak wood house and its interior design was gorgeous. It’s a pity we could not take photos. Entrance was 100 baht per adult and 50 baht per student.

A MUST SEE in Bangkok. I've been to Bangkok twice. I've been to the Jim Thompson House each time. The first time, my friends dragged me kicking and screaming. I really wasn't that excited to see some old house owned by a guy I had barely heard of. However, after a long slog through hot Bangkok, the house was a refreshing break from the loud city. If you have any interest in Thai architecture, Buddhist imagery, Thai silk or "the way things used to be," this is worth a visit. The tour lasts about 40 minutes and you get a good feeling for what it must have been like to be an expat in Thailand in the 50's. Tours are available in many languages. The grounds are small, but very peaceful. There is also a Jim Thompson store selling whatever sorts of silk or JT branded stuff you may need. I was a bit disappointed that I couldn't buy just plain silk from there. There is also an excellent cafe which serves a killer lychee blended drink and also some very good albeit pricey Thai food. The second time, I brought my girlfriend. She really liked it.Oh, don't miss the freshwater stingray by the sign in desk.

A must see. We have been to Bangkok very many times, but I never tire of visiting this spot, an oasis of calm in the frenetic activity of Bangkok. The entry cost is not excessive and the fact that this goes to the Bangkok School for the Blind should stop anybody complaining, surely.The architecture of the house, consisting of a number of antique buildings from around the country being brought together in this spot, is remarkable and the contents beautiful. Admission is by guided tour, though you are free to wander around the gardens and ground floor.All round, a wonderful, inspiring building and I look forward to going back next time we are in Bangkok.

Don't Underestimate. We visited this place on our last day in Bangkok and found the place extremley interesting.We didn't really know who this guy was and found the guided tour very interesting and endearing. We arrived just after 9am in the morning, from getting the Sky train to Siam and walked 5 minutes to it. It is in abit of an ususal location as it is off down a side street, but you have to remember that Bangkok has been built up around it!We didn't have to wait long at all for a tour, and found the teak buildings - 6 in all - very beautiful. We found out that he was the first person to export the Thai silk to America, and found that his disappearence also intriging.This is a little hideaway not to be missed for some cultural enlightenment!

beautiful architecture. I've been here several times, once alone and then with out-of-town guests. It's like stepping back into time and visiting a home and museum in one. The mysterious disappearance of silk trader Jim Thompson also adds extra dimension to the tour. Very beautiful, lush property. An exquisite experience.

Peace in central Bangkok. I was very pleasantly surprised at this place. It is off a small side street near to National Stadium BTS skytrain station. It is very easy to find. I only waited 5 minutes for a guided tour. It is a very calm environment and has small but lovely gardens. The exhibits are intersting to keep you occupied without being overwhelming and overpowering. If you have a hour spare and want to do something that is in a cool restful shady spot go for it!

Very cool activity in Banfkok. Walked to Jimmy's place from our hotel, Siam @ Siam Design Hotel. We are a family of four, two girls 12 and 10. Loved it, the stories of his life, the house itself and the chance to chill out in the lovely atmosphere of this oasis in the middle of Bangkok. We were only there for a couple of hours, but it made our day.F.Y.I.-Very close to National Stadium sky train station.

A Must See. We walked to Jim Thompson House easily from our hotel, couldsee it from our room window (Pathumwan Princess).This is a beautiful oasis, with very good guides and ample time towander around the house grounds before and after your tour.We took friends back there on our return to BKK, a week later and they too were very impressed.100bht entrance fee and you can stayas long as you like, great value. Wonderful shop on site as well.Don't miss it.

always a 'must' for us in bangkok. We love this place. First visited on our second trip to bangkok- having 'done' the palace, wat po, wat arun etc etc the fist time around. Wow! It is peaceful and wonderful. Everytime we tour the house, we learn something new. Exhibition hall is also fun; this year they had an exhibition of burmese fabrics with some commentary about the female weavers and how it all relates to varied cultural roots. (see, that anthropology degree decades ago came in useful after all!)seriously, though, it is fabulous and a great place for lunch. you can go thai, or if you need a western hit, they do a great tuna sandwich. Made all the more exciting when I learned from my mom that JT lived in Delaware next to my grandmother in the early 20th century; amazing what a global world it really is.Can't afford the silks, although we have bought a few things there. However, the greeting cards (blank inside) are of the JT designs and are the nicest I have found anywhere in the world, and they're a bargain, less than 50 pence a card so a real bargain. We buy dozens and use them for all family birthday cards and so forth. if you want the real Jim T silk items, there is an outlet store with last years designs at huge reductions- it's a short taxi away from the last skytrain stop (same as Tesco) and a great place for products or fabric at knocked down prices.

One of my favorite spots in Bangkok!. This house/museum is a must see while in Bangkok. The house is a showcase of traditional Thai design and provides a multitude of ideas for what to buy ELSEWHERE.The major complaint you often hear about this joint is that its hard to find. Nonsense! Your map is probably wrong and the tuk-tuk driver may want to take you someplace where he can get a commission, but you're smarter then that! If you depart the North-west exit of the National Stadium sky-train station and head a few meters to the west, you cannot miss Soi Kasemsan 2 (there is a big blue sign for the road/JT House and its the only alley before you hit a major road). JT's house is at the northern end of this alley (just before the canal) on the left. You'll know you're in the right place because of the 5 tuk-tuks lined up waiting for tourists to require a ride to the next attraction. Most metered taxis and a good portion of tuk-tuks will get you there without any problems on the first try. Simple.The big attraction is the house--cobbled together from several other Thai houses to create a fusion-architectural layout. Why not just go see a Thai house? Because this house showcases the differences between Thai and Eastern design. Plus, the guides have some of the best foreign language skills in the city--so you'll be sure to understand the tour! In addition to the architectural beauty, the house also showcases a variety of antiques and design motifs that are worth a look. The pictures, decorations and furniture are amazing. Each time I visit the house, I find something new that I want to purchase--but from one of the markets, not from the over-priced store.One of the things that makes this house so nice is that it provides an oasis in the middle bustling Bangkok. It really does feel like a jungle in the gardens. Yes, Bangkok is still throbbing on the outside, but this place seems a bit calmer and cooler. After seeing everything that you'd like to purchase elsewhere, it's an easy walk over to MBK or the rest of the Siam Square stores to find the real bargains.To be honest, I have not eaten in the restaurant in years because it was not too good the first two times I tried it. I could see why people like it, but it was a little more westernized than I like and just tasted a bit bland compared to the nearby alternatives. The store is beautiful, but I never spend more than 2 minutes in there. Everything is expensive, compared to what you'll find elsewhere in the city.So in summary: be persistent and you will find the Jim Thompson House. Once you get there, you will not be disappointed--unless you are looking for good food and a bargain.

Jim Thompson's House. Hi - to all visitors in Bangkok I highly recommend taking a tour of Jim Thompson's House. It is a wonderful Teak House with gorgeous furnishings. It costs 100 baht for adults and I am sure you will come away thinking it was money well spent. There is also a great restaurant which serves both Thai and Western food and it is absolutely delicious. Don't be put off by the swanky look it is very reasonably priced, and the service is excellent. To get there just follow the signs from the National Stadium Bts Station ( Sky Train ) it is about a five minute walk from there, and don't listen to the guys on the street that say "Jim Thompson House closed today" ( They say this if you are on foot near any major attraction )

Didn't see the wonderful people say. First of all, you have to walk a relative long distance if you go by BTS, then you have to wait until they have a guide available, (we had to wait 40 minutes) to be able to see the famous house, which doesn’t have many extraordinary things that worth it, is boring, and of course you can’t take photos inside just outside that even is beautiful, the house and gardens, I think is expensive and they make lost your time.Finally they have a café and the shop that is very expensive. The silk is good quality but if you go to Chiang Mai wait until get there to buy. You've already contributed to the organization paying that ticket that cost 250 bath per person which is expensive in comparison with other much better atractions.

Wonderful. This place is an architectural masterpiece. In addition to that, the hostesses are truly classy and they have a wonderful museum restaurant and shop. The restaurant is a great way to break for lunch and you can get a table by the giant koi fish in the pond next to you. Thompson was a genius and his home is quite a beautiful oasis in this chaotic yet wonderful city! DO NOT miss this place!

Calm, peaceful, attractive. Anyway enough about me! Bangkok is bustling with tourists, polluted and can feel chaotic - Although it still a great place to visit. Unlike many sites Jimmy T's house (we're close friends) is off the main road and set in a quiet side street with easy access by the skytrain, and has a calmness and beauty about it in its architecture and setting. Probably one of the best places you can see in Bangkok, you get a guided tour and a quick history lesson and there's a place to grab something to eat or drink out of the heat and in a relaxed setting.

Must-See. This is an absolute must-see stop. I would rank it right up there after Wat Phra Kao and Wat Aroon. No other place open to the public gives you a comprable idea of the beauty, simplicity and sophistication of the Thai domestic arts. It's very inspiring and educational at the same time as being pleasurable. I go every time I visit Bangkok - before I go shopping.
